title: ResultsPlus
description: GOLF 6 Up, 7 Left, Hoch Fails Payne Stewart's 3-foot par putt on the Houston Open's first playoff hole gave him a remarkable victory over Scott Hoch, who squandered a six-shot lead with seven holes to go yesterday. Hoch collapsed on the back nine with three bogeys and the double-bogey that started with a tee shot in the water. "You can print it now: Hoch as in choke," said a distraught Hoch. That rhyme surfaced when Hoch missed a 2-foot putt that would have won the Masters in 1989. After Stewart had birdied the 18th hole to give him a four-under-par 68 and a 12-under 276 total, Hoch forced the playoff with a 35-foot birdie putt on 18 for a three-over 75. In the playoff at the par-4 18th, Stewart's drive was in great shape on the fairway, but Hoch pulled his tee shot to the left among some trees and he had no clear shot to the green. (AP) AUTO RACING Senna Teammate Wins Damon Hill spoiled the day for the Ferraris by winning the San Marino Grand Prix in Imola, Italy, yesterday, then dedicated the victory to the late Ayrton Senna. "What happened last year was a sad thing, and I think Ayrton would have liked the fact that we had a good day today," Hill said after driving his Williams-Renault to victory in the race where Senna, his teammate, was killed last May 1. Hill beat Ferrari's Jean Alesi and Gerhard Berger by 18.5 and 43.1 seconds. (AP) MARTIN'S BIGGEST VICTORY: Mark Martin won the biggest race of his career, passing Dale Earnhardt with two laps to go yesterday and holding off Jeff Gordon to win the Winston Select 500 at Talladega Superspeedway in Alabama. Earnhardt, who took the lead when Rusty Wallace had to pit for gas with just 4 laps left in the 188-lap race, tried gallantly to keep Martin's Ford Thunderbird behind his Chevrolet Monte Carlo. But Martin pulled alongside the leader on the main straight and zoomed past, bringing Gordon with him. (AP) TENNIS Recovered Muster Wins Thomas Muster beat fatigue with plenty of sleep, enabling him to rally past Boris Becker, 4-6, 5-7, 6-1, 7-6 (8-6), 6-0, in the Monte Carlo Open final in Monaco and remain unbeaten this year on clay courts. Muster saved two match points in the tie breaker. The Austrian got dehydrated during his semifinal. (AP) YACHT RACING Pettengill Is Second Steve Pettengill sailed into Charleston Harbor yesterday, finishing second in the BOC Challenge. The Middleton, R.I., sailor's finish was the best by an American in four runnings of the solo around-the-world yacht race. Pettengill, sailing Hunter's Child, completed the 27,000-mile voyage in 128 days 4 hours 3 minutes 9 seconds. Christophe Auguin of France finished Thursday. (AP)

title: Tort Cases
description: Although tort reform is all the rage, the number of tort cases -- civil lawsuits in which plaintiffs allege injury, loss or damage from negligent or intentional acts of the defendants -- in the region has remained steady in recent years. The movement to curtail the number of civil lawsuits picked up steam in March when the House of Representatives passed measures that would limit damages in product liability cases, make it more difficult for shareholders to sue corporations and raise the evidence threshold for obtaining punitive damages. The bills are now being considered by the Senate. Experts say the high number of tort cases in this area can be partly explained by high population density, heavy industrialization and traffic. Mr. Duke died on Saturday, not Sunday. The obituary, which also appeared in some editions on Sunday, also misstated the maiden name of his third wife, who died in 1961. It was Maria Luisa de Arana, not Aranal. The list of survivors omitted his fourth wife, Robin Chandler Duke.

title: Trial of the Vanities
description: There is no such thing as an O. J. Simpson T-shirt in the United Kingdom. We do not have the climate. An old man at a London bus stop said to me, why watch the O. J. trial? Everyone does the same as they did the week before, so why not turn on a better soap opera? A woman told me the trial makes her angry; others are mildly amazed. Some envy O. J.'s teeth. Many see how he could be popular purely by way of contrast. Compared to his team of lawyers, the man seems a dear.

title: GOODYEAR RAISES TIRE PRICES 3 to 8 PERCENT
description: The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company said yesterday that it would raise prices on replacement tires 3 percent to 8 percent because of the rising costs of raw materials. Goodyear, based in Akron, Ohio, said passenger and light-truck tire prices would go up 3 percent. Prices on tires for commercial, truck, farm and industrial uses would rise 3 percent to 5 percent. And off-road vehicle tires would increase 5.5 percent to 8 percent. The increases are effective June 1.

title: FORD TO MAKE LEASE-BACKED SECURITIES OFFERING
description: In a first among the Big Three auto makers, the Ford Motor Company this month is planning to issue securities that are backed by its car leases. The plan by the Ford Motor Credit Company has been two years in the making and may set a standard in the industry. The General Motors Acceptance Corporation, a unit of the General Motors Corporation, is also working on a lease-backed securities offering. An offering from the Chrysler Corporation is farther off, industry analysts said. If Ford makes lease securitization feasible in the market, it will open up a major new category of asset-backed securities, analysts said.

title: SILICON GRAPHICS ANNOUNCES INTERACTIVE-VIDEO CHIPS
description: Silicon Graphics Inc. said yesterday it had developed a set of computer chips that would make it easier for companies to incorporate interactive video in consumer products. The chips consolidate technology first developed for Time Warner's trial of interactive television in Orlando, Fla., company officials said. Separately, Silicon Graphics said that Tom Whiteside had stepped down as president of its MIPS Technologies subsidiary, which developed the chips. Mr. Whiteside, who joined MIPS in July 1993 after heading development of the Power PC chip at I.B.M., will be succeeded by Ronald Bernal, former vice president and general manager of Silicon Graphics' supercomputing systems division. AT&T Network Systems, Philips Electronics and Samsung said they intended to adopt the new Silicon Graphics chip, known as the MIPS Magic Carpet, in their communications and interactive consumer products lines. And Time Warner Cable said it supported the use of the technology for interactive applications. The chips are microprocessors that have been designed to handle three-dimensional graphics, sound and video.

title: Hummingbirds Bear Mixed Gift to Flowers in Tropical Forest
description: EVERYWHERE throughout this jungle the pouting, blood-red lips of Hamelia flowers draw in hummingbirds, which stop for a moment to sip nectar and shed a dusting of precious pollen. But like many of the rain forest's complex relationships, this trade between bird and flower is more intricate than it looks. Researchers have found that in addition to pollen, these plants receive flower-attacking mites that come cruising through the forest riding on the beaks of the dazzling birds.

title: Afro-Celtic or Not, It's Bouncy and Intense
description: Laura Love, an effervescent singer and songwriter based in Seattle, has invented her own musical idiom, which she calls "Afro-Celtic." Pretentious as that label may sound, Ms. Love, who shared the bill with the Scottish singer and songwriter Dougie MacLean at Town Hall on Friday evening, makes strikingly original music that suggests a buoyant hybrid of gospel, country and folk flavors with a pronounced Scottish-Irish modality. Its intense rhythmic bounce finds a deep kinship between African and Celtic dance beats.

title: Biologists Find Site Of Working Memory

title: 3 Works From 3 Countries at a War's End

Honegger's Third Symphony, the "Liturgique," takes the emotions of wartime to church. Strauss's "Metamorphosen" is private suffering at its most sophisticated. Marc Blitzstein's "Airborne Symphony" is pure propaganda: flag-waving, drumbeating populism eager to rally the folks back home.

title: BREAST IMPLANT MAKERS DISCUSS ADDING TO CLAIMS FUND
description: Silicone breast implant manufacturers have begun talks to increase a $4.2 billion fund to pay women reporting injuries from the devices after the judge said the current fund might be too small. The Bristol-Myers Squibb Company, Baxter International Inc., the Dow Corning Corporation and the Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company are the largest contributors to the so-called global settlement, which is intended to end hundreds of thousands of potential lawsuits against implant manufacturers. Critics had said before that the fund was too small to pay the promised benefits of $105,000 to $1.4 million to each claimant. United States District Judge Samuel Pointer said yesterday that the fund might be too small to settle all the claims. He urged manufacturers to begin negotiations to increase the size of the fund.

title: U.S. WILL RETURN REFUGEES TO CUBA IN POLICY SWITCH
description: The Clinton Administration ended 35 years of special treatment for refugees from Cuba today, announcing that it would start summarily returning Cuban boat people to their country after admitting a final group of about 20,000 now being held at Guantanamo Bay Naval Station.

title: 'E' on Replacement Umpire
description: Managers have been ejected, players have registered complaints and mistakes have been during the replacement umpires' reign. No mistake, though, was as ridiculous as the one made tonight during the Expos' 9-6 victory over the Mets.

title: In Brief
description: * Fluor Daniel Inc., a subsidiary of the Fluor Corporation, said yesterday that it would take part in a venture to build a $2.5 billion power plant in Paiton, Indonesia. Duke/Fluor International Services, an association between Fluor Daniel and the Duke Power Company, will work with Mitsui & Company Ltd. and Toyo Engineering Company to construct the 1,230-megawatt, coal-fired power plant, the company said. * The ITT Corporation said yesterday that it had completed the sale of its ITT Commercial Finance unit to Deutsche Bank North America, a unit of Deutsche Bank A. G., for $2.6 billion.

title: Pepsico Posts Strong Earnings Despite Restaurant Weakness
description: Despite a continuing struggle with sluggish same-store sales in its restaurant businesses, Pepsico Inc. posted strong first-quarter earnings yesterday, exceeding Wall Street analysts' estimates and driving the stock price up $1 to its highest level in more than a year, $43, on The New York Stock Exchange.

title: Sensormatic Electronics Corp.(SRM,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
CHRONICLE
description: At the United States Mint in Philadelphia yesterday, EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER struck the first of a series of commemorative silver dollars that bear her likeness and declared, "I'm usually modest, but this time I am overjoyed."

title: First Brands Corp.(FBR,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-After an extraordinary loss from repurchase of debt of $ 4,493,000, or 21 cents a share.Year-ago results are pro forma to exclude results of Prestone antifreeze and car care product business which was sold in August 1994. Including Prestone, sales for the 1994 third quarter were $ 244,364,000 and net income was $ 11,387,000, or 51 cents a share.Including Prestone for the eight weeks prior to its sale, sales in the 9 months were $ 745,107,000, net income before the extraordinary charge was $ 41,170,000, or $ 1.91 a share, and net income after the 21 cent a share charge was $ 36,677,000 or $ 1.70 a share.

title: Triarc Cos.(TRY,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-Included after-tax gains of $ 1.9 million, or 6 cents a share, associated with the January 1995 settlement agreement with Victor Posner and certain entities controlled by him; and $ 1.2 million, or 4 cents a share, from an insurance settlement realized by the company's textile unit.

title: Ideas Abound, but Blocking Oklahoma-Type Bombs Is Seen as Unlikely
description: Preventing the homemade manufacture of an ammonium nitrate-fuel oil bomb like the one used in Oklahoma City is virtually impossible in the United States, experts say.

title: Devils' Goal Is Defense
description: Devils Coach Jacques Lemaire graduated from the Montreal Canadien school of defense where protecting your goal was the top priority. Winning the Jennings Trophy, which is given to the National Hockey League team that allows the fewest goals, is vital to Lemaire and his players, who have digested his philosophy that defense wins.

title: Eastern Utilities Associates (EUA,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Pentium Prices Lowered
description: The Intel Corporation has lowered prices for its Pentium computer chips. The new prices, which went into effect on Monday, averaged about 27 percent lower than previous prices for new Pentium chip versions and 10 percent for older, slower chip models, according to analysts.

title: Man Guilty in Murder of Girl, 6
description: A jury deliberated for less than two hours yesterday before convicting David Cooper, 23, of raping and murdering 6-year-old Latasha Goodman under the porch of an abandoned house in Asbury Park in 1993. Mr. Cooper's lawyer had acknowledged that his client killed the girl but argued that it was an accident. An assistant prosecutor, Elaine A. Leschot, told the jury that Mr. Cooper had murdered the girl on purpose, after enticing her from her aunt's backyard with the promise of ice cream and candy and then taking her under the porch where no one could see them.

title: Wellman Inc.(WLM,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Howard E. Wooden, Art Historian, 75
description: Howard Edmund Wooden, a museum director and art historian, died on Friday at the Wesley Medical Center in Wichita, Kan. He was 75 and lived in Wichita.

title: The 2 Seized Hardly Tried To Cover Their Tracks
description: Gary Allen Land and Robert Jacks were two of the most-wanted men in the United States when they stopped here on Monday afternoon, but they made no effort to hide their identities. It was as if they were cocky, careless or just oblivious to the legions of law-enforcement officers fanning out across the region in search of them.

title: CHASE MANHATTAN TO SHUT FUTURES UNIT, CUTTING 170 JOBS
description: The Chase Manhattan Corporation said yesterday that it would close its worldwide futures business, laying off about 170 people. Chase, the sixth-largest United States bank, had tried to find a buyer for the Chase Manhattan Futures Corporation for about a month, according to those familiar with the situation. Most of the bank's futures traders will lose their jobs within a week. Those employed in clearing and execution will work for another three to six months as Chase closes its business, an official said. Chase will lay off 100 in New York and Chicago, 50 in London, 17 in France and a few in Ireland and Singapore.

title: We, the Studious People
description: Students from East Brunswick High School placed second in a national competition that tested their mastery of the United States Constitution. A California school, Amador Valley High of Pleasanton, placed first in the competition here, which involved more than 1,250 students.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: FIRST COMMERCE CORP., New Orleans, said it would acquire Peoples Bancshares Inc. for about $30.6 million in stock. MICHIGAN NATIONAL CORP., Farmington Hills, Mich., a bank holding company, said the sale of substantially all the assets and liabilities of its corporate and private banking divisions of Independence One Bank of California to Southern California Bank of Anaheim had been completed.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Don't read too much into the double-barreled appearances by Gov. CHRISTINE TODD WHITMAN for Columbia University this week. Mrs. Whitman, the Governor of New Jersey, attended the Business School's annual dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria on Monday, and yesterday she was the guest speaker at a dinner given on campus by the Friends of the School of General Studies.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: OFFICERS INDICTED IN CORRUPTION INQUIRY

title: Close Call Has Knicks Overcome With Relief
description: The Knicks know they are fortunate. They made a crucial defensive mistake that could have cost them the pivotal game of a series they are expected to win.

title: AT THE NATION'S TABLE: Pittsfield, Mass.; In the Berkshires, A Tradition on a Bun
description: The hardest part of ordering mini-franks, a Pittsfield specialty, is deciding how many. One or two of these four-bite hot dogs, which are grilled, cradled in a soft bun and loaded with mustard, chili sauce and minced onions, are never enough. Three or four are about right, although heartier eaters order five or six. The unofficial local consumption record is 32 franks at one sitting.

title: Chargers' Executives Get Extensions
description: Coach BOBBY ROSS and General Manager BOBBY BEATHARD of the San Diego Chargers yesterday received contract extensions through the 1999 season. Beathard, the Chargers' general manager since 1990, was in the final year of a three-year contract. Ross was in the last year of a four-year deal he signed in January 1992.

title: Canadian National Railways reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-Included gains of $ 43 million on the sale of CN Exploration Inc. and $ 39 million on the sale of the operating assets of Central Vermont Railway Inc.Canadian National Railways is owned by the Canadian government.Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Transit Workers Suspected Of Dealing Stock on the Job
description: Investigators say they believe that several Transit Authority employees have used authority computers to buy and sell stocks while they were at work, and transit officials say that one worker was caught using a transit computer to gather stock information.

title: 100% Blue Agave, the V.S.O.P. of Tequila
description: TEQUILA, unlike chocolate, was not an indigenous Mexican treat. The Spanish conquerors who knew how to distill spirits taught the Mexicans to turn the fermented juice of the agave plant into tequila.

title: Indictments Seen on Third-World Loans
description: An investigation of the market for developing-nation bank loans by the Manhattan District Attorney's office and the Federal Reserve Board is expected to result in indictments soon, people close to the investigation said yesterday.

title: Blood Drops Analyzed for Simpson Jury
description: Prosecutors in the double-murder trial of O. J. Simpson entered in earnest the esoteric realm of blood, enzymes and mathematical probabilities today, seeking to show that microscopic analysis of blood swatches proved incontrovertibly that Mr. Simpson was the killer.

title: For a Night, the Ads Are the Main Attraction
description: When the definitive history of the second half of the 20th century is written, silly television commercials might loom large as factors in the decline and fall of Western civilization. They are diabolically clever at selling viewers what those people probably don't need, and the viewers most likely to be persuaded are those who might not be able to afford the products in the first place. The esthetics of nations have been rearranged around the commercial breaks that determine the very shape of our most popular entertainments.

title: U.S. Fails to Enlist European Allies in Iranian Trade Embargo
description: The United States effort to get other countries to join a trade embargo of Iran faltered today when leading European nations rejected the idea, and, in Bonn's latest sally against Washington, a German official called the American initiative wrong.

title: Xilinx Inc.(XLNX,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 1
description: b-Included pretax charge of $ 2.5 million, or 6 cents a share, for write-off of minority investment in Star Semiconductor Corp.

title: Legal Fee Cut in '81 Suit Lost by New York
description: The legal fee sought by the civil rights lawyers whose 1981 suit led to the abolition of New York City's Board of Estimate was cut by more than 25 percent yesterday by a Federal judge in Brooklyn.

title: Stop War Metaphor From Further Spread
description: To the Editor:

title: TV Spots Accepted On Use of Condoms
description: Planned Parenthood of New York City said yesterday that new public service announcements promoting condom use as a means of birth control had, for the first time, been accepted in principle by some local television outlets.

title: New Leads in Multiple Sclerosis Fight
description: "MULTIPLE clerosis. Will anyone recovered from it please communicate with patient. T272 Times."

title: 2 Are Detained in Bombing Case But Are Freed After Questioning
description: Two men described by the authorities as possible material witnesses in the bombing of the Oklahoma City Federal building were arrested in Missouri early Tuesday, but early today, a little more than 18 hours later, they were released from custody by the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: Top Clinton Aide Ordered Payments Hidden, Banker Says
description: An Arkansas banker has told Whitewater prosecutors that Bruce Lindsey, President Clinton's most trusted aide and now the deputy White House counsel, directed him to illegally conceal cash payments to Mr. Clinton's 1990 campaign for governor, lawyers involved in the investigation said today.

title: 2d Suspect Identified in a Murder Attempt
description: The police yesterday identified a suspect whom they are seeking in the attempted murder of John Giordano, a reputed mob figure, who was shot three times from a passing car as he was leaving Lenox Hill Hospital on April 10.

title: Mariner Health Group (MRNR,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Facing Ouster, Top U.S. Spy Plans to Retire
description: Six days after the incoming head of the Central Intelligence Agency vowed to purge the agency's top spies, the chief of covert operations, Hugh E. Price, announced his retirement tonight.

title: Personal Health; Breast scans may indeed help women under 50.
description: IT is hard enough to get healthy people to go for checkups that might pick up hidden cancers while they are still curable. But when experts argue among themselves about who should get various tests and how often, reluctance can turn into outright refusal.

title: Sonics Coach Pushed to the Brink Again
description: The Seattle SuperSonics are about to repeat. The dubious achievement -- consecutive first-round playoff exits -- would nudge their coach to the ledge. The suspense then becomes whether George Karl jumps.

title: How the Black Panthers Came to Be, Sort Of
description: "Whip me, beat me, but don't bore me," Mario Van Peebles says he was told by Clint Eastwood when the two made "Heartbreak Ridge" together. It's a credo that Mr. Van Peebles has since taken to heart. His directorial style is pure bluster, with a restless, pumped-up energy that would be as suitable for cartoon superheroes as it is for serious political firebrands. In his overexcitable "Panther," Mr. Van Peebles somehow finds both those extremes.

title: Only Sure Thing for Rangers: 8th Place
description: The Rangers will be seeded eighth in the Eastern Conference playoffs after last night's 4-3 loss to the Florida Panthers at Madison Square Garden. The outcome left the defending Stanley Cup champions with many unanswered questions entering the post-season.

title: Bids for British Channel
description: Four groups of companies -- led by Virgin P.L.C., Pearson P.L.C., the CanWest Global Communications Corporation and B Sky B Group P.L.C. -- filed bids to operate Britain's fifth television channel. The bids ranged from $:36.3 million ($58 million) a year by the CanWest group to $:2 million a year from the B Sky B Group, which is contolled by Rupert Murdoch. The Independent Television Commission will award the license by November.

title: Isles Go Back to Drawing Board
description: As the Islanders closed out their season tonight with a 2-0 loss to the Philadelphia Flyers in a meaningless game at Nassau Coliseum, they closed the door on their first three-year plan under the current management committee as well.

title: Body Shop Reports Weak Sales in U.S.
description: Body Shop International P.L.C. disclosed yesterday that its sales in the United States had been torpid, and it predicted little profit growth this year. The company's chairman, T. Gordon Roddick, said the company, a British maker of natural beauty products, would slow the pace of United States store openings and increase spending on new products and advertising.

title: REBEL SERBS SHELL CROATIAN CAPITAL
description: Rebel Serbs attacked the Croatian capital today, firing rockets that slammed into a central square here and spread death and mayhem among people strolling in the warm spring air.

title: U.S. Backs Pequots
description: Ignoring neighbors' objections, the Government has approved the Mashantucket Pequot tribe's plan to annex 247 acres for its Ledyard, Conn., reservation.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Sunday about Judith A. Goldman, who was long active in Jewish cultural and philanthropic causes, misspelled the given name of a former First Lady of Israel with whom she founded an environmental group. The former First Lady is Aura Herzog, not Ora.

title: Elsa Voelcker; Interior Designer, 91
description: Elsa Voelcker, a retired interior designer who worked on several well-known buildings in New York City, died on Sunday at her home in Manhattan. She was 91 and also kept homes in Oakland, N.J., and on Bequia, St. Vincent.

title: Stanley Cohen, 66, Creator of Moppets
description: Stanley Cohen, a graphic artist who created Moppet greeting cards, T-shirts and other merchandise, died on Friday at New York Hospital. He was 66 and lived in Mount Kisco, N.Y.

title: I.B.M. Plans Software for Easier Systems Management
description: Promising to reduce the spiraling costs of managing computer networks, I.B.M. is expected to announce the first in a line of new software today that will integrate and automate the management of large computer systems from the most advanced mainframes to the lowliest desktop machines.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the writer Otto Friedrich on Friday misstated the time and place of his death. Mr. Friedrich died on April 25, not last Wednesday, at North Shore University Hospital in Glen Cove, L.I., not North Shore, L.I. His death occurred a week after a diagnosis of lung cancer, not two weeks afterward.

title: Lives Redirected by Libraries
description: A sculptor creating a bust of Christopher Columbus, a girl growing up in a family where money was tight, women trying to change jobs (or careers) -- they all turned to libraries for inspiration. At a ceremony here today, the New Jersey Library Association will honor these people and others who wrote stories about how libraries changed their lives.

title: Applebee's International Inc.(APPB,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 26
description: b-Included pretax, one-time costs of $ 1,770,000 related to merger with Innovative Restaurant Concepts on March 23, 1995.c-Restated to reflect mergers with Pub Ventures of New England Inc. and Innovative Restaurant Concepts Inc., on a pooling-of-interests basis.Net income results are pro forma.

title:
AT THE NATION'S TABLE: Chicago;
Elegant Treatment For a Food Court
description: A food court is a food court is a food court, unless, of course, it's Foodlife, in Chicago's elegant Water Tower Place shopping center, on North Michigan Avenue.

title: New Equity on Cuban Refugees
description: The Clinton Administration struck the right humanitarian balance yesterday when it announced that most of the remaining Cubans at Guantanamo Bay Naval Station would be allowed to enter the United States. By doing this, and by declaring that nearly all Cubans who flee to the United States in the future will be returned home, the White House has taken a significant step toward a more sensible relationship with the Castro regime. It marks the end of the double standard under which Cuban immigrants were given preferential treatment over others who tried to reach American shores.

title: Indiana Energy Inc.(IEI,N) reports earnings for 12mo to Mar 31
Sun Healthcare Group Inc.(SHG,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-Included extraordinary charge of $ 3,413,000, or 9 cents a share, related to the tender of Mediplex 113/4 percent senior subordinated notes due 2002.Sun Healthcare Group said its latest first quarter results also include $ 3,256,000 in nonrecurring pretax expenses related to the conversion of Mediplex 61/2 percent convertible subordinated debentures due 2003.

title: Shell Canada reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-Included a gain of $ 95 million on the sale of the company's polypropylene business.Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: A Guide to Gym Etiquette for Weight-Lifting Women
description: IN the old days, nearly 15 years ago, I joined Spa Lady, which had just opened in the Washington area. Its equipment was pink, and even the biggest weights on the resistance machines were not very heavy. But like most women, I went for the aerobics and the "toning," with a fervent but futile hope that by doing hundreds of repetitions without using any added weight, we could somehow, miraculously, melt those bumps and bulges away.

title: Canadian Occidental Petroleum (CXY,A) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Canada Will Not Pay to Keep Franchises
description: The Winnipeg Jets and the Quebec Nordiques of the National Hockey League, both in jeopardy of being sold and relocated to the United States, were told yesterday that they cannot count on money from the national government to help them stay in Canada. A Minnesota group is interested in the Jets and a group in Denver is looking at the Nordiques. (AP)

title: Settling the Shabazz Case
description: A settlement on the eve of trial has avoided further embarrassment for the Government in the bizarre case against Qubilah Shabazz, accused of plotting to kill the Rev. Louis Farrakhan, the leader of the Nation of Islam.

title: Value Health Inc.(VH,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Anarchists Disavow The Tactics of Terror
description: To the Editor:

title: Times Is Expanding Its On-Line Access
description: The New York Times Company said yesterday that it had reached an agreement with the UMI unit of the Bell & Howell Company to provide researchers with on-line access to recent copies of the newspaper.

title: Between Slices of Mozart, the Meat Is Modern
description: A program beginning and ending with Mozart? No need to worry; the infernally brilliant violinist Gidon Kremer has not suddenly gone soft. At the outset of a Carnegie Hall concert with members of his Kremerata Musica festival ensemble on Monday night, Mr. Kremer lulled unsuspecting listeners with Mozart's bucolic Flute Quartet in D. He then unleashed a challenging cluster of 20th-century works by Arthur Lourie, Sofia Gubaidulina and Alfred Schnittke. Those waiting for a sweet Mozartean reward at the end were instead confronted with the 50-minute Divertimento in E-flat for String Trio, the largest and strangest of Mozart's chamber works.

title: Performance Food Group Inc.(PFGC,NNM) reports earnings for 13wks to Apr 1
description: Performance Food Group said ''an acquisition completed in January 1995 did aid the gain in sales for the quarter, but net sales from our existing operations still increased 24 percent excluding that increment.'' The company also said this year's first quarter results include Milton's Institutional Foods, an Atlanta-based distributor which was acquired in January 1995. Milton's contributed about $ 19 million to net sales for the first quarter.

title: What Do the French Want?; Social Programs to Stay
description: To the Editor:

title: Palestinians Hold Quick, Secret Trials
description: First reports emerging from the Palestinian Authority's closed trials of Islamic militants indicate that tribunals are handing down summary verdicts after short court proceedings, some no longer than a few minutes.

title: Xtra Corp.(XTR,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Pomp and Special Circumstance
description: Should Victor Cavazos, an exchange student from Mexico, be allowed to march down the aisle when 216 students in his class at Monmouth Regional High School graduate on June 22? The school board is willing to let Mr. Cavazos, 17, sit on stage and be honored with his classmates. But it says it will make no exception to the rule that says the only students who can march are those who have completed all the course requirements for a diploma. His American hosts, Richard and Linda Barcalow, said they do not believe that is fair, and they have sued the school board. The matter is now before an administrative law judge.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L. Capitals Stall Penguins' Drive for Top Spot Olaf Kolzig stopped 36 shots and Peter Bondra had two goals last night as the Washington Capitals beat visiting Pittsburgh, 7-2, stalling the Penguins' bid to earn the top-seeded spot in the Eastern Conference playoffs. Pittsburgh needed a victory to move ahead of Quebec, which can clinch first place tonight with a victory or tie in its finale against visiting Hartford. The Penguins close at home against Florida. The Capitals, who finished the season 22-18-6, clinched sixth place and will probably open the playoffs against Pittsburgh.

title: Market Place; For Japanese chip makers, a boom time mixed with caution.
description: MUCH of Corporate Japan is closed this week for the so-called Golden Week holidays. But semiconductor factories will keep operating. Demand for computer memory chips continues to soar, defying predictions that the chip shortage would turn to glut this year.

title: FLEET UNIT BUYS MORTGAGE SERVICING FROM HOUSEHOLD
description: A unit of Fleet Financial Group Inc. bought $13.1 billion of mortgage servicing rights yesterday from Household International Inc. Mortgage servicing rights are the fees that banks earn for collecting homeowners' monthly mortgage payments and passing them on to the institution that owns the loans. Fleet Mortgage Group also agreed to service Household's $1.9 billion portfolio of home mortgages. Fleet's mortgage servicing portfolio is now at $105 billion, up almost 28 percent from the $82.2 billion it held at the end of 1994, according to Gerald L. Baker, chairman and chief executive of Fleet Mortgage.

title: Bailey and Polian Reunite With Panthers
description: The Carolina Panthers yesterday signed the free-agent linebacker CARLTON BAILEY, who left the Giants last month after two seasons. Bailey, 30, spent five seasons with the Buffalo Bills, playing on all four of the Bills' American Football Conference championship teams before signing with the Giants in 1993 as a free agent.

title: Public Broadcasters Propose a Trust Fund to Replace Direct U.S. Financing
description: A group of public broadcasters proposed today that their partial Government financing, an arrangement under attack by Congressional Republicans, be replaced by a trust fund that commercial broadcasters and telecommunications companies would support through the payment of fees.

title: 3 Bronx Men Are Arrested In Carjacking
description: When three Bronx men missed the last train home from Mount Kisco last September, they could have returned to a friend's house nearby.

title: Cyrk Inc.(CYRK,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: Sales are net sales.

title: Capital Re Corp.(KRE,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: Capital Re said that without net realized investment gains, net income was 74 cents a share in the latest first quarter, up from 63 cents a share in the 1994 first quarter.

title: A Police Merger, at Last
description: New York City's long struggle to merge its three police forces has finally succeeded. Mayors Edward Koch and David Dinkins both tried for merger and failed. But Rudolph Giuliani, through lawsuits and brute politics, has at last brought transit and housing cops under the control of the New York City Police Department and its Commissioner, William Bratton.

title: An Update on the Lives Of 7 Evolving Doctors
description: If you missed the first two installments of "Making of a Doctor," a continuing 10-year "Nova" chronicle that began in 1987, you can catch up in the first hour of tonight's two-hour program. The second hour carries the careers of seven recent alumni of Harvard Medical School into their internships, from 1991 to 1994. The report is steadily absorbing, at moments exciting, if not quite up to "E.R."

title: Book Notes
description: Mayle on Parenthood

title: Sheriff's Dog Bites the Sheriff
description: It started out as a simple get-acquainted news conference yesterday to introduce Nando and Larro, two drug-detecting German shepherds who are joining the Morris County Sheriff's office.

title: F.C.C. Rejects Effort to Curb Murdoch Role
description: Federal regulators have decided against forcing Rupert Murdoch to revamp his company to comply with foreign-ownership rules for its American television broadcasting licenses, giving a crucial victory to Mr. Murdoch in what has been a serious legal threat to his media empire.

title: The Road Watches You
description: Highway authorities throughout the country are building futuristic "smart-road" systems designed to unclog traffic and improve driver safety. But these smart roads could lead to an Orwellian surveillance state if we aren't careful.

title: Cigna Corp.(CI,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: Cigna reported operating income, or net income excluding realized investment results, of $ 146 million, or $ 2.02 a share, compared with $ 100 million, or $ 1.39 a share, in year-ago period.The company attributed its results to solid profits from its health, pension and life operations, and significantly lower losses from its property and casualty operations.

title: Jumron Has Taken Odd Road To Derby
description: His trainer, who spent six years as a pharmacist at Fourth and Wilshire in Santa Monica, has never raced a horse outside California.

title: Nature, Mother of All Myth-Making
description: LANDSCAPE AND MEMORY By Simon Schama Illustrated. 652 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $40.

title: Officer Not Indicted In Paterson Shooting
description: A grand jury yesterday declined to indict a housing police officer who fatally shot an unarmed teen-ager in Paterson in February. The incident touched off several days of unrest and looting in New Jersey's third-largest city. The 16-year-old, suspected of drug dealing, was shot in the back of the head during an arrest attempt. The officer, a rookie, has said his revolver went off accidentally during a struggle. But witnesses denied there was a struggle.

title: A Luxuriance of Twyla Tharp
description: Rather than pay tribute to dead choreographers and composers, import guest stars or rush patrons to a dinner where the flower arrangements are as important as the program, American Ballet Theater opted for a change of pace on the gala scene. Having taken a five-year sabbatical from the company, Twyla Tharp returned in style on Monday night.

title: Business Travel; Amsterdam's Schiphol is named the best airport in Europe and North America for two straight years.
description: FOR the second consecutive year, Amsterdam's Schiphol Airport has been named the best major airport in Europe and North America. The distinction was conferred by airline passengers surveyed by the International Air Transport Association, and it is not likely to come as a surprise to the growing number of American business travelers to the Netherlands.

title: New Jersey Supreme Court Hears Bitter Legal Argument Over 'Megan's Law'
description: For three hours today, New Jersey's Supreme Court heard arguments and peppered lawyers with scores of questions about the tough crackdown on sex offenders known as "Megan's Law."

title: Emerson Electric Co.  (EMR,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: Sales are net sales.

title: Fund Manager and Publisher Charged With Investment Fraud
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission charged a mutual fund manager and a newsletter publishing company yesterday with fraud for improperly promoting an investment strategy in a newsletter edited by the manager.

title: A Subdued Start to Spring Auctions
description: The usual suspects packed Sotheby's salesroom last night for the first important art auction of the spring. While the audience looked the same as it always does, the crowd of dealers and collectors, art experts and auction-house groupies who came to watch and to bid on contemporary art didn't act the same. Hadn't they taken their vitamins?

title: Lumber Company: Sox Unload On Yanks
description: The Red Sox served notice last night that the Yankees aren't about to run away with anything in the American League East. Though the Yankees might have more overall talent, the Red Sox pack enough lumber to make any game resemble slow-pitch softball.

title: Top Jobs Realigned At Campbell Mithun
description: Campbell Mithun Esty in Minneapolis said yesterday that it would realign the duties of two top executives. William D. Dunlap, 57, chief executive since 1982, will relinquish that role and take the new position of chairman. Howard Liszt, 48, president and chief operating officer, succeeds Mr. Dunlap as chief executive.

title: Aon Corp.(AOC,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Budgetary Matters Intrude On Call for Medicare Unity
description: Republican Congressional leaders today invited President Clinton to join them in forging a bipartisan policy to control Medicare costs and keep the program solvent. But they found themselves struggling against White House assertions that their primary motivation was to balance the budget at the expense of the elderly.

title: Wang Laboratories Inc.(WANG,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-Included a charge of $ 64.2 million for integration, consolidation, and other initiatives principally related to Wang's acquisition of certain of the businesses of Groupe Bull.c-Net income. The 9 months was after a net gain of $ 488 million, which included a $ 329.3 million extraordinary gain on debt discharge and $ 193.6 million to adjust the company's balance sheet to fair market value recorded as a result of the confirmation of the reorganization plan and the adoption of ''fresh-start'' reporting.These gains are reduced by $ 34.9 million of professional fees, restructuring initiatives, and other expenses related to the company's reorganization under Chapter 11.Share earnings information is not presented for the year-ago nine months, due to the implementation of ''fresh-start'' reporting in connection with the confirmation of the reorganization plan, which resulted in a revised capital structure of the company as of Sept. 30, 1993.(Loss)

title: A Tangled Tale of a Suit, A Lawyer and Billy Joel
description: When the singer Billy Joel, in October 1993, withdrew a $90 million fraud and conflict-of-interest lawsuit against Allen Grubman, the lawyer who had long represented him in his dealings with Sony Music, Mr. Joel and Mr. Grubman refused to discuss the settlement terms publicly -- or even say whether any settlement took place.

title: After World Cup, Still on the Verge; L.I. Team Hopes Soccer's Young Fans Will Lead to Success
description: In a ritual that has gone largely unnoticed, 20 young men have been assembling each evening on a field next to the Nassau Coliseum to bounce black-and-white leather balls off one another's heads.

title: F.B.I. Rejects An Account Of Treason
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation has searched its files and found no credible evidence to support charges that the architects of the atom bomb betrayed the United States a half century ago by spying for Moscow, and in fact has secret evidence to the contrary.

title: Bad Old Days Staging Comeback in New York

description: A grand jury in Passaic County voted today against indicting a rookie housing police officer who fatally shot an unarmed teen-ager here during a drug search in February. The death provoked several days of unrest, protest marches and anger on the streets of this working-class city.

title: 20 Criminals Face Deportation
description: In a weeklong sweep that ended yesterday, the United States Immigration and Naturalization Service picked up 20 people convicted of committing serious crimes in New Jersey. Because they were found guilty of drug-related felonies or violent crimes, the aliens will appear before an immigration judge, who will determine whether they will be deported.

A15 SERBS SHELL CROATIAN CAPITAL Rebel Serbs fired rockets on Croatia's capital, Zagreb, one day after the Croatian Government launched an offensive against Serbian-held territory. title: CSX TAKING 2D-QUARTER PRETAX CHARGE TO ELIMINATE JOBS
description: The CSX Corporation of Richmond, Va., said yesterday that it would take a second-quarter pretax charge of $200 million to $250 million to eliminate an undetermined number of jobs and overhaul its telecommunications network. The company has not yet determined how many positions would be cut, said Suzanne S. Walston, a spokeswoman for the railroad and transportation company. Part of the charge stems from CSX's 10-year agreement, announced yesterday, for the AT&T Corporation to design and manage a new telecommunications system for the company. As a result, CSX will write down the value of certain telecommunications assets. Shares of CSX fell 12.5 cents yesterday, to $79.125, in Nasdaq trading.

title: In France, Decorum Dominates TV Debate
description: Jacques Chirac, the conservative candidate in France's Presidential elections on Sunday, and his Socialist opponent, Lionel Jospin, met tonight in their first debate of the campaign, each maintaining that only he could bring real change to the country's unemployment-ridden economy.

title: Class Notes

Faced with rising costs of raw material and a slowdown in United States auto sales, Ford requested the cut while promising to take steps that will mean savings for the steel companies, Ford officials said. Ford, which spends about $2 billion a year for steel, signed three-year agreements with steelmakers last year that raised prices an average of 8 percent in the first year and a total of 5 percent in the remaining two years.

Kemper Financial Services, which has about $62 billion in assets, is the 11th-largest United States mutual fund company, although it has been losing assets while the mutual fund industry surged.

title: Prisoner Interests I.O.C.

description: Once again, Police Commissioner William J. Bratton has had to sit under hot television lights, stare out at a forest of minicams on hastily planted tripods and apologize for a situation that is clearly anathema to him: officers under his command charged with criminal behavior.

title: A Drive to Make the Streets Safer
description: In a vacant lot in one of the most blighted areas of this impoverished city of 87,000, a group of ministers gathered yesterday to announce plans to make the streets safer. The goal, they said, is to halt the violence that has led to 25 killings here this year. Last year, 48 people were slain. The plan includes community development, street ministry, voter registration drives and tutoring for students.

ABB, which is 50-50 owned by BBC Brown Boveri of Switzerland and Asea A.B. of Sweden, also said in a statement that orders rose 8 percent in the first quarter to $8.9 billion, increasing its order backlog to $34.4 billion.

description: For more than a decade, the Government has been tinkering with the nation's pension system, largely in the name of two good causes: cutting the deficit and making retirement benefits more equitable.

description: In this season of historic anniversaries, Kent State deserves notice. It remains a testament to the malignant power of inflammatory rhetoric from officials who, in the service of narrow ambition, create the conditions for tragedy.

title: Georgia-Pacific Riding Out Building Slump on Demand for Paper
description: A surge in pulp and paper prices is expected to help the Georgia-Pacific Corporation ride out a slump in the construction market, the company's chairman and chief executive said on Tuesday.

description: The head of the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the Deputy Attorney General told Congress today that the Justice Department was preparing to loosen the standards for investigating suspicious organizations, despite the insistence of senior Administration officials since the Oklahoma City bombing that there were no plans to do so.

description: The Government index designed to forecast the economy fell in March for the second consecutive month, pointing to subdued growth for the balance of 1995.

title: The Last Open Space May Come With Tees
description: LIKE the pioneers, they talk about land, wide-open, green and rolling. But their quest in the exurban wilderness is not for a farm in God's country; it's for a $400,000 house with a view of the 18th hole.

title:
CURRENTS;
Khaki Days Are Here Again
description: IS it a coincidence that as the 50th anniversary of the end of World War II approaches, khaki is showing up in homes around the country, not only as vintage pieces but in new textiles, bath towels and beach chairs as well? Barbara Tischler, a historian at Columbia University, doesn't think so. "There are celebrations all over now," she said, "and we are honoring the servicemen and women we are proud of."

title: Woman Tells Of Carjacking And 6 Hours In the Trunk
description: Jean Morgan, five months pregnant with her third child, went to the Smith Haven Mall last Friday to buy a maternity dress. She ended up the victim of a carjacking in which she was locked in the trunk of her car for more than six hours.

title: Burnett Organizes Media Council
description: The Leo Burnett Company in Chicago said yesterday that it would reorganize its worldwide media functions and form a Worldwide Media Leadership Council to coordinate the media operations of 766 employees at 63 offices in 53 countries.

title: Bailey Elected to Racing Hall
description: Jerry Bailey, the jockey who has won the Kentucky Derby, the Breeders' Cup Classic and as many as seven races in one day, and Bobby Frankel, the trainer whose horses have won $63 million, were elected to the Racing Hall of Fame today along with three great race horses of the past.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: HOCKEY Canada Tops U.S. Canada scored two goals in a 50-second span of the first period and went on to beat the United States, 4-1, yesterday in the quarterfinals of the world championships in Stockholm. Canada, which finished last in its preliminary group while the United States won its group with an unbeaten record, will play the defending Olympic champion, Sweden, in the semifinals tomorrow. The Czech Republic, which defeated Russia, 2-0, in the other quarterfinal yesterday, will meet Finland in the other semifinal. Canada won the world title last year with a much stronger team that featured several National Hockey League players, but is made up mostly of minor leaguers this time. (AP)

title: Ground Broken for Police Center
description: The dirt was dished yesterday on Route 54 here in Atlantic County. The event was the groundbreaking for construction of a $12 million headquarters for Troop A of the state police in southern New Jersey. Wielding the spade were Attorney General Deborah T. Poritz and the State Police Superintendent, Col. Carl A. Williams.

title: International Briefs; Tate & Lyle Earnings Up
description: The British sugar company Tate & Lyle reported yesterday that it had a 17 percent rise in half-year earnings and was optimistic about prospects for the rest of the year. The company, whose businesses span Europe, North America and Australia, registered pretax profit for the 26 weeks that ended on March 25 of $:152.8 million ($247 million), up from $:130.9 million. Sales rose to $:2.09 billion ($3.4 billion) from $:1.99 billion. (Reuters)

title: True Blue Replace the Keystone Kops
description: It may be a family. A large, rather dysfunctional family, as pointed out many, many times in the last eight months. But it's baseball's own family. And with the return of the last prodigal sons -- the once locked-out umpires -- the battling Bickersons of professional sports were reunited yesterday.

title: North Carolina Center To Turn Professional
description: RASHEED WALLACE, the star center for North Carolina, reportedly will announce today that he is giving up his last two years of eligibility to enter the National Basketball Association. Several North Carolina newspapers reported yesterday that the 6-foot-10-inch sophomore will disclose his plans at a news conference at Simon Gratz High School in Philadelphia, where Wallace played. Wallace finished as North Carolina's second-leading scorer, averaging 16.6 points per game. One of Wallace's classmates at North Carolina, forward JERRY STACKHOUSE, has yet to say whether he is staying with the Tar Heels or opting for the draft. The deadline is May 15. (AP)

title: Three Women's Views Of On-Screen Eroticism
description: "Erotique" is based on the principle of equal-opportunity eroticism. Three women from different countries have directed unrelated erotic films, which might have explored the differences between women's and men's sexual fantasies. Instead, two of the three -- by the American director Lizzie Borden and the German film maker Monika Treut -- prove that women can be as trite as men. The producers of "Erotique" were smart to save the Hong Kong-based film maker Clara Law's segment for last: it's the only one worth watching.

title: Congressional Memo; G.O.P. Feels the Heat. The Furnace: Medicare.
description: Very little has rattled Republican leaders since they took control of Congress four months ago, but their anxiety in recent days has been almost palpable. The reason is Medicare, and the growing furor over Republican plans to rein in spending on that 30-year-old health insurance program for the elderly.

description: The rebel Serbs who long held this town have fled before the Croatian Army, leaving their washing still soaking in buckets, their food still sitting on stoves, and their now ownerless pigs and chickens meandering aimlessly among deserted houses.

description: Gen. William C. Westmoreland will be the guest of honor at a parade and ceremony in Nassau County on May 13 to commemorate the 20th anniversary of the fall of Saigon, county officials announced today.

title: Yale University Paying Employees to Call New Haven Home
description: When Ian Baucom was named an assistant professor of English at Yale University last year, he and his wife, Wendy, set about looking to buy a home. While eager to remain in New Haven -- they had rented various apartments there as Mr. Baucom pursued a doctorate over the last six years -- the two were leery of the city's high property taxes and mulling a move to a nearby suburb.

description: Less than 24 hours after accusing the California Angels of racism, designated hitter CHILI DAVIS reached agreement with the club yesterday on the three-year deal he sought, and apologized.

title: Reminders Are Everywhere for Rangers
description: A year ago, the picture of the Stanley Cup was a daily reminder, framed above the exit to the dressing room at the Rangers practice rink, their thinly veiled only way out. That is just one of the changes 12 months have brought. Across the room from where that reminder once rested is now a picture of the moment of victory, when Mark Messier leaped toward the roof of Madison Square Garden, Mike Richter raised his goaltender's stick and the Vancouver Canucks hung their heads.

title: Sweden's Poet of Film and Stagecraft
description: IF ever a film seemed destined to age badly, it was "The Seventh Seal," Ingmar Bergman's medieval fantasy about a Knight playing chess with Death. The 1957 film was a major part of Mr. Bergman's international breakthrough, and the white-faced, black-robed Death figure was parodied almost as soon as it appeared. The image has passed from the still hilarious 1968 short "De Duva" ("The Dove"), in which Death plays a mean game of badminton, to a cameo appearance by Death two years ago in "The Last Action Hero." By the time an image appears in a Schwarzenegger movie, it has probably been co-opted beyond recovery.

title: International Briefs; A 56% Jump in Profit Is Posted by Electrolux
description: Sweden's Electrolux A.B., the world's largest household-appliance maker, said that its first-quarter pretax profit soared 56 percent, to $144.8 million, buoyed by strong sales in Europe. The maker of Electrolux, Zanussi and other appliances said, however, that North American white goods sales declined slightly.

title: Kevin Kline Romps As a French Jewel Thief
description: Given all the talent and scenery to be found in "French Kiss," Lawrence Kasdan's new film starring Paris, Provence, the Riviera, Meg Ryan and Kevin Kline, the lack of fizz is just plain inexplicable. Yet this is a romantic comedy with barely a laugh or a spark, and with a pace that makes it feel longer than Mr. Kasdan's previous work, "Wyatt Earp."

title: New Rules Are Approved For Nationwide Caller ID
description: The Federal Communications Commission adopted final rules today for nationwide "caller ID" services, which will enable telephone customers to get the telephone numbers of incoming calls from anywhere in the country.

title: Ex-Officer Pleads Guilty
description: A former police officer arrested last year on corruption charges in the 30th Precinct pleaded guilty yesterday to a count of extortion in return for a reduced prison sentence. The officer, Alfonse Compres, 34, admitted that he had accepted bribes from two gangs of drug dealers on 139th Street near Broadway in return for leaving them alone.

title: No Headline
description: "I came by choice from Morocco, equipped with a fair idea of Western societies. But until now I can't understand what they mean by integration. I want to be a Muslim living in Holland. But that does not mean I want to melt completely in this society and disappear, which is what the Dutch want." MOSTAPHA DALOUJ [ A5:3. ]

title: These Yankee Fans Have Come to Play
description: This has been Fan Appreciation Week at Yankee Stadium, but all they gave us was a cheesy copy of Babe Ruth's bill of sale, to bust the visiting Red Sox, and a magnetized Yankee schedule for the refrigerator door. There were free bleacher seats for the young and the restless, and a promise that we could use the stub of a paid-for ticket to get two tickets for the price of one. We'll see if that works.

title: CHRONICLE
description: It says a lot about her popularity that an executive who is moving on was worried about including people from the night shift at her farewell party.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CATERPILLAR INC., Peoria, Ill., said its unit Australia Ltd. had won an order valued at $35 million to provide 24 mining trucks to BHP Iron Ore of Australia. The trucks will be made at the Caterpillar plant in Decatur, Ill. CITIZENS FEDERAL BANK, Miami, agreed to sell its four branches in Virginia to First Virginia Bank-Colonial and will report a pretax gain of $12 million on the sale.

title: Abroad at Home; Words Matter
description: When the courts held that American Nazis had a constitutional right to march through the streets of Skokie, Illinois, freedom of speech was the more secure for all of us. But it did not follow that we should be indifferent to the hateful message of the Nazis. To the contrary.

title: DELL COMPUTER REDUCES PRICES ON ITS DIMENSION PC LINE
description: The Dell Computer Corporation said yesterday that it had cut the prices on its Dimension personal computers by as much as $150. Dell, based in Austin, Tex., said the cuts varied among the systems, but the average reduction was $125 to $150. For example, the new price for a Dell Dimension XPS system, set up as an office work station, is $2,999, compared with $3,149, the company said.

title: Jackson State Wants N.C.A.A. Invitation
description: Jackson State's golf coach, EDDIE PAYTON, believes his team has been denied the right to become the first from a historically black college to play in the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament. And he's fighting to change that. "Our kids have earned the right to compete for the national championship," he said. The Tigers, the Southwestern Athletic Conference champions, are not one of the eight teams in line for a bid to the N.C.A.A. Central Regional. The selections are not final until Monday.

title: 3 Large Hospitals Plan to Merge
description: Three hospitals with combined revenues of $635 million, 9,000 employees and 1,600 beds would consolidate, under plans announced here yesterday, to create the largest multihospital system in the state. All three hospitals -- Morristown Memorial, Overlook in Summit and Mountainside in Montclair -- would stay open under the plan, which must be approved by the Federal Trade Commission and the State Department of Health.

title: New Hope for Return of Daily Jewish Newspaper
description: The Forward, the English weekly that is an offshoot of the old Yiddish Daily Forward, reported yesterday that it had a new investor who might help it become a daily Jewish newspaper in New York City once again.

title: Europe's Muslim Population: Frustrated, Poor and Divided
description: In the streets rising from Marseilles's old port, couscous is easier to find than croissants. Cockney neighborhoods in London are now bazaars for Muslims from Bangladesh. Muezzins call Turks to prayer from new minarets in Cologne.

title: A $7.1 Billion Hoechst Deal For Dow Unit
description: After months of on-again, off-again negotiations, Hoechst A.G., the German chemical and pharmaceuticals giant, agreed yesterday to buy Marion Merrell Dow Inc. for $25.75 a share, or $7.1 billion. The deal would create the world's second-largest drug maker, behind the recently merged Glaxo Wellcome of Britain and just ahead of Merck & Company.

title: Reebok Settles Price-Fixing Case and Will Pay $9.5 Million
description: Reebok International Ltd. agreed yesterday to settle charges that it fixed the retail price of its shoes, and to pay $9.5 million in Federal and state antitrust claims.

title: Moody's Lowers Salomon Rating
description: Salomon Inc.'s rating on $26 billion in senior debt was lowered yesterday to Baa1 from A3 by Moody's Investors Service.

title: Ford Cuts Its Output Plans
description: The Ford Motor Company trimmed its second-quarter North American vehicle-production plans today by 2.3 percent, including cutting about 40,000 cars from its United States schedules. Ford's actions follow similar second-quarter cuts by two rivals, the General Motors Corporation and the Chrysler Corporation. Ford said late today that its United States, Canadian and Mexican vehicle output was now seen at 1.17 million for the current quarter, down from 1.2 million estimated a month ago and 1.19 million units produced in the second quarter of 1994.

title: This Year, It's Lakers' Turn To Quiet SuperSonics Early
description: The Seattle SuperSonics rest, but not in peace. Their coach seems on borrowed time, their players are still shaking their heads at Nick Van Exel and vacation is once again here too soon.

title: Clinton Backs Aide Who Is Inquiry Target
description: Anticipating that President Clinton's most trusted aide, Bruce Lindsey, may soon be indicted on Federal banking violations, White House advisers said today that he would not be asked to resign and that he would vigorously contest any charges.

title: Ballet, Ballet Everywhere
description: The annual ballet marathon at Lincoln Center was obviously in full swing by Wednesday. In the evening, the New York City Ballet came up with a blockbuster array of three senior ballerinas -- Merrill Ashley, Kyra Nichols and Darci Kistler -- as well as debuts and a revival. In the afternoon, American Ballet Theater's "Giselle" had Kathleen Moore making an unscheduled debut as Myrta while Susan Jaffe, with Jeremy Collins, returned to the title role after many years.

title: Dancing Cheek to Cheek, and That's Only the Beginning
description: ON a bitter cold and rainy night last winter, when the sidewalks were so wet that a four-step sprint from a cab to a doorway could bring a pair of dancing pumps to the point of ruin, I decided to attend the winter ball given annually by an organization called Colonial Dances Ltd. ("founded in 1952 as a series of events that would emphasize good music, good dancing and social friendship"). I had learned about Colonial Dances, which also sponsors a spring ball each year, from other amateur ballroom enthusiasts. They had learned about it through the major communications medium of the ballroom scene in New York -- word of mouth -- and they were attracted by the elegant setting and the black-tie formality of the dress code.

title: Jury Trouble at the Simpson Trial
description: The murder trial of O. J. Simpson, which has been in disarray for weeks, is in serious danger of disintegrating altogether for lack of a jury. Seven jurors have been excused or dismissed during the trial. Only five alternate jurors remain, and the trial, now in its fourth month, is far less than half over. At the rate jurors are falling, Judge Lance Ito may be forced to declare a mistrial.

title: At the Bar; In the constitutional amendment on the right to bear arms, one clause defines a cause.
description: These 12 words were engraved in red stone near the entrance to the National Rifle Association headquarters, which used to be near the White House: "The right of the people to bear arms shall not be infringed."

Both men have their roots in Vienna. Mr. Morton came to the United States as a youth during World War II; Mr. Faudon arrived in 1979. "Cross Town Sabbath," as Mr. Faudon prefers to spell it, has been shown on German, Austrian and Swiss television. Tomorrow night the hourlong film is being broadcast on WNET, and it is to be shown later on other major public-television stations.

description: Saying Westchester County could lose up to $20 million in state aid this year, County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke announced today that 24 county employees would be laid off next month.

The Boss was instrumental in getting the real Tammany Hall moved to its swell new digs on 14th Street and Irving Place; this Tammany Hall is all the way up on Third Avenue and 28th Street.

Three anti-administration candidates in the May 9 Township Council election say that is wrong. They said yesterday that they were appealing a Superior Court ruling upholding the North Bergen Housing Authority's ban on politicking on authority property.

title: El Salvador: A U.N. Success Story
description: With the departure of its peacekeeping mission from El Salvador last Friday, the United Nations can celebrate a quiet victory. Three years after the initial peace agreement was signed between the Salvadoran Government and guerrilla insurgents, a divided society has begun to heal. Lawlessness, human rights abuses and bitter mistrust have given way to the beginnings of a civil society.

title: Shhh. The Paintings Are Conversing
description: Nearly 40 years ago, Louise Reinhardt Smith began collecting art to distract herself from the death of her husband, Bertram Smith, a successful investment banker. She acquired paintings, sculptures and works on paper with two things in mind: her own pleasure and the needs of the Museum of Modern Art, where she has been a trustee since 1966. She has now officially promised the Modern 33 masterworks, ranging from monotypes and drawings from the 1880's and 90's by Degas, Seurat and Redon to a dozen Picassos. As is usual with such transactions, the Modern has reciprocated with an exhibition in its, and her, honor. It includes two works Mrs. Smith gave the museum in 1957: Picasso's startlingly blunt "Pregnant Woman" of 1950 and his famous "Absinthe Cup" of 1914. The latter, a brightly dappled object, was Picasso's first foray into Cubist sculpture, and is, with Meret Oppenheim's "Fur-Lined Teacup," one of the smaller stars of the collection.
