High Court Did Well In School-Guns Case
description: To the Editor:

title: Bail Granted Rape Suspect Who Fled U.S.
description: Eight years after fleeing the country to avoid trial in the rape of two teen-age girls, Alex Kelly stood today before a judge who said he would be free to go home to his parents in Darien once they posted a $1 million bond.

title: Ryland Group Inc.(RYL,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-After a gain of $ 2,076,000, or 13 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting.

title: Will Devils Bring Deja Vu to Life?
description: The memory of eliminating the Boston Bruins in four straight games after losing the first two at home in the Stanley Cup playoffs last spring still lingers for the Devils. The two teams will meet again in a four-of-seven-game series, beginning Sunday afternoon at Boston Garden. But the Devils are aware that Boston is now a better team.

title: Accounts
description: * Brown-Forman Beverages Worldwide, Louisville, Ky., a unit of the Brown-Forman Corp., to Altschiller & Co., New York, part of the Omnicom Group, to handle national advertising for its Tropical Freezes line of wine-based daiquiris, margaritas and punches, previously handled by the agency in test markets for the last year. Altschiller also handles Brown-Forman brands like Southern Comfort and Canadian Mist. The billings were estimated at $15 million.

title: Ewing Receives A Respite Of Sorts
description: The ice packs were strategically placed. The knees were entombed. The calf muscles, which recently flared up as sore spots, were obscured by ice-filled bulging bandages. If Patrick Ewing was in agony, it didn't show. And he wasn't saying.

title: Home Video
description: Multimedia Hesitation

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Pierce Quits Match Illness forced top-seeded Mary Pierce to retire from her match at the Citizen Cup tournament yesterday in Hamburg, Germany. Pierce, the Australian Open champion, easily beat Petra Bergerow of Germany, 6-3, in the first set, and Bergerow won the second by 7-5. Bergerow was ahead by 3-0 in the third set when Pierce retired. (AP)

title: Macy Outlets Will Be Closed
description: Federated Department Stores Inc. said today that it would shut its 14 Macy's Close-Out stores, trim 600 jobs and take a second-quarter charge of as much as $25 million.

title: Nothing Is What It Seems And No One Is Either
description: The central character in "Mercede," a surrealist comedy satirizing the political and social strains tearing at Egyptian society, is a misfit named Noubi (Zaki Abdel Wahab). The product of a secret liaison between his wealthy mother, Warda (Yousra), and an African diplomat, Noubi is raised as a Christian and grows up not knowing his true paternity.

title: Police Corruption -- Again
description: The sight of police officers being led off in handcuffs is becoming distressingly common in New York City. Earlier this week, 16 police officers from the 48th Precinct in the Bronx were indicted on charges of robbery, burglary, larceny, filing false police reports and insurance fraud. Seven others narrowly escaped indictment but were suspended from the force for various offenses, including failure to report criminal acts by fellow officers. Three adjoining precincts -- the 46th, the 44th and the 52d -- are also under scrutiny for police corruption, law enforcement officials say.

title: Discovery Zone Inc.(ZONE,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 2
description: b-Net loss and after a charge of $ 5,774,000, or 12 cents a share, for cumulative effect of change in method of accounting for preopening costs.Discovery Zone said the increase in its revenues in the latest first quarter was primarily due to an increase in the number of company-owned FunCenters in operation during the period. At the end of the latest first quarter, the company had 336 FunCenters in operation, up from 197 at the end of the 1994 first quarter.(Loss)

title: City Life's About the Same Under Giuliani, Poll Finds
description: Most New Yorkers say the quality of life in the city has neither improved nor worsened since Rudolph W. Giuliani became Mayor in 1994, according to the latest New York Times poll.

title: Pratt & Lambert United Inc.(PLU,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: The latest first quarter included results of United Coatings, which merged with the company on Aug. 4, 1994.In the year-ago period, the company reported pro forma net income of $ 1,738,000, or 16 cents a share, on pro forma sales of $ 98,789,000. Pro forma figures indicate the comparative combined performance of Pratt & Lambert and United Coatings.

title: Redemption Is a Slam In 10th for Hundley
description: Todd Hundley was taking the Mets' poor start to the season hard, very hard. That much was obvious. On Wednesday night, he had one of the Mets' four hits off Pedro Martinez, the Expos' starter, yet he sat in the locker room afterward, mute, his face stony and his shoulders slumped.

title: Knicks on Target For Advancement
description: Relying on long-range field-goal shooting, the Knicks defeated the host Cleveland Cavaliers, 93-80, last night and advanced to the second round of the National Basketball Association playoffs. After eliminating the Cavaliers by three games to one, the Knicks now face the Indiana Pacers in a rematch of last year's Eastern Conference finals, which the Knicks won in seven games. The Eastern Conference semifinals, which will be a four-of-seven-game series, will begin Sunday at Madison Square Garden.

title: Dole Defends Threat to Bar A Vote on Surgeon General
description: The Senate Republican majority leader, Bob Dole of Kansas, today defended his threat to block floor debate on the nomination of Dr. Henry W. Foster Jr. to be Surgeon General, saying that there was "plenty of precedent" to support such a decision.

title: Ex-Aide Says Sheik Wanted Mubarak Dead
description: A former close aide to the Muslim cleric charged in New York City bombing plots testified yesterday that the sheik told him to assassinate the President of Egypt, Hosni Mubarak, while Mr. Mubarak was visiting the United States two years ago.

title: John Edwin O'Toole, 66, Leader In Advertising for Three Decades
description: John Edwin O'Toole, a lifelong advertising executive who was one of the most articulate spokesmen for the agency industry, died on Wednesday at New York Hospital in Manhattan. He was 66 and lived in Greenwich, Conn., and Carefree, Ariz.

title: Chile Fears a Delay in Trade-Bloc Entry
description: With negotiations over Chile's admission to the North American free-trade bloc scheduled to begin next month, trade officials and business leaders here are worried that the United States, engulfed in domestic concerns, could delay its promise to bring Chile into the pact.

title: Hello Mother Russia: Smirnoff Returns to Its Roots
description: Smirnoff, the popular American-made vodka, is going back to its Russian roots to challenge such high-end imported vodkas as Stolichnaya and Absolut.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday with the continuation of an article about the resignation of Kenneth Gribetz, the Rockland County District Attorney, misidentified the man accompanying him into court. The man was Mr. Gribetz's uncle, Lester Gribetz, not his lawyer, Andrew J. Maloney.

title: Adele Marcus Is Dead at 89; Taught Many Notable Pianists
description: Adele Marcus, teacher to two generations of outstanding pianists, died on Wednesday at her home in Manhattan. She was 89.

title: Yankees Show Off New Weapon: the Home Run
description: Pitching and timely hitting have helped the Yankees to a solid start in this season of high expectations. Last night, they showcased another element of their attack: the long ball.

title: Unemployment Rates Up in New York State and New Jersey
description: Economic growth in New York State continued to stagnate last month as the unemployment rate rose again, Labor Department officials said yesterday.

title: Crying Out to the Heavens With 414 Voices
description: Mahler's "Symphony of a Thousand" was really a "Symphony of 690" at Carnegie Hall on Thursday night, but no one felt the budget crunch. With 414 singers from the Atlanta Symphony Orchestra Chorus, the Cleveland Orchestra Chorus, the Cincinnati May Festival Chorus and the Oberlin College Choir filling the first two tiers; with a soprano singing "Come, raise yourself" from the heavenly heights of the Carnegie balcony; with the stage packed with an expanded Cleveland Orchestra, the American Boychoir, a chorus, an organ, a piano and seven soloists; and with Robert Shaw virtuosically leading the entire assemblage, there was plenty of opportunity to hear Mahler's Eighth Symphony with all its bombast, vulgarity, kitsch, madness and brilliance intact.

title: Rally in Bonds Helps the Dollar Gain Against the Yen and Mark
description: The dollar ended slightly higher yesterday, helped by a rally in Treasury bonds.

title: No Headline
description: The things I thought were important prior to the 19th of April don't seem so important anymore. People. Touching people in a positive manner does. The thank you's that didn't come so easily before. They just come out, now. More compassion to my fellow man is what this has taught us. -- MAJ. DWAYNE DOOLITTLE of the Oklahoma City Fire Department. [ 8:5. ]

title: Old National Bancorp (OLDB,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: All per-share data have been adjusted for stock dividends and splits including a 5 percent stock dividend paid Feb. 10.

title: Westcoast Energy (WE,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: Preferred-share dividends were $ 5 million in the latest first quarter and $ 3 million in year-ago period.Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Lynch Corp.(LGL,A) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary gain from the sale of subsidiary stock of $ 150,000, or 11 cents a share.Year-ago results are restated to reflect a change in accounting for long-term contracts at Lynch Machinery Inc. to percentage-of-completion method from completed-contract method.

title: Hooper Holmes Inc.(HH,A) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Newsletter on Visions Reappears
description: A local couple's newsletter about visions of the Virgin Mary in a Marlboro Township backyard shrine has reappeared. It is the first edition since the lifting of a court order that sought to restrain publication because of the traffic problems and commotion caused by visitors. In the newsletter, Come to This Place: A Message from Marlboro, Vincent and Karen Bove assert that though the miraculous appearances on Joe Januszkiewicz's yard on the first Sunday of each month temporarily ceased while the matter was in court, the visions will resume.

title: For Croats and Serbs, an Uneasy Reunion
description: An ethnic barrier fell in the Balkans today. After four years, the wall between Croats and Serbs came down in this ravaged town, allowing the first, tentative meeting of two estranged and suspicious communities.

title: Antonio Salemme, 102, Painter And Sculptor of Robeson Nude
description: Antonio Salemme, a sculptor and painter who won renown in the 1930's with his life-size nude sculpture of the singer and actor Paul Robeson, died on Tuesday at his home in Williams Township, Pa. He was 102.

title: B Sky B Signs Pacts With Cable Operators
description: British Sky Broadcasting Group P.L.C., a satellite television company, has signed 10-year contracts with Britain's two largest cable television operators, giving them cheaper access to B Sky B programs and locking them into noncompete clauses on sports programming.

title: Family Posts $1 Million Bond And Ex-Fugitive Goes Home
description: The parents of Alex Kelly put liens on their house and two other properties in Darien today as security for a $1 million bond and then drove their son home for the first time since he fled the United States in 1987 to avoid trial in the rape of two teen-age girls.

title: An American's Bizarre Sit-In In Moscow
description: When Paul E. Tatum, an American businessman, found that his offices at the luxury hotel he had helped build were locked and sealed off by his erstwhile Russian partners, he donned a bulletproof vest and used an electric drill to force his way in.

title: Blame Likely to Fall on Sonics' Coach
description: Their Thursday morning itinerary said, "SHOOTAROUND: 10:30 A.M. bus," but only 11 of their 12 heads were on time. At 10:42, Shawn Kemp finally stepped his size 17's on board, without apology and without reprimand, and this, in a nutshell, explains the plight of the Seattle SuperSonics.

title: Canadian Tire reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 1
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $ 3,668,000, or 5 cents a share.Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: PanCanadian Petroleum reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.The company is listed on the Toronto, Montreal and Vancouver stock exchanges with the ticker symbol PCP.

title: International Briefs; In Brief
description: * Telecom Italia S.p.A., the state-controlled monopoly, will spin off its cellular phone business in July into a separate company with estimated 1995 sales of three trillion lire ($1.8 billion). The new company, Telecom Italia Mobile S.p.A., will manage cellular phone service as well as paging and public radio mobile communications. It inherits Telecom Italia's 2.2 million cellular phone subscribers.

title: U.S.C. Hires Bibby As Assistant Coach
description: HENRY BIBBY, a former Knick and a starting guard on three National Collegiate Athletic Association championship teams at U.C.L.A., has been hired as an assistant coach at Southern Cal, the Bruins' crosstown Los Angeles rival.

title: PURCHASE OF A GE CAPITAL COMPUTER UNIT IS SET
description: The International Business Machines Corporation agreed yesterday to buy GE Capital's computer maintenance unit. The purchase price was not disclosed, although individuals familiar with the properties estimated that they would sell for $50 million to $100 million. I.B.M. said the purchase would help expand its computer maintenance business. GE Capital Systems Support Services, which is based in Atlanta, employs 1,300. I.B.M. has not determined how many it will keep. GE Capital, the financial services unit of the General Electric Compnay, said the unit up for sale was one of eight technology-management businesses owned by GE Capital. Together, the eight units had $1.2 billion revenue in 1994, a G.E. spokesman said.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: HOCKEY Sweden and Finland to Meet in Title Game It will be an all-Scandinavian final tonight at the world hockey championships in Stockholm. Daniel Alfredsson's overtime goal gave Sweden a 3-2 victory over Canada, and Finland beat the Czech Republic by 3-0 in the semifinals yesterday. Alfredsson, 22, scored two goals for the Swedes. He had only one goal and one assist in his six previous games. Mikael Johansson, who tied the score, 2-2, with a power-play goal for the Swedes late in the third period, set up the game-winner at 8 minutes 17 seconds of overtime with a perfect pass to Alfredsson in front of the goal. Goaltender Jarmo Myllys, who played for Minnesota and San Jose during his brief National Hockey League career, got the shutout in Finland's triumph. (AP) TENNIS Teen-ager Advances in the Citizen Cup Martina Hingis showed the staying power of a champion yesterday, beating Judith Wiesner, 7-6, 6-1, in the Citizen Cup at Hamburg, Germany. The 14-year-old Hingis, who turned professional late last year, won the last five games against the 29-year-old Wiesner. Hingis goes into her first WTA semifinal against Anke Huber, who defeated Petra Bergerow, 3-6, 6-4, 6-2. (AP) BATTLE BETWEEN SWEDES: Third-seeded Magnus Larsson edged Mats Wilander, a fellow Swede and his boyhood idol, 6-3, 3-6, 6-2, yesterday to advance to the semifinals of the AT&T Challenge in Duluth, Ga. The victory set up a match today with No. 1 Andre Agassi, who defeated Christian Ruud, 6-4, 6-4. Michael Chang, the defending champion, slipped past Jordi Arrese, 7-5, 6-3, and will face Todd Martin, a 7-5, 7-6 (10-8) winner over Brett Steven. (AP) GOLF Ziegler Takes Lead in Windy Conditions Larry Ziegler shot a six-under-par 66 yesterday to take the lead after one round of the PaineWebber Invitational on the Senior PGA Tour. Playing in the morning on the wind-swept T.P.C. at Pipen Glen course at Charlotte, N.C., where contestants with afternoon tee times battled winds gusting to 25 miles an hour, Ziegler carded five birdies, three in a row to close the round, with the help of some long putts. Trailing Ziegler were Graham Marsh and Roger Kennedy, both at 67. (AP) DAVIES SHOOTS 64: The long-hitting Laura Davies shot a bogey-free, eight-under-par 64 and built a three-stroke lead over seven players in yesterday's opening round of the Sara Lee Classic at Old Hickory, Tenn. Her score was one better than her opening-round 65 last year on the way to the tournament title. (AP) PORTER SHARP IN THE RAIN: Bill Porter, a three-time Nike Tour winner who has made only two cuts in his rookie season on the PGA Tour, shot a seven-under-par 65 in the rain-interrupted opening round Thursday, and it stood up yesterday to earn him a share of the first-round lead with Jim Gallagher Jr. in the BellSouth Classic at Marietta, Ga. Porter has won only $5,014 this year. (AP)

title: Keying Manhattan's Mail
description: Along about the age of 3, most Americans are taught (by their parents) to memorize their home phone numbers. Next they have to memorize their Social Security numbers, and eventually their bank card pin numbers. Then there are their zip codes, their burglar-alarm codes and their telephone calling card numbers, not to mention their frequent-flier number. By next year residents of Manhattan will also have "key numbers" to contend with.

title: Janine Andre-Schwartz, Immunologist, 62
description: Dr. Janine Andre-Schwartz, an immunologist and specialist in electron microscopy, died on April 26 at New England Medical Center in Boston. She was 62 and lived in Brookline, Mass.

title: Ex-Sergeant Is Sentenced For Stealing
description: A former sergeant responsible for making sure colleagues in Harlem's corruption-stained 30th Precinct behaved honestly was himself sentenced yesterday to two years and nine months in prison for lying and stealing.

title: MILITARY BUSINESS SALE TO LORAL IS COMPLETED
description: The Unisys Corporation said yesterday that it had completed the previously announced sale of its military business to the Loral Corporation for $862 million in cash. The operations sold employ about 8,500 people and had revenues of approximately $1.4 billion in 1994. The sale does not include the Unisys Federal Systems and Health Information Management business units, which provide commercial information systems and services to the Federal Government and other public sector clients.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day on Thursday with articles about management changes at Time Warner misstated the total 1994 revenues and cash flow of the company. Time Warner had combined revenues of $15.91 billion, not $7.40 billion, and combined cash flow -- or earnings before income taxes, depreciation and amortization -- of $2.96 billion, not $1.81 billion.

title: Monsanto's Potato Approved by U.S. Regulators
description: The Monsanto Company's genetically engineered potato that fights a devastating pest without insecticide won final Government approval today.

title: BRODERBUND SOFTWARE IN BANNER BLUE ACQUISITION
description: Broderbund Software Inc. said yesterday that it had acquired Banner Blue Software, which markets a line of products called Family Tree Maker that helps families trace their ancestors. The terms of the deal were not disclosed. Banner Blue, a closely held company, has 75 employees and offices in Fremont, Calif., and Provo, Utah. Its products allow families to store video clips and snap shots, organize textual information like names and addresses, and explore a data base of more than 100 million names. Broderbund, based in Novato, Calif., is best known for entertainment software like Myst.

title: Clinton Aides in '92 Saw Political Threat from '90 Loans
description: The 1990 bank loans at the core of the case that prosecutors are building against Bruce Lindsey, President Clinton's most trusted adviser, seem obscure, but during the 1992 Presidential race they were the subject of heated debate among campaign aides worried that they could pose a serious political threat.

title: H & R BLOCK ELECTRONIC TAX-RETURN FEES OFF SHARPLY
description: H & R Block Inc. said yesterday that fees from its electronic tax-return filing program fell 27 percent in the just-ended tax season, reflecting changes in Internal Revenue Service policy. Fees in the program fell to $146.9 million. The number of returns Block filed electronically declined 21 percent, to 5.91 million, according to preliminary data. Volume in Block's tax business in the United States and abroad fell 1.5 percent, to $1.07 billion, in the fiscal year that ended on April 30. Tax-preparation fees rose 4.6 percent, however, to a record $905 million. Shares of the company, based in Kansas City, Mo., were down 62.5 cents yesterday, to $41.375.

title: For Medellin Assassin, 10 Life Sentences
description: One of the Medellin drug cartel's top hit men was sentenced in Federal Court in Brooklyn yesterday to 10 consecutive life terms in prison for his role in the 1989 bombing of an Avianca jetliner that exploded over Bogota, Colombia, killing all 107 people aboard.

title: Sports of The Times; The Fans Just Want To Be Sure
description: LEN COLEMAN, the National League president, grew up in a Montclair, N.J., household in which he and his mother were Brooklyn Dodger fans. His father was a Giants fan. His uncle, who lived one flight up, pulled for the Yankees.

title: Knicks Know Enemy All Too Well
description: The Knicks are preparing for physical play, a little trash talking, a lot of tense moments and a major test.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Clerking for Associate Justice WILLIAM J. BRENNAN JR. of the Supreme Court was, Judge RICHARD S. ARNOLD said the other day, "probably the best job I ever had."

title: After 30-Year Rift, Farrakhan's Meeting With Dr. Shabazz Stirs Hope
description: At the Apollo Theater in Harlem, hundreds bought tickets this week for what many believe will be a historic moment for New York City's black community.

title: Excerpts From Clinton's Commencement Speech
description: Following are excerpts from President Clinton's commencement speech today at Michigan State University, as transcribed by the Federal News Service, a transcription company:

title: Prudential Insurance Pays a Record $5 Million Fine for Violations in New York State
description: The Prudential Insurance Company of America paid a record $5 million fine yesterday for violations of New York insurance law. The infractions did not cause serious harm to customers, but showed widespread disregard for rules requiring that agents and the policy forms they use be approved by the state.

title: Detained, Awaiting Muse
description: After school, Room 131 at Intermediate School 238 in Queens is the scene of unusual, if not cruel, punishment.

title: Day 17 at Blast Site: Hope Ends and Healing Begins
description: Barely 14 hours after they called off their mournful search for victims, hundreds of firefighters, police officers and other rescuers today stood shoulder to shoulder beside the shattered ruin of the Federal Building, silent witnesses at a memorial service signaling the end of hope and beginning of healing in this wounded city.

title: Now for the Real Skate Toward July
description: After a regular season that was delayed and truncated by a contentious lockout, the Stanley Cup playoffs mark an upbeat return to happy normalcy in the National Hockey League.

title: Stocks Decline on Concern About Corporate Earnings
description: Stocks declined again yesterday in erratic trading, as the economy's first loss of jobs in more than two years raised the prospect that corporate earnings would slump.

title: To Toss or Grind in New York: Disposal Reconsidered
description: For decades, New York's banana peels have been forced to endure slow, foul, putrescent deaths in kitchen wastebaskets and landfills. Now there is a chance they will be heading for a quicker, if more violent, end.

title: As It Winds Down, France's Campaign Becomes Personal
description: Jacques Chirac and Lionel Jospin ended their campaigning today for Sunday's presidential election on a harshly personal note, accusing each other of endangering the well-being and security of France.

title: CULBRO STOCK SOARS AFTER SALE AGREEMENT
description: The stock of the Culbro Corporation soared 44 percent yesterday after the diversified tobacco company agreed to sell a controlling stake in its unit that makes Macanudo cigars to a Spanish concern for $100 million. Culbro shares jumped $8.75, to $28.375, on the New York Stock Exchange. The Spanish tobacco and food company Tabacalera S.A. said on Thursday that it had agreed to buy a 51 percent stake in General Cigars, which makes the Macanudo and Partagas brands, two of the most popular in the United States.

title: After Scandal, a Mission; Precinct Chief Trying to Regain Trust
description: Capt. Terence Monahan knew there was something rotten in the 48th Precinct when he took command of it in December. He just didn't know how rotten.

title: Corrections
description: The Pulse charts in some editions of The Metro Section on Wednesday and Thursday, on the rate of new cases of AIDS, misstated the trend from 1993 to 1994. Because of a redefinition of the disease in 1993, and the decision to reclassify a backlog of people who met the new criteria, the figures for that year were inflated. Using a consistent definition, the trend is generally upward, not downward. A chart using data based on consistent definitions of the disease appears on page 21.

title: William Mulligan, Garden Writer, 52
description: William C. Mulligan, a gardening writer who was an expert on the use of lattices to enhance outdoor spaces, died on Wednesday at Twelve Oaks Hospital in Houston. He was 52 and had moved to Houston from Manhattan in 1992.

title: Youth, Cynics, the 48th Precinct and the Difficult Road Ahead
description: OFFICER WALTER BROSNAN'S job has just become more difficult. For almost 15 years, he has been going into the schools in the 48th Precinct telling children that the policeman is their friend and that they should respect the law and those paid to uphold it.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the terrorism trial of Sheik Omar Abdel Rahman misstated the year in which he is accused of issuing an edict authorizing the assassination of Anwar el-Sadat in some editions. It was 1981, not 1991. Because of an editing error, the article misstated the year of his arrival in the United States in some editions. It was 1990; he was not already in the country in 1981.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 2-5 FRENCH CAMPAIGN WINDS UP The two candidates who will compete in the final round of the French presidential election this Sunday ended their campaigning on a harshly personal note. 1 U.S.-JAPAN TRADE TALKS FAIL The United States and Japan broke off talks over trade in automobiles and auto parts. The Clinton Administration is weighing what kinds of trade sanctions to impose. 1 PLANS FOR U.S.-RUSSIAN MEETING News analysis: President Clinton and his advisers know what they would like out of a meeting next week with the Russian President but doubt they will get it. 3 EUROPE AND ITS MUSLIMS Whether Europe succeeds or fails to incorporate Muslim immigrants could have important lessons for the United States, with its own large, new Muslim presence. 4 NEW BATTLE IN JERUSALEM Israel's latest seizure of Arab-owned land in Jerusalem has touched off a political storm that threatens the already battered talks with Palestinians. 4 A BARRIER FALLS IN BALKANS After four years, a wall between Croats and Serbs in a ravaged town came down, allowing the first, tentative meeting of two estranged and suspicious communities. 5 BRITISH CONSERVATIVES BRUISED Britain's governing Conservative Party suffered a bad defeat at the hands of the Labor Party in local elections, leaving it in disarray after 16 years in power. 5 St. Helier Journal: Facing Nazis, upper lips were not always stiff. 2 National 6-10 A WRENCHING SEARCH ENDS Searchers who had dug through the rubble of the shattered Federal Building in Oklahoma City held a memorial service for the scores of people who died in the bombing. 1 CONDEMNING POLITICAL VIOLENCE President Clinton, speaking on the home turf of a paramilitary group, called the belief that violence against the Government is justifiable "wrong and un-American." 1 The investigation of the bombing will be reorganized. 8 UNEMPLOYMENT SURGES The slowdown in the economy spread visibly to the job market in April, as the unemployment rate jumped three-tenths of a point and the number of new jobs fell. 1 DISPUTING CONSPIRACY THEORY The Los Angeles Police Department's chief forensic chemist disagreed with a defense theory that blood samples were used to frame O. title: A Night of 100 Years Of Onstage Experience
description: The double bill at the Blue Note (131 West Third Street, Greenwich Village) through tomorrow night, which features the tenor saxophonist Johnny Griffin and the vibraphonist Milt Jackson, is in many ways a lesson on how age and knowledge intersect in jazz. Mr. Griffin and Mr. Jackson are members of the first few generations of be-boppers, and they've spent roughly 50 years apiece on the stage. Jazz is an art form that revels in increments and details, and only age allows for a real control of texture and pitch and the control that makes a performance bloom with emotional significance.

title: U.S. Seizes a New York Savings and Loan
description: The American Savings and Loan Association, a mutual savings institution based in New York, was placed in receivership today by the Office of Thrift Supervision.

title: Israel Widely Mistreats the Detainees
description: To the Editor:

title: Former Grace Executives Back Bid for Health Subsidiary
description: A little-known investment group of former executives of W. R. Grace & Company is teaming up with Constantine L. Hampers in his $3.5 billion bid to buy National Medical Care, the company's health care subsidiary.

title:
HORSE RACING;
Trainer In Derby Is Under A Cloud
description: The trainer Kenny McPeek, who saddles the colt Tejano Run in the Kentucky Derby at Churchill Downs today, is considered one of the rising stars on the Kentucky circuit. But his success has been tempered by a pending one-year suspension handed down by the New Jersey Racing Commission contending that McPeek knowingly entered a horse in an unfit condition, which subsequently led to the horse's death.

title: Proposal for a Bridge Intrudes on Island Life
description: The five-minute boat ride from the bustling resorts and subdivisions of coastal Route 17 to this egg-shaped island nestled in the delta of the Waccamaw and Great Pee Dee Rivers might as well be a journey of a thousand miles.

title: Portrait of Javits Center's Chief: Autocratic, Disdainful of Rules
description: Late in the day on Thanksgiving eve in 1991, Kevin Nolan was heading out the door for the holiday weekend when a messenger walked into his Brooklyn office with a letter from Fabian G. Palomino, then the new chief executive of the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center.

title: Observer; Shooting From the Lip
description: Talk radio is in an uproar about G. Gordon Liddy. One of the medium's prime yakmeisters, Liddy incensed many colleagues by advising his audience on how to shoot vexatious agents of the Federal Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms police.

title: 22 Held in Ring That Traced And Sold Mobile Phone Codes
description: Federal agents said yesterday that they had broken up a ring of high-tech bandits who were stealing cellular telephone codes off the airwaves and installing them on other telephones illegally.

title: Clinton Assails The Preachings Of the 'Militias'
description: President Clinton came within earshot of the Michigan Militia today and in ringing tones denounced as "wrong and un-American" any suggestion that citizens' grievances against the Federal Government could ever justify the threat of violence by paramilitary groups.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about a Connecticut man who was arraigned for two 1986 rape charges eight years after fleeing the country misstated the circumstances of the picture. Alex Kelly was leaving, not entering, court in Stamford, Conn. The picture also carried an incorrect credit. It was taken by Janet Durrans for The New York Times, not by The Associated Press.

title: International Briefs; Canada Plans to Sell Railroad in Big Offering
description: The Canadian Government plans to sell its state-owned Canadian National Railway Company for as much as $2 billion (Canadian) this fall in a public offering. The Transport Minister, Douglas Young, said conditions of the sale would include a restriction on individual ownership to 15 percent, maintaining the railroad's headquarters in Montreal and insuring that the company's operations remain bilingual. There will be no restrictions on foreign ownership, Mr. Young said.

title: Nintendo Delays Introduction Of Ultra 64 Video-Game Player
description: After months of speculation, Nintendo of America Inc. confirmed yesterday that its Ultra 64 video-game player would not be ready in time for the 1995 Christmas season.

title: Europeans Struggle to Balance Old Ways With New Muslim Immigrants
description: Michel Gourdin, a French baker in the northern Paris suburb of Garges-les-Gonesse, remembers the day a year ago when gangs of unemployed North African Muslim youths wrecked his shop in a riot.

title: Algeria Militants Kill 5 Foreign Oil Workers
description: Muslim militants killed five foreigners working on a pipeline in Algeria's oil-producing region today, stirring concern about disruption of the country's crucial oil and gas sector.

title: In America; The Issue Is Jobs
description: "The Turk" is the name professional football players have given to the low-level management functionaries who, in training camp, have the gruesome task of summoning players to the coach's office, where they receive the news that they are being dropped from the team.

title: California Governor Defends Himself on Issue of Illegal Alien
description: Scrambling to get his Presidential campaign back on political track, Gov. Pete Wilson pleaded with voters today to be "fair" in judging whether he committed a serious wrong when he employed a Mexican maid who was an illegal alien and then failed to pay her Social Security taxes.

title: Nominee to School Board Denounced at State Hearing
description: A Greenwich P.T.A. leader who has been nominated to serve on the State Board of Education was denounced at her confirmation hearing today as an intolerant extremist of the Christian right who has tacitly encouraged ugly racial remarks.

title: U.S.-Japanese Auto Trade Talks End in Failure
description: A last-ditch effort to avoid a major confrontation with Japan over trade in automobiles and parts failed last night, and Clinton Administration officials said they would decide today what kind of trade sanctions to impose on billions of dollars in Japanese goods imported into the United States.

title: Trism Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-Net loss, which included extraordinary charge of $ 231,000, or 4 cents a share, on loss from early extinguishment of debt.(Loss)Trism attributed its revenue growth to the addition of E.L. Powell & Sons Trucking Co. and Diablo Transportation Inc., strong specialized freight demands and continued improvement in its freight network management.

title: Cigarette Makers, in New Direction, Move to Raise Prices
description: Displaying new confidence that the heated legislative climate surrounding the tobacco industry has cooled enough to permit a price increase, the largest United States cigarette makers raised their wholesale prices yesterday by 3 cents a pack, or nearly 4 percent for premium brands.

title: Still True to the Cause
description: Twenty-five years after the Kent State shoot ings at a time when Robert McNamara has said that those who protested the Vietnam War were right and Newt Gingrich is vowing to bury the "McGovernik" counterculture -- what is the legacy of 1960's activism for today's students?

title: Chase Is Turning to a Specialist To Help Sharpen Its Budget Ax
description: The banking industry's toughest cost-cutter is coming to the Chase Manhattan Corporation. That means the sun may soon set on the potted palms at Chase Manhattan Plaza near Wall Street -- and on the careers of thousands of the bankers whose offices they adorn.

title: St. Helier Journal; Facing Nazis, Upper Lips Were Not Always Stiff
description: With their green, rolling pastures and trim, stone cottages within earshot of seagulls and the surf, the Channel Islands seem an incongruous setting for the Nazi jackboot.

title: Russian Troupe Far Off Broadway
description: It was 10 minutes to curtain, or would have been if there had been a curtain. In the dim Off Off Broadway playhouse where a weeklong festival of the Russian American Musical Theater was under way, Alexander Zhurbin strode the boards with an edgy optimism.

title: Animal Rites? Judge Says No
description: They got his goat, and fined him $325 to boot. Emilio Saladrigas, a Santeria priest, had claimed the right to keep a live goat restrained behind his shop, for use in a religious ceremony. But a municipal court judge has convicted Mr. Saladrigas of cruelty to animals. The goat went to happier prospects living on a South Jersey farm.

title: Selective Insurance Group Inc.(SIGI,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: The results included an investment loss of $ 87,000 in the latest first quarter and an investment gain of $ 3,491,000 in year-ago period.

title: Nova Scotia Power reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: The results are in Canadian dollars.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: AUDIT SEES DISREGARD FOR RULES AT JAVITS A decision to replace Allied Sanitation with another company was one of the first actions taken by Fabian G. Palomino at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center, and it is one of his many decisions now under review by investigators from the State Legislature and the Comptroller's office. In retrospect it seems a telling indication of how auditors say Mr. Palomino ran the center until he resigned earlier this year: with great autonomy and little apparent regard for state regulations. Page 1. NEW YORK CITY SENTENCING IN AVIANCA BOMBING One of the Medellin drug cartel's top hit men was sentenced in Federal Court in Brooklyn to 10 consecutive life terms in prison for his role in the 1989 bombing of an Avianca jetliner. Page 23. 22 HELD IN MOBILE TELEPHONE RING Federal agents said that they had broken up a ring of high-tech bandits who were stealing cellular telephone codes off the airwaves and installing them on other phones illegally. Page 23. DETAINED AND AWAITING A MUSE After school, Room 131 at Intermediate School 238 in Queens is the scene of unusual, if not cruel, punishment. Detention hall, that is. "The method of correction is poetry," said an assistant principal. Page 23. PRIEST CHARGED IN RAPE ATTEMPT A Roman Catholic priest was arrested and charged with trying to rape a 30-year-old parishioner of a Staten Island church, the police said. Page 22. EX-SERGEANT SENTENCED IN HARLEM A sergeant who was responsible for overseeing integrity among his fellow officers in the corruption-stained 30th Precinct in Harlem has been sentenced to two years and nine months in prison for lying and stealing. Page 22. PRUDENTIAL TO PAY $5 MILLION FINE The Prudential Insurance Company of America paid a $5 million fine for violations of New York insurance law. Page 38. Fugitive in Pennsylvania murders arrested in Manhattan. Page 25. REGION RAPE SUSPECT FREE ON BOND The parents of Alex Kelly put liens on their house and two other properties in Darien, Conn., as security for a $1 million bond and then drove their son home for the first time since he fled the United States in 1987 to avoid trial in the rape of two teen-age girls. Page 24. P.T.A. LEADER DENOUNCED AT HEARING A Greenwich P.T.A. leader who has been nominated to serve on the State Board of Education was denounced at her confirmation hearing as an intolerant extremist of the Christian right, but she cast herself instead as a reasonable proponent of back-to-basics education. Page 24. RIDERS DISSATISFIED WITH L.I.R.R. Dissatisfaction with service on the Long Island Rail Road, particularly the cleanliness of trains, has increased sharply, according to a railroad survey. Page 24. UNEMPLOYMENT RATES RISE IN REGION Economic growth in New York State continued to stagnate last month as the unemployment rate rose again, Labor Department officials said. Page 38. About New York by Michael T. Kaufman 22

title: Bomb Investigation To Be Reorganized
description: The Justice Department will reorganize its investigation of the Oklahoma City bombing, putting the case under the direct supervision of a prosecutor and an F.B.I. inspector, law-enforcement officials said yesterday. The appointments are expected to be announced next week.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball American League CLEVELAND INDIANS -- Placed Paul Shuey, pitcher, on the 15-day disabled list, retroactive to May 4. Recalled Chad Ogea, pitcher, from Buffalo of the American Association. National League LOS ANGELES DODGERS -- Placed Todd Hollandsworth, outfielder, on the 15-day disabled list. Recalled Jose Parra, pitcher, from Albuquerque of the Pacific Coast League. Midwest League ROCKFORD CUBBIES -- Sent Jared Snyder, catcher to Daytona of the Florida State League. Added Jack Johnson, catcher, and Brandon Pico, outfielder, to the active roster. Texas-Louisiana League RIO GRANDE VALLEY WHITEWINGS -- Signed David Tollison, second baseman, and Chris Cassells, third baseman. Northern League SIOUX FALLS -- Signed Pete Weber, outfielder. Released Cliff Jones, pitcher. Football National Football League NEW ENGLAND PATRIOTS -- Re-signed Sam Gash. Gash, fullback. NEW YORK JETS -- Waived Sean Conley, kicker; Brian Drummy, tackle; and Brian Thompson, center. Canadian Football League SHREVEPORT PIRATES -- Named Jim Willer director of concession operations. TORONTO ARGONAUTS -- Signed Brad Harris, defensive end, and John Thornton, defensive tackle. WINNIPEG BLUE BOMBERS -- Signed Joe Pica, quarterback. World League of American Football FRANKFURT GALAXY -- Placed Kevin Williams, running back, on injured reserve. LONDON MONARCHS -- Waived Al Wooten, running back. Hockey National Hockey League HARTFORD WHALERS -- Signed Sean Burke, goaltender, to a multiyear contract. Colonial Hockey League LONDON WILDCATS -- Announced they have suspended operations for the 1995-96 season. Lacrosse Major Indoor Lacrosse League NEW YORK SAINTS -- Announced the resignation of William Dougherty coach. Soccer Continental Indoor Soccer League ANAHEIM SPLASH -- Released Steve Mackenzie, Bobby Reyes, Juan Carlos Sanchez and Rolando Uribe, forwards. College ARKANSAS -- Announced women's softball will become a varsity sport for the 1996-97 season. COLGATE -- Named Dan Hunt, tight end coach, and Scott Meserve, defensive end coach. FRESNO STATE -- Announced the resignation of Annan Wilson, women's assistant basketball coach. HAMPTON -- Named Darren Metress and Jarrell Wilkerson, men's assistant basketball coaches, and Roderick Ford, men's basketball academic counselor. JUNIATA -- Announced the varsity programs in men's cross country, golf, swimming, tennis and wrestling will be discontinued for the 1995-96 school year. SACRED HEART -- Named Dave Laliberty women's soccer coach and women's ice hockey coach. SOUTHERN CAL -- Named Henry Bibby men's assistant basketball coach.

title: Precision Castparts Corp.(PCP,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 2
description: b-After a charge of $ 2.9 million, or 15 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting.Precision Castparts said the sales increase in the latest fourth quarter occurred in its core businesses, primarily in sales of airfoil castings.The company also said it benefited from the addition of its new specialty products division, which was part of the company for less than a month. Its specialty products division also contributed to an increase in selling and administrative expenses from historic levels.

title: Cubans Found at Sea May Test New U.S. Policy
description: A group of 13 Cubans picked up at sea this week is becoming the first test of the Clinton Administration's stern new policy intended to halt the flight of refugees from Cuba in rafts.

title: For America's Cup Boats, the Big Game Is Here
description: There is a moment of truth that comes with any sport, a suspended string of seconds when the world thinks and the competitors feel that things could go either way. In the Super Bowl, it's the opening kickoff. In the World Series, it's the first pitch. And in yachting, it's the first boat over the starting line in the America's Cup.

title: Fisher Scientific Intl.(FSH,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: Fisher Scientific International said continued integration of recently acquired distribution facilities and other investment spending restrained net income growth.The company also said its sales in the latest first quarter were helped by recent acquisitions and a strong performance by its North American distribution operation.

title: Jobless Rate Rises to 5.8% In Clear Sign of Slowdown
description: The slowdown in the economy spread visibly to the job market in April, as the unemployment rate jumped three-tenths of a point, to 5.8 percent, and the number of new jobs fell for the first time in more than two years, Government figures showed today.

title: Exar Corp.(EXAR,NNM) reports earnings for Year to Mar 31
description: b-Included a $ 27,826,000 write-off for in-process research and development.c-Net income and included a gain from an accounting adjustment of $ 200,000, or 2 cents a share.Share earnings and shares outstanding are restated to reflect the 3-for-2 stock dividend in October 1994.(Loss)

title: A New Camera From Kodak
description: The Eastman Kodak Company is introducing a disposable camera in the United States that uses 20 percent fewer raw materials than the current version, as the company continues its drive to squeeze more profit from its products.

title: Life Partners Group Inc.(LPG,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary item.c-Included an extraordinary item.Latest quarter's income from continuing operations of $ 4,800,000, or 18 cents a share, included after-tax charge of $ 9.2 million, or 36 cents a share, related to April 1995 settlement of certain pending class action and other related litigation.

title: WAVEPHORE DEAL WITH INTEL SPURS STOCK RISE
description: The stock of Wavephore Inc. hit a 52-week high yesterday on news that it planned to develop technology for the Intel Corporation to allow reception of data transmitted within video television signals. Under the agreement, Wavephore will license some of its proprietary technologies to Intel. Wavephore makes high-speed wireless data broadcasting technologies for distributing digital data via broadcast television signals. Intel will grant certain rights to Wavephore involving the sale and distribution of products incorporating such technologies. Wavephore's stock was up $3.125, to $13.125, in Nasdaq trading, where its 31 percent gain was among the best of the day.

title: Arms Cache Found in Bronx Apartment
description: City marshals trying to evict tenants from an apartment in the Bronx yesterday discovered a cache of weapons, as well as books describing how to make bombs, the police said.

title: Bridge
description: Since the Precision System was introduced three decades ago, there has not been a major effort to popularize a new system in the United States. Developments since then have been mostly small improvements in the five-card major style.

title: Security Capital Corp.(SECP,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-After a charge of $ 889,000 from an adjustment in accounting.There were no per share earnings in year-ago 9 months because company went public on Dec. 30, 1993.

title: Senate G.O.P. Trims Legal Overhaul Plan
description: Stymied in their effort to pass a sweeping bill, Senate Republicans today scaled back their effort to limit damage awards in liability suits, hoping to attract enough votes for passage in a vote scheduled for Monday.

title: Land Sale to Ease Budget Deficit
description: To generate revenue to help close its $161 million budget deficit, Essex County is selling 363 acres of undeveloped land for $30 million to the Essex County Improvement Authority, which will issue revenue bonds to pay for it. The tract, known as the Hilltop, transverses Verona, Cedar Grove and North Caldwell. County officials suggested that those towns could apply for state Green Acres funding to buy the land from its new owner if they want to preserve it as open space.

title: Kamieniecki And Mattingly Hurt in Victory
description: In the space of one inning last night, Yankee Manager Buck Showalter saw his No. 4 starter and his starting first baseman go down with injuries.

title: Wilder and Miller In One-Act Festival
description: If the 1950's were the era of "Father Knows Best" in America, it also gave birth to "The Twilight Zone." For every sunny cultural image of a suburban Eden, there was a shadowy counterpart, a specter that addressed both apocalyptic anxieties and an implicit boredom with a status quo that seemed fixed in smooth, homogenous concrete.

title: Adventures And Song In Chicago
description: If "Oklahoma" (1943) was the advent of a new American musical theater era, then "Pal Joey" (1940) was the brilliant coda to the old. Here was a show in which cynicism, sophistication, bogus sentimentality and high spirits were as much the content as the form of an otherwise traditional Broadway musical.

title: Lewis T. Preston, 68, Dies; Led World Bank Into 90's
description: Lewis T. Preston, a former president of J. P. Morgan & Company who led the World Bank into the post-Communist world after his appointment in September 1991, died on Thursday at his home in Washington. He was 68. Mr. Preston had suffered from heart problems in recent years and was under treatment for cancer. He resigned as the World Bank's president in March.

title: Borrowing by Consumers Surges In Increase Led by Credit Cards
description: Consumer borrowing accelerated in March at the fastest pace since last summer even as the overall economy was losing momentum, Government figures showed today.

title: Rams Sign Rypien
description: Quarterback MARK RYPIEN, the most valuable player of the 1991 Super Bowl, has signed a contract with the St. Louis Rams. Length and terms were not disclosed. Rypien, 32, played for the Cleveland Browns last season, mostly in a backup role to VINNY TESTAVERDE. Rypien, who started three games, completed 59 of 127 passes for 694 yards and 4 touchdowns with 3 interceptions.

title: Chief Is Chosen By YPF Board
description: The board of YPF S.A., the Argentine oil giant, today named a successor to Jose Estenssoro, its president and chief executive, who died on Thursday in a plane crash.

title: Heading Off a Stealth Candidate
description: Yikes, said members of the state Democratic committee when they saw who filed as their party candidate in the June 6 primary for the 22d Assembly seat. The district, a patch of Union, Middlesex, Somerset and Morris counties, is so heavily Republican that the Democrats had not planned to contest it. The stealth would-be nominee, John Kucek, is a Ku Klux Klan enthusiast who claims that the Holocaust was a hoax. Horrified that Mr. Kucek might take the nomination by default, the Democrats named two write-in candidates to head him off.

title: Madison Gas & Electric Co.(MDSN,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: Results were after preferred dividends of $ 64,000 in latest first quarter and $ 120,000 in year-ago period.

title: Misguided Legal 'Reform'
description: Straining to keep pace with their House counterparts, Senate Republicans loaded up a pending bill on product liability with amendments that would spell relief from lawsuits for a host of companies and individuals who do not like to be sued. They went too far, and now must retreat to a more modest -- but still radical -- measure that would limit punitive damages for defective products in every state and Federal court.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Not every word that emanates from the Supreme Court is lofty. There is, for example, this item from the current issue of Oyez! Oyez!, the Court's in-house publication, which appears every two weeks:

title: New Optimism on Surgeon General Choice
description: Dr. Henry W. Foster Jr.'s prospects to be Surgeon General improved considerably this week, his supporters say. Democrats are increasingly optimistic that Republican efforts to prevent a vote on his nomination will fail.

title: Keep Court Reporters, Panel Says
description: Replacing 58 court reporters with videotape equipment might save $3.2 million a year, as Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's budget suggests, but a state Supreme Court committee report issued yesterday recommends caution about moving too quickly. The report says that any reduction in court reporters should be made through attrition.

title: Agents Scour Arizona Town In Plodding Search for Clues
description: Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation knocked door to door through a nondescript subdivision here today, showing a new set of photographs of possible suspects in the deadly Oklahoma City bombing.

title: Who's in Net Is Just One of Many Questions for Rangers
description: The bus was waiting outside the practice rink for a trip to the airport, a flight to Quebec and whatever awaits the Rangers in the defense of their Stanley Cup championship. Mike Richter, a championship goaltender last spring, was reluctantly talking about the unresolved sideshow surrounding his team -- the unnamed starting goalie for Game 1 -- when Coach Colin Campbell walked by.

title: International Briefs; Heinz Chief Buys Stake
description: Anthony J. F. O'Reilly, the Irish businessman who is chairman of the H. J. Heinz Company in the United States and has newspaper interests in Europe, South Africa and Australia, bought a 28.3 percent stake in the New Zealand newspaper publisher Wilson & Horton Ltd. for $200 million. In 1992, Heinz bought Wattie Foods Ltd., New Zealand's biggest nondairy food producer. The Pittsburgh-based Heinz is 20 percent owned by O'Reilly trusts.

title: New Deal for Burke
description: Goaltender SEAN BURKE has signed a new multiyear contract with the Hartford Whalers, the team said yesterday. Terms were not released. Burke, 28, finished the season with a 17-19-4 record and a 2.68 goals-against average, the lowest of his career. His .912 save percentage also was a career best. Burke joined the Whalers in a 1992 trade with the Devils. (AP)

title: Reno Defends U.S. Conduct In Waco Raid
description: Attorney General Janet Reno tonight gave a strong defense of the Government's conduct in the disastrous 1993 raid on the Branch Davidian sect, rejecting the idea of "a moral equivalency" between that assault and the Oklahoma City bombing.

title: Asian-Americans Stake a Claim on Rock
description: The Ear of the Dragon Tour, which stopped on Wednesday night at the Mercury Lounge, may be a first for rock music. On the bill were four bands with Asian-American members: Seam, Versus, A Miniature and Venus Cures All. None of these bands have a musical style or lyrics that define them as Asian-American groups. But by going on the tour and contributing to a related compilation, also called "Ear of the Dragon" (Fortune5 Records/A.Sides), these bands are, perhaps for the first time in their careers, staking a claim on their identity. It's a brave move for groups that want their music to be considered on its own terms within the broader context of rock instead of as outsider rock made from an Asian-American perspective.

title: Long Island Trains Are Often Dirty and Late, Rider Survey Finds
description: Dissatisfaction with service on the Long Island Rail Road, particularly the cleanliness of trains, has increased sharply, according to a railroad survey released today.

title: 3 States' Heaviest Political Guns Try to Save Their Military Bases
description: The elected officials from the three states had all come to the hearing held aboard the aircraft carrier Intrepid yesterday to argue the same basic point, that the Federal Government was making a terrible mistake in trying to close down their military installations.

title: Trump Agrees To End Feud Over Hotel
description: Donald J. Trump, the New York developer, and Jay A. Pritzker, the Chicago financier, have settled a long-running legal feud over the management of the Grand Hyatt Hotel in New York, which they jointly own and which the Pritzker family's Hyatt Corporation manages.

description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

description: The Police Department's chief forensic chemist in the O. J. Simpson case today offered an innocuous alternative to the defense's main conspiracy theory.

title: J. K. Bosee, 75, New Yorker Chief
description: J. Kennard Bosee, a former president of The New Yorker, died yesterday at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 75 years old and lived in Manhattan and Nantucket, Mass.

title: International Briefs; Mannesmann in Black
description: Mannesmann A.G., a diversified German engineering company, said yesterday that it had returned to profitability in 1994, with net income of 340 million marks ($248 million), after a loss of 513 million marks the previous year. The company said operating profit rose to 598 million marks in 1994, from a 1993 operating loss of 127 million marks. As previously reported, sales rose 9 percent, to 30.4 billion marks, while new orders rose 20 percent. In a statement, Mannesmann credited its machinery and plant construction, automotive technology and telecommunications divisions with the return to profit.

title: Walkway Will Link 2 Trumps
description: Hoping to expand an existing casino into a nearby hotel without obtaining a new gambling license, Donald Trump got approval yesterday to connect his Trump Plaza Hotel Casino to the nearby Trump Regency Hotel. It will be done with a walkway across the Atlantic City Convention Center, which stands between the two buildings. Later this month, the Casino Control Commission will hold a hearing on the Trump plan to link the properties and create a contiguous space to expand gambling to a 40,000-square-foot area inside the Regency without requiring a separate casino license. Nicholas L. Ribis, who runs the Trump casinos, said the walkway itself won't have gambling.

title: Justice to Change Its Team As Hunt for Suspects Slows
description: The Justice Department is preparing a large-scale reorganization of the Oklahoma City bombing investigation and will soon announce the appointment of a lead prosecutor and an F.B.I. inspector to supervise the case, law-enforcement officials said today.

title: STATE STREET BANK AGREES TO ACQUIRE BAYBANK UNIT
description: The State Street Bank and Trust Company agreed yesterday to acquire Baybank Inc.'s $4.4 billion-asset corporate bond trusteeship business consisting of 269 accounts. The terms of the acquisition were not disclosed. State Street is one of the nation's largest corporate bond trustees, paying interest and dividends on more than $210 billion in corporate bonds. State Street handles the paperwork for $1.9 billion in assets and makes investment decisions for another $180 billion in assets. State Street is a unit of the State Street Boston Corporation. Its shares were up $1.25 yesterday, at $33.25, on the New York Stock Exchange while shares in Baybank were up $1.875, at $67, in Nasdaq trading. Both banks are based in Boston.

title: Corrections
description: A chart on Thursday listing the officers charged with wrongdoing in the 48th Precinct in the Bronx misstated the charges against two officers in some editions. Sgt. Michael McCarthy was accused of making false statements to cover up an assault by two officers, but he was not charged with assault. Officer Michael O'Callaghan was accused of assault, as well as making false statements and official misconduct.

title: Israeli Seizures of Arab-Owned Land Set Off Storm
description: It was by turning on the radio news that Dr. Mohammed Jadallah happened to learn about Israel's plans to confiscate the last two acres of rocky land that his family can still call its own.

title: Room for Missed Note
description: To the Editor:

title: Half Mozart, Half Wild: Two Different Worlds
description: One could argue that the music on the New York Philharmonic's program this week either comes from or has deep roots in Central European traditions, and that the performances are therefore explorations of different sides of the same stylistic coin. But that would be a stretch. Actually, the program, conducted by Zdenek Macal, was more like a pair of entirely distinct short concerts, one on either side of the intermission, or alternatively, like a lesson in art's formalities followed by a wild party in which folk and formal styles mingled and caroused.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Unemployment Rate Jumps As Number of Jobs Falls The nation's unemployment rate jumped three-tenths of a point, to 5.8 percent, in April and the number of new jobs fell for the first time in more than two years, as the slowdown in the economy spread to the job market.

description: To the Editor:

title: Keeping Up With Jones Too Much for 1-8 Reds
description: Bobby Jones did not feel like a pitcher who was exactly one month removed from the start of spring training. He did not pitch that way either.

title: Don't Rush to Sanctions
description: President Clinton's advisers meet today to decide whether to impose trade sanctions on Japan after failure to reach agreement on opening up Japanese markets for foreign automobiles and automobile parts. Japan's auto market is the right target for an aggressive American stand because it is closed to foreign suppliers and accounts for almost 60 percent of the $66 billion bilateral trade deficit. But instead of imposing sanctions on its own, Washington should work through the new World Trade Organization, created with American support to deal with this kind of grievance.

Edwin Blum, 89, Writer for Stage And the Screen
description: Edwin H. Blum, who wrote the screenplay for "The Canterville Ghost" and helped write the screenplays for "The Adventures of Sherlock Holmes" and "Stalag 17," died on Tuesday in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 89.

description: b-After a gain of $ 16.5 million, or 75 cents a class B share, on sale of Dorman products division, and a charge of $ 629,000, or 3 cents a class B share, on extinguishment of debt. description: In the free market that is religion in the United States, uncounted numbers of people change faiths, leaving behind what they learned in childhood and seeking a new spiritual embrace.

description: Treasury prices rallied sharply yesterday, sending long-term interest rates down for a second day to their lowest level in more than a year after an employment report showed unexpected weakness.

title: Arthur Scouten, 85, Scholar of Drama And a Professor
description: Arthur H. Scouten, a scholar of Restoration and 18th-century English drama, died on Sunday in St.-Germain-en-Laye, outside Paris. He was 85.

title: The Show Goes on at Waterloo
description: The new executive director of the financially troubled Waterloo Foundation for the Arts said yesterday that the historic village will remain open with a full slate of cultural activities, even though its summer music school and festival have been canceled for this year. In her first day on the job yesterday, Judith R. McAlpin, the new director, said it is "much too soon to tell" about the long-term future of the classical music festival, but a full calendar of summer concerts and other events is still on schedule. The phone number for program information is (201) 347-0900.

title: Atlanta Gas Light (ATG,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: The latest results included after-tax restructuring charges of $ 13 million, or 50 cents a share, in the second quarter, and $ 41.4 million, or $ 1.62 a share, in the 6 months.All periods were after preferred dividends.

title: Priest Charged In Sex Case
description: A Roman Catholic priest was arrested and charged yesterday with trying to rape a 30-year-old parishioner of a Staten Island church, the police said.

title: FMC SUES MOORCO INTERNATIONAL IN HOSTILE BID
description: Making its hostile bid for Moorco International Inc. even more hostile, the FMC Corporation sued Moorco, a Houston-based equipment maker, yesterday, the same day it began its $223 million tender offer for Moorco shares. FMC filed a lawsuit against the maker of pressure-release valves and liquid flow meters, contending Moorco and its board breached its fiduciary duty by refusing to negotiate with FMC about its $20-a-share bid. FMC, a Chicago-based company, which owns 100 shares of Moorco, wants the court to force Moorco to negotiate with it. The company also wants the court to stop Houston-based Moorco from carrying out its "poison pill" anti-takeover defense.

title: Krone Is Going Both for the Roses And for the Record
description: "Sometimes in your mind," Julie Krone was saying today, "you have to back up a little and say, 'This is just another race.' But galloping Suave Prospect this morning, and breezing him the other day, I got the real feeling that this is what it is: the Kentucky Derby. And I can win it."

title: OHM AMENDS ACCORD TO BUY PARTS OF WMX TECHNOLOGIES
description: The OHM Corporation said yesterday that it had amended its agreement to acquire WMX Technologies Inc.'s hazardous-waste and nuclear cleanup businesses, now valuing the deal at about $106 million. OHM will now issue 9.7 million common shares, 700,000 fewer shares than originally offered, in exchange for the operations, which are part of WMX's Rust International Inc. OHM stock was down 12.5 cents, at $11 a share, on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. Rust shares were down 12.5 cents, at $15.375.

title: Bulls Have Jordan Worried
description: Michael Jordan would not say whether it was a bad omen or merely a bad quarter. But moments after the Chicago Bulls eliminated the Charlotte Hornets from the playoffs, 85-84, on Thursday night, he voiced his concern for his team's immediate future.

title: Summit Meeting in Moscow: U.S. Recasts Its Aims
description: President Clinton and his top advisers know exactly what they would like to get out of next week's meeting with President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia. The trouble, as the advisers concede, is that they no longer see much chance of getting it.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page summary yesterday about the Knicks' defeat of Cleveland on Thursday incorrectly described the Knicks' achievement in making 13 3-point field goals. It was a single-game playoff record for the team, not for the National Basketball Association. That record is held by Houston, which made 19 3-point field goals in a playoff game.

title: Mr. Gribetz's Misdemeanors
description: As the successful prosecutor in a number of prominent cases spanning his 20-year reign as the District Attorney of Rockland County, Kenneth Gribetz became one of New York State's best known law enforcement officials. But that bright career collapsed in disgrace this week as Mr. Gribetz resigned his office and pleaded guilty to two Federal misdemeanor counts, avoiding imminent indictment on more serious felony charges.

description: b-Included after-tax special costs of about $ 7.6 million for acquired research and about $ 300,000 for development and amortization.c-Net incomeRevenue is total revenues.(Loss)

description: b-Net income, and included a loss of $ 76,000, or 1 cent a share, from discontinued operations.(Loss)

title: Lee Cass, Bass-Baritone, 70
description: Lee Cass, a bass-baritone who taught voice at Carnegie Mellon University, died on Sunday at Shady Side Hospital in Pittsburgh. He was 70 and lived in Pittsburgh.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: BMC INDUSTRIES, Minneapolis, a designer and manufacturer of precision etched products, will invest $80 million to $85 million to expand its current aperture mask production capacity. H. W. KAUFMAN FINANCIAL GROUP LTD., Farmington Mills, Mich., a financial holding group, said it had received a bid of $8 a share, or $27 million, to acquire its 3.4 million shares outstanding. The name of the bidding company was not disclosed. LUKENS INC., Coatesville, Pa., a specialty steel producer, has sold the assets of its Energy Coatings Company, Houston, a pipeline protective coatings concern, to Dresser Industries, Dallas. Terms of the transaction were not disclosed.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Some things in life are worth repeating, and for RAYMOND J. GREENWALD, a real estate executive and theatrical producer, a bar mitzvah is one of them.

title: Britain's Tories Shaken by Rout in Local Vote
description: Britain's governing Conservative Party suffered a thumping defeat in local elections on Thursday, losing to the opposition Labor Party by nearly 2 to 1 and leaving it in political intensive care after 16 years in power.

title: Maritime Telegraph reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: Year-ago first quarter was restated.Preferred share dividends were $ 906,000 in the latest quarter and $ 1,037,000 in year-ago period.Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Turkey's War of Words
description: One of the greatest tragedies in Turkey's history is happening now. Our Kurdish brothers are being slaughtered, and apart from a couple of hesitant voices, no one is standing up and demanding to know what the Government is doing. No one is saying, "You are riding towards doomsday, leaving the earth scorched in your wake." What will come of all this?

title: Beatrice Lees, Dance Teacher, 84
description: Beatrice Lees, an innovative teacher of improvisational dance movement, died on Monday at Lenox Hill Hospital. She was 84 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Not Guilty Plea to Gambling
description: Alfonse Cataldo, a Florham Park man whom Federal authorities have identified as a Lucchese crime family member, pleaded not guilty yesterday to state charges that he ran a $3 million a year numbers racket in Essex County. Mr. Cataldo, 53, was arrested in Irvington on Thursday along with Melvin Goode, 46, of Newark, who also pleaded not guilty. Authorities said they confiscated $6,000 in cash along with slips indicating $10,000 in bets during the arrest. JOE SHARKEY

title: Big Supply and Weak Demand Drive Down Prices for Cattle
description: Cattle futures fell to a nine-year low today as the number of animals sent to slaughterhouses overwhelmed tepid spring demand.

title: As Chinatown Moves North
description: Mitch Perl, general manager at Cala Di Volpe, an elegant SoHo restaurant, says two Broome Street vegetable wholesalers are spoiling his business. First, there is the stench from vegetables stored on the sidewalk. Then, there are the delivery trucks that block the view of the restaurant, at the corner of Broome and Crosby Streets.

title: Scores With Star Power
description: To the Editor:

title: Fresh Air Fund's Treat: 2 Weeks at Beach
description: LIKE many Manhattanites, Eric Thomas looks forward to spending his two-week vacations at his summer home on Long Island, where he can ride his bicycle to the beach, soak up the sun and run barefoot through the sand.

title: Backtalk; Women's Team Lacked Power of a Different Sort
description: My America's Cup initiation came last spring at the Plaza Hotel in New York City. Bill Koch brought in one of his $3 million America's Cup yachts by trailer the night before to serve as a backdrop for the official announcement of his historic all-women's team. I was an Olympic rower recruited to bring strength and endurance to the boat as a grinder. But at the time of the announcement, even though people were congratulating us for our courage and efforts, the women's team was still a mere concept. The team had done no sailing together, and so I set foot aboard my first America's Cup boat in the middle of Manhattan.

title: Ms. Silverman and Mr. Lowenstein
description: Emily Ann Silverman, a daughter of Irene and Sidney Silverman of New York and Amagansett, L.I., was married on Friday to Jonathan Lowenstein, a son of Nettie Lowenstein of London and the late Heinz Bernard Lowenstein. Rabbi Einat Rimon performed the ceremony at the couple's house in Tel Aviv.

title: The War Between the Women
description: TARA REVISITED Women, War, & the Plantation Legend.By Catherine Clinton.Illustrated. 240 pp. New York:Abbeville Press. $27.50.

title: When J. R. Was Shot The Cliffhanger Was Born
description: IT HAD BEEN A TYPICAL DAY FOR J. R. Ewing. Only six death threats. That night, as he worked late in his office, two gunshots were fired. J. R. (played by Larry Hagman) fell to the floor. A cleaning woman soon discovered him, and the second full season of CBS's nighttime soap "Dallas" came to a close.

title: Let the Owner Beware
description: SLIDE MOUNTAIN Or the Folly of Owning Nature. By Theodore Steinberg. 212 pp. Berkeley: University of California Press.

title: Airplane Inspection Inquiry Turns to Senator's Wife
description: Government investigators have obtained evidence that Linda H. Daschle, second in command at the Federal Aviation Administration, may have used her position to help her husband, a United States Senator, reduce safety inspections of an air-charter company owned by a family friend, Government officials have said.

title: Docket: Casino Lowers a Bet, and Jury Lowers the Boom
description: An occasional compilation of verdicts around the state, first reported in The New Jersey Law Journal.

title: Katharine Burdsall and Paul Heller
description: Katharine C. Burdsall and Paul R. Heller, both equestrians, are to be married today in the apple orchard of their Heller home, Orchard Hill Farm in Carmel, N.Y. The Rev. Sherry Driscoll, a Methodist minister, is to officiate. Cantor Bernard Fitch is to take part in the ceremony.

title: Athletes and Stigmas
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: French Folk Songs and Other International Notes
description: VARIETY awaits music lovers today, with programs honoring the United Nations, showcasing French and Irish folk songs and presenting Finnish jazz. Also on the list is chamber music from Germany and England and an Italian opera set in Paris.

title: Sharing the Bounty of the Country
description: MARLENE and Fred Nucifora know they're lucky. They live in a nine-room house on an acre of land in the shadow of Berkshire Mountain. Their children, Keith, 12, and Dana, 5, spend summers playing in the backyard, swimming in their 20-by-40-foot pool and boating on Lake Hopatcong.

title: Jeanne Lavelle, Christopher Russo
description: Jeanne Marie Lavelle, a daughter of James and Maureen Lavelle of Rye, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Christopher Michael Russo, the son of Anthony and Vera Russo of Syosset, L.I. The Rev. Lawrence C. Inzeo performed the ceremony at the Church of the Resurrection.

title: A Living Lesson
description: WHERE to start in chronicling the last few months in the life of Celeste Lopes of Plainview. From the mountains of Colorado for a little downhill skiing to the valleys of California for an award-winning horseback competition that included jumping and bareback riding, Ms. Lopes (pronounced LOW-pess) has kept mighty busy.

title: The World: Power Grab; Ground Rules For the Great
description: NO less a social philosopher than Wilt Chamberlain, in the days when he literally stood head and shoulders above everyone else on the basketball court, put the matter succinctly: "No man roots for Goliath."

title:
EARNING IT: MINDING YOUR BUSINESS;
I Wanna Be Just Like Bill Gates
description: Q. I would like suggestions for teaching my kids how to become entrepreneurs.DON GANN, Brooklyn A. Now there's an answer to the shrinking of Social Security checks -- start making sure those kids can support you in the style to which you can easily become accustomed.

title: Showing Courage
description: To the Sports Editor:

title:
NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: WAKEFIELD;
A Cool, Sweet Taste of Home
description: Jose Castillo and Ramon Guerrero pull their rusting blue and silver Chevy van up to their favorite stretch of curb along 233d Street near Bronxwood Avenue. From the back, they unload tables and the crates of mangoes and plump papayas they have stacked high. Against the side, they prop bundles of sugar cane stalks.

title: Where Mass Transit Means a Free Ride
description: WHILE air pollution and highway congestion force the state to seek ways to promote mass transit, a long-established rural bus route has found a way to double its ridership.
