title:
FILM;
Get Me (Glub, Glub) Rewrite
description: A YEAR AGO THE Hollywood screenwriter Michael Schiffer was having brunch at a Columbus Avenue restaurant in Manhattan with his cousin, a City University of New York philosophy professor, and their wives. The subject of Mr. Schiffer's latest movie assignment came up, and he excitedly outlined the story: two men battle for control of a crippled submarine and the right to launch or not launch nuclear missiles at Russia.

title: Research Expeditions For the Adventuresome
description: Two California-based programs are offering educational variations on the standard vacation this summer.

title: Celebration Is in the Air
description: Parties for two dance companies, Whitney Museum, New York Urban League and International Center of Photography.

title: An Imaginative Tactician Who Was at Ease in Complexity
description: Mikhail Botvinnik liked to think of himself as a master logician who approached every chessboard problem with objectivity and equanimity. No one has ever come out in print to argue with him, but he was wrong. Indeed, he won a lot of games in magnificent textbook fashion, yet lesser top players performed such feats, too, though maybe not quite as well. He really won because of an incredible tactical imagination that made him comfortable in the midst of what others would have regarded as agonizing complexity.

title: What Juries Have Learned From O.J.
description: I knew this tour of jury duty was going to be different when my fellow jurors and I were dispatched for a break and one juror immediately commented, "What do you think the deal is with all these sidebars?"

title: Is Demolition This Landlord's Aim?
description: A construction worker's death in the collapse of 402 West 38th Street last month -- followed by the demolition of three adjacent buildings -- were but the latest chapters in a two-decade battle over one of Clinton's most despised landlords. And some say there is a method to his badness.

title: The Women Who Flew - but Kept Silent
description: WHAT DAY IN 1940 WHEN I FOUND out Civilian Pilot Training courses were starting at Shaw Airport outside of Iowa City, I skipped my university classes to sign up. Lucky me -- one woman to each class of 10, and I made the cut. I was a prairie child. We didn't have the mountains, the sea; what we had was sky. And the yearning to take to the air was whetted by living history; Lindbergh had given the world a new dimension. I took lessons before my 8 o'clock classes. Later I learned the C.P.T. courses were intended to help provide the pilots we would desperately need if we entered the war.

description: On the surface, few eras would seem to have less in common than the tie-dyed turmoil of the 1960's and the edgy, armed-to-the-teeth anger of the 1990's.

title: New Tretyakov Gallery A Decade in the Making
description: For the last 10 years, the famously closed-for-repair State Tretyakov Gallery has been Moscow's equivalent of the Boston Red Sox -- beloved but seemingly cursed.

title:
FILM;
Capturing History As South Africa Seizes the Moment
description: ON SUNDAY, APRIL 24, 1994, the director Danny Schechter was speaking on a telephone at a rooming house in downtown Johannesburg when there was a thunderous boom. "That was a bomb," he said into the telephone and, 10 minutes before the police arrived, he and his camera crew of South Africans and Americans were recording the damage.

title:
DANCE;
Virtuosic Dances and a Head for Business Too
description: THE CHOREGRAPHER AND dancer David Parsons has a lot going for him. He's drop-dead handsome, charming, an exuberant performer, and he has a wide range of contacts within the arts world, having danced for nine years with the Paul Taylor Dance Company. He knows how to choreograph entertaining dances and has put together a nine-member troupe that shares his passion for sexy, virtuosic movement. He also happens to have a shrewd business sense. Add it all up, and it becomes clear why the Parsons Dance Company is one of the few troupes thriving these days.

description: They gave us some of the most famous images of the war, but what were their favorites? Here with their signature images are three frames from the private archives of the war's greatest living photographers.

title: In Moment of Confusion, Driver Crashes Into a Salon, Injuring 7
description: A woman trying to park at a shopping center in Commack, L.I., confused her car's accelerator and brake and smashed through the front window of a beauty salon yesterday, injuring seven people, six of them seriously, the Suffolk County police said.

title: POSTINGS: Condominium Project Halted in '84 Is Back on the Market; At West 66th St. Building, 21 Full-Floor Apartments
description: Sales began last week at Europa, a new luxury condominium building at 22 West 66th Street.

title: HOW POT HAS GROWN
description: I'm not sure just how to react to Michael Pollan's article glorifying the ingenuity of those growing marijuana, while remaining largely ambivalent about its use ("How Pot Has Grown," Feb. 19).

title: New York City to Rise in Las Vegas
description: Ground has been broken on yet another Las Vegas megaresort, the 2,119-room New York-New York Hotel and Casino. The resort, on the Las Vegas Strip, is modeled on the New York skyline. Among its 10 buildings, each to be roughly a third of the original's size, will be a 48-story, 525-foot-high version of the Empire State Building, a 42-story Chrysler Building and a 26-story AT&T Building. All the buildings will contain guest rooms.

title: F.Y.I.
description: Q. I have often read about the Five Points area of Manhattan in histories of New York City. Can you pinpoint it on a modern map? A. Five Points, a 19th-century slum described variously as "an abode of atrocious crime" and a place where once "evil passions made their playground," was located about where the southwest corner of Columbus Park in Lower Manhattan is today.

title: 2 East End Magazines Join Hot Rivalry
description: COUNTRY and International, two free magazines, have joined the hunt for advertising dollars in the crowded East End market.

title: Licia M. P. Hurst, Jared L. Hoffman
description: Licia Maria Pilar Hurst, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. J. Paul Hurst Jr. of Rydal, Pa., was married yesterday to Jared Lewis Hoffman, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Joel S. Hoffman of New York. The Rev. Dr. Peter Lee Scott, a Unitarian Universalist minister, performed the ceremony at the Union Chapel in the Grove on Shelter Island, L.I.

title: Dueling Empires: Jordan Vs. Shaq
description: Sometime this week, Michael Jordan will find himself driving hard to the basket, lifting off from the ground with only a 7-foot-1-inch, 303-pound obstacle in his path. Shaquille O'Neal's eyes will open wide, his knees will bend, his wingspan will grow and he will rise to confront Jordan.

title: Many Cubans Don't Share Havana's Pride in Pact With U.S.
description: For days now, the sea has been calm and the sky clear along the waterfront and beaches that stretch for miles here. It is just the sort of weather that for more than 30 years has beckoned Cubans to board rafts and try to make their way across the Straits of Florida to seek political asylum.

title: Italian Ministry Investigates the Anti-Corruption Investigators
description: The magistrates whose corruption inquiries brought down Italy's political old guard have been thrust into the public eye once again, with word that the Justice Ministry is trying to decide whether they can be prosecuted.

title: Japan Cites U.S. Demands In Collapse of Auto Talks
description: Japan's Government and car manufacturers closed ranks today, placing the blame for a breakdown of automobile trade talks with the United States squarely on what they called Washington's unreasonable demands for Japan to set numerical targets for purchases of American auto parts.

title: Ms. Montgomsery And Mr. Edwards
description: Diana Montgomery, the daughter of George Granville Montgomery of San Francisco, and the late Elinor White Montgomery, was married yesterday to David Barnard Edwards, the son of Sara and Donald Edwards of Cranbury, N.J. The Rev. Louise L. Kingston, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Holman Ranch in Carmel Valley, Calif.

title: Aftermath of a School Ruling: Rallies and an Appeal
description: EVER since Superior Court Judge Harry Hammer ruled in favor of the State of Connecticut last month, and against 17 plaintiffs in the landmark Sheff v. O'Neill desegregation lawsuit, the protests in Hartford have been reminding many black leaders of the civil rights struggle they endured three decades ago.

title: Mystic, Conn.
description: The stretch of coastline centered around Mystic, Conn., represents the heart of New England's nautical heritage. As exemplified by New London, one of the finest small deep-water ports on the East Coast, this legacy stretches back uninterrupted to the American Revolution. At the time, New London, eight miles west of Mystic, was the base for a fleet of privateers that preyed on British ships. After the Revolution, whaling came to the fore.

title: The Lost Episode
description: SINCE 1989, it was always there, among the ads for laser surgery and podiatry: "Decision/La Decision," the soapy story (in English and Spanish) of Marisol and Julio, who are negotiating love in the age of AIDS.

title: No Headline
description: "What strikes me is there's a strong element of commemoration as well as celebration. There's a much heightened awareness that what happened in the war was horrific and that what we are commemorating is the end of a dark night." MARTIN GILBERT, historian, on the 50th anniversary of V-E Day. [ 8:1. ]

title: How Do They Know When to Shout Fore?
description: What golfers want, Jerry Wolkoff said, is to play golf in their spare time, and he has built what he calls the first 24-hour golf course on Long Island, the Heartland Golf Course in Islip, which is scheduled to open under the lights on Friday. (Eric Michaelson for The New York Times)

title: Two Mansions, Two Eras in Providence
description: THE first time I visited the Nightingale-Brown House, I had to wear a hard hat. The house, one of the largest 18th-century wooden buildings in America, wasn't simply a wreck, it was dangerous. A giant plastic tarpaulin shrouded the exterior; inside, ceilings and floors were missing, and architectural entrails of all sorts -- wiring, pipes, steel reinforcements -- were exposed. It wasn't a pretty sight. But that was four years ago. Today the Nightingale-Brown House literally gleams, especially in late afternoon, when its glossy clapboards, now painted a rich, custardy yellow, take on an even deeper, silkier patina from the low sun over Providence (the new shade is similar to one of 30 layers of paint found on the exterior of the house).

title:
NEW ENGLAND ISSUE;
Roadside Attractions On Route 7
description: ROUTE 7 in Fairfield County, Conn., is definitely not the one less traveled by. In fact, since my husband and I moved to nearby West Redding seven years ago, we've tried to avoid this major route on summer weekends, when multitudes of visitors are trolling its antiques shops, and especially in October, when it becomes the route of choice for New Yorkers heading north on foliage tours.

title: Stacey Street, Jason Anniballi

An important historical clarification, however, is that burial in the churches of Florence was not a privilege of the upper classes in the Middle Ages but was open to Florentines of all economic strata.

"Last year we didn't think we had a chance in Games 1 and 2," Coach Larry Brown said today as Indiana prepared for Sunday's series opener. "We were just happy to be there."

title: Q and A

My husband and I will be traveling to England this year and hope to replace pieces of our "Sun" pattern tableware, made by Stonehenge Midwinter, a member of the Wedgwood group. There are a number of china-matching services in England, but you don't have to travel to Britain to find "Sun" replacements.

His classroom on the 40th floor of the Grace building looks onto panoramic vistas. The Empire State Building looms large, a spearlike calamus leaf abutting a cloudless sky.

title: The Decline of Discourse?
description: To the Editor:

title: Goo-Goo Eyes
description: DEMOCRATS WANT an outside goo-goo to determine the standards of right and wrong," I wrote in a recent piece about the ethics of Speaker Newt Gingrich. "But internal goo-goos are elected to do that job, guided by the public's sense of right and wrong."

title: Conversations / Kenneth B. Clark; An Integrationist to This Day, Believing All Else Has Failed
description: HE bought the dolls at Woolworth's on 125th Street in Harlem, one of the few places that sold black dolls then. And when he offered groups of black and white children a choice, both overwhelmingly rejected the black dolls for white ones. Nearly a half-century later, black dolls are more visible. So are black people. Yet the corrosive race consciousness revealed by his experiment, and invoked by the United States Supreme Court in its ruling that equal but segregated schools are unconstitutional, endures.

title: Escape From Pompeii At Busch Gardens
description: "Escape From Pompeii," a new attraction at Busch Gardens Williamsburg, opened last month, allowing visitors to tour a re-creation of the excavation site in boats. As Vesuvius rumbles, the boats are swept along by the current into the ruins. The eruption grows in intensity, cracking huge overhead beams and sending them crashing into the water, narrowly missing the boat. Fireballs fill passageways, statues topple and roofs are consumed by fire. Eventually the passengers find themselves in a black, steam-filled room and are left to wonder if they have drifted into a subterranean chamber of Vesuvius itself. A door opens suddenly, blinding the passengers with sunlight as the boat drops five stories to a plunge pool.

title: Convict Appealing Death Sentence Turns to the Internet for Aid
description: Girvies L. Davis is on death row in Illinois. And he is on the Internet everywhere.

title: Prominent Anarchist Finds Unsought Ally in Serial Bomber
description: When newspapers last week published a letter from the elusive serial bomber in the Unabom case, at least one person -- a rumpled, middle-aged man who lives here in Eugene -- found some measure of tempered satisfaction in all the attention given the writer's pro-anarchist views.

description: On a recent afternoon, Ilana Friedman, Rebecca Josephson and nearly 30 other eighth graders from a Manhattan school dropped by the Federal courthouse in Foley Square for a glimpse of the biggest terrorism trial ever to come to an American courtroom.

description: A bill to reshape the nation's legal system is on the ropes in the Senate. The President, so lately accepted as weak -- or worse, irrelevant -- brands it the "Drunk Drivers Protection Act" and it dies that afternoon.

title: We All Must Die; Who Can Tell Us When?

title: The Nation; The Doctor Heals Himself
description: IN two days last week, Dr. Henry W. Foster Jr. demonstrated just how malleable political fortunes can sometimes be in Washington -- his own and President Clinton's. As he talked, laughed, wept and bristled his way through a Senate confirmation hearing on whether he will be the next Surgeon General of the United States, he seemed to wipe away the gloom that had settled over the nomination just a few weeks ago. Instead, he gave an uncomfortable jolt to those Republicans trying to derail the nomination on the grounds that during a 38-year medical career as an obstetrician he had performed some three dozen abortions.

title: From Riches to Rags in 5 Years
description: THE BEEF: Jeffrey P. Woloson, 33, inherited a $380,000 bond portfolio when his partner died of AIDS in 1990. When he went to a tax accountant earlier this year he thought his portfolio would be worth around $400,000. Not by a long shot. His broker's active trading had left him, the accountant told him, actually owing money to his brokerage firm. Mr. Woloson, who previously managed to live off his inheritance, now cleans houses to make ends meet.

title: The Care and Feeding of May's Seedlings
description: MAY, the month for planting, also happens to be the month for plant sales. Nurseries, garden centers, nature centers, garden clubs, specialty stores, plant societies and even the occasional supermarket -- all are in on the act.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE LONGEST MEMORY By Fred D'Aguiar. Pantheon, $20.

description: Not since the grim old days of the cold war have relations between the United States and Russia been quite as problematic as they are this weekend, on the eve of President Clinton's visit for celebrations marking the 50th anniversary of the Allied victory in Europe in World War II.

title:
HOME CLINIC;
Gilding and Gold Leafing, 2 Ways to Restore the Luster of Yore
description: RESTORING the original metallic luster to a gilded picture frame requires some basic techniques of gilding and applying gold leaf. The terms gilding and gold leafing are often used interchangeably, but there is a difference. Gilding is covering a surface with a metallic finish like gold, silver or any metallic composition, even imitation gold paint. Gold leafing means covering a surface with thin sheets of genuine gold.

title: Soane's Museum In London Expands
description: A new gallery and a restored breakfast parlor have been opened at Sir John Soane's Museum in London after the completion of a $4.8 million, five-year restoration. The original museum is at No. 13 Lincoln's Inn Fields, but the new rooms are in the house next door (No. 12), where Soane, an architect known for the Bank of England and other buildings, lived beginning in 1792. In 1812 he moved into the larger premises at No. 13, which is now connected to No. 12 by a new doorway.

title: Habitats/Middletown, Conn.; A Design That Keeps in Mind the Owner's Disability
description: A MINUSCULE piece of paper taped to the door of John Frazer's painting studio carries a brief message: "In creating, the only hard thing is beginning."

title: Ladder of Years
description: The French have said that William Wyler, the great director of movies like "Dodsworth" and "The Best Years of Our Lives," had a "style sans style." Anne Tyler has this same deceptive "style without a style." Opening one of her books in the middle and picking a page at random, a reader might not immediately recognize her individual rhythm or idiosyncratic temperament. She does nothing fancy, nothing tricky. But so rigorous and artful is the style without a style, so measured and delicate is each observation, so complex is the structure and so astute and open the language, that the reader can relax, feel secure in the narrative and experience the work as something real and natural -- even inevitable.

title: Bookshelf

Selections from those powerful interviews are interspersed with handsome black and white photographs.

title: New Jersey to Bronx Bombers: Stay Put!

title: The Biggest Con Man In the Marines
description: ANYONE WHO DOUBTS THAT GOD possesses a cosmic sense of humor did not serve in the Second Battalion of the 29th Marines (reinforced) 50 years ago. Only a sublime imagination could have provided comic relief during what was, on the whole, a thoroughly disagreeable war. To be sure, God did not do it alone. In such situations even the Almighty needs a hand -- a straight man, as it were -- and in this case, He was memorably assisted by Col. Victor F. Bleasdale U.S.M.C., our regimental commander.

title: More Smoke

title: A Russian Master's War
description: Some consider Yevgeny Chaldey to be the Russian Robert Capa. As a staff photographer for Tass during the war, he produced a vast documentary archive. Long buried in the files, his work is the great photographic treasure to emerge from the end of the cold war -- most of it has never before been seen in the West.

title: The Irish Question, Poetry Dept.
description: OBJECT LESSONSThe Life of the Womanand the Poet in Our Time.By Eavan Boland.254 pp. New York:W. W. Norton & Company. $23.

title: All the Rage, Posthumously
description: THE BRIEFEST LIVES SOMETIMES leave behind the strongest vibrations. Without Mozart or Rimbaud or James Dean, there is no guarantee that the sustained echo of classical music, symbolist poetry and method acting would still ring so clearly through the decades.

title: Joanna B. Lapkin, Bernard Ravina
description: Joanna Bethany Lapkin, a daughter of Millicent and Dr. Benjamin Lapkin of Larchmont, N.Y., was married last evening to Bernard Mayer Ravina, a son of Ruth and Oscar Ravina of Upper Montclair, N.J. Rabbi Jon Haddon performed the ceremony at the Metropolis Country Club in White Plains.

title: Authentic Colt Pistols (Not-at-All-Automatic Weapons)
description: The long-barreled Colt six-shooters look like souvenirs from the dusty Oregon Trail or remnants from a Civil War skirmish, as if they might have been drawn from the holster of a forgotten cavalryman.

title: At Landmarks, a Businesslike Balancing Act
description: "I'VE been surprised about how much misperception and negative perception there is about what we do," said Jennifer J. Raab, the eighth chairperson of the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission and the first lawyer to hold that post.

title: CHATTER: Paying for Schools; A Household Surcharge Controlled by the State
description: Education is the most important community service and is our future. The cost is rather unfairly distributed to individual homeowners. A lot of New Jersey families live in apartments, which have a different, lower tax base. I think the fairer method would be a surcharge based on the number of people who live in a household, and let it be controlled by the state, not the community. Considerations should be made for those on fixed incomes.

title: Commercial Property/Round-Up Newcomers; Moving Out to a Home on the Ever-Costlier Range
description: IN California, Ken Marble lived in upscale Newport Beach, drove a Mercedes and owned a boat-cleaning business. Two years ago he traded the California life style for harsh winters, seven-day work weeks, and the uncertain financial future of owning a Western ranch.

title: Mothers and Children, Together in Healing
description: THE Stamford woman was tired, so tired that her soul was ready to lie down and let her body go on without it. After 16 years of angling for money and making midnight drug runs in rain or snow, she finally said to herself, "Why don't you just give it up, and get some help."

title: After the Valley, the Peak Is All the Sweeter
description: ONE OF THE WORLD'S GREAT dancers needs a haircut. In the studio, amid the many dancers rehearsing for American Ballet Theater's 1995 season, he is unrecognizable beneath thick, shaggy locks -- until he starts to move. His whirring pirouettes and double air turns are dispatched with immeasurable speed and style and tinged with that portent of danger peculiar to memorable dancers.

title: City Closes Porn Theater for Allowing Sex Among Patrons
description: A pornographic theater was closed Thursday night by city officials following reports by undercover health inspectors of more than 80 instances of high-risk sex among the men who patronized it.

title: FUNDS WATCH
description: No More Free Ride For the Little Guy

title: Different Drummers; One Man's Parade, Another's Parking Lot
description: This weekend, like every other spring weekend, the streets are filled with people exercising a privilege cherished by every group of citizens in New York: the right to inconvenience every other group of citizens in New York.

title: Andrew Brodey and Eugenia Erlij
description: Eugenia Erlij, the daughter of Sarah and Dr. David Erlij of Brooklyn, was married last evening to Andrew Brodey, the son of Z. Riki and Dr. James Brodey of West Hartford, Conn. Rabbi Marjorie Slome performed the ceremony at Bargemusic, the performance space in Brooklyn.

title: INSIDE
description: INVESTING IT /Page 4 Everyone knows that sentiment should play no part in investing, but just try telling that to an animal lover thinking of buying into the pet business. At the Gate, by Reed Abelson. MUTUAL FUNDS /Page 8 It shouldn't be too surprising that the company offering the nation's best choice of mutual funds to employees in its retirement plan is in the fund business. By Mary Rowland. SPENDING IT /Page 12 The best and worst of business books. Plus this month's list of New York Times Business Best Sellers. By Barbara Presley Noble. EARNING IT /Page 13 Is your office a mess? Maybe a professional organizer can help. At least for a while. By J. Peder Zane.

title: Hospital Helps Uninsured Regain Financial Health
description: Janie H. Hunt works as a receptionist here at the Danville Regional Medical Center, and even though she is earning $5 an hour at the age of 55, she has never enjoyed a job more.

title: Fourth Line For Devils Goes Front And Center
description: The Devils have no players who match the caliber of Boston's Ray Bourque or Cam Neely or even Adam Oates, but they have a secret weapon that few teams in the league possess. They have a fourth line that is truly instrumental to the team's success.

title: April 30 - May 6: A New Phase; The Balkan Wars Heat Up As Croatia Takes the Field To Roll Back Serbs
description: The wars of Yugoslavia's collapse entered a new and extremely volatile phase last week as the Croatian army swept to a decisive victory in the Serbian-held enclave of western Slavonia. The lightning strike against the Serbian pocket demonstrated the new prowess of the Croatian army, the increasingly debilitating divisions of the Serbs, and the impotence of a United Nations peacekeeping force caught in the midst of a war.

title: World Trade Center Sale Is Reconsidered
description: Facing intense political pressure to turn over some of its vast property holdings to private control, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey plans to select an investment banking firm this week to decide whether it should sell its best-known asset, the World Trade Center.

title: In Philippines, Wary Hopes For a Shift From Stagnation
description: It became the nightmarish symbol of a desperate nation -- thousands of Filipinos swarming over a mountain of garbage as tall as a 10-story building, scavenging through this Everest of rotting trash with their bare hands.

title: Where Bright Colors Are Welcome
description: On occasions of great ceremony at the Cornelius Vanderbilt Mansion on Fifth Avenue, fashionable New Yorkers used to pass through the 58th Street entrance gates. In 1927, when the mansion was demolished, the family donated one of the gates to Central Park, which placed it at the entrance to the Conservatory Garden. Now, fashion has moved up to Fifth Avenue and 105th Street, where last Wednesday more than 1,000 well-dressed people passed through the gate to attend the conservancy's Frederick Law Olmsted Awards Luncheon. It honored Anne Johnson and Thomas G. Labreque, the chairman of Chase Manhattan Bank. The benefit has become the city's foremost spring fashion spectacle, even replacing the Easter Parade, and this year $1.2 million was raised for the park. One hundred and four women chose pink suits, and 197 guests wore hats in styles associated with Ascot in England. While the fashion world wears all black, these women professed color.

description: Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction 1 1 2 THE RAINMAKER, by John Grisham. (Doubleday, $25.95.) Four poems celebrating women. Weeks This Last On Week Week List Nonfiction 1 1 2 IN RETROSPECT, by Robert S. McNamara with Brian VanDeMark. (Times Books/Random House, $27.50.) The Secretary of Defense under Kennedy and Johnson ruefully recalls his role in the Vietnam War. 2 2 30 THE HOT ZONE, by Richard Preston. (Random House, $23.) The discovery of a lethal virus, more infectious than H.I.V., and the efforts to keep it from spreading. 3 4 12 THE DEATH OF COMMON SENSE, by Philip K. Howard. (Random House, $18.) How governmental rules and regulations are fettering the lives of all Americans. 4 6 19 SISTERS, by Carol Saline. Photographs by Sharon J. Wohlmuth. (Running Press, $27.50.) How to "generate wealth in all its forms." 2 2 102 MEN ARE FROM MARS, WOMEN ARE FROM VENUS, by John Gray. (HarperCollins, $23.) Communicating. 3 1 4 MARS AND VENUS IN THE BEDROOM, by John Gray. (HarperCollins, $22.) Maintaining passion. 4 1 HOW TO ARGUE AND WIN EVERY TIME, by Gerry Spence. (St. Martin's, $22.95.) A lawyer describes ways to win arguments at home and at work. Rankings reflect sales figures, for the week ending April 22, at 3,050 bookstores plus wholesalers serving 28,000 other retailers (gift shops, department stores, newsstands, supermarkets), statistically weighted to represent sales in all such outlets nationwide. An asterisk indicates that a book's sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. And Bear in Mind (Editor's Choices of other recent books of particular interest) EDMUND WILSON: A Biography, by Jeffrey Meyers. (Peter Davison/Houghton Mifflin, $35.) Lively, shapely and evocative, this book offers insights into Wilson's public and private lives that Wilson, despite his own autobiographical writings, lacked the introspection to achieve. EXCELLENT CADAVERS: The Mafia and the Death of the First Italian Republic, by Alexander Stille. (Pantheon, $27.50.) This fascinating and horrifying examination, based on immense piles of documents, shows how in the last 25 years the Mafia has terrorized Sicilian society and perverted Italian politics. THE INFORMATION, by Martin Amis. (Harmony, $24.) Mr. Amis's cool and brilliant novel is sustained throughout by the corroding, corrupting envy of an unsuccessful novelist for a successful novelist who is also his best friend. MEMOIR FROM ANTPROOF CASE, by Mark Helprin. (Harcourt Brace, $24.) The slowly unfolding self-revelation of Oscar Progresso, the thoughtful, aged eccentric who narrates this novel while planning a fantastical crime. MEN IN BLACK, by Scott Spencer. (Knopf, $23.) A smart, affectionate comic novel in which an honorable but unsuccessful novelist's life is overturned when his pseudonymous potboiler about extraterrestrials becomes a best seller. A MOMENT ON THE EARTH: The Coming Age of Environmental Optimism, by Gregg Easterbrook. (Viking, $27.95.) Essays on the most complex of modern subjects, treating our considerable environmental accomplishments and our puzzling neglect of threats (diseases, for instance) in other people's backyards. NANO. The Emerging Science of Nanotechnology: Remaking the World -- Molecule by Molecule, by Ed Regis. (Little, Brown, $23.95.) Crisp science journalism about a possible world of endless bounty, produced by incredibly tiny machines. NOAH'S CHOICE: The Future of Endangered Species, by Charles C. Mann and Mark L. Plummer. (Knopf, $24.) The authors persuasively contend that humans will decide, by default or by intention, who goes extinct, and at present have not a clue how to do so wisely. OSWALD'S TALE: An American Mystery, by Norman Mailer. (Random House, $30.) Stoked by a passion to believe J.F.K.'s death was more than a meaningless absurdity, Mr. Mailer pursues and delivers the assassin's very slightly significant soul, using his own research and that of others. REDEYE: A Western, by Clyde Edgerton. (Algonquin, $17.95.) An elaborate, unbelievable plot, chock-full of believable, well-developed characters, sustains this woolly western by an admirable Southern novelist. THE TRIAL OF ELIZABETH CREE: A Novel of the Limehouse Murders, by Peter Ackroyd. (Nan A. Talese/Doubleday, $22.) A claustrophobic, agitated novel of London in 1880; everyone (including a clutch of famous contemporary reformers) is connected to everyone else.

title: Inside the 48th -- A special report; Bronx Police Inquiry Depicts A Night Shift Out of Control
description: The police corruption scandal in Harlem last year produced dozens of indictments, much disgrace and promises of radical management changes. But for all the handcuffed officers and pledges from Police Commissioner William J. Bratton about "re-engineering" the department citywide, there was no revolution in supervision at the 48th Precinct in the Bronx.

title: April 30 - May 6; Should Harvard Beam Him Up?
description: Suppose somebody writes a book called "Abduction: Human Encounters With Aliens," consisting mainly of the case histories of 13 people who say they have been abducted by diminutive, large-eyed, gray-colored space creatures and forced to have sex with them. And the book becomes a national best seller and the author a star on the talk-show circuit.

title:
The View From: Port Chester;
The White Shoe Edict and Other Change-of-Season Customs
description: FROM Memorial Day to Labor Day, you may wear white shoes. Not before and not after. As a command, the White Shoe Edict should be clear and simple enough. Do not violate it."

Sherman of Capital Investments International and Byron R. Wien of Morgan Stanley -- to offer insights. They were surprisingly unified on several things: Cyclical stocks are cheap. Utilities are not. And there is no reason that the major averages cannot keep rising.

The installation was meant to honor the first anniversary of Mr. Mason's latest one-man show, "Politically Incorrect," playing at the John Golden Theater, 252 West 45th.

title: MARKET TIMING
description: Monday Sentate Budget Committee meets to work on the Federal budget. May Department Stores is one of several retailers reporting quarterly earnings this week. Analysts expect May to come in at 47 cents a share. Tuesday The Commerce Department reports March wholesale trade. Forecast: up 0.6 percent. The Labor Department announces productivity and costs for the first quarter. In the fourth quarter, they rose 1.7 percent. Boston Chicken is expected to announce earnings of 13 cents a share, British Petroleum, $1.39, the Equitable Companies, 46 cents and The Limited, 13 cents. Wednesday The Federal Reserve Board releases its "Beige Book" report on the economy. W. R. Grace annual meeting in Boca Raton, Fla. Certain to come up is last week's $3.5 billion buyout offer from Constantine L. Hampers, a company executive vice president, for National Medical Care, a Grace subsidiary. Federated Department Stores is expected to report a loss of 4 cents a share. Thursday The Labor Department announces the producer price index for April. Forecast: up 0.4 percent, after recording no change in March. Chain store sales are reported by the Commerce Department. Forecast: up 0.2 percent. Analysts expect The Gap to report quarterly earnings of 42 cents a share, Lands' End, 12 cents, and Royal Dutch/Shell Group, $1.95. Friday The Labor Department announces the consumer price index for April. Forecast: up 0.3 percent, after a 0.2 percent increase in March. The Commerce Department reports March business inventories. Forecast: up 0.6 percent.

title: April 30 - May 6; Exit Two Bit Players on a Road to Nowhere
description: IN the end, if it really was the end and not just some bizarre entr'acte for two unlikely actors in a still-unfinished national drama, Gary Land and Robert Jacks made their exit the same way they had made their entrance, in a clunky Ford Thunderbird. The scene was almost as improbable as what had come before: the million-to-one coincidences about their backroads meanderings, their reported flying-color scores on F.B.I. polygraph tests and, ultimately, the unraveling of a nationwide manhunt for a suspect known only as John Doe No. 2.

title: A Traveler's Guide to Europe in a Day of Weak Dollars
description: IF your travel plans for Europe are still as murky as the sound of a railroad loudspeaker, sharpen them now. Savings can be realized with advance research and some time with a travel agent, unless you prefer to do battle yourself with airlines, railroads and car rental agencies.

title: CLIFFORD GEERTZ
description: Surely you don't believe that Clifford Geertz's intellectual waffling, peppered with puerile insults from his petulant former disciples, fairly represents anthropology ("The Unabsolute Truths of Clifford Geertz," by David Berreby, April 9). Your readers need to know that our field is alive and well, that it continues to make discoveries about human nature and experience and that it will survive the disproportionate media attention given to this handful of aging enfants terribles who produce little more than the loudest, the laziest and the silliest forms of armchair philosophizing that anthropology has to offer. MELVIN KONNER, M.D. Professor of Anthropology Emory University Atlanta

title: Guarding Against Intruders
description: IN the Middle Ages, castle royalty found security behind water-filled moats and turret-topped towers. In ancient China, an entire civilization found security behind a 5,000-mile stone wall. Beefing up security, it seems, is a universal preoccupation.

title: The O.J. Simpson Trial, as Not Seen on TV
description: During a pre-trial interview with a talk-show host, Judge Lance Ito crosses his legs, revealing that he forgot to wear pants under his robes. In the courtroom, Johnnie Cochran is passing out business cards to the jury. Kato Kaelin's mother interrupts his testimony to ask: "Where did I go wrong?" Finally, a canine expert is brought in and the murderer is fingered, or rather, pawed, by the only witness to the famous double murder: Nicole Brown Simpson's Akita.

title: 'I AM THE BOMBARDIER!'
description: "You're going to organize all this, fix up my grammar?" Joseph Heller asks, and without waiting for an answer plunges into a story sure to resonate with readers of "Catch-22," which Heller began writing in 1953 and finished eight years later. Having sold more than 10 million copies, it is one of the best-selling novels of all time. At 72, young-looking despite his cottony white hair, Heller radiates good humor. The wrinkles on his face are from smiling. His voice is earthy, his words rushed, his accent closer to Brooklyn, where he was raised, than Oxford, where after the war he spent a year on a Fulbright scholarship. The tale he tells is salted with wit, but though he chuckles from time to time he doesn't expect his listener to laugh along. He is not a showman, and this is a straight reckoning, a summing up, not a performance.-- Adam Begley

title: Gramm Extends Olive Branch of Sorts to Ease Strains With Conservatives
description: Senator Phil Gramm went to Liberty University in Lynchburg, Va., today to deliver the commencement address -- and to make peace with social and religious conservatives who have been uneasy with his Presidential campaign.

title: A Maestro (Really!) Out Of Costume
description: THE IMAGES OF ARTHUR FIEDLER THAT endure, more than 15 years after his death, are not those of a veteran conductor standing before an august orchestra, wielding a baton. They are those of an avuncular Santa Claus leaning on a mantel, a high-stepping cancan dancer flanked by gartered women, a gold-suited toreador with a scarlet cape, a mink-coated rake posing before 1920's flappers, a red, white and blue Uncle Sam with top hat and cane: vaudevillian images of "Mr. Pops" at play, on the jackets of the more than 50 million of his records that have been sold.

title:
HORSE RACING;
One Long, Long Ride To the Winner's Circle
description: Gary Stevens was tired, burned out over a professional grind that demanded he ride five times a week, 52 weeks a year, with days off only for injuries. His personal life also was causing strain; he and his wife, Toni, had agreed to a divorce, and though they have remained friends, Stevens had trouble adjusting to not being with his four children.

title: Feeling Down? How About a New Pollster?
description: WHEN Bill Clinton's Presidential crusade plunged into scandal in the 1992 primaries, his pollster, Stanley B. Greenberg, told him the campaign was in "meltdown" and helped devise a plan to cool it off. When Mr. Clinton faced George Bush in the general election, Mr. Greenberg explained to the candidate what was on America's mind. When Mr. Clinton scored gutsy legislative victories with his first budget and Nafta, Mr. Greenberg, by now the official White House pollster and political tactician, pshawed modestly. "I'm dealing with a President who has an intuitive sense of what's going on in the country," he told a conclave of political sages.

title: Let's Ask Why They Can't Spell
description: "About Long Island": " 'If You Can't Spell You Look Stupid' " [ April 9 ] calls attention to why it should be mandatory for certified teachers to know how to teach reading, writing and spelling. Reading Reform deserves applause for its intensive and effective outreach. But like myself and other literacy providers it is applying a Band-Aid to a hemorrhage.

title:
SHATTERING GERMANY;
A Deadly Welcome
description: I WAS A RIFLEMAN IN THE 327TH GLIDER Infantry, a regiment of the 101st Airborne Division stationed at Reading in the south of England. This was a good camp, I wrote home in the spring of 1944, "where they really feed us." Luxuries like candy and cigarettes were available, and in the evening you could go to a movie in camp or to a pub where you drank half-and-half (beer and stout). When the pub closed, you walked the dark, unlighted streets back to your Quonset hut.

title: The Unseen Painful Legacy Of a Careless Dog Walker
description: To the Editor:

title: Experiments in Deceit
description: THE PRIVATE SCIENCE OF LOUIS PASTEUR By Gerald L. Geison. Illustrated. 378 pp. Princeton, N.J.: Princeton University Press.

title:
HORSE RACING: NOTEBOOK;
A Swift and Honest Pace Wears Down Serena's Song
description: Winning Colors won the Kentucky Derby in 1988 because no one challenged her early, leaving her fresh for the stretch run. Seven years later, Serena's Song paid for it.

title: Knocking New York
description: It never fails. Just when you're feeling pretty good about yourself, something comes along and knocks the stuffing right out of you. Last week it happened to New York.

title: Ethiopia Holding Elections in Federal System
description: In a bold political experiment, Ethiopia will hold its first elections Sunday that will put into effect a federal system granting regional and ethnic groups the right to secede if they choose.

title: Not Gilding Any Lilies, Just Updating Them
description: THE apron dress was sugar pink with flowers scattered over its surface. Nothing surprising about that. Floral housedresses have been around since homemakers were called housewives.

title: Frazzled by the Voltage, Soothed by the River
description: DOWNTOWN -- "I never want to see another TV for as long as I live," Holly Solomon was saying in her SoHo gallery on April 29. The usually put-together doyenne of avant-garde art dealers looked in need of some electronic Super Glue to pull herself together at the high-tech opening of Nam June Paik's exhibition.

title: Counting Travelers
description: The Census Bureau, which usually prefers that people stay put long enough for its head count, is switching its focus to Americans on the move.

title: IF THEY BUILT A MEMORIAL TO THE WAR IN THE STREETS
description: Odds Are Against You," by the photographers Carrie Mae Weems and Jeffrey Hoone, one of the seven proposals to honor the urban dead, spoke volumes to me ("If They Built a Memorial to the War in the Streets," April 9).

title: Rangers Nearly Paint A Playoff Masterpiece
description: They said they were angry, not dispirited. The Rangers understood exactly what needed to be done to limit the Quebec Nordiques in the first round of the Stanley Cup playoffs, especially here at le Colisee, where the home team has been defeated just once this year.

title: At Eagle Reunion, Every Story Still Has a Brooklyn Angle
description: Harold H. Harris knows how he would start the article: "After 40 years since the demise of the old Brooklyn Eagle, many former staffers assembled to renew acquaintances and to review how time had treated them."

title: The 3-Run Homer Is Back In Vogue
description: Once when the topic of conversation was team chemistry, Jim Frey said, "Give me a three-run home run and I'll show you good chemistry."

title: The World; Why Japan Hasn't Said That Word
description: CHIHIRO HOSOYA'S younger brother and childhood friends were killed in World War II, their remains left mingled with the dust of distant battlefields. Mr. Hosoya, 75, a history professor, says they were honorable young men who went to war to safeguard their homeland, not to invade their neighbors.

title:
NEW ENGLAND ISSUE;
Byways Of Western Massachusetts
description: THE most memorable moment, as every traveler knows, is the serendipitous one, the one no guidebook predicts. Recently I wandered western Massachusetts hoping for such moments, heading off the beaten path through less-traveled hills and valleys. The resulting tour winds for about 110 miles through several Massachusetts landscapes, including the northern Berkshires, the rolling, pastoral Apple Valley and the Holyoke Range, with its wide midstate vistas.

title: Off Into Cyberspace to a Universe of Artisans
description: CLICK-CLICK INTO THE everexpanding Internet, and you might see astronauts being interviewed on a space shuttle or the endangered temples of Ankhor Wat. Click again and, beginning tomorrow, you can enter the world of crafts, where you can see artisans in their studios potting vessels, forging metals, weaving baskets and blowing glass.

title: Why Does the Market Keep Going Up . . . When Economic Trends Are Pointing Down
description: AMERICA'S trade deficit is as big as the gross national product of Switzerland. Ten dollars hardly buys a cappuccino in Tokyo. And President Clinton is telling Newt Gingrich that the ballooning budget deficit is now a Republican problem. Yet the stock market just keeps flying upward, and bond prices have recovered smartly from last summer's doldrums. Go figure.

title: AT AGE OF 12, A LIFE BEGINS
description: I NO LONGER REMEMBER WHERE OR how I met the man I shall call Kuba. Probably, he lived in the same building in Cracow where, by some sort of miracle, my mother had found an apartment. We had arrived in 1945 from Kielce. The Russians had by then expelled the German Army from most of Poland. My father, swept up in the Russian retreat from Poland in 1941, was still missing. Kuba was a Jew: he said he was from Warsaw. He had not been in a concentration camp, and yet, unlike everyone else around us who had not been killed during the war in Poland, he had neither hidden in some cellar or walled-up room nor passed as a Catholic Pole using Aryan papers. To hear him, he had gone on just as before, floating mysteriously from cafe to cafe, doing a little business here and there, dabbling in underground resistance. I was 12, and had not yet read "Madame Bovary"; I knew nothing about men accustomed to handling thoroughbred horses and fallen women. Perhaps for that reason, I found Kuba incredibly charming; it did not surprise me that he had a charmed life.

title: Strawberry Works Out
description: DARRYL STRAWBERRY has been working out with the Palm Springs Suns for the last several days.

title:
OUT OF ORDER;
On the Cutting Edge, or Pretty Close to It
description: THE lawn-care season is well under way, and even the most reluctant husbands are forced to concede defeat. The owners of the local garage sight the coming of spring from the date when grumpy men start showing up with little gas cans muttering, "Darn grass growing again."

title:
VOICES: FROM THE DESK OF;
How to Pinch Pennies After a Life of Plenty
description: ONE recent spring day, after tossing my winter jacket into the washing machine, vacuuming the area rug and mopping my wood floors, I walked to the library to read Money magazine. While none of these activities may seem startling, for me, at 56, they were milestones.

title:
CUTTINGS;
Orchids: There's Nothing to Fear but Fear Itself
description: Orchids strike fear in the souls of the hardiest plant people. Yet their reputation as flamboyant but frail, the Camilles of cultivated flora, is unjust, argues Robert Wolaver, a collector who, with his wife, Michelle Carroll, owns an orchid nursery, Makai Farms, here on the north coast of Kauai. "If you establish the right environment," Mr. Wolaver said, "they are very tough plants."

title:
FILM;
Some Moviegoers Wonder: Will This Title Never End?
description: WHAT'S IN A TITLE, A movie title? Especially a long movie title? Michael Kelly, a student of the subject, believes that the right selection of words -- in the right order, with the right rhythm -- can be valuable in helping a film make a name for itself in the crowded cultural marketplace.

title: In a Cathedral of Print, Only the Date Differs
description: The Main Reading Room of the New York Public Library is an architectural masterpiece. Its hushed stillness is like that of a great cathedral. Dark bronze lamps with green shades grace rows of long wooden tables flanked by wide, comfortable armchairs, and red quarry tiles line the floor.

title: Sometimes, Having It All Means Feeling Left Out
description: The Assembly and Senate budget writers are back in town after a month of trying to stay awake, and they actually looked interested as they listened to ordinary voters during April's traditional field hearings on the budget. Now they have two months to write their $16 billion spending plan, and unlike their colleagues in Albany, they will not miss the deadline. But whatever the civics books teach about coequal branches and checks and balances, the decisions on this budget are not going to be made during staid speeches and committee hearings, but by a handful of heavy hitters presided over by the hitter with the heaviest bat of all -- Governor Whitman.

title:
FRUGAL TRAVELER;
A Monastic Retreat In New Hampshire
description: "IT'S on a hilltop -- a windy hilltop -- lots of sky, lots of clouds, -- often lots of sun and moon and stars. You come up here on a fine afternoon and you can see range on range of hills -- awful blue they are . . . ." This is how the Stage Manager in Thornton Wilder's "Our Town" sets the scene for the play's final act -- a cemetery in southern New Hampshire, somewhere near the fictional hamlet of Grover's Corners. But there is reason to believe that when he wrote the passage Wilder had a real place in mind, a graveyard surrounded by a mossy, tumbledown stone wall just beneath a stately old Greek Revival mansion that crowns a hill near Peterborough, N.H.

title: Something Is Rotten on the Island of Roosevelt
description: The Roosevelt Island community was conceived as an enclave apart from the rest of the city, an escape from crowds, crime, traffic, noise, litter, dirt and pollution. There has been one distressing hitch. Instead of enjoying refreshing river breezes, residents are often subjected to the pungent odor of raw sewage.

title: In Bridgeport, More Than a Touch of the 60's Revisited
description: THIS year at the Discovery Museum in Bridgeport has metamorphosed into the Year of the Connecticut Artist as well as the 30th anniversary of the Connecticut Commission on the Arts, grounds for further celebration. It takes the form of "Roots and Reality," a show that, given its cast of 16 black artists, has more than a touch of the 60's revisited.

title: Japanese Police Foil Gas Attack in Subway
description: The authorities said today that they had foiled another attempted poison gas attack on the Tokyo subway system, this one involving cyanide gas in one of the city's busiest subway stations.

title: Out of the Comfort Zone, On to New Adventures
description: TODAY IN ALICE TULLY Hall, Wynton Marsalis faces one of his toughest challenges yet. And for a while at least, the magnetic jazz and classical trumpeter won't even be allowed to pick up his horn. He'll have to sit in the audience with everybody else and face the music, as the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center presents the premiere of his new work for string quartet, "(At the) Octoroon Ball."

title: Lighten Up, Yorick! You're On!
description: ON a recent Saturday morning, the gymnasium at Old Greenwich Elementary School was alive with unaccustomed activity. Amid parallel bars, climbing ropes and floor mats, a group of men and women were rehearsing a theatrical production to be performed for several benefit audiences in the coming weeks.

title: Farewell To the Man Behind Kiehl's
description: One employee, Una Cassidy, recalled how he tap-danced in front of customers. Another, Danielle Zucker, remembered how he slapped his Blue Astringent on the face of most anyone who walked in the shop with a pimple.

title: Domestic Upheaval
description: THE DISTINGUISHED GUESTBy Sue Miller.282 pp. New York:HarperCollins Publishers. $24.

title: Sports of The Times; Lukas Improves His Average
description: THE gibes come with the territory. Wayne never saw a camera he didn't like. Wayne's got too many irons in the fire. Wayne's got an answer for everything.

title: For Families Of the Dead, A Pilgrimage To the Scene
description: Busloads of praying relatives and friends of those who perished in the Federal Building made a final pilgrimage to the site of the blast this afternoon.

title: The World; Vietnam Speaks English With an Eager Accent
description: QUOC KHOI carries the history of Vietnam on the tip of his tongue. As foreign powers have come and gone, Mr. Khoi, who is now in his 50's, has learned French, then Japanese, then English, then Russian. Vietnam is on its own now, and Mr. Khoi is again riding the linguistic wave of history: He is making his living teaching English.

title: Going to a Plant Sale? Plan Ahead
description: MAY, the month for planting, also happens to be the month for plant sales. Nurseries, garden centers, nature centers, garden clubs, specialty stores, plant societies and even the occasional supermarket -- all are in on the act.

title:
DINING OUT;
A Hideaway on the River in Peekskill
description: GETTING here is hardly half the fun. Between Route 9 or 9A and the river, chain link, barbed wire and hurricane fencing enclose stretches of industrial flotsam. But suddenly, around a bend in this wasteland, appears the grail -- Crystal Bay -- commanding one of the region's best river views.

title: City to Country: Vacation Time
description: UNTIL last summer, Lee Terrell had never seen a daddy longlegs. Until last summer, Eli Walkley never wore baggy shorts slung low on the hips or a baseball cap turned backward on his head.

title: Lease Is Over, but Scrapes Linger
description: MOST cars accumulate some battle scars -- parking lot dings, scratched bumpers and the like. If a vehicle is privately owned, such damage simply reduces its resale value. But with a leased car or truck, such seemingly normal "wear and tear" -- the description most leasing companies use for acceptable levels of damage -- often leads to disputes between the consumer and the lease company.

title: And Now, for 86th: Maybe Not a B.I.D., After All
description: For better and for worse, 86th Street has gone through major transformations as Yorkville's hub. In its heyday of middle European immigration, 86th flourished with Continental flair. But as that era faded, the street became populated by drug pushers, peddlers, prostitutes and panhandlers.

title: From Japan, Wall St. Looks Down Hill
description: THE American stock market rose to record highs last week -- at least if you measure it in dollars. But viewed from Tokyo, this market looks very different.

title: De La Hoya Scores Second-Round Knockout of Ruelas
description: They fought for the championship of the neighborhood and, two rounds later, Oscar De La Hoya was crowned bully. Hispanic Los Angeles had chosen sides -- white collar loved De La Hoya; blue collar loved Rafael Ruelas -- and that is why the people in tuxedos had grins this evening.

title: Tour Companies Add European Surcharges
description: Some tour companies have responded to the fall of the dollar against most European currencies in the last year by adding surcharges to the price of their European vacations.

title:
HOME CLINIC;
Gilding and Gold Leafing, 2 Ways to Restore the Luster of Yore
description: RESTORING the original metallic luster to a gilded picture frame requires some basic techniques of gilding and applying gold leaf. The terms gilding and gold leafing are often used interchangeably, but there is a difference. Gilding is covering a surface with a metallic finish like gold, silver or any metallic composition, even imitation gold paint. Gold leafing means covering a surface with thin sheets of genuine gold.

description: SUBURBAN GUERRILLASBy Joseph Freda.214 pp. New York:W. W. Norton & Company.

title:
CLASSICAL MUSIC;
A Woman's Work Well Done
description: NOT OFTEN DO musicological symposiums degenerate into name-calling and near-fisticuffs. Yet that happened at a Schubertiade seminar several seasons ago at the 92d Street Y in Manhattan, when Susan McClary analyzed the "Unfinished" Symphony in the light of Schubert's probable homosexuality. "Is it also relevant to Schubert's music that he was short and fat and wore spectacles?" an indignant audience member shouted.

title: CRIME

Perhaps no decision was better timed than his last: to sell Berger Associates, which runs the three Berger funds, to Kansas City Southern Industries one year ago.

title: Joie Piderit, C. P. Morrison

The Rev. John J. Piderit, the president of Loyola University in Chicago and a brother of the bride, performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the Fordham University Church in the Bronx.

description: THE Pepper'd Owl sounds like an endangered species, and it may well be. This new spot in Huntington is that rare bird, a restaurant with serious food, live music and no alcohol.

ART;
Photographs Alloyed and Unalloyed and Other New Creations

description: AFTER putting on two shows of tourist appeal, "Ain't Misbehavin' " and "I'm Not Rappaport" (both prize-winning hits), in its debut season last summer, Fleetwood Stage Company is upgrading to the classy, if not first class.

title: DOING BATTLE ON TWO FRONTS
description: BLACKS IN THE SECOND WORLD War battled two cruel enemies, Hitler and Jim Crow. As the war began, the armed services were nearly as segregated as the Deep South. Black troops in most military settings were forbidden to eat, watch a movie, get a haircut or ride a bus alongside whites. Even the blood supply was segregated, with plasma from black donors stored separately in containers labeled "A" for African.

title: Scenes From the Deep
description: After watching movies at one of those old theaters that have been converted from one screen to three, most people probably are prepared to watch movies on a submarine. But the new theater at the U.S.S. Bowfin Submarine Museum and Park in Pearl Harbor is not actually on the sub itself; it's in the museum building next to it. Each of the four 20-minute movies shown daily focuses on the exploits of a different World War II submarine, including the Bowfin, which sank 44 enemy ships in the Pacific after its launch in 1942.

title: High-Profile Prosecutor's Aggressiveness Puts His Future Under a Cloud
description: For an ambitious prosecutor, Somerset County, a suburb of freshly developed homes and high-tech office parks, seems to offer little material for glory. But a succession of high-profile cases and a relentless pursuit of drug dealers have made Nicholas L. Bissell Jr. perhaps the best-known County Prosecutor in New Jersey.

title:
SHATTERING GERMANY;
Through the Eyes of A Young German Soldier
description: MAJOR HISTORICAL DATES ARE not always personal red-letter days, not even when the historical event is a turning point in one's life. May 8, 1945, the day when the document ratifying Germany's surrender was signed in Berlin, is a perfectly shapeless day in my memory. I was in an American transit camp, in the midst of an enormous crowd of German prisoners who had all fled west from the collapsed Oder front to avoid falling into Soviet captivity. For five days we had been bivouacking under the open sky on a vast field surrounded by barbed wire. The military units had disintegrated in the chaos of the general flight, so there were hardly any familiar faces. We were hungry and covered with lice, and most of us were sick as a result of drinking undistilled water from the ditch that flowed through the camp, and because we had been lying on the bare ground day and night.

title: THE FIRST PRIMARY
description: John Connally raised $10 million and won just one delegate to the Republican National Convention. If Lamar Alexander raises $20 million, perhaps he will get two delegates, which, in the opinion of many native Tennesseans, including myself, will be two too many. H. N. CALLAHAN New York

title: There Isn't A Game That Can Beat Her

The student and athlete, then 13 years old, had been in New Orleans playing with a girls' all-star basketball team representing Connecticut. After a week of basketball against topnotch competition, she looked forward to a week of rest on the beach.

title: Susan B. Curbow, Edward M. Morris
description: Susan Bartley Curbow, a daughter of Gary and Judy Curbow of Newport News, Va., was married yesterday to Edward Matthew Morris, a son of John and Lucille Morris of Old Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. David Cliff officiated at the Duck United Methodist Church in Duck, N.C. The Rev. Stanley O'Konsky, a Roman Catholic priest, took part in the ceremony.

title: WHO PUT THE LID ON GP120?
description: In "Who Put the Lid on gp120?" (March 26), Jesse Green focused on the preventive potential of the vaccine, but it is important to note that there were trial sites in which the treatment potential of gp120 was being tested, as well.

title: The Day the Emperor Spoke in a Human Voice
description: OUR SETTLEMENT WAS IN A VALLEY SURROUNDED BY a dense forest. A short distance up the river that traversed the valley was a V-shaped hollow wedged between boulders and a bamboo grove -- my private inlet. The water that pooled there from the river was lukewarm, and a layer of clay covered the rocks on both sides and even the sand at the bottom. Taking off my clothes, I would lie back in the inlet and pass the time gazing up at the forest and the sky. It was my habit to trace, in the narrowed oblong of sky that I could see above the deep green of the hillside, a gigantic woman with a little man standing close by her side -- Oshikome and Meisuke. Oshikome's black hair was loose down her back, and her robe reached to her ankles. Meisuke wore a topknot and carried a sword at his side and a musket on his arm. Oshikome was the matriarch of the pioneers who had cleared a village in this forest. Meisuke was a trickster full of amusing schemes to keep the village from under the thumb of the feudal lords of the region and the authority of the imperial system. And he had succeeded, at least until the beginning of modernization.

In the Region/New Jersey;
The Industrial Market Perks Up in Morris County
description: A 70-ACRE industrial and office park opened here in the late 80's, but when the recession set in development work ceased. Now it is about to resume.

description: The conditions on New York City's streets vary widely between rich and poor neighborhoods, with less affluent residents far more likely to endure cracked sidewalks, missing road signs and rubbly vacant lots, according to a survey released by the Public Advocate's office yesterday.

description: FIFTH AVENUE-style shopping in the Essex County suburbs did not begin with the Mall at Short Hills.

NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: WAKEFIELD;
Back on Graffiti Track at Board 12
description: For several years, vandals have used the exterior walls of 4104 White Plains Road, which houses the offices of Community Board 12, as a graffiti gallery. They scrawl their personal "tags" and street slogans on the 92-year-old red bricks.

description: Visa or Plus cardholders can find information on the Internet about accessible automatic teller machines throughout the world.

description: Charity may indeed begin at home, but these days it may also be found bicycling, walking, hopping or marching down the street.

description: Airplane manufacturers often conclude that their planes could recover from a given mechanical failure in flight because their design engineers assume pilots would take corrective actions. But those actions may, in fact, be unreasonable or impractical, according to a team that reviewed the design of the Boeing 737 after two unexplained crashes.

description: Call him a dreamer, but Carl Wolf envisions a day when Americans will find rich foods downright unappealing.

description: AFTER THE FACTTwo Countries, Four Decades,One Anthropologist.By Clifford Geertz.198 pp. Cambridge, Mass.:Harvard University Press.

title: From Trend Spotting to Juggling Job and Family
description: IF you're going to be a lapdog, find a powerful lap. The pop futurologists Alvin and Heidi Toffler hooked up with Newt Gingrich way back when -- when, that is, he was just another anonymous backbencher with an ideology and a dream and they were author/trend spotters who periodically went into eclipse. One sign that the Tofflers' moon is full again: their treatise on life as it could be in the 21st century, "Creating a New Civilization" (Turner Publishing, $7.95), came out of nowhere to hit the paperback best-seller list at No. 3. Someone out there is watching.

title: The War and the Law
description: WHEN IT started, I was standing on a ticket line, behind my mother, in the giant rib cage that was Leipzig's main railroad station. Suddenly, from a hundred speakers atop the station's girders, Adolf Hitler was screaming blood and thunder: Germany is on the march! It must avenge this dastardly attack! -- by Poland's pathetic infantry. Although that speech made me an "enemy alien," in a place where being Jewish was bad enough, I don't remember much else about Sept. 1, 1939, except the satisfaction my mother took whenever in later years she recalled the mumbled comment of the stunned German man in line behind us. "I knew when I saw the synagogues burn," he said, "I knew then that we would some day pay for it."

title: FOR AMERICA, IT TRULY WAS A GREAT WAR
description: AMERICA WAS BOOMING. America was at war. Men and women were working again. Men and women were dying. There were dreams of a new world order. There were fears of a new Depression. For Americans, more than for any other combatants, World War II was a paradoxical experience -- simultaneously horrifying and exhilarating. For all the fervor with which Americans committed themselves to a great national cause, they were terrified at the possibility of losing the struggle -- a possibility that seemed particularly real in that first difficult year after Pearl Harbor -- and of having to live in a world dominated by tyranny. Even as the war neared its end and victory seemed assured, optimism mingled with doubt; and several very different ideas about the nation, the world and the future seized the American imagination. Fifty years later, many of those ideas seem relics of a more innocent time. But perhaps for that very reason, they resonate still in the stories World War II veterans tell about themselves, and in the imaginations of their children and grandchildren.

title:
SHATTERING GERMANY;
The Yiddish Lesson
description: ON APRIL 13, 1945, I WAS SITTING IN an abandoned German Panther tank in the Harz Mountains of Germany with Capt. Max Zera, late of the Bronx and now a fellow-sufferer in the First U. S. Infantry Division. We had hopped into the Panther to take shelter from a German artillery sweep. Max turned on the tank's radio to see if it still worked -- pointlessly, I thought, since neither of us could speak German (although Max could speak Yiddish, which is fairly close). Suddenly, a voice -- not German but plummy B.B.C. -- could be heard: "We must bring you the melancholy news that President Franklin D. Roosevelt died in Warm Springs, Ga., yesterday afternoon."

title: April 30 - May 6: Boat People; U.S. Cuts a Deal With Castro Over Refugees

While they applauded the agreement for admitting to the United States 21,000 Cubans who have been held at the Guantanamo Bay Naval Station since being intercepted at sea, they were outraged that the United States had agreed to return future boat people to Cuba.

title: Royals Call Up Coleman

title: When Implication Matters More Than Plot
description: THE winding down of the theater season, inevitably, bears updates, substitutions and, fittingly, the last of four directors' thesis productions at the Yale School of Drama. Such student-staged productions are the surest sign of theater in the act of perpetuation.

title: Neatness Counts, and They're Out to Prove It
description: JULIE MORGENSTERN spends her days listening to the dark secrets of business people. "I can't think straight," they tell her. "I panic when someone calls and needs information," they confess. "I work incredibly long hours and accomplish nothing," they complain.

title: Wheeling Down the Ski Slopes
description: I HAVE ridden the chairlift to the top of Killington Peak many times in winter, but last July I discovered the ski trails looked much steeper from 4,200 feet without their cushioning mantle of snow. The Green Mountains, liberated from winter monotones, undulated northward toward the Canadian border in a luxuriant carpet of forest. Fleecy clouds muted the sun's warmth and thunderheads were building up on the horizon. I picked my route through the fall line and started down the trail, but cautiously, checking my descent not with the metal edges of my fiberglass skis but with the hand brakes on my mountain bicycle.

title: When the Sea Calls
description: AMONG the tugs and feverish yearnings that seem to beset me this time of year -- the restlessness and desire to shed winter skin, to inhale only green warmth and fresh air -- is the urge to go seaward. It comes sometime in May, after the bloom of violets and foamflowers and before Memorial Day, usually at the first hint of real heat. It's a powerful craving for radiant sea light and the good crunch of sand, for the cries of seagulls and sanderlings, and most of all, for the smells of the sea: the salty, wind-fresh mornings, the sweet, mossy scent of seaweed drying on the coastline after a storm, the tarry odor of weathered timbers and driftwood fires, the faint notes of fishiness.

Under his revolutionary theory of selective compliance, either we all can evade the obligations of legislation we didn't vote to support (in which case I expect Carter to help defend me if I refuse to pay the tax increases imposed by Congresses controlled by Democrats) or we must all go along with the obligations imposed by indirect representation, in which case his entire article collapses under the weight of its own sophistry.

title: Florentine Walls
description: To the Editor: In Avis Berman's article, "The Walls of Florence" (March 19), I am surprised that she neglected to mention, in the Church of Santa Maria Novella, the frescoes by Ghirlandaio in the choir and high altar. On the left wall are seven scenes of the life of the Virgin; on the right wall, seven scenes from the life of St. John the Baptist commissioned by the Tournabuoni family, with the donors prominently featured in the frescoes. They have been restored over a period of years and their colors glow. NANCY C. WELLS Upper Montclair, N.J. Avis Berman responds: I did intend to write about the Ghirlandaio frescoes, but when I got there the poor viewing conditions made me decide against recommending them as a focus. The middle and lower sections of the murals are obstructed by the high altar and tourists are not permitted behind it for a closer look.

title: UNTOLD WAR STORIES
description: FOR JUST ABOUT THE FIRST TIME SINCE 1815, NO great powers are at one another's throats. Civil wars and snarling ethnic savageries continue on both sides of the Equator; even so, most of the world is at peace. That's a monumental change since World War II gripped millions in its jaws. Even after half a century, the teeth marks remain in red lines on maps, in blue numbers on forearms, in endless rows of white grave markers. About 400,000 Americans died in action, nearly as many as died in the Civil War on both sides. Worldwide, between 1939 and 1945 more than 30 million died, 20 million or more of them Russian. World War II was the fulcrum of our time.

title: An Actress First And Then a Dancer
description: NO OTHER MOVIE STAR'S name carries the resonance of that of Ginger Rogers, who died at age 83 on April 25. It's not just the magnitude of her stardom. Or that she's our best-known female dancer ever -- the New World Lady to Fred Astaire's Gentleman, or that she's the singer who introduced some of Ira Gershwin's, Jerome Kern's and Irving Berlin's most wistful ballads. It's that 50 years ago, this young woman of the svelte walk, the quiet looks, the quick retorts, the (usually) blond pageboy, somehow turned into a personification of America itself. In World War II, soldiers used her name as a password; pilots wrote it on their planes; a tank in Burma proudly carried a life-size cutout of her on its front.

They just looked at him as he passed by, trying to quietly absorb his presence with their gaze in the jaded way that New Yorkers respond to fame.
