title: DIARY
description: THE ECONOMY Jobless Rate Heads Upward . . . So is it over? Did the Federal Reserve manage, all too well, to yank the economy to a crawl? It may seem so on the news that April unemployment jumped 0.3 points, to 5.8 percent, and payrolls fell for the first time in more than two years. But no, analysts said, the expansion is still alive -- but humbled. "This is not a recession," said the head of the National Association of Manufacturers. And Labor Secretary Reich saw "no evidence that the economy's going into reverse." The bond market like it just fine, as long-term interest rates headed down close to 7 percentCHECKKKKKKK, the lowest level in a year. . . . but Layoffs Slow Down But look at it another way. The truly wrenching part of the job picture in recent years has been the mass layoffs, which, properly placed, can devastate whole neighborhoods or towns. But according to the latest employment report from the outplacement firm Challenger, Gray & Christmas, fewer layoffs were announced in April than in any month since May 1993. In fact, for 1995's first four months, the report said, layoffs were down by nearly half from last year. So even though unemployment is up, "wholesale cuts are slowing," said John Challenger, the firm's executive vice president. And "layoff figures are more indicative of how companies are looking at workforce reduction." LIABILITY Bankruptcy Over Implants? The breast-implant mess keeps taking a toll -- and not just on the true victims, the women involved. Last week Dow Corning, facing 20,000 lawsuits, said it might have to file for bankruptcy protection, which would put a halt to all the litigation. Not that it would be broke. The company is owned by Dow Chemical and Corning, and also last week came news that Marion Merrell Dow -- 71 percent owned by Dow Chemical -- would be bought by Hoechst of Germany. What that means in the industry is yet another huge merger, this one creating the world's No. 2 drug maker, right after Glaxo Wellcome. And what it means for Dow Chemical is $5.1 billion (out of a total purchase price of $7.1 billion) to help it with implant settlements. TELEVISION Danger! Ad Rates on the Loose! Wait a second. Hasn't everyone in the universe already seen "Jurassic Park" 11 times? Well, NBC clearly hopes they'll make it an even dozen, for it paid $50 million for the rights to broadcast it, the first showing being tonight. And advertisers are paying $650,000 for 30-second spots -- an otherworldly figure that puts the event (that's the way NBC wants you to think of it, as an "event," not a mere "movie") up there with such pivotal moments in world history as this year's Academy Awards or the "Cheers" finale in 1993. (Of course, it's still well behind recent Super Bowl ad rates, which are too absurd to mention.) Among the advertisers, of course, is the Ford Explorer -- which, you'll recall, got rather unkind treatment from Mr. Rex. AUTOS It's Drizzling in Detroit Well, Chrysler has been saying -- to fend off pesky takeover offers -- that it needed its $7.5 billion nest egg in case rainy days returned, and it may be right. Last week auto makers said sales were slipping badly -- off 6.1 percent in April, the fourth straight monthly drop. (One exception: Ford keeps selling light trucks; they rose 16 percent.) What's up? For one thing, even as interest rates ease, car-loan rates stay stubbornly high -- not to mention car prices. Maybe it's just part of a slowing economy. And maybe, with so many good used cars around -- thanks in part to leasing -- buyers don't care so much about shiny and new. But whatever the reason, watch for more rebates and good deals. BLAME GAME A Team Effort at Barings Nicholas Leeson is still in a Frankfurt jail, taking most of the heat for the collapse of Barings two months ago. But the new owner of what's left of Barings -- the Dutch company ING -- decided last week that it was unlikely that Mr. Leeson was the lone gunman, the supervillain of the piece. Without ladling out fixed doses of guilt, ING ousted 21 top Barings executives, saying they had "functional responsibility" for the mess at the Singapore outpost. The clear message: Even if those executives didn't know the disastrously risky road Mr. Leeson was taking, they should have known. BANKING Tellers With a Difference Yes, First Chicago had any number of sound, sober reasons for that $3 teller fee. And who knows -- maybe it is the best way to keep banking costs low for the low of balance. But let's face it: walking freely up to a teller (after waiting in line, of course) is right up there with sunshine and tulips -- it seems almost a constitutional right. Tinker with tulips and you make yourself an awfully easy target for all manner of reactions, from indignant to teasing. And sure enough, some Chicago-area banks had a field day, as Lake Forest Bank gave $3 to customers after their transactions were finished, and a Harris branch handed out dollar bills to customers who asked whether it charged fees. What did Richard Thomas, First Chicago's chairman, think of all this? "A little silly," he said. NEWSPAPERS NEWS TO 42D ST.: SO LONG In 1930, The Daily News built an Art Deco temple for itself on -- where else? -- 42d Street, the center of the known universe. The building so resonated with nostalgic newspaperdom that it was used as a set in the "Superman" movies. But like the world, The News has changed. In 1947, its daily circulation was 2.4 million; today, the paper's bruises still healing from labor battles, it's scarcely a third of that. The payroll has plunged from 9,000 to a little over 1,000. The presses left the 42d Street building more than a decade ago. And last week The News made its biggest symbolic break with its past, leaving that home behind and moving to a single floor across town -- one with the high-tech bells and whistles deemed necessary for a modern paper. PUBLISHING Today's News (Net Wt., 12 Oz.) And here's another sign of changing journalistic times: when Times Mirror named a new chief executive last week, it wasn't someone from the ranks but Mark Willes, a General Mills vice chairman with no media experience. His message: "Start from the consumer," strive to be "the low-cost producer," "refresh" products just as food companies tinker with cereals and cake mixes. Yes, many newspapers are hurting -- Times Mirror's two big papers, The Los Angeles Times and Newsday, reported big circulation drops last week. But what's coming? Banner headlines saying "Light and Fluffy" or "Only 17 Calories"? BROADCASTING The Murdoch Exemption Some matters, it seems, transcend the laws of the land -- matters like Rupert Murdoch's ownership of American TV stations. Yes, the F.C.C. said last week, Mr. Murdoch and his News Corp. had violated foreign-ownership laws -- but the agency said it had no intention of doing anything about it. No fines, no drastic cutbacks in his ownership stake. Why? As one commissioner, James Quello, put it, the "compelling public interest" lay in the creation of a fourth network to promote competition. As for Mr. Murdoch, he rejoiced that the "meritless, wild and malicious charges of some of our competitors" had been rejected. But of course the ownership issue was clearly not meritless -- just rejected.

There will be games within games -- Reggie Miller versus John Starks, Patrick Ewing versus Rik Smits, Mark Jackson returning home to face the team that traded him away.

title: Anarchist Picnic: Pig and Pot (Dress: Casual)
description: It was 4 P.M. on a cool, overcast day. A multiethnic, multiracial cluster of 25 New Yorkers sat on stone pilings in La Plaza Cultural, a lot on the corner of Ninth Street and Avenue C. Their clothes were tattered and grimy. Most were squatters or homeless; they looked anywhere from 20 to 50 years old. Their long hair was straight and greasy, or multicolored, spiked or in dandruff-flecked dreadlocks. Some sported nose, lip and eyebrow rings.

title: Too Much, Too Soon? After Scandals, Rockland County Reflects on Change
description: In the close-knit village atmosphere that still prevails in much of Rockland County, people aren't sure what to make of the downfall of District Attorney Kenneth Gribetz and scandals that preceded it, involving the local utility company and the community college. Do they reflect something about Rockland itself and its rapid transformation from rural enclave to New York City suburb? Or is it more a question of the particular people involved?

On the cold, desolate coast of Newfoundland in 1911, several characters act out a passion play: a young man named Fabian, who sketches birds for a living, murders his mother's lover. "What 'The Bird Artist' undertakes is redemption by art, and it succeeds," Louis B. Jones said here last year.

Kmart has received certification to begin the city's uniform land-use review process; it has not been given a permit to build.

description: LISTEN TO THE STORIES Nat Hentoff on Jazz and Country Music.By Nat Hentoff.HarperCollins, $23.

title:
MUSIC;
Making Music in the Ivory Tower
description: THE corridors of the Institute for Advanced Study here are quiet, because busy brains don't make any sound, even when they're all working at once. In its offices, which look out on blossoms and new grass, are historians, mathematicians, physicists -- and a lone musician, Robert Taub. On a fine spring day, he sat struggling for a polite answer to "How'd you get this gig?"

description: Nancy Ellen Hegy, a daughter of Eugene A. Hegy of New York and the late Marcella A. Hegy, was married yesterday to Jefferson Keith Martin, a son of R. Keith and Carolyn Martin of Bronxville, N.Y. The Rev. Thomas K. Tewell performed the ceremony at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church in New York.

The Rev. Vincent DeCola, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Fordham University Church in the Bronx.

description: PETER MILLER is an American artist living in Kamakura, Japan. Akiko Shirai is a Japanese artist living in Manhattan. Both of them use their art as a way to interpret their adopted homelands.

description: To the Editor:

description: RECURRING rumors of the Mafia's decline have typically turned out to be greatly exaggerated.

title:
San Antonio Journal;
Folks Seeking the Southwest's Soul Discover It's a Bargain at a Quiet Cafe
description: Much has changed here since 1978. Political correctness has raised sparks at the Alamo, as historical revisionists have revisited the famous last stand. Republicans have thrice won the Texas governorship. The Mexican peso has crashed to beyond absurdity. The city's favorite son, Henry Cisneros, has seen his political fortunes rise, fall, rise and fall again.

title: When the Radio Was New, And Voices Took to the Air
description: IN the early 1920's, when radio was new, one of the first to glimpse its possibilities was A. C. Gilbert of New Haven, inventor (of the Erector set, among other things) and manufacturer. He stayed in the radio field for only a few years; it would present patent battles, and he had other operations to tend to. But during those years he put New Haven on the air, put equipment into eager hands and put radio sets into living-room decor.

title: Pressure Builds On H.O.V. Rules
description: LESS than forecast use of the high-occupancy-vehicle lane on the Long Island Expressway is creating pressure to expand the hours to open the fourth lane to all motorists.

title: KEEP THE HOME FRIES BURNING
description: My father, who was raised on a Nebraska dairy farm, spent part of the Second World War in a body cast thinking about cottage cheese.

title:
RESTAURANTS;
New World French
description: I CAN only imagine the joy of the first reviewer who stumbled upon Chez Madeleine. She (or he) must have been dazzled not only by the veal, but also by the charm of the room, which is so Old World Gallic it's almost tacky, as some of the best neighborhood restaurants in Paris are. Here are mirrors, fake brick and more accordion music than you've heard since the days of Charles de Gaulle.

Tickets, $50, from (212) 260-8660. Kennedy Jr. and Noel Hord, the president of the Footwear Group of the United States Shoe Corporation, at a reception from 6 to 9 P.M. on the east balcony of Grand Central Terminal. Cocktails, hors d'oeuvres and a silent auction will be included. Tickets, $100, from (914) 279-2995, extension 203. Remembering Fulbright MONDAY -- Metro International, which administers the Fulbright Visiting Scholar Enrichment program in the New York City area, will benefit from a dinner that begins with drinks at 6:15 P.M. in the Delegates Dining Room of the United Nations. Cocktails at 7 P.M. will be followed by dinner and dancing to the Michael Carney Orchestra. Tickets, $1,000, from (203) 328-4319. A reception will begin at 6 P.M. at Tavern on the Green, followed by music and a light supper. Tickets, $85, at the door. Information: (212) 241-5461. Katharine Graham, the former publisher of The Washington Post, and former Gov. Mario M. Cuomo will be among the honorees. Cocktails at 6:30 will be followed by dinner at 7:30 and music. Tickets, $500, from (212) 410-1111. Evening of Theater TUESDAY -- The American Federation of Arts will hold a theater evening. A cocktail reception and dinner will begin at 5:45 at "21," followed by a performance of "Indiscretions" at 8 at the Ethel Barrymore Theater. Tickets, $300, from (212) 988-7700, extension 36. Benefit for Child Development TUESDAY -- A black-tie dinner-dance at the Plaza will benefit the Northside Center for Child Development, which provides clinical services to families in Harlem. J. Bruce Llewellyn, the chairman of the Coca-Cola Bottling Company in Philadelphia, and Ron Delsener, the music promoter, will be honored. Drinks at 7 P.M. Tickets, $375, from (212) 245-6570. title: Remember to Water, but Not Too Much
description: Some places have been dry this spring, so don't forget to keep an eye on newly planted seeds, to insure germination. Mulch seedlings and transplants lightly, if the soil is dry, to slow down evaporation. If it doesn't rain, water the vegetable garden about one and a half inches a week. The lawn needs only an inch a week. If you have a sprinkler, set old coffee cans around the garden or lawn and see how long it takes an inch to accumulate. That will be your guide for how long to water. And remember, water is a precious resource. Don't let those automatic sprinklers run if there is plenty of rain.

title: GREEN DAYS

Here, I believe, she underestimates the staying power of a good thing. Gardening is more akin to a religion than to the latest craze. LOUISE HANDELMAN Princeton, N.J.

title: HAS POETRY GONE TO THE DOGS?
description: Those wishing to bone up on dogs in print should not overlook the work of Silverdene Emblem, Eugene O'Neill's Dalmatian, whose 1956 swan song, "The Last Will and Testament of an Extremely Distinguished Dog," is a case of a pooch coming to resemble its master, at least in terms of literary style: "I become too sick a burden on myself and on those who love me. It will be sorrow to leave them, but not a sorrow to die. Dogs do not fear death as men do." STAN FRIEDMAN Edison, N.J.

title: THE SHIP AHEAD JUST DISAPPEARED
description: SOME BELIEVE IT WAS THE MOST critical engagement between surface ships in World War II. At the time, we called it the Third Battle of Savo Island, but it came to be known as the Naval Battle of Guadalcanal. One of its participants, our destroyer the Fletcher, was the first of its kind, equipped with a new radar that displayed target positions on a screen. As the ship's communications officer, I was technically in charge of the radar but knew almost nothing about it. That night it was our lifesaver.

title: In Allendale's Mural, Portrait of a Spirit of Cooperation
description: If you plunked the fictional town of Mayberry down in the middle of Bergen County, you might end up with Allendale. It's a tiny town -- 6,300 residents live on 2.8 square miles -- with a giant sense of community. Nothing embodies that spirit better than a giant mural that townspeople painted last year to celebrate Allendale's centennial. The project was the brainchild of Stiles Thomas, a 71-year-old retired insurance salesman who has lived his entire life in Allendale because, he said, "I feel out of place anywhere else."

title: Tall Tales
description: What the Bayeux Tapestry is to the Norman Conquest, Sam Chamberlain's watercolor paintings are to the Mexican War. Chamberlain (1829-1908) was by turns a Boston choirboy, a Texas roughneck, a United States cavalryman, a scalp hunter, a Civil War general, a curio-collecting gentleman of leisure and a Massachusetts prison warden. The paintings in SAM CHAMBERLAIN'S MEXICAN WAR: The San Jacinto Museum of History Paintings (San Jacinto Museum of History/Texas State Historical Association, $49.95) -- some of which illustrated Chamberlain's picaresque memoir, "My Confession: The Recollections of a Rogue" -- record his adventures in frontier Texas and Mexico. Chamberlain portrayed himself as a dime-novel hero -- storming adobe fortresses, dueling with saber and bowie knife and rescuing no fewer than six different maidens in distress. His art reflected what he had seen of the Mexican War: herds of mustangs, shrouded in dust, are mistaken for hostile cavalry; red-shirted Mississippi riflemen turn back a charge by Mexican lancers; in a nightmare cavern, Arkansas soldiers shoot down terrified villagers; guerrillas ambush supply trains and trade shots with dispatch riders. William H. Goetzmann, who teaches history at the University of Texas, Austin, ably sets the historical context, sorting out the truths in Chamberlain's tall tales. Boastful, cynical, sardonic and celebratory, these paintings are the triumph of a rough-edged American master. ALLEN BOYER

title: The Redtails: Fleet of Fin, And Proud

title: RESULTS PLUS

In her first pro final, Hingis will face Conchita Martinez, the Wimbledon champion who is ranked fourth. Martinez routed Magdalena Maleeva, 6-0, 6-0. (AP) AGASSI AND CHANG ADVANCE: Andre Agassi, ranked No. 1 in the world, and the defending champion, Michael Chang, won yesterday and advanced to the final of the $328,000 AT&T Challenge in Duluth, Ga. Agassi beat the third-seeded Magnus Larsson, 6-4, 6-4, after the second-seeded Chang defeated No. 4 Todd Martin, 6-3, 6-0. (AP) GOLF Davies Keeps the Lead Laura Davies shot a 3-under-par 69 yesterday for a two-day total of 11-under 133 in the second round of the $525,000 Sara Lee Classic in Nashville. That kept her one stroke ahead of the record-setting Michelle McGann, who was at 134 after a 65. That came a day after Davies's 64, which was a stroke off the course record.(AP) MURPHY IN FRONT: Bob Murphy took the lead at the PaineWebber Invitational in Charlotte, N.C., with a six-under-par 66 that gave him a two-round total of 10-under-par 134. The senior golfer closed the round with an eagle-birdie-birdie. (AP) WOMEN'S RUGBY Princeton Goes to Final Princeton, playing at home, trounced the defending champion, Air Force, by 29-5 yesterday in the semifinals of the women's collegiate rugby championships. In today's final, Princeton will face Penn State, which shut out Stanford, 17-0. VOLLEYBALL U.C.L.A Wins Title Top-ranked U.C.L.A. won its 15th National Collegiate Athletic Association Division I men's volleyball championship yesterday, scoring a 3-0 victory over the defending champion, Penn State, in Springfield, Mass. The Bruins defeated Penn State by 15-3, 15-10, 15-10 for their 19th consecutive win to complete a 31-1 season. COLLEGE TRACK AND FIELD A Javelin Champion Jen Pastore, a Villanova freshman, and Najuma Fletcher, a Pitt junior, set meet records in the Big East track and field championships at Villanova's Jumbo Elliott Track. Pastore won the javelin with 167 feet 1 inch, a personal best by four feet. Fletcher, leading Pitt's attempt to win its second straight women's team title, won the triple jump and qualified for both the 100-meter and 400-meter hurdles finals. HIGH SCHOOLS Record in Triple Jump Two athletes from A. P. Randolph in Manhattan, Michelle Hickman and Monique Coleman, turned in impressive victories yesterday in the 26th annual St. Anthony's Invitational Meet in South Huntington, L.I. Hickman set a meet record with a triple jump of 38 feet 5 1/2 inches, and Coleman took the 200-meter dash in 25.49 seconds.

title: Mass Transit Spending

A similar equation is at work regarding mass transit. New York City subways and buses serviced about 81 percent of the state's mass transit riders in 1993 but received 67 percent of its transit aid. Gov. George E. Pataki's current budget proposal would cut the city's subsidy from the state's dedicated mass transit fund by $86 million, while giving slight increases to Metro North, the Long Island Rail Road and upstate transit authorities. Last year, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani reduced city aid to the subways and buses by $128 million. To avoid a fare increase, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority has approved the first widespread bus and subway service cuts in 20 years.

"My dear, you have the guts of a bank robber," he told her. Ms. MacLaine, in a recent interview at the Peninsula Hotel, put it a little differently. "I didn't know what he meant," she said. "I didn't know enough to be scared."

description: The Senate Budget Committee took the first tentative step today in the long march toward enacting the first Republican budget in history, with one senator after another staking out a political position for the days of debate that lie ahead.

title: SONAT OFFSHORE IN NEW TALKS WITH READING & BATES
description: Sonat Offshore Drilling Inc. said yesterday that it had had more talks with the Reading & Bates Corporation about the possibility of combining operations after two failed bids to buy the oil service company. Reading & Bates last month rejected a revised $520 million tender offer for its shares. Sonat Offshore's second bid was for $8.40 a share, and the original offer, made in February, was $7.50 a share. Reading & Bates has aimed to become a leader in putting together floating production systems that allow oil companies to extract oil from prospects more than 1,000 feet deep.

title: Max McCarthy, 67, Buffalo Lawmaker
description: Richard Dean McCarthy, a former Democratic Congressman from Buffalo, died last Friday at his home in Arlington, Va. He was 67.

title: Mason Wins 6th Man Award
description: It will not erase the sting of Sunday's loss to Indiana, but the Knicks' Anthony Mason received a coveted personal honor yesterday when he was named winner of the National Basketball Association Sixth Man Award.

title: Court Appoints New Lawyer For Oklahoma City Suspect
description: A new lawyer was appointed today for Timothy J. McVeigh, the only suspect charged in the bombing of the Federal Building here, ending a protracted search to find someone willing to take on such a client.

title: NGC TO BUY KERR-MCGEE OKLAHOMA PIPELINE OPERATIONS
description: The NGC Corporation, an energy products and services company, said yesterday that it would acquire the Kerr-McGee Corporation's oil pipeline and related trucking assets in Oklahoma. Terms were not disclosed. NGC said the 1,300-mile pipeline system served the Wynnewood, Okla., refinery. NGC said it intended to operate the pipeline through its NGC Oil Trading and Transportation Inc. unit.

title: Dr. Kevorkian Assists at His 22d Suicide
description: Dr. Jack Kevorkian stood by today as a terminally ill man killed himself, exactly two weeks after the Supreme Court refused to consider the doctor's appeal of a Michigan court's ruling that assisted suicide is a crime. It was the 22d time Dr. Kevorkian has assisted in a suicide.

title: Rabin Visits Family Of Slain American
description: Yitzhak Rabin, the Israeli Prime Minister, went to New Jersey last night to pay a sympathy call to the family of Alisa M. Flatow, the college student who died in a terrorist attack in the Gaza Strip last month.

description: Gathering in the vibrant capital that has risen from the ruins of the city where Hitler planned his war of aggression, leaders of France, Britain, Russia, the United States and Germany pledged today to prevent a repetition of the European cataclysm that ended on this date 50 years ago.

description: "Sunset Boulevard" was the strongest entry in a scrawny musical field at the Tony Award nominations yesterday, landing 11, 2 of them unopposed.

title: Man Is Sentenced to Life For Murder in a Carjacking

title: Stakes at Auctions Rise Again: A Collection Brings $65 Million
description: An intense week of four consecutive evening sales of Impressionist and modern art got off to a dazzling start last night at Sotheby's, where a Picasso portrait of the artist Angel Fernandez de Soto (1903) brought a staggering $29.1 million, the highest price paid for a painting since the art market took a nose dive in 1990. Another stunning price, $18.85 million, was paid for a Matisse, setting a record for the artist.

In this competition, which is the first of a new "Super Classic" series organized by the association, Kasparov scored a convincing 7 1/2-2 1/2.

description: A joint venture involving the Keppel Corporation of Singapore, Singapore Press Holdings Ltd., Cable and Wireless P.L.C. of Britain and Hong Kong Telecommunications Ltd. will be the first competitor to Singapore Telecommunications Ltd. in Singapore's mobile phone market. The Telecommunications Authority of Singapore said it chose the venture, called Mobile One (Asia) Pte. Ltd., from among five contenders for the 20-year license. Singapore Telecom's monopoly rights to mobile phone and paging services expire April 1, 1997. The new licensee will have to introduce its services on that date.

title: Offer Russia A Peace of Vienna
description: America's relations with Russia have veered off the promising path set by Presidents Ronald Reagan and Mikhail Gorbachev as they ended the cold war. The United States, alarmed by the violence in Chechnya, is eying its former adversary warily. Russia is equally alarmed by the threat of NATO's expansion to its borders. President Clinton can begin to move this critical relationship back on course when he meets with President Boris Yeltsin today.

title: Prices of Treasury Securities Are Down in Thin Trading
description: Prices of Treasury securities were down yesterday, fluctuating slightly in thin trading, as traders awaited a new supply of bills and notes and new data on inflation.

description: NBC's Bill Walton must be acquainted with a second John Starks, a consistent John Starks, a reliable John Starks, a court-savvy John Starks.

And today Mayor Bill Bredesen and Nashville City Council officials announced the formation of a sports authority to look into the possibility of attracting a National Hockey League franchise to their city.

title: NATO, Then and Now
description: After the dissolution of the Warsaw Pact and the disintegration of the Soviet Union, the need for NATO is less than clear. But instead of reconsidering an alliance created in 1949 to counter a threat now virtually vanished, Washington has made NATO expansion the centerpiece of its European policy. That is a mistake that promises not only to cramp relations with Russia, but also to perpetuate an archaic approach to Europe as a whole.

description: PETER D. BELL, the chairman of CARE, the relief agency, since 1990, was elected its president and chief executive at a meeting of the board in Washington on Sunday.

description: In an unusual twist that could damage the Government's campaign against the Colombo crime family, Federal prosecutors in Brooklyn said yesterday that an F.B.I. agent had for years disclosed confidential information to a high-ranking member of that Mafia group.

title: The Stage as a Meadow And Other Tricks of Art
description: Literalists may insist that it doesn't matter where anyone thinks the dancers are gathered in Jerome Robbins's "Dances at a Gathering." This choreographic suite, they'd claim, simply echoes the moods of its accompanying piano music by Chopin. But what hard hearts those literalists must have. Mr. Robbins's choreography is so playful and tender that it is easy to imagine that the 10 members of the cast have assembled at a picnic or family reunion.

title: Empathy Unfolds Slowly in a Child
description: THE human capacity for empathy may be deep, but, as history makes clear, it is neither bottomless nor guaranteed. Researchers who study empathy in children have tracked the stages of its leisurely unfolding, and they have learned which sorts of conditions are likely to yield a graceful, compassionate person, and which a self-pitying or indifferent or hostile individual.

title: Ernest H. Martin Dies at 75; Half of Broadway Producing Team
description: Ernest H. Martin, who with his partner Cy Feuer produced Frank Loesser's "Guys and Dolls" and "How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying" as well as other long-running Broadway musicals, died on Sunday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 75.

description: To the Editor:

title: Lead-Based Battery Used in Electric Car May Pose Hazards
description: For years, electric cars and vans powered by lead-based batteries have been promoted as a way to reduce health-damaging urban smog. But now the potential risk from production of the batteries, long quietly acknowledged, is drawing more careful scrutiny from scientists, and their findings are alarming.

title: A Black Businessman's Ordeal as a Suspect
description: Reading his newspaper and sipping his orange juice on the 6:42 train from Chappaqua, Earl G. Graves Jr. looked and felt like the briefcase-toting businessman he is. But when the train arrived at Grand Central Terminal at 7:35 and he stepped onto the platform, he was transformed.

title: Bail Set in Killing of Officer
description: Two men identified by the police as members of the Warlocks motorcycle gang were held on $2 million bail each yesterday in the fatal shooting of a Franklin Township police officer. The officer, Sgt. Ippolito Gonzalez, was shot Saturday night during a routine traffic stop about 150 yards from the police station.

title: DNA: From Crime Scene to Courtroom
description: The focus of the O.J. Simpson trial shifted yesterday to DNA analysis. In the ocming weeks, prosecutors plan to present DNA results implicating Mr. Simpson in the deaths of his former wife and her friend. Defense lawyers expect to question everything from the amount and quality of blood available for testing to the reliability of the results. Presented with the prosecution's case will be a new vocabulary of acronyms and words, and a few lessons in statistics. Here is a primer on DNA, highlighting areas in dispute. BRENT HATCHER

description: Dr. Willet F. Whitmore Jr., a New York specialist on tumors of the urologic tracts, died yesterday at his home in Amagansett, L.I. He was 78.

description: Republicans in the Senate today failed again to act on a measure intended to reduce the number of civil lawsuits, even though Senator Bob Dole, the majority leader, had scaled back the proposal drastically to attract the needed votes.

title: One for All and All for One, Sort of
description: IT faxes. It copies. It scans. It prints. What it needs is a decent name. For now, "multifunction product," abbreviated "MFP," is the norm, but that sounds like a toothpaste ingredient. I prefer "E pluribus unum," which my third-grade teacher assured me means "Out of many, one."3

title: A Shady-Past Mayor, But at Least He Cares
description: IT isn't often that this fading industrial town gets compared to the nation's capital. But Stacie Lubanda felt the comparison was fair enough after seeing the results of last week's mayoral election here.

title: Dollar in Widespread Decline; U.S.-Japan Trade Friction Cited
description: The dollar fell against the yen and other leading currencies after the United States and Japan failed to reach an accord in talks aimed at opening Japan's market to more American cars and car parts.

title: Find Suggests Weaving Preceded Settled Life
description: SOME 27,000 years ago, an innovative group of hunters and gatherers were in the habit of setting up their summer base camps near a river along the Pavlov Hills in what is now the southeastern Czech Republic. They mixed the fine soil with water and molded it into human and animal figurines and fired them, creating the oldest known fired ceramics. They took the two-and-a-half-million-year-old technology of flaking stone tools a step further by grinding them into smoothly polished pendants and rings, the earliest known examples of ground stone technology in Europe.

title: Pataki Drops Bid to Deny Pay for Staff
description: Rebuffed again in court, Gov. George E. Pataki tonight abandoned his fight to deny pay to 4,000 legislative employees as long as the state was without a budget for the new fiscal year. But he said he would continue his appeal on the broader question of whether he had the authority to withhold pay from those workers to force passage of a timely budget.

title: Adding Bitter to a Sweet Blend
description: If Midori's prodigious musicality has made her a bankable star of the classical music world, it has also given rise to an auxiliary handwringing industry. When she was a teen-age violinist playing with major orchestras and conductors, the worry was whether the early spotlight would arrest her artistic growth. Her transition to maturity was closely scrutinized, and when she proved to be an artist of substance, one heard fretting about whether the next crop of prodigies would send her into a tailspin. When she canceled four months of concerts because of a digestive disorder earlier this season, the full repertory of concerns was trotted out for reconsideration.

title: Mystery Is Lifting on Mechanisms Of Disease That Killed Lou Gehrig
description: UNTIL very recently, the horrendous degenerative disease that killed the baseball star Lou Gehrig nearly 60 years ago was a complete mystery. Doctors recognized the symptoms of the disease, amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, or A.L.S., but they did not know what caused them.

title: Cortines Hails Effort to Push Tough Classes
description: The push by Schools Chancellor Ramon C. Cortines to have all of New York City's high school students take college preparatory math and science courses has made impressive gains in its first year, with thousands of additional students passing these tougher courses.

title: France's New Regime: Looking Ahead, Not Back
description: To understand how much the presidential election Sunday represented a generational changing of the guard in France, it was enough to look at this morning's military parade commemorating the 50th anniversary of the German surrender in World War II.

title: Anguish in Era of AIDS: Choosing to Have Babies
description: In Westchester County, Sandy L. spent years in soul-searching discussions with her husband before they decided, out of love, to have a baby despite the risk. The baby is due this month.

title: International Briefs; In Brief
description: * The Exxon Corporation's Malaysian unit, Esso Production Malaysia Inc., said yesterday that it had signed 10 contracts worth $200 million for the construction of a natural gas pipeline. Construction is to start this month for installation in 1997.(Bloomberg Business News) * Pratt & Whitney, the United States aircraft engine manufacturer, will set up its Asian regional maintenance center in Taiwan. The company, a unit of the United Technologies Corporation, will set up a $17 million joint venture with China Airlines, Taiwan's national carrier, and an engineering company owned by Singapore Airlines. Under a contract to be signed on Wednesday, Pratt will have a 51 percent stake in the venture, with two partners sharing the remainder.(AP)

title: Pentagon Chief Proposes 10-Year, $1 Billion Plan to Fix or Replace Military Housing

In a match in which wind and waves did not provide an excuse for either competitor, the jet-black boat from New Zealand led at every leg and defeated Dennis Conner's newly adopted yacht, Young America, by 4 minutes 14 seconds.

title: 'Light Fare' Gets Heavy Turnout at Taco Bells
description: How did Taco Bell's great food giveaway go yesterday? "I felt like I was in a shark tank holding a big piece of steak," said John Martin, the company's chairman and chief executive, who joined his 135,000 troops behind the counter.

title: Behind Closet Doors, Decay and Leftovers
description: There is no shortage of ghosts is Strindberg's "Ghost Sonata," ghosts of old loves, old deceits, even old kindnesses. "Ghost Sonata," which is being given an intriguing revival by the Irondale Ensemble Project, is one of the so-called "chamber plays" that Strindberg wrote toward the end of his life, in which he sought to create a new, intimate form of theater that moved beyond the naturalism with which most of his work is associated.

title: Dow Up 40.47, Pushing a Rally Into 5th Month
description: After a retreat on Friday, the stock market resumed its rally yesterday, pushing up the Dow Jones industrial average 40.47 points, to a record 4,383.87.

description: To the Editor:

title: At a Womb Of Horror, Croats Offer Ray of Hope
description: Here at the site of one of the most monstrous death camps of World War II, Croatian soldiers dug new trenches today to face the Serbian enemy across the Sava River in Bosnia.

title: LCI INTERNATIONAL TO ACQUIRE LONG-DISTANCE PROVIDER
description: LCI International Inc., a telecommunications company, said yesterday that it had signed a preliminary agreement to acquire Corporate Telemanagement Group Inc. of Greenville, S.C., for about $120 million. LCI said the final price would be based on certain future operating results at Corporate Telemanagement, a long-distance phone services provider. Under the agreement, LCI will pay about 60 percent in stock and the rest in cash. Corporate Telemanagement had revenue of about $56 million last year. But LCI said it expected Corporate Telemanagement, which acquired three companies in the last year, to have revenue of about $100 million a year later this year, when the acquisition is expected to be completed.

title: Simpson Judge and Jury to Get Crucial Lesson in DNA Testing
description: Prosecutors in the O. J. Simpson murder trial say the evidence is irrefutable. In what could be the decisive phase of the trial, prosecutors this week begin to present results of DNA tests performed on more than two dozen blood samples which they say directly and conclusively link the former football hero to the death scene.

title: 3 Finalists Named In 3M Review
description: The Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company has named three finalists in its review of the bulk of its worldwide corporate and consumer account, now handled by 25 agencies. The billings were estimated at $40 million to $50 million.

title: FPI Ltd. reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: The results are in Canadian dollars.

title: By Design; Chic in Black and White
description: Pastels are fine for some but not for everyone. A chic alternative for spring into summer is the sharp combination of black and white, whether in stripes, dots, checks or even solids like a white jacket topping black pants.

title: SANTA CRUZ OPERATION SEEN OFFERING NEW UNIX SOFTWARE
description: The Santa Cruz Operation Inc. is expected to introduce a new, more reliable version of its flagship Unix software today for computers run by one or more Intel microprocessors. Called SCO Open Server Release 5, the new software is mainly aimed at small or medium-sized businesses. The Santa Cruz Operation is one of the largest sellers of Unix software. Its sales have increased as a growing number of businesses, particularly retail chains, deploy more sophisticated computer systems. Responding to concerns about the reliability of Unix-based systems, Santz Cruz Operation said Release 5 incorporated more safety mechanisms to preserve data, added more system-management tools and could be made to operate like Microsoft's Windows operating system.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in the sports pages yesterday headed "Blowing the Whistle on the Knicks and the Pacers," about their basketball game on Sunday, was centered on an erroneous statistic. The total of 59 fouls on Sunday did not set a record for two teams in a playoff game. The record is 106, by Syracuse and Boston in 1953, in a game that lasted into four overtimes.

title: Kibeho Journal; Inside Rwandan Camp: Foul, Fetid and Fear-Filled
description: In the hospital courtyard in Kibeho, small boys picked through human waste for kernels of corn, collecting them in pieces of plastic, washing them with rainwater and then cooking them on small campfires.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Washington Defeats Chesnokov MaliVai Washington defeated Andrei Chesnokov of Russia in three sets yesterday to advance to the second round of the $1.8 million German Open in Hamburg. In an upset, Marc-Kevin Goellner of Germany beat Paul Haarhuis of the Netherlands, 6-1, 6-4. Goellner will next meet top-ranked Andre Agassi, who had a bye in the first round. (AP) WOODFORDE UPSET: Fifth-seeded Mark Woodforde of Australia failed to convert on three match points yesterday and was upset by Guillaume Raoux of France, 2-6, 7-6 (7-5), 6-4, in the opening round of the Rolling Rock United States Clay Court Championships in Pinehurst, N.C. No. 7 Chuck Adams of Pacific Palisades, Calif., was the only other seeded player to lose on the first day. He was beaten, 6-2, 6-1, by Fernando Meligeni of Brazil. (AP) WEISNER ADVANCES: Judith Weisner of Austria was one of five seeded players to advance in the opening round of the Italian Open in Rome. Weisner, the 12th-seeded player, defeated Bettina Fulco-Villella of Argentina, 6-1, 6-2. The other seeded players to reach the second round were No. 13 Helena Sukova, No. 14 Karina Habsudova of Slovakia, No. 15 Irinia Spirlea of Romania and No. 16 Nathalie Tauziat of France. (AP) AUTO RACING Earnhardt Is Again Alone in First Place Dale Earnhardt's first Nascar Winston Cup victory on a road course has moved him back into sole possession of first place in the series' standing. Earnhardt, who passed Mark Martin with less than two laps to go and held on to win Sunday's Save Mart Supermarkets 300 in Sonoma, Calif., now leads Martin by 9 points (1,494 to 1,485) 10 races into the 31-race schedule. (AP) UNOFFICIAL, BUT FAST: Arie Luyendyk, the 1990 Indianapolis 500 winner, was clocked at 234.107 miles per hour during practice yesterday, shattering the unofficial Indianapolis Speedway record and putting Roberto Guerrero's official qualification marks in jeopardy. Luyendyk, driving a Menard-powered Lola, topped the former top practice speed of 233.433 m.p.h. by Jim Crawford in 1992. Only speeds recorded during qualifications for the race itself are considered official. But Luyendyk gave a preview of the speeds that will likely erase Guerrero's three-year-old records on Saturday, the first of four days of qualifications for the May 28 race. Guerrero set the one-lap record of 232.618 m.p.h. and the four-lap mark of 232.482 m.p.h. to capture the pole position for the 1992 race. (AP)

title: No Headline
description: I believe that for our countries here, it was the last time we will ever fight against each other. I cannot believe that we will ever revert to the old way of doing things." -- JOHN MAJOR, Prime Minister of Britain. [ A10:1. ]

description: Science Times has an electronic mail address for comments from readers about published articles and suggested areas of coverage:

title: Keep Historic Sites Free
description: At a time of constricted budgets, Bernadette Castro, the new New York State Parks Commissioner, is understandably looking for ways to generate more income from the users of the thousands of campsites, nature centers, beaches and golf courses enjoyed by tourists and New Yorkers alike. The heir to the Castro Convertibles fortune and onetime Republican candidate for the Senate says she wants park managers to become more "entrepreneurial," often by charging fees for visiting these public facilities.

title: Moeller Pleads No Contest; Jail Unlikely
description: The former Michigan football coach GARY MOELLER pleaded no contest yesterday to charges of assault and battery and disorderly conduct in what the police said was a drunken attack on a police officer. Moeller, 54, appeared before District Judge BRYAN LEVY and entered the no-contest plea for both misdemeanor charges. He faces up to a $100 fine and 90 days in jail.

title: Marsalis Officiates As Classical Weds Jazz
description: Lincoln Center's executives have for years been trying to arrange marriages, or at least trysts, between the center's constituents, and on Sunday afternoon at Alice Tully Hall one of these unions bore fruit. The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center and Jazz at Lincoln Center collaborated on a program that brought together jazz-inspired classics and improvisations in classic jazz styles. For the occasion, there was also a newly commissioned patch of common ground, "At the Octoroon Balls," a string quartet by Wynton Marsalis, the trumpeter who directs the jazz series.

title: Landmark Hotel, 72, Is Dead
description: The Flanders Hotel, a landmark on the boardwalk for 72 years, closed its doors yesterday. In its heyday, the elegant six-story building, with its chandeliers and plush carpeting, was filled with wealthy vacationers. But the Flanders suffered from the lack of a liquor license and the loss of convention business to Atlantic City, and the occupancy rate tumbled.

title: Rubin Opposes G.O.P. Bill on Banks Again
description: Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin said today he strongly objected to plans by the House Banking Committee chairman to give broad regulatory powers to the Federal Reserve as part of a bill that would allow securities companies to merge with banks.

title: Giants Re-Sign Sparks, a Cornerback
description: The Giants said yesterday that they had re-signed the veteran cornerback PHILLIPPI SPARKS, a restricted free agent whose time with the Giants has been limited by injuries. Terms of the agreements were not announced.

title: Tougher Welfare Measures Gain
description: A package of bills placing new demands upon welfare recipients was passed yesterday by the Senior Citizens and Social Services Committee. Two measures require recipients to provide information to help find a missing parent and to attend conflict-resolution classes. Another bill requires that teen-agers under the age of 18 live with a parent, guardian or other relative to receive welfare payments. ROBERT W. STOCK

title: Jingling the Keys to Cyberspace, Cable Officials Sing a New Tune
description: Cable television executives, as they stretch for the future, are nothing if not flexible.

title: SCHWAB TO OFFER SERVICES OVER INTERNET BY SUMMER
description: The Charles Schwab Corporation will offer financial services over the Internet within the next few months, Charles Schwab, its chairman, said yesterday at its annual meeting. Each attending shareholder was given a copy of Fundmap, software that helps customers shop for mutual funds. The company previously established Telebroker, an interactive telephone service that now accounts for 55 percent of Schwab's brokerage customer contacts. The technological edge, combined with discount services, helped Schwab increase its customer equity 28 percent last year to $123 billion. In the first quarter, the company said, earnings rose a half-percent to $38.4 million, or 44 cents a share, from $38.2 million, or 43 cents, in the corresponding period in 1994. Mr. Schwab credited the growth largely to his company's mutual fund operations. He said he hoped to expand the discount brokerage service into Germany.

title: Stackhouse Decides to Enter N.B.A. Draft
description: A fleeting chance to make a lot of money fast and a desire to help his parents are part of the explanation for the decision by JERRY STACKHOUSE to head for the National Basketball Association. The 6-foot-6-inch all-American from North Carolina said yesterday in Chapel Hill that he would follow the lead of teammate RASHEED WALLACE, forfeiting his final two years of eligibility to enter next month's N.B.A. draft. Wallace announced last week that he was leaving.

description: An unsolicited $3.5 billion offer to buy National Medical Care Inc. has left W. R. Grace & Company little choice but to get rid of the profitable subsidiary, the company's new chairman and chief executive told major institutional shareholders and Wall Street analysts in separate meetings yesterday, attendees said.

title: Clinton Urges Fast Action on Terrorism Bill
description: Returning political fire from Speaker Newt Gingrich, President Clinton today urged quick passage of a bill to give Federal agents sweeping new eavesdropping powers for combatting terrorism.

title: Cable Venture for China
description: Tele-Communications Inc. plans to join with CCTV, China's state-run television network, to develop programming in China, John C. Malone, the president and chief executive of Tele-Communications, said last night at a dinner of the Economics Club in New York. Mr. Malone did not disclose details of the deal, which is expected to be announced today. But he said his company, along with others, had been looking for ways to enter the Chinese market. Tele-Communications is the world's largest cable system operator.

title: Mets Losing Patience With a Losing Bullpen
description: Dallas Green, the Mets' manager, still has some patience with his pitching staff. So does Joe McIlvaine, the general manager. After this past weekend, though, that patience is bound to be getting a bit short.

title: Clinton Pays Homage to an 'Extraordinary Generation'
description: On an Army parade ground rich with history, President Clinton paid solemn tribute today to the generation that won World War II and prevailed in the cold war, thanking veterans for their sacrifice but warning that the nation still faced "forces of darkness" abroad and at home.

title: Top Union Official Is to Retire; Future Hierarchy Is in Question
description: Thomas Donahue, considered a compromise candidate to succeed Lane Kirkland as president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., yesterday disclosed his decision to retire as secretary-treasurer of the labor federation.

title: Fed Ends Inquiry Into an Arkansas Family
description: The Federal Reserve has decided to take no action after completing a two-year inquiry into the financial ties of the Stephens family in Little Rock, Ark.

title: Pitchers' Duel Merely Sets Up the Mets' Bullpen to Fail
description: Josias Manzanillo provided the answer last night to what has become a daily question for the Mets this season: Which relief pitcher will make the most costly mistake?

title: Treasury's Long Bond Yield Slides Below 7%
description: The Treasury's long bond yield slid below 7 percent for the first time in more than a year yesterday, as the market continued to rally on more evidence of an economic slowdown.

title: In America; Guantanamo's Kids
description: "I am 17 years old. My mother and father are both dead. Our home was used as a voting bureau during the 1990 elections and so after the coup, in 1992, the military came to our home and shot my father. I saw him killed before my very eyes. Right after that my mother and I went into hiding but we went to two different places. The military found my mother and beat her so bad that a few days later she died in the hospital. . . . My older brother died at sea, when he was attempting to escape Haiti. . . . I am afraid to go back to Haiti. All my family has been killed. I have a relative in New York. Please let me go there."

title: Still Pricier Fountain Pens Gain Cachet and Profit
description: To the generation accustomed to the Web and cyberspatial schmoozing, the fountain pen is about as useful as a quill. But to increasing numbers of people, it is an item of such allure that they think nothing of paying a sum that could get a computer aficionado a down payment on a respectable laptop.

description: The stock market closed mixed and little changed yesterday, a circumstance that would normally go unremarked in the fifth month of a substantial rally in stocks.

title: Mr. Gingrich Still Owes an Accounting
description: House Speaker Newt Gingrich has finally stepped down as the chairman of Gopac, the political action committee he has used to recruit, train and finance Republican House candidates -- and bolster his own political power in the process. It is the right move. Mr. Gingrich ought to distance himself from Gopac's big money fund-raising and concentrate on his new role as Speaker. But Mr. Gingrich cannot resign his responsibility to provide the full public accounting of the group's donors that he promised months ago.

description: The price at the pump is only 99 cents a gallon. The catch is that what's on sale at a Shell station just outside the Holland Tunnel is compressed natural gas. An estimated 500 vehicles, most from company or government fleets, will be able to use the station, a joint venture of Shell Oil and Public Service Electric and Gas. Everybody else will have to keep filling 'er up with regular unleaded gasoline -- which Shell was selling yesterday for $1.15 a gallon.

description: Sotheby's sales of Impressionist and modern art continued last night, but unlike Monday evening, when protracted bidding wars brought record-breaking prices, the auction was a somber affair of bottom-fishing and restraint.

description: MAKING wine is one of those jobs like writing books or building bridges or fighting wars: you don't have many chances in one lifetime to get it right.

description: President Francois Mitterrand will hand over his office next week to Jacques Chirac, the conservative who won last Sunday's elections with 52.6 percent of the vote, several aides of Mr. Chirac said today.

description: The American minister who organized a conference in Senegal that brought together 1,000 black Americans and 4,000 African government officials and business executives said today that the meeting was the first step toward building a movement for American blacks to help Africa.

title: Chief Accountant Is Named at S.E.C.
description: Michael H. Sutton, a partner in Deloitte & Touche, was named the chief accountant of the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday, filling a post that had been empty since Walter Schuetze retired in March.

title: Scientists Reject Criteria for Wetlands Bill
description: One day before the House begins debate on a bill that would greatly reduce Federal protection for wetlands, the National Academy of Sciences today published an authoritative report to Congress that repudiates the basic approach taken by the bill.

title: Just Stuff. Just Art?; Clutter of 1995 Goes to Museum
description: If "the apparel oft proclaims the man," as Polonius declaimed to his son Laertes, what about kitchen utensils? Or a barbecue? Do these say anything about the person who owns and uses them?

title: Rare Accord on Essex Budget
description: The Essex County Executive and the Board of Freeholders are happy, and maybe a little bit surprised. In a rare partnership, they have reached preliminary agreement on a $516 million budget with no property tax increases for homeowners.

title: New Yorkers Criticize Proposal To Revise U.S. Clean Water Act
description: As competing revisions of the 23-year-old Clean Water Act were considered on Capitol Hill today, environmentalists from the New York region criticized the dominant Republican proposal, saying it would hinder efforts to clean up Long Island Sound and threaten the purity of New York City's water supply.

title: Money-Laundering Indictment
description: Enrico Alberto Isaza flew to Newark last week from Cleveland, carrying $300,000 in cash, the authorities say. He still had $88,000 on him when he was arrested near his home here, according to United States Attorney Faith S. Hochberg.

title: 80-Year-Old Widow Is Found Bludgeoned to Death at Home
description: An 80-year-old retired real-estate agent who had been battling cancer for the last four years was found bludgeoned to death early yesterday morning in the living room of her stone town house in a historic section of Bedford-Stuyvesant, the police said.

title: BOARD IS GIVING IN OVER SCHOOL CUTS
description: Board of Education officials conceded yesterday that they are likely to find a way to cut the school bureaucracy by hundreds of millions of dollars next year without affecting classrooms very much, just as Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said they could.

title: Economic Crisis Hits Mexico's States, With Some Nearly Broke
description: The severe economic crisis that has thrown hundreds of thousands of Mexicans out of work and devastated the balance sheets of many Mexican companies is also taking its toll on the country's 31 states, which have asked the federal Government to help them avoid bankruptcy.

title: U.S. Witness Admits Silence On Death Plot
description: A former aide to the Muslim cleric charged with plotting bombings and assassinations in New York acknowledged yesterday that while cooperating with Federal agents, he did not inform them for a year that the cleric had told him to assassinate the President of Egypt.

title: Bill Spivey, 66, Kentucky Star Implicated In Scandal of 1950's

description: Granting a mandate to shake up the Central Intelligence Agency, the Senate today voted 98 to 0 to confirm John M. Deutch as the nation's 17th Director of Central Intelligence.

title: Royer Retires as Jets' Pro Personnel Chief
description: JIM ROYER, the Jets' pro personnel director, retired yesterday at age 62 after 25 years in the National Football League, the past 20 with the Jets.

title: Miller Hasn't Learned To Put Up or Shut Up
description: Who was that Reggie Miller last night in Madison Square Garden? He was not quite the gate-crasher we were expecting. He was just this angular jump-shooter with no good angles from which to shoot. He was as harmless as he was silent, incapable of so simple a chore as keeping his navy blue shirt from climbing out of his long, baggy shorts.

title: Fly in a Russian MIG, But No Dogfights, Please
description: Lee Rosenberg, 64, usually spends his days in an office, overseeing the 21 employees of the Knickerbocker Electrical Equipment Corporation in Bohemia. But the other day, he was sitting at a table with several other business people in a hotel here, listening to a man in a flight suit pitching a vacation package that sounded more like an ad for a war movie than a getaway for an executive from the suburbs.

description: On some campuses the question of whether gay groups are entitled to official recognition is a matter of social policy. On others it seems to amount to a struggle for the university's soul.

title: CONTINENTAL CORP. HOLDERS APPROVE BUYOUT BY CNA
description: Shareholders of the Continental Corporation approved the insurance company's acquisition by the CNA Financial Corporation for $1.1 billion, or $20 a share, the company said yesterday. The Loews Corporation, which is controlled by the Tisch family, owns 83 percent of CNA. The merger, which is expected to close today, is the latest example of consolidation in the troubled United States property and casualty insurance industry, which has suffered from price competition and a crowded market of insurance providers. The company said last week that it would cut 3,000 to 6,000 jobs after the deal closed.

title: Mysterious Disease Kills at Least 56 in One Month in Zaire
description: International teams of scientists, some equipped with protective suits and respirators, are being sent to Zaire to investigate an outbreak of a mysterious disease that has killed at least 56 people and put another 100 in hospitals in the last month, an official of the World Health Organization said last night.

title: 2 Industrial Units Merge
description: Cegelec S.A., a unit of Alcatel Alsthom S.A., and AEG A.G., a unit of Daimler-Benz A.G., merged their industrial-controls operations yesterday, creating one of the world's largest makers of automation equipment. The plan to create the company was announced in September. The venture will be 51 percent owned by Cegelec and 49 percent by AEG and will be called Cegelec AEG Drive Systems. With combined annual revenue of 4.5 billion French francs, or $938 million, the venture has 3,700 workers, most of them in Europe. The company will design, make and sell mechanical drives for industrial assembly lines.

title: 4 in Brooklyn Are Fined $40,000 for Prejudice in Renting to Minorities
description: The woman seeking an apartment in Brooklyn was a 23-year-old education consultant with a psychology degree from Wesleyan University. And she was black. The real estate agent was a 40-year-old emigre from South Africa. And she was white.
