title: Kent Electronics Corp.(KNT,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 1
description: Year-ago results is for the period ended April 2, 1994.

title: CHARGE BROUGHT AGAINST 2D MAN IN BOMBING CASE
description: Federal prosecutors in Oklahoma City have filed a criminal charge against Terry Lynn Nichols, accusing him of a direct role in the bombing of the Federal Building there that killed 164 people, law-enforcement officials said tonight. Mr. Nichols is an Army buddy of Timothy J. McVeigh, the initial suspect charged in the case.

title: Where Truancy Is Punished by Law
description: Instead of a morning spent in class studying history and fractions, Adam was truant again. A few blocks away from school, the 10-year-old was distributing pizza fliers to earn money; he wants a remote-controlled car. But this time, his slide from class was cut short by a police officer who cited him and sent him to juvenile court.

title: Security Plan: Close Pennsylvania Avenue
description: After months of study, the Treasury Department is preparing a plan to convert a stretch of Pennsylvania Avenue into a pedestrian mall to protect the White House from car bombs, several people involved in writing the plan said today.

title: Handy & Harman (HNH,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: Handy & Harman said the primary contributors to its latest first-quarter earnings were its electronic materials subsidiary and Sumco, a precision plating company acquired in September 1994, along with Handy & Harman's specialty wire companies.Those contributors were partially offset by additional expenses incurred by the company's automotive group to match changing volume requirements, and also continued competitive pricing pressures for precious metal fabricated products.

title: Software Maker Stake
description: The software maker Electronic Arts Inc. said today that it had acquired a minority stake in Nova Logic Inc., an interactive computer-game developer and publisher in Calabasas, Calif. Nova Logic also signed a four-year agreement to give Electronic Arts exclusive distribution rights for Nova Logic's CD and floppy-disk entertainment software in English-speaking countries. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Phone Bets Put OTB and Racing Unit at Odds
description: A 10-week-old experiment that lets horseplayers watch live races on television and call in their bets has proved to be a financial and marketing bonanza for the often-beleaguered New York City Off-Track Betting Corporation. But the test has provided less spectacular returns for the New York Racing Association, which lighted OTB's home-betting fires by making the TV signals of its races from Aqueduct and Belmont race tracks available free on cable.

title: Frustration In Balkans
description: The return on the United Nations' investment of $1.6 billion a year on peacekeeping in Bosnia and Croatia has been looking extremely slim of late.

title: State to Contribute for Stadium
description: By Mayor James Whelan's calculations, $12 million and a 6,000-seat baseball stadium would add up to more tourists.

title: Dollar General Corp.(DG,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
description: Sales included franchise stores sales of $ 845,000 and $ 953,000 in first quarters 1995 and 1994, respectively.Year-ago share earnings and shares outstanding are restated to reflect the 5-for-4 stock split of March 6, 1995.

title: Virginia's Alexander Looks to N.B.A.
description: CORY ALEXANDER, whose career at Virginia was marked first by promise and then by season-ending injuries, applied Monday for early entry to the National Basketball Association draft.

title: Great Dane Holdings Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: Share earnings are adjusted, based on 16.8 million shares outstanding which reflects a 16,800-for-1 stock split associated with the company's planned initial public offering. The offering was withdrawn.

title: Ford Sees 1995 Auto Sales Falling Below Level of Last Year
description: The Ford Motor Company said today that after lowering its forecasts for the second time in about a month, it expected 1995 auto sales to fall below the levels of last year.

title: James Merrill Memorial
description: A memorial tribute for the poet James Merrill will be held at 4 P.M. on Saturday at the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue at 42d Street. Among those speaking and reading from Mr. Merrill's work will be Allan Gurganus, Anthony Hecht, John Hollander, Alison Lurie and J. D. McClatchy. Seating will be first come, first served. Mr. Merrill, a resident of New York City and Stonington, Conn., died on Feb. 6 of a heart attack.

title: British Petroleum Co. (BP,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: Results in United States dollars have been translated from the British pound at the exchange rate of $ 1.58 to the pound for the latest first quarter and $ 1.49 to the pound for the year-ago period.The net income is the replacement cost profit after exceptional items. After-tax credits totaled $ 5 million, or 1 cent a share, in the latest quarter and $ 35 million, or 8 cents a share, in year-ago period.Share earnings are in American depository receipt (A.D.R.).

title: GENERAL MILLS DIPS AS SPINOFF OPENS AT LOW PRICE
description: The stock of General Mills Inc. fell yesterday after its restaurant spinoff brought a price from investors that was less than expected. Shares in the parent company, which makes Cheerios and Wheaties, fell $1.125, to $59.875, on trading of 1.2 million shares. Stock in Darden Restaurants Inc. closed at $9.75 in its first day of trading on a when-issued basis, instead of the $12 to $13 a share expected by Wall Street analysts. A share of Darden, which owns the restaurant chains of Red Lobster, the Olive Garden and China Coast, will be distributed May 28 for each share of General Mills as of the record date, May 15.

title: The Case of Order v. Disorder in the Court
description: THE SUPREME COURT REBORN The Constitutional Revolution in the Age of Roosevelt By William E. Leuchtenburg 350 pages. Oxford University Press. $30. IT IS SO ORDERED A Constitution Unfolds By Warren E. Burger 242 pages. William Morrow & Company. $22.

title: Dimetapp Account Is Moved to Y.& R.
description: The Whitehall-Robins Healthcare division of the American Home Products Corporation in Madison, N.J., said yesterday that it would eliminate Avrett, Free & Ginsberg in New York from its agency roster by moving the Dimetapp cold and allergy medication account to Young & Rubicam New York, which handles other Whitehall-Robins brands like Advil and Anbesol. The billings were estimated at $30 million.

title: The Pentagon's Blind Ambition
description: The Army is waiting for Pentagon approval to begin production of an anti-personnel weapon called the Laser Countermeasure System next month. If the go-ahead is given, don't expect the fanfare that usually greets the inauguration of a new submarine or missile system. The manufacturer, Lockheed Sanders of Nashua, N. H., refers all queries about the system to the Army; the Army has clammed up.

title: Allied Victory in Europe Is Commemorated in Moscow
description: More than 6,000 Russian veterans of World War II, with medals gleaming on their chests and scarlet battle streamers flying from their flagstaffs, marched briskly across the ancient cobblestones of Red Square this morning to mark the 50th anniversary of the Allied victory over Nazi Germany.

title: AT WORK WITH: Paul LeClerc; A Quiet Power at the Library
description: EVEN in the quiet, well-ordered life of a librarian, there are days that qualify as ecstatic, and Paul LeClerc, the president of the New York Public Library, had a beaut a couple of weeks ago. For starters, he was pleased to announce that Dorothy and Lewis B. Cullman had given $12.5 million toward renovating the Library for the Performing Arts at Lincoln Center.

title: Ranger Oil Ltd.(RGO,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
CONVERSE TO BUY APEX ONE, SPORTSWEAR MAKER
description: Converse Inc. said yesterday that it would buy Apex One Inc., a designer and marketer of sports-related footwear and apparel, in a transaction with an indicated value of about $51 million. Apex One, of Piscataway, N.J., also makes products under licenses with professional sports teams and leagues, and with colleges and universities. It had 1994 revenues of about $100 million. Under the agreement, Converse, a maker of athletic shoes based in North Reading, Mass., would issue $11 million of notes to Apex investors and 1.75 million warrants granting the right to purchase shares of Converse Inc. at $11.40 a share over five years. Converse would also assume about $20 million of existing Apex bank debt.

title: Life Terms in Detective's Death
description: The man who shot a Newark police detective to death in the Essex County courthouse in 1993 has been sentenced to two consecutive life terms.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Falling Interest Rates Could Lift the Economy

title: Business Travel; Cruise ships are eager to be host to business conferences and to change U.S. tax law.
description: ON its way from a shipyard in France, Royal Caribbean Cruises' gleaming new Legend of the Seas paid a three-day courtesy call at the New York Passenger Terminal before sailing for Miami yesterday afternoon. A week earlier, at the same terminal, Angela Lansbury christened Crystal Cruises' sleek new Crystal Symphony. Both ships were built primarily for leisure travelers, but each was also designed with the business traveler in mind.

title: Elbit Ltd. (ELBTF,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: Consolidation of Fibronics and Diasonics operations reduced latest quarter net income by about $ 3 million.

title: Advertisers Altering Payment Methods
description: The number of advertisers paying their agencies the traditional 15 percent commission has decreased significantly as they continue to look for alternative compensation systems, according to a survey released yesterday.

title: United Retail Group Inc.(URGI,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 29
Foreign Affairs; Eye on the Prize
description: Before President Clinton left for Moscow, Secretary of Defense Bill Perry gave a White House briefing at which he said something quite remarkable -- that his discussions with senior Russian military officers had left him with the impression that they were "relatively unconcerned" with gradual NATO expansion and "they did not see this as a military threat."

title: The Price of Liberty
description: To the Editor:

title: Enterra (EN,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Transactions
description: Baseball American League

title: Celebrating The Blues, Romancing Dancing
description: The trial, the bombing, continued downsizings, hot-air politicians: it's time for a break. Two very different and splendid sources of relief are available this evening, both at 9 P.M. WNET has a 90-minute "In the Spotlight" special called "Eric Clapton: Nothing but the Blues," and American Movie Classics is using a half-hour entitled "Gotta Dance" to send a mash note to what seems to be a revival of ballroom dancing.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ADVANCED MICRO DEVICES INC., Sunnyvale, Calif., which builds components for computers, will sell 486 computer chips to Hewlett-Packard Co., Palo Alto, Calif., for undisclosed terms. HARTMARX CORP., Chicago, Ill., a wholesaler and apparel maker, agreed to sell its Kuppenheimer Men's Clothiers unit to Kupp Acquisition Corp., an investors group led by Gene Kosack, former chief executive officer and president of NBO Stores Inc., for $16.5 million in cash and notes.

title: Ray McKinley, 84, Versatile Musician In Major Jazz Bands
description: Ray McKinley, a big-band drummer, singer and band leader famous for his work with the Dorsey Brothers' Orchestra and the Glenn Miller Orchestra, died on Sunday in Largo, Fla. He was 84.

title: W. L. Naumann, 83, Worker Who Moved to Top at Caterpillar
description: William L. Naumann, whose 55-year career at Caterpillar Inc. took him from humble beginnings on the factory floor to chief executive and chairman of the board, died late Monday at Bethesda Hospital in Boynton Beach, Fla. He was 83 and lived in Delray Beach, Fla.

title: Now Also Let In the Detained Haitian Children
description: To the Editor:

title: Aaron Rents reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: The company said revenues growth was led by its rental purchase division.

title: NOVO NORDISK CLEARED TO SELL GROWTH HORMONE IN U.S.
description: Novo Nordisk A/S of Denmark has become the first European drug maker cleared to sell its human growth hormone in the United States. The genetically engineered hormone is used to treat children who are not growing fast enough. The drugs have led to controversy, with some public interest groups contending that the condition is overtreated. The approval from the United States Food and Drug Administration means that the Danish drug maker will compete for market share against the two established United States makers of human growth hormones: Genentech Inc. and Eli Lilly & Company. The United States market is estimated at $300 million to $400 million a year.

title: Gooden in Traffic Accident
description: Dwight Gooden, the Mets' free-agent pitcher who is serving a one-year suspension for a drug-related offense, escaped significant injury in a traffic accident on Monday in St. Petersburg, Fla. Gooden's agent, Jim Neader, said yesterday that Gooden had the accident after leaving a workout at Eckerd College.

title: WHIRLPOOL SHARES FALL ON 2D-QUARTER WARNING
description: The shares of the Whirlpool Corporation fell 7 percent yesterday after the company warned that second-quarter sales and earnings might not match levels of the corresponding period last year. The shares fell $4, to $50, after Goldman, Sachs & Company traded a block of one million shares at $50. David Whitwam, chairman of Whirlpool, and Ralph Hake, executive vice president of the company's North American Appliance Group, issued the earnings warning in a presentation to analysts in Longboat Key, Fla.

title: Big Story Of Series Is the Two Big Men
description: He is the center who hesitates to talk about the pain. But it is the worst-kept secret in this series between the Knicks and Pacers. His calves are hurting. He is ailing. And even if his left calf is wrapped in a bandage from his foot to his knee, making him look like a half-dressed mummy, he will fight. He is Patrick Ewing.

title: A.L. Pharma (ALO,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-Figures excluded interest expense on both the cash consideration paid and expenses incurred associated with the Apothekernes acquisition. Including the expenses, net income was 14 cents a share.Year-ago results are restated for acquisition of Apothekernes Laboratorium AS on Oct. 3, 1994.

title: Visiting Leaders Try to Honor a Past Victory and Protest a New War
description: President Clinton waited two minutes in his hotel, after the last Russian jet fighter screamed over this afternoon's military parade, before venturing outside to attend the opening of a vast new Russian museum to the Great Patriotic War.

title: Minority Legislative Candidates Pledge Loyalty to Electorate
description: As Nassau County prepares to elect its first county legislature, a black voting rights group offered a field of eight candidates today who have pledged their loyalty to the "African-American and Hispanic electorate."

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: The F.B.I. Overreaches
description: Some of the Clinton Administration's top law enforcement officials seem to be playing a shell game with Americans in the wake of the Oklahoma City bombing, undoing investigative safeguards they promised to preserve. Jamie Gorelick, the Deputy Attorney General, and Louis Freeh, the Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, declared one day they would not rewrite Justice Department guidelines that set a careful and appropriate standard for opening and conducting terrorism investigations. A few days later they outlined an easing of restrictions -- merely clarifications, they said -- that would grant Federal agents intrusive new license to investigate constitutionally protected activities.

title: Uniforce Temporary Personnel Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Ramos Victory in Philippines May Speed Economic Reform
description: President Fidel V. Ramos maintained today that he had a fresh mandate after early election returns showed that his supporters would control both houses of the Philippine Congress, a result that should allow him to push ahead with economic reforms that have begun to revive the long-stagnant economy.

title: Sola Intl.(SOL,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-Included charge of $ 3 million for the termination of a management agreement in the quarter and year. The periods also included an extraordinary charge of $ 3,915,000, or 22 cents a share, related to write-off of unamortized debt issuance costs.c-Net loss, which included acquisition-related charges of $ 27.8 million in the quarter and $ 72.9 million in the year.(Loss)Sola International reported pro-forma net income of $ 9,819,000, or 44 cents a share, for its latest fourth quarter, compared with pro-forma net income of $ 4,894,000, or 22 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Sola completed its initial public offering in March.The company reported pro-forma net income of $ 23,645,000, or $ 1.05 a share, for its latest fiscal year, compared with pro-forma net income of $ 9,611,000, or 43 cents a share, in 1994.Pro-forma figures give effect to certain nonrecurring transactions associated with the acquisition of the Sola business in 1994 and the company's initial public offering and related debt payments in 1995, as if they had occurred at the beginning of the respective periods.

title: 7 Suspects Say F.B.I. Agent Helped Incite Mob Murders
description: Gregory Scarpa, an admitted Mafia leader and killer, died 11 months ago, but his shadowy double life as a Government informer emerged yesterday as potentially the most critical issue in the trial of seven men accused of engaging in a deadly mob war.

title: Hospital Investigated After a Patient Is Scalded to Death
description: A patient at a Veterans Administration hospital in Los Angeles died after being immersed in a scalding bath there, the Los Angeles County coroner's office said yesterday.

title: No Headline
description: "It's ridiculous. I can't go into a diner and smoke over a cup of coffee like I used to just a month ago. Diesel trucks are spewing exhaust up and down the street while I am being made to feel like a criminal for doing what is perfectly legal. I pay my taxes. I'm a good citizen and, you know, my mother knows I smoke." SUSIE JACOBS, protesting New York's new smoking restrictions. [ B1:3. ]

title: Campbell Issues Call To Protect Rangers
description: Colin Campbell of the Rangers is a rookie head coach in the National Hockey League, but he is a veteran of two decades as a player and an assistant.

title: Low-Fat Diet Can Help Children At No Peril to Growth, Study Says
description: Children with high cholesterol levels can safely be placed on low-fat diets to reduce their risk of future heart disease, a new study shows. Over a three-year period, children in the study lowered their blood cholesterol levels without interfering with their growth, nutritional status or emotional well-being.

title: Corrections
description: The heading of the American Stock Exchange table in Business Day yesterday misstated the trading date in some editions. The prices listed reflected Monday's trading, not Friday's.

title: Personal Health; Common sense and conflicting health studies.
description: MANY health-conscious Americans are understandably confused. Medical researchers cannot seem to make up their minds about what people should do to preserve their health for as long as possible.

title: Fairy Tale Doing a Child's Job: Reveling in Exuberant Play
description: Springing from the world of gloomy privilege that shaped Frances Hodgson Burnett's stories ("Little Lord Fauntleroy," "The Secret Garden"), the new film version of "A Little Princess" achieves something irresistible: a bright, beautiful and enchantingly childlike vision.

title: Article 613595 -- No Title
description: A few weeks after proposing to sell the Queens Hospital Center as part of an effort to privatize some of New York's public hospitals, the city has decided to cancel a $485 million reconstruction of the hospital.

title: McCall Says He May Run For Mayor
description: State Comptroller H. Carl McCall said yesterday that he was so unhappy with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's leadership that he would consider running against the Mayor in the 1997 election.

title: Unilever's Earnings Decline 7% in Period
description: Unilever N.V. said yesterday that its first-quarter profit dropped 7 percent, hurt by the strength of the guilder and sluggish consumer spending in Europe. The British-Dutch maker of consumer products reported profit was 783 million guilders, or $509 million, compared with 845 million guilders a year earlier. The earnings fell short of what most analysts expected, and the company's stock suffered. The American depository receipts of Unilever, traded on the New York Stock Exchange, fell $7.375, to $127.

title: PCS to Sell Stake To Texas Utilities
description: PCS Primeco, a wireless services alliance between Airtouch Communications Inc. and three regional Bell telephone companies, said today that it had signed an agreement to sell an equity stake in its business in three Texas cities to the Texas Utilities Company.

title: Nordstrom Inc.(NOBE,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
Violent Storm Inundates New Orleans
description: Parts of New Orleans, a city built in a saucer, became lakes on Monday night as a violent rainstorm swept in, resulting in at least five deaths. In addition, thousands of motorists were stranded, the airport was temporarily closed and countless houses in the city and suburbs were flooded.

title: World News Briefs; Basque Terrorists Seize Businessman for Ransom
description: The Basque terrorist organization known as E.T.A. apparently kidnapped a local businessman for ransom late last night, the authorities said today.

title: Feminists Find History in the Kitchen
description: TWENTY years ago, feminists were intent on getting women out of the kitchen. Today, many are back in there, searching for women's lives.

title: 'Enough': Smokers Find a Friend
description: IN the month that Local Law 5 has been in effect, smokers, who were its target, have been finding sanctuary, solidarity and solace in Drake's Drum. Like the persecuted once hounded into catacombs, they huddle in the restaurant on Second Avenue at 90th Street, puffing away and castigating the smoke-free air act as an unconscionable intrusion on personal liberties and on humankind's God-given right, since Eden, to choose its own poison.

title: Policy Management Systems Corp.(PMS,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: Policy Management Systems said its first quarter 1994 results included a pretax loss of $ 17,000 on the sale of marketable securities.

title: Animals Die as Pet Store Burns
description: Animal Kingdom, one of the biggest pet stores in Essex County, was destroyed by fire yesterday morning. The blaze killed four dogs, 110 tankfuls of fish, about 50 small birds and other small animals, including ferrets and chinchillas. Officials said Animal Kingdom's owner, Albert Migliori, planned to rebuild the store, a fixture here for about 20 years.

title: Youths Guilty in Rape at a Brooklyn Pier
description: Two youths charged with attacking a 30-year-old art teacher and forcing her friend to watch as they raped her last year have pleaded guilty, the Brooklyn District Attorney's office said yesterday.

title: GEICO TO BUY BACK UP TO 7 MILLION COMMON SHARES
description: The Geico Corporation, the insurance company, said yesterday that it would buy back as many as seven million common shares over time, depending upon market conditions. The buyback would include 3.28 million shares remaining under the board's previous authorization. The company has more than 68 million shares outstanding. Geico's stock closed up 50 cents, at $54.875, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Paramilitary Groups Are Presenting Delicate Legal Choices for the States
description: The rise of so-called militia organizations has come despite laws in 41 states that bar or regulate armed paramilitary groups.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Yzaga Upsets Becker It was slow and damp yesterday at the German Open, and the conditions were not much different from Boris Becker's game. After losing in the clay court final at Monte Carlo, Monaco, last month, then in his first match at the BMW Open in Munich last week, the world's third-ranked player fell, 2-6, 6-2, 6-3, in the second round on the same surface in Hamburg to No. 52 Jaime Yzaga of Peru in a match twice delayed by rain. In other matches, ninth-seeded Wayne Ferreira of South Africa defeated Dmitri Poliakov of Ukraine, 6-2, 6-3, and Andrea Gaudenzi of Italy beat Marcelo Filippini of Uruguay, 4-6, 7-6 (8-6), 6-1. (AP)

title: Panamerican Beverages Inc.(PB,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Two Wildwood Stores Burn
description: The Boardwalk survived, but a T-shirt shop and a game concession went up in flames yesterday in a four-alarm fire here. A third business, the White Dolphin restaurant, was damaged by fire and smoke. Two firefighters suffered minor injuries.

title: Pressure Grows in Mexico to Question Ex-Chief in Killing
description: With little progress apparent in the investigation of a political assassination that the Government has attributed to a brother of former President Carlos Salinas de Gortari, prosecutors are coming under growing pressure to question Mr. Salinas.

title: Paper Maker To Spin Off Tobacco Units
description: The Kimberly-Clark Corporation, the maker of Kleenex tissues and Huggies diapers, announced yesterday that it would spin off its $404 million tobacco-related businesses, in a move that analysts said had been prompted by shareholders' concern over the legal liabilities of cigarettes.

title: Nuclear Pact May Continue By Consensus
description: A compromise was taking shape today that could allow the indefinite extension by consensus of an international treaty that has limited the spread of nuclear weapons for a quarter of a century.

title: Who's Offering Advice? Just About Everyone
description: IN Moliere's comedy "Les Femmes Savantes," Martine, the kitchen girl, warns, "Books and marriage don't go well together."

title: GEORGIA-PACIFIC PLANS TO BID FOR RIVERWOOD
description: The Georgia-Pacific Corporation is planning a $1.34 billion bid for the Manville Corporation's controlling stake in the Riverwood International Corporation, according to those involved in the negotiations. Georgia-Pacific, one of the nation's largest forest-product companies, based in Atlanta, would pay $25 a share for Manville's 81.5 percent stake in Riverwood, a maker of boxes for Sara Lee pies and cardboard six-packs for Coca-Cola and Miller Brewing -- a subsidiary of Philip Morris Inc. -- according to those involved. Shares in Riverwood rose $1.125 yesterday, to $24.625, a 52-week high, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: A Modern 'Pearl' Inside Old Barcelona
description: It is a situation that architects usually only dream about, to be sought out by the mayor of a rich European metropolis and told: "I'd like one of your buildings in my city. What would you like to do?" But since the city was Barcelona, it was not a dream.

title: Croat Meets With the Nets
description: Arijan Komazec, the Croatian shooting guard being courted by the Nets, met with the team's ownership today. Komazec, the Italian league's leading scorer a season ago, met with Nets General Manager Willis Reed and the Nets coaching staff on Monday.

title: Vermont's Alien Sugar Maples
description: New sugar maples were planted on the Statehouse grounds here this week. But they won't last long -- not because they are unhealthy, but because they are from New Jersey.

title: Crown Life reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Bill Allowing Bank-Broker Mergers Clears a House Panel
description: The House Banking Committee approved a bill today that would repeal the Depression-era law that bars mergers of banks and securities firms.

title: Fall in Bond Rates, To 14-Month Low, May Deter a Slump
description: Interest rates on long-term bonds have been falling sharply in recent days as the economy slows, and yesterday they plunged below 7 percent for the first time in 14 months. The decline is starting to show up in lower rates for home mortgages -- and that may be just the jolt the economy needs to revive later this year or next. But rates on other kinds of loans have not budged.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Mom, apple pie and motor oil? A new campaign stresses the heritage of a Mobil brand.
description: ADS for expensive Scotch whisky brag about how long it has been aged. Fine wine is sold on its vintage. Now a far more prosaic product, a brand of motor oil, is boasting about its heritage, too.

title: Senate Agrees on Bill to Cut Civil-Court Damage Awards
description: After two weeks of contentious negotiations to fashion a measure intended to limit the number of civil lawsuits in the nation, the Senate today settled on a bill remarkably like the relatively narrow measure it took up when the process began.

title: 'Arcadia' Is Honored By Drama Critics Group
description: The New York Drama Critics' Circle yesterday voted Tom Stoppard's "Arcadia" the year's best new play, and Terrence McNally's "Love! Valour! Compassion!" best new American play. The critics group voted to give no award for best musical.

title: U.S., Enforcing New Policy, Turns Over 13 Boat People to Cuba
description: In the first application of the Clinton Administration's new policy of forcing all Cuban refugees intercepted on the high seas to return to Cuba, a United States Coast Guard cutter docked at a naval base here this afternoon and turned over 13 boat people to waiting Cuban authorities.

title: Harlem Landlords Sentenced For Ignoring Court Repair Orders
description: A landlord and his wife were ordered by a State Supreme Court justice on Monday to spend 30 days in jail and pay nearly $2 million in fines for repeatedly ignoring court orders to repair decrepit buildings they own in Harlem.

title: Winners Are Named For Andys and Clios
description: The Advertising Club of New York has announced the winners of its 31st annual International Andy awards for creative excellence. Separately, the Clio Awards organization has announced the winners of its public service advertising awards.

title: T.W.A. Rescinds Limit on Travel Agents' Commissions
description: Breaking ranks with other major airlines, Trans World Airlines agreed yesterday to rescind a limit on travel agent commissions at least through September.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The show must go on, so forget the appendicitis.

title: Monrovia Journal; Old Elite From America Loses All in Liberia
description: Like most Liberians, Clarence L. Simpson does not have to look far for signs of his country's collapse into chaos and barbarism.

title: The City's Stiff School Requirements
description: Schools Chancellor Ramon Cortines imposed stiffer graduation requirements in math and science for New York City high school students eight een months ago amid much doubt that it would work. But early results suggest that the program is achieving success. The great majority of ninth graders are now taking the tougher courses, sometimes called college preparatory or Regents-level courses. Thousands more are passing the higher hurdles. The only cloud on the record is that a higher percentage of students are flunking the classes. That is no reason to derail the initiative but rather a call to increase the effort.

title: Congress's Medicare Plans Rejected by Clinton Aides
description: Stepping up the political war over Medicare, the Clinton Administration today rejected many of the leading options being discussed in Congress to shore up the finances of the health-insurance program for the elderly.

title: G.O.P. Leaders Offer Bills to Move American Embassy in Israel
description: Republican leaders introduced legislation today to move the American Embassy from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem, a step that has considerable bipartisan support in Congress but that the Clinton Administration says is ill-timed because it could undermine the peace talks in the Middle East.

title: COLLEGE LACROSSE REPORT
description: Who's In, Who's Out

title: Plan to Abolish Commerce Dept. Risky for G.O.P.
description: The most prominent Government department chosen for elimination in the Republican budget announced today is also the one that the Clinton Administration has declared to be the Government's most potent weapon in an age of international economic conflict: the Commerce Department.

title: LDDS Communications Inc.(LDDS,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: Latest results included the operations of WilTel Network Services, which it acquired on Jan. 5.Year-ago results are restated to reflect the December 1994 merger with IDB Communications Group Inc., which was accounted for as a pooling of interests.LDDS Communications, doing business as LDDS WorldCom, said on a pro forma basis, as though the acquisition of WilTel occurred at beginning of 1994, revenues for the latest first quarter rose 23 percent, compared with pro forma revenues of $ 702.7 million a year ago.

title: Clifford C. Clogg, 45, Authority on Demographics
description: Clifford C. Clogg, a sociology professor at Pennsylvania State University and an authority on population statistics, died on Sunday while jogging near his home in Bellefonte, Pa. He was 45.

title: EQUITABLE COS. (EQ,N)
description: Equitable Companies, the insurance and financial services company, reported flat operating earnings yesterday, although first-quarter net earnings rose 18.5 percent, to $65.2 million, or 32 cents a share, from $55 million, or 25 cents, in the 1994 first quarter.

title: Woman Gets 2-to-6-Year Term For Crash That Killed 2 Priests
description: A Queens woman was sentenced yesterday to two to six years in prison for killing two high-ranking Greek Orthodox priests when she crashed into their car last year after smoking a hallucinogenic drug.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Consoltex Group reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-Included a net gain of $ 10,365,000, or 76 cents a share. Brodeur and Devils Quite a Team
description: There is no goaltending controversy on the New Jersey side of the Hudson River in the Stanley Cup playoffs. Martin Brodeur of the Devils is without a blemish in the first two games of the series with the Boston Bruins, registering two consecutive shutouts with the help of exceptional defense from his teammates.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about a Senate measure that seeks to reduce the number of civil lawsuits misstated the number of votes needed to stop debate. It is 60 votes, not a two-thirds majority.

title: A One-Dish Indian Meal of Curried Vegetables
description: CURRY can be made with any of the spices that are generally used in Indian curried dishes, in any proportions. In this one-dish meal of cauliflower, potatoes and peas, the ginger adds sweetness, the red pepper some heat and the others -- coriander, fennel and cumin -- offer the intriguing and easily recognizable characteristics of Indian food. The turmeric provides the color. Serve it with rice or bread. Curried Cauliflower, Potatoes and Peas 4 ounces whole onion or 3 ounces chopped, ready-cut onion (1 cup) 1 teaspoon olive oil 1 large clove garlic Fresh or frozen ginger to yield 1 tablespoon, coarsely grated 1 pound whole cauliflower or 8 ounces ready-cut cauliflowerettes (3 to 3 1/2 cups) 12 ounces potatoes 1/2 teaspoon ground coriander 1/2 teaspoon fennel seed 1 teaspoon ground cumin 1/2 teaspoon turmeric 1/4 teaspoon hot red pepper 1 1/2 cups water 1/2 cup no-salt-added canned tomato puree 1 cup peas 1/8 teaspoon salt Freshly ground black pepper to taste.

title: Time for Hardball With Japan
description: McLEAN, Va. With the collapse of U.S.-Japan trade talks, the hour of the economic nationalist may be at hand.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Addenda listing on the Media Business page yesterday, about a shift in advertising agencies by Bay Bank of Boston, misstated the circumstances. The bank and its previous agency, Korey Kay & Partners of New York, parted company by mutual agreement; the agency was not dismissed.

description: EILEEN FULTON, who has had seven husbands, 70 lovers, three children (one of whom she sold) and who twice lost her mind in her decades as a soap opera vixen on "As the World Turns" on CBS, is marking two milestones this month -- as if she needed any more excitement.

title: Here Comes the Bill; How Experts Cut the Costs But Keep The Magic

title: F.B.I. Leader at 1992 Standoff in Idaho Says Review Shielded Top Officials
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation's commander at a 1992 standoff with a white separatist in Idaho charges in a letter to the Justice Department that the F.B.I.'s review of the operation was a cover-up intended to shield top officials, including a trusted top aide to Director Louis J. Freeh.

description: b-Included a charge of 2 cents a share related to prepayment of debt. Before the charge, net income was 21 cents a share. The 2 cents charge reflects shareholders' portion of the $ 2.28 million charge. Part of the charge was absorbed by limited partners' share of income from the operating partnership.Funds from operations in the latest first quarter totaled $ 25,480,000, or 52 cents a share, compared with $ 21,836,000, or 48 cents a share, in year-ago period. These results are the company's share.

description: Giovanni Grimaldi is in love, and he's not embarrassed to talk about it.

title: Vista Hotel for Sale, Port Authority Says
description: In its most aggressive effort to sell a major asset, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey said yesterday that it was seeking a buyer for the New York Vista Hotel in the World Trade Center.

description: b-Adjusted for unusual items, $ 40 million in unrecorded interest expenses for pre-petition debt obligations and bankruptcy-related costs, the company reported net income from operations of $ 95.7 million.c-After a charge of $ 5,600,000, or 11 cents a share, from the adoption of SFAS No. 112, accounting for postemployment benefits.Year-ago income from continuing operations of $ 140,200,000, or $ 2.77 a share, is adjusted for unusual items, $ 32 million in unrecorded interest expenses for pre-petition debt obligations and bankruptcy-related costs, the company reported net income from operations of $ 102.2 million.

title: Wars Old And New Are Noted In Grozny
description: It was not the roar of the nightly shelling or the lack of heat that woke Vasily I. Dmitriyev early this morning. He is used to all that.

title: Amid Inconclusive Health Studies, Some Experts Advise Less Advice
description: AMID the deluge of health advice, health news, health tips and health warnings that swells ever larger each year, a number of public health experts and medical researchers are calling for a timeout. The public, they contend, should be told not just what the latest study says but also what it does not say, and how certain it is that the conclusion is correct.

title: Knicks Breathe Easier After Storming Past Pacers
description: Reggie Miller had a lot to say after Game 1. The Knicks had the last word in Game 2.

title: In the San Gabriel Valley, Sampling Chinese Food at Its Best
description: IT is Friday night and I have just eaten my 12th meal in 36 hours. I'm a little full and sort of hoping that the food will not be too delicious. But here comes a waitress carrying a platter of shrimp that were swimming in a tank just two minutes ago. We pull the hot pink bodies from crackling shells and dip them into soy sauce and scallions. The shrimp are fabulous. My hunger comes rushing back. Soon, I am devouring bowls of pungent sour plum duck soup and broccoli stems cut so they seem to burst into bloom when they hit the hot pan.

title: 2 Ways to Look at the End of Things
description: "Is That All There Is?," a cinematic self-portrait by the British director Lindsay Anderson, who died in 1994, begins with a motto, "Perfection is not an aim." This quotation, from an esthetic manifesto that Mr. Anderson helped write in 1956, sets the tone for the film's offhandedly intimate glimpses of a day in the life of the director shortly before his death at the age of 71.

title: Japan Gets the Avalon
description: The Toyota Motor Corporation has started selling the United States-made luxury passenger car, Avalon, in Japan, Toyota said today. The Avalons, equipped with a right-side steering wheel for Japan's roads, are made at the Toyota plant in Georgetown, Ky. Toyota said it hoped to sell about 15,000 of the cars annually in Japan.

title: McDowell: 12 Hits, 9 Runs, 4 Innings
description: Burdened by a two-game losing streak and still without the services of the injured Paul O'Neill and Don Mattingly, the Yankees needed Jack McDowell to come to the rescue tonight in the opener of a three-game series against the Blue Jays at the Skydome.

title: Beard Awards: A Little Politics, Lots of Good Food
description: THE late James Beard is most often remembered as an advocate of American cookery, and the awards given in his name on Monday night were described by Donna Hanover Giuliani, who was the host of the event with Robin Leach, as "a testimony to American cuisine."

title: Corrections
description: A chart yesterday headed "Passing the Regents Test," about New York City students in college preparatory math and science courses, characterized the numbers incorrectly. The chart showed how many students in the fall took the courses -- known as Regents courses -- not how many were taking the Regents tests given in June.

description: WHAT, me worry?

Ruling Bolsters Rights of Mentally Ill Suspects
description: The Connecticut Supreme Court today restricted the state's power to force a mentally ill person accused of a crime to take medication that might make him fit to stand trial.

title: New Syringe Idea Wins Science Prize
description: The invention of a nonreusable syringe to help prevent the spread of AIDS brought two New York City teen-agers top honors in a science and technology competition.

title: Fulton Crackdown Bill to Cover All Fish Markets
description: A bill before the City Council intended to rid the Fulton Fish Market of corruption has been modified to broaden the city's ability to regulate business owners and workers in other wholesale or retail fish markets in New York City.

title: Kennedy Taxis in Holding Pattern
description: Trying to turn the mad jockeying of yellow cabs into an orderly procession may be New York's version of tilting at windmills, but officials at Kennedy International Airport have decided to give it a shot.

title: Restaurant Owners Plan Fight Against Smoking Restrictions
description: New York restaurant and tavern owners yesterday began what they called a counteroffensive against New York City's sweeping, four-week-old restrictions on smoking in public places, lining up members to testify at a city hearing and releasing a survey of owners who said their businesses were hurt by the rules.

title: Teresa Teng, Singer, 40, Dies; Famed in Asia for Love Songs
description: Teresa Teng, a singer from Taiwan whose love songs won her spectacular fame across East Asia, died suddenly on a holiday in Thailand on Monday. She was 40.

title: INTERACTIVE TV VENTURE NAMES ITSELF TELE-TV
description: The interactive entertainment venture backed by three regional Bells and the Hollywood talent agency Creative Artists has been named TELE-TV. Nynex, Bell Atlantic and Pacific Telesis Group and Creative Artists plan to a start in late 1996 of their interactive venture, which will broadcast over the companies' broadband and wireless networks in six of the nation's top seven media markets. Bell Atlantic, Nynex and Pacific Telesis serve more than 30 million homes in cities that include New York, Boston, Philadelphia, Washington, San Francisco and Los Angeles.

title: Corrections
description: An article and a picture caption yesterday about the auction of Impressionist and modern art at Sotheby's in Manhattan on Monday night, and a front-page summary in some copies, misstated the sale price of Matisse's "Hindu Pose" (1923). The price, a record for a work by the artist, was $14.8 million.

title: Corrections
description: A news analysis article last Wednesday about Russian-American relations misstated the scope of the second strategic arms limitation treaty. The treaty provides for the dismantling and destruction of nuclear delivery systems, but not of nuclear warheads themselves.

title: 'Emerging Viruses' in Films and Best-Sellers
description: "Emerging viruses" is the medical world's understated phrase for the several strange and often deadly pathogens, little explored in Western textbooks, that have appeared out of the blue or expanded well beyond their range in recent years.

title: Senate Panel Offers Budget That Balances
description: After months of making many promises but offering few specifics, Republican senators today proposed a historic plan that showed in actual dollars and cents how they hope to balance the Federal budget with cuts in projected Government spending of nearly $1 trillion over the next seven years.

title: ECI Telecom Ltd.  (ECILF,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-Included a one-time charge of $ 750,000, or 1 cent a share, reflecting a writedown to market value of $ 1 million bond issued by Barings B.V. and guaranteed by its parent Barings PLC.

title: Artisan of Quiet Crises And the Little Things
description: "The Stone Diaries," which won this year's Pulitzer Prize for fiction, is a rich, panoramic novel in the guise of a biography. As Carol Shields traces the life of Daisy Goodwill, from birth to death, through the 20th century, she creates a family tree and inserts an album of family photographs in the center of the book to underscore the tangibility of her characters.

title: New Zealand Races Away From Conner for 3-0 Lead in the Cup
description: It is a Southern Hemisphere nation the size of California. But when it comes to yacht racing, New Zealand has a self-image as big as China. That explains, in part, not only the country's willingness to take on the United States in the America's Cup, but also why it has won the first three races in the match for the cup.

title: N.B.A. PLAYOFFS
description: This time the so-called "choke artists" applied a choke hold. This time there was no catching the Knicks in the last 18.7 seconds. This time the Knicks smothered the Indiana Pacers in the second half at Madison Square Garden and evened the second round four-of-seven playoff series at a victory apiece. This time, Reggie Miller, who had shocked and mocked the Knicks in the opener, scored only 10 points. Game 3 is tomorrow night in Indiana.

title: Ag-Chem Equipment Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Swiss Bank Is Seen in a Plan To Take Control of Warburg
description: The boards of S. G. Warburg P.L.C. and the Swiss Bank Corporation approved in principle today a proposed acquisition valued at $:800 million, or about $1.27 billion, that would give the big Swiss institution control of Warburg, Britain's biggest investment firm, people close to the negotiations said.

title: 'Thing of Love' to Close
description: "My Thing of Love," a comedy by Alexandra Gersten, is to close after the matinee on Sunday at the Martin Beck Theater, 302 West 45th Street, Clinton. The matinee of the play, directed by Michael Maggio and starring Laurie Metcalf, will be its 13th regular performance; it had 12 previews.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: MCI to Form Partnership ith News Corporation MCI will invest up to $2 billion in Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation and form a global media partnership that could transmit "The Simpsons" over telephone lines or sell products over the Internet.

title: Flood Danger Rises North of New Orleans
description: As the most extensive floods in the city's history receded, towns to the north struggled today to move residents from inundated houses into evacuation centers that were themselves being threatened by flood waters.

title: MCDONNELL DOUGLAS GETS BIG HUGHES CONTRACT
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation said yesterday that it had received a satellite launching contract valued at up to $1.5 billion from Hughes Space and Communications International Inc. McDonnell Douglas, based in St. Louis, said it would launch at least 10 Hughes satellites using its new Delta 3 rocket. Hughes, a maker of communications satellites, is part of the Hughes Electronics unit of General Motors.

title: International Briefs; Clearance Is Granted To Lufthansa Subsidies
description: The European Commission said yesterday that it would not object to Lufthansa receiving 1.55 billion marks, or $1.13 billion, in pension subsidies from the German Government, ruling that the plan does not amount to state aid.

title: Turkmenistan Oil Venture
description: Lukoil, Russia's largest oil company, said today that it would participate in a $320 million venture to explore for oil and gas in the former Soviet republic of Turkmenistan. Lukoil will finance all prospecting work and will receive priority in winning licenses to develop any deposits found, officials at the Ministry of Oil and Gas said. Further details were not available. Preliminary studies put possible reserves in the region at about 700 million barrels of crude oil. An estimate for gas reserves was not available.

title: 2 Russians in Concert With Opera Orchestra
description: The baritone Dmitri Hvorostovsky and the mezzo-soprano Olga Borodina are to sing works by Rimsky-Korsakov, Tchaikovsky, Saint-Saens, Rossini and Donizetti in a concert with the Opera Orchestra of New York on Wednesday at Carnegie Hall. Eve Queler is to conduct.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Since fashion shows traditionally end with a model coming down the runway dressed as a bride, the 1,500 people in the audience of "Inspiration '95," a group show at the Manhattan Center on Tuesday evening, had no idea they were about to witness a real ceremony.

title: Words From Mothers' Hearts
description: MY first impulse when I became pregnant with my first child was to read. Books on pregnancy, childbirth, babies, toddlers, Dr. Spock, Penelope Leach, "What to Expect When You're Expecting," Bruno Bettelheim, Tracy Hotchner -- I read as voraciously as I ate, hungry for the information that would prepare me to be a good enough parent.

title: G.O.P. Suggests Smaller Benefit Adjustments
description: As part of their plan to eliminate the Federal budget deficit, House Republicans today recommended a reduction in the annual cost-of-living adjustment for Social Security and other Government benefits, starting in 1999.

title: Tejas Gas Corp.(TEJ,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Global Women's Forum Fights China's Barriers
description: Organizers of an international forum on women that was expected to draw more than 40,000 people to Beijing this summer are balking at a Chinese demand to move their conference 32 miles away from the Chinese capital and will ask Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali's help.

title: Hogan in Intensive Care After Surgery
description: The golfing great BEN HOGAN remained in fair and stable condition yesterday after undergoing emergency surgery to remove a tumor from his colon. Hogan, 82, was in the intensive-care unit of All Saints Hospital in Fort Worth. His wife of more than 50 years, VALERIE HOGAN, said her husband is doing fine after the procedure. "The doctors all say he's doing remarkably well," she said. "They removed all of the tumor and said he'll be fine. It's just going to take a few weeks to get his strength back."

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: A Guest Speaker? Tyson Says It's Not So
description: Saying he had "no plans for public appearances in the near future," the heavyweight boxer MIKE TYSON issued a statement yesterday denying published and broadcast reports that he would speak on Sunday at a Mother's Day charity dinner in Fresno, Calif., to benefit homeless women.

title: Entering the U.S. Illegally And Provoking Anger
description: "Slamming the Door" captures the spreading resentment against immigrants, particularly against illegal immigrants and most particularly against illegal immigrants who commit crimes.

description: The company said the sales increase reflects strong order intake and sales growth at its information access and mail processing systems business segments.(Loss)

title: WMX TO BUY PUBLICLY TRADED SHARES OF RUST UNIT
description: WMX Technologies Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the remaining publicly traded shares of its Rust International unit -- representing a 4 percent stake -- for about $50.5 million. WMX, based in Oak Brook, Ill., said it would pay $16.35 for each of the 3.1 million shares. After the transaction, WMX, a garbage and waste handling company, will own 60 percent of Rust, an environmental and engineering services concern in Birmingham, Ala. The other 40 percent will be owned by Wheelabrator Technologies Inc., a Hampton, N.H., company that is 57 percent owned by WMX. Shares of Rust rose 37.5 cents, to $16, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Williams's Home Run Lifts Yanks In 11th
description: The Toronto Blue Jays may have trailed the Yankees by 16 games when the strike prematurely ended the 1994 season, but technically the Blue Jays are the defending World Series champions. More than that, they have enjoyed a psychological and statistical edge over the Yankees in recent years.

title: R. Gwin Follis, 93, Is Dead; Led Standard Oil of California
description: R. Gwin Follis, who presided over the Standard Oil Company of California as it grew from a modest regional oil and gas company into the nation's ninth-largest corporation by the time he retired in 1966, died on Monday at his home in San Francisco. He was 93.

title: Accounts
description: International Herald Tribune, Paris, jointly owned by The New York Times Co. and The Washington Post Co., selected three agencies to handle its national and international advertising, previously handled in-house: Ambler Rodford Advertising, London, for creative in television and print; Osprey Communications, London, for direct marketing in Europe, and Carat International, London, to handle media services. The billings were estimated at $5 million. Bertelsmann Interactive, New York, a unit of Bertelsmann A.G., to Ground Zero, Venice, Calif., as the first agency to handle its account. The billings were estimated at more than $2 million.

title: 'Air Pataki' Replaces 'Air Cuomo,' as Family Members Ride
description: During last year's campaign, Gov. George E. Pataki harshly criticized Mario M. Cuomo for allowing family members to fly on state aircraft, a symbol, he said, of Mr. Cuomo's "outrageous free-spending liberal philosophy."

title: International Briefs; Ericsson Pretax Profit Up
description: Ericsson, the Swedish telecommunications company, said yesterday that its pretax profit totaled 1.21 billion kronor, about $168 million, in the first quarter, up 48 percent from 813 million kronor in the period a year earlier. The result was at the lower end of expectations. Analysts surveyed by the Swedish news agency Direkt had expected profit of 1.27 billion kronor, with estimates ranging from 985 million kronor to 1.55 billion. Sales rose to 19.81 billion kronor from 15.98 billion, while new orders rose to 25.92 billion kronor from 21.50 billion. (Bloomberg Business News)

title: Clinton Visit To Ukraine Is Welcome
description: When the White House proposed that President Clinton stop here for a full day on his way home from the Moscow summit meeting, Ukrainian officials were flattered. But when the White House proposed that he spend a night in the capital, Ukrainian officials were slightly alarmed.

title: Owners' Meeting Produces No Plans for Negotiations
description: Emitting signs of an uncertain labor strategy, baseball club owners met in a Chicago suburb yesterday to discuss their plans a day before a new lawyer goes to court in an effort to shed the injunction that prompted the players to end their strike and return under the old work rules.

title: Ex-Tiffany Official Is Sentenced in Jewel Robbery
description: A former security supervisor at Tiffany & Company, who was acquitted in a daring $1.9 million robbery of the store, was sentenced yesterday to 5 to 15 years in prison for an earlier robbery of a Tiffany's executive.

title: McVeigh Said to Play Role in Seeking Holes in Government's Case
description: Since his arrest in the Oklahoma City bombing three weeks ago, Timothy J. McVeigh has continued to express antipathy to the Federal Government and has taken an active role in building a defense that will most likely concentrate on poking holes in the Government's evidence, according to people familiar with what his legal team is considering.

title: Harry Connick Jr.'s Search for Roots in Rhythm-and-Blues
description: Geography doesn't always spell musical destiny. Growing up in New Orleans and studying with rhythm-and-blues virtuosos has not made Harry Connick Jr. a master of funk, as he demonstrated on Tuesday night at the Beacon Theater, where he returns tonight and Saturday. In recent years, Mr. Connick has been a tuxedoed big-band leader crooning standards and a neo-bop jazz pianist. Now, touring with his Funk Band, he's a New Orleans rhythm-and-blues songwriter and singer. It's not his best format.

title: SHARES OF MAXIM GROUP FALL ON EARNINGS ESTIMATE
description: Shares of Maxim Group Inc. fell 21 percent yesterday after the company, a retailer of floor coverings, said its fourth-quarter earnings would be below analysts' expectations and results of the corresponding period a year earlier. The stock was down $2.75, at $10.25, on Nasdaq. The company, based in Marietta, Ga., said Tuesday night that its per-share results for the fourth quarter, which ended on March 31, would fall below Wall Street expectations of 17 cents, the average estimate of three analysts polled by Zacks Investment Research. Maxim said it would be profitable, although earnings would be below the 12 cents a share in the previous fourth quarter.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report by The Associated Press in the Company News column of Business Day in some editions last Thursday about a bankruptcy trustee's recommendation on a bid for the D. L. Clark Company misstated the title of the executive who submitted the bid. The executive, James Clister, is a general agent for the Guardian Life Insurance Company of America; he is not Guardian's president.

title: Boston ChickenInc.(BOST,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 16
description: b-Included a $ 3.1 million pretax provision for support center relocation.Boston Chicken said royalties and franchise-related revenues rose to $ 24.8 million in the latest first quarter from $ 10 million in the year-ago period due to an increase in royalties associated with higher systemwide sales, an increase in interest income generated on loans to financed area developers, and an increase in lease income.

description: b-Included after-tax restructuring expenses of $ 2.5 million, or 11 cents a share.Year-ago results are not meaningful, as the company completed its acquisition of Colonial Group Inc. and became a public company in late March 1995.

title: Women Are Becoming Equal Providers
description: Working women say they are providing about half of their families' financial support, according to a new survey by Louis Harris & Associates Inc.

title: Sinn Fein And Britain Finally Talk
description: For the first time in 23 years a British Government official sat down today for formal talks with stand-ins for the I.R.A., the organization waging a long and violent struggle to unite Ulster with the rest of Ireland.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: DATA BROADCASTING CORP., New York, which provides financial market news and data, completed the sale of its Shark Information Services unit to a subsidiary of Automatic Data Processing Inc. for about $18 million in cash plus the assumption of about $2 million in debt.

title: Tugboat Empress Stays in Jail
description: A state appellate court ruled yesterday that Evelyn Berman Frank, who once ran a marine empire of tugs, barges and tank-cleaning companies, must stay in prison despite her lawyer's claims that she is ill and that a jail term would kill her.

title: No Headline
description: A brittle alliance uniting two armed Islamic movements battling against Algeria's military Government has come apart, further reducing any prospect for a negotiated end to the violence and increasing the potential for what a senior Government official called "banditry" by splinter groups roaming the country.

title: BAY NETWORKS PLANS A $140 MILLION ACQUISITION
description: Bay Networks Inc. said yesterday that it would acquire Centillion Networks Inc., a privately held company that provides computer networking switches, for $140 million in stock. Bay Networks said Centillion, based in Mountain View, Calif., would remain an independent operating unit. Centillion provides Token Ring switches, which are intended to speed data flow among desktop computers, storage servers and mainframe computers. Bay Networks, based in Santa Clara, Calif., was formed last year by the merger of Wellfleet Communications and Synoptics Communications.

description: Deadly Virus Identified

title: Shutout Streak Ends Off Teammate's Skate
description: One hundred 49 minutes and 59 seconds after the opening face-off of their first-round playoff series, Boston was finally able to slip a puck past the Devils' goaltender, Martin Brodeur.

description: The Knicks have won their last three games in Indiana. Will that trend continue? Or will the Pacers finally turn their home court into an advantage against New York?

description: b-Net income, which was after a gain of $ 3.3 million, or 13 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting.(Loss)

title: A 77-year marketing nightmare ends for Bayer, and a new headache begins for Foote, Cone.
description: AN American marketing nightmare extending over three-quarters of a century has come to a close for one of the world's biggest conglomerates. But for Bayer A.G., the German drug and chemical company, and its agency, Foote, Cone & Belding in Chicago, their biggest marketing challenge has only begun.

title: Dow Surges 13.84, to 4,404.62 as the Bond Market Drops
description: The Dow Jones industrial average surged past 4,400 for the first time yesterday and the Standard & Poor's 500 index moved higher to another record, despite a sour market for bonds that would normally send stock prices tumbling.

title: Ralph Meader, 90, Medical Researcher
description: Ralph Gibson Meader, a medical investigator and research administrator, died last Friday at Franklin Regional Hospital in Franklin, N.H. He was 90 and lived in Sanbornton, N.H.

description: The same murder suspect was convicted a second time yesterday when John Dreher, a millionaire businessman from Chatham, was again found guilty of killing his wife.

The account was placed in review in late March after 13 years at Sive/ Young & Rubicam in Cincinnati.

title: Health Officials Renew Warnings Against Danger of Rabies
description: With the approach of warm weather, health officials expressed concern yesterday that rabies could pose a new danger because of something almost as predictable as summer: human complacency.

title: A Garden Strewn With Memories
description: FOR people suffering from Alzheimer's disease who live at the Hebrew Home for the Aged in Riverdale, Thomas Balsley is designing a garden with a dual function. "It is to be peaceful," said Mr. Balsley, a landscape architect in Manhattan, "and the focus is to try to trigger positive memories from the past."

title: Timberwolves Ready to Promote McHale
description: KEVIN McHALE has had success throughout his basketball career. That record will be challenged with the Minnesota Timberwolves. McHale, a former Minnesota high school and college star who helped the Boston Celtics win three N.B.A. titles, is expected to officially assume control of the team's operations today.

title: The 6:42 From Chappaqua
description: The experience of being presumed a criminal until proved otherwise is one that African-American men, rich and poor, know too well. Taxis that fail to stop, nighttime pedestrians who scuttle away in fear and random roustings by police and security guards are common events in the lives of black men -- but often viewed as paranoid fantasies by white Americans, who are generally exempt from the presumption of criminality.

title: Ian Ballantine Memorial
description: A memorial service for Ian Ballantine, the pioneering publisher who founded three paperback houses, will be tomorrow at 1 P.M. at the Hudson Theater at the Hotel Macklowe, 145 West 44th Street. Speakers are to include his wife and business partner, Betty Ballantine; Irwyn Applebaum, the president and publisher of Bantam Books; George Davidson, a vice president of Ballantine Books, and Peter Mayer, chief executive of the Penguin Group. The public is invited. Mr. Ballantine died on March 9 at age 79.

title: E-Z Serve Corp.(EZS,A) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 26
description: E-Z Serve said its increased revenues in the latest first quarter reflect the Time Saver acquisition, completed in January.

description: The share earnings and shares outstanding are in American depository receipt (A.D.R.) and each A.D.R. represents 10 ordinary shares.The results are in United States dollars.

title: Administration Rejects Plan As Based on False Promises
description: The White House locked horns with Congressional Republicans in the strongest terms yet today, denouncing their plans for balancing the Federal budget by the year 2002 as feckless and economically risky efforts to keep an "arbitrary campaign promise" and insisting that they drop their proposed tax cuts for the wealthy as a condition of negotiations.

title: ABC to Broadcast Beatles Documentary in the Fall
description: A five-hour documentary on the Beatles, produced with the cooperation of the band's former members, is to have its American television premiere in November on ABC. The show, which does not yet have a title, is to be presented in two parts. The broadcast dates have not been set.

title: Teacher and Girl: A Step Ahead of the Law
description: From seedy motel to seedy motel, a muscular man in his 30's and a lanky teen-ager toting a stuffed tiger have crossed the country in the last two months, running through their money at amusement parks and always staying just one step ahead of the police.

title: No Headline
description: "I am a gun owner and an avid hunter. Over the years I have agreed with most of N.R.A.'s objectives, particularly your educational and training efforts, and your fundamental stance in favor of owning guns. However, your broadside against Federal agents deeply offends my own sense of decency and honor; and it offends my concept of service to country." -- GEORGE BUSH [ B10:5. ]

title: Muslims Say They Own Site Proposed for a U.S. Embassy in Jerusalem
description: A dispute over whether the United States Embassy in Israel should be moved from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem grew more complicated today when Muslim religious leaders said land set aside for a new embassy building here actually belongs to them.

title: Western Beef Inc.(BEEF,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: Western Beef said the fact that the Easter holiday fell in the second quarter of 1995, compared with the first quarter of 1994, hurt sales in the latest quarter, along with continuing competition from other supermarket chains.

title: Top Prosecutor Proposes Easier Public Access to Criminal Records
description: The state's top prosecutor today proposed allowing citizens and businesses to check the criminal backgrounds of job applicants, renters and others for a $5 fee.

title: Employees to Take Part In Grace Unit Buyout Offer
description: Constantine L. Hampers, who made an unsolicited $3.5 billion offer last week for National Medical Care Inc., the most profitable subsidiary of W. R. Grace & Company, said today that senior employees of National Medical Care would take part in the bid, which he described as "not hostile."

title: Late-Inning Luck Changes for the Mets
description: Pete Harnisch, the Mets' starter, was in the clubhouse to watch the final two innings of the game at Shea Stadium last night. He saw the tying run score on a bases-loaded walk. He saw the deciding run score on a broken-bat bloop single to center field. He saw Jose Oliva, the Braves' third baseman, get drenched when a sprinkler accidentally started to spray.

title: DNA Expert Says Blood Test Puts Simpson at Crime Scene
description: In testimony that linked O. J. Simpson directly to the murder scene for the first time, a forensic scientist testified today that DNA tests showed a genetic match between Mr. Simpson's blood and splotches found near the slashed bodies of his former wife and her friend.

title: Still Writing, Still Walking, Still Celebrating New York
description: "Beyond! Beyond! Beyond was 'the city,' " Alfred Kazin wrote almost 45 years ago in his memoir, "A Walker in the City." For a young man of his generation, Manhattan was the center of intellectual life in America. And he was an immigrant's son in Brooklyn, staring longingly across the water at the "jeweled breast" of its skyline. Eventually, Mr. Kazin made it across the bridge, and with his book "On Native Grounds," in 1942, changed critical perceptions of American literature.

title: Smith Barney Manager Quits
description: Smith Barney Inc. said yesterday that Joseph Carballeira, its head of Government bond trading, had resigned amid losses in his unit.

title: Clinton Favors Coke In Russian Cola War
description: When President Clinton decided to make one detour from his Moscow summit-meeting agenda to publicize a successful American business investment in Russia, he chose Coke.

title: Tribune Plans A Station Swap
description: The Tribune Broadcasting Company has agreed to swap two of its California radio stations with the Henry Broadcasting Company for Henry's Denver station and an undisclosed amount of cash.

title: Heavy Battle Erupts Between Serbs and Croats in Bosnia
description: Heavy fighting erupted today between Croats and Serbs on a crucial corridor connecting Belgrade with Serb-held land in western Bosnia and Croatia.

title: HOUSE COMMITTEE ISSUES 7-YEAR PLAN TO ERASE DEFICIT
description: The House Budget Committee voted largely along party lines early this morning to approve a seven-year blueprint for future Federal budgets that would wipe out the deficit by the year 2002, largely by reining in health care costs and abolishing hundreds of agencies.

title: An Angry Bush Ends His Ties To Rifle Group
description: Former President George Bush has resigned from the National Rifle Association, expressing outrage over a recent fund-raising letter in which a top N.R.A. official described some Federal law-enforcement agents as "jackbooted Government thugs."

description: The inspiring skills of the Quebec Nordiques, and their ability to produce breathtaking plays in a conference-leading season, can conceal a basic truth. The National Hockey League playoffs, an often-painful grind from the start, can provide a reminder.

title: 3-Day Settlement Alters S.E.C. Rules
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission adopted a series of rule changes today intended to make the delivery of prospectus information easier when a shortened payment period for securities purchases takes effect in June.

title: Bridge
description: Every Mother's Day weekend, Manhattan becomes the center of the bridge world. The 21st Cavendish Invitational Pairs will be played Saturday and Sunday at Loew's New York Hotel, 569 Lexington Avenue. Kibitzers will be charged a $10 fee. Proceeds will go to the Chemotherapy Foundation of Manhattan, which aids cancer research.

title: Cigarettes for $1,000 a Carton
description: A guard at the Atlantic County Jail collected $1,000 from an inmate for a carton of cigarettes, the authorities said.

description: INSURANCE is the kind of business where there are exceptions to every trend.

title: Modigliani Sets a Record in a $38 Million Auction
description: The taste of the accomplished collector has an unbeatable allure at auction this spring. Last night, Christie's sale of modern art from collection of Ralph and Georgia Colin was a triumph for the auction house. All 76 artworks found buyers, a majority of whom were willing to spend far more than Christie's had expected.

description: A Designer Block East 60th Street between Second and Third avenues; (212) 753-0221.

title: International Briefs; NEC in China Venture
description: Japan's biggest personal computer maker, the NEC Corporation, said yesterday that it would start production in Shanghai this year, gaining a foothold in China's potentially vast market. NEC said it had signed an agreement on Wednesday to set up a joint venture for computer-related products with the Chiangiang Computer Union Corporation in Shanghai. The venture will build I.B.M.-compatible desktop and notebook PC's as the first Japanese PC maker in China. The venture will also develop printers and point-of-sales terminals for use in shops and work stations. (Reuters)

description: b-Included $ 88 million first-quarter charge for a voluntary retirement program.c-Included one-time, $ 65 million accounting write-off of nuclear fuel assets in the quarter and 6 months. The 6 months was restated to reflect amortization charge.The Tennessee Valley Authority said revenues were hurt by the loss of a contract settlement payment of about $ 40 million for the quarter.

title: T.W.A.'s Move Cheered By Most Travel Agents
description: Travel agents, jubilant yesterday at Trans World Airlines' decision to remove its $50 maximum for commissions on domestic air fares, were vowing to try to steer passengers to T.W.A. -- a move many agents hoped would lead other airlines to lift their commission caps as well.

title: Black Executives Forming Group to Defend Minority Programs
description: A group of black business executives said today that they were forming a political action committee and hiring a lobbyist to fight efforts to eliminate or modify affirmative action programs, including those that set aside a percentage of Government contracts for minority-owned companies.

title: Virtual Environment?
description: To the Editor:

title: Suspect Is in Coma After Arrest
description: A 22-year-old Florida man was in a coma yesterday after a scuffle with an off-duty Jersey City police officer while in custody on Sunday, the police and hospital officials said. About 200 people gathered at City Hall last night during a City Council meeting to protest the incident, chanting, "We want justice!"

title: Automobile Driver Shot to Death in Harlem
description: A car with four people inside crashed into the front of a brownstone in Harlem yesterday after the driver was shot in the head and killed, the police said.

title: Diverse Group Tries to Stop Illinois Inmate's Execution
description: A hard-nosed former police chief here, Richard J. Brzeczek, is a believer in the death penalty. But these days, his faith has been shaken, at least in the case of Girvies L. Davis.

title: Coast Guard to Close Stations
description: A last-ditch effort to prevent the closing of 23 small Coast Guard boat stations, including four in New Jersey, failed in the House of Representatives on Tuesday. The stations handle search and rescue assignments as well as drug, fisheries and immigration law enforcement. The New Jersey stations are Shark River, Townsends Inlet, Salem and Great Egg.

title: Playing Hardball Over Rockefeller Center
description: The Mitsubishi Estate Company, the Japanese real estate company that owns 80 percent of Rockefeller Center, is again playing hardball with Rockefeller Center Properties Inc., the publicly held real estate investment trust that holds the $1.3 billion mortgage on the troubled property.

title: Amtrak's Plan to Electrify Line Clears Final Hurdle
description: Amtrak's plan to convert the line between New Haven and Boston to electric power cleared its final procedural hurdle before the Federal Government on Tuesday, moving a decades-old vision of trains speeding from Boston to New York in under three hours closer to reality.

title: Taylor Comeback? Don't Get Too Excited
description: LAWRENCE TAYLOR may be interested in coming out of retirement. His former team and coach aren't. Neither the Giants nor the former Giants and current New England Patriots coach, BILL PARCELLS, sounded excited yesterday about the prospect of seeing the 36-year-old back in uniform. Taylor, one of the greatest linebackers in National Football League history, retired after the 1993 season after 13 years with the Giants but hinted this week of a possible return.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Monday about changes in the multimedia strategies of large media companies referred incorrectly to one such multimedia effort, Time Warner's Pathfinder service on the World Wide Web. The service allows Internet users to find information and promotional materials about videocassettes from Time Warner's HBO Home Video unit; users cannot order home videos through the service.

title:
PARENT & CHILD;
Spanking Is Becoming the New Don't
description: HAVE you ever spanked your child? Perhaps a better question is, would you admit to it?
