description: The Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corporation said yesterday that its first-quarter profit rose on stronger-than-expected gains in hospital admissions, showing that the company is taking market share from rivals.

title: Solving the Problems Of Public Education
description: Although "Reading, Writing and Rukeyser" begins with a look at a Baltimore school that has successes along with failures, tomorrow night's hourlong program is less a report than, in Louis Rukeyser's favorite image, an alarm bell. It is a chorus of interviews about what is wrong with the public schools and, sketchily, what should be done about it.

title: When It Comes to Giant Sperm, This Tiny Fruit Fly Is a Whale
description: Don't underestimate little guys. In the world of procreation, a new record holder has emerged in the longest-sperm category.

title: A VICTORY FOR TEXAS INSTRUMENTS IN PATENTS CASE
description: A Federal District Court jury in Dallas ordered three semiconductor companies yesterday to pay Texas Instruments Inc. $51.8 million in damages for patent infringement on a chip packaging technology. The jury decided that the Cypress Semiconductor Corporation and VLSI Technology Inc., both of San Jose, Calif., and the LSI Logic Corporation of Milpitas, Calif., had willfully infringed two Texas Instruments patents for packaging integrated circuits. The companies said they would appeal. The jury ordered Cypress to pay $17.8 million; LSI, $14.6 million, and VLSI, $19.4 million. The companies sold products using the process in the late 1980's and early 1990's, Texas Instruments said. T. J. Rodgers, president and chief executive of Cypress, said the decision would not affect operations of the companies because the patents had expired.

title: Clinton and Yeltsin Find Way To Ease Strains at Least a Bit
description: President Clinton and President Boris N. Yeltsin announced partial agreements today on aspects of European security and the spread of nuclear weapons, but they remained far apart on the expansion of NATO, Russian nuclear sales to Iran and the war in secessionist Chechnya.

title: Joseph V. Quarles; Executive and Naturalist, 87
description: Joseph V. Quarles, a former president of the Simmons Company and treasurer of the National Audubon Society, died on Tuesday at his home in Greenwich, Conn. He was 87.

title: THE HOUSE AND SENATE BUDGET PROPOSALS
description: The House and Senate Budget Committees have proposed deep and broad cuts in projected Federal spending over the next seven years, with the goal of balancing the Federal budget by 2002. Once approved by Congress, the Budget Committees' decisions lock in the total amounts to be spent in each of a dozen Congressional committees, which share responsibility for the categories listed below. While the two budget committees have made recommendations about how to meet the new limits, it is up to the House and Senate Appropriations Committees to identify specific programs for specific reductions. Here are the spending targets for the broad categories and some of the budget committee's recommendations. Figures are in billions of dollars. title: Senate, 61-37, Approves Narrow Punitive-Damages Curb
description: The Senate today approved a measure that would set nationwide limits on punitive damages in certain kinds of civil lawsuits, a notable victory for a coalition of manufacturers that had sought such a change for more than a decade.

title: Quiet No Longer, David Dinkins Finds a Voice, With an Edge
description: IF New Yorkers were to divide their mayors into two groups -- reserved and gregarious -- David N. Dinkins would most definitely fall into the first category. When he was Mayor he was accessible but contained, a lawyer-politician who chose his words with deliberate care, as if intent on fending off a hypothetical objection from some unseen opposing counsel.

description: Tufts University in Medford, Mass., has become the second university known to have accepted Gina Grant, the 19-year-old high school senior whose admission to Harvard was revoked after the school learned she had killed her mother in 1990.

title: Corrections

In addition to columns about children with AIDS, Mr. Dwyer's winning entry included columns about Irish-American involvement in the Northern Ireland peace process, the death penalty and other topics.

title: U.S. Is Moving Against Japan Trade Practices On Two Fronts
description: Picking up a new cudgel in its confrontation with Japan, the Clinton Administration said today that it was filing a broad legal challenge against Tokyo's trading practices with the newly formed World Trade Organization, but would also go ahead with planned unilateral sanctions against Japanese imports.

title: A Summit for the Season
description: These are uneasy times in relations between the United States and Russia, and yesterday's summit meeting in Moscow showed the wear and tear. President Boris Yeltsin gave some ground on Russia's nuclear energy deals with Iran, but not an inch on the war in Chechnya. The two men argued over NATO expansion, and will again. They recommitted themselves to seek ratification of the 1992 nuclear arms reduction treaty, with no guarantee a balky Russian Parliament will comply.

title: 3 Tell Council They Beat Homeless to Clear Out Business District
description: Three formerly homeless men told a City Council committee yesterday that they beat up other homeless men living on the streets of midtown at the urging of an official of the Grand Central Partnership, a business improvement district that had hired them to help the homeless.

title: Bail of $1.4 Million Set for Rap Artist
description: Tupac Shakur, the rap performer who is serving a prison sentence for sexually abusing a fan, can be freed on bail pending the appeal of his conviction, an appellate court judge in Manhattan has ruled. The decision, however, was put on hold pending another hearing.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: SOCCER Real Zaragoza Wins Cup Winners Cup Real Zaragoza beat Arsenal, 2-1, to win the Cup Winners Cup last night in Paris when Mohamed Nayim lobbed a 40-yard shot off the fingertips of the backpedaling goalkeeper, David Seaman, in the last minute of overtime. The winning kick gave the Spanish soccer club the biggest victory in its history. Arsenal was seeking to become the first team to win the cup two straight years. Zaragoza opened the scoring in the 67th minute with a 25-yarder into the upper corner of the net. John Hartson tied it for Arsenal in the 75th minute, sliding in a short pass from Paul Merson. TENNIS Agassi and Sampras Win in Hamburg Top-ranked Andre Agassi and No. 2 Pete Sampras won their opening matches in straight sets yesterday at the German Open in Hamburg. Agassi defeated Marc-Kevin Goellner, 6-2, 7-6 (7-4), while Sampras downed Carlos Costa, 6-3, 7-5, to move into the third round. The victory was Sampras's first on clay this year; he lost in the first round in Barcelona, Spain, and injured his right ankle at Monte Carlo, Monaco, two weeks ago. (AP)

description: A former state prosecutor who helped to investigate the killing of a Roman Catholic Cardinal in 1993 and other drug-related crimes was shot to death today in the western city of Guadalajara.

title: How Clean Is Clean Enough?

She was worrying that she had let them play in a place that could be dangerous. "I always throw them in a bath and wash their clothes as soon as I get home," she said.

title: Today's Man Selects The Cox Group
description: Today's Man Inc., a men's apparel retailer based in Moorestown, N.J., said yesterday that it had selected the Cox Group in New York to handle its account, with billings estimated at $8 million to $10 million. The account had most recently been handled in-house after the retailer and J. Walter Thompson New York, a unit of the WPP Group, mutually decided to end their relationship last May after three months. Cox was awarded the account after a six-week review that also involved three agencies in the Philadelphia area, one of which was Gyro Advertising in Philadelphia.

B3. MAYOR AND CORTINES COOPERATE AT LAST City Hall and the Board of Education are working more cooperatively to solve the serious budget problems both are facing. It is a stark contrast to a few months ago, when Mayor Giuliani and Schools Chancellor Ramon C. Cortines accused each other, in turn, of profligate spending and of ruining the schools. News analysis, B3. NEW GRADUATE SCHOOL FOR DRAMATIC ARTS Underscoring the vibrancy of the theater and film communities in the city, the trustees of the New School for Social Research voted to establish a graduate school for dramatic arts. B3. DAVID DINKINS TALKS AND HAS LOTS TO SAY When David N. Dinkins was Mayor he was accessible but contained, a lawyer-politician who chose his words with deliberate care. Mr. Dinkins is quiet no longer. The former Mayor has, 16 months after Rudolph W. Giuliani replaced him, found his voice. And it has an edge. Metro Matters, B3. EX-TIFFANY OFFICIAL SENTENCED IN THEFT A former security supervisor at Tiffany & Company, who was acquitted in a daring $1.9 million robbery of the store, was sentenced to 5 to 15 years in prison for an earlier robbery of a Tiffany's executive. B9. There were renewed suggestions that Mitsubishi Estate Company, the Japanese company that owns 80 percent of Rockefeller Center, might allow the Manhattan landmark to seek bankruptcy protection. Business Day, D4. REGION AMTRAK CLEARED TO ELECTRIFY LINE Amtrak's plan to convert the line between New Haven and Boston to electric power cleared its final procedural hurdle before the Federal Government, moving a decades-old vision of trains speeding from Boston to New York in under three hours closer to reality. B6. 'AIR PATAKI' REPLACES 'AIR CUOMO' During last year's campaign, Governor Pataki harshly criticized Mario M. Cuomo for allowing family members to fly on state aircraft. But five months into his own tenure, Mr. Pataki has yet to ban the trips. B6. ACCESS TO CRIMINAL RECORDS PROPOSED New Jersey's top prosecutor proposed allowing citizens and businesses to check the criminal backgrounds of job applicants, renters and others for a $5 fee. B6. TOWN MUST PAY BUILDERS $5 MILLION A New York State appeals court ruled that Town of Orangetown officials violated the civil rights of Patrick and John Magee when they revoked their building permit in 1985, effectively blocking them from building an office park. The court upheld a lower court ruling giving the Magees $5 million in damages. B6. FORMER TEACHER TO SUE OVER SEX CHARGES Margaret Kelly Michaels, the former day care teacher who spent five years in a New Jersey prison before her conviction on sex-abuse charges was overturned in 1993, said that she planned to file suit against state and local agencies for her arrest and prosecution. B4. HEALTH OFFICIALS RENEW RABIES WARNINGS Health officials expressed concern that rabies could pose a new danger because of something almost as predictable as summer: human complacency. B5.

title: Giuliani and Cortines Unite at Last
description: For Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, the turning point in his rocky relationship with Schools Chancellor Ramon C. Cortines came in January. He said this week that he finally realized that another midyear budget cut would be destructive to children and classrooms, so he instead borrowed the $120 million -- even though the decision led a bond-rating agency to warn that the city's credit rating might be jeopardized.

title: Parlor Pianos Return, Full of Digital Tricks
description: IN the Gay Nineties -- not ours, but the one a hundred years ago -- the parlor piano was the center of the household, the focus of family life. Young women counted passable piano playing among their indispensable accomplishments.

title: Bruins Find Way to Score On Brodeur
description: The Devils, shutout winners in their first two playoff games at Boston Garden, became slightly lackadaisical during the second part of the middle period in Game 3 tonight. It cost them dearly, for the Bruins seized the moment by scoring three goals and then holding off New Jersey for a 3-2 victory that left the Bruins slightly delirious.

title: Leetch's Goal Brings Victory on a Bruising Night
description: In the best game of what is turning into a great first-round playoff series, the Rangers beat the Quebec Nordiques, 4-3, last night in an exhausting, exhilarating, bruising thriller at Madison Square Garden.

title: MCI AND MURDOCH TO JOIN IN VENTURE FOR GLOBAL MEDIA
description: MCI Communications announced plans today to invest as much as $2 billion in Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation and form a global media partnership that might one day distribute "The Simpsons" over the Internet and home-shopping services by satellite.

title: Seeking Love in the Wrong Places
description: "Dog Opera," Constance Congdon's new play at the Joseph Papp Public Theater, insinuates itself into the consciousness like a conversation overheard in the next booth at a diner. At first it's banal and random, the information without particular consequence and characterized mostly by a desperate jokiness.

title: Miller's Mouth Has a Minus
description: Larry Brown, the Pacers' coach, thinks that Reggie Miller's calling the Knicks "choke artists" after Game 1 effectively took the focus off his own performance.

title: From Travels, An Exotic Store
description: IS it more fun to buy and hoard? Or to buy and sell, in order to buy again? Those are the questions that bedeviled Mark Zeff, a Manhattan architect, and his wife, Carolina, a fashion designer, after years of travel through Morocco, Kenya and South Africa. They chose the latter, and on April 1, they opened Zeff (right), a shop in Southampton, L.I.

title: Truth in Argentina
description: On the eve of Sunday's election in Argentina, President Carlos Saul Menem has had to use some creative public relations to deal with ghastly disclosures of military involvement in "death flights" during the late 1970's.

title: International Briefs; AT&T Buys Stake In French Venture
description: The AT&T Corporation will own about 20 percent of Iris, a business telecommunications venture in France involving Generale des Eaux S.A. and Unisource, and thus gain access to the world's fourth-largest telephone market. Iris, created last month, will be a unit of Uniworld, a joint venture formed last year between AT&T and Unisource. AT&T owns 40 percent of Uniworld, with Unisource holding the rest.

title: Quantum Health Resources (QHRI,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Confederate Submarine Is Discovered Off South Carolina
description: Divers exploring off the coast of Charleston, S.C., say they have discovered the long-sought sunken iron hull of a Confederate submarine, the Hunley, which was the first submarine in history to sink a warship.

title: Ex-Nursery Worker to Sue Over Ordeal of Sex Charges
description: Margaret Kelly Michaels, the former day care teacher who spent five years in prison before her conviction on sex-abuse charges was overturned in 1993, said today that she planned to file suit for damages from state and local agencies for her arrest and prosecution.

title: Bulls Change the Numbers That Matter
description: The commotion made its way around Orlando Arena the moment he peeled off his warm-up jacket before the tipoff. As the game wore on, center court began to look an awful lot like a telephone booth.

title: Treasury Securities Prices Retreat From Recent Highs
description: Prices of Treasury securities retreated yesterday, but not before testing recent highs.

title: Journal; The 'Rambo' Culture
description: When American liberals woke up to a Republican Congress last fall, they were equally stunned to discover that a whole other American culture was thriving -- the so-called non-mainstream media in which the news is dispensed by Rush Limbaugh rather than Peter Jennings and in which William Bennett, not Quentin Tarantino, rules. But given what we know after Oklahoma City, the geological fault between the new media and the old now looks like relatively tame stuff: However much conservatives and liberals may battle, they are still engaged in the same, albeit angry, conversation.

title: Kirkland's Supporters Rally at A.F.L.-C.I.O.
description: Supporters of Lane Kirkland started mobilizing backers for the 73-year-old president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. today, saying that union heads who are challenging Mr. Kirkland's stewardship are tearing the labor movement apart at a time when it desperately needs unity.

title: Elevating Textiles To Grand Art
description: NOTHING stays on top forever," said the Swedish-born tapestry artist Helena Hernmarck with a twinge of native stoicism. Still, she seems to have done just that for almost three decades.

title: 32 Bases Added to List for Possible Closing
description: Sending alarm through dozens of communities that thought they were off the hook, an independent commission today added 32 military installations to the list of bases under review to be closed, reduced or consolidated.

title: Sithe Energies Inc.(SYT,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-Included a gain of $ 8.6 million, or 16 cents a share, from the sale of the Bayside project contract. Before the gain, net income was $ 6.9 million, or 12 cents a share.c-Net loss(Loss)

title: Sergeant Pleads Guilty in Theft
description: He was a state police sergeant responsible for buying electronic equipment for the force. He also owned an electronics business in Freehold. On Tuesday, George Hruszczak pleaded guilty to having equipment he bought for the state delivered to his store and reselling it there. Investigators said Mr. Hruszczak, 45, ordered $500,000 worth of television sets, camcorders, car alarms and videotape players using state police invoices. He faces 10 years in prison. ROBERT W. STOCK

title: Onex Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-Included $ 19.8 million in gains on the sale of subsidiaries' shares. The per-share impact was not disclosed.c-Included $ 39.5 million in gains on the sale of subsidiaries' share. The per-share impact was not disclosed.Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Hall of Fame Names Three Advertisers
description: The New York chapter of the American Marketing Association has added three advertisers to those that "have built their names into outstanding brands" -- Apple Computer Inc., the Walt Disney Company and the MTV Networks unit of Viacom Inc. -- by naming them to its Marketing Hall of Fame. They will be honored on June 7 at a ceremony to present the 27th annual Effie Awards, which recognize effectiveness in advertising.

title: Barros Is Named Most Improved Player
description: DANA BARROS, who led the Philadelphia 76ers in six offensive categories, won the National Basketball Association's most improved player award yesterday. Barros averaged career highs in points (20.3), assists (7.5), rebounds (2.4) and steals (1.82). He shot a team-record .464 from 3-point range and set an N.B.A. mark by making at least one 3-pointer in his last 58 games. The 5-foot-11-inch guard received 50 of a possible 105 votes from a nationwide panel of sportswriters and broadcasters. (AP)

title: AT THE STUDIO WITH: Herb Alpert; Tijuana Brass, Right? Don't Ask
description: THE earthquake last year damaged the three-story contemporary office building Herb Alpert bought in 1993 to house his recording and art studios and philanthropic foundation, but he is pleased with its restoration. His own oil paintings hang on the walls, and an occasional piece of sculpture punctuates the decor. A large spiral staircase leads up to the top floor, which looks out onto palm trees and the Pacific Ocean several blocks away.

title: Investment Is A $2 Billion Bet on the Net
description: With its $2 billion investment in Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation, the MCI Communications Corporation is making corporate America's biggest bet yet that the Internet is going to be a thriving business in a few years.

title: CHRONICLE
description: DAVID H. KOCH is the oil executive and industrialist who has bought the Fifth Avenue apartment of Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis, and on Tuesday he will cross paths with her legacy once again.

title: Atmos Energy Corp.(ATO,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: Atmos Energy said earnings in the latest quarter were increased by rate increases implemented in its West Texas, Colorado and Louisiana service areas, by a $ 1.6-million decrease in operating and maintenance expenses, and an increase of 11,284 customers.

title: In City Parks, A Childhood Joy Is Now a Rarity
description: LIKE many parents in New York City, Darcy Minsky doesn't need tulips to know when it's spring. She knows by the sinking feeling she gets when she pulls off her children's shoes -- to behold sand in the heels, sand in the socks and sand wedged cunningly between their toes. Tiny sand mountains suddenly lurk in the carpeting. Picturesque sand dunes await in her sheets.

title: An Insane Execution
description: Varnall Weeks is insane, says the state of Alabama. But not so insane that it won't execute him at one minute after midnight tonight.

title: Sports of The Times; Rangers' Musical Goalies
description: MUSICAL goaltenders usually mean your hockey team is off key. But you can shuffle your goalies, as the Rangers are doing now, and win the Stanley Cup. It has happened.

title: Tokyo Journal; Denying Subway Killings, He Steals Girls' Hearts
description: Her hair in a bob, her blue school uniform as neat as could be, Itsuko Watanabe, 14, clutched a book bag filled with tonight's homework assignments and waited eagerly for her idol to emerge.

title: Quilting: Artistry Over the Internet
description: THE quilting bee, where people stitch face to face, may become obsolete. At the New York Quilt Festival, 21 of the 325 quilts exhibited were made by women who met on the Internet.

title: Way Beyond the Glass Ceiling
description: For some 20 years, Ann M. Fudge quietly climbed the corporate ladder. Then, just over a year ago, she reached a rung where, for women, the oxygen gets decidedly thin. Named president of Maxwell House Coffee, Ms. Fudge now runs a $1.4 billion business within the Philip Morris Companies' Kraft Foods division. With profit-and-loss responsibility for such a big operation, she's undoubtedly among the top 20 women in American industry.

title: Slain Man Found in Burning Apartment
description: Firefighters responding to a blaze in a basement apartment in Brooklyn early today found the body of a man whose throat had been slashed, the police said.

title: 2 Banks to Buy Meca Software For Personal Financial Program
description: Nationsbank and BankAmerica announced yesterday that they had agreed to the joint purchase of Meca Software Inc., producer of the Managing Your Money personal finance program, from H & R Block for $35 million.

title: House of Suspicion; Drugs Plague Building Owned by Ex-Officers
description: The apartment building looks like hundreds of its neighbors in the central Bronx -- the same stolid gray brick face, the same severe metal door, and the usual knot of watchful teen-agers affixed to the stoop. They murmur "Knockout," or sometimes "Pay Day," or "Wall Street" -- sales pitches for heroin.

title: Surrender Turns to Defiance in Face of Evidence
description: When Terry Lynn Nichols parked his blue pickup truck outside the public safety office in Herington, Kan., on April 21 and surrendered, he sent investigators down a two-week trail of detective work and hardball legal tactics that culminated in the charges filed against him today in the Oklahoma City bombing.

title: Gasoline Prices Rise as Workers Strike Brazilian Oil Refineries
description: Gasoline prices rose yesterday as a strike by oil workers in Brazil and refinery problems in Ohio and Louisiana threatened to reduce supplies.

title: The Growth of NATO: Will Moscow Go Along?
description: The big question on the table in Moscow this week was not Chechnya or even the sale of nuclear equipment to Iran.

title: Music Rated, Zagat Style, On Internet
description: OVERWHELMED by the choices at Tower Records? Can't find a reviewer whose enthusiasms match yours more than one-third of the time?

title: Ermina Stimson; Fashion Editor, 93
description: Ermina Stimson, an illustrator, art director and fashion editor during 36 years with Women's Wear Daily, died on Tuesday at her home in Wellfleet, Mass. She was 93.

title: Attempt to Moderate Water Bill Fails
description: The House opened a heated debate today on changes to the Clean Water Act, but the deep divisions over how drastically to change one of the nation's main environmental laws did not fall along party lines.

title: Chicken Farm's Food Is Banned
description: Since Jan. 1, school lunches in New Jersey and four other states have included chicken nuggets and patties from a farm in Georgia. But this week Federal inspectors found bone and cartilage in a shipment in Connecticut, and now all five states have banned the food from the schools, The Associated Press reported. An official of the food manufacturer, Fieldale Farms, of Baldwin, Ga., said it had received no word of the ban, which also involves Michigan, Nevada and West Virginia.

title: 2d Suspect Faces 2 Counts in Oklahoma Bombing
description: Federal prosecutors today widened their case against the bombers of the Federal Building in Oklahoma City, charging Terry Lynn Nichols, an Army buddy of the only other man arrested so far, with helping to plan and carry out the explosion.

title: Deadly Virus Is Identified In the Outbreak in Zaire
description: Scientists have found preliminary evidence that the Ebola virus, one of the deadliest infectious agents known, is the cause of a mysterious disease that has broken out in Zaire, officials of the World Health Organization and the United States Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said last night.

title: Arab Dissent Over Israel Delays Decision on Nuclear Treaty
description: A decision on the future of the treaty to halt the spread of nuclear weapons was postponed today, hours before an agreement was expected to be announced, because of an Arab proposal to single out Israel's undeclared nuclear program for mention.

title: Ann M. Lingg; Musicologist, 87
description: Ann M. Lingg, who wrote articles and books about music and musicians, died on Tuesday at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center in Manhattan. She was 87 and lived in Manhattan.

title: George Seuffert Jr., 82, Leader Of a Concert Band for 63 Years
description: George F. Seuffert Jr., recipient of the Handel Medal, New York City's highest cultural award, and a music consultant to five mayors, died on Saturday at South County Hospital in Wakefield, R.I. He was 82 and lived in Douglaston, Queens.

title: Rockefeller Center Forced to File For Bankruptcy by Tokyo Owner
description: Rockefeller Center, a symbol of wealth, commerce and power the world over, was forced yesterday to file for bankruptcy protection by the Japanese company that controls it.

title: Ewing Sits, Then Vents Frustration
description: Patrick Ewing was angry and frustrated. And he let everyone know it.

title: Farm Credit System reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: The system said the latest first-quarter net income was helped by a $ 9 million reduction in bank merger-implementation costs, which fell to $ 5 million from $ 14 million in the year-ago period.

title: BUDGET BALANCING GAINS IN CONGRESS
description: The budget committees in the House and the Senate today approved separate fiscal plans that would bring the Federal budget into balance over the next seven years and change the face of much of American government.

title: Councilman Resigns? No. Yes.
description: City Councilman Gary Harris, convicted six weeks ago on a charge of accepting bribes, said yesterday that he had resigned from office, as requested by the State Attorney General. But the Attorney General's Division of Criminal Justice begs to differ.

title: Courthouse Evacuated in Scare
description: A bomb scare at the Hudson County Administration Building and Courthouse, set off by an anonymous caller, forced the evacuation of 700 workers and 70 prisoners for nearly two hours yesterday. They were let back in at 1:30 P.M. after searchers found nothing.

title: 5 Derby Horses Ready for Preakness
description: The top five finishers in the Kentucky Derby were booked into the Preakness yesterday for the second race in the Triple Crown series, including Thunder Gulch and Timber Country, who ran first and third in the Derby as the stars of the traveling cavalry of D. Wayne Lukas.

title: Jack A. Applebaum; Jewish Federation Executive, 75
description: Jack Alta Applebaum, a former executive of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies, precursor of the UJA-Federation, died on Wednesday at the Westchester County Medical Center. He was 75.

title: School Buses: No 'Sin Ads'
description: School buses will carry no "sin ads," Schools Chancellor Ramon C. Cortines has declared, that is, no advertisements for cigarettes or beer or condoms.

description: b-Included a restructuring charge of $ 7,842,000, or 7 cents a share, in both the quarter and year.The charge is related to the closure of a warehouse and 12 retail outlets, and the reduction of about 120 employees, at Grand & Toy, as well as the closure of eight Steak & Burger and three Swiss Chalet restaurants.Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: A Nuclear Milestone
description: The planet is a safer place because more than 170 nations agreed yesterday to extend the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty, indefinitely and unconditionally. This bargain between the five acknowledged nuclear countries and most of the rest of the world benefits everyone, containing the spread of nuclear arms and assuring the transfer of civilian nuclear technology under safeguards.

title: One Week After a Victory, Calcavecchia Is in the Hunt
description: There was a certain symmetry at work here today in the first round of the GTE Byron Nelson Classic. On the 50th anniversary of Nelson's incredible streak of 11 straight tournament victories, the only player on the PGA Tour with a chance to start a streak of any kind shot a 64 and is just a stroke behind the leader, Glen Day.

title: SUSPECT HOARDED BOMB MATERIALS, AFFIDAVIT IMPLIES
description: An F.B.I. affidavit released today suggested that planning for the bombing of the Oklahoma City Federal Building began as far back as September 1994, when Terry L. Nichols began buying thousands of pounds of ammonium nitrate fertilizer and rented the first of several storage sheds in small towns in Kansas.

description: To the Editor:

description: The comparisons between tonight's game, Game 3, and the infamous "choke" game in the series opener between the Knicks and the Indiana Pacers were natural and abundant. Reggie Miller was asked point blank if the Knicks choked after squandering a 10-point lead with about 5 minutes left.

title: Rewritten Clean Water Act Gains in House
description: The House today moved toward approving major revisions of one of the nation's main environmental laws, the Clean Water Act, turning back liberal Democrats and moderate Republicans who tried to toughen the bill's controls on pollution.

title: Virus Kills a 3d Italian Nun at Zaire Hospital
description: A third Italian nun died today from the Ebola virus, which has stricken a city in Zaire where the nuns worked and has sent alarms throughout the world.

title: U.S. Lists Threats of Terrorism, Mainly From Iran
description: The Government of Iran provides up to $100 million a year to terrorists in a campaign to attack its enemies and derail Mideast peace talks, American intelligence officials said today.

description: JEREMY IRONS zipped across the Atlantic on the Concorde to be there. MICHAEL CHEPIGA zipped across town in a taxi, but first he had to get out of New York Hospital.

description: Lands' End said its international and new businesses accounted for nearly all the sales increase in the latest first quarter from the period a year ago.

title: The G.O.P. and the N.R.A.
description: It always irritates the brass of the National Rifle Association when public figures talk sensibly about guns. In times past, the N.R.A. has aimed its churlish demagoguery at police chiefs who favor the assault-weapons ban and at Jim and Sarah Brady for their advocacy of a waiting period on handgun purchases. Now they are accusing former President George Bush of acting hastily in turning in his N.R.A. card in disgust.

title: From Italy, Another 19th Century
description: "Masterpieces of 19th-Century Italian Painting From the Gaetano Marzotto Collection" at the National Academy of Design is the latest in a long series of attempts to introduce the public at large to an alternative 19th century. One thing that it proves beyond doubt is that for those who like pictures to tell stories, the Italian 19th century has much to offer.

title: Clinton Meets With Opponents of Yeltsin
description: In an effort to suggest that his Russia policy is not entirely focused on the politically battered Boris N. Yeltsin, President Clinton ended his two-day summit meeting in Moscow today by having breakfast with 10 leaders of the President's opposition.

title: Accounts
description: * Jack Daniel Distillery, Lynchburg, Tenn., a unit of the Brown-Forman Corp., to Simmons, Durham & Associates, St. Louis, to introduce Jack Daniel's 1866 Classic Amber Lager Beer in test markets including Baltimore and Nashville. The billings were not disclosed.

title: Back to the Old School (It's Better Than Ever)
description: FORTY-FOUR years after I crawled under every row of seats in the auditorium of Booker T. Washington during a music appreciation class to win a nickel bet with Billy Hill, I went back on Thursday to be be Principal for a Day.

title: Syndicated Shows Post Gain in Ads
description: In another sign that advertising spending around the world continues to grow, reports released yesterday show that ad sales on syndicated television programming are gaining in the United States and overall ad spending is rising in Germany.

title: Betty Boop, Coyly Sexy 60 Years Later
description: Think of her as Jessica Rabbit's grandmother: Betty Boop, the innocently sexy cartoon character with her signature garter and skimpy dress, her kewpie-doll eyes and baby-doll voice. For the next two weeks, Film Forum will present "Betty Boop Confidential," a collection of 11 nostalgic and still-amusing shorts made in the early 1930's by Max Fleischer's studio. Many come from the days before the Production Code sanitized movies, even cartoons. Among the most fun are "Boop Oop a Doop" in which the circus owner who is Betty's boss asks, "Do you want to keep your job?," then whispers something that makes her slap his face. She goes on to sing, "You can feed me bread and water/Or a great big bale of hay/But don't take my boop oop a doop away!"

title: Banc One Lives Up to Its Name; Switch to Centralization Is Seen Lifting Share Price
description: In 1992, after the Banc One Corporation bought the largest banking company in Arizona, Banc One's chairman, John B. McCoy, proposed chopping the new acquisition into separate pieces and sprinkling them among the state's major markets.

description: Here is a sampling of shows and exhibitions that are to close soon: Closing This Weekend "MY THING OF LOVE," Martin Beck Theater, 302 West 45th Street, Clinton. Through Sunday. Performances: Today at 8 P.M.; tomorrow at 2 and 8 P.M.; Sunday at 3 P.M. Tickets: $24 to $45. Information: (212) 239-6200.

title: Groundbreaking Law Firm Shifts Its Focus to Personal-Injury Cases
description: They are, by some accounts, two of the most recognizable legal surnames in the nation: Jacoby and Meyers. Indeed, for the sizeable part of the American public that would mistake the words Skadden, Arps for a kind of nervous disorder or a brand of upscale ice cream, Jacoby & Meyers may be the nation's only name-brand law firm.

title: Messages for Tunnel Traffic
description: Commuters may soon have an easier time navigating the clogged arteries leading to the Lincoln and Holland tunnels. The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey said yesterday that it would soon install a variable message sign a few miles outside each tunnel.

description: Burgoyne Diller Michael Rosenfeld Gallery 24 West 57th Street Manhattan Through June 3

description: Terry Winters Drawings Sonnabend Gallery 420 West Broadway SoHo Through May 20

title: Reuel Denney, Scholar, Writer And Poet, 82
description: Reuel Denney, who studied, analyzed and illuminated American popular culture as a scholar, author, teacher, journalist and poet, died on May 1 at the Kaiser Medical Center in Honolulu. He was 82.

title: MORRISON KNUDSEN GETS BRITISH AIRWAYS CONTRACT
description: The Morrison Knudsen Corporation said yesterday that its joint venture with John Laing P.L.C. of Britain had received a $240 million contract to build a cargo-handling building for British Airways at Heathrow Airport in London. Construction is scheduled to start immediately and take about three years to complete, including six months for testing. Morrison Knudsen, based in Boise, Idaho, said the cargo building would handle 800,000 to a million tons of freight and mail traffic a year.

title: Deciding the World's Fate From the Ocean's Bottom
description: THE planet is on the brink again with "Crimson Tide," a big, boastful, ear-splitting submarine movie with a bad case of Clancy envy. Torpedoes are strategically poised. Beads of sweat glimmer in close-up. An opening title announces that the captain of a nuclear weapon-bearing vessel like this, the Alabama, is one of the three most powerful men in the world. And don't think he doesn't know it.

title: Masterworks Usually on View Only Privately
description: When the first "International Fine Art Fair: Renaissance to Impressionism" took place last year, its organizers, Brian and Anna Haughton, aimed to set it off from other art fairs by including an equal number of European and American dealers, all of them unmistakably blue chip, and by limiting the selection to works done between 1300 and 1900. The special allure of the exhibition lay in the chance it provided to see Old Masters and museum-quality works normally visible only by appointment, if at all. Evidently, it was a success, for the fair is back again with an even more glittering roster of exhibitors, ranging from Piero Corsini of New York to Richard Green of London to Galerie Segoura of Paris.

title: Mitterrand Criticized for Words on German War Dead
description: President Francois Mitterrand has stirred a new controversy in his final days in office with two speeches on the reconciliation of France and Germany after World War II.

title: Ex-School Head Pleads Guilty
description: Vito Dellegrippo Jr., the former director of the Point Pleasant Community School, pleaded guilty yesterday to stealing $2,300 in school board funds.

title: Love, Peace, Money, Lawsuits; Vendors and Charities Feel Cheated by Woodstock Promoters
description: Last summer, Susan Acosta, the director of a substance abuse treatment program in Ulster County, heard about a golden opportunity to raise money. If she could round up 110 of her people -- recovering addicts, counselors, volunteers -- to sell sausages and peppers from a booth at the Woodstock '94 festival, then the promoters would donate 8 percent of the booth's sales to her charitable organization.

title: Devils Expect Stevens On the Ice for Game 4
description: Steam was slowly running out of Brian Sutter's coffee cup this morning, just as it had slowly run out of the Devils on Wednesday night after their captain, Scott Stevens, was flattened by Bryan Smolinski and forced to leave Game 3 of their first-round playoff series.

title: Nancy Sinatra Returns, Swathed in Leather
description: Of course Nancy Sinatra wore boots to play the Limelight on Wednesday night. They were knee-high, black-leather, spike-heeled boots; they weren't just made for walking, but for swaggering. They went with a black leather miniskirt, a satiny orange blouse and, when she made her entrance, a motorcycle jacket and sunglasses. In one of the least expected of comebacks, the 54-year-old Ms. Sinatra has returned as a preserved version of her 1960's self: "a wicked chick," as she called herself in one song.

title: Another Big Lead Turns Into Another Big Loss
description: For the second time in a week, what looked like a victory for the Knicks became a crushing defeat.

title: Pursuing an Assassin, 130 Years Later
description: More than 125 years after a body identified as that of John Wilkes Booth was buried in a large family plot in the Green Mount Cemetery in Baltimore, two members of the Booth family are asking a court to allow that it be exhumed. They want to know if it actually is Booth, the actor who assassinated President Lincoln at Ford's Theater here in 1865.

title: PRESIDENT OF DOW CHEMICAL IS NAMED CHIEF
description: The president and chief operating officer of the Dow Chemical Company, William S. Stavropoulos, was named chief executive yesterday at Dow's annual meeting, succeeding Frank P. Popoff, who will remain chairman. Mr. Stavropoulos, who is 55, joined the company as a chemist in 1967. He was named president and chief operating officer in 1993. Mr. Popoff, 59, has been chief executive since 1987, and was named chairman in 1992. Mr. Popoff will relinquish his chief executive duties on Nov. 1 in conjunction with his 60th birthday. Dow also said it would raise its quarterly dividend by 15 percent; the company will pay a quarterly dividend of 75 cents a share on July 28 to shareholders of record on June 30.

As Frank, the leader of a trio of murderous robbers, Timothy Patrick Cavanaugh gives an icily matter-of-fact portrayal of a snappish young thug who blithely blows people's brains out when his patience wears thin. That usually takes less than two minutes.

Yesterday, after two days of searching by the police, his parents, Joseph and Lisa, appealed for the public's help in finding him, and a 24-hour number -- (201) 592-3500 -- was opened.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on April 30 about the smuggling of the coolant Freon into the United States misstated the extent of the ban that takes effect at the end of the year on the production of chlorofluorocarbons. The ban involves the Freon used in auto air-conditioners and in most refrigerators. The ban does not extend to HCFC-22, the coolant used in home air-conditioners. Its production is permitted in the United States until the year 2020 and elsewhere until 2030.

title: Making a Mountain Out of a Hill
description: The slender charms of Christopher Monger's semi-autobiographical film about Welsh villagers begin with its title: "The Englishman Who Went Up a Hill, but Came Down a Mountain." That's a name stubborn and unwieldy enough to do its Welsh story proud. It's also redolent of the film's overriding quirkiness, which is its most likable quality. Mr. Monger isn't a world-class eccentric like Bill Forsyth ("Local Hero") or Peter Chelsom ("Hear My Song"), but his sweetly picturesque film is full of affection for the oddballs who make Ffynnon Garw their home.

Employee Benefit Plans, based in Minneapolis, provides managed health care services to self-financing employers. The company did not identify the suitor and said there was no guarantee that an agreement would be reached. Shares of Employee Benefit Plans rose $2.625, to $12, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Over 100 Gold Miners Killed in South African Accident

title: You're Cute, but No Arnold Ziffel
description: Gordy is a cute pink piglet whose family is hauled away from their home on an Arkansas farm to an ominous place they call "up north" (translation: sausage factory). All the animals in "Gordy" talk. Unfortunately, their voices are so badly synched and the acting so false that the effect is as if a tiny child were putting on a puppet show. "You're the man of the family now," the father pig tells Gordy. Imagine this line in a fake deep voice coming out of a sock, and you'll have a sense of how flat and low-rent a children's movie "Gordy" is.

title: Restaurants
description: Each time I sit in the serenely peaceful Japanese dining room at Otabe, I imagine the chef in the kitchen gnashing his teeth and tearing his hair. Kazuyuki Azumaya specializes in the cuisine of Kyoto, and his kaiseki dinners are exquisitely wrought multi-course meals featuring seasonal ingredients. But looking around at the tables, I noticed that everyone seemed to be eating sushi. It must be terribly frustrating.

title: Producer Prices Rise as Retail Sales Fall
description: In what may prove remarkably good timing, a long-expected rise in inflation seems to be emerging just as the economy has decelerated enough to keep the increase in prices from climbing much further, Government figures suggested today.

Trumka, president of the United Mine Workers. While he is often mentioned as a possible candidate, he has not publicly said he would consider such a campaign, nor given any such indication.

title: Whatever You Do, Don't Sit Still!
description: CHILDREN aren't known for their ability to sit still. Put them in a hushed, darkened auditorium and within minutes they're climbing over and under the seats. Parents may be relieved, then, to learn that the Brooklyn Academy of Music fully expects its young audiences to be itching to move this weekend. In fact, at most of the productions of the academy's first International Children's Festival of Theater and Music, stony faces and folded hands are absolutely not allowed.

title: One-Upmanship Games In a Chinese Village
description: "Ermo" is a delicious, unexpectedly wry comedy from China about keeping up with the Joneses. The dour-faced heroine, Ermo, makes and sells noodles to support her ailing husband, a former village chief called Chief, and their son, Tiger. For Ermo, the Joneses are the couple next door in their peasant village: the slightly cross-eyed husband, called Blindman, and his snobbish wife, Fat Woman, who wears a bright orange, Western-style blazer and owns a color television.

title: ANTITRUST CHIEF HAS CONCERNS ABOUT T.W.A. PLAN
description: The Justice Department's antitrust chief said yesterday that she had "serious" concerns about the proposed settlement of a lawsuit involving caps on travel-agent commissions. Federal antitrust regulators said they were closely examining the settlement, announced earlier this week, in which Trans World Airlines Inc. and a national travel agents' group linked future commission levels to the amount of money the airline makes from ticket sales by travel agents. "An agreement between all travel agents and an airline to increase that airline's sales at the expense of other carriers raises serious competitive concerns," said Assistant Attorney General Anne K. Bingaman. In February, the leading airlines said they would cap at $50 the commission paid to travel agents for round-trip air tickets.

title: World News Briefs; Australia Believes Sect Tested Gas on Ranch

title: Coram Healthcare Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-Included a restructuring benefit of $ 4.1 million and an income tax benefit of $ 1.1 million.

title: Uno, Dos, Tres: A Miami Love Story
description: In a dream, Juan Raul Perez (Alfred Molina) sees a family on a beach. A woman in a flowing white dress carries a baby and a frilly white parasol. In their elegant white clothes, the entire family wades into the ocean. Juan Raul, the former owner of a sugar plantation, wakes in the Cuban prison where he has spent 20 years and soon arrives in Miami as part of the Mariel boatlift in 1980. He is camped with other refugees in the Orange Bowl, wearing a gaudy, faded flowered shirt.

title: Mercantile Exchange Sues State Over Gasoline Plan
description: In a highly unusual case, the New York Mercantile Exchange took the State of New Jersey to court yesterday, trying to save a program requiring use of a special blend of gasoline in the winter.

title: At the Bar; Brokerage firms steer dissatisfied customers away from court, but in only one direction.
description: The brokerage industry scored a big victory in 1987, when the United States Supreme Court ruled that stockbrokers could force customers to relinquish their rights to go to court with their complaints.

title: Haitian Children Make a Plea to Clinton
description: As more than 20,000 Cuban refugees prepare to leave the American naval base in Guantanamo Bay for the United States, 230 Haitian children and teen-agers who will be left behind are pleading with President Clinton to be admitted as well, saying in a letter, "We cannot hold on any longer."

title: Business as Usual in Kiev: By Taunt and Bribe
description: When the Kiev city government began building a six-lane highway through the parking lot of a modern, Western-managed office complex last month, the South African Ambassador to Ukraine, whose embassy is in the building complex, blocked the city's bulldozers with his Mercedes-Benz.

title: AMR SAYS EARNINGS WILL BE HURT BY TEXAS HAIL STORM
description: The AMR Corporation, the parent of American Airlines, said yesterday that losses from a hail storm in late April that disabled 55 jets in Dallas would hurt the company's second-quarter earnings. Industry analysts say losses from the storm could be as high as $50 million. AMR, based in Fort Worth, is expected to report earnings of 38 cents a share, according to an average estimate of 11 analysts surveyed by Zacks Investment Research. Steve Lewins, an analyst at Gruntal & Company, predicted yesterday that hail-related losses would cost AMR 20 cents to 30 cents a share, or almost $23 million. Shares of AMR rose 62.5 cents, to $68.25, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Cleaner, Popular, Costlier Gas
description: The average price of a gallon of regular unleaded gas in New Jersey jumped almost 6 cents last month to $1.13, and industry officials predicted an additional 2-cent rise by the end of June. They attributed 3 to 4 cents of the April increase to the cost of using reformulated fuel required by Federal clean-air guidelines.

title: Elek-Tek Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31

About Real Estate;
Investors See Potential In a Run-Down Building
description: A group of Manhattan investors who have acquired 30 formerly distressed properties in the last three years have purchased a run-down apartment building in the Clinton Hill area of Manhattan that was on the brink of foreclosure. The group plans to upgrade the building and improve its rent return.

title: A Gay Party and No Sad Undertones
description: Near the end of David Dillon's raucously funny comedy "Party," the noisiest of seven gay friends who have convened for an evening of campy repartee and salacious party games announces that the group is like "the Brady Bunch on Fire Island." His witty description of this combination gabfest and sexual show-and-tell is not far off the mark.

title: Bank Is Set to Study Sale of Trade Center
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey said yesterday that it had selected the Chemical Securities investment bank to examine whether it should sell the World Trade Center, which would allow the agency to focus more on its original mandate of transporting people and goods.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: PREVENTIVE CHILD WELFARE IS THREATENED

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF Robbins Leads L.P.G.A. After Round 1 Kelly Robbins, with two runner-up finishes in the last three weeks, used a good putting touch yesterday to shoot a five-under-par 66 at the DuPont Country Club course and take the first-round lead in the Ladies Professional Golf Association Championship in Wilmington, Del. Robbins, who had five birdies, finished one stroke ahead of a group of four players that included Patty Sheehan and Dottie Mochrie. Laura Davies, the defending tournament champion and the leading money winner on the L.P.G.A. tour this year, and Alice Ritzman were another stroke back at 68. Robbins has recorded six straight rounds below par, including five in a row in the 60's. Michelle McGann, who won the Sara Lee Classic in Nashville last week for her first tour victory in seven seasons, withdrew. She complained of allergies and severe headaches early in the week, a tour spokeswoman said. (AP) TENNIS Agassi Picks Up Victory in 51 Minutes Andre Agassi breezed into the quarterfinals of the German Open with a victory yesterday in Hamburg. Agassi, the world's top-ranked player, coasted to a 6-2, 6-1 victory over Slava Dosedel of the Czech Republic in 51 minutes. But Pete Sampras, No. 2 in the rankings, battled for three hard sets to win, 6-2, 3-6, 6-2, against Daniel Vacek, a Czech ranked No. 53. The $1.7 million clay-court tournament is a major warm-up for the French Open, which starts May 29. In the quarterfinals, Agassi plays Sergi Bruguera of Spain, the French Open winner two years in a row. Bruguera missed six weeks with a knee injury earlier this season and, by a twist of fate, a similar injury to Richard Krajicek allowed him to move into the last eight when the Dutchman pulled out, trailing by 3-0. Sampras will next play Wayne Ferreira, the South African who beat the 1993 champion, seventh-seeded Michael Stich of Germany, 7-5, 6-1. (AP) UPSETS KEEP ROLLING IN ITALY: Unseeded Shaun Stafford touched off another wave of upsets with a surprise victory yesterday at the Italian Open and powered her way into the quarterfinals. Stafford, at 65th in the world the lowest-ranked player left in the field, eased past No. 16-seeded Nathalie Tauziat of France, 7-6 (7-3), 6-2. In another surprise, fourth-seeded Gabriela Sabatini, a four-time Italian champion, self-destructed in a 2-6, 7-6 (7-3), 7-6 (8-6) loss to 13th-seeded Helena Sukova. A South African, Joanette Kruger, shocked fifth-seeded Anke Huber of Germany, 6-4, 7-6 (7-4). Mary Joe Fernandez, seeded sixth, became the second American to reach the quarterfinals when she breezed past Meredith McGrath, 6-1, 6-1. Mary Pierce, seeded No. 2, who has dual American and French citizenship, but plays out of France, defeated Irina Spirlea of Romania, 6-2, 6-0. (AP) FRANA IS BACK IN FORM: Javier Frana of Argentina, fully recovered from a serious case of hepatitis in 1994, toppled third-seeded Jason Stoltenberg of Australia in the second round of the United States clay court championships yesterday in Pinehurst, N.C. The 60th-ranked Frana, who also upset the 25th-ranked Stoltenberg four weeks ago, scored a hard-fought 2-6, 6-2, 6-4 victory to advance to the quarterfinals. Top-seeded Magnus Larsson of Sweden routed Nicolas Pereira of Venezuela, 6-2, 6-3. (Reuters) BOXING Savon of Cuba Is Heading to the Finals Felix Savon, on track to win his fifth heavyweight title, survived a hard-hitting Frenchman yesterday and led three Cuban boxers into tomorrow's finals of the world amateur championships in Berlin. Savon outpointed Christophe Mendy, 9-6. Cuba's defending champions, Juan Hernandez and Ariel Hernandez, also won. The two remaining Americans, the light heavyweight Antonio Tarver and the superheavyweight Lawrence Clay-Bey, fight their semifinal bouts today. (AP)

description: More than 170 nations agreed today to extend in perpetuity a treaty that has limited the spread of nuclear arms for a quarter of a century.

description: President Clinton came to this capital today to begin a two-day celebration of Ukraine's striking new willingness to surrender its nuclear weapons and embrace a market economy.

title: Who Will Be the World's Doctor?
description: The rare but terrifying Ebola virus has emerged from its hiding place in the African rain forests once again to kill scores of people in Zaire. The virus -- one of a host of emerging viruses that have medical scientists worried -- becomes an unbelievable nightmare on the infrequent occasions it invades the human body. It turns internal organs to mush, causes profuse bleeding from virtually every orifice, and typically kills 90 percent of those infected. There is no vaccine to prevent it, no drug to treat it, not even a clue as to what animal or insect serves as its normal reservoir until some luckless human comes into contact and is infected.

title: GAP INC. (GPS,N)
description: Gap Inc. said yesterday that its fiscal first-quarter earnings fell 21 percent because of lower profit margins and declining same-store sales at its flagship Gap stores.

title: Disney and Developer Are Chosen To Build 42d Street Hotel Complex
description: In the first tangible sign that the long-awaited redevelopment of a tawdry stretch of Eighth Avenue is more than a pipe dream, the Disney Development Company and a large New York developer were chosen yesterday to build a huge hotel, entertainment and retail complex on 42d Street at Eighth Avenue.

title: The Course Of an Affair To Forget
description: "Nina Takes a Lover," a vapid romance about a woman's brief affair with a mysterious photographer, relies so heavily on acting subtext that it forgets to supply meaningful dialogue for that subtext to illuminate. As its lovers coyly tango into bed, the film confuses dark, meaningful gazes and stumbling monosyllabic conversation with insight and feeling.

title: Teplice Journal; Grown-Up Ways Are Baffling, and Children Pay
description: The E 55 highway from this spa town to Germany, once a little-traveled road to a heavily guarded cold-war frontier, has become a route of garish prostitutes, greedy pimps, free-spending German clients in smart cars and a tragic consequence: babies dumped as orphans.

title: Cinemark USA Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: Cinemark USA attributed its increased revenues in the latest first quarter to admission and concession price increases and the addition of 88 screens since the year-ago quarter.

title: The Spoken Word
description: "IN THE AMERICAN EXPERIENCE," Graduate School of the City University of New York, 33 West 42d Street, Manhattan. A free symposium on American culture to celebrate the 80th birthday of the writer Alfred Kazin, who will be present; participants include the author E. L. Doctorow; Sean Wilentz, a history professor from Princeton University; Leon Wieseltier, literary editor of The New Republic; Daniel Aaron, a cultural historian and author; Michael Kazin (Alfred's son), a history professor at American University; Christine Stansell, a history professor at Princeton, and Anthony Lewis, a New York Times columnist. Today, 9 A.M. to 5 P.M. Free. Information: (212) 642-2641. "MOTHER-DAUGHTER CONNECTION," 92d Street Y, at Lexington Avenue. A panel discussion with mothers and daughters, including Kitty Carlisle Hart, chairman of the New York State Council on the Arts, and Dr. Catherine Hart, an internist, and Carol Jenkins, a television newswoman, and her daughter, Elizabeth Hines, a student at Yale. Sunday at 8:15 P.M. Tickets: $16. Information: (212) 996-1100.

title: No Headline
description: "Here you didn't have to know the judge. You only had to know the data entry clerk." ROBERT M. MORGENTHAU, Manhattan District Attorney, describing a welfare fraud. [ B6:3. ]

title: Also of Note
description: Critics' choices of some other Manhattan art shows: LYNN DAVIS, Houk-Friedman Gallery, 851 Madison Avenue, near 70th Street (through tomorrow). The landscapes and travel photos in this retrospective are for the most part simply composed, and printed with an undeniable elegance. But however handsome, few of the pictures go much beyond that (Charles Hagen).

title: Mother Tapes Video Plea to Teen-Age Girl Who Ran Off With Teacher
description: The mother of a 15-year-old Manhattan girl who ran off with her junior high teacher pleaded publicly yesterday for her daughter to come home, telling her in a broken-voiced appeal: "You didn't do anything wrong. We can work anything out."

title: Budget Cuts Threaten Effort To Preserve Families at Risk
description: Denise Richardson, 18, was pregnant with her second daughter when her boyfriend was murdered. Depressed and scared, she flipped through the Yellow Pages and phoned a social service agency near her home in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn.

title: The word on Madison Avenue is 'Partners,' partner, and you can't have too many.
description: ALONG Madison Avenue, the phrase of the day seems to be "Put 'er there, partner."

description: The Federal Communications Commission today rejected efforts by seven states, including New York and California, to regulate prices of cellular telephone service.

title: Boston Chicken Bets on Manhattan
description: Today, when Boston Chicken Inc. opens one of its new concept stores in Manhattan, company executives said, it will be both an end and a beginning of sorts.

title: Leo Hofeller; Magazine Editor, 88
description: Leo Hofeller, a former executive editor of The New Yorker, died on Wednesday at his home in Seattle. He was 88.

title: FRONTIER TO ACQUIRE 2 TELECOMMUNICATIONS COMPANIES
description: The Frontier Corporation, a long-distance telephone company based in Rochester, said yesterday that it would acquire Schneider Communications Inc. for about $127 million. The deal will also give Frontier a majority stake in the Link USA Corporation of Cedar Rapids, Iowa, a provider of calling-card and operator services to long-distance companies. Schneider Communications, a long-distance provider with about 11,000 customers, is being sold by Schneider National Inc., a trucking company based in Green Bay, Wis. Under the deal, Frontier will also get Schneider's 80.8 percent stake in Link USA.

title: Brogna Earns Star By Playing Like One
description: John Franco is a hockey fan, and he knows hockey lingo. So Franco, the Mets' closer, knew what to call Rico Brogna after last night's game against Atlanta. He called Brogna the "first star" of the game. The honor was well-deserved.

title: Making Magic Out of Videos, or Trying To
description: The video artist Gary Hill might be called a magic theorist. His midcareer survey at the Guggenheim Museum SoHo, an impressive presentation of 13 video installations from the last decade, is as contradictory as the term implies. One minute, Mr. Hill's multi-monitor installations will dazzle you with their technical prowess and visual intelligence, their palpable ambition and above all their utter faith in video as an art form equal to all others. The next minute, and too many after that, they may bore you silly.

title: SHARES OF KELLOGG RISE ON GOLDMAN RECOMMENDATION
description: Shares of the Kellogg Company surged yesterday after Goldman, Sachs & Company recommended that investors buy the stock. A Goldman, Sachs analyst, Nomi Ghez, raised her recommendation to "buy" from "market performer," according to a research official at the firm. Shares of Kellogg, the cereal company based in Battle Creek, Mich., gained $3.50, to $66.125, on the New York Stock Exchange, after trading as high as $66.875. The company's shares surged last month after strong first-quarter earnings persuaded investors that the cereal industry would not engage in a price war.

title: Questions at L.P.G.A. Not About Game
description: The best players in women's golf tried in vain today to focus on their game but could not avoid confronting the controversy over lesbianism on the tour that dominated the second round of play at the Ladies Professional Golf Association's McDonald's Championship.

title: Remembering Waco, and Stealing It
description: The timing of the Oklahoma City bombing, two years to the day after the Federal raid on David Koresh's followers outside Waco, Tex., raised the question of a connection. And, indeed, there is apparently a link between the two April 19 tragedies -- but it does not run both ways. The raid on the compound at Mount Carmel has led to a political crusade, albeit one that the survivors haven't joined and don't even approve of.

description: When he decided in mid-1993 to learn more about the White House plan to overhaul the nation's health care system, Representative John R. Kasich, then a fairly obscure Republican from Ohio, went to the top: he invited Hillary Rodham Clinton, the architect of the plan, to his town house for dinner.

title: Observer; Time For The Pain
description: It is a question of pain. Everyone agrees there must be pain for everybody, though something in the manner of those who talk of pain's necessity hints that they themselves expect exceptions will be made in their cases.

title: SPECULATION ON NOVELL TALKS HELP LIFT BORLAND
description: peculation that Novell Inc. is in talks to acquire Borland International Inc. sent shares of Borland up more than 11 percent yesterday, while Novell shares rose 3 percent. Analysts and investors said speculators were buying Borland shares on the rumored takeover talks between the two software companies. Officers at Borland, based in Scotts Valley, Calif., and Novell, based in Provo, Utah, had no comment. Analysts said the combination made some sense for Novell, which might want full control of the Borland data base Paradox that Novell sells in its bundle of software programs. Borland's stock rose $1, to $9.875 a share, in Nasdaq trading. Novell stock climbed 62.5 cents, to $21.125 a share.

title: Larmer Strikes the Final Blow in an Uphill Battle
description: The Rangers are one victory from an upset of the Quebec Nordiques in the first round of the Stanley Cup playoffs. In another nasty, brutal battle filled with dangerous play and one major controversy, they beat the Nordiques by 3-2 last night at Madison Square Garden on a goal by Steve Larmer in the ninth minute of overtime.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK CITY THE LAST SUMMER VACATION? This may be the last year of traditional summer vacations for some students in New York City schools as officials try to move the system into year-round schooling. For students at two schools, the change might come as early as the next school year, said Schools Chancellor Ramon C. Cortines. Page 23. JUVENILE PROGRAM LOWERS RECIDIVISM Julio A. told juvenile justice officials that the three days he spent at Spofford Detention Center in the Bronx last year were the worst of his short life. At 14, he and a couple of his friends had been arrested for a robbery in his Brooklyn neighborhood. Julio was put on probation and voluntarily enrolled in New York City's Juvenile Justice Aftercare program, which tries to keep teen-age offenders out of trouble once they are released from detention. Page 23. TOUGHNESS OR WEAKNESS IN BARGAINING? The contract with school bus drivers that Mayor Giuliani proudly unveiled could save the city $400 million over the next five years, as the administration contends. But it is a measure of Mr. Giuliani's reputation for toughness at the bargaining table that many union leaders and labor experts actually saw the contract as a glimpse of possible weakness. Page 23. LEADER OF DRUG GANG GETS LIFE IN PRISON The leader of a drug gang that committed at least three murders in South Jamaica, Queens, was sentenced to life in prison in Federal District Court in Brooklyn, two years after his conviction. Judge Raymond J. Dearie ordered Gerald Miller, 32, of Queens Village, to serve a life term without parole. Page 23. REGION A NOMINEE WITHDRAWS Facing what appeared to be an unwinnable confirmation battle, Kay Wall, the most criticized of Gov. John G. Rowland's five nominees to the State Board of Education, withdrew from consideration. Page 24. PROPOSED NUCLEAR DUMP DIVIDES TOWN Nuclear power is part of the rhythm of life in Salem, Conn., as the mills were once, and the farms before that. Connecticut, in fact, relies more on nuclear energy than all but two states, and every last bit of it is in Salem's backyard. But some people are now saying that Salem's easy familiarity with rads and rems has gone too far. Our Towns by Kirk Johnson, page 24. RUTGERS STUDENTS FACE LESSER CHARGES Eleven Rutgers University students have been charged with disorderly conduct stemming from an April 12 protest. Though several students scuffled with police officers, an official said that they would not be charged with assault because the authorities were concerned about endangering their futures. Page 24. POKER PLAYERS SETTLE WITH METRO-NORTH Four men who were arrested last year for playing poker aboard a commuter train bound for Westchester County will get an undisclosed amount of money in a settlement reached with the Metro-North Commuter Railroad, officials of the railroad said. As part of the settlement, the men dropped a $4 million civil suit in which they claimed that they had been falsely arrested by the Metro-North police. Page 22. OFFICER PLEADS GUILTY TO DRUG CHARGES A New York City police officer who played a crucial role in an inquiry that led to the corruption arrests of 16 city officers last week has pleaded guilty to drug charges in Rockland County, law enforcement officials said. The officer, Timothy Zaccardo, 31, entered guilty pleas for three misdemeanor counts relating to possession of cocaine. Page 22.

title: A Use for the Useless Yugo
description: The Yugo flopped as a cheap compact car, but it makes a smashing work of pop art. Students and graduates of the School of Visual Arts in New York City have converted 28 dead Yugos into 28 lively creations on display through May 26 in the spacious old waiting room at Grand Central Terminal.

title: Larmer Makes a Little Noise
description: Scoring overtime goals is like saving money or eating right or a lot of other good things in life. It's nice if you begin doing it in your youth, but it's never too late to start.

title: They Play Like Amateurs, and They're Darned Proud of It
description: The Beastie Boys have been making records since 1981, and making hits since 1986. They still sound like amateurs, and that's the best and worst thing about them. At the Nassau Coliseum in Uniondale, L.I., on Thursday night, they had an arena full of teen-agers jumping, slam-dancing and shouting along to low-fi sounds that could have been assembled in someone's basement.

description: Year-ago first quarter's share earnings and shares outstanding are pro forma. The company went public in November 1994.

title: On Hearing the First Hoot-Hoot of Spring
description: If you have a holey old cast-iron wood stove, you know what a constant preoccupation fussily feeding it can become. The phoebes, cardinals and grosbeaks sing; a deer, well-camouflaged, drifts down a line of trees; and you stuff the maple and birchwood in.

title: Hindemith's 'Mathis der Maler' as a Ballet
description: James Kudelka depicted a struggle for transcendence in "States of Grace," the often-compelling work that American Ballet Theater presented in its world premiere on Thursday night at the Metropolitan Opera House. This lofty creation's accompaniment was Paul Hindemith's "Mathis der Maler" Symphony, which, as conducted by Charles Barker, rang out with a stony majesty. So, too, Mr. Kudelka's images filled the large stage like monumental sculptures in motion.

title: Burl Ives Memorial
description: A memorial tribute to Burl Ives is to be held on Wednesday at 5:30 P.M. at Marble Collegiate Church, Fifth Avenue and 29th Street. Mr. Ives died last month at the age of 85. Appearing at the tribute, which is open to the public, will be the poet Maya Angelou; the folk singer Odetta; Guy Davis, a musician and actor; Christine Lavin, a folk singer; Julie Gold, a songwriter, and Dorothy Ives, the performer's daughter.

title: Sally Moffet, 63, Stage and TV Actor
description: Sally Moffet, a stage and television actress, died on Monday at her home in Upper Nyack, N.Y. She was 63.

title: Foster Mother Gets 32 Years
description: Superior Court Judge Louis F. Hornstine sentenced Giocondo Rivera to 32 years for creating "a time of living hell" for her four abused foster children, one of whom, a 7-year-old girl, was forced to eat a dead rat. The state had placed the siblings with the woman after they were neglected by their own cocaine-addicted mother. The children have since been placed in other homes.

title: U.S. Plans to Appeal Crown Hts. Ruling
description: The United States Justice Department plans to appeal a Federal judge's ruling that a black teen-ager, indicted on civil rights charges in the killing of a Hasidic student in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, in 1991, should be tried as a juvenile, a department spokesman said yesterday.

A Killer Racked by Delusions Dies in Alabama's Electric Chair
description: Varnall Weeks, a convicted killer described by psychiatric experts as a paranoid schizophrenic who believed he would come back to life as a giant flying tortoise that would rule the world, was put to death this morning in Alabama's electric chair.
