description: Sales are net sales.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball National League CINCINNATI REDS -- Placed Benito Santiago, catcher, on the 15-day disabled list, retroactive to May 8. Optioned John Courtright and Matt Grott, pitchers, to Indianapolis of the American Association. HOUSTON ASTROS -- Activated Chris Donnels, infielder, from the 15-day disabled list. Optioned Ricky Gutierrez, shortstop, to Tucson of the Pacific Coast League. MONTREAL EXPOS -- Signed Kash Beauchamp, outfielder, and assigned him to Harrisburg of the Eastern League. Football National Football League ARIZONA CARDINALS -- Named Craig Cason scout. CINCINNATI BENGALS -- Announced the retirement of Tom Waddle, wide receiver. Hockey National Hockey League N.H.L. -- Fined New Jersey Devils left wing Mike Peluso $1,000 for throwing an elbow at Boston Bruins center Jozef Stumpel during Wednesday night's playoff game. EDMONTON OILERS -- Announced they purchased the remaining 50 percent share of their A.H.L. affiliate from Sydney, Nova Scotia, and are now sole owners of the team.

title: It's Hard to Be Neutral About a Nuclear Dump
description: NUCLEAR power is part of the rhythm of life around here, as the mills were once, and the farms before that.

title: Suspect Dies And Officer Is Suspended
description: A police officer with a history of violent encounters during arrests has been suspended without pay after the death of a 22-year-old man he had subdued at a gasoline station here early Sunday morning.

title: JAZZ
description: A Tough America's Other, Hidden Side Bill Frisell, guitarist Village Vanguard

title: Corrections
description: The Our Towns column on April 25 about school integration in Montclair, N.J., misstated black enrollment at Montclair High School. It is 52.9 percent of the total, not 66.6 percent.

title: Myers (L.E.) (MYR,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: L.E. Myers said its newly acquired Harlan Electric and Sturgeon Electric operations made a substantial contribution to revenue and earnings and exceeded its expectations.

title: Executive Changes
description: AIR L.A. INC., Los Angeles, named Dennis W. Altbrandt chief executive, succeeding Wayne Schoenfeld, who continues as chairman. Also, William Hirsch was named president and chief operating officer, succeeding Timothy Clarey, who continues as senior vice president of market planning. CHASE MANHATTAN BANK, New York, named Andy Feldman manager of institutional marketing in its derivatives origination and structuring group, succeeding Mark Starr, who will move to the Chase office in London this month. CHEROKEE INC., Sunland, Calif., the casual apparel and footwear company, appointed Robert Margolis chairman and chief executive. CKE RESTAURANTS INC., Anaheim, Calif., the parent company of Carl Karcher Enterprises Inc., which operates Carl's Jr. restaurants, named Joseph N. Stein chief financial officer, succeeding Loren C. Pannier, who will assume the new post of senior vice president, treasurer, continuing his responsibilities for overall corporate financing activities. DELOITTE & TOUCHE, Wilton, Conn., named William Fowler, its regional managing partner in the Northwest and Pacific regions and the head of the company's office in Seattle, to be chief financial officer, succeeding Robert Pivik, who is retiring. LYNCH, JONES & RYAN INC., New York, said Stephen A. Blumenthal would join its Washington Research Group unit as a senior vice president, effective July 1. Mr. Blumenthal is counsel to the House Commerce Committee.

title: Terry Nichols Gets a Well-Known Lawyer
description: Terry L. Nichols, the second man charged in the Oklahoma City bombing, had a new lawyer appointed for him today: Michael E. Tigar, a widely known defender whose clients have included John Demjanjuk, the man accused of being a Nazi death-camp guard.

title: Court Seeks Financial Records
description: The mother of a cerebral palsy victim who had sued for some independence from his family must hand over her financial records by Friday or go to jail. Superior Court Judge Amos C. Saunders ordered Marjorie Jantzen of Wayne to surrender documents sought by the court since last fall. Her son, Donald Jantzen, 44, who can't speak or write, sued his mother and siblings in September, seeking control over a $600,000 medical malpractice settlement awarded a decade ago. He later tried to withdraw the suit, but the judge refused to dismiss the case pending an investigation into Mr. Jantzen's initial allegations that the money had been used to buy a family vacation home and invest in a business.

title: China Industrial Group Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: Shares outstanding assumes full conversion of convertible preferred shares issued in January 1994.

title: Romping About, Jazzily and Snazzily
description: David Parsons is a wonderfully likable and gifted performer. He has assembled a troupe of nine first-rate dancers. And the spirited, high-energy gala program he presented on Tuesday night at the opening of a two-week season at the Joyce Theater (175 Eighth Avenue, at 19th Street, Chelsea) brought many in his audience to their feet to cheer the company.

title: Thousands Turn Out to Cheer Clinton in Ukraine
description: President Clinton stood before an enormous outdoor rally in this capital today to pay another tribute to the course Ukraine has chosen since the Soviet Union's collapse.

title: At Cemetery in Zairian City, Grieving Friends Must Wait
description: Even the dead are dangerous in the heart of the Ebola virus epidemic.

title: Bluffing Has a Price
description: The contract with school bus drivers that Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani proudly unveiled on Thursday could save the city $400 million over the next five years, as the administration contends. But it is a measure of Mr. Giuliani's reputation for toughness at the bargaining table that many union leaders and labor experts actually saw the contract as a hint of his possible weakness.

title: U.N. Chief Orders Review of Peacekeeping Mission in Bosnia
description: The United Nations Secretary General, Boutros Boutros-Ghali, responding to the worsening plight of peacekeepers in Bosnia and Herzegovina, ordered a "fundamental review" today of a mission that has recently appeared hostage to a war it is unable to curb or control.

title: With Bomb Plot Suspect Held in Jail, Neighbors Help by Planting His Crops
description: Three weeks ago, Federal agents combed the flat brown fields of James D. Nichols's farm, searching for evidence of explosives. This week, his friends planted those fields with oats and barley.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Market Ignores Inflation As Stocks Continue Surge Stocks pushed higher, with the Dow Jones industrials rising 19.37 to a record 4,430.56, as traders ignored the strong hints of inflation in the Consumer Price Index for April and instead expressed confidence that the Federal Reserve would not need to raise interest rates again.

title: Serv-Tech Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
The Damages Bill Is Veto Bait
description: To fix a legal system that is not broken, the Senate has passed what it calls the "Product Liability Fairness Act of 1995." It is a political victory for the manufacturers and trade associations after a decade of expensive lobbying. The bill would ease the burden on manufacturers and product sellers to pay punitive damages when juries find that their products flagrantly and even deliberately -- not just negligently -- injure their customers.

title: Missing Boy Was at Friend's
description: Twelve-year-old Justin Cannady probably won't be able to come out and play this weekend. The boy, reported as missing when he failed to arrive home from school on Monday, was back safe at home yesterday after turning up in Queens. The authorities said he had walked across the George Washington Bridge and taken a subway to visit a friend, whose parents believed he had parental permission for the sleep over. His hosts learned differently on Thursday night when they saw a television news broadcast about the frantic search for the boy.

title: Cuba, in Ideological Retreat, To Lay Off Many Thousands
description: In an effort to make Cuba's sagging economy more efficient, the Government is abandoning one of the most cherished concepts of the Communist state, the guarantee of full lifetime employment, and has begun layoffs that are expected to eliminate hundreds of thousands of jobs.

title: Morgan Grenfell in Russia
description: Morgan Grenfell & Company of Britain said yesterday that it expected to open a brokerage firm and a depository company in Moscow next month, aiming to compete with CS First Boston. Last week, CS First Boston, the leading foreign-owned financial firm in Russian markets, was dealt a setback when its two co-directors and several top traders in Russia resigned. Morgan Grenfell, a unit of Deutsche Bank, said it would deal in Russian securities for domestic and foreign clients.

title: NEW YORK STATE ELECTRIC AND GAS PAY CUT DEFEATED
description: A stockholder proposal that would have cut the pay and other compensation of the top executives of the New York State Electric and Gas Corporation by 36 percent, the same percentage the dividend was cut in October, was defeated at the utility's annual meeting yesterday. The proposal, which was introduced by Edward Rudy, a stockholder from Manhattan, received 13.8 million shares in support, compared with 35.95 million shares against. The meeting was attended by about 700 in Dryden in upstate New York. Mr. Rudy said the vote showed that many stockholders were unhappy with the dividend cut.

title: WARCO TO BEGIN HOSTILE BID SOON FOR TURNER BUILDERS
description: The Warco Acquisitions Corporation said yesterday that it would soon begin a hostile offer to acquire the common stock in the Turner Corporation, the big international construction company, directly from shareholders. In response, Turner said it had "severe doubts" about Warco's credibility. Warco, an investment firm based in Huntington, L.I., which owns about 5 percent of Turner's shares, said it had made several overtures to Turner about a potential acquisition and was rebuffed. Turner, based in New York, said that two of Warco's principals, Richard LaCroix and Richard Reiben, approached Turner last December but failed to show up at a meeting with Turner's advisers. Turner's stock closed up $1.25, at $11.875, on the American Stock exchange.

title: King World Ousts Chief Financial Officer
description: King World Productions Inc., distributor of "Wheel of Fortune" and "The Oprah Winfrey Show," has dismissed its chief financial officer for conduct the television-program syndicator called inconsistent with his role.

title: 3 Are Convicted in Crime Spree
description: Three Newark men were convicted yesterday in a crime spree that spilled through the streets on a Saturday night in March 1994. Assistant Prosecutor Gary J. Bogdanski said the two-and-a-half-hour rampage began with several armed robberies and assaults, followed by a car theft, the shooting of a man on Central Avenue, the armed robbery of another at Summer Avenue, the shooting of a teen-ager and a woman on Sanford Avenue,, the robbery of three women on Leslie Street -- and the use of the stolen car as a weapon to ram a pursuing city police vehicle. A jury found Howard Caesar, 20, Nathaniel Troup, 21, and Carl Jacobs, 19, guilty of attempted murder, aggravated assault, robbery and weapons offenses.

title: Disney on 42d Street
description: The Times Square redevelopment plan, now 14 years old, has had its share of setbacks. But the dream of restoring glitz and glory to the seedy west end of 42d Street came another step closer to reality this week when the Disney Development Company and a New York partner committed to building a mammoth hotel, entertainment and retail complex on 42d Street and Eighth Avenue.

title: Killings That Broke the Spirit Of a Murder-Besieged City
description: Every killing added its own specific grief to the city, like water dripping in a bucket already too heavy to carry. In all, 21 people died violently in New Orleans from Feb. 25 to March 4, the bloodiest week in recent memory in a city with a record-setting murder rate.

title: Poker Dispute With Railroad Ends Well For 4 Players
description: Four men who were arrested last year for playing poker aboard a commuter train bound for Westchester County will get an undisclosed amount of money in a settlement reached with the Metro-North Commuter Railroad, officials of the railroad said today.

title: A Visa for Taiwan's President
description: The White House is pandering needlessly to China in refusing a visa to President Lee Teng-hui of Taiwan for a private visit to the United States. Mr. Lee has been invited to speak at Cornell University, where he earned his doctorate. This week the House and the Senate overwhelmingly approved nonbinding resolutions that Mr. Lee be granted a visa. The State Department is not budging. A spokesman declared a visit would have "serious consequences for United States foreign policy." President Clinton should overturn that judgment.

title: Celestial Chords In Gorgeous Array
description: On Friday night, I heard Mahler's Eighth Symphony in Carnegie Hall: it harnessed immense forces to a musical narrative of surprising swiftness, even brutal efficiency. Four nights later, I heard something no less gigantic: Morton Feldman's "For Philip Guston," which sent a small complement of musicians into music of vast dimensions. The flutist Petr Kotik, the pianist Joseph Kubera and the percussionist Chris Nappi, all members of the S.E.M. Ensemble, played this five-hour trio in the Paula Cooper Gallery in SoHo on Tuesday night; the audience was about a twentieth the size of Carnegie's, but the burst of stupefied pleasure at the end was just as intense.

title: Sturm Ruger & Co. (RGR,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Lifeguard Indicted on Forgery
description: A lifeguard who was reading a magazine when an 8-year-old nearly drowned March 27 at an indoor pool in Atlantic City was indicted on charges of falsifying her Red Cross credentials and endangering the welfare of a minor. Nicyce A. Smith, 36, was on duty during an after-school swimming program when the boy fell into 12-foot-deep water. After some children alerted her, Ms. Smith tried to rescue the child using a pole before jumping in herself. Lloyd Barksdale, a city Recreation Department worker, rescued both the child and the floundering Ms. Smith. The boy recovered after six days in the hospital. The incident led to the dismissal of Charles Goodman, the city's youth services director, who had ignored prior complaints from Mr. Barksdale about Ms. Smith's qualifications, city officials said.

title: Rothmans Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Tele-Communications Posts Loss Of 8 Cents a Share in 1st Quarter
description: Tele-Communications Inc., the nation's largest cable company, reported a net loss tonight of $45 million, or 8 cents a share, for the first quarter of 1995, in contrast to earnings of $32 million, or 7 cents a share, a year earlier. After dividend payments to preferred shareholders, the 1995 loss is $53 million.

title: RELIGIOUS LEADERS PREPARE TO FIGHT PATENTS ON GENES
description: Opening what could be a passionate new battle over religion and science, many mainstream religious leaders are about to start a campaign against a financial pillar of the biotechnology industry: the ability to patent human genes and genetically engineered animals.

title: Rubber Workers' Union Acts To Merge With Steelworkers
description: Seeking to shore up strength amid the declining fortunes of organized labor, the governing board of the United Rubber Workers union has approved a proposal to merge with the United Steelworkers of America.

title: Whose Music Is It?
description: To the Editor:

title: Jacome Can't Hold A Couple Of Leads
description: With the roster-trimming deadline rapidly approaching, it is still premature to speculate on whether Jason Jacome will be with the Mets when the major league rosters are frozen at 25. Perhaps a better question is will he remain in the starting rotation.

description: To the Editor:

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Loss to Bruguera Upsets Agassi Top-ranked Andre Agassi was upset by 12th-ranked Sergei Bruguera of Spain, 6-3, 6-1, in the quarterfinals of the German Open yesterday in Hamburg. Agassi was apparently very disturbed by the loss. While leaving the court, Agassi was heckled by a male spectator for his poor play and was told it was "a waste" of the spectator's time. Agassi swore at the spectator twice and brought up the stabbing of Monica Seles on the same court two years ago. "Are you going to get a knife?" Agassi asked, referring to the April 1993 stabbing. Agassi, who had 6 double faults and 35 unforced errors, said: "Some guy didn't like me that much. At least he had the decency to wait until the end of the match." Tournament officials said they were not planning any action. In other quarterfinals, No. 2 Pete Sampras advanced with a 6-2, 6-2 victory over Wayne Ferreira and will play Andrei Medvedev in the semifinals. Bruguera will meet Goran Ivanisevic, who beat Marc Rosset, 6-1, 6-3. (AP) LARSSON STOPS PALMER: Top-seeded Magnus Larsson survived three tie breakers and two match points in a 6-7 (7-5), 7-6 (7-2), 7-6 (8-6) victory over Jared Palmer in the quarterfinals of the United States Clay Court Championships in Pinehurst, N.C. Larsson's semifinal opponent will be Argentina's Javier Frana. Today's other semifinal will match second-seeded Thomas Enqvist of Sweden against an American, fourth-seeded David Wheaton. (AP) ROWING Temple Crew Is the One to Beat The Temple University men's heavyweight varsity eight won its qualifying heat by 6.6 seconds, or one and a half boat lengths, in the Dad Vail Regatta yesterday, indicating the Owls are again the crew to beat on the Schuylkill in Philadelphia. Temple has won the featured heavyweight title for the last 6 years, and 11 times in the last 12 years. The only eight to win its heavyweight heat in a time faster than Temple's 6 minutes 1.95 seconds was Drexel, which was clocked in 6:01.39. All 11 finals are today. BOXING Cuban Parade to World Finals Continues Three more Cuban fighters punched their way into the finals of the world championships yesterday in Berlin, but featherweight Raul Gonzalez, the 1992 Olympic silver medalist, was stunned by Zoltan Lunka of Germany in an 11-8 decision. The Cubans have won three bronze medals and sent six fighters into the weekend finals. The United States secured at least a silver medal when a light heavyweight, Antonio Tarver, registered a 9-6 decision over Vasily Yirov of Kazakhstan. A superheavyweight, Lawrence Clay-Bey, settled for the United States' other medal, a bronze, when he was outpointed, 5-2, by Aleksei Lezin of Russia. (AP)

title: SALE OF WATER-TREATMENT CONCERN HINTED
description: W. R. Grace & Company's new chief executive has indicated he plans to put the company's water-treatment unit up for sale in several months, company shareholders said yesterday. Analysts estimated that Grace Dearborn, based in Lake Zurich, Ill., which had $363.4 million in sales last year, could be sold for as much as $500 million. Mary Lou Kromer, a spokeswoman for the company, said Grace had no plans to divest itself of Dearborn, which provides water-treatment services for industrial boilers, cooling towers and industrial-process water systems.

title: Puritan-Bennett Corp.(PBEN,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
description: b-Included a charge of $ 200,000 for obligations associated with Thermo Electron Corp.'s unsolicited tender offer. Without the charge, earnings would have been 52 cents a share.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Senator DANIEL PATRICK MOYNIHAN had a cataract removed from his right eye on Tuesday morning, at his doctor's office in Washington. The 68-year-old Democrat was back on the job by afternoon but was advised not to fly anywhere for a few days. That turned out not to be a problem, not even for a peripatetic politician who likes to spend weekends on his farm in upstate New York: Mr. Moynihan was asked to appear tomorrow on the NBC News program "Meet the Press," which originates in Washington. JAMES BARRON

title: Hitchcock Leaves Red Sox Woozy
description: The Red Sox were supposed to be fresh after having had their Thursday game against the Baltimore Orioles rained out. The Yankees were supposed to be drained after having arrived here at 4:30 in the morning following an exhausting series with the Blue Jays in Toronto.

title: Now Magic Has Jordan's Number
description: After all the fuss and the fines, Orlando Magic Coach Brian Hill may have lent the best perspective of all: "It's not the number," he said. "It's the person inside the uniform."

title: A Soprano Who Conquers Bellini's Leaps and Scales
description: The operas that Eve Queler presents in concert form with her Opera Orchestra of New York are usually a bit rarer than "I Puritani," Bellini's tale of English Roundheads, Cavaliers and the woman whose family and lover are on different sides. The Metropolitan Opera has a production of the work (last heard in 1991), and the New York City Opera has presented it within the last decade.

Arthur Hill, Finance Executive And Ex-Ginnie Mae Chief, 46
description: Arthur J. Hill, a prominent Florida banker and securities executive who was one of the highest-ranking African-American officials in the Bush Administration, was found dead on Wednesday morning in his hotel room at the Airport Hilton in Elizabeth, N.J., where he had attended a dinner of the Republican Governors Association the night before. He was 46 and lived in Miami.

description: b-Included pretax charges of $ 4.5 million for litigation settlement and costs related to the decision to relocate its Australian plant operations. Excluding the impact of the charges, income before extraordinary item was $ 10 million, or 41 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 34 million, or $ 1.40 a share, for the year.The year-ago periods also included extraordinary losses of $ 320,000, or 1 cent a share, in the quarter and $ 15,820,000, or 65 cents a share, in the year, from debt extinguishment.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about an accord for indefinite extension of the Treaty on the Nonproliferation of Nuclear Weapons misstated the options facing the conference at which the accord was reached. The gathering was to choose among three options -- indefinite extension, extension for a fixed period and extensions for a series of fixed periods. Ending the treaty was not an option.

description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $ 1,371,000, or 15 cents a share, and a charge for adoption of FASB No. 112 of $ 739,000, or 8 cents a share.Revenue in both the latest and year-earlier periods are revenues from continuing operations.(Loss)

title: Evelyn Lincoln, Secretary To Kennedy, Is Dead at 85
description: Evelyn Lincoln, the devoted personal secretary who served President John F. Kennedy from the day he entered the Senate to the day he was assassinated, died on Thursday at Georgetown University Hospital in Washington. She was 85 and lived in Chevy Chase, Md.

title: Primark Corp.(PMK,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day on Thursday with articles about a large investment by the MCI Communications Corporation in the News Corporation misstated the amount each company will contribute to a new joint venture. It is $200 million, not $100 million.

title: Stocks Continue to Climb Despite More Inflation Hints
description: Stocks, the 30-year bond and the dollar all moved higher yesterday, with major stock indexes setting records. Traders ignored even stronger hints of inflation in the Consumer Price Index and continued in their confidence that the Federal Reserve would not raise interest rates.

title: International Briefs; Founders Selling Venture Company Stock
description: Four founding shareholders in the 3i Group, Europe's biggest venture capital company, will sell up to 20 percent of 3i's shares in June. The Bank of England, Lloyds Bank P.L.C., Barclays P.L.C. and the Midland Bank P.L.C., the holders that are selling shares, currently own about 32 percent of 3i. They first reduced their holdings when 3i became a publicly traded company.

description: The Homely Sounds of Home As Transformed by Strauss The New York Philharmonic Avery Fisher Hall

title: Keeping a Stern and Watchful Eye on Juvenile Offenders Is Paying Off, Officials Say
description: Julio A. told juvenile justice officials that the three days he spent at Spofford Detention Center in the Bronx last year were the worst of his short life.

title: The Little Pushcarts That Could; Malls Find a Revenue Engine in Updated Peddler's Wagons
description: When Shawna and Randy Heninger decided three years ago to go into business selling refrigerator magnets and personalized key chains from peddler's carts at the giant Mall of America here, most friends and relatives told them they were crazy. The young couple, who had a 3-year-old son, were abandoning secure jobs with the Internal Revenue Service and a comfortable home outside Salt Lake City.

title: Wheat Prices Surge as Planting Is Expected to Face Rain Delay
description: Wheat prices continued to surge yesterday, reaching their highest levels in three months as rains forecast for the Midwest threatened to delay spring planting until late in the season.

description: To the Editor:

title: Haiti Paramilitary Leader Is Found Hiding in Queens
description: If Mr. Constant, 38, is deported to Haiti, it will mark an important step in judicial reform in Haiti as officials there seek to punish those responsible for the deaths, rape and torture of thousands of Haitians after the coup that ousted President Jean-Bertrand Aristide in September 1991. Mr. Aristide was returned to office last October after 20,000 American soldiers landed there.

title: Rockefeller Center Filing May Mean Big Tax Bill
description: While the bankruptcy-law filing by Rockefeller Center saved the Mitsubishi Estate Company from pumping more money into the cash-short property, it could cost the Japanese company as much as $190 million in taxes, accountants and analysts said yesterday.

title: Virginia Picks Holland
description: Virginia reached into its past with an eye to the future yesterday, hiring the former men's basketball coach TERRY HOLLAND as its new athletic director.

description: To the Editor:

title: International Briefs; In Brief
description: * The Mobil Corporation agreed yesterday to acquire 72 service stations in the Netherlands from Elf Aquitaine S.A. of France. Terms were not disclosed. Mobil has 274 stations and 9 percent of the Dutch gasoline market. The additional Elf stations will put it third, with more than 10 percent.

title: Riley Believes Referees Show Little Respect For Ewing
description: The Knicks spent a long day here today, angry at referees, angry at themselves, and angry to be facing another dangerous situation.

title: Leucadia National Corp.(LUK,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-Included after-tax security gains of $ 412,000.c-Included pretax gain of about $ 8,458,000 associated with disposition of El Salvador government bonds and after-tax security losses of $ 1,467,000.Leucadia National's catastrophe losses in the latest first quarter was about $ 700,000, compared with $ 15,950,000 in year-ago period. The company said the catastrophe losses in the year-ago quarter included about $ 10,900,000 from the earthquake in Northridge, Calif.

title: Data Documents Holdings Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: Data Documents Holdings said operating earnings were $ 4.4 million in the latest first quarter, up 37.5 percent from $ 3.2 million a year ago.The company said its latest quarter's earnings reflected increases in all product categories, with significant increases in business forms and in pressure-sensitive labels.

title: Els's 61 Meets Great Expectations
description: For all the stir that accompanied his arrival as a full-time player on the Professional Golfers' Association Tour this year, the big man had been awfully quiet. During much of the early part of this golf season, Ernie Els, the latest rage of the age, last year's world money leader, made almost no noise.

title: For Chechens in Mountains, Fighting Is Winning
description: It is a lovely three-mile walk from the nearest village to this spectacular, lush hamlet in the Caucasus. Lovely except for the artillery thudding in the background, the helicopters buzzing the tree line, and the dull roar of tanks in the distance.

title: Two Year-Round Schools May Begin In September
description: This may be the last year of traditional summer vacations for some students in New York City schools as officials try to move the system into year-round schooling.

title: Golf Reporter And CBS Deny Remarks On Lesbianism
description: Ben Wright, the CBS golf reporter, and the network went on an aggressive attack yesterday against the newspaper that attributed to Wright remarks about the impact of lesbianism on the women's golf tour.

title: An Adversarial Relationship; Divorce Can Lead to War, Sometimes Between the Lawyers
description: As every lawyer knows, when negotiations in a case reach gridlock, it's time for a little arm-twisting.

title: Jeweler Is Robbed At Manhattan Hotel
description: A German jeweler who was visiting New York City to conduct business in the Diamond District was robbed at gunpoint yesterday in his room at the New York Palace hotel by two well-dressed bandits, the police and hotel officials said.

title: No Headline
description: "There is no winning. We know that. If we are fighting, we are winning. If we are not, we have lost. The Russians can kill us all and destroy this land. Then they will win. But we will make it very painful for them." -- KHAMZAT ASLAMBEKOV, a Chechen officer. [ 1:3. ]

title: CHRONICLE
description: Speaking of talented young scholars, KATHLEEN TRESEDER has accomplished something that most researchers only dream about: a cover article in Nature, the scientific journal. As if that was not unusual enough, she did the research when she was an undergraduate, at the University of Utah.

title: Grey Advertising Inc.(GREY,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: Revenue is commissions and fees.

title: IMO INDUSTRIES WILL SELL BUSINESSES TO LITTON
description: Imo Industries of Lawrenceville, N.J., said yesterday that it would sell most of its military-related businesses to Litton Industries. Imo will sell most of the operations of its Varo Inc. and Baird Optical Systems units, both of which are based in Dallas and make night-vision goggles and certain laser systems. title:
THING;
Poems Are Made by Refrigerator Magnets Like These
description: WHAT: Magnetic Poetry, 440 tiny magnetic word tiles intended to evoke the Ovid in everyone. Magnetic Poetry has its origins in writer's block. Whenever Dave Kapell, 33, a Minneapolis songwriter, felt creatively choked he would scribble words on strips of paper and rearrange them in various orders, a common exercise for poets. Then one day a friend who worked in a pizza parlor gave him a stack of refrigerator magnets. Having sneezed, wiped and spilled much of his work into oblivion, it dawned on Mr. Kappell that gluing his words to the magnets would give his verse staying power. True enough. Though hit singles are still elusive, Mr. Kapell is no longer struggling. Magnetic Poetry sales, which at $19.95 a kit recently topped 200,000 after 18 months, have bought him a house and a car. "I'm quickly becoming bourgeois," Mr. Kappell said.ALREADY A MUSEUM PIECE: Magnetic Poetry is sold at many museum gift shops and other specialty boutiques. More important is where you can use it, which is basically on anything with magnetic force; most popular are refrigerator doors, filing cabinets, cookie sheets and car hoods.STARS ARE ATTACHED: Kits are known to have been purchased by Tim Robbins, Daryl Hannah and Gloria Steinem. Mr. Kappell personally gave one to Uma Thurman. Last Christmas, he sold them in bulk to executives at Paramount and Columbia Studios in Hollywood. "Perhaps they were trying to give screenwriters a hint," Mr. Kappell conjectured. Mr. Kapell says he hopes Magnetic Poetry will help "subvert the mentality that only people with berets can write and read poetry." Truth is, he didn't much enjoy the genre at the University of Minnesota. "I got turned off trying to understand Ezra Pound and all of T. S. Eliot's Catholic references," he said. "I want to rebel against this fad of poetry slams where all these pretentious, tortured artists read such garbage."WHAT REAL POETS THINK: "It's a fabulous way of seeing how words rub up against each other," said Jonathan Galassi, president of the Academy of American Poets. Georgia Shreve, a poet, uses the game as a learning tool for third graders. "It's particularly useful when teaching the style of E. E. Cummings, who liked short and simple words," Ms. Shrieve said.THE POWER OF WORDS: "I'm not saying I'm John Lennon but I am beginning to realize that if my product is someone's first exposure to poetry, then I do have a certain responsibility, because it can change people's lives," Mr. Kapell said. He's not being immodest. There's the child psychologist whose 10-year-old patient expressed the pain of incest through a poem written with Magnetic Poetry. And the 85-year-old woman who wrote in to say: "I found a part of myself I didn't know existed."FUTURE VERSE: Already out is Magnetic Poetry for children, with larger letters and child-oriented words like "mom," "dad," and "dinosaur." "No diminutives like doggy or kitty," Mr. Kapell exhorted, ever aware of his influence. Soon to come is a romance version that will contain lots of "loves," "candlelights" and "touches," as well as some semi-erotica like "skin," "breast," "stomach" and "thigh." Mr. Kapell says he chooses words based on their multiplicity. For instance, "behind" can serve as an adverb or a preposition, but also as a noun.

Some arrive from the rutted remoteness of their villages in Mercedes-Benzes equipped with cellular telephones. But make no mistake. title: La Lance et la Boule
description: LAST August, just about the time the major leaguers were going on strike, an American boy introduced la lance et la boule to an assemblage of villagers more familiar to a reader of Gustave Flaubert than Ring Lardner. The American's name was Rory, and he was in Kerdelan, in the dirt square where Breton farmers once threshed wheat, because his parents had, years ago, bought a ruined stone house smack dab in the middle of the village.

title: Barbara Snitzer and David Solit
description: Barbara Sylvia Snitzer, the daughter of Gail and Edward Snitzer of Rydal, Pa., was married last evening to David Brian Solit, a son of Linda and Dr. Robert Solit of Elkins Park, Pa. Rabbi William I. Kuhn officiated at Congregation Rodeph Shalom in Philadelphia.

title: A Towering Presence And a Complex Figure
description: Ferdinand Lewis Alcindor Jr. was almost always taller than anyone else his age; this is a central definer of his public and private life. He was always far away. He was also usually smarter and more sensitive. It is no surprise that Alcindor will be inducted into basketball's Hall of Fame tomorrow, as Kareem Abdul-Jabbar. Or that he is still what he seemed to be as a teen-ager, a seeker, one of SportsWorld's more complex, fascinating, evolving characters.

title: The Kings of Calisthenics
description: They came. They saw. They jumped, ran in circles, pushed up, sat up and pulled up. They even Scrabbled. And when the South Bronx High School men's fitness team returned home last week from the National Youth Physical Fitness Championships, at the Marine Corps Recruiting Depot in San Diego, they had conquered.

title: Managers Developing Team Spirit
description: TO help mutual fund investors make educated decisions, the Securities and Exchange Commission told fund companies a year ago to disclose the name of their managers in the primary fund document, the prospectus. Fund companies are reluctant to do so, however, fearing investors might follow the managers if they leave the company. So more and more fund companies are taking advantage of the exemption allowed for funds run by teams. A search of the data base of Morningstar Inc., the fund tracking service in Chicago, showed that 35.5 percent of all funds were listed with "team management" at the end of April, up from 30 percent a year ago and 26 percent at the end of 1992. Pay Practices

title: Cooling Off With the Girl From Ipanema
description: STROLLING, JOGGING or rollerblading on the sidewalks along Rio de Janeiro's famous beaches calls for a thirst quencher with a tropical twist. On a hot summer day, one of the kiosks along the sands of Copacabana, Ipanema and Leblon will sell as many as 150 chilled coconuts. Insist that yours be "bem gelada," good and cold. Then watch the vendor's skill as he hacks a hole for your sipping straw into the fresh green globe. The taste is subtle but sweetly pleasant. A coconut bought along the beach is about $2.30. If you're energetic, you can break off a piece of the shell and use it to carve out some coconut meat for a healthy snack.

title:
HOME CLINIC;
Color Balance and Harmony, or What Works Well in a Room
description: IT is not easy to chose a color scheme for a room. Unfortunately, most homeowners do not have the time to learn the theory of color balance and harmony before putting a room together. There are no hard and fast rules for picking colors. It is a matter of personal taste. Nevertheless, guides and suggestions based on color theory and the results of research by psychologists and behavioral scientists can help.

title: Admirer of the U.S. in Recital
description: ELENA IVANINA craved the latest American music as a teen-ager studying the piano in Moscow. But while the authorities allowed the work of George Gershwin to be played, the music of more contemporary composers could be heard only underground.

title: Unfair Market
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Young Man With a Mission Takes Up the Fiedler Baton
description: THE BOSTON POPS, THE bestknown, most recorded and arguably most popular orchestra in the United States, just opened its season at Symphony Hall under a new music director, Keith Lockhart, a little-known, 35-year-old American conductor. To find a comparable vote of confidence in a young American by a vested orchestral institution, one has to look back to 1930, when the Boston Pops was turned over to another little-known 35-year-old, Arthur Fiedler.

title: Journal; Gingrich Family Values
description: "Why do we have all these problems we didn't have in 1955?" asked Newt Gingrich rhetorically last Sunday on "Meet the Press." Tim Russert had just asked the Speaker to defend his incendiary past statements linking Susan Smith's infanticide and Woody Allen's sex life to the platforms of the Democratic Party. Mr. Gingrich held firm, attributing America's post-1955 social decay to "a long pattern of counterculture belief . . . deep in the Democratic Party" that had "undervalued the family" and "consistently favored alternative life styles."

title: A QUESTION FOR: Joan Rivers
description: Q: Have you ever regretted anything you've said? A: Remember all the Elizabeth Taylor jokes, which I did when she was fat? When she was fat! "She has more chins than a Chinese phone book." "She's the only woman to stand in front of a microwave oven and scream, 'Hurry!' " "When she went to Sea World, she saw Shamu and said, 'Does he come with vegetables?' " I regretted those. So I had a mutual friend call her up, to see if it was hurting her, to say that I was starting to regret this and that I'd stop. And she sent back a message saying, "It doesn't get me where I live." From then on, I was crazy about her. People say a lot of things, and then you wake up the next morning and think, "I shouldn't have said that." Oh! Here's an O. J. Simpson joke! I bet Ron Goldman regrets saying: "I'll take those glasses! I'll be passing right by. Oh sure, it's not out of my way!"

description: FROM the outside and in, First Church in Windsor, United Church of Christ, looks like a lot of other New England churches: an old white clapboard building anchored near the center of town and a congregation characterized more by ordinariness than anything else.

description: Jim and Laura Butterworth opened their bagel place two years ago, and by now it has the air of a bed and breakfast without the bed - or, as Mr. Butterworth puts it, a "neighborhood bar without the fights."

title: The World; The Land That Can't Be Named
description: TO an outsider, it is hard to fathom how countries can quarrel over a name -- not over ideology or territorial aggression, but a name. Yet that is precisely what Greece and Macedonia are doing. They disagree intensely over whether Macedonia, which seceded from Yugoslavia at the outset of its turmoil in 1991, can call itself "Macedonia."

The View From: New Rochelle;
Lessons of Life and Death as Gleaned From a Tankful of Fish
description: WELCOME to the fish farm. The Isaac E. Young Middle School fish farm here, that is, where 100 brook trout swim in a 3,600-gallon tank -- actually an above-ground swimming pool -- and more than 100 sixth, seventh and eighth graders learn about everything from piscine biology to water chemistry.

title: Mass-Produced Designs, An Early Master
description: COLLECTORS WHO would not dream of owning anything that was not handmade fall all over themselves when it comes to objects by Christopher Dresser, Britain's first industrial designer. His works were produced by machines and look much like what his contemporaries in the Arts and Crafts movement did by hand.

title: Corrections
description: An article on April 30 about charity among the wealthy misstated the amount pledged by Ronald O. Perelman, chairman of Revlon Inc., to build a student center at the University of Pennsylvania. Shortly before the article was published, he increased his pledge to $20 million from $10 million.

title: Upper Crust
description: IT SEEMS silly to talk about the fish at a pizza parlor, but that's the beauty of Star Tavern "World Famous Pizzeria." When the owner finds good fish, he puts it on the menu, and for a ridiculous price.

title: What the Critics Can't Wait to See
description: If "Kids" lives up to its advance word (and if Miramax does in fact release it this summer), this frank movie about casual sex and drug taking among New York teen-agers may ignite audiences who think that its cast members look like jail bait. Larry Clark, a well-regarded photographer, makes his directing debut with the film, which seems destined for an NC-17 rating. With "Kids," written by a 19-year-old fellow whom Mr. Clark met in Washington Square Park, Hollywood may finally be catching up to television talk shows in portraying the discontent of the under-18 set without a sentimental gloss. -- Stephen Holden

title:
INVESTING IT;
The Latest Flight to Gold Lacks Rising Fares
description: Like Olympic hopefuls, some investors are making a run for the gold. But in one more proof of the metal's quirkiness as an investment, the growing demand has barely bumped up its price.

title: A Decade of Style From a Miyake Loyalist,
description: Issey Miyake, a leader of the Japanese avant-garde articulating a fin de siecle style in their Paris collections, is among those who draw their energy from the ancient form of kimono structure and hand-loomed fabrics, favoring clothing that camouflages the body while giving it new shape. Mr. Miyake's show in March included six models, ages 67 to 93, dramatizing his belief that fashion knows no age. Seated in the audience was one of his clients, Mme. Leon Gischia, a nonagenarian, who has been providing a discreet show of her own for the last 10 years in her arrivals at Mr. Miyake's March and October shows. A former theater costume designer who is married to an artist, Mme. Gischia dressed at Gres in the 1940's and 50's, changing in the 60's to the modernism of Courreges. The next change in her style came when Mr. Miyake opened his Paris shop in the late 70's. She wears his most innovative designs with a confidence and a swagger that are entirely Parisian. In March, she wore a three-piece pleated jacket with fins cascading down the back (bottom right). She topped the outfit with a dashing black felt hat whose crown was decorated with the dripping from a wax candle (bottom far right). Cone-shaped sunglass lenses with a coal-shovel-shaped hat (top far left) or a torso-shaped black plastic tote bag (bottom center) were just a few of the eye-catching looks of this stylish woman whose enthusiasm for creative dress remains as imaginative as ever.

title: New Indian Casinos In Western States
description: Nevada and Arizona have new casinos established by Indian tribes under a Federal law that gives them the right to operate on their sovereign land any game of chance permitted under state law.

It is the season of the blockbuster, when studios roll out their big-budget films and pit them against one another. By taking in more than $145 million at the domestic box office, any one of this summer's films could unseat some of the 50 top-earning movies of all time. Last year, three summer movies joined the club: "Forrest Gump," "The Lion King" and "True Lies." ("The Santa Clause," released at Christmas, squeeked in with $145 million to claim 48th place.)

A mild winter has raised fears that infestations of the tiny ticks that transmit the disease may be heavy during their season, from April to October.

title: F.Y.I.
description: Swimming in Circles Q. Do people actually swim in the waters off Manhattan? I heard this and cannot believe it. Why would they do that? Isn't the water disgusting? Isn't it illegal? A. Last things first. It is not illegal to swim in Manhattan's waters, according to spokesmen at the Police Department and the Coast Guard, but it is no walk in the park: the Coast Guard says that swimmers venturing far from shore should obtain a permit and be accompanied by a boat to prevent interference with boat traffic.

Cigar smokers can choose either a 10-day segment leaving Nov. 10 from Fort Lauderdale, a five-day cruise on Nov. 10 from Fort Lauderdale to Barbados, or a five-day trip in the reverse direction on Nov. 15. Activities include a lecture on how to choose the perfect meal for each type of cigar. On the longer cruise, passengers visit the Caribbean Cigar Company in Barbados and join a seminar at Cohiba Cigars in the Bahamas. Fares begin at $1,077 a person, double occupancy, for the five-day cruises; $2,154 a person for 10 days (air fare extra). Call Custom Cruises, (800) 621-6010.

At night, when workers from the legal and financial printing companies left, the streets were deserted, the few bars and restaurants shuttered. title: Shapes the Eye Cannot See
description: Photographed straight and twisted, stolid and melancholy, standing and fallen, leaned on by ladders and buried in leaves, verdure has seldom had such a dreamy portraitist as Michael Kenna, though his greens are black and white. As Peter C. Bunnell, a professor of the history of photography and modern art at Princeton University, writes in the introductory essay to MICHAEL KENNA: A Twenty Year Retrospective (Treville Company/RAM Publications, 2525 Michigan Avenue A-2, Santa Monica, Calif. 90404, $65), it is precisely because Mr. Kenna is a monochromist that his pictures seem like works of fiction rather than records of fact. "The black and white film," Mr. Bunnell writes, "inherently peels off interesting images from the world; it sees things we do not see, and thus insists on the existence of a phantom presence within reality." The boundary between real and abstract blurs. In this sense Mr. Kenna, who was born in Lancashire, England, and now lives in San Francisco, takes after the artist who first sparked his interest in photography 20 years ago, Bill Brandt. But there is one big difference. Brandt played off human forms. In Mr. Kenna's still world, there are no people. Instead there are trees, some lonely, some sociable. Even the photographs that do not feature trees -- the photos of the architectural follies at the Desert de Retz a few miles west of Paris, of the Eiffel Tower's underbelly, of fence posts in Wales, of rails diverging from the Gare St.-Lazare in Paris, of the stumpy towers at England's Ratcliffe power station -- are arboreal shapes, homages to branches and trunks. Looking through Mr. Kenna's book, one has the feeling of being an intruder in an eerie grove. SARAH BOXER

description: A tankful of gasoline and a day off: How to make the most of them? One answer could be the new Hagstrom road atlas that covers a 75-mile radius from Columbus Circle, the juncture of Central Park South and Broadway, in New York. The 60-page spiral-bound book has 35 pages of road maps, airport maps and indexes of beaches, boat ramps, campsites, golf courses and other points of interest. The pages measure 10 inches by 13 inches, and the atlas lies flat when opened. It costs $10.95 from the Hagstrom Map and Travel Center, 57 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; (212) 398-1222. JOSEPH SIANO

title:
Long Island Q&A;: Sharon Sultan;
Riding a Demographic Wave, Marketing to the Over-50's
description: PEOPLE older than 50 own more cars, spend more on personal care and trips and have more financial assets than any other age group, according to demographers. Though the group makes up 28 percent of the Long Island population, experts expect that percentage to grow dramatically as a majority of baby boomers begins to turn 50 next year. The Long Island Regional Planning Board estimates that by 2010, 39.7 percent of Long Islanders will have passed 50.

title: Burmese Raid Border Camps In Thailand
description: The long, tense border between Thailand and Myanmar has erupted in fighting in recent days with repeated cross-border attacks on Burmese refugees in Thailand by former Burmese rebels now backed by the junta that runs Myanmar.

title: In a Kashmir Conflagration, India Faces a Turning Point
description: From an almond grove above the ruins of this ancient town, the thick smoke spiraling into the air seems like a totem of the miseries that have afflicted Kashmir in the five years since decades of political tensions erupted into guerrilla war.

title: For BMT George's, a Beloved Greasy Spoon, It's the End of the Line
description: In a corner of the upper level of the BMT Stillwell Avenue subway station, behind a wooden door that reads "For Transit Authority Employees Only," things were just as George Bekas left them. Ashtrays were set on faded orange, red and green Formica tables, glass cases were stocked with cookies and potato chips, and a bowl of raw eggs chilled in a refrigerator next to the grill, as if they were still going to be cracked open for the $1.80 breakfast special.

title: Washington Talk; For G.O.P. Contenders, Nixon's (Still) the One
description: "Dying is no excuse: Nixon in '96."

title: Can the Republicans Really Help the Cities?
description: One of the jokes told at the annual dinner of the Legislative Correspondents Club Wednesday night went like this: "If Governor Whitman put a few more dollars into her urban program, it would cost as much as her house."

title: The Great Sublimator
description: WALTER PATER Lover of Strange Souls.By Denis Donoghue.364 pp. New York:Alfred A. Knopf.

title: The Country Graces Of Mantua
description: Mantua is a place of stories, more than histories. In its narrow streets and beneath its bridges, one can envision the murders, trysts and vendettas for which the Italian city is renowned. It is here that the dark tale of Rigoletto's misery and loss is set; it was here, too, that Romeo came to buy poison.

title: A Growing Taste for the Fruit of the Vinyl
description: FOR most of the quarter century that it has been on the market vinyl siding got no respect. While less tinny and more damage-resistant than aluminum siding, it served the same purpose -- covering unsightly, low- to mid-priced older homes.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: MYSTERIOUS SKIN By Scott Heim.HarperCollins, $20.

title: Sponges and Wine
description: To the Editor: Sherry Marker's appealing article on the delights of Monemvasia, ("Two Towns, Well Aged, in Greece," Feb. 26), is silent on that city's greatest claim to fame: malmsey. Elizabethan dramatists were fond of writing about "a butt of malmsey," and, probably, imbibing it, too. Malmsey took its name from the Malvasia grape (from an alternative name for Monemvasia) used to make it. It was a rich, sweet, aromatic wine and appears to have been as popular in England as Madeira, sherry and port were later to become. TALIAFERRO BOATWRIGHT Stonington, Conn.

title: 'No One Was Interested'
description: To the Editor:

title: JOHN HOPE FRANKLIN
description: A few years ago, while visiting my daughter at Northwestern University, I attended a round-table discussion for alumni and students. At one point, I expressed dismay that, unlike when I attended Northwestern, now there was a segregated fraternity system -- a throwback to the days of "separate but equal."

title: Tracing Nazi Victims In Red Cross Files
description: To the Editor:

title: A Top Performing Fund That Santa Claus Could Love
description: AMONG mutual fund nest eggs, Twentieth Century Giftrust Investors is a Faberge. The fund performed best of 665 mutual funds tracked by Lipper Analytical Services in the past decade, with an annual average gain of 23.6 percent.

title: Settle Down, Class. Experience Is Talking.
description: IN the early 1980's, public schools across the country were grappling with a major predicament: a lack of competent teachers to fill classroom vacancies. In some districts, it was not unheard of to hire a biology teacher with scant science background. All too often, emergency teaching certificates were being granted to people without college degrees.

title: Jailed Youth Recalls Whim That Led to Robbery and Rape
description: The idea to rob someone was spontaneous, Lamont Cherry said: the selection of a victim completely arbitrary. He said the escalation of the crime from a theft to a rape and brutal beating was instant and insane.

title: What the Critics Can't Wait to See
description: Enough about the kilt (as if we've never seen a man's knees before). Forget about the hair weave (as if there could be a historical hero with a shaved head). "Braveheart" promises what summer movie fans want -- an action epic with a genuine movie star. Mel Gibson directed and stars as a 13th-century Scottish hero who leads his men on a rampage against the British. With its three-hour running time, the film is risky. But the quirky "Braveheart" may offer something for everyone: spear-wielding battles for action fans and a romantic heart for people who swoon over Mel Gibson. -- Caryn James

title: L.P.G.A. Head Says Women Are Targets
description: The commissioner of the Ladies Professional Golf Association said today that the controversy set off here by comments attributed to a CBS senior golf analyst is indicative of a "systemic problem that goes far deeper than golf."

title: Moliere So Straight, So Pure -- So Mock!
description: NO one planned it that way, but it appears that Connecticut is in the midst of a Moliere festival of an odd sort. One might call it a Mini-Ado About Moliere. Though three plays are being offered in two theaters, only one is producing the real thing; the other is the mock.

title: Bruce Willis Moonlights
description: THE GARRETT-JACOBS MANSION is in fact three houses knocked into one, with interiors redesigned by Stanford White toward the end of the last century, and stained-glass windows by Tiffany. Since 1962, this imposing pile has been a club for the members of the upscale Engineering Society of Baltimore. But on a day in late March, "Twelve Monkeys," a $28 million Universal Pictures production, is being shot and two top-dollar movie actors are crouching together at the bottom of an ornate staircase that leads up from a lavish dining room to a balcony.

title: A Hot Issue
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: IRAN SAYS IT PLANS 10 NUCLEAR PLANTS BUT NO ATOM ARMS
description: Iran's top nuclear official said today that his country hopes to build about 10 nuclear power plants in the next two decades, but he denied charges by the United States that Iran is trying to develop nuclear weapons.

title: Jennifer Grenier, L. J. Kandel Jr.
description: Jennifer Bair Grenier, a daughter of Vieva and G. Rankings reflect sales figures, for the week ending April 29, at 3,050 bookstores plus wholesalers serving 28,000 other retailers (gift shops, department stores, newsstands, supermarkets), statistically weighted to represent sales in all such outlets nationwide. An asterisk indicates that a book's sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. And Bear in Mind (Editor's Choices of other recent books of particular interest) EXCELLENT CADAVERS: The Mafia and the Death of the First Italian Republic, by Alexander Stille. (Pantheon, $27.50.) This fascinating and horrifying examination, based on immense piles of documents, shows how in the last 25 years the Mafia has terrorized Sicilian society and perverted Italian politics. THE INFORMATION, by Martin Amis. (Harmony, $24.) Mr. Amis's cool and brilliant novel is sustained throughout by the corroding, corrupting envy of an unsuccessful novelist for a successful novelist who is also his best friend. LANDSCAPE AND MEMORY, by Simon Schama. (Knopf, $40.) A learned and perceptive survey of Western attitudes toward nature in the last five centuries; Mr. Schama's starting point is the Renaissance fascination with river, forest and mountain as signs of a revered prototypal world. MEMOIR FROM ANTPROOF CASE, by Mark Helprin. (Harcourt Brace, $24.) The slowly unfolding self-revelation of Oscar Progresso, the thoughtful, aged eccentric who narrates this novel while planning a fantastical crime. MEN IN BLACK, by Scott Spencer. (Knopf, $23.) A smart, affectionate comic novel in which an honorable but unsuccessful novelist's life is overturned when his pseudonymous potboiler about extraterrestrials becomes a best seller. A MOMENT ON THE EARTH: The Coming Age of Environmental Optimism, by Gregg Easterbrook. (Viking, $27.95.) Essays on the most complex of modern subjects, treating our considerable environmental accomplishments and our puzzling neglect of threats (diseases, for instance) in other people's backyards. NOAH'S CHOICE: The Future of Endangered Species, by Charles C. Mann and Mark L. Plummer. (Knopf, $24.) The authors persuasively contend that humans will decide, by default or by intention, who goes extinct, and at present have not a clue how to do so wisely. OSWALD'S TALE: An American Mystery, by Norman Mailer. (Random House, $30.) Stoked by a passion to believe J.F.K.'s death was more than a meaningless absurdity, Mr. Mailer pursues and delivers the assassin's very slightly significant soul, using his own research and that of others. REDEYE: A Western, by Clyde Edgerton. (Algonquin, $17.95.) An elaborate, unbelievable plot, chock-full of believable, well-developed characters, sustains this woolly western by an admirable Southern novelist. RULE OF THE BONE, by Russell Banks. (HarperCollins, $22.) A novel that reinvigorates the Huck Finn myth in the person of Chappie, a mall rat from upstate New York who lights out for Jamaica with a runaway farm worker. THE TRIAL OF ELIZABETH CREE: A Novel of the Limehouse Murders, by Peter Ackroyd. (Nan A. Talese/Doubleday, $22.) A claustrophobic, agitated novel of London in 1880; everyone (including a clutch of famous contemporary reformers) is connected to everyone else.

title: ENTREPRENEURS: Model Prisoners
description: It's the old bad boy look, with a twist. These boys don't just look bad. They're all convicted criminals in the Oregon prison system. And the clothes they're wearing are made by inmates (including the models themselves) for the Prison Blues clothing label, created in 1991. So far, 400 American stores acrry this line of jeans, shirts and jackets, as do about 100 in Europe. A mail-order catalogue (featuring some of the above felons) is produced by a private by a private marketing company called Big House. Inmates must apply for the garment jobs and are paid what workers on the outside would get. Eighty percent of their pay goes to victim restitution, taxes and room and board. They keep the rest, but are allowed to spend only a maximum of $30 a week. The rest goes into savings. If Prison Blues are not available at your local Army-Navy-Penitentiary store, try 1-800-597-7472.
