description: Ignoring the perfect plan and planting violas at will, by Anne Raver.

title: Ms. Macdonald, Mr. Szczepiorkowski
description: Heather Ann Macdonald, the assistant director of career services at Regis College in Weston, Mass., was married yesterday to Dr. Zbigniew Szczepiorkowski, a research fellow at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston. The Rev. David Punch officiated at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Newport, R.I.

title: Nissequogue Channel Declared Unsafe for Boats
description: RETURNING from a clamming trip last summer Sam Sakellarides's boat hit sand in a channel at the mouth of the Nissequogue River in Long Island Sound. The accident cost Mr. Sakellarides, of Kings Park, $200 for a new water pump for his 16-footer.

title: POSTINGS: Second Design Gets Backing After First Is Opposed; Plan for Armani Store Comes in a Taller Size
description: What a difference a floor makes. Only two months ago, it seemed, neighborhood residents were opposed to Giorgio Armani's plan to demolish the facades of a nondescript two-story brick building at the northwest corner of Madison Avenue and 65th Street and build a three-story showroom of limestone and glass.

title: San Miguel's Cosmopolitan Charm
description: EVEN if I hadn't seen the sign I would have known this was the bus for San Miguel de Allende. In a sea of Mexicans stood a small island of gringos: an oldish couple wearing the kind of gear, and attitude, that proclaims Provincetown or Woodstock, several backpackers and two tall, stringy women in their 30's who, it turned out, would talk New York publishing nonstop while the rest of us attempted sleep. San Miguel, four hours north of Mexico City, is 75 percent Mexican but its air is that which is breathed in every arts colony in every part of the world. Here conversation is purer than it is elsewhere, having been filtered (at least for a while) of both commerce and critics.

title: Once Again, Norway Builds A Soccer Field
description: When a soccer field donated by the Norwegian Football Federation was burned down last fall, the children of Red Hook lost a treasured place to practice the sport. But 12-year-old Andrew Mankowski has a solution -- bring his soccer-playing brethren to the field's new site in Bay Ridge.

title: Rookie Pitcher Has Yanks' Number
description: After posting two victories and 13 scoreless innings in his first two major league starts, the question was this: Is Vaughn Eshelman for real or is this just a case of beginner's luck?

title: ALSO INSIDE
description: MAKING IT WORK 3 Far off the beaten path, a community of shacks thrives in the South Bronx. NEW YORKERS & CO. 4 Garment industry survivor: A shoemaker to the stars and a haven for the traumatized foot. PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD 11 A celebration of the tattoo at the Seaport; a record and book sale in Yorkville; Indian art on the Upper East Side. MOVIE CLOCK 13 What's showing at the local movie houses, today through Thursday. GOOD EATING 14 A tour of Brooklyn; the romantic River Cafe; the cheerful Brawta Cafe; the congenial Garden Cafe; spicy Thai cuisine at Lemongrass Grill. SOAPBOX 15 One marriage and the dog issue. And letters.

title: Lurching Toward Democracy
description: THE HAUNTED LAND Facing Europe's Ghosts After Communism. By Tina Rosenberg. 437 pp. New York: Random House. $25.

title:
HOME CLINIC;
Color Balance and Harmony, or What Works Well in a Room
description: IT is not easy to chose a color scheme for a room. Unfortunately, most homeowners do not have the time to learn the theory of color balance and harmony before putting a room together. There are no hard and fast rules for picking colors. It is a matter of personal taste. Nevertheless, guides and suggestions based on color theory and the results of research by psychologists and behavioral scientists can help.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: 'CAPTURING AN IMAGE'

title:
If You're Thinking of Living In/Queens Village;
A Global Village of Cultural Diversity
description: LESS a melting pot than a swirling stew of ethnic identities, Queens Village is a testing ground for cultural diversity where races and nationalities commingle and co-exist without ever quite coalescing.

title: An Informer on Drug Use Complains of Harassment
description: Jeffrey Salnick was an outgoing eighth grader at Park Ridge Public School. He played ball with his buddies and hung out with kids at Marc's Deli & Pizza next door to the school. More than 70 of his friends celebrated at his bar mitzvah in November.

title: A Northwestern Lake of Ever-Changing Moods
description: First, the throat clearing. To my fellow Northwesterners, keepers of the secrets of yellow-aster hideaways and lakeshore meadows that have never felt a human sandal print: I confess. What follows is a sonnet to one of our sacred places. But Lake Chelan is too big to hide. And sometimes exposure is a good thing. After all, President Gerald R. Ford, an old Boy Scout, agreed to approve the Alpine Lakes Wilderness only after seeing a picture book of the forest land east of Seattle.

title: Band From West Point To Play Again in Rye
description: IN May 1992, the Pulvermann Foundation began its series of free community concerts with a visit from the United States Military Academy Band and a special guest, the bass-baritone Jerome Hines. This afternoon at 3, the West Pointers and Mr. Hines will return for a fourth-anniversary reunion at Rye High School, although with a different leader. Yielding the baton will be the band's new director, Lieut. Col. David H. Deitrick.

title: Mental Health in an H.M.O.: 'A Quick Therapeutic Jolt'
description: To the Editor:

title: 3 Big Hospitals Want to Merge, and That's Just for Openers
description: Quickly and quietly, a revolution is taking place in the sprawling network of hospitals -- large and small, public and private, for-profit and nonprofit -- that care for New Jerseyans.

title: Straus Park: A Renovation Deferred
description: In the tortured history of Straus Park, a dilapidated triangle at the intersection of Broadway, West End Avenue and 106th Street, sometimes even good news is bad news.

title: Sharks and Jets Are Ready to Rumble Again
description: TIME IS ANOTHER DANCER IN this room. Jerome Robbins, in his signature gray beard, faces the young dancers of the New York City Ballet for a run-through of his "West Side Story" Suite. The work, consisting of original choreography from the 1957 musical, along with a newly created piece, will have its premiere on Thursday at the New York State Theater at Lincoln Center.

title: A Hillside Haven
description: WE were thumbing our guidebooks frantically last summer, eager to get away from vast and gritty Mexico City, when we stumbled upon what one guidebook called an "undiscovered gem" of a town near the Gulf Coast. My friend, Marcelle, and I soon headed southeast, over the mountains, to Jalapa (or Xalapa, as it is also called), which is both the lively, modern capital of Veracruz State and a relaxed, very pretty small town about a five-hour drive from Mexico City.

title: Habitats/Carroll Gardens; Moving Close to Family
description: VINCENT AND ELIZABETH DEMARTINO -- Vinnie and Liz to their friends -- grew up a few blocks from their new home. He lived in a Carroll Gardens rowhouse on President Street, she in one on Degraw Street.

title: Americans See Strangers in Their Midst
description: It is the season of lilacs and Little League in this middle-class Chicago suburb. Radio Flyer wagons roll down sidewalks. At the train station, commuters clutching briefcases hurry home for a barbecue. Down at the ice cream stand on Main Street, customers relax on sun-dappled benches.

title:
The View From: Milford;
It's High Drama for the Younger Set
description: WHEN Mimi Baker decided to create a drama club at the Matthewson School in Milford, she figured 20, possibly 25 children would turn out for the first meeting.

title: Private Sources Help Bolster Beleaguered Public Schools
description: THIS fall, a group of foreign language students at Staples High School in Westport will be able to converse on the Internet with their counterparts in France, Spain or Germany. They plan to collaborate on projects, honing language skills as well as computer expertise.

title: Mayor Names Hispanic Woman to Advisory Post
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani appointed Amalia V. Betanzos yesterday as the new chairwoman of the Mayor's Commission on the Status of Women. The Mayor, whose standing among Hispanic New Yorkers has been lagging in recent polls, noted during the announcement that Ms. Betanzos is Hispanic.

title: Science Fiction
description: THE KILLING STAR (Avonova/Morrow, $22), by Charles Pellegrino and George Zebrowski, is a novel of ideas -- or, rather, of one big idea. Carl Sagan, among others in the scientific community, has argued that any intelligent forms of extra terrestrial life we encounter, either in space or here on Earth, are likely to be friendly, since overly aggressive species will most probably destroy themselves before they become capable of interstellar travel or communication. Mr. Pellegrino and Mr. Zebrowski beg to differ. They have embedded their rebuttal in a novel of such conceptual ferocity and scientific plausibility that it amounts to a reinvention of that old Wellsian staple: Invading Monsters From Outer Space.

title: Still Out on a Limb, but With Her Feet on the Ground
description: Annie Lennox would rather not appear in public these days. But when she does, she makes an impression. Just before the release of her new album, "Medusa," in March, she agreed to present an award at the Grammys. "Normally I shy away from that sort of thing," she says. "Then I thought, 'What the heck, I'm about to have a record out, people need to see me. I'll use this.' So I became an industry slut for the night.

title: Earth Day Founder
description: To the Editor:

title:
In the Region/Long Island;
A Civic Center to Enrich Glen Cove's Downtown
description: TWO imposing turn-of-the-century limestone structures at the corner of Glen and School Streets here are being transformed into the city's new civic center. What was once the Glen Cove Bank Building will be the new City Hall; the former Nassau Union Building will be the City Court. Both buildings were used most recently to jointly house a branch of Fleet Bank.

title: F.B.I. Hasn't Tried to Change the Rules in Bombing Aftermath
description: To the Editor:

title: Tan Line
description: When your swim wear leaves a lasting impression

title: 1890's or 1990's, the Visions Are of an Apocalypse Soon
description: THE WORLD HAS BEEN ENDING for a very long time, but the approach of the year 2000 has convinced a multitude that This Is It. Doomsday has in fact loomed large at least since the atom bomb gave us the power to destroy the planet, casting a dark fallout on art, on literature like Don DeLillo's "White Noise" and Richard Adams's "Watership Down," and on films from "Godzilla" to "Bladerunner." Recently, gaping holes in the ozone layer offer new evidence of how prodigal we have been in inventing means of self-annihilation, and the appearance of seemingly invincible viruses serve as a warning that the powers of medicine and science are more limited than we had thought.

title: Pentagon Blocks Gulf Syndrome Funds
description: To the Editor:

title: Foreign Affairs; O Jerusalem
description: On April 18, 1990, Bob Dole made a speech in the Senate arguing against a resolution to move the U.S. Embassy from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem.

title: EUREKA
description: BETWEEN 1869 AND HIS DEATH IN 1931, at age 84, Thomas Alva Edison was granted more than a thousand patents for inventions familiar and eccentric: from the typewriter, electric pen, electric light, phonograph, motion picture camera and alkaline storage battery -- to the talking doll and a concrete house that could be built in one day from a cast-iron mold.

title: Country Furnishings, an Italian Menu
description: THE Italian restaurant marathon continues. Biscotti Food Company in Ridgefield, at the upper (ground) level of a historic building, has an anteroom that triples as a coffee bar, wine bar and take-out food area with a glass-fronted display case.

title: Forecast of Downturn?: 1,000 Jobs May Move
description: Beginning in the late 1970's, the fortunes of downtown Jamaica sank as several major local employers -- Macy's, The Long Island Press, Ideal Toys, two banks and the flagship Gertz department store -- folded or moved. But a turning point came a decade ago when the Gertz family turned the eight-story department store into an office and retail complex called Gertz Plaza.

title: Drifter Is Charged
description: An armed drifter with a chemistry degree who has been arrested on an old weapons charge told investigators he knew Timothy J. McVeigh, one of the suspects in the Oklahoma City bombing.

title: Chelsea Is Short-Changed By Community Board 4
description: To the Editor:

title: An Agency Makes Room for H.I.V.-Positive Models
description: THE models represented by the Proof Positive division of the Morgan Agency have everything models are expected to have: good looks, high-paying jobs and national exposure in advertising campaigns. But they also have something unexpected: they are H.I.V. positive.

title:
ART;
A Gallery of Women, Displaying a Wide Variety of Faces
description: THE WOMEN SERIES 1992-1994" is an impishly titled installation at the Hudson River Museum that will fill the bill for anyone needing to visit a shrine appropriate for Mother's Day. More than 200 photographs of women's faces are hung on the coffee-brown walls on the first-floor landing of the museum's historic Trevor Mansion.

title:
SOAPBOX;
This Old Place
description: THE 90's haven't been easy for Bogota. The pizzeria count fell by half when Paulie's and Louie II's closed. Yeah, we still have Master Pizza and Angelo's, and that's more than any Bergen County town of 8,125 people is probably entitled to. But for a while, we had real freedom of choice.

title: Pataki Seeks Inquiry on L.I. Prosecutor
description: Gov. George E. Pataki has ordered the State Commissioner of Criminal Justice Services to review allegations of official misconduct made against the Suffolk County District Attorney, James M. Catterson.

title:
MUSIC;
Glory and Tragedy Do Battle in 'War Prayer'
description: MY subject is War, and the pity of War," says the preface to Benjamin Britten's "War Requiem." The soldier who penned that line didn't survive World War I, but the composer's setting of his words, threaded through his score of the liturgical mass for the dead, became famous as a searing indictment of war's waste: "I am the enemy you killed, my friend."

title: Mary Jo Carville, Robert L. Nutt
description: Mary Jo Carville and Dr. Robert L. Nutt were married yesterday at their home in Englewood, N.J. Judge J. Arthur Lesemann of the Superior Court of New Jersey in Hackensack officiated.

title: Stalking the Elusive Tax-Free Bond Price Quotation
description: FOR investors in municipal bonds, it is now getting easier to find something that has long been hard to come by: bond prices.

title: Los Angeles's Covered Bazaar
description: THE NOTION OF STREET food in Los Angeles, where the idea of a long stroll is getting from a+ mall parking garage to The Gap, might strike some as an oxymoron. Sidewalk vendors like those found in many Eastern cities are rare in this sprawling metropolis. However something close can be found in the heart of downtown.

title: Seattle
description: In the spring, under temperamental gray skies, the colorized version of Seattle comes to life. Rhododendrons and azaleas blossom in every nook of the city, from formal English gardens to service-station strips. The scent of lilacs rides westerly breezes in from Puget Sound. At the same time, people take to the water in prodigious numbers, in a place where one out of every five people owns some kind of boat.

title: Backing Deficit Reduction, Executives Are Wary of Deep Cuts
description: At the end of a week of passionate Washington arguments over how much to cut the Federal budget, both Republicans and top officials of the Clinton Administration came here to convince America's top business executives that their approach has the best chance of keeping a thriving American economy from driving off the edge.

title: Praising Amtrak
description: To the Editor: Although I realize that Amtrak-baiting is a cherished pastime, I would nonetheless like to react to some letters in your news paper.

title: Debra Lee Hart, William D. Ryder
description: Debra Lee Hart, a daughter of Rina and Edward Hart of Stoneboro, Pa., was married yesterday to William Dawson Ryder, the son of Mary Lee Ryder of Chappaqua, N.Y., and Dawson Adams Ryder of Scarsdale, N.Y. The Rev. David R. Vaughn performed the ceremony at the United Methodist Church in Stoneboro.

title: Correction
description: An entry in the "Where to Complain" listing last Sunday misidentified the agency to call regarding stray animals. It is the city's Center for Animal Care and Control, at (212) 442-2071, no longer the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals.

title:
MUTUAL FUNDS;
Jumping Back Into Junk Bond Funds
description: SOME people just can't stop reaching for that extra bit of return. When domestic stocks were doing well two years ago, high-flying markets in places like Hong Kong and Mexico looked even better to them. This year, despite stellar returns by Treasury securities, they are pouring money into junk bonds, the high-risk corner of the bond market.

title: Kyoko Miyamoto, Tariq Mundiya
description: KYOKO MIYAMOTO, a classically trained violinist and a Japanese language instructor and translator in New York, grew up in Tokyo, where romance is often as formal as the gardens.

title: Sad Echo
description: To the Editor:

title: Tour of Short Hills Mall: A Study in Condescension
description: To the Editor:

title: Tracy Talbot, Matthew Spencer
description: Allison Tracy Talbot, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Timothy R. Talbot 3d of Chester, N.J., was married yesterday to Matthew Crosthwaite Spencer, a son of Ann E. Spencer of Providence, R.I., and Geoffrey C. Spencer of Miami Beach. The Rev. Martha Robson performed the ceremony at the Hilltop Presbyterian Church in Mendham, N.J.

title: Carbon Monoxide Poisoning Is Posing Summertime Dangers
description: HOURS after moving into a rental home in Brentwood on Feb. 9, Earlene Randolph's 29-year-old daughter began complaining of a severe headache. Then her 5-year-old grandson woke up screaming. Later her 12-year-old granddaughter had a headache. Soon Ms. Randolph was feeling woozy.

title: Gay Youth Center, The Neutral Zone, Raises a Ruckus
description: It's 10 P.M. on a Tuesday night and all is quiet in front of the Neutral Zone, a center for gay and lesbian youth on Christopher Street.

title: Marcelo Andrade, Lisa Bjornson
description: Lisa Bjornson and Dr. Marcelo Carvalho de Andrade, international bankers, are to be married today in Key Largo, Fla. The Rev. John Twiname is to perform the Episcopal ceremony at the Chapel at Ocean Reef.

title: The Best Restaurants In Mercer? Go to Trenton
description: To the Editor:

title: Connecticut Q&A: Drew M. Crandall; A Minister Goes to the Marketplace
description: DREW M. CRANDALL, 39, is the founder and president of Keep In Touch, a sales and marketing company in Vernon, and the head of the New England chapters of Fellowship of Companies for Christ Inc.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE GOOD NEGRESS By A. J. Verdelle. Algonquin, $19.95.

title: Beyond Penny Lane, The Great Old Port of Liverpool
description: In the south of Britain every place beyond Watford, a small town some 20 miles outside London, is referred to as "up north." This definition includes Coventry, Birmingham, Edinburgh and the whole of Wales. On a map of the British Isles, Liverpool is on the bump on the left-hand side; situated on the River Mersey, which flows into the Irish Sea, it faces Dublin. London is nearly 200 miles inland, down south and heading for the English Channel. Nowadays, Liverpool is known as the birthplace of the Beatles, a somewhat inconsequential consideration when placed beside Daniel Defoe's assessment of the town in 1684 as "one of the wonders of Britain." That the plague had descended on London 20 years before -- followed by the Great Fire -- causing numbers of wealthy merchants who dealt in cotton, sugar and tobacco to desert the capital and decamp north to Liverpool, had much to do with its emergence as a great port.

title: THE BOSNIA CALCULATION
description: By focusing solely on the number of dead in Bosnia and Herzegovina, George Kenney overlooks the primary objective of Serbian war plans -- ethnic cleansing ("The Bosnia Calculation," April 23). The atrocity is not the number dead but the way state-sponsored murder, massacre, rape and siege of cities is used to expel people and to create ethnically pure territories.

title: A Day Without Fanfare Is Still a Day for Remembrance
description: The dignitaries have gone. No bands play, no speeches are delivered. It is a simple weekday. But still they come, the survivors and the mourners, to touch, to stare. Alone with their thoughts, the visitors to New Jersey's Vietnam Veterans' Memorial seek quiet communion with the casualties of a war whose political ambiguity once cast a dark shadow over their service.

title: Junk Souls
description: RIDING THE RAP By Elmore Leonard.294 pp. New York: Delacorte Press. $22.95.

title: Koufax in Dispute With Collectibles Dealer
description: The Hall of Fame pitcher SANDY KOUFAX said he was misled by a collectibles dealer, but the dealer says it was all a misunderstanding. Koufax said he was upset that yarmulkes he had autographed had been sold by B & J Collectibles of Lakewood, N.J. Koufax said he had been told the skullcaps were to be presented to children at an awards ceremony at a Hebrew school.

title: Sports of The Times; At Boston Garden, There's Much More Gold Than Green
description: WHEN the New Jersey Devils were in Boston last weekend, a visitor told a taxi driver, "Take me to the Garden."

title:
OUTDOORS;
The Call and the Shot on Turkey Hunt Requires Discretion
description: When Chris Strasser, Chris Ingvordsen and I stepped out of the spike camp on Steve Renehan's sprawling property high above the Delaware River shortly before dawn on the opening morning of Pennsylvania's turkey hunting season, the doves were cooing, a woodpecker was already at work and, off in a distant valley, a soulful old barn dog and a jaunty rooster were having an absurd pre-dawn dialogue.

title: Arthur Lubin, 96, Director Of 'Mr. Ed' TV Series, Dies
description: Arthur Lubin, the Hollywood director whose more than 60 credits ranged from the lush 1943 remake of "Phantom of the Opera" to "Francis the Talking Mule" and its spinoff, the "Mr. Ed" television series of the 1960's, died on Thursday at the Autumn Hills nursing home in Glendale, Calif. He was 96.

title:
Commercial Property/Land Use;
A Way to Compensate for Building in the Wetlands
description: SINCE 1972, when the Clean Water Act was passed, permits have been needed from the Army Corps of Engineers to work in wetland areas. To obtain these permits builders must agree to restore, enhance or create an equal number of wetlands acres -- generally in the same watershed -- as those damaged or destroyed in a construction project.

title: The battle over a new biography of Katharine Hepburn.
description: To the Editor:

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/1996 Acura 2.5TL; The Vigor Is Departing; The Vim Hasn't Arrived
description: FOR years I have thought to do a column that rates cars on the merits of their ashtrays. Just as a consumer service, you understand, for die-hards like me who refuse to quit.

title: A Guide to the Guidebooks
description: WHILE Mexico's 16th-century cathedrals seem immune to tourism's fickle whims, the charming inn you found a few years ago may be this year's Benetton boutique. Fortunately, there are several guidebooks that will keep you from a futile chase through today's quickly changing Mexico. But, alas, there are still plenty that will lead you down the crowded trail of phony culture and bad hotel disco music.

title:
NOTICED;
For the Chic-of-Mouth
description: THEY are often mistaken for cheap candy, the kind sold by the pound in Woolworth's. But with a 15-ounce tin priced at $28, Grether's Pastilles hardly qualify as cheap. In fact, they do not even qualify as candy; they are cough drops. Despite such considerations, grown men and women are popping them like children on a sugar jag.

title:
SPENDING IT;
Foreclosure Sales: Home Buying for the Fearless
description: AFTER sitting empty for nearly two years, the town house would have sent most buyers running for the hills. It had a gaping hole in the kitchen ceiling and no appliances except for a built-in dishwasher. "The place was so bad my son cried that he didn't want to move there," said Lisa Hatala, who was living with her husband, Brian, and two children in a cramped two-bedroom condominium in the same development in East Brunswick, N.J.

title: May 7-12; Found: a Very Sinkable Sub
description: The disappearance of the Confederate submarine Hunley on the night of Feb. 17, 1864 was a profound mystery, but no surprise. After the announcement last week of its discovery by divers off the coast of South Carolina, engineers and historians may learn the cause of the Hunley's doom. A more enduring question is, why would anyone have volunteered for the crew of this unseaworthy vessel?

title: In the Region/Connecticut; 2 New Projects Enhance a South Norwalk Recovery
description: TWO new projects costing a total of $6 million are scheduled to open in South Norwalk in July, signaling a recovery from four years of recession-hobbled growth in an area the city has counted on to seed future development and spark tourism.

title: From Mountains to Shore, the Patter of Feet
description: This list is selective. It is national in scope but concentrates on the Northeast. California

title: Streetscapes:/The New-York Historical Society; The Genesis of a Museum on Central Park West
description: AS part of its revival under Betsy Gotbaum, the new executive director, the New-York Historical Society is seeking a developer interested in erecting a 15-story building on its 102- by 100-foot empty lot at 7-13 West 76th Street.

title: A Celebration Still Looking for a Soul
description: GREAT MUSIC AND PERFORMING-ARTS festivals, like great cities, often have their origins in mythic ideas. Rome has the stories of Romulus and Remus and their joining of forces; the Salzburg Festival has tales of Hugo von Hofmannsthal and Max Reinhardt and their attempt to codify Austrian culture. Jerusalem has its biblical roots; Bayreuth has its Wagnerian manifestoes.

title: Modern Munich's Sophisticated Cuisine
description: TRAVELERS heading for Munich should erase from their minds every cliche about German food: the dark beer halls reeking of stale beer, oversized platters of sauerbraten drowning in gravy, floury dumplings that could double as lead sinkers. Modern Munich is another world altogether.

title: Making Over Grand Central
description: To the Editor:

title: A Sense of Direction, On Stage and Off
description: Name: Shannon Berry Age: 18 School: Red Bank Regional High School, where she is enrolled in an intensive performing arts program. Latest Achievement: Won first place in the English Speaking Union's 1995 National Shakespeare Competition, reciting one of Ophelia's Monologues from "Hamlet" at Lincoln Center last month (Which scene? "It's the one where Ophelia goes crazy.") Currently Starring In: A high school production of "Fiddler on the Roof," as Golda. College Plans: To study drama at Rutger University's Mason Gross School of the Arts. Favorite Actress: Drew Barrymore Favorite Ophelia Quote: "Lord, we know what we are, but know not what we may be." Career Goal: "To act on stage, on television, in the movies - whatever comes up." Role Model: Wayne Rose, director of the performing arts program at Red Bank Regional High School, who encouraged her to audition for the Shakespeare competition. Person She Would Like To Meet: "There are a million. I met the actor Robert Sean Leonard once already, but I'd love to see him again." Impressions Of Acting As A Career: "Someone once told me that if you can be talked out of acting, you were never meant to do it. But I could never see myself doing anything else. Every timme I try to picture myself in another career, I realize that I would only want to play it on television." Impressions Of Ophelia: "She's very beautiful, innoncent and fragile. She's pure, but then she's intense. I see her a lot of times in certain people at my high school. Her moods and her situations are very modern, very real. As I get deeper into her, I feel a lot of her coming into me."ABBY GOODNOUGH

title: Final Destinations
description: If you can't take it with you, you might as well leave something splendid behind. As, for example, a Bedouin tent for a Victorian adventurer; an allegory of France grieving for an 18th-century warrior; a pyramid for a Roman magistrate; a tasteful temple for the founder of Christian Science, and an entertainer in eternal song. R.I.P.

title:
In the Region/New Jersey;
'Buyer Beware' Giving Way to 'Buyer Be Aware'
description: A RULING last month by the State Supreme Court that tightened disclosure rules is being hailed by proponents as another in a series of decisions aimed at dispelling the notion of caveat emptor -- let the buyer beware.

title: For Women, the Country Club Is the Big Handicap
description: Respect. Dignity. Equality. Fundamental fairness.

title: A Spruced-Up Beverly Hills Hotel to Reopen
description: The Polo Lounge will be exactly the same; the coffee shop will be exactly the same; the pool will be exactly the same. In fact, when the Beverly Hills Hotel reopens June 3 after a two-and-a-half-year renovation, virtually the entire exterior will be just as it was, according to Kerman Beriker, the general manager.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LOSER DEALS By Peter Viertel. Donald I. Fine, $21.95.

title: What the Critics Can't Wait to See
description: When the immovable object is a book that's been parked on the best-seller list for nearly three years, and the irresistible force is Clint Eastwood, it's natural to wonder what will give. At the very least, "The Bridges of Madison County" will test the maxim that Hollywood finds better movie material in bad books than good ones. Also worth wondering: Will "Apollo 13" fare well in telling a true story that is stranger than any fiction? And will Hugh Grant lend a touch of class to the American comedy "Nine Months"? It would be smashing if he could. -- Janet Maslin

title: Turning the Tides At Mont-St.-Michel
description: For most of its history, the island of Mont-St-Michel off Normandy, with its magnificent Benedictine abbey, has towered above the sea amid the perpetual motion of tides rolling up and receding. Part of its mystical beauty was the illusion that the cone of granite and its fine buildings were afloat. But man's tinkering with the coastline has changed that.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 3-12 IRAN'S NUCLEAR PLANS Iran's top nuclear official said his country intends to build as many as 10 nuclear power plants in the next two decades but denied trying to develop nuclear weapons. 1 JAPAN SAYS NO TO CRIME More than any other developed country, Japan has resolved to "just say no" to crime; Japanese society ostracizes offenders and demands they show remorse. 1

title:
VOICES: FROM THE DESK OF;
A Dabbler's Guide To the Futures Market
description: ACCORDING to most investment advisers, a pensioner like myself should invest his liquid resources primarily in bonds, preferred stocks and blue chips.

title: A Flawed Character
description: GOD A Biography. By Jack Miles. 446 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $27.50.

title: Constructing History The Way You Like It
description: MARK POLO, president of the Polo Gallery here, asks whether archeology is proof of our existence or just a form of manipulation. He does so politely in a brief introduction to "Post-Archeology," the show currently occupying his waterfront gallery, from which can be glimpsed a Manhattan looking like an overcrowded graveyard.

title: Putting A Co-op To Work
description: ANNOYED by film production companies that cordon off sidewalks, park their trailers at the curb, shine their lights into the lobby of some building and then act like what they are doing is a big secret?

title:
MAKING IT WORK;
On 'the Little Hill of Happiness'
description: FROM his backyard perch on a bluff at the edge of the Hunts Point peninsula, Benedict Rives can see clear across the East River basin, from Rikers Island to the Triborough Bridge to the factories of Mott Haven. Sailboats dot the river's rippling, flashing waters. In the distance rise the jagged peaks of Manhattan, silhouetted in the glare of the late-afternoon sun.

title: It's the Category, Not the Fund
description: To the Editor:

title: Whistle or No Whistle, It Stays No Goal
description: Outside the Rangers' practice facility this afternoon, a carnival, complete with clowns and rides, was in full swing.

title: Artisanry Explored In Museum Festival
description: WHEN the Bruce Museum's 10th annual Outdoor Crafts Festival opens at the Roger Sherman Baldwin Park in Greenwich on Saturday, it will be for the last time at this site. Next year the event will revert to its original locale, high on a hill on the museum's grounds. But for now the show meanders on a four-acre-plus peninsula that juts into Greenwich Harbor. Park benches maximize views and provide venues for lunch or tea. And tented structures like sand castles provide respite from sun and rain, as well as creating a Shangri-La atmosphere.

title: Megan Pezzuti, Todd D. Pelino
description: Megan Margaret Anne Pezzuti, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank K. Pezzuti of Fair Haven, N.J., was married yesterday to Todd Douglas Pelino, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Douglas W. Pelino of Pittsford, N.Y. The Rev. Joseph E. Stearns performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at St. William Church in Naples, Fla.

title: Chelsea Is Short-Changed By Community Board 4
description: To the Editor:

title: Lakers Enjoy Celebrity Atmosphere Again
description: Dennis Rodman met Charlie Sheen, Vlade Divac met Chevy Chase, and the San Antonio Spurs met defeat. The playoffs in Hollywood can mean only one thing -- face time -- but the best pose of all has been struck by Nick Van Exel.

title: Man in the News: Jayantha Dhanapala; The Helmsman for the Nuclear Arms Pact
description: As a global conference on the future of the treaty banning the spread of nuclear weapons wound to a close tonight, there was consensus on more than extending the accord indefinitely. Praise for the conference president, Jayantha Dhanapala of Sri Lanka, was even broader and certainly more enthusiastic.

title: If It's Tuesday, This Must Be My Family
description: THEY are the road warriors of business. With their platinum frequent-flier cards and their roll-on luggage, road warriors are the growing number of business travelers who spend more time on the road than in the office -- 70, 90, more than a 100 days a year. And they love it. Hotel clerks know them by name, airlines adore them. Their friends think they are crazy and their children, if they have them, wonder who they are.

title: IN BRIEF
description: Franklin Lakes Says No To a Mini-City for the Elderly

title: Avenue A Safari: Natives Are Restless
description: Anyone who is looking for proof that Avenue A is in the midst of a bona fide economic resurgence need not look any further than the red double-decker tour buses regularly wending their way down the street. Last month, New York Apple Tours added this once derelict street, now bustling with trendy sidewalk cafes and boutiques, to its itinerary, which includes fabled tourist attractions like the Empire State Building, Chinatown and Little Italy.

title: Surely but Slowly, Life Returns to Rivers Scarred by Years of Neglect (and Worse)
description: The lower Saddle River, for now, is just about dead.

title: Former Campers Returning the Favor
description: AT Camp Wonposet at Bantam Lake in Morris, founded in 1906, R. Mark Davis, the director, turns on the computer in his office. Soon a row of names appears on the screen, along with addresses and telephone numbers. These are among the 2,000 or so former campers Mr. Davis tracks for what he calls the "Wonposet Old Boys Association."

title: Istanbul's King of Kilims
description: Just as you can drink tea anywhere but should go to Japan for a tea ceremony, you can buy rugs in New York or London but for the full flavor of the rug cult should head to Istanbul.

title: The Riviera Next Door
description: THE Connecticut landscape conjures images of stone walls, tony suburban houses and the perfect ratio of split rails and wrought-iron gates. Joan and Michael Gray's garden is different. For starters, there is the scent of rosemary wafting off the terrace. Squint into the sun reflected in the Long Island Sound below and, for a second, you might be in Cannes waiting for Cary Grant to pick your pockets. The pool across the lawn prolongs the fantasy. It is smack against a sea wall so close that the occasional wave laps over a low flagstone parapet. The peaked tin roofs of two attendant pavilions strike a most un-Connecticut-like note of seaside pageantry.

title: Mental Health in an H.M.O.: 'A Quick Therapeutic Jolt'
description: To the Editor: The public needs to know more about the damage that managed mental health care can cause.

title: From the Appeals Court Decision
description: Following are excerpts from a decision handed down Friday by the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit finding constitutional an amendment to the City Charter of Cincinnati that prohibits the City Council and other government bodies from granting "minority or protected status" to homosexuals in any law, regulation or policy:

title: Twentieth Century Girding for the Millennium
description: IN the city where everything's up to date, Twentieth Century Mutual Funds is about to go the way of the buggy whip -- in name, at least. Approaching the new millennium, the company needs a new identity, a marketing nightmare in an industry in which reputation and name recognition are among the biggest assets.

title: The Singular Follies Of Sir Francis
description: ONE visits some houses because they bear witness to remarkable lives, others because they epitomize a period or a style, still others simply because they are beautiful. West Wycombe Park, a country house in Buckinghamshire within easy reach of London, encompasses all three, but its greatest interest lies in the way it records an enthusiasm -- the mania for building that revised the English landscape in the 18th century and ushered in the fashion for whimsical little structures that came to be known as follies. The folly was by definition of no practical use, other than to satisfy its creator's appetite for the sublime.

title: Adults Recall Suffering Abuse
description: THIRTEEN years after Susan Psillos was sexually abused at the age of 4 by four teen-age boys in her neighborhood in Centereach, she continued to remember the incident. She was living in Wading River and was on her way to having several abusive relationships, some involving rape, because, she said, she "thought that was normal."

title: A Bargain Grill Dinner In Southwestern Style
description: THE Southwestern-Texas grill dinner served on Thursdays at Jim Tonic's in Huntington Station is one of the biggest $10.99 meals on Long Island.

title: Secret in the Attic
description: RESISTANCE By Anita Shreve.222 pp. Boston:Little, Brown & Company.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Valley People

title: A Kind Word for Stepmothers
description: The word "stepmother" has long connoted cruelty, neglect and jealousy. Ask Cinderella or Snow White -- or a friend of mine. For the first years of her remarriage, her stepchildren called her a "stepmonster."

title: C.I.A. Staff Hears of Plan for Shakeup From the New Boss Himself
description: When the top brass at the Central Intelligence Agency took their assigned seats at a "town meeting" on Thursday at the agency's headquarters to welcome their new director, John M. Deutch, the joke going around the room was that beneath each chair was a trap door.

title: TICKET TO TROUBLE
description: Your article states that lotteries are a "regressive tax since play [ is ] concentrated among minorities." This is inaccurate in one crucial respect. The lottery is not a tax; no one is forced to buy a lottery ticket. ANDREW T. LONG Brooklyn

title: Just a Damn Minute
description: YOU ARE SHORT of time. Technologists know this and are trying to help -- in their fashion.

title: Study Ties Educational Gains To More Productivity Growth
description: The first detailed American business survey of its kind, a study conducted by the Census Bureau for the Federal Department of Education, has found that increases in workers' education levels produce twice the gain in workplace efficiency as comparable increases in the value of tools and machinery.

title: Ideas & Trends; Now, the Magazines of 'Me'
description: "IT'S true, every word of it. I really am fat. I really am a slob. This really is the diary of a really fat slob."

title: SCHOOL: The Teaching Game
description: 'A breakthrough in education," says Cheryl Coles, principal of P.S. 68 in the Bronx, where the P.T.A. just paid $1,084 for giant pieces to equip two chessboards (one shown above, playfully rearranged) painted on the schoolyard pavement.

title: A Sense of the Unreal In New Orleans Flood
description: In the midst of a three-day exercise this week to learn how to cope with a killer hurricane, 3,000 Federal, state and local officials taking part in the drill were slapped in the face by reality: a spring storm remarkably like the edge of the storm being simulated.

title: Getting to Know Mr. Lincoln
description: In September, I moved to Washington to take up a teaching job at George Washington University. I was provided housing in a brownstone the college owns in a once-swampy area of town called Foggy Bottom. From my house, the White House was about five blocks east, the Kennedy Center about the same distance in the other direction. I found my way around Foggy Bottom quickly enough. Like that of many cities, the history of Washington is about water. There's always too much or too little. Less bossy than it used to be, the Potomac River now cradles Foggy Bottom. Parkland along the riverbank provides ample walking paths, north and south and across the river into Virginia. I walked and walked, to Cleveland Park, to Georgetown.

title: A Menu of Massages
description: Like ordering a cup of coffee, deciding on a massage nowadays is not the simple choice it used to be. The Four Seasons Hotel New York, at 57 East 57th Street, offers a menu of eight different massages at its fitness club. One of them, for example, is designed to prepare travelers for a long flight, with aromatherapy and a cup of chamomile tea. For those at the other end of the itinerary, a jet-lag massage helps remoisturize dry skin and fight dehydration. Whatever the choice, the traveler's credit card gets a brisk rubdown, too: Each massage costs $110 for hotel guests and $120 for nonguests. Call the Four Seasons Hotel New York's fitness center at (212) 350-6420.

title: Accord on Nudists On Fire I.
description: IN characteristic Fire Island "live and let live" fashion, four organizations have reached an agreement that will continue nude swimming and sunbathing at Fire Island Light on the National Seashore east of Robert Moses State Park.

title: Victoria McKee, Gregory D'Agostino
description: Victoria Robinson McKee, a daughter of Kathryn C. McKee of New York and Thomas J. McKee of Wilton, Conn., was married yesterday to Gregory Gerard D'Agostino, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen I. D'Agostino of Hobe Sound, Fla. The Rev. Stan Mosley performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the Church of St. Thomas More in New York.

title: No. 1 Fan of Knicks' 6th Man
description: AS the New York Knicks super sub Anthony Mason held aloft the trophy he received for winning the National Basketball Association's Sixth Man Award before the Knick-Indiana Pacer second playoff game on Tuesday night, he tilted it up toward his mother, sitting just above courtside.

title: Where Have All The Doctors Gone?
description: FOR Loretta Cullen of Waterford, who has been hospitalized many times over the past few years, finding a doctor proved to be almost as big a challenge as her illnesses.

title: Drifter Says He Knew Bombing Suspect, But Inquiry Fails to Tie Him to Explosion
description: An armed drifter who was arrested Friday on Federal weapons charges has told investigators that he knew Timothy J. McVeigh, one of two men charged with the bombing of the Federal Building in Oklahoma City, but so far, investigators said today, there is no evidence to link him to the bombing.

title: Galway. Western Ireland's Lilting Heart
description: Galway is one of the liveliest and most attractive towns in the whole of Ireland. It is the undisputed capital of Connacht, the western province that contains Counties Galway, Leitrim, Mayo, Roscommon and Sligo. Built at the shallow, turbulent mouth of the Corrib River, protected from the Atlantic by a wide, deep bay, it falls somewhere between a large town and a city, with many of the advantages of both but without their attendant ills. It is the only university town the region boasts, and is a center for medicine, fishing, light industry and tourism, with easy access to a richly varied hinterland.

title: A. M. Withington, Robert M. Elwood
description: Dr. Amelia Margaret Withington, a psychiatrist at Hahnemann University Hospital in Philadelphia, was married yesterday to Robert Murray Elwood, an associate at Dechert Price & Rhoads, a law firm in Philadelphia. The Quaker ceremony was held at the Appleford Estate in Villanova, Pa.

title: Giorgio Belladonna, 72, Player On Fabled Italian Bridge Team
description: Giorgio Belladonna, one of the greatest bridge players of all time, died on Friday in Rome. He was 72 years old.

title: She's a Poor Orphan, but It Could Be Worse
description: Ride for Your Life An interactive film at the Sony Theater at 19th Street in Manhattan and other theaters in the New York metropolitan area. Adam West Directed by Bob Bejan PG Audiences see two back-to-back showings of a film that runs between 19 and 24 minutes, depending on the scenarios created by viewers using pistol-grip controls to determine the action.

title: 'Turandot' Without Music in the Bronx
description: SINCE the theater has already had a go with Goldoni two goes, actually -- and one with Machiavelli, the executive director, Marco Greco, and the artistic director, Dante R. Albertie Jr., of the Belmont Italian American Playhouse figured it is by rights Gozzi's turn. "Besides, I didn't want Gozzi cursing the theater from the grave," Mr. Greco said.

title: Your Wine God Will Serve You Now
description: THE EXECUTIVES at Caesars Atlantic City could have called their newest restaurant Son of Bacchanal, or perhaps Bach II: the Future. Linguistic subtlety -- or subtlety of any kind -- has never been a high priority with Caesars; when it opened a French restaurant called Le Posh in 1984, and someone pointed out that the term posh is British slang that has nothing to do with French, the late Nat Hart, then the Caesars food and beverage executive, snapped, "Who cares?"

title: Pacers Can Make Do Without Davis
description: As the last two reporters finally cleared the crowded Indiana Pacers locker room, Dale Davis could spread out and relax. His right shoulder was wrapped up in a bandage, which covered up bags of ice. He winced from the pain caused by his shoulder first popping out of its socket after a collision during the Pacers' 98-84 victory over the Knicks and then popping back in minutes later.

title: Cancer Fear Is Unfounded, Physicists Say
description: The world's largest group of physicists, the American Physical Society, has taken a stance on a contentious public health issue by saying it can find no evidence that the electromagnetic fields that radiate from power lines cause cancer.

title: Political Figures of Speech
description: Of the recorded words of Ulysses S. Grant -- from "I propose to fight it out on this line, if it takes all summer" to "Let us have peace" -- the most unexpected and revealing are these, in a July 1885 letter to his physician, John H. Douglas, shortly before his death: "I am a verb."

title: A Plan to Revamp Vocational Education
description: THE pathway to work in America is rocky. "Whether we are dealing with the culinary arts or any other vocation, the real problem is our dismal record of readying our youth for the world of work," said Rudiger J. Flik, president of Flik International, a food service company in Mamaroneck. Using his industry as an example, Mr. Flik pointed out that the food service industry was one of the nation's largest providers of jobs, employing about six million people in eating and drinking establishments alone. "Yet currently there are only 64,000 students enrolled in the industry's educational programs," Mr. Flik said. "That's a drop in the bucket when you realize that approximately three million students graduate from high school every year with about only half of them going on to higher education."

title: ON THE TOWNS
description: MUSIC

title: Mom the Provider
description: Everyone knows there are women at work. But working women, especially those with families, are still seen as supplemental. Sure, there have been the high-powered mothers: Michelle Pfeiffer, Hillary Clinton, Marcia Clark, who outearned their husbands or supported their children alone. But out of the limelight, ordinary women's earning power has been growing substantially, too. No longer do they provide just the extra cash for a vacation or a new car.

title: This Home-Grown Idea Went National
description: Wendy Kopp was a 21-year-old student at Princeton University in 1989 when she used her senior thesis to propose the creation of a national teacher corps. Her goal was to give teaching an aura of selectivity and status.

title: Article 720095 -- No Title
description: I was saddened by your photographic essay "$6 a Dance" (April 23). Although it may be representative of the way in which we in modern Western society view the elderly, I had hoped for more sensitivity from your magazine. Elderly ladies are not garish buffoons. Yes, there are little miracles of friendship and the pleasures of social dancing. However, the tenor of your report is denigrating and snide.

title: From the Heights, Hill, and Slope
description: BRAWTA CAFE ++ (718) 855-5515; 105 Bond Street, Boerum Hill; $; no credit cards

title: A Glittering Legacy
description: The original Metropolitan Opera House was built in the 1880's because clannish "old money" (the Astors) would not let "new money" (the Vanderbilts) have boxes at the Academy of Music, where society attended grand opera. A miffed Vanderbilt, along with a Roosevelt, a Goelet and a Havemeyer proceeded to build a bigger house with more boxes at 39th Street and Broadway.

title: In the Tale of a Mugger, A Message for Everybody
description: To the Editor:

title: For 3 Street Oracles, Store Is Toil and Trouble
description: Ancient Greeks flocked to the Delphic oracle for counsel. Charlie Brown paid Lucy a nickel for tidbits of wisdom. And since 1988, confused New Yorkers have gathered at the corner of West Broadway and Broome Street to seek free advice from the Advice Ladies, three self-described "Ann Landers in black" who answer questions on topics that vary from naming your baby to "getting rid of your jerk."

title: A Child-Abuse Case, in the Eyes of the Accused
description: IT WAS THE LONGEST AND MOST expensive criminal case in the nation's history. It set a baseline for the legal exploration of child abuse and its treatment by the courts, the police and the press. And it left a legacy of bitterness and ruined reputations.

title: Guarded From Pollution, Da Vinci on View Again
description: "The Last Supper," Leonardo da Vinci's masterpiece, has reopened to the public in Milan after a six-month project that effectively constructed a bubble of clean air around the fragile wall painting to protect it from pollution.

title: Words, Children, Mothers and Sisters
description: Plenty of parties, and for plenty of causes.

title: In Montclair, a Historic House With a Recent History
description: A year ago, Ellen F. Cooke, then treasurer of the national Episcopal Church, and her husband, the Rev. Nicholas T. Cooke 3d, paid $465,000 for this house in Montclair, just up the street from St. Luke's Church, where Mr. Cooke was rector.

title: A Celestial City
description: ANGELS designed Puebla, the story goes, and you can see these celestial town planners in a mural in the Museo Amparo. Finished in 1990 by Pedro Diego de Alvarado, it shows four angels, each with a plumb line, hard at work on the fledgling town while the Blessed Virgin hovers over them looking for all the world like a stern site engineer. We now know why Mary seems so worried. Puebla was built on a fault line.

title: Singer's Success Requires Reading Between the Bottom Lines
description: INVESTORS love a good story, and the Singer Company has all the makings of a best seller: a strong brand name, operations in exploding consumer markets like China and India and plenty of fans on Wall Street.

title: From Friel, 6 Characters Yearn for Renewal
description: BE IT dreaming the impossible dream, ascending out of the commonplace into the rare or finding the sweet mystery of life, it's the pop song that has routinely given voice to grand passions touched by idealism and romance.

title: Artist Says Setting's Revealing, Nudity Isn't
description: For three years Spencer Tunick has defied convention by photographing nude models in public all over the world, including in London, Paris, Jerusalem and Los Angeles. His only arrest came last Dec. 31, at Rockefeller Center.

title: Feeling Threatened, Lakehurst Clings to Its Landmark
description: For more than six decades, Lakehurst has been home to the Naval Air Engineering Station, a development center for aircraft and aircraft carriers that is perhaps best known as the place where the German zeppelin Hindenburg burned at its mooring on May 6, 1937, killing 36 people.

title: The World; For Serbs, a Reckoning
description: IT was not so much the Croatian armed forces sweeping through the Serbian enclave of western Slavonia this month that gave a sense of the direction of the Balkan wars. It was the fleets of Croatian builders, engineers, bankers and telecommunications experts following in their wake.

title: Q and A
description: Studying in Latin America

title:
ART;
New Soundings From a Poet of Industrial Debris
description: A SIGN IS POSTED AT THE entrance to the Storm King Art Center, the 400-acre sculpture park in Mountainville, N.Y. "No touching, no climbing, no dogs," it admonishes visitors to the mammoth outdoor artworks -- David Smiths and Alexander Calders, a new Richard Serra, an even newer Magdalena Abakanowicz and many more. That sign will also greet the large numbers expected to arrive after yesterday's opening of Mark di Suvero's first American museum exhibition in 10 years.

title: Mets' Bullpen Collapses Again
description: Dave Mlicki did his job. Once again, the Mets' relievers did not do theirs.

title: For Many, a Slower Climb Up the Payroll Pecking Order
description: LAWYERS are famous for being in oversupply. Any labor expert will tell you that. Yet, somehow, they are the best paid workers in America today. Obviously, lawyers who do get work don't discount their fees.

title: Despair Not
description: To the Editor:

title: Mayoral Race Widens In Yonkers Despite Past
description: THE last thing Republican Party leaders in this city want is deja vu all over again.

title: Sleep Disorder May Affect Many Truck Drivers, Researchers Say
description: A sleep disorder that causes fatigue may affect many of the nation's long-haul truck drivers, raising the risks on America's highways, researchers at Stanford University said.

title: Speaking in Tongues
description: No, these signs aren't describing the quickest way to get to Lenin's Tomb or to Tiananmen Square. Rather, they tell subway riders the best way to get around New York. With the Manhattan Bridge closed to subway riders on weekends and at midday, the Transit Authority has posted signs in Russian (mainly for Brighton Beach residents) and in Chinese (for Sunset Park and Chinatown residents) describing how to cope with the changes over the next six months.

title: Alpa J. Desai, Alpesh R. Chokshi
description: Alpa J. Desai, a daughter of Hansa and Javahar Desai of North Potomac, Md., is to be married today in Baltimore to Alpesh R. Chokshi, a son of Vijya and Ramesh Chokshi of Reading, Pa. Harendra Dave, a Hindu priest, is to perform the ceremony at the Marriott Hotel at the Baltimore-Washington International Airport.

title: It's All in the Story, and How You Tell It
description: MERIS PALMER, a therapeutic recreation director from Waterbury, was sitting with a dozen people in a Cheshire living room one recent evening. Rising with apologies and the admission that she had hoped to be able to leave that night without speaking, she instead starting using gestures and different voices to tell the group a Native American folk tale about an octopus and a crow.

title: Gomez Loses Arbitration With Orioles
description: The Baltimore Orioles yesterday won baseball's first salary arbitration case that was heard and decided by three arbitrators. The panel ruled for the Orioles and a $925,000 salary over the $1.85 million salary sought by LEO GOMEZ, their third baseman. Gomez had a $550,000 salary last year.

title: Correction Officers Become Last of 83 Unions to Reach Pact With the City
description: The union representing New York City correction officers reached agreement on a new contract with the city yesterday, becoming the last of the city's 83 municipal unions to reach a deal in the current round of bargaining. The pact marked the first time that all the city's uniformed service unions have agreed to the same level of increases as other city workers.

title: Is This Long Run A Newt Rally?
description: Call it the Gingrich Gallop. Wall Street's current rally began in November, with bonds starting to advance despite widespread pessimism. It took a few weeks for the stock market to join in, but it has now done so with a vengeance. Now even the dollar is showing signs of life.

title: The Great Street Fair Crunch
description: The battle over street fairs is entering a fractious new phase as city officials clamp down on the size and duration of many events, citing quality-of-life issues and the need to cut police and sanitation costs.

title: Colonial Officer Statue Moving From Mystic
description: REPRESENTATIVES of the Golden Hill Paugussett, Schagticoke, Wampanouag, Nipmuck, Mohawk, Lakota, Seminole and Cherokee tribes were there. So were officials of the Narragansett and Mohegan tribes as well as the Pequots. There were ceremonial offerings of tobacco and sweetgrass and a moment of silence.

title: Ms. Oestreicher Haspel, Mr. Bernheim
description: Rachel Oestreicher Haspel, the president of the Raoul Wallenberg Committee of the United States, a human rights organization in New York, was married last evening to Charles Alexander Bernheim, a managing director of Bear, Stearns & Company, the New York investment bank. Rabbi Ronald B. Sobel performed the ceremony at the bridegroom's apartment in New York.

title: These $2,000 Boots Are Handmade for Walking
description: BILL COSBY says he finally faced reality "somewhere between the wingtips and the Weejuns."

title: F.B.I. Seeks A Couple On the Run
description: A United States magistrate issued a Federal fugitive warrant yesterday for the Manhattan gym teacher who ran away with a 15-year-old ninth grader two months ago. The F.B.I. immediately joined the case and threw its nationwide resources into the previously limited search for the elusive couple.

title: Thoughts on Motherhood Not Captured in Cards
description: UPTOWN -- Robin Quivers, Howard Stern's sidekick on his radio show and self-styled Queen of All Media, doesn't make a big deal of Mother's Day.

title: When In Rome, Get A Haircut
description: Having lived in Rome for a dozen years, I fly back once or twice annually and always go through the same rituals of readjustment. I slug down a cappuccino, I order a bowl of spaghetti con vongole -- and I have a haircut. This last act may seem strange, but in fact it signifies that I've truly returned. Rome is a city scaled to human dimensions and can only be summed up by a person. For me, that person is Sandra Kennedy, a hairdresser whose pluck, talent for improvisation, cleverness, self-deprecating humor, beauty and tensile strength are the embodiment of a metropolis that calls itself eternal, yet displays the frenetic energy of a fruit fly living only for the moment.

title: Ideas & Trends; Notes From the Underground
description: Personal zines often carry a small box introducing the writers to their readers, like this one from Pagan's Head:

title: The Outsider
description: POPE JOHN PAUL II The Biography. By Tad Szulc. Illustrated. 542 pp. New York: A Lisa Drew Book/Scribner. $27.50.

title: May 7-12: Chronology of Terror; Prosecutors Build A Case Against McVeigh and Nichols
description: "Go for it!!" Terry Lynn Nichols is said to have written to his former Army buddy, Timothy J. McVeigh, in a letter last November as the pair embarked on what prosecutors portrayed last week as a terrorist's shopping spree. For six months, the authorities said, the two men methodically assembled the raw materials used in the 4,800-pound bomb that they are accused of detonating outside the Oklahoma City Federal building on April 19, killing 166 people.

title: A Young Pianist Tries to Reinvent the Past
description: SOMETIME DURING A performance by the jazz pianist Marcus Roberts, the New appears. Not some rehashed notion of the avant-garde, noisy and wild, but something that hasn't been heard before. Mr. Roberts has the tools to reach new territory, and not surprising, they derive from a knowledge of history. Among his generation, the 30-year-old Mr. Roberts is one of the few pianists who has assimilated the sound of the piano in 20th-century American music. His playing incorporates the whirring and grinding of the stride players, the energy, rhythms and ideas of blues and ragtime that provide much of jazz's foundation.

title:
FILM;
The Un-Cannes Film Festival
description: THE LINEUP OF FILMS invited to compete in the Cannes International Film Festival, which begins on Wednesday, is impressive, with Christopher Hampton's "Carrington" (about the Bloomsbury group), Ken Loach's "Land and Freedom" (about the Spanish Civil War) and Nicholas Hytner's "Madness of King George" from Britain.

title: TICKET TO TROUBLE
description: Thank you for Lois Gould's eye-opening article "Ticket to Trouble" (April 23) on how the lottery system really functions. I think New York State should change the motto to "It only takes a dollar, a dream, a good attorney, an excellent accountant and a personal financial adviser."

title: Box Populi
description: THE TOTAL PACKAGE The Evolution and Secret Meanings of Boxes, Bottles, Cans, and Tubes. By Thomas Hine. Illustrated. 289 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Company.

title: ANIMALS OF THE WEEK: Off With Their Heads
description: Eating endangered species, according to Nabisco, is the best way to save them. The company recently released its limited edition Endangered Collection of Barnum's Animal Crackers, featuring 16 endangered animals.

title: A New Glimpse of the Heyday of the Peconic Art Colony
description: IN the 1840's, Walt Whitman admired the North Fork for its rural beauty, quaint characters and simple life. At the turn of the century those qualities attracted the Peconic Art Colony, two of whose members are among the best-kept secrets in art history.

title: Mount Vernon Seeks to Lease Memorial Field
description: THE impressive Romanesque columns and arches of the Memorial Field grandstand here have stood proud on Sanford Boulevard and Garden Avenue for more than 64 years. This aging brick and limestone stadium and its 12 acres of track and field, which are in need of major repairs, have provided residents with recreational open space and countless nostalgic memories.

title: Providing Sanctuary for Retired Nuns
description: THE woman was asleep, her body elevated slightly in the portable hospital bed and her chapped lips parted in a silent half moon. Sunlight from an exquisite spring afternoon streamed into the room and a 1940's big band tune wafted from the radio, just loud enough to be heard. Sister Jeanne Giebelhouse, a nun from the Ursuline Order, gestured at the woman and spoke in a hushed but very precise voice. "I don't want to tell you her name," Sister Jeanne said, "but I'll tell you about her."

title: CUNY Campuses Prepare to Reduce Faculty and Classes
description: Bracing for the one-two punch of state and city budget cuts, retrenchment committees at each of the City University of New York's 18 colleges are drafting plans to reduce the number of faculty members and classes by 25 percent, eliminate departments, cut security staffs and even have some professors cleaning their own offices.

title: SOUTH STREET SEAPORT; Celebrating the Tattoo, Past and Present
description: THE thoroughly modern mother may not dream of having her son show up for Mother's Day with "I love Mom" tattooed on his forearm, but in the 19th century the tattoo was a popular way for sailors to show loyalty and devotion to their mothers.

title: Fugitive Slaves and the Bitter Price of Freedom
description: THE time is 1859. The place is northern Virginia. The night is bitter cold. Everything is ominous, and that includes bolts of lightning, claps of thunder and the smell of smoke spreading through the woods.

title: Have You Hugged Your Computer Today?
description: MY NAME is David. I am afraid of my computer.
