description: The following list of performers and concert dates is selective. Performances are subject to change. Arizona

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: BODYTALK The Meaning of Human Gestures.By Desmond Morris.Crown, paper, $14.

title: Rosemary Conlan, John K. Braniff
description: Rosemary Conlan, a daughter of Agnes and Joseph Conlan of Aberdeen, N.J., was married yesterday to John Kevin Braniff, a son of Carol and Edward Braniff of Holmdel, N.J. The Rev. Michael Lanning performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at Holy Trinity Church in New York.

title: Hope H. Eighmy, Michael Pascucci
description: Hope Harden Eighmy, the daughter of Beverly and Thomas Eighmy of Washington, was married yesterday to Michael Philip Pascucci, a son of Francis and Philip Pascucci of Beverly, Mass. The Rev. Elton Smith performed the Episcopal ceremony at St. Alban's Parish in Washington.

title: Dolphin Draft Choice's Career in Jeopardy
description: The Miami Dolphins rookie receiver SHANNON MYERS lost part of a kidney as a result of an injury during a workout, and his career is in jeopardy. Myers landed on his elbow and lacerated a kidney trying to catch a pass from BERNIE KOSAR and underwent surgery last Sunday. The last player chosen by the Dolphins in this year's National Football League draft, Myers is out for the season and uncertain whether he will be able to play again. Myers set receiving records at tiny Lenoir-Rhyne College in Hickory, N.C. (AP)

title: Mothers Dear
description: America's generous image if itself is in grave danger this Mother's Day. Out of habit, we've sent 155 million cards to moms, grandmoms and moms-in-law, and millions of $25 bouquets. Today we'll call or visit, and maybe go out to dinner -- reinforcing the piety that motherhood remains sacred. But the vocabulary of America's politics no longer jibes with our greeting-card sentiments. Motherhood among the poorest Americans is now held in contempt, and the children of those poor mothers are being promised "liberation from dependency" on public support.

title: On Sunday; Pledge Night In the Sorority Of the Robbed
description: THE CITY has a way of mauling flowers in the spring, letting them show up bright and true for a bit, but then scuffing them underfoot in wayward human traffic. Blithe spirits get the same treatment.

title: She's a Poor Orphan, but It Could Be Worse
description: Crimson Tide Gene Hackman, Denzel Washington Directed by Tony Scott R 113 minutes

title: And Now, Something For the Grown-Ups
description: BETWEEN SUCH COSTLY summer extravaganzas as "Waterworld" and "Batman Forever," between children's films ranging from "Pocahontas" to "Mighty Morphin Power Rangers: The Movie," the summer's jammed release schedule includes a surprising number of adult movies too. (Well, moviegoers can at least hope that they are meant for people over the age of 25.)

title: Court Upholds Anti-Homosexual Initiative
description: A Federal appeals court has upheld the right of Cincinnati voters to deprive homosexuals of specific legal protections, dealing a serious setback to the gay and lesbian civil rights movement.

title: TICKET TO TROUBLE
description: I unabashedly acknowledge that I am a lottery dreamer. In my defense, my mini-addiction began years ago when New York State convinced me the lottery receipts went to education. These days, my boss promises that if he wins the lottery, he'll give me a car phone (but not a car). I promise him a car, after bumming rides home, but later quip that, if I win, I'll be his boss. I dream about the charities (besides my own) that I would lavish checks on. My sibs and parents would live comfortably. I would vacation in the dying rain forests of Madagascar and spend the rest of the year in Ireland and Israel, investigating my cultural and religious roots.

title: BENEFITS
description: 100th-Birthday Party MONDAY -- The Union Settlement Association will celebrate 100 years of service to East Harlem with a party at the New York Academy of Medicine, 1216 Fifth Avenue (enter at 103d Street). The event, from 6 to 8:30 P.M., will include refreshments, entertainment, dancing and a silent auction. Tickets, $125, from (212) 360-8818 or at the door. Playwrights' Readings MONDAY -- Edward Albee, Maria Irene Fornes and Romulus Linney are among the playwrights who will read from their works at a benefit for Theater for the New City, 155 First Avenue (10th Street). A reception at 7 will be followed by the reading at 7:30 and a panel discussion on "An Artist's Responsibility in the Gingrich Years." Tickets $25, from (212) 254-1109. River Spirit MONDAY -- Gov. George E. Pataki of New York will speak at a black-tie fund-raiser at the Pierre for Scenic Hudson, an environmental organization that works to protect the Hudson Valley. Cocktails at 6:30 will be followed by dinner, dancing and a live auction at 7:30. Tickets, $350, from (212) 838-2660. For Manhattan Theater Club MONDAY -- The Manhattan Theater Club will benefit from a dinner and musical performance at the New York Hilton. Cocktails at 7 will be followed by dinner. Then, Stockard Channing, Nathan Lane, Mary-Louise Parker and others will perform tunes from current Broadway musicals. Tickets, $350, from (212) 645-5590, extension 141. In Support of Jewish Artists MONDAY -- The National Foundation for Jewish Culture will present an evening of dance, music and drama performances in the Sylvia and Danny Kaye Playhouse at Hunter College, 68th Street (Lexington Avenue). Amy Irving, Ron Rifkin and Eli Wallach are among those scheduled to perform, and Arthur Miller will be among those honored for contributions to the arts. The event, which will raise money for arts grants, begins with a 6 P.M. cocktail reception at the Asia Society, 725 Park Avenue (70th Street), followed by the performances at 8. Tickets, $500, from (212) 629-0500, extension 215. Scholarship Dinner MONDAY -- The Brown University Club in New York will hold a black-tie dinner at the Plaza to raise funds for regional scholarships. A reception at 6:30 P.M. will be followed by dinner and dancing. Tickets, $350, from (212) 861-6496. Cancer Society at the Pierre TUESDAY -- The American Cancer Society will hold a black-tie dinner-dance at the Pierre to raise money for its research, education and patient-care programs. Cocktails at 7 will be followed by dinner and dancing at 8 to the Bob Hardwick Sound. Charlotte Ford will be among those honored. Tickets, $350, from (212) 237-3890. Spirits of the City TUESDAY -- A Spirit of the City Awards ceremony will benefit the arts and social service programs of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. Cocktails at 6:30 P.M. will be followed by dinner and the awards ceremony, which will honor the choreographer Jerome Robbins and the late Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis, among others. The violinist Midori and the composer and pianist Marvin Hamlisch, both honorees, will perform at the black-tie event. All at the cathedral, 112th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Tickets, $500, from (212) 675-9474. Radio Days TUESDAY -- The American Federation of Television and Radio Artists will hold a fund-raiser for its scholarship fund at Cafe 44, 315 West 44th Street. Members of the organization will perform a vintage radio mystery. The event begins at 6:30, and dinner will be served at 7. Cash bar. Tickets, $35, from (212) 532-0800. For Older New Yorkers TUESDAY -- The Council of Senior Centers and Services of New York City, which provides assistance to the elderly, will benefit from a cocktail reception at the reading room of the McGraw-Hill building, 1221 Avenue of the Americas (48th Street). The reception at 5 P.M. will be followed by the presentation of an award to Peggy and Alan Tishman. Tickets, $100, from (212) 563-7160. Havana on the Park TUESDAY -- The Henry Street Settlement, a social services organization, will benefit from "A Night in Havana," dancing and games of chance, starting at 7 at the Fourth Universalist Society Landmark on the Park, 160 Central Park West (76th Street). Dinner, dancing and entertainment are included. The designer Vera Wang will be among those honored. Black tie or white dinner jacket. Tickets, $500, or $175 for those 35 and under, from (212) 766-9211. Lung Association Auction WEDNESDAY -- An auction of autographed celebrity memorabilia, weekend trips, jewelry and other items at the Racquet and Tennis Club, 370 Park Avenue (53d Street), will benefit the American Lung Association's pediatric health programs. The auction and reception will begin at 6 P.M. Mary Civiello, a news anchor at WNBC-TV, will speak. Tickets, $30, from (212) 889-3370. For Press Freedom WEDNESDAY -- The Reporters Committee for Freedom of the Press will benefit from a cartoon auction and dinner to celebrate its 25th anniversary. A. M. Rosenthal, a columnist and the former executive editor of The New York Times; John Chancellor, a former commentator for NBC News; Benjamin C. Bradlee, the former executive editor of The Washington Post, and the political cartoonist Herb Block, also of The Post, will be honored for their support of the First Amendment. Tom Brokaw, Peter Jennings and Dan Rather will lead the evening. The author Calvin Trillin is to speak. The fund-raiser will be held in NBC's Studio 8H at 30 Rockefeller Plaza. Cocktails are at 6:30. The auction will include original political and strip cartoons. Tickets, $500, from (212) 353-8200. New York City Ballet THURSDAY -- The New York City Ballet will perform the premiere of Jerome Robbins's "West Side Story Suite" at 7:30 P.M. in the New York State Theater at Lincoln Center. The black-tie benefit performance will be followed by a dinner-dance at 9:30. Tickets, $675, or $12 to $65 for the performance alone, from (212) 870-5585. A Charlie Parker Tribute THURSDAY -- A jazz concert at the Supper Club, 240 West 47th Street, will pay tribute to Charlie Parker. The event will benefit the Veritas Therapeutic Community, a drug- and alcohol-treatment program in New York. Donald Byrd, Benny Powell, Ron Carter, Max Roach, Milt Jackson and Paquito d'Rivera are among those scheduled to perform. Representative Charles B. Rangel of Harlem will speak. Drinks and hors d'oeuvres at 6:30; the concert, 8:30. Tickets, $250, or $50 for the concert alone, from (212) 865-9182. The Iris Ball THURSDAY -- The Iris Ball, a dinner-dance for the Manhattan League of Helen Keller Services, an agency for the blind, will be held at the Metropolitan Club, 1 East 60th Street. The black-tie event begins with cocktails at 7. Tickets, $300, from (212) 285-7029. The Dessoff Choirs THURSDAY -- The Dessoff Choirs will celebrate 70 years of musical performances at a benefit in the Alger Mansion, 45 Downing Street (Bedford Street). Cocktails and hors d'oeuvres at 6:30 P.M. will be followed by a silent auction and a performance by the choir. Tickets, $40, from (212) 935-2551. Operation Smile on the Intrepid THURSDAY -- The New York chapter of Operation Smile, which provides reconstructive plastic surgery free to children who attend New York City public schools, will benefit from a dinner at the Intrepid Sea-Air-Space Museum, West 46th Street and 12th Avenue. Cocktails will be served at 6:30. Gen. John W. Vessey Jr. will be honored. Tickets, $150, from (212) 366-5300. Just for Laughs THURSDAY -- An evening of humor at the Horticultural Society of New York, 128 West 58th Street, will include a performance by Cassandra Danz, a satirist known as Mrs. Greenthumbs, who will speak on "The Great American Lawn, and How to Get Rid of It." The 7-to-9 P.M. event, called "Women in the Arts for Laughs," will benefit Watson Arts, a resident theater company of La MaMa E.T.C. Wine and hors d'oeuvres and other performances will also be included. Tickets, $60, from (718) 624-9854. For New York Cares FRIDAY -- New York Cares, a volunteer program, will benefit from an evening of wine tasting, from 6 to 10, at the 200 Fifth Club, 200 Fifth Avenue (23d Street). A buffet, an auction and lectures on wine and the wine industry are included. Tickets, $75, from (212) 228-5000. Salsa Dance FRIDAY -- The associates' division of the Samuel Waxman Cancer Research Foundation will benefit from salsa music and dancing from 8 until midnight at La Belle Epoque, 827 Broadway (12th Street). A buffet dinner, an open bar and a raffle are included. Tickets, $65, from (212) 241-6771, or $75 at the door. A Ball at the Grand Hyatt SATURDAY -- A black-tie dinner-dance at the Grand Hyatt will benefit Long Island College Hospital in Brooklyn. Cocktails begin at 7 P.M. Tickets, $350, from (718) 780-1234. Jamaica Bay Bird Watch NEXT SUNDAY -- The nature-protection work of the New York City Audubon Society will benefit from a bird-watching cruise around the islets of Jamaica Bay aboard the Express I. Representatives of the Audubon Society will provide commentary on their research and preservation work along the Jamaica Bay coast. A buffet dinner is included. The Express I will depart from Pier 11, at Wall Street and the East River, at 5:30 P.M. Cash bar. Tickets, $100, from (212) 691-7483. Lyrics and Lyricists MAY 22 -- Liza Minnelli will lead an evening of performances at the 92d Street Y, 1395 Lexington Avenue, that will highlight 25 years of lyrics and lyricists. Performers include the singers Karen Mason, KT Sullivan and Tovah Feldshuh and the composers Burton Lane and Charles Strouse. The Y's educational, cultural, social service and health programs will benefit. Cocktails and a buffet dinner at 6 will be followed by the show and then a dessert reception. Black tie. Tickets, $500, or $250 for the concert and dessert reception alone, from (212) 415-5488. Public Library Centennial MAY 22 -- The New York Public Library will hold a centennial celebration to benefit its four research libraries. The black-tie event, from 9 P.M. to 1 A.M., is to be led by Brooke Astor at the library's main branch on Fifth Avenue (42d Street). Cocktails and dessert are included, along with dancing to the music of Doc Scantlin and his Imperial Palms Orchestra and D.J. Johnny Dynell. Tickets, $100, from (212) 930-0730. Greenwich Village Readings MAY 22 -- Kim Hunter and Sylvia Miles will perform a staged reading, at 7 P.M., of a new play, "Alphabet of Flowers" by Elyse Nass, to benefit the Greenwich House Theater Company. It will be held at the company's theater at 27 Barrow Street (Seventh Avenue). A reception and dinner will follow at One If By Land, Two If By Sea, 17 Barrow Street. Tickets, $225, from (212) 633-8360. Against Discrimination MAY 22 -- The Lambda Legal Defense and Education Fund will hold its annual Liberty Awards ceremony, from 6 to 8 P.M., to recognize efforts to end discrimination against lesbians, gay men and people with H.I.V. and AIDS. The event will be held at the Sky Club in the Metropolitan Life building, 200 Park Avenue. Honorees will include Assemblywoman Deborah J. Glick, Democrat of Manhattan, and the director and producer George C. Wolfe. There will be cocktails and hors d'oeuvres. Tickets, $125, or $40 for students, from (212) 370-5804.

"You're a mortal, and as far as I'm concerned, it reflects a highly offensive class structure that places others beneath you."

title: Revelations, Secrets, Gossip and Lies: Sifting Warily Through the Soviet Archives
description: WITH the opening of the Russian archives there has come a flood of new works purporting to reveal the hidden truths of the former Soviet Union -- and a flood of new questions as well. What is one to make of these books? How can the veracity of the fresh, sometimes contradictory, information be tested? Has access to long-hidden records finally produced a consensus about Soviet reality?

title: Thank You for Not Smoking (as if You Had a Choice)
description: FORGET "STAR TREK," "STAR Wars," "2001." No outer-space adventure is as fascinating as the spatial dramas that take place right here on earth. New York City's tough new anti-smoking laws are a case in point. Push comes to shove a million times a minute in New York, but a new kind of territorial dispute doesn't come along every day. And the anti-smoking laws have made dining out an excellent refresher course in the dynamics of the territorial impulse and its impact on urban space.

title: The Loneliness of Being White
description: VINNY DEL NEGRO AND TWO OF HIS San Antonio Spurs teammates went slouching into a tony clothing store during a recent road trip. In their sweats and T-shirts, they didn't look especially promising as customers, just tall. Del Negro, the only white man of the three, was helped first. But when another customer asked one of the blacks for an autograph, the dynamic changed.

title: May 7-12: DNA Tests; Key Prosecution Evidence Links Simpson to the Scene
description: As O. J. Simpson's lawyers tell it, he spent the evening of June 12th last year at his estate, practicing his golf game, calling a girlfriend and taking a nap. But according to the testimony of a DNA expert last week, Mr. Simpson also spent some time at his former wife's condominium that night. And when he returned home, the testimony indicated, her blood was on his socks.

title: [ APPEARANCES ] ; The Way of All Flesh
description: I'M BREAKFASTING IN PARIS with Tyen, art director for Christian Dior. Although he has lived his adult life in France, he's Vietnamese, and has the comfortable bulk and disarming calm of a Buddha, a hip Buddha in black cotton clothes that quietly say Japanese designer. He lifts a slice of smoked salmon to his mouth and appreciatively inhales. "Fish in America never smells like fish," he says. "Cheese never smells like cheese." We talk about the American mania for refrigeration, the national fear of strong tastes and odors.

title: Word for Word / Talk Show Wannabes; They'll Risk Life, Face and Pride for a Little Air Time
description: WHY would anyone want to be on a talk show? There is little remunerative reward -- usually only the air fare to the show, a hotel room and a per diem. Yet people risk humiliation, their faces, even their lives, to be on the air. The National Talk Show Guest Registry is a data bank of people who have offered up themselves and their oddities to talk shows around the country (and have paid $3 a month for the privilege). Here are excerpts from their entries in the registry (in italics) and some things they said during telephone interviews about their desire to be on air. SARAH BOXER A Disney Fanatic George Reiger Jr. has permanently tattooed his body with Disney characters from Mickey Mouse to Snow White. Every room in his home is "Disney themed," using over 4,500 Disney-related items. He has visited Disney World 72 times and Disneyland 52 times. I want to go on television for the exposure and to show the world my tattoos. I have 415 Disney tattoos, and I can show all but 20 of them. I'm Disney's number one fan. It all started when I was watching the Mickey Mouse Club as a child. My first tattoo was 15 years ago. I was quiet about it for years. I was going to Disneyland five or six times a year, to Disney World seven or eight times a year. Then I learned there was a guy in Florida who has 100 characters tattooed on his body. He was getting all the publicity, even though he lives by Disney World. I live 2000 miles away. This is my life, my religion. The movie "Pocahontas" comes out in June; I already have the tattoos. I'm going to be cremated and my ashes will be scattered over the Seven Seas Lagoon. A Lost Dog's Guilty Master In 1988, Ronald Freed's daughter, Tina, was walking through the forest when she fell and hit her head, causing a severe concussion. Luckily, her dog, Spook, stayed with her. Tina was found after Mr. Freed heard Spook barking. On Oct. 19, 1992, Spook disappeared and Ronald blames himself for the dog's disappearance: "That dog SAVED my daughter's life. I sold him down the river." I want to be on a talk show because I have a dog who's been missing for 30 months. It's the only way I can get national coverage. I have spent thousands of dollars trying to find my dog. I can't get a billboard with his picture on it. I've got millions of leads but never the right one. I should have hired cops, the way you'd do for a missing child. When you watch the morons on talk shows, you see people who cheat on their mother's lawyer's boyfriend. I am a college graduate and a rabid antivivisectionist. I'm putting together a mini-book titled "Test America's Prisoner's, Not Animals." If I got on a talk show and nobody called, maybe I could put this thing behind me. I have to take care of my two cats. I can't commit suicide. An Imaginary Mother Patty McNeil (a pseudonym) had an extramarital affair. The affair ended with the man "tossing her aside like trash." When she discovered that she was pregnant, the ex-lover demanded that she have an abortion. She refused but then ended up miscarrying. "I never told him of the miscarriage. In fact, I told him that I delivered a sweet baby girl that had 'his eyes' for no other reason but to destroy his peace of mind." You see a talk show and think: How can they talk about that awful stuff? But I suffered for a long time in silence. And talk is healing. You just purge it. You can't go into a supermarket and say, "I was raped by my brother." In supermarkets people talk about diapers. But talk shows are for talking about painful or bizarre things. You're anonymous there. There are things I would say on television that I wouldn't say to my therapist. I was on once to talk about my affair with a younger man, and nobody knew I was on. I didn't tell anybody -- just one friend, my sister and my son. If my mother saw it, she'd think she was having D.T.'s. This time, if the story about my imaginary child comes out, the man will want to kill me. I would have to wear a wig or something. But he's a man; he's not going to be at home watching. He's got a job. An Elvis With Implants Mike Memphis has been an Elvis impersonator for 13 years (since he was 16 years old). In 1994, Mike underwent 7 facial operations to look more like "the King," including cheek implants, a lower lip implant, a chin implant and liposuction of the neck and chin. I'm an entertainer and there's one thing you can expect from being on a talk show: that you'll have another line for your resume. I have before-and-after pictures of myself and pictures of myself on the operating table. I have only one regret -- that I didn't do it earlier. But I'm not a psychopath. I'm using this as a stepping stone to other acting jobs. I could downplay the look, shave the sideburns, let the black dye wash out. I don't want to be Elvis when I'm 40. Multiple Personality Lori Crocker, R.N., is a psychiatric nurse who was assisting therapists in treating people suffering from multiple personality disorders when she suddenly realized that "someone inside" was talking to her as well. "For the next year and a half," she says, "I worked intensely with a therapist, uncovering 45 different alters." God has helped me and it's time to give something back. I want to tell everyone that there are a lot more people with multiple personality disorders than they recognize. People associate hearing voices with being crazy. But it may be people inside talking. Becoming a multiple personality is a coping skill, and not everybody has the ability to do this. Something very bad has to have happened. My opinion is that there has been satanic involvement in 80 percent of the cases. Both of my kids went through stuff like that -- satanism, orgies, drugs. The satanic cults have people, men, who get females pregnant, so they can take the children and sacrifice them. Or they will take infants in deep dark boxes and put them in the ground -- with bugs and stuff. I saw these rituals in flashbacks of my alters as they came out to heal. The alters are like best friends. They've taken on the pain for me. I know what I have been through. I know that if people attack, it's only out of fear. A Man With Long Second Toes Ron Chappell has researched historical references and myths about longer second toes for over 10 years. He avidly collects paraphernalia that make reference to the giftedness of people with this special trait. I'm trying to get some publicity for research I've done on second toes. The major works of art, pretty much all of your Italian artwork, and all your gods and goddesses have that toe. I put all the information together so people can feel good about themselves, so they can identify with Marilyn Monroe, Baryshnikov, the Greek gods and goddesses. Most people think a big second toe means something special -- that it means you're smarter, that you'll live longer or that you're royalty. I think it definitely connects us with fertility, with the earth and the gods. The earth gives off electromagnetic energy. Our toes are our antennas; the longer second toe enables people to draw in more energy. When I was little I asked my mother: How come my second toes are longer? She said I was special. But she is surprised that I took it this far.

title: A Lesson in Sexual Politics, 2,000 Feet Up
description: THE NINETY-NINES were founded in 1929 by 99 female pilots who decided to challenge the domination of men in the skies. Amelia Earhart was the club president. The women announced their first charity dinner by putting four of their planes in a tight formation and staging an air raid on Manhattan. They bombed the city with thousands of leaflets. Crowds on the streets cheered.

description: THIS was not exactly what Pat Riley had in mind. On Friday he made a blatant and surely well-rehearsed plug to remind the league's mission control that officials had been overly officious against Patrick Ewing.

description: Friday night's Silent Whistle isn't the first example of "Ranger Rules" helping the home team win games at Madison Square Garden this spring.

title: A Safer Society -- A special report.; Japanese Say No to Crime: Tough Methods, at a Price
description: To understand why Japan is probably the safest industrialized country in the world, it helps to talk to a short, squat man with rumpled clothes, a gentle smile and big, leathery hands that once picked up a hammer and crushed his neighbor's head.

title: Mixed Messages
description: At the age of 12, in my haste to become an adult and (therefore) a person in my own right, I turned to fashion magazines. Perhaps, I hoped, the years that stretched before me until my real life would get under way could be assimilated, like chapters in a textbook. From Seventeen, I moved on to Glamour, Mademoiselle, and then, as a sophomore in high school, I graduated to Vogue, in which the models weren't girls but women -- full-fledged citizens of cocktail parties and candlelit dinners for two. I scrutinized pictures of expensive clothes and pored over descriptions of some new mascara formula. That this information often turned out to be useless to a small-town teen-ager was immaterial to me; the day would come when I would have to choose an eyebrow pencil or buy a bra to wear under a strapless evening gown, and then I would be up to the task.

title: The World; The Long Road to Somewhere
description: This week, budget resolutions will be debated on the floor of the Senate and House. The House will finish. The Senate may finish, or it may take until next week to finish. But there is much, much more. Here is a rough timetable for arriving at a budget: June. A conference committee will meet to resolve differences between the House and Senate resolutions. Once there is a conference agreement on a single measure, the House and Senate will vote on it. July. Committees in the House and Senate will begin writing appropriation bills and an omnibus measure called a reconciliation bill that includes changes in tax policy and in entitlement programs like Social Security, Medicare and welfare. These are the bills that actually set policy. Floor votes on some of them are likely before Congress goes into recess for most of August. September and beyond. The remaining appropriations bills and the reconciliation bill will be approved by the House and Senate, the differences will be resolved by conference committees and the final versions will go back for votes and then to President Clinton. Congress must reconsider any measures that are vetoed, and probably will not adjourn until all the bills have been signed into law.

title: DIARY
description: CONGRESS Budget-Cutters on the March Like it or not, Congress is inching steadily closer to dismantling Government as we know it. When House and Senate budget panels approved plans last week to balance the budget in seven years, the main sticking point was tax cuts -- the House wants $350 billion in cuts, the Senate none. They'll have to hash that out if, as expected, the bills pass this week. But then would come the messy part: figuring out specific cuts, not just simple numbers. How bad will the pain be? It's a numbers game. Some estimates put it at 7 percent or more from overall spending. But since Social Security and the military are off limits, cuts in things like education and the environment could be more like 30 percent. That's pain. COMMUNICATIONS MCI Joins Murdoch's Team Rupert Murdoch is on a roll. He just got the F.C.C. off his back on the thorny issue of foreign ownership of American TV stations. Then last week MCI said it would invest up to $2 billion in his News Corporation. The new partners' talk was full of grand global plans, of "synergies" -- and these two companies do indeed have a history of rattling all sorts of cages. But analysts saw a coup for Mr. Murdoch, questioning those vaunted synergies. After all, even if MCI eventually owns 13.5 percent of the company, the deal gives it no true voting power. And on the news, MCI's stock fell and the News Corporation's rose. So what's in it for MCI? Clearly, a possibility of fulfilling global dreams that go beyond long distance. REAL ESTATE What Went Bankrupt? It really comes down to two questions: 1) Come on, how could Rockefeller Center possibly be bankrupt? 2) Oh, does it really matter? To tackle No. 2 first, it was best summed up by a candy-store worker, right in the belly of the Midtown beast, who responded to a query about last week's Chapter 11 filing this way: "Truthfully, sir, I have no idea what you're talking about." As for No. 1, let's see: The family took out a huge mortgage. A Japanese company bought 80 percent of the center, paying too much. Rents fell when they were supposed to rise. And somehow, with all sorts of overlapping companies called Rockefeller Group, Rockefeller Center Properties, RCP Associates, things just stopped adding up. Is that clear now? WORK FORCE Women Pay Their Way Not long ago, if a woman had a job, it was often for little extras -- not the meat of a family budget. Well, in case you hadn't noticed, that world is long gone. If any doubts persisted, they were dispelled by a survey released last week that showed that more than half of employed women provided at least half of their household income. The study "challenges the persistent notion that women's earnings are supplemental," said Arlene Johnson of the Families and Work Institute, co-sponsor of the survey. Not that all women want to be breadwinners -- 31 percent said that if money were abundant, they'd be tending to their families, while just 21 percent of men stated that preference. And some women, of course, have no choice -- the men aren't around. MARKETS Emerging Is as Emerging Does It was a noble idea, fairly oozing with pioneer spirit. Three years ago the American Stock Exchange decided to give a break to some little companies that didn't quite fit the mold but that, it hoped, had boundless futures. Last week the Amex ended the experiment, called the Emerging Company Marketplace, saying no new companies would be added. Not only did some of the companies fail to emerge, but nearly a quarter of them are now worthless. The tales behind the companies range from the blatant (one's largest shareholder was a convicted arsonist) to the bizarre (another's chairman had been sued by the S.E.C., but had since had a sex-change operation). But the lesson seemed to be that there is, after all, a reason for an exchange to have rigorous rules for membership. Or simply this: Emerge first, then apply. ANNUAL REPORTS The Pepsi Investor Next Door Pity the designers of annual reports. They're duty-bound to put heavy machinery or cereal boxes on the covers -- but don't want to make them so dull-looking that stockholders will quickly toss them. Why, they must wonder occasionally, can't they put some glamorous model on the cover? No, what a silly idea, they surely say, as they switch off their daydreams and try to think good thoughts about tractors. But apparently someone at Pepsi had that very daydream -- and forgot to wake up. And so it is that Pepsi's just-released annual report could easily be mistaken for Glamour or Vogue -- there's Cindy Crawford gazing seductively out at you -- without a soda can in sight. The cover line: "A typical investor looks us over." Sure, Pepsi, sure. RIVALRIES From Cold War to Cola War Who says there are no superpower rivalries left? Even with the cold war over, Coke and Pepsi are still engaged in their mythic battle for the gullets of the masses. And even if Pepsi scored one for having the sexiest annual report, Coke caught the Presidential eye in Russia last week. Mr. Clinton, picking an American investment to publicize by bestowing a visit, chose a Coke plant near Moscow. There was a reasonable political explanation: Coke owns its Russian plant, while Pepsi's is a joint venture. But could it be because Coke has contributed more to Democrats lately? Or maybe Mr. Clinton, weary of vodka, craved a soda -- and figured the Coke plant was the nearest place to get a free one. It was, after all, right on the way to the airport. TRANSPORTATION You Could Always Walk In a single century, a historical speck, we've gotten used to the odd notion that if we want to be 30 miles away in half an hour, we should be able to do it -- no matter what damage is done to the environment. Now, as the world struggles to retain that luxury, someone had the bright idea of mandating a certain number of electric cars by 1998 -- a down payment on a pristine new world of travel. But is it possible? Practical hurdles still loom, of course -- but there's more: now comes a study saying that emissions from mining and smelting the lead needed for batteries might cause their own nasty threats to public health. But what of the argument that at least pollution would be shifted away from cities? Not so, said one toxicologist; "lead particles can move long distances." SOUVENIRS 23! 45! 23! Oh, Never Mind Does Michael Jordan realize he is tampering with some basic elements of our economic system? A basketball uniform is merely a piece of cloth, but with a star's number on it, it becomes a glowing -- and pricey -- symbol of all that's glamorous. So when he picked No. 45 for his comeback, a huge industry instantly took shape -- caps, T-shirts, banners, you name it. So when he abandoned that number last week for his old 23, he demolished the value of all that stuff. It was as if Calvin Klein decided to change his name to, say, Oliver North. All those people strutting around town in their Calvin underwear would feel, well, a bit cheated. No wonder the N.B.A. fined Jordan's team for the switch; Jordan upset a delicate balance of capitalism.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: PARALLEL TIME: Growing Up in Black and White By Brent Staples. Avon, $11. The author, an editorial writer for The New York Times, recalls his experiences as the eldest son of a black family in Chester, Pa., a town where obvious forms of segregation had vanished but more subtle divisions between the races were strong. His memoir explores those boundaries and the one between himself and his brother Blake, a drug dealer who died violently. "It is a complex portrait of a worldly education, written at times with affection, at times with a sting," Verlyn Klinkenborg wrote here last year. A BOOK OF COMMON PRAYER By Joan Didion. Vintage International, $12. Charlotte Douglas, a woman with no understanding of revolutions, seeks her 18-year-old daughter, who is trying to foment one. After participating in a bombing and a hijacking, the young woman is believed to be in Boca Grande, a fictional Central American country. Grace Strasser-Mendana, another American expatriate, tells their story. In 1977 our reviewer, Joyce Carol Oates, said that Joan Didion "has been an articulate witness to the most stubborn and intractable truths of our time, a memorable voice, partly eulogistic, partly despairing; always in control." Vintage has also brought another of Ms. Didion's novels back into print: DEMOCRACY ($12), in which the author herself is a character. She narrates the drama of the Victor family, whose life in 1975 involves both politics and murder. The author "is wonderful not only at hearing her characters but at naming them," Mary McCarthy said in the Book Review in 1984. LISTENING By Hannah Merker. Harper Perennial, $12. More than two decades ago, the author went skiing for the first time -- an event that marked the last time she would ever hear completely. Her book assesses the importance of sound and demonstrates how she adjusted to the silence imposed by a devastating accident. Writing in these pages last year, Lou Ann Walker said: "We feel her loss. . . . But we are receptive to the lessons of listening she is teaching us." Also reissued is TRAIN GO SORRY: Inside a Deaf World, (Vintage, $13). The author, Leah Hager Cohen, is the daughter of the superintendent of the Lexington School for the Deaf in Queens. A hearing child of hearing parents, she describes her life within a culture she could never really be part of. In 1994 our reviewer, Russ Rymer, said the book often reads "like a love story -- as intimate, tender and troubling a love story as any you're likely to find." THE WAY WE KNOW IN DREAMS: Stories By Gordon Weaver. University of Missouri, $14.95. Many of the men in this collection are disappointed middle-aged souls who feel powerless to change their fates -- as well they might, since two of the other characters are God and Satan. The result is "inspired, clever and unexpected fiction," Chris Bohjalian wrote here last year. The men in the stories in WANTING ONLY TO BE HEARD, by Jack Driscoll (University of Massachusetts, $12.95), are even more desperate. Frequently hunters and fishermen, often bereft of female company, they live close to nature -- and to violence. In 1993 Jonis Agee said in the Book Review that "Jack Driscoll's poetic language gives them a stature that makes their struggle meaningful, tragic and universal." MOTHERLESS DAUGHTERS: The Legacy of Loss By Hope Edelman. Delta, $12.95. The author, who was 17 when her mother died, draws on clinical research and the experiences of more than 200 other women to analyze the impact of such a loss. Daughters in mourning, she explains, often feel that their own lives are incomplete. This is "a moving and valuable treatment of a neglected subject," Nancy Caldwell Sorel said here last year. Maternal roles are also examined in THE MYTHS OF MOTHERHOOD: How Culture Reinvents the Good Mother, by Shari L. Thurer (Penguin, $12.95). Ranging from the Stone Age to today, this history reveals how society, not biology, has defined women's task as parents. In 1994 our reviewer, Rachel Billington, called it "positive, sensible and readable." ACTS OF LOVE By Emily Listfield. Penguin, $10.95. It's a familiar scenario: a gun goes off in a suburban living room, and a marital quarrel ends in death. The question this novel poses is whether Ted Waring deliberately or accidentally killed his estranged wife. The author's "chilling meditation . . . is a sobering reminder that some puzzles are better left unsolved," Sarah Ferguson said in the Book Review last year. THE PROTEAN SELF: Human Resilience in an Age of Fragmentation By Robert Jay Lifton. Basic Books, $13. If a foolish consistency is indeed the hobgoblin of little minds, the author has found quite a few large-minded people. Their response to the dislocation of today's world is to become eminently adaptable. In 1994 our reviewer, Richard A. Shweder, found this "a fascinating and appealing book because it is a near-perfect example of an intellectual stance that skeptics sometimes disparage." Human resilience is also evident in THE AGELESS SELF: Sources of Meaning in Late Life, by Sharon R. Kaufman (University of Wisconsin, $11.95). A study of 60 elderly men and women, it demonstrates that strength of spirit and mind often compensates for bodily weakness. It is "a book that no novelist or indeed any caring person with a fondness for human interiors could resist," Paul West said here in 1987. DROWN ALL THE DOGS By Thomas Adcock. Pocket Books, $5.50. Detective Neil Hockaday has to confront his own family's shadowy past when he returns to Ireland to find out about the father he never knew. Last year our reviewer, Marilyn Stasio, called this mystery's dialogue "lively and literate." LAUREL GRAEBER

title: A Conductor Devoted To Approximating What Mozart Heard
description: WHEN THE TOMB OF Tutankhamun was discovered in 1922, a seal was found affixed to a door that had not been opened for more than 3,200 years. It took the renowned philologist Sir Alan Gardiner seven days to decipher the nearly illegible text: "The King of Upper and Lower Egypt, who devoted his life to making images of the deities, heralds the god Osiris." From boyhood, Sir Alan later wrote, he had been "fired with the desire to become an Egyptologist . . . to read the hieroglyphic inscriptions and to capture the actual words of the ancient people."

title: The Nation; Why Science Loses Women in the Ranks
description: THE best metaphor to describe the plight of women in science, and their continued scarcity at the upper reaches of their profession, is not the glass ceiling or the broken ladder or even the old boy and their clubs, but rather a bit of plumbing: the leaky pipe. It is a pipe with leaks at every joint along its span, a pipe that begins with a high-pressure surge of young women at the source -- a roiling Amazon of smart graduate students -- and ends at the spigot with a trickle of women prominent enough to be deans or department heads at major universities or to win such honors as membership in the National Academy of Sciences or even, heaven forfend, the Nobel Prize.

title: A Sampling Of Violence From Japan
description: This particular Japanese export is called anime, which sounds like AHNEE-may. The phenomenon, sometimes called Japanimation, began emerging in this country around 1975. Cartoons heavily influenced by Disney on the kitsch side and, even more so, by Marvel Comics on the violence side began appearing here in video shops. A cult was born, complete with not-for-children warning stickers. Fabulous animation technology was put in the service of doomsday stories, and the usual result is enough to give violence watchdogs in this country a severe attack of hives.

Like many other transit agencies across the country, New Jersey Transit is taking part in "Try Transit Week 1995." The agency's executive director, Shirley A. DeLibero, will greet customers at Long Branch, Newark and Hoboken, urging people who have never used New Jersey Transit to "give us a try," she said. Or scarves and neckties with enough sensors and computer intelligence to warn you that the accompanying blouse or shirt is a dubious fashion choice? title: RESULTS PLUS
description: AUTO RACING Brayton Captures Indy 500 Pole Scott Brayton nailed down the pole position for the Indianapolis 500 yesterday while the elite Team Penske was shut out in the opening weekend of qualifications for the first time. Al Unser Jr., the winner of last year's pole and race, and Penske teammate Emerson Fittipaldi, like Unser a two-time Indy winner, didn't even make a qualifying attempt as the interrupted opening round of time trials and the second round were completed on a warm, sunny day. Brayton's four-lap, 10-mile average was 231.604 miles an hour. The best previous start at Indianapolis by the 36-year-old from Coldwater, Mich., was second in 1985. Brayton will be starting his 14th Indy, the most of any driver entered. Arie Luyendyk, who won the 1990 race and the 1993 pole, put his Menard V6-powered Lola in the middle of the first of 11 three-car rows with a 231.031. Twenty-five of the 33 starting spots for the May 28 race were filled by the end of the second of four days of time trials, with the rookie Eliseo Salazar of Chile the slowest qualifier at 225.023 m.p.h. (AP)

title: Robbins Leapfrogs to Title At L.P.G.A. Championship

Ms. Knight has been recognized for establishing the Visiting Nurse Association of Central Jersey's mobile clinic, which provides care to boardinghouse residents. The 10-year-old program serves more than 1,300 people a year at 133 places in central New Jersey. Ms. Knight, a family nurse practitioner, said she would use the award to expand the clinic.

Trouble is, he was flying an airplane at the time, and before the plane could pull off the road it had to land on the road. Mr. Christie, of Stephentown, N.Y., landed on Route 23 in Morris County. Neither he nor a woman accompanying him was injured, the police said. The rented plane had taken off from Greenwood Lake Airport. Mr. Christie tried to make it back there when he realized he was low on fuel, the authorities said.

title: Bar Exams
description: The percentage of people passing the region's bar examinations has risen recently. Except in New Jersey, where the grading system was altered in 1992, it is hard to pinpoint the reason for the rise, and experts say it really doesn't matter since just about everyone who takes a bar exam eventually passes it and becomes a lawyer. A person in this area can take the bar in two states simultaneously. The New York exam can be combined with either Connecticut's or New Jersey's by taking the first half of New York's exam on July 25, the Multistate Bar Examination portion the next day (which the states have in common) and the half specific to either Connecticut or New Jersey on July 27.

description: Hope springs eternal. That helps explain why Time Warner Inc.'s stock was up $1.25 on Friday, to $39.25, as investors bet that MCI's $2 billion investment in the News Corporation might prompt the AT&T Corporation to make a similar investment in Time Warner.

title: Unlikely Alliances Attack Property Rights Measures
description: Rarely does an issue unite an anti-pornography preacher in Mississippi, the cultural elite in New York City and families living here in the cozy towns of the Cascade foothills.

title: Where Violence Reigns: A special report.; Even at a Time of Relative Calm, Rikers Stands on the Razor's Edge
description: The inmates on Rikers Island readied for battle last November by scouring for weapons: plexiglass broken from light fixtures, razor blades attached to toothbrushes, metal wrenched from radiators. Thousands refused meals to protest cuts in services. Correction officers went on high alert. The nation's largest jail complex braced for a riot.

title: Despite Criticism, Israel Affirms Jerusalem Land Seizures
description: Rejecting sharp criticism from overseas and within its own ranks, the Israeli Government today affirmed its decision to confiscate land in largely Palestinian areas of Jerusalem.

title: Two States, Two Gatherings and a Lot of Anti-Government Sentiment; In New Hampshire, Common Themes for Diverse Elements
description: Some brought family members, some their friends, some just the gun racks in the back of their pickup trucks.

title: Fire Foiled at Metals Plant
description: A metals plant hit by a fire on Saturday was expected to be in operation today, company officials said over the weekend. The blaze at the Degussa Corporation, believed to have been caused by an electrical flaw, burned three empty tanks, but firefighters kept the flames from spreading to tanks holding ammonia, hydrogen peroxide, hydrochloric acid and other corrosives. The company processes precious metals for electronics. DAVID STOUT

title: Case of '76 U.S. Assassination Reaching Final Stage in Chile
description: Since arguments were concluded three months ago on appeals by two military officers convicted of ordering the assassination of a Chilean opposition leader in Washington in 1976, tensions have been rising here as each side in the case has accused the other of trying to influence the Supreme Court in its decision.

title: People

She was previously a senior partner and client services director at Tatham Euro RSCG, Chicago, a unit of Euro RSCG. * Peter G. Engler was named to head client services, a new position at Woolward & Partners, San Francisco. He was previously senior vice president for marketing at the Interactive Network, Menlo Park, Calif.

title: Auditors for Cash Businesses
description: The Division of Taxation says it will hire 100 more auditors, examiners and assistants to examine the records of businesses that deal mostly in cash -- restaurants, liquor stores, pizzerias, convenience stores and video rental outlets.

title: Angry Michigan Court Upholds Injunction Against Kevorkian
description: On the same day that Dr. Jack Kevorkian assisted in his second suicide in five days, the Michigan Court of Appeals handed the police and prosecutors here a new weapon in their campaign to stop him: the threat of a contempt of court citation.

description: Goodby, Silverstein & Partners in San Francisco won the most awards at the 36th annual Clio Awards ceremony sponsored by Clio Awards Ltd.

description: Republicans may play a mean, low-down political trick on Democrats still railing at proposals to stem the tide of red ink: to put the budget submitted to Congress a few months ago by President Clinton up for a vote.

title: India Sends 2 Top Aides to Kashmir Over Ruined Mosque
description: The Indian Government sent two of its most powerful Cabinet ministers to Kashmir today to assess the turmoil raging there in the aftermath of the destruction by fire of the disputed region's most revered Muslim shrine.

title: Havana Rights Leader's Trial Causes New Tension Between Cuba and U.S.
description: Even as the Cuban and American Governments have begun collaborating to prevent Cubans from boarding rafts to seek political asylum in Florida, the trial of a prominent human rights leader here is generating new tensions in relations between the two countries.

title: Wave of Rape Adds New Horror To Rwanda's Trail of Brutality
description: When Hutu militiamen went to the town of Gikongoro in the midst of Rwanda's ethnic massacres last year, Marie-Chantal begged the Hutu captain directing the killings to save her life. The 18-year-old Tutsi recalled last week how he took her by the hand and hid her in a house.

title: The Talk of Hollywood; A Simple Little Family Film and Its Anxious Producer
description: How can a relatively small family film like "A Little Princess," without Disney animation or big stars, survive in a summer marketplace surrounded not only by potential blockbusters like "Batman Forever" and "Die Hard With a Vengeance" but also by such children's films as "Pocahontas" and "Casper"?

title: Nordiques Stick Around by Sticking to Hockey
description: The fleur-de-lis still flies on hockey jerseys, at least for one more game. In the most tame, least controversial and most cautiously played game of this interesting first-round playoff series, the Quebec Nordiques edged the Rangers by 4-2 at le Colisee this afternoon.

title: A Composer Who Made Her Timely Choice
description: The women's movement has had the sense to appropriate Amy Beach as one of its symbols. An American composer and pianist of evident skills, Beach curtailed her career in favor of Victorian marriage, resuming music in earnest after her husband's death in 1910. Although for 25 years Beach's public forum shrank to occasional concert-giving, she never stopped composing.

description: International A3-9 MENEM LEADS IN ARGENTINA

title: First Infants on Gene Therapy Seem Better
description: The first three infants to undergo gene therapy seem to be responding to the highly experimental treatment. Two years after being given a gene that they were missing at birth, the children are producing a blood factor that is crucial to their survival, doctors reported last week.

title: Devils Close Out Garden And Bruins
description: The second round of the playoffs has yet to begin, but the Devils have already accomplished their mission of making history this spring. Tonight, before a sellout crowd in Boston Garden, they beat the Bruins, 3-2, to eliminate them from the playoffs and turn out the lights for good in the ancient building on Causeway Street.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Sweaty palms and stage fright? No problem. A word-for-word text and a Teleprompter to read it from? No need. Slides on the big screen above the stage? Now the architectural historian VINCENT SCULLY is worried.

description: WHY is New York City so dirty?

title: Graduation at Stony Brook
description: The president of the State University of New York at Stony Brook told students at the university's commencement exercises that they must use their educational experience to see that ballots win out over bullets in the wake of the bombing tragedy in Oklahoma.

title: Ammirati Is Choice For Epson Account
description: The Epson America unit of the Seiko Epson Corporation in Torrance, Calif., has selected Ammirati & Puris/Lintas in New York, a unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies, to handle its imaging products account in North America, with billings estimated at $25 million to $30 million. The account, for products like printers, had been at Foote, Cone & Belding in San Francisco, a unit of True North Communications, for the last 11 years until January, when it was shifted to that agency's FCB Technology division.

description: To the Editor:

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Sales Up to Developing Nations
description: Since 1990, New Jersey's exports to developing countries have jumped 42 percent, reaching almost $3.7 billion last year, the World Bank said. The top-selling products included chemicals, industrial and commercial machinery and computer and transportation equipment.

title: No Headline
description: "I believe some birds sing purely for pleasure. I wouldn't be surprised if a male song bird singing on top of a tree is having a glorious time." -- DR. FERNANDO NOTTEBOHM, a neuroscientist at Rockefeller University. [ C10:5. ]

title: Tobacco Suit's Plaintiffs Suffer A Court Setback
description: In a setback for plaintiffs in a giant class-action suit against American tobacco companies, a Federal district judge in New Orleans agreed to allow his class-action certification of the case to be taken to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit.

title: Interpublic Renames Two of Its Agencies
description: The Interpublic Group of Companies said yesterday that as expected it had renamed two of its agencies.

title: Mercer Intl.(MERCS,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: Mercer International said the increase in revenues in the latest first quarter compared with year-ago period was primarily due to the inclusion of $ 31.6 million in pulp sales and increased paper sales resulting from higher prices and the inclusion of sales from two additional mills.The year-ago quarter's sales included a government supplement of $ 4.1 million related to the operation of Dresden Papier AG.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt * BellSouth Telecomm Inc., a unit of the BellSouth Corporation, is selling $300 million of debentures due in 2035 through Morgan Stanley. The debentures are priced at 97.859 to yield 7.8 percent. Callable in 10 years, the issue is rated triple-A by Moody's Investors Service Inc., the Standard & Poor's Corp. and Duff & Phelps. * Federal Farm Credit Bank is selling $25 million of medium-term notes due in 2010 through CS First Boston. The noncallable issue is priced at par to yield 7.06 percent. * Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae, is selling $100 million of medium-term notes due in 2000 through Salomon Brothers. Callable in two years, the issue is priced at par to yield 6.95 percent. * First Chicago Corp. filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission to sell as much as $2 billion of various debt securities, including preferred stock. * Fleet Mortgage Group Inc., Providence, R.I., a unit of Fleet Financial Group Inc., filed to sell as much as $500 million of debt securities. Salomon Brothers will be the lead underwriter. * Kelley Oil and Gas Corp., Houston, filed to sell $100 million of senior notes through Salomon Brothers.

title: New York Commits Budget Suicide
description: To the Editor:

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Plea for Art and Music
description: All around the state, parents are organizing nonprofit foundations to raise money in support of school programs hit hard by budget cuts. But a group of parents in this upscale Atlantic County town are pushing the envelope: they're asking residents for $40,000 so that an art teacher and a music teacher at Belhaven Avenue School will not be reduced to part-time status. The Emergency Committee on the Arts sent out letters seeking donations three weeks ago.

title: Greenpoint to Pay $660 Million For 60 Home Savings Branches
description: In a deal that will create one of the biggest savings banks in New York, the Greenpoint Financial Corporation said yesterday that it would buy 60 branches from Home Savings of America for $660 million.

title: On My Mind; When Is an Ally?
description: For America, the purpose and test of power is the ability to get things done that protect its security and interests or ward off dangers to them. In the use of power -- economic, political or military -- America can act alone or with allies.

title: DANCE
description: Two Collaborations Where Mystery Prevails Phoebe Neville Company St. Mark's Church Danspace Project

title: Officer in Fatal Beating Is Arrested and Suspended
description: A Jersey City police officer accused of using excessive force in the past was arrested and charged today with fatally beating a 22-year-old man while breaking up an argument.

title: Israel-Syria Talks Move Ahead, U.S. Says
description: The Clinton Administration said today that Syria and Israel had narrowed their differences over the security arrangements they have offered in peace talks in which Syria is demanding that Israel withdraw from the Golan Heights.

title: Bankruptcy Case May Cost Charities Heavily
description: The Foundation for New Era Philanthropy, a tax-exempt charitable organization in Pennsylvania that solicited funds from museums, universities and other nonprofit organizations with promises that it would double their money, filed for bankruptcy protection yesterday.

title: The Mayor and the Overseers
description: Never one to welcome criticism, Mayor Rudolph Giuliani has responded petulantly to critiques of New York City's budget proposals by a state fiscal monitor. The Mayor thinks it would be a good idea to eliminate the monitor's job entirely. His pique is misplaced. The worst fiscal crisis in a generation is no time to discard the very agents that lend the city needed financial credibility.

title: Supreme Court Roundup; Court Lowers Local Barriers To Housing for the Disabled
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that municipalities may not use single-family zoning to bar group homes for disabled people, including recovering alcoholics and drug addicts, by enforcing occupancy limits in a discriminatory way.

title: David Golomb, 74, Everlast Executive
description: David L. Golomb, chairman of the Everlast Sporting Goods Manufacturing Company, a leading maker of boxing equipment, and a board member of several Jewish organizations, died on Friday at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan. He was 74. Mr. Golomb had lived in Port Washington, L.I., for 35 years before moving to his native Manhattan in 1982.

title: Support Seen for State Leeway on Welfare
description: Senator Bob Packwood, the chairman of the Finance Committee, said today that Senate Republicans supported legislation that would vastly increase state control over welfare programs, with no Federal restrictions except a requirement for many welfare recipients to work.

title: Dollar Slips vs. Yen and Mark After Last Week's Strong Rally
description: The dollar slipped against the German mark and Japanese yen yesterday, giving up some gains from last week's rally.

title: Bond Prices Continue Rise in Light Trading
description: Treasury securities continued their recent rally yesterday, with both the 30-year bond and bills of shorter maturity rising.

title: O'Neill Put On the D.L. As Yanks Trim Down
description: With Paul O'Neill unlikely to play in the five-game homestand that begins against the Cleveland Indians tonight at Yankee Stadium, the Yankees yesterday placed the outfielder on the 15-day disabled list as one of three moves to trim the club's roster from 28 to 25 players.

title: Future of Endangered Species Act in Doubt as Law Is Debated
description: THE Endangered Species Act, hailed by its supporters as the strongest conservation law in the world, has come under heavy criticism in Congress, and its future is in doubt.

title: Mental Illness Found Rising in Poor Nations
description: Mental illness and behavioral problems are on the increase in the world's poorest nations, even as advances are made against debilitating or fatal physical diseases, a team of experts assembled by Harvard Medical School said here today.

title: New World Communications Group Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-Included a gain of $ 2.5 million from the sale of WSBK for about $ 107 million.The company said its results for the latest first quarter also included results for KSAZ (Phoenix) and WDAF (Kansas City), which were acquired in September 1994, and two months of operations of WSBK (Boston), which was sold in March 1995.(Loss)

title: An Airborne Telescope Risks a Look At Mercury
description: AS the world's only flying astronomical telescope nears the end of its long and productive life, it has begun targeting the most dangerous prey it has ever hunted: the mysterious little planet Mercury.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on April 28 about Corliss Lamont, the Socialist author and crusader for civil liberties, misstated his birth date and the number of votes he received in the 1952 Senate race. Mr. Lamont was born on March 28, 1902, not May 28. Running on the American Labor Party ticket, he won 104,702 votes, not 10,000.

title: Gang Members Convicted Of Murders in 3 Boroughs
description: In a heavily guarded Manhattan courtroom, eight members of the Wild Cowboys, one of the largest and most violent drug gangs brought to trial in New York City, were convicted yesterday of carrying out a series of murders to maintain their control over a cocaine business that flourished in three boroughs.

title: Chinese Conduct Nuclear Bomb Test
description: China exploded an underground nuclear bomb today at its Lop Nur test range in the far west of the country, part of a series of tests expected to continue into next year.

title: For a Sex Offender, Freedom Is Limbo; A Monitor on Ankle And Other Controls
description: Last September, Carl DeFlumer was declared a free man. But he slept in a prison cell many months beyond what the law required, because his sister's suburban neighbors did not want a convicted murderer and sex offender in their midst, and he and the state could find no other place for him to go. Ten halfway houses had refused to take him, saying he posed too high a risk.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Royal Mistic throws convention to the wind in its newest campaign by Joseph Victori Wines.
description: ONE of the more unconventional advertising efforts in some time is being introduced, appropriately enough, by a marketer known for unconventionality.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about an investigation of a car leasing deal in Suffolk County referred imprecisely to evidence of forgery, perjury and misuse of taxpayers' money. The County Legislature's special counsel did not indicate who might have been involved. The juxtaposition with a paragraph about District Attorney James M. Catterson was inadvertent.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: HALLIBURTON CO., Dallas, an oilfield equipment and service company, plans to sell a part of its Brown & Root Inc. subsidiary, NUS Training Corp., that provides industrial training products and services. MEDALLIANCE INC., Nashville, formerly ImageAmerica Inc., which operates diagnostic imaging centers, said it would sell its 70 percent stake in a partnership that owns its Little Rock, Ark., imaging center for about $12.5 million in cash. SUN HEALTHCARE GROUP INC., Albuquerque, N.M., a health care concern, purchased more than eight million shares, or about 15 percent, of Ashbourne P.L.C., a British nursing home group. Sun paid $19 million for the stock, purchased from current Ashbourne shareholders.

description: THOMAS SLANE, an air traffic controller at the county airport here, expected security to be tighter around the control tower after the bombing in Oklahoma City.

title: 12 Stricken at Nursing Home Are Better
description: Testing continued yesterday to determine what caused an outbreak of respiratory illness that killed two elderly patients at a Greenwich, Conn., nursing home, but doctors said all 12 other patients who had come down with pneumonialike symptoms were improving.

title: The Oilers Release Givins
description: ERNEST GIVINS, Houston's leading career receiver was released yesterday by the Oilers, who cited the economic realities of the salary cap. "It is always hard to release a player who has given so much to the franchise over the years, let alone the franchise's all-time leading receiver," General Manager FLOYD REESE said. "Unfortunately, this is football in the '90s." (AP)

description: This week, through Thursday, a series of health-care specials can be seen on MTV. Yes, MTV, carrier of the beach party and, among the music videos, a former obnoxious bike messenger (out of "Real World") turned equally obnoxious disk jockey. Now "Out of Order: Rock the Vote Targets Health," in four half-hour programs, offers six dramatized stories dealing with health-related problems especially affecting young people.

description: A big Dutch trading company, Hagemeyer N.V., announced an agreement in principle today to buy a Dutch rival, Borsumij Wehry N.V., in a stock deal worth as much as $468 million. The deal would create one of the world's five largest trading companies, with annual revenue of roughly $5 billion.

title: Three Named to Microsoft's Top Management
description: The Microsoft Corporation promoted three executives yesterday to its office of the president, a move that analysts viewed as a broadening of management control as the software developer moves into new businesses.

title: INGERSOLL-RAND SELLS PAVING EQUIPMENT BUSINESS
description: The Ingersoll- Rand Company said yesterday that it had sold its domestic paving equipment business for an undisclosed amount, in hope that the transaction would clear the way for its acquisition of the Clark Equipment Company. Ingersoll-Rand, based in Woodcliff Lake, N.J., sold the business, based in Shippensburg, Pa., to Champion Road Machinery Ltd. of Canada. The sale could eliminate antitrust concerns about its $1.5 billion offer for Clark, based in South Bend, Ind., which makes highway paving equipment through its Blaw-Knox group.

title: Tomb of Ramses II's Many Sons Is Found in Egypt
description: Ramses II, one of ancient Egypt's greatest pharaohs, is said to have fathered more than 100 children, including 52 sons. Archeologists have now discovered an enormous mausoleum with at least 67 chambers, the largest tomb ever explored in the Valley of the Kings, and they think this was the resting place for most of those royal sons.

description: Although the pain of last year's championship loss to Connecticut has been eased, the senior members of Seton Hall's baseball team will not let their teammates forget how they let a Big East title slip through their fingers.

description: Circling Dogs

title: CHRONICLE
description: Between 1960 and 1966, JOHN LEWIS, a founder of the Student Nonnviolent Coordinating Committee (or SNCC) and one of the 13 original Freedom Riders, was beaten into unconsciousness and arrested and jailed 40 times for his civil rights activities. Each time, "it was a lawyer from the NAACP Legal Defense and Educational Fund who came to my rescue," he said yesterday. "I am so grateful and appreciative of all those unsung heroes and heroines."

title: MEDICARE TARGET COULD BE ELUSIVE, MANY EXPERTS SAY
description: As Congress rolls toward a vote this week on more than $250 billion in Medicare savings, a variety of health policy experts say there is no magic formula for extracting that much money from the program by 2002, the Republicans' self-imposed deadline for balancing the Federal budget.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Calendar column of The Home Section on Thursday about a self-guided house tour in the Randall Manor neighborhood on Staten Island, to benefit the Society for Seamen's Children, carried an incorrect date. It is this Sunday; it was not May 14.

description: Sales are net sales.

title: Frenzied 5-Hour Manhunt Ends Solitary Meditation
description: What began with gasps of terror on the crowded Tokyo subways ended quietly today in a muddy field on a foggy day.

title: Christian B. Anfinsen, Nobel Winner in Chemistry, Dies at 79
description: Christian B. Anfinsen, a biochemist whose work with the building blocks of all living cells led to a Nobel Prize in 1972, died on Sunday at Northwest Hospital Center in Randallstown, Md. He was 79.

title: China Is Urged By Its Scientists To Ease Curbs
description: One of China's premier nuclear physicists and a designer of the country's first atomic bomb joined 44 other scientists and intellectuals today in calling on China's leaders to lift the "counterrevolutionary" verdict from those who took part in the 1989 pro-democracy movement at Tiananmen Square.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Beauty Plus Cooking Talent
description: For decades, the Miss America pageant has sought to refurbish its longtime image as a bathing suit contest by emphasizing its contestants' brains, entertainment talents and charitable bents. Now, a book commissioned by the pageant is ballyhooing their culinary skills.

title: NORWEST TO BUY FOOTHILL GROUP IN STOCK SWAP
description: The Norwest Corporation agreed yesterday to buy Foothill Group Inc., a commercial finance company based in Los Angeles, for about $441 million in stock. Norwest, a banking company based in Minneapolis, said the purchase would help provide $5 million to $50 million loans for companies that do not meet traditional credit standards. Under the agreement, Norwest plans to issue 16.4 million shares of common stock. Each common share of Foothill would be exchanged for 0.920 share of Norwest.

title: ResultsPlus
description: TENNIS Edberg and Martin Extended in Rome Stefan Edberg and Todd Martin were pushed to three sets by unseeded players before advancing yesterday in the first round of the Italian Open in Rome. The 12th-seeded Edberg, appearing in Rome for the first time since 1984, opened play with a 6-2, 4-6, 6-3 victory over Arnaud Boetsch. Martin, seeded 10th, downed Alberto Costa, 7-6 (7-3), 5-7, 6-3. Michael Chang, seeded No. 2, had an easier time against a hard-hitting, 18-year-old Australian, Mark Philippoussis, winning by 6-4, 6-3. MaliVai Washington upset fifth-seeded Alberto Berasategui of Spain, a top clay-court player, 7-5, 6-3. Another seeded player fell to an American when Jeff Tarango knocked off No. 11 Marc Rosset of Switzerland 7-6 (7-4), 6-3. Other Americans to advance included Vince Spadea, who beat Carlos Costa, a former Italian Open finalist, 6-4, 6-3, and Richey Reneberg, who ousted the Italian Stefano Pescosolido, 7-6 (7-2), 7-6 (7-5). The 29-year-old Edberg, a serve-and-volley player from Sweden, is battling to return to the top ranks of the tennis world after sliding out of the top 10 for the first time in a decade. After a solid first set, he lost his serving touch and began making errors on his forehand. "I started serving better in the third set," Edberg said. (AP) TWO SEEDED AMERICANS FALL: The seeded Americans Lori McNeil and Marianne Werdel-Witmeyer were upset in the opening round of the German Open in Berlin. Russia's Tatyana Panova ousted No. 11 McNeil, 6-4, 2-6, 6-3, and Ann Grossman beat a compatriot, Werdel-Witmeyer, 2-6, 6-3, 7-5. Naoko Sawamatsu of Japan, seeded ninth in the clay-court tuneup for the French Open, advanced with a 6-2, 6-4 victory over the American Kimberly Po. Steffi Graf, who has won the last four German Opens, dropped out because of a flu. (AP) CYCLING The Sprint King Does It Again Mario Cipollini outsprinted the pack yesterday to win the third stage of the Tour of Italy race, his second victory in three days and 11th this year. The powerful Italian cyclist, known as the king of sprints, took the lead 250 yards from the finish line and won easily in Marotta, his arms raised in triumph. The Belgian Johan Capiot edged Italy's Giuseppe Citterio and the Slovak Jan Svorada for second place. Tony Rominger of Switzerland finished in the pack, in the same time as the winner, and retained the pink jersey of overall leader. (AP)

description: New Jersey will join the national movement seeking tort reform under a plan worked out by Gov. Christine Todd Whitman and the Legislature to limit punitive damages in most liability cases.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball American League BALTIMORE ORIOLES -- Optioned Jeffrey Hammonds, outfielder, to Bowie of the Eastern League. Assigned Jim Wawruck, outfielder, to Bowie.

title: For the Pirates, the Past Is a Lonely Hideaway
description: As Frank Sinatra said, when he could still put the words to good music, there used to be a ball park here. It was Forbes Field, and it served as the home park of the Pittsburgh Pirates for 61 years. Remnants of the park serve as reminders that before there were University of Pittsburgh buildings, there was a ball park here.

title: Slow-to-Adapt Encyclopaedia Britannica Is for Sale
description: Encyclopaedia Britannica, one of the world's foremost storehouses of human knowledge, is being put up for sale by its owners, after limping through three years of losses and dwindling sales, according to several executives familiar with the company's plans.

title: International Briefs; In Brief
description: * J. Sainsbury P.L.C., a British grocery retailer, said yesterday that it would close 26 stores in its recently acquired Texas Homecare chain of British home-improvement stores. The number of closings is less than half what Sainsbury had originally expected when it acquired Homecare from Ladbroke P.L.C. in January. The remaining stores will be converted to outlets of Sainsbury's Homebase chain, creating an operation with 297 stores across Britain. * Tate & Lyle P.L.C. said yesterday that its French manufacturing unit, Orsan S.A., had an agreement to buy 51 percent of a monosodium glutamate factory in Guangzhou, China, for $15 million.

title: Dibble Joins the White Sox
description: ROB DIBBLE is back in the major leagues. The former All-Star relief pitcher was called up Sunday by the Chicago White Sox from Class AA Birmingham, where he was 0-1 with a 7.86 earned run average and 1 save in 8 games.

title: The Religious Right Readies Agenda for Second 100 Days
description: For months, religious conservatives watched, and many applauded, as the new Republican majority in Congress wielded its political muscle against Government spending. Now, they are urging those same Republicans to take up moral issues as well and push for restricting access to abortion, reducing Federal influence in education and, most important, creating a Constitutional protection for student-led school prayer.

title: Being Smart About Music That Isn't
description: Faith No More plays dumb rock smartly. On Saturday night at a sold-out concert at Roseland, the band performed the sappiest soft-rock, the stiffest hip-hop and the most testosterone-fueled heavy metal. But within each song, Faith No More subverted the genre, getting playful, experimental or just plain weird. At times its vocalist, Mike Patton, played the clown, singing as he flipped in the air and landed on his rear; sometimes he played the scientist, turning his microphone into an instrument by holding it close to the stage monitors and modulating the feedback.

title: Ronstadt Sings Her Way Back Through the Years
description: Linda Ronstadt's career has taken so many twists and turns over the last decade and a half that it is easy to lose sight of the fact that at bottom she is an American pop classicist with a California point of view.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Suits Lead Dow Corning Into Bankruptcy Filing Dow Corning filed for bankruptcy protection, seeking to pre-empt injury claims by hundreds of thousands of women who used silicone breast implants.

title: Quebec Has Confidence; It Needs Goals
description: It's a long series. That reminder has been repeated by the Quebec Nordiques throughout their Stanley Cup series with the Rangers, even when the superior experience of the defending champions, an unproductive Quebec power play and a controversial Game 4 nullification of a Nordique goal threatened to dramatically shorten Quebec's post-season.

title: Court Hears Tape of Man Buried Alive
description: An audiotape in which a kidnapped executive is heard talking to one of his captors while lying chained and buried alive in a 6 by 4 foot hole was introduced yesterday in a Manhattan court, providing the first detailed public glimpse of the man's ordeal.

description: Even at a recent memorial service for an old friend, held in a Harlem church just down the block from the house where he was born, Representative Charles B. Rangel used his turn at the pulpit to preach against "the silence of good people" while, as he sees it, the world is falling apart.

title: Ebola Virus Cases Expected to Rise
description: The number of cases in the epidemic of Ebola virus infection in Zaire has risen to 84, including 77 deaths, and the numbers are expected to rise sharply in the next few weeks, the World Health Organization said today.

description: Schools Chancellor Ramon C. Cortines told the City Council yesterday that Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's proposed budget cuts would devastate New York City's public schools.
