description: The battle between book publishers for the rights to the original draft of "The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn," which includes unpublished material, has begun in earnest now that the three parties claiming ownership have reached a settlement.

title: International Briefs; Astra Profits Jump 55%; Ulcer Drug Sales Cited
description: The Swedish drug maker Astra A.B. posted a higher-than-expected 55 percent rise in first-quarter pretax profit, propelled by surging sales of gastrointestinal drugs in the United States and Europe. Pretax earnings rose to 3.1 billion kronor, or $419 million, in the quarter that ended on March 31, compared with 2 billion kronor a year earlier.

title: Rockefeller Lender Vows To Stay Afloat
description: The company that made the $1.3 billion mortgage loan to Rockefeller Center, which is now in bankruptcy, said last night that it had enough cash to stay afloat "in the near term" and that it would be able to arrange longer-term financing.

title: A Contract for Lobo
description: REBECCA LOBO, the University of Connecticut basketball forward, has agreed to a three-year endorsement contract with Spalding Sports Worldwide. Company officials said they will announce details of the contract during a news conference today at Spalding's headquarters in Chicopee, Mass.

title: Doom at 8 Cents A Pound
description: It takes a great deal of fertilizer to feed the world. Ammonium nitrate, made by the millions of tons out of air and water, and readily available in farm supply stores, is equally serviceable as an explosive and a plant food. Yet it was sold without question -- until the Federal building was bombed in Oklahoma City. Now the victims of that bombing have sued the manufacturer of the ammonium nitrate, asking why, since it can be rendered harmless, they were put at risk.

title: Lowe's Cos. (LOW,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
New California Laws Will Aid The Recovery of Orange County
description: Gov. Pete Wilson of California signed into law today five bills crucial to the recovery plan of Orange County, Calif. But he vetoed a sixth bill that would have authorized him to impose a trustee to manage the financial affairs of the brankrupt county.

title: Acting Out Their Troubles
description: He tries shocking them; he tries loving them. He orders them to do push-ups; he lets them dance. Detective Frank DiPaola of the Los Angeles Police Department pulls out all the stops in his innovative program for troubled teen-agers, but for most of them, he knows, it is useless.

title: Air Force Blocks New Contracts for Stewart & Stevenson
description: The Air Force has suspended Stewart & Stevenson Services Inc. from receiving new Government contracts, two weeks after the company and its chief executive were indicted on fraud charges.

title: T.W.A. Offers New Debt Plan To Its Creditors
description: Trans World Airlines announced a broad plan yesterday to reduce its debt and better insure its ability to continue to defy the predictions of many industry analysts who have been predicting its demise.

description: Grim-faced workers were drilling holes today in the concrete columns of what is left of the Federal Building here, preparing to bring the mangled structure down some time in the next few days.

description: To the Editor:

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Nursing Home or Hospital?
description: Two Republican lawmakers have proposed letting hospitals take care of patients who now are treated in nursing homes or rehabilitation centers, a step they say would lower the cost to taxpayers.

title: Athlete in Residency Battle Is Allowed to Return to School
description: Jason McLean, the star athlete expelled from a New Jersey high school after school administrators accused his family of flouting residency requirements, was reinstated yesterday and is expected to graduate with his class in June.

title: State Senate to Consider Bill On Release of Mentally Ill
description: A Senate committee today released a bill its backers said contained safeguards to prevent local communities from being overwhelmed by hundreds of mental patients scheduled for release from state psychiatric hospitals over the next three years.

title: By Design; Nylon's Tough Love
description: Tough and shiny nylon is a high-fashion fabric this spring, inspired at least in part by Prada's heavy-duty nylon bags, ubiquitous in chic circles, and subsequent clothing made of the same hardy material.

title: 'He Said, She Said,' With a Twist
description: What did Ben Wright, the CBS broadcaster, say about lesbians on the women's golf tour? And why did he say it?

title: Which Is Better: One Parent or Two?
description: "The Vanishing Father" is a dad-friendly program that suggests that old-time attitudes about marriage and divorce may be back in fashion. The program's theme is set by Sara McLanahan, a Princeton professor of sociology whose decade of study of single-parent children has brought her to some gloomy conclusions: they are more likely than children of two-parent families to do poorly in school, to drop out, to have trouble finding jobs and to wind up divorced; daughters raised by a single parent are more likely to become teen-age mothers, and sons are more likely to spend time in jail. And those findings, says Ms. McLanahan, herself a single mother, cut across class and race.

title: Abdul-Jabbar Center of Attention at Hall
description: John Kundla was uncertain that his coaching credo -- "Praise loudly, blame softly" -- would have any effect in today's world of pro basketball.

title: HILLS STORES REJECTS DICKSTEIN PARTNERS' HOSTILE BID
description: The Hills Stores Company said yesterday that its board had rejected the $25-a-share hostile takeover bid of its largest shareholder, Dickstein Partners Inc. It said the offer was inadequate and lacked the necessary financing. Dickstein Partners had offered to buy the 90 percent of Hills Stores' 10.7 million shares that it does not already own in an offer that valued the discount retailer at about $270 million. Hills Stores stock dipped 25 cents on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, closing at $23.75 a share. Hills Stores also postponed its scheduled June 12 annual meeting.

title: German State Vote Adds Muscle to the Greens
description: Germany's upstart, environmentalist Green Party emerged as the country's potential kingmaker in local elections on Sunday that brought no solace at all to the country's political old guard, official results showed today.

title: Using the Internet the Netcom Way
description: NORMAL human beings, the kind who still think "harem" when someone says "Unix," have limited choices of ways to gain access to the Internet. This is obviously a temporary situation, since everybody who has ever used electronic mail is now either starting an Internet business or writing a book about the Internet, and Internet software will probably be stuffed in cereal boxes before too long. But for now, there are two main alternatives for getting wired without becoming a Unix administrator.

title: New Chief Executive At WPP Group Unit
description: In its second change in top management in two months, the Ogilvy & Mather Direct Worldwide unit of the WPP Group promoted Reimer Thedens to chairman and chief executive yesterday. He succeeds Jerome W. Pickholz, 62, who becomes chairman emeritus, a new position.

description: 2 Works That Offer A Chance to Let Loose New York City Ballet New York State Theater

description: In an unexpected move, the Mets optioned outfielder Carl Everett to Class AAA Norfolk yesterday and recalled outfielder Chris Jones.

title: Menem's Victory in Argentina Seen as Endorsement of Free Market
description: The overwhelming victory of President Carlos Saul Menem in elections on Sunday was seen today as an endorsement of the free-market reforms that have slowed inflation andled to economic growth in Argentina. But it raised questions about the balance of power in this young democracy.

The 9 months also included a charge of $ 10,950,000, or 68 cents a share, for change in accounting for postretirement benefits and income taxes.(Loss)

title: RITE AID SELLS ITS AUTO PARTS STORES FOR $66 MILLION
description: The Rite Aid Corporation said yesterday that it had sold its ADAP Inc. specialty automotive parts retail unit to an investment group led by Falcon Capital Inc. for about $66 million. Rite Aid, based in Camp Hill, Pa., a drugstore chain operator, said the transaction occurred Friday. The sale of the unit was the final part of Rite Aid's plan, announced in January, to focus on its drugstore business. Rite Aid had previously sold its Sera-Tec Biologicals, Encore Books and Concord Custom Cleaners businesses.

title: Clinton Praises Bush for Quitting N.R.A.
description: President Clinton lashed out sharply at the National Rifle Association today, praising former President George Bush's resignation from the organization because of its reference to Federal agents as thugs, and saying that those who would denigrate law-enforcement officers "ought to be ashamed of themselves."

title: Associate of Gerstner Selected I.B.M. Counsel
description: Once, the best way to get ahead at I.B.M. was to spend your career laboring away within the company. Now it appears that the fastest route to the top is to be listed in the Rolodex of Louis V. Gerstner Jr., the company's chairman and chief executive.

title: Dow Corning In Bankruptcy Over Lawsuits
description: Overwhelmed by injury claims filed against it by hundreds of thousands of women who used silicone breast implants, the Dow Corning Corporation filed for bankruptcy protection in a Federal court in Bay City, Mich., today.

description: I left the Clinton Administration in January when the White House issued a budget that I felt turned away from its previous commitment to deficit reduction and sensible public investment.

title: F.B.I. Kept Watch on AIDS Group During Protest Years
description: The New York office of the Federal Bureau of Investigation kept watch on Act Up, the AIDS advocacy group, during the years that it staged some of its most conspicuous demonstrations against Government policy on AIDS, according to a file supplied by the bureau to the Center for Constitutional Rights.

title: A Budget Harsher Than It Seems
description: Now we know how House Republicans hope to pay for the huge $350 billion tax cut they have promised -- with rosy projections of savings and revenues that may never materialize. If the forecasts go awry, the Republicans would be forced in future years to clamp down on spending even more harshly than they are now proposing.

description: The Manhattan gym teacher facing kidnapping charges after running away with a 15-year-old ninth grader two months ago has agreed to turn himself in this morning, ending months on the run, law enforcement officials said.

The 9 months was also after a gain of $ 6,866,000, or 85 cents a share, for effect of change in accounting principle for income taxes.(Loss)The results were after preferred dividends of $ 36,000 in latest third quarter and year-ago period. title: Harnisch Earns 4th (Moral) Victory
description: Put away the brooms. The Mets rallied for three runs in the bottom of the eighth inning at Shea Stadium last night and won, 5-3, to avert a four-game sweep by the Montreal Expos.

title: Sports of The Times; Ready or Not, It's Time To Step Up
description: HE weighs not a pound over 200, but said he is ready to bang with Charles Oakley and Karl Malone. He is keeping his college basketball options open, but the rules state that there's no turning back. His advisers claimed they're concerned about an 18-year-old in the pro basketball life style, but his reaction to the prospect of millionaire bachelorhood was to beam and say, "Come on, ladies, come on."

title: MASSACHUSETTS APPROVES NYNEX PRICE CAP REGULATION
description: The Massachusetts Department of Public Utilities has approved a petition by the Nynex Corporation to replace traditional "cost plus" regulation of its rates and profits with an alternative form of regulation called a price cap. The utilities department said that with the price cap, rate payers would benefit because Nynex's rates would be controlled according to a formula that accounts for inflation, productivity growth and certain other changes in costs that were beyond the control of the company. But the regulators would no longer directly control the level of Nynex's profits and the company could not pass costs of new technology on to customers. Rates for basic residential services will be frozen until August 2001.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Panel on State Mandates
description: An effort to require the state to pay for mandates it imposes on local governments made a significant gain Monday. Two Senate committees cleared a compromise plan that was put together by the Whitman administration, Republican lawmakers and local government interests. The compromise would set up a powerful panel that would determine whether lawmakers had passed an unfinanced mandate. It would also give lawmakers wriggle room by allowing some cases for which the state would not have to pay for mandates on local governments.

title: Russian Officials Report Finding Body of American Relief Expert
description: The body of a man reported to be Frederick C. Cuny, an American disaster relief expert who disappeared last month while on an emergency mission to Chechnya, has been found shot in the head in a village south of Grozny, the capital, officials said today.

title: American Express Deal
description: American Express Traveler Cheque Group, a unit of the American Express Company of New York, said yesterday that it was buying Special Teams Inc., a company that makes payment cards with preset spending limits. The financial terms of the deal were not disclosed. Special Teams, based in Brookings, S.D., manufactures so-called stored value payment systems, which deduct the costs of items from preset amounts electronically encoded on plastic cards. The company's systems are commonly used on college campuses for food service, bookstore purchases, laundry and other transactions.

title: Revisionist History Sees Pasteur As Liar Who Stole Rival's Ideas
description: Louis Pasteur, one of the legendary figures in the history of science, lied about his research, stole ideas from a competitor and was deceitful in ways that would now be regarded as scientific misconduct if not fraud, according to a revisionist history published this month. None of this would have come to light if not for a long scientific tradition: the laboratory notebook.

title: Grentz Is Leaving Rutgers
description: THERESA GRENTZ, who coached the United States Olympic women's basketball team to a bronze medal in 1992, is leaving Rutgers University after 20 years to take over as head coach at Illinois. Grentz will replace KATHY LINDSEY, who resigned after five seasons.

title: A Sneaky Blow at Campaign Finance
description: Senate Republicans are proposing to eliminate the best existing counterweight to the dominance of check-writing special interests in national politics. The budget blueprint unveiled last week by Pete Domenici, chairman of the Senate Budget Committee, includes a call to abolish the public campaign financing system for Presidential candidates.

Cummings AAF Gold Medal Awards for contributions to advertising. They are James Fish, 79, a former senior vice president of General Mills in Minneapolis, and Donald A. McDonald, 75, a former vice chairman of Dow Jones & Company in New York. They will be presented with the awards on June 1 at the organization's National Advertising Conference in Tampa, Fla.; the awards are named for the late Mr. Cummings, a former chairman of the federation.

title: Corrections

The concert, at the New Jersey Center for Visual Arts at 68 Elm Street in Summit, will be at 8:15 P.M. Saturday. Information: (201) 377-6599.

description: The Mimi Garrard Dance Theater presented a premiere and three works of the 1980's and 90's on Sunday afternoon in the concluding program of its 30th-anniversary retrospective at the Theater of the Riverside Church.

description: Jeep Cherokee No. SL542455 rolled off the assembly line last Oct. 9 at the Chrysler Corporation's plant in Toledo, Ohio. It left the factory with a price tag of an estimated $19,100.

title: New Zealand Says It Needs 5 Years to Prepare for Cup
description: Even as New Zealand yachtsmen accepted the America's Cup today in a formal presentation here, potential sponsors and sailors expressed concern that the Kiwi plan to stage the next regatta five years from now creates too long a period between matches.

title: JAPANESE ARREST CULT LEADER BLAMED IN POISON GAS ATTACKS
description: In an extraordinary spectacle that riveted the nation's attention, thousands of police officers conducted raids this morning and arrested the guru of the Aum Shinrikyo religious sect on charges of organizing the nerve gas attack on the Tokyo subway system.

title: Aetna Is Accused of Hiding Potential Real Estate Losses
description: A former executive at the Aetna Life and Casualty Company contended in a lawsuit filed today that the company's life insurance unit concealed from shareholders up to $1 billion in potential real estate losses during the 1990's, then dismissed him in retaliation when he went outside his department to tell what he knew.

title: Jimmy Raney, 67, a Guitarist Known for Versatility in Jazz
description: Jimmy Raney, one of the most gifted and influential postwar jazz guitarists, died on Wednesday in a nursing home in Louisville, Ky. He was 67.

title: From the Ashes in Kashmir
description: Whether it was Muslim terrorists or Indian troops who lit the fire, the burning of Kashmir's most sacred Muslim shrine last Thursday brings New Delhi's policies toward the rebellious province to a dangerous dead end. Neither military repression nor the promise of elections has succeeded in containing the violence that has left at least 20,000 people dead since 1990.

description: Fur Fights Back

title: Chess
description: It has been said that this is not the epoch for the traditional gambits, that the scientific development of the game has made it too difficult to justify the nebulous risk-taking that they involve, and that rational defensive technique must now prevail. As a matter of statistics, that is true, but the individual game can always be an exception.

title: Corrections
description: A classical music listing in the Arts and Leisure section on Sunday misstated the date of a free concert at Stuyvesant High School by the cellist David Finckel and the pianist Wu Han. It is May 24 at 6:30 P.M., not this Thursday.

title: Major Stock Indexes Set Records as Bonds Continue to Rally
description: Stock traders, expecting no surprises in economic data due out today, bid up the major stock indexes to more record highs, as the bond market also continued its rally.

title: Iranian Leader Says U.S. Move on Oil Deal Wrecked Chance to Improve Ties
description: President Hashemi Rafsanjani of Iran tried to appeal directly to the American people today, asserting that the United States missed a chance to improve relations when it forced the cancellation in March of a $1 billion deal Teheran had made with an American oil company, and urging Washington to lift its recent trade embargo against his country.

description: Science Times has an electronic mail address for comments from readers about published articles and suggested areas of coverage:

title: NBC Shoots for a 3d Comedy Night in the Fall
description: NBC is sticking with the old adage that says never change a winning game. So after two seasons of capitalizing on bold moves with comedies, the network yesterday announced a fall prime-time schedule built with a similar strategy. Two of the network's biggest comedy hits, "Mad About You" and "Friends," will be moved to new times. And NBC served notice that it would try to make Sunday its third strong night of comedies, in addition to Tuesday and Thursday. Overall, the network will introduce 7 series, 6 of them comedies, giving it 16 situation comedies, the most of any network.

title: Teacher Who Ran Away With Student Is to Give Up
description: The Manhattan gym teacher who ran away with a 15-year-old ninth grader has agreed to turn himself in this morning, ending more than two months on the run, law enforcement officials said last night.

title: TOYS 'R' US INC. (TOY,N)
description: Toys "R" Us Inc., the world's largest toy retailer, said yesterday that its net earnings in the fiscal first quarter fell about 51 percent, to $18.4 million, or 7 cents a share, from $37.6 million, or 13 cents a share, in the corresponding period a year ago.

title: Kolomna Journal; A Bizarre Election in Russia: Is This the Future?
description: The cast of candidates in Kolomna's special election sound more like suspects in a hokey murder mystery than contenders in a political contest.

title: Tucker Foundation Awards Career Grants
description: The Richard Tucker Music Foundation has awarded its 1995 Robert M. Jacobson Study Grants to Emily Pulley, a soprano; Laura Tucker, a mezzo-soprano; John Packard, a baritone, and Eric J. Owens, a bass-baritone. The awards, which are named for the longtime editor of Opera News, who died in May 1987, are intended for singers at the beginning of their careers. Each prize carries a cash award of $5,000.

title: Health for Youth On Council's Agenda
description: The Advertising Council, the agency industry's public service organization, said yesterday that it would place additional emphasis on campaigns that benefit "the health and well-being" of the nation's youth.

title: DIGITAL TO OFFER 'CRADLE-TO-GRAVE' PC SERVICE
description: The Digital Equipment Corporation said yesterday that it would begin offering a flat-fee "cradle-to-grave" service for personal computers that includes software, system upgrades and maintenance. The plan, called PC Utility, was scheduled to be introduced today. For a monthly fee of from $100 to $400, Digital would assume total responsibility. The company said the service was a way for corporations to reduce the costs associated with owning PCs. The Gartner Group, a consulting firm based in Stamford, Conn., estimated that the cost of owning a PC for five years more than doubled to almost $41,000 in 1993 from $19,000 in 1987. Bott Ikeler, a Digital spokesman, said of the company's plan, "It allows a customer to have Digital purchase the PC's for them, maintain, upgrade and take care of training," for a lower overall cost.

title: Observer; Stumped for Words
description: It is commencement season. Last winter I foolishly agreed to make a commencement speech. Winter is when they get you for commencement speeches. In winter it's hard to believe in commencement. Winter is not a commencing time of year. In a good old Middle Atlantic winter it is only natural to believe nothing will ever commence again.

title: Slaney Is Thinking Gold
description: The possibility of ending 20 years of Olympic frustration by winning her first gold medal at next year's Atlanta Games is keeping MARY DECKER SLANEY going at age 36. "It's not impossible," Slaney said yesterday of the prospect she could win the 5,000-meter race despite injuries in recent years that have required surgery.

title: The Cutting Edge: In Need of a Whetstone
description: The way to write about a Susanne Bartsch spectacle, taking a cue from the hundreds of articles about Susanne Bartsch spectacles past, is to highlight the most outrageous moment, not only to titillate the curiosity of the readers but also to make them feel square, puritanical, dull by comparison.

title: Pacific Telesis Sees 10% Drop in Earnings
description: Stung by lower rates and a falling market share of local toll calls in California, Pacific Telesis Group said today that it expected its 1995 earnings to fall about 10 percent.

title: Alice Kaplan, Art Collector And Patron, 91
description: Alice Manheim Kaplan, an art collector and a leading supporter of the arts in New York City, died on Sunday at her home in Manhattan. She was 91.

title: Devils Set For Four Possible Opponents
description: After the convincing elimination of the Boston Bruins in five games, the Devils were rewarded with two days off by Jacques Lemaire. While his players rest, however, the Devils' coach and his staff will be busy preparing for the next round of the playoffs. There are a lot of possibilities.

title: United Parcel Service of America Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Corrections
description: An article on May 4 about a campaign by the Association of Flight Attendants to make child safety seats mandatory on airplanes misidentified the type of plane in which a baby was torn from her mother's arms by the force of a crash last July and killed. She was on a twin-jet USAir DC-9, not a turboprop.

title: BERKSHIRE HATHAWAY INC. (BRK,N)
description: Berkshire Hathaway Inc., the holding company controlled by the investor Warren E. Buffett, said yesterday that while first-quarter net income fell 9.5 percent, its profit from operations rose 52 percent, led by improved underwriting results in its catastrophe reinsurance business.

title: In a Grand Procession of Mahler
description: A tremendous musical opus rounded itself out on Friday evening, when the Berlin Philharmonic, led by Claudio Abbado, sounded (just barely) the dying notes of Mahler's Ninth Symphony here at the Concertgebouw. Despite repeated cast changes in the meantime, that ineffably quiet farewell recalled with ideal symmetry the germinal opening thread of the First Symphony, played on May 3 by the Royal Concertgebouw Orchestra under Riccardo Chailly as part of the same great Mahler festival.

title: American Found?
description: The body of a man reported to be Frederick C. Cuny, the American disaster relief expert who disappeared last month in Chechnya, was found shot in the head in a village south of the capital, Grozny. There was no official confirmation.

title: The Mystery Of Music: How It Works In the Brain
description: A 61-YEAR-OLD Canadian businessman, who asked that his name not be used, recently took his wife to a fancy restaurant to celebrate their wedding anniversary. As they sat down, he asked the musicians to play the couple's favorite song, "La Vie en Rose."

title: Legal System and Science Come to Differing Conclusions on Silicone
description: In the case of silicone breast implants, the courts and much of the scientific world have proceeded on strikingly unparallel tracks. While the courts have handed down multimillion-dollar awards based on the presumption of a health hazard, leading yesterday to Dow Corning's declaration of bankruptcy, the heavy-duty scientific studies now being completed have pointed to exactly the opposite conclusion, that there is no evidence that breast implants are harmful.

title: American Israeli Paper Mills Ltd. (AIP,A) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: American Israeli Paper Mills said the rise in sales and profit was due to a quantitative increase in all activities and a significant improvement in sale prices.

title: Fast on His Feet and Quick to Doubt
description: The race took 10 seconds to run and two years to put out of his head. At the 1991 world track and field championships in Tokyo, Leroy Burrell ran 100 meters in 9.88 seconds, breaking his own world record by two-hundredths of a second. The problem was, in Burrell's words, Carl Lewis "broke it a little better."

title: CHRONICLE
description: LINDA McCARTNEY, who for more than two decades has been trying to convince people to give up meat, is taking her mission a giant step forward next week: she is to open a factory in Fakenham in Norfolk, England, that can produce one million vegetarian meals a week, The Observer reported on Sunday.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; More Coverage for Mothers
description: Representative Marge Roukema, Republican of Ridgewood, asked yesterday for a state law requiring insurance companies to reimburse new mothers for at least 48 hours of hospital care after childbirth. Speaking before a meeting of the New Jersey Assembly's Advisory Council on Women at Holy Name Hospital here, she said that some insurers, to cut costs, have proposed reducing coverage of a hospital stay after birth to as little as 12 hours.

title: Soccer Report
description: United States The Americans will not get their first -- and only -- choice to be the new coach of the national team. The president of the United States Soccer Federation, Alan Rothenberg, said yesterday that Carlos Queiroz of Portugal had withdrawn his name from consideration for the job.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Postal Worker Is Indicted
description: A former Postal Service employee was indicted yesterday in the fatal shooting of two postal workers and two customers during the $5,000 robbery of a Montclair post office in March. title: One Life After the Nazis Came

After converting their claims, Cadillac Fairview's senior debt holders will hold about 54 percent of its common shares; its junior debt holders will hold about 15 percent. description: EVOKING images of corncob pipes and cantankerous farmers warding off unwelcome visitors with shotguns, hard cider seems as outdated as the horse-drawn plow. But hard cider is coming back, worming its way into an alcoholic beverage market niche somewhere between wine and beer.

description: The Sunbeam-Oster Company said yesterday that its second-quarter and 1995 earnings would not meet analysts' reduced estimates, because sales of its outdoor products had been slow as a result of bad weather. The company, which makes furniture, barbecue grills and household appliances, also said it planned to repurchase as many as five million shares, or 6 percent of its stock, during the next two years. Sunbeam-Oster, based in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., said second-quarter earnings would be 30 cents to 34 cents a share, compared with 36 cents in the corresponding period last year. Some analysts lowered their estimates to 36 cents during the last week. Shares of Sunbeam-Oster rose 50 cents, to $19.125, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Mine Hill to Get Its Own ZIP
description: The United States Postal Service is putting this community on the map. Mine Hill, with a population of 3,333, has been using Dover's ZIP code, but because the municipalities have streets with the same names -- George Street, for example -- mail sometimes goes astray. Confusion should diminish beginning July 1, when Mine Hill Township gets its own ZIP, 07803. "This will give us our own identity," said Mildred C. Orlandi, Mine Hill's municipal clerk. LAWRENCE VAN GELDER

description: The Toyota Motor Corporation said today that at least for the next month, it would not pass on to its dealers or customers the cost of tariffs imposed by the United States Government.

title: Japanese Sect May Struggle To Get By Without Its Leader
description: Shoko Asahara prophesies that a huge conflict will destroy the world in 1997, but that his enlightened followers will survive. But with Mr. Asahara's arrest this morning, Armageddon appears to have come two years early for his Aum Shinrikyo sect, and it is far from clear whether it will survive.

title: Prayer, by Government Order
description: From the start, Ralph Reed of the Christian Coalition has been open about his strategy to attack the constitutional tradition of religious freedom in America. He said the religious right would lie low while the new Republican majority in Congress worked on budget issues and other elements of the Contract With America. Mr. Reed did not want to get the public aroused about his plan to impose prayers in public places. Now he and his allies are ready to unveil their theocratic vision and demand that the Republican Party dance to their tune for the second hundred days and from now on.

title: Injury Retires Go for Gin at 4
description: Go for Gin, who won the Kentucky Derby last year and ran second in the Preakness and the Belmont Stakes, was retired today with a leg injury.

title: Happily Ever After
description: To The Living Section: "How a Groom Survived the Pageant" [ May 10 ] details everything wrong with weddings of late. To spend that much time and that much money (presumably someone else's) on a four-hour party is wasteful and ridiculous. A script? A program? I'm thankful I wasn't invited.

title: Reva Rubin, 76, Nursing Expert
description: Reva Rubin, who was among the first specialists in maternity nursing, died on Saturday at her home in Harrisville, Pa. She was 76 and also lived in Panama City, Fla.

title: Scallops That Hint of Summer
description: SCALLOPS should never be cooked for a long time; they toughen up and lose all their flavor. Tiny ones, like bay and calico scallops, take onlya couple of minutes. Whole sea scallops may take five minutes, but they can also be cut up for quicker cooking.

title: Michigan Keeps Carr as Coach for Season
description: LLOYD CARR will coach Michigan's football team for the 1995 season, it was announced yesterday. Carr, who had been an assistant head coach and is starting his 16th year with the Wolverines, was appointed interim coach earlier this month when GARY MOELLER resigned after a drunken confrontation with the police. Athletic Director JOE ROBERSON said the move will allow him to search at a more leisurely pace for a permanent replacement and give players some stability.

title: Cato Corp.(CACOA,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 29
They Can't Keep Up With Mets' Joneses
description: Bobby Jones was bothered by the way he was pitching this evening, that much was obvious. He talked to himself after he threw several pitches, mopped his forehead repeatedly, walked around a bit more than usual. And when Todd Hundley, the Mets' catcher, made one of his multiple visits to the mound at the Astrodome, Jones motioned frantically with his hands, indicating that he could not get a feel for the ball.

title: Dying of Cancer, Woman Battles Bank on Eviction
description: Earlier this month, the world came crashing down on Doris Sanders. Within a few hours, she received a notice of eviction from her home of 19 years and she learned she was dying of cancer.

title: Casino Profits in Steep Climb
description: New Jersey's 12 casinos posted gross operating profits of $192 million for the first three months of the year, up 53 percent from last year. The report by the Casino Association of New Jersey, a trade organization, attributed the improvement to a milder winter than in 1994, the addition of more slot machines and the casino operators' ability to control costs and increase revenue. Gross operating profit represents the money left over after a casino pays its daily expenses, including salaries, utilities and supplies.

title: A Reassuring Return for R.E.M.
description: "Hey Bill, how you doing?" Michael Stipe asked Bill Berry during R.E.M.'s set here at the Shoreline Amphitheater, its first United States concert since 1989. The question wasn't exactly casual. Mr. Berry, R.E.M.'s drummer, suffered a brain aneurysm on March 1 as the band performed in Switzerland, and the concert on Monday night was his first full set since then. His drumming showed no weakness; it was forceful and authoritative, whether he was tapping a single cymbal or mobilizing a march.

title: LIMITED TO PUT RETAIL CHAINS INTO 2 NEW COMPANIES
description: The board of Limited Inc., based in Columbus, Ohio, has approved a plan to put many of its retail chains, including Henri Bendel, a luxury retailer of women's clothing and accessories, into two new companies and sell majority stakes to the public. Limited, which said in March that it was considering such a plan, said Monday that the board had approved the sale of 15 percent stakes in one new company for women's apparel and another for lingerie and personal care products. The inclusion of Henri Bendel in the new women's apparel company is the big change since the preliminary plan was announced; it called for Henri Bendel to be a wholly owned property of the parent. Besides Henri Bendel, the new women's apparel company would include The Limited, Express, Lane Bryant and Lerner New York.

title: Foreign Affairs; The Turkish Nightmare
description: On my way home from Moscow a couple of weeks ago, I visited Turkey. Talk about a country in a bad neighborhood. Look at a map. Turkey today provides one-stop shopping to all the troubles of the post-cold-war world. Turkey is connected geographically, ethnically or politically to the problems of Iraq, Iran, Armenia, Azerbaijan, Bosnia, Cyprus, Greece, Bulgaria, Russia, Tajikistan, Syria and Islamic fundamentalism. All the Turks are missing is a border with Chechnya. No wonder Turkey had four foreign ministers last year. Turkish foreign policy today is a 360-degree nightmare.

title: Case Closed in Japan?
description: The arrest in Japan of the fugitive guru of the Aum Shinrikyo religious sect, along with many of his followers, was accompanied by confident declarations that the case of the subway gas attack in March has been solved. That may prove true, since the police in Japan almost never charge anyone with a crime unless they are certain of a conviction. But the mystery of why even a small number of Japanese on the fringe of society might want to kill innocent people is likely to remain no more comprehensible to the Japanese than the Oklahoma bombing case has been to Americans.

title: Agents Stand Back
description: In the wake of intense public criticism over a shootout involving Federal agents and a fugitive at an Idaho cabin three years ago, Federal and local authorities are avoiding confrontations. They have holstered their weapons and decided to play it safe as similar situations have arisen at three sites in Montana.

title: ABC Seeking Young Adult As Viewers
description: Looking to keep its leadership in prime time while expanding its appeal beyond its base of family-oriented shows, ABC announced a new fall schedule yesterday with more comedies centering on young adults.

title: No Headline
description: The Intel Corporation said today that it planned to distribute computers based on its newest computer chips, code-named the P6 to users, so that they could test it for flaws.

title: 2 Disciplined On Asbestos In Subways
description: Two top officials at the Transit Authority yesterday became the first to be punished for the mishandling of asbestos removal at six subway stations in Brooklyn and Queens more than two years ago as the agency's president cut their salaries and demoted one of them.

description: Results are in Canadian dollars.The company is listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange.

title: A's Aren't That Easy
description: The college graduation season has arrived, a time marked by caps, gowns and accusations of rampant grade inflation. Those who decry slipping standards were reinforced by last month's disclosure that a C student at a California community college had forged a transcript, transferred to Yale, and maintained a B average there.

title: Harry Bergold, Ex-Envoy to Nicaragua, Dies at 63
description: Harry E. Bergold Jr., an official and diplomat who provided information to journalists that led to the discovery that American Government funds were being sent illegally to anti-Sandinista fighters in Nicaragua, died yesterday at his home in Paris. He was 63.

title: Energy Commission Gives Utilities Freer Trade in Low-Cost Power
description: The Federal agency that oversees the nation's utility industry issued two orders yesterday aimed at widening access to the transmission system and making it easier for utilities and independent producers with surplus, low-cost power to sell it to other utilities.

Rangers Take First Step on Road to Another Cup
description: The Rangers are still around to defend their Stanley Cup championship. They eliminated the Quebec Nordiques last night with a 4-2 victory at Madison Square Garden and will face the Philadelphia Flyers in the Eastern Conference semifinals, which will open next Sunday at the Spectrum.

title:
Real Estate;
Scholastic is expanding in SoHo, with two new leases near its headquarters at 555 Broadway.
description: SCHOLASTIC INC., a publisher of educational materials for children, is expanding along the Broadway corridor that forms the eastern boundary of the SoHo district.

title: Proceeds From a New Lottery May Refurbish Covent Garden
description: Proud as it is of its lavish productions, the Royal Opera House at Covent Garden has now taken to boasting about its shortcomings, about its lack of air-conditioning and the blocked sight lines from its top balcony, about the antiquated state of its equipment and the acute shortage of space behind, beside and even above its stage.

title: Blood on a Simpson Glove Matches Victim's, Expert Says
description: Blood on a glove found on O. J. Simpson's property appears to match that of Ronald L. Goldman, a Government forensic expert testified today, offering the first genetic results on that central piece of evidence.

description: THE World Bank, for the first time since its founding in 1945, is becoming an advertiser.

title: Miami Journal; New Policy on Cubans Met by Protest Drive
description: A Cuban exile leader was on the telephone with a police lieutenant, coordinating arrangements for the day's demonstration, while in another room the Miami City Manager, Cesar Odio, warned organizers that if any protesters continued spitting at police officers, the city's efforts at nonconfrontation might prove in vain.

title: World News Briefs; Europe's Christians Need To Regret War, Pope Says
description: In an address marking the 50th anniversary of the end of World War II in Europe, Pope John Paul II said today that Christians there should feel "bitter regret" that such a cruel war engulfed a continent long dominated by Christianity.

title: Added Slowdown Evidence: Industry and Home Building
description: More signs of an abrupt economic slowdown emerged today as industry operated at a markedly lower pace in April while home building failed to rebound from a poor winter, Government statistics showed.

description: * The Nova Corporation of Alberta said yesterday that it had agreed to sell the polypropylene business of its United States subsidiary to a unit of the Huntsman Chemical Corporation for $44 million plus working capital. The assets include a manufacturing plant in Marysville, Mich., with an annual capacity of 140 million pounds of polypropylene, which is used to make automotive trim materials and baby seats used in cars.

title: Japan Plans Appeal to New Trade Group
description: The Japanese Government said it would take action today to strike down the 100 percent tariffs that the United States declared on Japanese luxury cars by taking the matter to the new World Trade Organization.

title: Gypsum Accepts Sweetened Bid Of $1.2 Billion
description: The National Gypsum Company, the nation's second-largest maker of gypsum-coated wallboard, said yesterday that it had accepted a sweetened $1.2 billion takeover offer from Delcor Inc., a private investment company led by National Gypsum's former chairman.

title: Greenspan Says Weak Dollar Is Caused by Federal Deficits
description: Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, today attributed the dollar's weakness to large Federal budget deficits and welcomed recent efforts to balance the budget.

description: Centuries before anyone in France uttered the word escargot, the imperial chefs of Vietnam knew all about the gustatory delights of the snail. They are a delicacy here. Common garden snails are gathered in the fields by the handful and then sauteed with a little garlic and salt.

title: No Charges Filed in Strip Search
description: Deeming the strip searching of third graders "stupid but not criminal," prosecutors decided yesterday not to bring charges against the Plainfield school principal who directed 21 children to remove their clothes to see if they had stolen money. Prosecutor Andrew K. Ruotolo Jr. criticized the principal, Evelyn Baker, for a "lack of judgment and common sense" in the April 12 episode, adding, "We cannot measure the emotional impact this incident has had on these children." The missing money -- $12 -- has not been recovered.

title: A Protest Over Cuba Policy
description: About 200 anti-Castro demonstrators blocked the main shopping street in this largely Cuban community for an hour at lunchtime yesterday to protest President Clinton's Cuba policies. Most Cuban-owned businesses along Bergenline Avenue drew their shutters in solidarity with the protest. A spokesman for the United Cuba Organizations, an umbrella group, said the protesters were seeking an economic blockade against Havana and a reopening of the United States to Cuban rafters. The group, which was involved in a rush-hour protest that blocked the Lincoln Tunnel on Monday, plans to demonstrate again at Liberty State Park on Friday and here on Sunday.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-8 SANCTIONS PUT ON JAPAN The Clinton Administration imposed a 100 percent tariff on 13 Japanese luxury cars that accounted for $5.9 billion in sales here last year, including Toyota, Nissan and Honda's flagship lines. The tariff, the largest ever imposed by Washington against any trading partner, takes effect Saturday. A1 POOR RECORD IN PAST DEALS News analysis: Washington and Tokyo have a long history of coerced agreements intended to protect American industry from Japanese competition. But the record of those past deals is at best mixed and at worst a dismal failure. A1

title: BORDEN PLANS TO SELL SOME DAIRY OPERATIONS
description: Borden Inc. said yesterday that it planned to sell its dairy operations east of the Mississippi River in a revamping effort outlined for employees. The company, based in Columbus, Ohio, makes dairy products, Cracker Jack snacks and Creamette pasta. It said the operations for sale had $500 million in revenue during 1994. The company, purchased this year by the takeover firm Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company of New York, will also reorganize into nine business units with "minimal impact on head count," the chief executive of Borden, C. Robert Kidder, wrote to employees.

description: Dennis Keene established his credentials as a Durufle specialist in 1989, when he led his Ascension Music Chorus and Orchestra in a festival of Durufle's works, complete with performances by Marie-Madeleine Durufle, the composer's widow, with whom Mr. Keene studied. He revisited two infrequently heard Durufle works on Monday evening at the Church of the Ascension: the "Cum Jubilo" Mass and, as an encore, a French setting of the Lord's Prayer.

title: BALLY ENTERTAINMENT PLANS CASINO WITH PARIS THEME
description: The Bally Entertainment Corporation said yesterday that it planned to develop a $420 million, 2,500-room resort in Las Vegas, Nev., modeled after Paris. The planned resort would feature a 50-story replica of the Eiffel Tower and reproductions of the Seine River and the Arc de Triomphe. The resort, to be called Bally's Paris Casino Resort, would have mimes and jugglers, a working winery, a cabaret and French restaurants. Shares of Bally fell 25 cents, to $10.75, on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday.

(previously known as Republic Pictures Corp.), which was acquired in the 1994 second quarter, and Virgin Interactive Entertainment Ltd., acquired in the 1994 third quarter.The company issued about 22 million common shares in connection with the Virgin acquisition, increasing the average shares outstanding in the 1995 first quarter compared with the year-ago period.In addition, in the latest quarter the company conformed its accounting policies related to revenue recognition of television programming to the policies of affiliated companies. The accounting change resulted in the recognition of about $ 13,796,000 in revenues for the latest quarter, which in turn increased operating income and earnings from operations before depreciation and amortization by about $ 5,026,000.This increase was offset by write-downs to net realizable value of about $ 9,077,000 with respect to certain of the company's entertainment product.

title: RAYTHEON WINS $105.8 MILLION AIRCRAFT CONTRACT
description: The Raytheon Company said yesterday that its military business had won a contract valued at $105.8 million from the Air Force for equipment and training for Taiwan's F-16 aircraft. The equipment protects aircraft radio frequencies from being jammed. Raytheon, based in Lexington, Mass., also said it had completed the acquisition of E-Systems Inc., a maker of spy electronics for the military, on May 8. Raytheon paid $2.3 billion in cash for E-Systems. Shares of Raytheon rose $1, to $76.125, on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday.

title: Seeing India Through a Train Window
description: Seeing India by rail is an inviting prospect, and "The Great Indian Railway," tonight's two-hour tour courtesy of National Geographic, gives a notion of what it might be like, whether for visitors enjoying British Empire service on a six-day luxury ride through Rajasthan aboard the Palace on Wheels, or for just folks amiably enduring the crush of second class on the Grand Trunk Express, which ends up in Madras. As for commuters, the commuter trains out of Bombay were built to carry 1,700 standing passengers, but the number regularly on board is closer to 7,000. So stop complaining about the Long Island Rail Road.

title: Comments to Fan Cost Agassi $2,500
description: ANDRE AGASSI was fined $2,500 by the ATP Tour for unsportsmanlike conduct after his dispute with a spectator after his 6-4, 6-1 quarterfinal loss to SERGI BRUGUERA in last week's German Open in Hamburg. The fan castigated Agassi for his poor play as he left the court, and Agassi cursed the fan and responded angrily, "Are you going to get a knife?" alluding to the incident in which a fan stabbed MONICA SELES, then No. 1, in the back during a match in Hamburg on April 30, 1993. The ATP said the fine was for cursing.

title: Blues' Shanahan Has Broken Ankle
description: BRENDAN SHANAHAN, a St. Louis Blues forward, fractured his right ankle in Monday night's overtime loss to the Vancouver Canucks and will be out indefinitely, the team said yesterday. Shanahan got tangled up with GINO ODJICK and fell awkwardly in the third period of Vancouver's 6-5 victory in St. Louis that gave the Canucks a 3-2 series lead. Shanahan leads the Blues with four goals and five assists in the playoffs.

title: MARIETTA TO TURN OVER FINANCIAL DATA TO DICKSTEIN
description: The Marietta Corporation said yesterday that it would turn over confidential financial information to Dickstein Partners Inc., which is seeking to buy the company, as part of an agreement reached earlier this week. Marietta, which provides guest amenities for the travel and lodging industries and sample-size packaging for consumer products companies, rejected a $33.7 million offer from Dickstein in March. Dickstein, an investment firm based in New York, had indicated before its bid was rejected that it might sweeten its offer if the firm could gain access to Marietta's private financial information.

description: HARRY MITCHELL, the BOC single-handed sailor who has been missing at sea since March 2, was honored by a gathering of BOC sailors, officials, friends and race supporters Tuesday night in Charleston, S.C. Present were the seaman's wife, DIANA MITCHELL, and son, PAUL. Mitchell was racing from Sydney, Australia, to Punta del Este, Uruguay, when an emergency distress signal was activated aboard the 70-year-old skipper's 40-foot Henry Hornblower about 1,500 miles west of Cape Horn.

The committee's work, however, is far from over.

description: LEROY BURRELL, the world record-holder in the 100-meter dash, has withdrawn from Sunday's New York Games at Wien Stadium because of a foot injury. title: Man Acquitted of 1983 Murder
description: Twelve years after his girlfriend's slaying, nine years after his murder conviction was overturned and six years after his subsequent manslaughter plea bargain was rejected, Jose Machado was acquitted yesterday at his second trial for the 1983 murder of Nicole DeCombe, 22. He was accused of stabbing her more than 20 times and dumping her body in a marsh in Kearny. Lawyers for Mr. Machado, now 35, argued that the prosecution's evidence was gathered improperly and incompletely and that the crime may have been committed by a serial killer.

title: Lloyd Webber Ends Picasso Mystery
description: The composer Sir Andrew Lloyd Webber was the buyer of Picasso's portrait of the artist Angel Fernandez de Soto at Sotheby's in New York City on May 8, it was announced yesterday. Sir Andrew paid $29.1 million for the work, which is from the artist's blue period. That was the highest price paid for any painting since the art-market boom ended in 1990.

Staff members of the Public Theater are scheduled to speak and videos of Mr. Abdoh's work will be shown at the tribute, which is open to the public. Mr. Abdoh, who was also director of the theater ensemble Dar a Luz, died last Thursday. He was 32.

title: AT HOME WITH: Joe Morton; All 10 Toes On the Ground
description: JOE MORTON, sweetly convincing as the mute, three-toed Brother From Another Planet in John Sayles's 11-year-old cult film, is anything but otherworldly. He is a doting husband and father who brags about the social life of his 2-year-old daughter. For a wild time, he has friends over for backyard barbecues at the family's suburban home in Essex County, N.J.. And in his more than 20 years as an actor, Mr. Morton says he has been out of work maybe a total of 12 months.

Mr. Giuliani now says that savings can be achieved in other ways, notably from wage and benefit concessions by the drivers. Competitive bidding remains a sound basis for city contracts. But the Mayor is wise to be flexible in his negotiations, as long as his calculations of alternative savings are shown to add up as he says.

title: Yesterday in Washington
description: CURRENT SPENDING: President Clinton vowed to use the first veto of his term to block a bill to cut $16.4 billion from current spending, accusing Republicans of protecting money for roads, courthouses and pork-barrel projects at the expense of education, the environment and crime prevention. "I believe a bill that cuts education to put in pork is the wrong way to balance the budget, and I will veto it," Mr. Clinton said. But he also insisted, "I am not against cutting spending," and offered alternative cuts. The Republicans vowed to pass their cuts anyway BALANCING THE BUDGET: The House began debate on a Republican plan to balance the Federal budget, largely through savings in Democratic-inspired programs. Although the legislators will not vote until Thursday, the Republican plan is destined to be approved. That proposal would wipe out the deficit over seven years, reducing future spending by $1.5 trillion and taxes by some $350 billion.

title: Using Our Brains
description: Practical people agree that the best way to balance the budget is to reduce by half the relentless increase in the cost of Medicare.

title: Bridge

The field of 40 pairs included several with world reputations: Bob Hamman and Bob Wolff; Neil Silverman and Kit Woolsey; David Berkowitz and Larry Cohen, and Pyotr Gawrys and Krysztzof Lasocki, among others. But none of these were in contention for top honors at the finish.

For a double bed, the longer sides replace the original headboard and footboard and two longer rails are added.

The purchase, which includes a 488-mile pipeline, was made possible by the privatization of Australia's natural gas industry. To finance the deal, Tenneco Gas will use part of the $1.4 billion raised last year by its parent, Tenneco Inc., from the offering of shares in the Case Corporation and Albright & Wilson, its former chemical unit. With the Australian deal, Tenneco has invested $900 million in its natural gas, packaging and auto parts businesses. Tenneco, based in Houston, has said it is seeking growth and higher returns from those businesses.

The move, which thwarted legislation to open the test results to mothers, was made by top Administration officials in Washington despite some disagreement at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in Atlanta, and it even surprised those who support it.

description: The dollar ended little changed yesterday, recovering from an early fall against the German mark that stemmed from worries about whether the new French Government would maintain a strong franc policy.

description: The family that owns The News & Observer of Raleigh, N.C., said yesterday that it had agreed to sell the newspaper, one of the few remaining larger independent dailies in the South, to McClatchy Newspapers Inc. of Sacramento, Calif., for $373 million.

title: D.M.V. Workers Set to Walk
description: Union leaders say state workers at 25 Motor Vehicles offices will be walking off the job today -- again. A Whitman administration spokeswoman said managers will try, as they did during an April 19 walkout, to keep the offices open. The motor vehicles workers are unhappy with plans to turn the offices over to private contractors.

title: HARVARD INDUSTRIES TO ACQUIRE DOEHLER-JARVIS
description: Harvard Industries said yesterday that it would acquire Doehler-Jarvis Inc., the nation's largest independent aluminum die caster, for $104 million in cash. As part of the transaction, Harvard, an auto parts maker based in Tampa, Fla., will also refinance or assume about $114 million of Doehler-Jarvis debt. Harvard said it would finance the deal with cash and proceeds from a sale of debt securities. Harvard, which had sales of $615 million last year, expects to complete the acquisition by the end of June. Doehler-Jarvis, based in Toledo, Ohio, was founded in 1907 by Herman Doehler, the inventor of the die-casting process. The company had $232.9 million in sales in 1994.

title: Lemuel Wright, 82, Cornell Professor And a Biochemist
description: Lemuel Dary Wright, professor emeritus of biochemistry and nutritional sciences at Cornell University, died on Friday at Tompkins Community Hospital in Ithaca, N.Y. He was 82 and a resident of the Oak Hill Manor nursing home in Ithaca.

Family's Soul Still Lies in Rubble
description: For nearly a month now, the body of Christy Rosas and the soul of her family have been entombed beneath tons of rubble and sorrow, the remains of the bomb-ravaged Federal Building here.

title: France Starts New Conservative Era as Chirac Is Sworn In
description: Jacques Chirac, the conservative who won France's presidency on his third try earlier this month, took the oath of office today, vowing to heal the social and economic wounds left by recession and make France more vibrant under a new generation of political leadership.

title: Columbia Confers Degrees
description: In his second commencement address as president of Columbia University, Dr. George E. Rupp said yesterday that previous generations had left America in fiscal straits, and he urged new graduates to use their knowledge to help "clean up the mess we have made."

Those duties had been handled by Martin/Williams in Minneapolis for two and a half years until Shoney's ended its relationship with that agency in February.

description: The Campbell Soup Company reported strong third-quarter sales and on-target earnings yesterday, but the company's stock traded down. Wall Street seemed disappointed in the company's product volumes, international biscuit margins and debt obligations.

description: The New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority made an offer yesterday to keep the financially unhappy Devils from moving less than a day after the Nashville Metro Council passed a package of inducements to lure the Devils, or any hockey or basketball team, to play at a $120 million arena there.

description: A Levittown school bus struck another at a busy intersection here this morning, injuring 25 sixth graders, a teacher and the bus drivers, the Suffolk County police said. None of the injuries were serious.

COMPANY BRIEFS

FIDELITY NATIONAL FINANCIAL INC., Irvine, Calif., a title insurance company, said it would acquire WTC Financial Inc., a holding company, in a stock swap. Terms were not disclosed. OHM CORP., Findlay, Ohio, an environmental services company, has been awarded an estimated $144 million in contracts for hazardous waste cleanup work at Federal sites.

title: How Time Warner May Calm Its Investors
description: With investors clamoring over Time Warner's anemic stock price, the company's annual meeting today in New York could be a strained affair. But Gerald M. Levin, the chairman and chief executive, is expected to announce a cable television deal and a new on-line venture that may at least temporarily mollify his audience.

title: A Conference on Tactics For People 50 and Over
description: PEOPLE over 50 are being fired and laid off right and left, and if you let corporate America plan your future, you'll be in a lot of trouble," said Julie Frank, the producer of "The 50-Plus Experience," a two-day symposium at the Sheraton New York that begins this Sunday. More than 100 speakers will explore ways to help people over 50 avoid feeling victimized, whether by the loss of a job, illness, bad investments or retirement. Last year, 8,000 people attended the conference.

title: TJX Cos.(TJX,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 29
CIBA-GEIGY AND MEDAREX TO DEVELOP NEW CANCER DRUG
description: The Swiss drug maker Ciba-Geigy A.G. and Medarex Inc. said yesterday that they had formed a partnership to develop and market Medarex's treatment for certain cancerous tumors. Medarex's product, MDX-210 Bispecific, is being tested as a potential treatment for breast, ovarian, prostate and other cancers. Under the agreement, Ciba-Geigy will spend $8 million to acquire common shares of Medarex, a biopharmaceutical company based in Annandale, N.J. In addition, Ciba-Geigy will provide as much as $31 million for research and development and pay all costs relating to clinical trials, regulatory approval and the introduction of MDX-210. Shares of Medarex rose 87.5 cents, to $4.25, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Groups Join In Stressing Public Funds In Campaigns
description: Four public-interest organizations began a crusade for public financing of New Jersey legislative races today along with limits on the amount of money candidates may raise and spend.

description: The German steelmaker Fried. Krupp A.G. Hoesch-Krupp said yesterday that it was "considerably nearer" paying its first dividend since its creation in 1992, as its results continued to improve. It repeated forecasts that it would have a "clearly positive result" this year.

description: The nerve gas attack in March got all the attention. But if it hadn't been for an alert cleaning woman, Japan might have suffered an even worse poison gas attack early this month.

title: International Briefs; Addition of Rover Group Helps BMW Sales Climb
description: Bayerische Motoren Werke A.G. said yesterday that new BMW models and the inclusion of the sales of Rover Group P.L.C. had pushed revenue 52 percent higher for the first five months of this year. Including Rover, which BMW bought last year, five-month sales rose to 19.55 billion German marks ($13.58 billion). That compares with 12.82 billion marks without Rover in the corresponding period a year earlier. Excluding Rover, five-month sales rose 14.8 percent, to 14.72 billion marks. The figures include estimates to the end of May.

title: Possible German Role in Russian Plutonium Deal Is Investigated
description: Months after the smuggling of weapons-grade plutonium from Russia to Germany sounded alarms across Europe, the Parliament in Bonn and a court in Munich are investigating the possibility that the traffic was a conspiracy by German intelligence.

title: Serv-Tech Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
The Gold Old Days Are Now, Knick Fans
description: Madison Square Garden held onto its basketball team last night and New York City kept its celebrity coach because Patrick Ewing wasn't ready to let go of his championship dream.

title: 10 More Become Ill At a Nursing Home
description: An outbreak of respiratory illness at a Greenwich, Conn., nursing home that claimed two lives has continued, with 10 new cases reported over the last two days. To date, 24 residents of the home, the Nathaniel Witherell Nursing Home, have been affected.

title: Toys to Test-Drive
description: JUST JAKE, a new toy store in TriBeCa, is named after 20-month-old Jake Assael, but his mother, Ellen Rosenfeld, is in charge. Designed by Dean/Wolf Architects in New York, it is a toy store with a twist: children are welcome to sample most of the items on sale. There are balls to roll around on, materials for art projects, a stage that beckons young puppeteers and a carpeted "Book Boat" that is lined with books. In another twist, Power Rangers and X-Men are nowhere in sight.

title: SHARES OF APPLIED MATERIALS SOAR ON STRONG EARNINGS
description: Shares of Applied Materials Inc. and other makers of semiconductor manufacturing equipment rallied yesterday, after the company reported second-quarter results that were better than expected. Applied Materials, which is based in Santa Clara, Calif., and is the world's largest maker of computer-chip manufacturing equipment, said net income soared to $1.08 a share in the quarter that ended on April 30, far outpacing analysts' estimates of 87 cents, and up from 65 cents in the corresponding period a year ago. The results came amid predictions that the chip industry would remain robust through 1996. Shares of Applied Materials jumped $11.5156, to $80.2656, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Slaying Is Tied to a Hot Temper
description: Mohammed Ismail Abequa killed the wife he loved in a fit of hysterical anger. That was the argument advanced yesterday by his lawyers, who put three of Mr. Abequa's relatives on the stand to testify that he has a hot temper. Mr. Abequa has admitted strangling his estranged wife, Nihal, in their Parsippany home last July. But he has pleaded not guilty to premeditated murder, which carries the death penalty.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; For many luxury auto makers and their agencies, the U.S.-Japan tariff battle is off limits.
description: IMAGINE if for some reason the Federal Government imposed a tax on soft drinks sold in contoured bottles. How many minutes would Pepsi-Cola wait before unleashing an ad blitz intended to exploit its sudden advantage over Coca-Cola?

title: Home Video
description: Hola, Simba! Consumers may not realize it, but there is another whole series of Disney hits out there: in Spanish. "We've been dubbing our movies in Spanish as far back as 'Snow White' in 1937," said Dennis Rice, a senior vice president of Disney.

title: G.O.P. May 'Go It Alone' On Medicare
description: Haley Barbour, the Republican national chairman, said today that he had reluctantly concluded that Republicans would have to "go it alone" in cutting projected spending on Medicare because President Clinton and Democrats in Congress had refused to join the effort.

title: Deal Making And Delights At Cannes '95
description: AN American blonde of television and tabloid fame looks down from a billboard here, her lips parted, her hands cradling a meaningful-looking gun. "Don't Call Me Babe!" reads the ad copy for her new film, offering a prime example of this town's brand of humor. All right, call her Doctor of Philosophy, but somebody had better behave in babelike fashion if this year's Cannes International Film Festival is to meet its glitter quota. It looks like an uphill battle this year, but Cannes is always game.

title: Walkout at Motor Vehicles
description: When customers arrived at some motor vehicle offices yesterday, there were no workers around to help them. And when Governor Whitman arrived at her office here, she found a 6-foot-long pink slip. Both surprises were delivered by employees upset about losing their jobs to private contractors. The Division of Motor Vehicles has gone to court, asking a judge to bar more walkouts by the workers.

title: Chrysler Snubs Kerkorian, Lifts Dividend 25%
description: The Chrysler Corporation raised its quarterly dividend by 25 percent today, to 50 cents a share, less than one-eighth the increase sought by its biggest and most meddlesome shareholder, Kirk Kerkorian.

title: BRUNO'S AND KOHLBERG, KRAVIS CUT BUYOUT PRICE
description: Bruno's Inc. and Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company said yesterday that they had reached a revised agreement in which Kohlberg, Kravis would acquire the supermarket chain for about $1.15 billion, a 4.2 percent reduction from the original agreement. The New York investment firm will acquire Bruno's for $12 a share and will assume $220 million in debt and capitalized leases. Bruno's, based in Birmingham, Ala., agreed last month to be acquired for $12.50 a share plus the assumption of debt, which would have brought the total transaction to $1.2 billion. Kohlberg, Kravis will now buy 83.3 percent of the company's stock, down from the 90 percent originally planned. Bruno's operates 254 supermarkets in the South under the Food World, Foodfair and Piggly Wiggly names.

description: More Than Friendly

title: German Free Democrats' Chief to Bow Out
description: With the Free Democrats facing eclipse as the crucial third force in German politics, Foreign Minister Klaus Kinkel announced today that he would not seek re-election when the party he leads assembles next month for its annual congress.

title: The Horrors Behind The McMartin Trial
description: When it comes to controversial subjects, the screenwriter Abby Mann is one crusader who takes no prisoners. His credits include the 1961 film "Judgment at Nuremberg," which won him an Oscar, and the 1973 television movie "Marcus-Nelson Murders," an Emmy-winning effort that was later developed into the "Kojak" series. Now, with his wife, Myra, as co-writer, Mr. Mann goes after yet another explosive subject in "Indictment: The McMartin Trial." The HBO Pictures production has its premiere tomorrow evening.

title: Labatt Is Target of Takeover Bid Valued at $2.73 Billion
description: A Canadian investment firm and Argentina's largest brewer made an unsolicited offer of $2.73 billion yesterday for John Labatt Ltd., the second-largest brewer in Canada and the owner of a wide range of entertainment assets, including a broadcasting business and a controlling stake in the Toronto Blue Jays baseball team.

title: NEW JOINT VENTURE TO BE FORMED TO BUY SYNERGY GROUP
description: The Northwestern Public Service Company and the Empire Gas Corporation said yesterday that they would form a joint venture to acquire Synergy Group Inc., a retail propane distributor based in Farmingdale, L.I. Northwestern, a utility based in Huron, S.D., said it would initially invest about $137.5 million. The company also has an option to sell certain Synergy retail branches to an unrelated and unnamed third party. If that option were exercised, it would reduce Northwestern's net investment to about $100 million. Empire, a propane distributor in Lebanon, Mo., said it would have the opportunity to own as much as 30 percent of the venture's equity. Synergy maintains 152 retail branches serving about 200,000 customers in 23 states.

title: A Kremlin Ploy Becomes Political Russian Roulette
description: When President Boris N. Yeltsin persuaded his final few supporters to form their own political party last month, it seemed like a crafty effort to circle the wagons: a powerful centrist bloc might be the only way to keep extremists from winning elections here this year.

title: Bank Teller Takes No Chances
description: The man who walked into the Hudson City Savings Bank here at 9:41 A.M. yesterday carried a knapsack and a note. The note said that he had a gun. That was enough to persuade the bank teller to put $3,800 into the knapsack. The man walked out into the morning and disappeared.

title: Sanctum Sanctorum for Writers
description: RECENTLY, walking into the main entrance of the New York Public Library for a ceremonial occasion before its centennial celebration this weekend, I was directed up the stairway to the left. I found myself, however, walking past the stairs, to a corridor behind them. Set into the corridor's marble wall was a double door of dark wood, tall and forbidding, no lettering on it to identify it, and I stood in front of it, remembering when I had a key to that door -- and when that key was one of my most precious possessions.

title: Treasurer Overestimated Taxes
description: There was another skirmish yesterday in the long-running battle of the budget projections.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Two Victories for Pierce Mary Pierce had to fight the wind, the cold and two opponents yesterday to reach the quarterfinals of the German Open in Berlin. Pierce kept pace with top-seeded Arantxa Sanchez Vicario, who breezed past Tatyana Ignatyeva of Belarus, 6-2, 6-1. Pierce, seeded second, made short work of Slovakia's Karina Habsudova, 6-2, 6-4, playing a match postponed Wednesday by rain. An hour later, she stepped back on the court and battled the bad weather that has plagued the event to beat Argentina's Florencia Labat, 7-5, 6-3.

title: Medicaid Games
description: Having failed to guarantee health care for all Americans, the Clinton Administration is pushing another strategy to expand coverage -- one that doesn't require Congressional approval. This well-intentioned effort has led to fiscal gimmickry that allows governors to cover more of their uninsured by raiding Medicaid, the program that provides medical care for the poor.

description: If you're tired of restaurants filled with bored yuppies wearing expensive clothes and cellular phones, F.illi Ponte is the perfect antidote. Despite the most elegant renovation in recent history, this former steakhouse on the waterfront downtown has not lost its rakish charm. You can sit swathed in Frette linen (the napkins have a buttonhole so they can be worn) drinking elegant wines and perusing menus printed on handmade paper while the woman at the next table looks at her grown son and says affectionately, "Aw, shut up, Joey."

title: Winger and Crystal in Love in Paris
description: Perhaps Paris will never wear out as a metaphor for romance, but this movie season puts it to a severe test. Kevin Kline and Meg Ryan traipse around the city and fall implausibly in love in "French Kiss." Now Billy Crystal and Debra Winger gawk at the Eiffel Tower and walk along the Seine in the romantic comedy "Forget Paris." They're a much more plausible couple. And the film, directed by Mr. Crystal, has the sense to recognize that while their love is true, it's also a cliche. Mr. Crystal's character actually notices that he is standing in front of the bridge where Gene Kelly and Leslie Caron danced in "An American in Paris."

title: SHERWIN-WILLIAMS'S REQUEST TO DELAY BIDDING IS DENIED
description: Grow Group Inc. said yesterday that a New York State Supreme Court judge had rejected an attempt by the Sherwin-Williams Company to delay bidding for Grow, which has set a deadline of noon Sunday for competing takeover offers. Both Imperial Chemical Industries P.L.C. of Britain and Sherwin-Williams are seeking to buy Grow, a paint and chemicals company. Sherwin-Williams, which offered to acquire Grow for $19.50 a share on May 8, had filed suit seeking a delay. Imperial Chemical offered on May 1 to buy Grow for $18.10 a share, or $290 million. The judge's ruling was announced after the stock market closed. Earlier, shares of Grow fell 12.5 cents, to $21.125, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Beastie Boys Block Rangers
description: Will those rappers known as the Beastie Boys roil the Rangers schedule? The Beasties are scheduled to play a Wednesday night concert at Madison Square Garden, the same day the Rangers want for Game 3 of their playoff series against the Philadelphia Flyers. After playing back-to-back games against the Flyers at the Spectrum on Sunday and Monday, the Rangers would prefer not to play consecutive games at the Garden on Thursday and Friday.

RIGAS, a cable TV executive backed by nearly $18 million in city-supplied cash and lease enhancements, reached a preliminary agreement yesterday to buy the financially ailing Pittsburgh Pirates. Rigas will pay $25.15 million in cash and assume $60 million in debt for the 108-year-old franchise. He will also assume the team's projected $13 million 1995 season debt, plus a $20 million city-backed loan to the team in 1985.

Nichols might not have been in Oklahoma City on the day of the bombing of the Federal Building, but prosecutors presented enough evidence to satisfy a judge that there was probable cause to hold Mr. Nichols on charges of being involved.

description: A prominent molecular biologist says he has restored dormant, 30-million-year-old bacteria to life, a feat so astonishing that if confirmed, it would force scientists to re-examine long-held notions about the temporal limits of life.

description: Two executives recently reassigned by their agency companies have found new employers.

title: Judgment of a Neo-Nazi By His Face and Words
description: Neo-Nazism is so wrapped up in pulp-fiction imagery that it is slightly disconcerting to see a documentary on the movement that shows no mustached little Hitlers goose-stepping around and no skinheads on the rampage. This is not to say that Winfried Bonengel's film "Profession: Neo-Nazi" soft-pedals its subject. Its portrait of Ewald Althans, a charismatic young leader of Germany's neo-Nazi movement, is deeply ominous, but in a subtle way.

title: Yesterday in Washington
description: BALANCED BUDGET -- House Republicans, with the help of eight conservative Democrats, endorsed a blueprint for balancing the Federal budget. The Republicans easily rejected three alternatives to their proposal before the final vote of 238 to 193. The Republican plan is a seven-year, $1.5 trillion behemoth of spending cuts and savings, ordered mostly to erase an annual deficit that threatens to surpass $200 billion next year. But about $350 billion of the package is earmarked to pay for an array of personal and business tax breaks the House approved last month. The Senate began debate on its version of the balanced-budget plan, which rejects any immediate tax cut, and a final vote is likely next week. MEDICARE CUTS -- Haley Barbour, chairman of the Republican National Committee, said he had reluctantly concluded that Republicans would have to "go it alone" in cutting projected spending on Medicare because President Clinton and Democrats in Congress had refused to join the effort. His comments were the first indication that Republicans were contemplating unilateral action and party-line votes to redesign Medicare.

title: Donations for Clinton and Gore
description: President Clinton and Vice President Al Gore will begin a fund-raising swing for their 1996 re-election campaign with a $1,000-a-head event here June 22. Al DeCotiis, a co-chairman of the fund-raiser at the Garden State Convention Center, said he hopes to raise $1 million. "Six months ago, there was more skepticism," said Mr. DeCotiis, a Roseland lawyer. "Today, I have Republicans walking up to me and making donations."
