title: International Briefs; Deutsche Bank Decline
description: Deutsche Bank A.G., Germany's largest bank, said yesterday that shrinking margins on loans contributed to a 7 percent decline in operating earnings in the first four months of the year. Deutsche Bank's chief executive, Hilmar Kopper, said at the annual shareholders meeting that it was sticking to its goal of "clearly improving" earnings in 1995 although it expected a difficult year. In the first four months, trading income and earnings from the bank's foreign activities were better than a year earlier, Mr. Kopper said. He did not provide figures but said that the bank's earnings after the first third of the year were "well above" a third of the previous year's total.

title: Tyson to Name an Opponent Next Week
description: MIKE TYSON plans a news conference next week to announce who he will fight in his first bout since serving three years in prison on a rape conviction. Tyson and the promoter DON KING will announce his opponent and the date of the fight Wednesday at the MGM Grand hotel-casino in Las Vegas, Nev. BILL DOAK, a hotel spokesman, declined to confirm or deny earlier reports that PETER McNEELEY would be the opponent and Aug. 19 the date of Tyson's first fight in more than four years. Another rumored possible opponent was the former heavyweight champion MICHAEL DOKES.

title: JUDGE FINDS BIAS IN HOME LOTTERY
description: In a significant civil rights housing decision, a Federal judge has ruled that the virtually all-white village of Island Park rigged a housing lottery in the 1980's to exclude blacks from federally subsidized homes and to reward politically connected villagers. As a result, he found the village liable for millions of dollars in damages.

title: Albany's Message to the City
description: The news that Gov. George Pataki and the Legislature have narrowed their differences on New York State's budget is welcome, especially because the Republicans appear to have dropped their most punitive reductions in the safety net for the poor. The emerging accord worsens the budget crisis for New York City's Mayor, Rudolph Giuliani, who is now stuck with a shortfall in savings from the state. But the Mayor has alternatives that he has so far resisted. He should now redouble his efforts to negotiate work-rule or benefit concessions from the city's labor force.

It was January 1993, and the derisive chant of "1940" was alive and well in opposition rinks. The Rangers were headed west to Los Angeles when Kovalev heard he was headed to the minor leagues.

title: EXXON TO BUILD AN ETHYLENE PLANT IN TEXAS
description: The Exxon Corporation announced yesterday said that it would build a new ethylene plant at the company's Baytown plant in Texas. Ethylene is one of the building blocks for many products including plastics, packaging, detergents, solvents, pharmaceuticals, paint and building products. The petrochemical had been in short supply last fall and prices rose considerably. Exxon said that the new plant would produce about 1.54 billion pounds of ethylene a year.

title: Thunder Gulch Is Lukas's Best Bet
description: Thunder Gulch drew the No. 11 post position on the far outside today for the 120th Preakness Stakes at Pimlico Race Course on Saturday. But he was still made the 2-1 favorite to win the Preakness two weeks after he won the Kentucky Derby and to give his trainer, D. Wayne Lukas, his fourth Triple Crown victory in a row.

description: Washington's confrontation with Tokyo widened on two fronts today, as growing signs emerged that Japanese officials were winning allies abroad in the trade struggle while another big American exporter complained about Japan's trade practices.

description: The Champion International Corporation said yesterday that it would raise newsprint prices 10 percent on Sept. 1, in a move that is being watched carefully by newspaper publishers.

description: A Federal judge in Baltimore today ordered the University of Alabama and four of its scientists to pay the Government and a researcher a total of $1.9 million for stealing her work and using it as their own to obtain Federal grants.

description: Reports of violence and other problems in New York City public schools rose 27.6 percent in the first half of the school year compared with the same period last year, school officials said yesterday.

title: GENETICS INSTITUTE TO TEST PLATELET DRUG FURTHER
description: Genetics Institute Inc. said yesterday that it would move its platelet restorative factor into Phase 3 trials by the end of the year after earlier tests showed positive results. The company, which is based in Cambridge, Mass., said its Phase 2 results announced on Wednesday showed 30 percent of the patients getting Neumega Il-11 at a higher dosage did not require platelet transfusions. At a lower dosage, 18 percent did not require transfusions. The patients tested had a variety of cancers. The results were statistically significant. Analysts say the market for platelet restorative factors could be $500 million a year worldwide. In Nasdaq trading yesterday, shares of Genetics Institute closed up $3.125 at $37.125.

title: A Dead End in Bosnia
description: With the Bosnian war winding up its year, current international policy to resolve it is at a dead end. An alternative is needed. Obsessed with the past, Muslims, Serbs and Croats repeatedly use yesterday's crimes as justification for today's violence. This insures that the war will continue indefinitely.

title: Japanese-American Judges Reflect on Internment
description: The places themselves Tule Lake and Manzanar, Calif.; Minidoka, Idaho; Topaz, Utah -- have largely returned to dust. But for five Japanese-American judges, the internment camps of World War II still loom large, either because they claimed chunks of their childhoods or because, even for those too young to have been in them, they cast a long and gloomy shadow over their lives.

title: CRESTAR SET TO BUY LOYOLA CAPITAL FOR $251 MILLION
description: The Crestar Financial Corporation said yesterday that it had signed a definitive agreement to buy the Loyola Capital Corporation, a savings and loan holding company, for about $251 million in stock. Under the agreement, Crestar will swap 0.69 of a share of its stock for each of Loyola's 8.1 million shares. In New York Stock Exchange trading yesterday, shares of Crestar closed down $1.25 at $44.875. Loyola, based in Baltimore, closed at $29, unchanged in Nasdaq trading. Crestar, based in Richmond, says buying Loyola and its Loyola Federal Savings and Loan Association unit will let it blanket the Baltimore-Washington area with branches.

description: Mabel Olsen Phillips, who was president of the United Nations Delegations Women's Club from 1971 to 1973, died on Monday at Arlington Hospital in Virginia. She was 75 and lived in Washington.

title: For Whitman and Senate, Agreement on School Aid
description: When Gov. Christine Todd Whitman proposed punishing some school districts and rewarding others for their spending habits, school officials and a number of legislators said she was changing the rules -- not in the middle of the game, but after it was over.

title: Anonymous 4 Cancels
description: The early-music vocal quartet Anonymous 4 has canceled its concert tonight at St. Michael's Church, Amsterdam Avenue at 99th Street, because of illness. It is to be rescheduled. Information: (212) 678-5432.

title: On My Mind; Entering the Swamp
description: In the summer of 1990, four months before the war with Iraq began, Patrick Buchanan said on TV that only two groups were "beating the war drums" -- the Israeli Defense Ministry and its "amen corner in the United States."

title: Japanese Team Weighs Releasing Mitchell
description: The Fukuoka Daiei Hawks confirmed yesterday in Tokyo that KEVIN MITCHELL has been removed from the Japanese team's registered list, a possible first step in releasing the former major league star. "We are now studying his future," said the Hawks' president, RYUZO SETOYAMA, who removed Mitchell from the list Wednesday in a reported a dispute over a knee injury.

title: Thompson Is Added To Heinz's Roster
description: The H. J. Heinz Company added J. Walter Thompson Chicago to its roster yesterday, by assigning to the agency the consolidated account of its Heinz Pet Products division. The billings were not disclosed.

title: Flextronics International (FLEXF,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-After pretax charge of $ 816,000 for acquisition costs in the quarter and year. Excluding the charge, net income for the latest fourth quarter was $ 2.7 million, or 22 cents a share, and net income for the latest year was $ 7 million, or 58 cents a share.c-Included unspecified extraordinary gain of $ 416,000.Flextronics International said the latest fourth quarter included results from the acquisition of the net assets of Flextracker, its Malaysian joint venture, and the acquisition of nChip.

title: Flouncing In Classical Symmetry
description: Classicism with a Spanish flourish is always fun to watch in ballet, and Natalia Makarova's staging of "Paquita" for American Ballet Theater is no exception.

title: Inside Art
description: Madonna Pitches In for High Art

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt * Michigan Consolidated Gas Co., Detroit, a unit of MCN Corp., is selling $30 million of first mortgage bonds due in 2020 through Edward D. Jones & Co. The bonds are priced at par to yield 7.5 percent. Callable in five years, the issue is rated A2 by Moody's Investors Service and A by the Standard & Poor's Corp. and Duff & Phelps. * Reebok International Ltd., Stoughton, Mass., is selling $100 million of medium-term notes due in 2000 through the CS First Boston Corp. The notes are priced at 99.54 to yield 6.86 percent. The noncallable issue is rated A3 by Moody's and A- by S.& P.

title: BellSouth, Seeking Savings, Is Planning More Job Cuts
description: Conceding that an earlier program of job cuts had not reduced costs enough, the BellSouth Corporation said yesterday that it would reduce its work force by another 9,000 to 11,000 employees by the middle of 1997.

title: At the Bar; Wherein a court-appointed lawyer is dismissed: 'flawed judgment' or 'a marriage penalty'?
description: In little more than a half hour in a Federal courtroom last week, a relatively obscure proceeding offered a repertoire of provocative contemporary questions for lawyers, notably this one: Do law partners who are wife and husband have different ethical obligations than nonmarried partners?

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: BINDLEY WESTERN INDUSTRIES, Indianapolis, a wholesale drug distributor, said its Kendall division had received a five-year contract valued at more than $160 million to supply pharmaceuticals to 16 United States Department of Defense facilities in Europe. EXIDE CORP., Reading, Pa., an automotive battery and after-market-accessories maker, completed its acquisition of Cie. Europenne d'Accumulateurs S.A., a French battery maker, for $425 million in cash.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: Starting Over In Latin America; Partnership Signals Revival Of Interest in Risky Market
description: It was hardly the typical leading indicator. But when Pedro-Pablo Kuczynski got into his red Porsche recently and headed south for Miami, that was as good a sign as any that the smart money was heading south, too, all the way back to Latin America.

title: Doctor in India Awakens From His Moral Blindness
description: Nihar Sengupta (Soumitra Chatterji), the protagonist of Sandip Ray's moving film "The Broken Journey," is a successful Indian doctor who caters to a wealthy clientele in Calcutta. The opening scene finds Dr. Sengupta at home with his wife, going over a speech extolling 20 years of medical progress that he plans to deliver at a Rotarian convention in a nearby city.

title: Time Warner Pledges Action On Rap Lyrics
description: Faced with resurgent criticism of some of its rap-music performers, Time Warner said yesterday that its music division would lead an industrywide effort to develop standards for rap lyrics.

title: Amtrak to Pay $4.5 Million
description: Amtrak must pay $4.5 million to the family of a man left comatose when he was hit by a train in 1990. Edwin Ocasio, now 34, was trying to cross the elevated tracks at the abandoned South Street station in Newark when a New Jersey Transit train struck him. An Essex County jury found Wednesday that Amtrak, which owns the tracks, should have fenced them off.

title: Paris Journal; Seducing France With Watercress Sandwiches
description: In the land of foie gras and chateaubriand, fish and chips has always been regarded as indigestible. The French eat well, the British merely take nourishment -- but Marks & Spencer, the British-based food and clothing retailer, is changing that notion fast.

title: 12 Indicted in Fraud
description: Twelve people, including two brothers identified by prosecutors as Mafia members, were accused of illegally obtaining about $5 million in asbestos-removal and construction contracts from New York City and state agencies that were intended for minority-owned companies.

title: Guatemala: A Pattern of Duplicity
description: America's relations with Guatemala are a chilling study in cynicism. Beginning with a 1954 coup engineered by the Central Intelligence Agency, cold war security concerns dictated nearly every aspect of the relationship with this impoverished country. Abuses by Guatemalan military and security services went unchecked, and Americans who wandered into the way were killed or tortured with barely a protest from Washington.

title: Autodesk Inc.(ACAD,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
description: Autodesk attributed its increased revenues to record new unit shipments of its AutoCAD design automation software package.

title: Now Pacers Are Feeling the Pressure, Too
description: Most people are disappointed when their vacations are postponed, but the Knicks are ecstatic.

title: XEROX DISAPPOINTS INVESTORS BY NOT RAISING DIVIDEND
description: The Xerox Corporation disappointed investors yesterday when the copier company's board voted not to change the dividend. Investors had been looking for Xerox to raise its dividend this year because earnings had increased. The last time Xerox raised its dividend was in 1981. It has been $3 since then. Xerox shares have been ascending for two years as the company has cut jobs, consolidated plants and refocused on its core document-processing business. In New York Stock Exchange trading yesterday, Xerox's shares closed down $4.375 at $117.75.

title: China Pledges Safe Passage Around Isles
description: Responding to concern by the United States, Japan and its Southeast Asian neighbors, China said today that its territorial claim to a group of islands in the South China Sea is not meant to impede freedom of navigation or the safe passage of aircraft.

title: Condom Plant to Close
description: Carter-Wallace, one of Trenton's largest private employers, confirmed yesterday that it will close its plant here, which makes Trojan brand condoms. That means 500 fewer manufacturing jobs in a city that once boasted "Trenton makes, the world takes." Carter-Wallace's other New Jersey operation, a research and manufacturing plant in Cranbury, is not affected.

title: Injury Idles Aouita for New York Games
description: SAID AOUITA of Morocco, the world record-holder at 2,000 meters, withdrew yesterday from Sunday's New York Games because of a pulled leg muscle. Aouita, 35, making a comeback after three years of inactivity, was to compete in the 3,000-meter race in the Grand Prix meet at Columbia University's Wien Stadium. (AP)

title: A Ruling in Trump's Favor
description: Regulators ruled yesterday that letting Donald J. Trump open another casino would not drive out competitors or discourage new entries into the casino market here. Mr. Trump still needs to get a casino license for the Trump Regency hotel, but that step is considered something of a formality after the decision by the Casino Control Commission. Mr. Trump said the casino would open by next March after $40 million in renovations at the Regency.

title: New Scandal Rocks Conservatives in Britain
description: For Prime Minister John Major and his besieged Conservatives, the timing could not have been worse.

title: Devils' Lease Is a Primer for Yankees
description: Is New Jersey's rush-rush attempt to keep the Devils from leaving the Meadowlands a prelude to George Steinbrenner's talks to move the Yankees?

title: Once More, With Feeling
description: "Make no mistake about it, this bill is a historic watershed," said Senator Bob Packwood, Republican of Oregon. "If this bill does not work, or if Congress and the President attempt to frustrate it, we will lose our last significant opportunity to deal with the deficit."

title: Legislators Denounce U.S. Policy on Cuba and Russia
description: The Clinton Administration's foreign policy came under sharp criticism on two fronts in Congress today.

title: Art in Review
description: John Newman Jason McCoy 41 East 57th Street Manhattan Through June 2

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a picture caption yesterday about President Clinton's speech to participants in a Federal school-to-work training program misidentified the youngster at whom the President was smiling. She was Nancyann Kesting, a student at St. Marys County Technical Center in Maryland. It was not his daughter, Chelsea, who was in school at the time.

title: Bomb Suspect in Court
description: In a preliminary hearing, a Federal agent said that the Government had indications that Terry L. Nichols might not have been in Oklahoma City on the day of the bombing. But a judge determined that there was probable cause to hold him.

title: Bulls Burst In the Air As Magic Moves On
description: When Shaquille O'Neal has children, and they are dunking over the children of Luc Longley and Will Perdue, he wants them to remember something.

title: Teacher Is Removed After Students Say He Told Sex Stories
description: A veteran teacher was removed from the classroom at Stuyvesant High School in Manhattan yesterday after students accused him of lecturing about his sexual fantasies during English class.

title: Japan Arrest Cultist Sought in Abduction
description: The police arrested a key member of the Aum Shinrikyo religious sect today who had been wanted on kidnapping charges, and they found he had undergone facial surgery to change his appearance.

title: Blood, Bombings, Car Chases, Subway Crashes, You Know
description: In the previous "Die Hard" movies, Bruce Willis started out as a reasonably well-groomed guy, only to end up as a tattered, bloody hero. In "Die Hard With a Vengeance," he's wearing a grimy undershirt at the start, as if to signal, "Let's cut to the chase." What fans expect, and what "Die Hard With a Vengeance" delivers, is pure action, with bigger and better explosions and stunts. The movie turns two hours of bombings, subway crashes, car chases and helicopter pursuits into the ultimate roller-coaster ride.

title: Waiting for Its New Leader to Engage, N.A.A.C.P. Shows Signs of Impatience
description: Three months ago, on an unseasonably warm winter night in New York, the board of the N.A.A.C.P. elected Myrlie Evers-Williams as its new chairwoman, ushering in what her backers said would be a new era for the storied but ailing civil rights organization.

title: Dow Plunges 81.96 Points In Largest Selloff of Year
description: In the biggest selloff of the year, stock traders knocked down prices from record highs, with the Dow Jones industrial average plummeting 81.96 points, to 4,340.64.

title: Art in Review
description: Richard Estes Marlborough Gallery 40 West 57th Street Manhattan Through June 10

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the possibility that Borough President Guy V. Molinari will run for Staten Island District Attorney misidentified the current District Attorney. He is William L. Murphy, not Richard O. Murphy.

title: Treasury Prices Are Down, But Investor Influx Cuts Loss
description: Treasury prices fell sharply yesterday, hurt in part by profit taking after its recent rally. But a steep selloff in the stock market helped limit losses as investors fled equities for the relative safety of Treasury bills.

title: AT THE MET WITH: Cindy Sherman; Portraitist In the Halls Of Her Artistic Ancestors
description: CINDY SHERMAN can't remember the last time she visited the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Today she's in the lobby, along with the tourists, fishing around the information desk for a map. What is there to see, she asks? She is open to suggestions. She has heard about a show of works by Nadar, the 19th-century French photographer, but doesn't know much about him. Might as well start there, she says.

title: Sports of The Times; Knicks Have Been Down This Road
description: OF course they can. After watching the Knicks plod and lumber and lurch and stagger and trudge through the last few seasons, don't you think they can go into Indianapolis tonight and grasp one more game for themselves? Out of sheer stubbornness, I mean. We're not talking right or wrong, good or bad, artistry or destiny. We're talking obstinacy.

title: When Needed, Oakley Flashes Finesse Game
description: Charles Oakley is not out there for his shooting touch. He's out there because he sends people to Illinois and Ohio when he goes up for a rebound in Indiana.

title: International Briefs; In Brief
description: * The German insurer Aachener und Munchener Beteiligungs A.G. said yesterday that its Aachen Re unit had completed the previously announced sale of most of its reinsurance business to the Employers Reinsurance Corporation of the United States for 192 million marks ($133 million). The acquirer is a subsidiary of the General Electric Company. * The Coca-Cola Company said yesterday that it planned to set up its largest Chinese bottling plant in Shanghai and establish the company's national operations headquarters there. The company has 13 plants running in China, and five more will be completed before the end of next year. * Saab Automobile A.B. said yesterday that it would begin selling cars in Chile. Saab said it would aim to sell 50 to 100 cars in the first year, with sales rising to 200 to 300 cars a year when all sales contacts were established.

title: No One Has Yet Found a Way to End Poverty
description: To the Editor:

title: Mutual Funds Plan to Make Buying Simpler
description: Potential buyers of mutual funds will get their first peeks in 30 to 60 days at an easier-to-understand offering prospectus, the document that details a mutual fund's risks and previous performance, Arthur Levitt Jr., chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, told an investment industry conference here today.

title: Pens' Jagr Attracts the Devils' Attention
description: Pittsburgh's explosive offense in general and Jaromir Jagr in particular are the main concerns for the Devils in their four-of-seven-game playoff series with the Penguins that begins tonight in Pittsburgh.

title: International Briefs; Sony to Raise U.S. Prices
description: Sony Electronics Inc. plans to increase prices on some consumer electronics products sold in the United States up to 2 percent in June to combat the decline of the dollar against the Japanese yen. The products targeted include televisions, VCR's, stereos and camcorders, according to Rick Clancy, a spokesman for the United States arm of the Japanese consumer electronics and entertainment company. Profits at many Japanese companies that are heavily dependent on overseas markets have been crippled lately by the advance of the yen against the dollar. As the yen gains in value against the dollar, goods made in Japan become more expensive when sold in the United States.

title: Poor Care Didn't Kill Fireman, Report Says
description: Describing a "systemic failure" in the emergency treatment for a firefighter who collapsed at a Brooklyn blaze in March, state health officials said no one took complete charge of care at the fire, that a crowded ambulance hampered treatment and that doctors at a hospital failed to correct a problem with the firefighter's oxygen tube.

title: The N.Y.P.D. Bacchanal
description: All the allegations of appalling behavior by New York City police officers in Washington on Sunday night and Monday morning have not been confirmed. But it is clear that some committed acts ranging from the merely loutish to the possibly criminal while they were visiting the capital to commemorate fellow officers who had died in the line of duty. Commissioner William Bratton is justifiably incensed. He needs to take the strongest action possible under department regulations against those involved.

title: Die-Hard Knicks Force Game 7 With a Vengeance
description: Fighting the odds, fighting history and at times fighting with each other, the Knicks held off a furious fourth-quarter comeback by the Indiana Pacers and stayed alive in the playoffs with a dramatic 92-82 victory tonight at Market Square Arena. After trailing by three games to one in the four-of-seven-game Eastern Conference series, the Knicks are one victory from shocking the Pacers, as well as many who believed the Knicks were finished.

title: A Classic Distilled To a Pure Essence
description: Just plain terrific would be the easiest way to describe how the New York City Ballet's latest premiere, Jerome Robbins's "West Side Story Suite," came across on Thursday night.

title: Court Backs Government In Detention Of Immigrants
description: Two days after a Federal court in Pennsylvania ruled the immigration service had wrongly held the passengers of a freighter, the Golden Venture, for nearly two years, an appellate court in Manhattan decided yesterday that the Government was within its rights not only to detain the smuggled immigrants, but also to deny them political asylum based on their opposition to China's policy of restricting families to one child.

title: Corrections
description: The About Real Estate column on May 12 about the acquisition of a run-down apartment building at 341 West 45th Street in Manhattan referred incorrectly to the neighborhood. It is Clinton; Clinton Hill is in Brooklyn.

title: Debt-Plagued County Likely To Get Relief
description: Orange County is on the verge of an important step in its efforts to emerge from the largest municipal bankruptcy on record. Investors in nearly $1 billion of the county's bonds have agreed in principle to wait a year for repayment, county officials and lawyers involved in the negotiations said today.

title: What Inner-City Jobs for Welfare Moms?
description: In the debate over welfare reform, conservatives like Gov. George Pataki argue that all we need to do to fix the welfare mess is to stop making life on the dole so comfortable. With this expensive, misguided New Deal system out of the way, they say, welfare mothers will go out and find honest jobs.

title: Marshal Royal, Music Director And Soloist, 82
description: The saxophonist and clarinetist Marshal Royal, best known as the lead alto saxophonist and music director of the Count Basie Orchestra for 20 years, died on May 8 in a nursing home in Inglewood, Calif. He was 82.

title: Rowdyism by New York Police Is Called Latest in Odd Pattern
description: The drunken rampage by several dozen New York City police officers attending a memorial service in Washington this week was hardly the first, and the Police Department had issued a stern directive early this month warning officers attending the ceremony to behave themselves.

title: The Pain of Believing Unites 4 New Plays
description: A farmer falling from a barn roof wonders if sheer power of thought can keep him from hitting the ground. A middle-aged woman, who has just lost both her lover and dog, spends Christmas Eve trying to persuade herself that there is comfort in her future.

title: Newark School Takeover Is Seen as Early as July
description: The Commissioner of Education, Dr. Leo F. Klagholz, said yesterday that the state government might start taking over the long-troubled Newark school system as early as July.

title: Rhode Island's Senate Sends Gay-Rights Bill to Governor
description: The Rhode Island Senate extended civil-rights guarantees to homosexuals last night, approving a measure that would bar discrimination in employment, housing, public accommodations and credit on the basis of sexual orientation.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Thursday about a proposed alliance between the Sprint Corporation and France Telecom and Deutsche Bundespost Telekom misstated the price the European companies originally proposed to pay for 20 percent of Sprint. It was $47.225 and $51 a share in two separate transactions, not $40.

title: A Shy Juliet Turns Bold In a Powerful 'Romeo'
description: American Ballet Theater presented this season's first performance of Kenneth MacMillan's "Romeo and Juliet" on Thursday night at the Metropolitan Opera House. It was a memorable occasion notable for its dramatic power and overall excellence.

title: Mayor Wants to Put School Safety Officers Under Police
description: Reviving a campaign pledge to reduce school violence, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that he wanted to put the 3,000 school safety officers under the control of the Police Department.

title: Du Pont Selling Four Medical Subsidiaries
description: E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company said yesterday that it would sell four medical-products units, which have about $1 billion in annual revenues, to help finance its share repurchase from the Seagram Company

title: The Developing World Needs Its Own Doctors; Research at Risk
description: To the Editor:

title: Why Choose Times Sq. For a Hotel Complex?
description: To the Editor:

title: Stomach Flat, Not Mercer
description: "You like my stomach, huh?" asked Ray Mercer, who used to keep it filled to the stretching point. Now the stomach is flat and Mercer is talking and walking tall.

title: Injured Boxer Dies
description: Jimmy Garcia, a 23-year-old super featherweight boxer critically injured in a fight with Gabriel Ruelas May 6, died yesterday morning in Las Vegas, Nev. Garcia had surgery to relieve a blood clot in his brain after absorbing a beating in the bout, but his condition deteriorated when he suffered kidney failure and lapsed into a coma.

title: Citing Publicity, Lawyers Seek to Transfer a Rape Trial
description: A poll shows that Alex Kelly, the former Darien High School wrestler accused of rape, has three times the name recognition in lower Fairfield County as Congressman Christopher Shays, said Mr. Kelly's lawyers, who commissioned the survey. Because of the publicity surrounding the case, they said today that they want his trial moved elsewhere.

title: Agreement Clears Way for All-Star Game
description: Baseball's players and owners took a small step yesterday that they hope they can convert into a giant leap to a new labor agreement.

title: MEDCO GETS F.D.A. APPROVAL ON HEART DISEASE DRUG
description: Medco Research Inc. said yesterday that the United States Food and Drug Administration had approved its drug Adenoscan, which is used for detecting coronary artery disease, for marketing in the United States. The pharmaceutical company, based in Research Triangle Park, N.C., said its adenosine injection drug was approved for use in dilating coronary arteries, along with radioactive thallium, to provide rapid and maximum dilation of the arteries to detect coronary artery disease. The company said Adenoscan was an alternative for treadmill stress tests, normally used to detect the disease, for those patients unable to perform them. The company's stock yesterday jumped $1.375, to $14.875, on the American Stock Exchange.

title: Radio Marti Advances No Agenda on Cuba
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Sees Peril in a U.N. Pullout
description: As NATO officials met in Europe to discuss how peacekeepers might be withdrawn from Bosnia, Defense Secretary William J. Perry told the United Nations Secretary General today that pulling out the force would be dangerous for the Balkan region, officials said.

title: Dollar Shows Strength vs. Mark But Slips Further Against Yen
description: The dollar edged up against the German mark but slipped against the Japanese yen yesterday in quiet trading.

title: BANCTEC AND RECOGNITION IN MERGER AGREEMENT
description: Banctec Inc. and Recognition International Inc. said yesterday that they had agreed to merge in a stock transaction valued at $180 million. Under the agreement, Recognition shareholders will receive 0.59 share of Banctec stock for each share of Recognition. A $65 million restructuring charge will be incurred by the concerns, which are computer software and services companies, to accommodate costs of the consolidation. Grahame Clark, chairman and chief executive of Banctec, will become chairman and chief executive of the combined company, which will have revenue of $500 million at the time of closing. Shares of Banctec, based in Dallas, rose 12.5 cents, to $17.75 yesterday. Shares of Recognition, based in Irving, Tex., rose $1.25, to $8.25. Both are traded on the Nasdaq.

title: I.B.M. Is Cutting Secretaries' Pay
description: I.B.M. has confirmed that it will cut the salaries of about 120 top secretaries by as much as 36 percent as part of a companywide cost-cutting strategy.

title: CHRONICLE
description: JUDITH R. SHAPIRO, who has just finished her first year as president of Barnard College, wanted to surprise the members of the class of 1945 who had assembled yesterday over breakfast for the opening of their 50-year reunion.

title: International Briefs; Dresdner Bank Net Falls
description: The Dresdner Bank A.G. said yesterday that its first-quarter operating profit was lower than a year earlier but that it was confident about earnings in 1995. Dresdner's chief executive, Jurgen Sarrazin, said operating profit in the first quarter was less than a quarter of its 1994 full-year profit. That would put first-quarter operating profit below 408.5 million marks $284 million.

title: Group Protests Ticket Rules
description: Ticket prices for sports events, concerts and other shows could go through the roof under legislation removing limits on markups for tickets, a citizens group asserts. The relaxed rules are a ticket to "price gouging," says Phyllis Salowe-Kaye, the director of New Jersey Citizen Action, which began a petition drive urging Governor Whitman to veto them.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: CAE INC., Toronto, has received a Canadian Defense Department contract valued at $100 million to design and install modern flight systems in a fleet of aircraft. HEALTHSOUTH REHABILITATION CORP., Birmingham, has completed its purchase of the rehabilitation hospital division of Novacare Inc., Valley Forge, Pa., a rehabilitation management services company, for approximately $215 million in cash and $20 million in assumed debt. INFORMIX CORP., Menlo Park, Calif., a data base management and computer software company, announced that its board has approved a 2-for-1 stock split that would increase the number of shares outstanding to about 132 million from about 66 million.

title: Leo Zippin, 90, Dies; Solved Math Puzzle
description: Leo Zippin, a professor emeritus of mathematics at Queens College, died on May 11 at his home in Manhattan, a spokesman of the college said. He was 90.

title: 2 Held in Subway Shooting
description: Two teen-age boys were arrested and charged with attempted murder yesterday after a shooting in a Brooklyn subway station that left two other teen-agers wounded, the police said.

title: Bridge
description: One of the greatest bridge players of all time died on May 12 in Rome at age 72. As a member of the Blue Team, Giorgio Belladonna won 16 world team titles between 1957 and 1975, a career performance that may never be equaled. He created two highly successful and original systems with his two favorite partners, Roman with Walter Avarelli and Super Precision with Benito Garozzo.

title: Seymour B. Durst, Real-Estate Developer Who Led Growth on West Side, Dies at 81
description: Seymour B. Durst, a Manhattan real-estate investor and developer who combined a passion for city history with an equally strong distaste for government involvement in land-use affairs, died yesterday at New York Hospital. He was 81.

title: Galloping Into a Night of the Blues
description: Songs fled, virtuosity vanished and the almighty power of the groove appeared on Thursday night at the Bottom Line. Fat Possum Records, perhaps the most important label now recording blues, brought in three bluesmen from the Mississippi Delta for a one-night appearance: Junior Kimbrough and R. L. Burnside, along with Dave Thompson.

title: Retirees Who, By the Way, Can Write
description: THE other day Eileen Tobin, who is 79, and Mary Harkins, who is 77, came down from their respective apartments at Morningside Gardens for the weekly writing class that the novelist Mary Gordon teaches for 15 elderly people who live at the cooperative complex at 124th Street off Broadway.

title: Fines Possible in Walkout
description: About 150 motor vehicle workers who walked out yesterday after receiving layoff notices could be fined $500 each and their union $10,000 if the state prevails in a court hearing on Monday. The state contends that the employees and the Communications Workers of America violated a court order barring further job actions, after 200 workers left their agencies to rally outside the State House against Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's plan to turn their agencies over to private companies. The union denied that it encouraged the walkouts. But in court documents, the state cited a memo by a union representative congratulating workers on closing every office "except Bayonne, Jersey City and Flemington.

title: Icahn Reported Buying Up Rockefeller Center's Debt
description: Carl C. Icahn, the financier best-known for wresting Trans World Airlines from its management, has been buying up the debt of Rockefeller Center Properties Inc., the real estate investment trust that holds the $1.3 billion mortgage on Rockefeller Center.

title: International Briefs; Viag Profits Quadruple
description: Viag A.G., a diversified German utility, said yesterday that its recent acquisition of Bayernwerk A.G., a Bavarian utility, had quadrupled its profit in 1994 and would create further earnings growth this year. Viag's chief executive, Alfred Pfeiffer, said he expected pretax profit in 1995 to reach 2 billion marks $1.39 billion, with sales reaching 40 billion marks. The company had pretax profit of 1.77 billion marks in 1994 on sales of 28.96 billion marks. Viag said one-time factors from its acquisition of Bayernwerk nearly quadrupled its profit to 1.12 billion marks $778 million in 1994, from 302 million marks.

title: Traffic Alert
description: TODAY Ninth Avenue will be closed to traffic from 37th to 57th Street from 8 A.M. to 7 P.M. for the annual Ninth Avenue Food Festival. TOMORROW Ninth Avenue will be closed to traffic from 37th to 57th street from 8 A.M. to 7 P.M. for the annual Ninth Avenue Food Festival. Amsterdam Avenue and cross streets will be closed to traffic from 77th to 96th streets from 8 A.M. to 9 P.M. for the Amsterdam Avenue Festival. Fifth Avenue will be closed from 57th to 79th streets from noon to 4 P.M. for the Israel Day parade.

title: Adviser to Dole Campaign Uses Slur for 2 Jewish Congressmen
description: Edward J. Rollins Jr., a senior adviser to Senator Bob Dole's campaign for the Republican nomination for President, has touched off a political furor by referring to two Jewish Congressmen as "Hymie boys."

title: Note to Readers
description: The Op-Ed page welcomes unsolicited manuscripts. Because of the volume of submissions, however, we regret that we cannot acknowledge an article or return it unless it is accompanied by a self-addressed, stamped envelope. If manuscripts are accepted for publication, authors will be notified within two weeks.

title: Bond Prices Dip as Market Seeks Direction
description: With little to give the credit markets direction yesterday, bond prices sagged a bit as investors traded cautiously and began to focus on next week's supply of new Treasury issues.

title: Oklahoma City Building Was Target Of Plot as Early as '83, Official Says
description: Twelve years before the Federal Building in Oklahoma City was bombed, a group of white supremacists with close ties to the neo-Nazi group Aryan Nations drew up a plan to bomb the same building in much the same way, according to evidence gathered in the late 1980's by a Federal prosecutor.

title: SUPERIOR INDUSTRIES GETS $1 BILLION G.M. CONTRACT
description: Superior Industries International Inc. of Van Nuys, Calif., has received a $1 billion, five-year contract from the General Motors Corporation to make cast aluminum wheels for all current G.M. models, Superior said yesterday. The auto parts maker said the contract will run from Jan. 1, 1996, to Dec. 31, 2000. Separately, the company raised its quarterly dividend to 5 cents a share from 4.5 cents. The dividend will be paid July 21 to shareholders of record July 7. Superior Industries' stock was up $1.75, at $30.75 a share, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: In America; Those Wonderful Kids
description: Teachers and school administrators never tire of telling us, often in the most syrupy of tones, how committed they are to the welfare of the wonderful, wonderful children in their care.

title: Fillies Can't Catch Serena's Song
description: Thirteen days after she led the Kentucky Derby for more than a mile before tiring and finishing 16th, the filly Serena's Song made a startling comeback today when she won the Black-Eyed Susan Stakes by nine lengths and gave D. Wayne Lukas his second stakes victory in two days at Pimlico Race Course.

title: Ex-Officer Pleads Guilty to Theft
description: A former rescue-squad lieutenant who organized a donation drive for a 7-year-old Millville boy paralyzed in a 1993 car accident pleaded guilty yesterday to stealing money from the fund. The terms of the plea require Richard J. Solkin, 23, of Linwood, to make restitution of $8,080 to the boy, Devon Fuentes. The Atlantic County prosecutors office said it will ask the court to impose a "substantial county jail term" at sentencing June 23.

title: With One Hand, Hulbert Climbs to Lead
description: Purists might cringe. Aficionados might wince. Hard-core fans might snicker. Mike Hulbert could not care less. His putting style might be a little unusual, but there is a lot of substance to it. And today, on a chilly, overcast day at Westchester Country Club, he once again showed why the real name of the game in golf is not how but how many.

title: Sumitomo, World's Biggest Bank, to Post Loss, a Rarity in Japanese Finance
description: It's the biggest bank in the world, owns a chunk of Goldman, Sachs, is being harassed and shot at by gangsters, and is little known outside Japan.

title: U.S. Agency on Front Line of Disease War: Crowded, Understaffed and Overwhelmed
description: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, which is in the front line of the world's response to the deadly Ebola virus epidemic in Zaire, is finding itself hard pressed to cope with the crisis.

title: Two Russian Singers Of Force and Passion
description: When Eve Queler and her Opera Orchestra of New York hire out Carnegie Hall, it is usually to bring along repertory most opera devotees know only from the occasional recording or from musical encyclopedias. During an evening of operatic excerpts on Wednesday, Ms. Queler's opera-in-concert company congratulated itself on another kind of originality and exoticism: its successful searches for new singers from far-off places.

title: Signs of Bald Eagle's Comeback
description: Good bird news: State wildlife officials spotted two newborn baby eagles in a nest atop a tree near the Round Valley Reservoir, a further indication that the endangered bald eagle is making a comeback in New Jersey. As recently as 1981, there was not a single eagle's nest in the state. Now there are at least 11, 9 of which have produced eagles. JOE SHARKEY

title: The Developing World Needs Its Own Doctors; Rescue Syndrome
description: To the Editor:

title: In Budget Battle, a Different Balancing Act
description: Senator Olympia J. Snowe, Republican of Maine, is unyielding on this point: The Federal budget must be balanced, and sacrifices must be made all around.

title: Space Agency Plans Layoffs, Shrinking to Pre-Apollo Size
description: The space agency said today that it would make deep cuts in its work force and streamline its operations as its budget shrinks in a new era of austerity.

title: McKay Has Surgery
description: The ABC sports broadcaster JIM McKAY was listed in critical but stable condition yesterday at the Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore after undergoing elective heart surgery. McKay, 73, is expected to be hospitalized for four to five days. (AP)

title: Agency Is a Victim of Its Own Success
description: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention is known for its quick response to outbreak emergencies, particularly those that are unusual.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball American League BOSTON RED SOX -- Purchased the contract of Ron Mahay, outfielder, from Trenton of the Eastern League. Placed Lee Tinsley, outfielder, on the 15-day disabled list. Signed Cory Snyder, outfielder, to a minor league contract. CHICAGO WHITE SOX -- Sent Steve Gajkowski and Mike Mongiello, pitchers, from Nashville of the American Association to Birmingham of the Southern League. MILWAUKEE BREWERS -- Placed Cal Eldred, pitcher, on the 15-day disabled list. Recalled Ron Rightnowar, pitcher, from New Orleans of the American Association. Transferred Jeff Bronkey, pitcher, from the 15-day to the 60-day disabled list. National League NL -- Suspended Terry Pendleton, Atlanta Braves third baseman, for four games for bumping umpire Bill Hohn during Tuesday's game against the Philadelphia Phillies. HOUSTON ASTROS -- Placed Mike Hampton, pitcher, on the 15-day disabled list, retroactive to May 15. Purchased the contract of Mike Simms, outfielder, from Tucson of the Pacific Coast League. ST. LOUIS CARDINALS -- Agreed to terms Ray Lankford, outfielder, on a one-year contract. SAN FRANCISCO GIANTS -- Agreed to terms with Rod Beck, pitcher, on a one-year contract. Football National Football League CLEVELAND BROWNS -- Acquired Harold Bishop, tight end, from the Tampa Bay Buccaneers for an undisclosed draft choice. DALLAS COWBOYS -- Agreed to terms with John Jett, punter, on a one-year contract. GREEN BAY PACKERS -- Named Barry Rubin strength and conditioning assistant. NEW YORK JETS -- Signed Stevie Anderson, wide receiver, and Everett McIver, guard, to four-year contracts. SAN DIEGO CHARGERS -- Re-signed Deems Mays and Shannon Mitchell, tight ends. Canadian Football League BIRMINGHAM BARRACUDAS -- Signed Kippy Bayless, Kenny Brown and Mike Smith, running backs; Paul Duckworth and Anthony Shamburger, linebackers; Mark Bounds, Mike Panasuk and Scott Player punters; Mac Cody, wide receiver; Rodney Armston, guard; Sam Watson, defensive back, and David Gulledge, quarterback. EDMONTON ESKIMOS -- Signed Kerry Ferrell, slotback. Hockey National Hockey League N.H.L. -- Suspended Glenn Anderson, St. Louis Blues right wing, for one game and fined him $1,000 for high sticking Canucks defenseman Mark Wotton during Wednesday's game against Vancouver. ANAHEIM MIGHTY DUCKS -- Announced that Stephan Lebeau, center, has left the team to play with Lugano in Switzerland. BOSTON BRUINS -- Fired Tom McVie, assistant coach. Central Hockey League C.H.L. -- Announced that Omaha, Neb., will join the league for the 1996-97 season. College BIG WEST CONFERENCE -- Announced the suspension of its football consortium following the 1995 season. ARKANSAS STATE -- Announced the resignation of Grady Bean, men's assistant basketball coach. BRIGHAM YOUNG -- Expelled James Heggins, Greg Steele and James Humes, defensive backs; Horace Tisdale, wide receiver, and Tony Hicks, running back for disciplinary reasons.

title: Rubin Favors Shutting Street At White House
description: Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin has recommended that President Clinton accept the advice of outside security experts to bar vehicular traffic from Pennsylvania Avenue in front of the White House in an effort to lessen the threat of a car or truck bombing there, senior Administration officials said tonight.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the On Stage, and Off column in Weekend yesterday, about the closing of several shows, referred incorrectly to "All in the Timing" at the John Houseman Theater. It did not close "recently"; it is to close tonight.

title: Friend Ties McVeigh to Oklahoma City Bombing
description: An Army buddy of Timothy J. McVeigh has told Federal authorities that he and Mr. McVeigh inspected the Federal Building in Oklahoma City as a bombing target several days before the blast, law-enforcement officials said today.

title: Bullpen Aces Squander McDowell's Big Effort
description: The day started badly enough for Yankee Manager Buck Showalter when he learned Don Mattingly's troublesome right eye would make him unavailable for at least the opener of a three-game series with the Orioles. His mood would get worse about 12 hours later when the Yankees let a badly needed victory slip away by blowing a two-run lead in the ninth inning.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Writing a best seller about a deadly disease is one thing, but seeing its ravages up close is quite another. RICHARD PRESTON, whose book about the Ebola virus, "The Hot Zone" (Random House), has been on the New York Times best-seller list for 32 weeks, has no intention of going to Zaire, where the death toll from a new outbreak of the disease rises every day.

title: Article 748495 -- No Title
description: The Government reported today that it had its largest one-month budget surplus in history last month, reflecting record revenues and the annual flood of income tax payments from individuals close to the April 17 deadline.

title: Unisys Wins Contract
description: The Unisys Corporation was awarded a $520 million contract today to begin the process of replacing the Internal Revenue Service's mainframe computers. The Service Center Support System contract covers the I.R.S.'s three existing computing centers in Tennessee, West Virginia and Michigan. In addition to operating the three computer centers, Unisys will "maintain and operate all mainframe computers for the I.R.S., receive and process electronic records, and maintain I.R.S.'s databases," the I.R.S. said.

title: CHRONICLE
description: HARRY A. BLACKMUN, the former Supreme Court Justice, and LAURENCE H. TRIBE, the Tyler professor of constitutional law at Harvard Law School, have encountered each other many times in courtrooms, academic settings and meetings. "I argued more than 20 cases before him," Professor Tribe said yesterday, "and in 1986, for example, we were on a symposium on justice and constitutionalism in Rome."

title: China's Conscience
description: China's intellectuals are daring to speak out again for greater political freedoms. Two petitions delivered to the authorities in recent days represent the most significant public calls for democracy since tanks crushed the student protesters in Tiananmen Square six years ago.

title: H. Norton Stevens, 65, Executive And Investor in South America
description: H. Norton Stevens, a business executive and investor in Latin American enterprises, died on Wednesday in Washington. He was 65 and lived in Manhattan and Waccabuc, N.Y.

title: For Anglers, a Bass Bounty
description: Anglers can keep at least an extra 22 inches of striped bass each day, thanks to a bountiful supply of the fish in state waters. The state issued new rules allowing fishermen to keep two striped bass, over 28 inches each, rather than the previous limit of one striped bass over 34 inches.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about Iran's nuclear energy program included a scrambled passage in some copies. It should have read: "For the Americans, the reactors are an ominous sign of Iran's determination to build nuclear weapons within the next decade, and a threat to American national security. There is no evidence that this site, 730 miles south of Teheran, is a center for a weapons program, and inspectors from the International Atomic Energy Agency have never reported suspicious activity."

title: A Human Pianist And Her Disklavier
description: The delightful performance of "By the Waters of Minnetonka" at Weill Recital Hall on Thursday night was a reminder of how enticing the piano can be not just when it is played but also when it is at play, when it seems to be an instrument of pleasure, toying with the music it produces and being toyed with by its master. In this case, the pleasure came not just from the Indian melodies and flowing figuration of Thurlow Lieurance's period piece from the 1920's but also from the very sight of the piano.

title: Pledge to Seize Arms in Gaza Falls Short
description: An emblem of crossed rifles and a bold painting of an armed radical flank the entrance to a mosque in this sprawl of cinderblock dwellings and dirt roads north of Gaza City.

title: After Big Selloff, Market Enjoys A Quiet Session
description: After its biggest selloff of the year on Thursday, the stock market shrugged off the potential complications of "double witching" and cruised through a quiet day yesterday. The major stock indexes closed mixed but little changed in moderate trading.

title: Serenade for Music Shoppers; Buyers Flock to 2 Big Stores, 1 1/2 Blocks Apart, on West Side
description: The day its top competitor, Tower Records, opened a block and a half away, the HMV Record Store at Broadway and 72d Street gave away hot dogs, popcorn and balloons and held a huge sidewalk sale. A man who has had plastic surgery to make him look like Elvis beckoned customers inside. Disk jockeys distributed free concert tickets.

title: Senate Dismisses Clinton's Fiscal Plan
description: In a ritual as familiar and solemn as Groundhog Day, the Senate voted today, 99 to 0, to reject President Clinton's budget.

title: 20 Years for Providing a Gun
description: Tinesha James, a court employee who smuggled a .357 Magnum into the Essex County Courthouse and gave it to a suspect who used it to kill a police officer in 1993, was sentenced to 20 years in prison yesterday. After receiving the gun from Ms. James, Al-Damany Kamau shot a narcotics detective, John Sczyrek, before the officer could testify at his trial. Ms. James, 24, must serve a minimum of 6 2/3 years before she will be eligible for parole. Mr. Kamau, 26, is serving two life terms in prison.

title: Bill Broadens School Bus Policy
description: Local school boards can provide busing for students who live close to school, and charge parents for the service, under a bill signed yesterday by Gov. Christine Todd Whitman. Previously, elementary students had to live at least two miles from school and secondary students at least two and a half miles away.

title: SPECIAL EDUCATION NEEDS REVAMPING, PANEL CONCLUDES
description: An independent panel yesterday released a proposal that recommends dramatically restructuring New York City's special-education system. The plan would take thousands of children who are currently segregated in separate schools or classrooms and return them to regular classrooms, where they would receive extra help.

title: Article 335795 -- No Title
description: Perhaps Nicholas Leeson, the young trader accused of bringing down Barings P.L.C., should have known more about Jurgen Schneider.

title: Robert Riger, a Sports Artist and Photographer, Dies at 70
description: Robert Riger, a sports artist who became a celebrated sports photographer and an award-winning television producer, director and cinematographer, died yesterday in Huntington Beach, Calif. He was 70.

title: Clinton Urges N.R.A. to Donate Money It Raised to Kin of Police
description: President Clinton today called on the National Rifle Association to back up its apology for a fund-raising letter that referred to Government agents as thugs by donating the proceeds to families of police officers slain in the line of duty.

title: International Briefs; Smith Sees Profit Dip
description: The W. H. Smith Group said yesterday that it expected its annual pretax profit to fall 8 percent, to about $:115 million $181 million, short of analysts' expectations. Smith's shares tumbled 15 percent to their lowest level in three years. Smith, a retailer of books, newspapers, music and hardware, said sales at its stores had declined 1.3 percent in the 11 months through April, to $:840.7 million. Operating profit from the group's retailing unit is expected to fall 18 percent, to $:14 million.

title: Two Stock Exchanges Report Rises in Uncovered Short Sales
description: The short interest was equal to 1.4 percent of the shares listed on the exchange.

title: Honda Posts First Annual Earnings Increase in 6 Years
description: The Honda Motor Company said today that group net income in its latest fiscal year rose for the first time in six years, as higher sales in North America, Europe and Japan offset the effects of the strong yen.

title: Student Gets Marching Orders
description: A foreign exchange student from Mexico who hoped to join his classmates in the commencement procession at Monmouth Regional High School got his marching orders from a state administrative judge: Stay seated at the ceremony. The ruling backed the Board of Education's denial of a request by Victor Hugo Cavazos, 17, who completed all graduation requirements except for two American history courses that he doesn't need to get his diploma in Mexico.

title: A Balkan Milk Run: Trucking Through Mortars
description: Roy Finstad apologized for lighting yet another cigarette. "It's difficult to stop smoking in this work," he said. "I have to wait till I come back to Norway."

title: We Can't Ignore Magnetic Field Studies
description: To the Editor:

title: Saberhagen Exits Early As Shoulder Stiffens
description: Bret Saberhagen was the one who wasn't supposed to be tired, or sore, or stiff. He took a commercial flight here from Houston, arrived before midnight on Thursday and got a good night's rest.

title: Legal Limbo For Suspects In Fraud Case
description: Fourteen people charged with welfare fraud have been in jail for more than a week without a bail hearing or legal representation because of a series of legal missteps, Legal Aid lawyers said yesterday.

title: Business Digest
description: Market Regains Its Calm After Thursday's Tumble The stock market shrugged off the potential complications of "double witching" day and Thursday's 81.96 point loss to cruise through a quiet day. The Dow edged up 0.69 point, to 4,341.33, while the broader Standard & Poor's 500 fell 0.39 point, to 519.19.

title: Montreal Journal; Neighbors Live in Fear As Biker Gangs Rumble
description: The police had to deal with bombs twice recently at 2885 Gilford Street, the fortress-like hangout of the Rockers motorcycle gang, located across the street from a rail yard and abandoned repair shops in a mixed industrial and residential quarter of East Montreal.

title: The F.D.A.'s Fear of the Future
description: President Clinton likes to be seen as a duck hunter, and even referred to his avocation in the State of the Union Message. Now, he should take aim at a regulatory turkey that has been given wing by his Food and Drug Administration.

title: Bell Atlantic Pulling Out of Italian Joint Venture
description: The Bell Atlantic Corporation is abandoning an Italian joint venture with Stet S.p.A. after Stet, the state-controlled telecommunications company, formed another joint venture with I.B.M.

title: Observer; Inching Down Fifth
description: Thursday 5 P.M. Heavy rain falling all over New York. Millions of cars burning gas, honking, going nowhere. I am marooned in a Fifth Avenue bus. Feels like two weeks ago I got on up at 155th Street.

title: Scarsdale Bank Manager Held in Theft From an Elderly Woman
description: Long after the advent of computerized monthly statements and automated teller machines, Louise Fletcher, 86, clung to an old-fashioned way of banking. She still used passbooks, became friendly with the branch manager of her neighborhood bank and even trusted him to handle her financial affairs.

title: District Attorney Clears Officers In the Shooting of a Bystander
description: Police officers acted properly in the pursuit of a gunman that ended in his death and that of a bystander in Queens last December, the Queens District Attorney, Richard A. Brown, said yesterday. Facing a rain of bullets, the officers had no choice but to return fire, Mr. Brown said. A bystander, Lackharaj Dalipram, 31, of Mount Vernon, N.Y., was killed during the exchange.

title: Squalor and Alarm At Elite Virus Lab
description: The Federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, in the front line of the battle against the deadly Ebola outbreak in Zaire, is crippled by staff shortages and deteriorating facilities, experts say.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about a clash of cultures between the courts and scientists over possible health hazards from silicone breast implants misstated an area of expertise of Dr. Nir Kossovsky of the University of California at Los Angeles. He is an associate professor of pathology who studies biomaterials, not a materials scientist.

title: Religion Journal; American Muslims Seek A Better Understanding
description: By now, a month after the bombing of the Federal Building in Oklahoma City, many people may have forgotten the initial reaction to the crime, when some news reports and some politicians blamed unknown "foreign terrorists," probably from the Middle East.

title: CABOT OIL AND GAS OUSTS ITS TOP OFFICER
description: The Cabot Oil and Gas Corporation said yesterday that it had ousted its chairman and chief executive, John Lollar, who engineered an ill-timed acquisition that led to losses in the last year. Charles Siess Jr., who retired as chairman, president and chief executive at the end of 1992, will return to those posts. Cabot Oil stock closed up 37.5 cents, at $15.625, on the New York Stock Exchange. A company spokesman, Steven Tholen, said Mr. Lollar's resignation was not related solely to last year's $168.6 million acquisition of the Washington Energy Company, which made Cabot Oil one of the nation's largest independent oil and gas companies.

title: POTOMAC ELECTRIC TO QUIT AIRCRAFT LEASING
description: The Potomac Electric Power Company said yesterday that it would leave the aircraft leasing business and take a $110 million charge as a result. H. Lowell Davis, chief financial officer of Potomac Electric, said the company would sell all of the aircraft assets held by its Potomac Capital Investment Corporation subsidiary. The assets include 13 aircraft currently on no lease or short-term leases, which the company said it would sell in the next 18 to 24 months.

title: Miller's Fireworks Come Far Too Late
description: For three quarters the Pacers fans at Market Square Arena waited for Indiana guard Reggie Miller to emerge from the deep freeze and bring this Eastern Conference semifinal series with the Knicks to an end.

title: China Arrests Prodemocracy Petitioner
description: Faced with a series of passionate prodemocracy petitions, the Chinese authorities have arrested a prominent intellectual as he and 55 others were preparing to issue a call to commemorate the "souls of those who died wrongful deaths" six years ago near Tiananmen Square.

title: Adelman Joins Warriors
description: RICK ADELMAN, who guided the Portland Trail Blazers to the N.B.A. finals in 1990 and 1992, was named coach of the Golden State Warriors yesterday. DON NELSON was forced out as Warriors coach in February, midway through a 26-56 season, and BOB LANIER had been the interim coach. (AP)

title: Health Dept. Criticizes Treatment of Firefighter
description: Describing a "systemic failure" in the emergency treatment of a firefighter who collapsed at a Brooklyn blaze in March, state health officials said yesterday that no one took complete charge of medical care at the fire, that an overcrowded ambulance hampered treatment and that doctors at Woodhull Medical and Mental Health Center failed to correct a problem with the firefighter's oxygen tube.

title: Senior Clinton Aides Urging Full Relations With Vietnam
description: Senior Administration officials have recommended that the United States establish full diplomatic ties with Vietnam, Administration officials said today.

title: Thai Government Collapses In a Land-Reform Scandal
description: The Government of Chuan Leekpai, Thailand's longest-serving elected Prime Minister, collapsed today in the middle of a scandal over a Government land-reform program.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 2-5 A PUSH FOR TIES WITH VIETNAM For the first time, a number of senior Administration officials have been recommending that the United States establish full diplomatic relations with Vietnam. 1

title: We Can't Ignore Magnetic Field Studies; Ozone Connection?
description: To the Editor:

title: Science Fair Is a New York City Sign of Spring
description: To the Editor:

title: Airliners Bump at Newark
description: Two jets bumped into each other while waiting to take off from Newark International Airport last night, slightly damaging both airplanes but causing no injuries, officials said.

title: Simpson Prosecutors Give Their Scenario of Killings
description: Prosecutors in the O. J. Simpson case described today for the first time the graphic details of how they believe the two victims were killed, prompting a heated argument over whether photographs that defense lawyers termed "horrendous" and "sickening" should be shown to the jurors.

title: Trooper Sentenced In Obstruction Plea
description: A former New York State police investigator who pleaded guilty last month to obstructing an investigation of state police evidence tampering was sentenced yesterday in Delhi, N.Y., to one year in prison.

title: India's Leader Survives Political Challenge
description: After two years of plummeting political fortunes, simmering tensions within the governing Congress Party broke into open revolt today with a rally in the capital at which a dissident faction named a party leader to displace Prime Minister P. V. Narasimha Rao.

title: Michael P. W. Stone, 69, Army Secretary in Bush Administration
description: Michael P. W. Stone, whose tenure as Secretary of the Army was marked by a shrinking military, the debate over the role of women in combat and by the Persian Gulf war, died on Thursday at his home in San Francisco. He was 69.

title: INSIDE
description: No Indictment, for Now

title: Nets Re-examine Lease
description: The Nets, whose lease at Byrne Arena runs through the 2000-01 season, are considering their position as the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority attempts to keep the Devils at the Meadowlands. DAVID GERSTEIN, one of the team's owners, said yesterday that the Nets would be meeting with authority officials regarding their lease.

title: An Arrest in Restaurant Shooting
description: Dismissed from his job as a dishwasher and demanding $50 in back pay, Zoltan Zahonyi, 45, took a bus from New York and then a cab to return to the Rock Oak Lodge. There, the authorities say, he first confronted the owner of the mountaintop restaurant, but then the chef and manager, Anthony Jablonski, interceded and was shot in the chest. Mr. Jablonski was in critical condition yesterday. Mr. Zahonyi was charged with attempted murder.

title: ILLINOIS TOOL AGREES TO ACQUIRE HOBART BROTHERS
description: Illinois Tool Works Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Hobart Brothers Company, a maker of welding equipment and filler metals based in Troy, Ohio. No terms were disclosed. Hobart, which is closely held, has annual sales of nearly $300 million and about 2,000 workers. Illinois Tool, based in Glenview, Ill., a manufacturer of industrial assemblies and fasteners, had 1994 earnings of $277.9 million on $3.5 billion in sales. Its stock slipped 50 cents yesterday, to $50.50, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Sir Anthony Wagner, 86, Dies; Medievalist and Senior Herald
description: Sir Anthony Wagner, a scholar of medieval history and former head of the College of Arms, Britain's official arbiter of heraldry, died in London on May 8. He was 86.

title: The Developing World Needs Its Own Doctors
description: To the Editor:

title: Colombian Fighter Dies
description: Jimmy Garcia, the 23-year-old Colombian who reportedly starved himself so he could box for a world title, died early this morning from massive brain injuries sustained in a Las Vegas, Nev., ring 13 days ago.

title: Crop Prices Fall as Skies Clear
description: Crop prices fell yesterday as skies cleared in the Midwest, allowing farmers to catch up on their planting. Prices had risen this week as traders grew concerned that heavy rains might have delayed spring planting enough to reduce the size of this year's crop.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: POLICE RAMPAGE IS NOT THE FIRST The drunken rampage by several dozen New York City police officers attending a memorial service in Washington this week was hardly the first of its kind, reflected in the Police Department's issuing a stern directive earlier this month warning officers to behave themselves. Following closely on three major precinct corruption scandals, several patrol car crashes and a rash of officer suicides, the incident underscores serious problems with police training, supervision and recruitment, police officials privately said. Mayor Giuliani called on the Washington police to carry out a full criminal investigation of the episode. [ Page 1. ] PROPOSAL TO RESHAPE SPECIAL EDUCATION An independent panel released a plan that recommends reorganizing New York City's special education system by taking large numbers of children who are currently segregated in separate "special ed" schools or classrooms and returning them to regular classrooms, where they would receive extra help. The draft report, presented to Schools Chancellor Ramon C. Cortines, offers a blueprint for remaking a system that now consumes more than 22 cents of every education dollar in New York City, includes one-quarter of all school employees and funnels a disproportionate number of black and Hispanic boys into segregated classrooms. [ 1. ] NEW YORK CITY COURT BACKS HOLDING IMMIGRANTS Two days after a Federal court in Pennsylvania ruled the immigration service had wrongly held the passengers of a freighter, the Golden Venture, for nearly two years, an appellate court in Manhattan decided that the Government was within its rights not only to detain the smuggled immigrants, but also to deny them political asylum based on their opposition to China's policy of restricting families to one child. [ 27. ] SHOOTING BY OFFICERS CALLED JUSTIFIED Police officers acted properly during the pursuit of a gunman that ended in his death and that of a bystander in Rego Park, Queens, last December, the Queens District Attorney said. The incident was the result of a landlord-tenant dispute in which the gunman shot and killed a husband and wife who were planning to evict him from a room in their house. [ 27. ] POLICE MAY CONTROL SCHOOL GUARDS Reviving a campaign pledge to reduce school violence, Mayor Giuliani said he wants to put the system's 3,000 school safety officers under the control of the Police Department. He made his remarks after he learned of a report showing an increase in incidents of violence and other problems in the schools. [ 26. ] REGION A TAKEOVER NEARS IN NEWARK New Jersey's Commissioner of Education said the state might start taking over the long-troubled Newark school system as early as July. The Commissioner said the main reason was the poor test results of Newark students, even after a decade of state monitoring. He noted that only one-quarter of high school seniors in one recent year had passed the tests required to graduate. [ 28. ] The lawyers for a former high school wrestling star from Darien, Conn., who has been accused of rape, want his trial moved because of publicity. [ 28. ] Traffic Alert 26 Chronicle 28

title: No Headline
description: "For the sake of America, maybe it's time we ended the war." -- SENATOR JOHN MCCAIN, who favors full ties with Vietnam. [ 4:3. ]

title: Whitewater Counsel Won't Seek to Indict Top Clinton Aide Before Deadline
description: The Whitewater independent counsel has decided not to seek an indictment against President Clinton's most trusted aide, Bruce Lindsey, before a deadline next week on Federal banking charges.

title: Sports of The Times; 'Wild Bunch' Looks to Its Wild Leader
description: WHEN it was over, when the Knicks were safely on their way back to New York for another seventh game against the Indiana Pacers, Patrick Ewing grabbed his nearest teammate, who happened to be Anthony Mason. Ewing hugged the most volatile Knick, then patted him hard on the rear, which was somewhat different from their encounter during a most tumultuous halftime.

title: Arab Leaders Seek Summit Meeting Over Jerusalem Seizures
description: Israel's confiscation of Arab land in Jerusalem has galvanized Arab kings and presidents to begin planning a rare summit meeting that may be held in the next two weeks.

title: Bad School Choices for Connecticut
description: In a state where the de facto segregation of public schools has been a divisive and highly emotional subject, Gov. John Rowland has displayed appalling insensitivity in his nominees for Connecticut's State Board of Education. Last week one of his choices was forced to withdraw. Kay Wall, a Greenwich conservative who helped sink a forward-looking education reform package last year, was widely seen as a divisive figure with little concern for the problems of city schoolchildren.

title: AIDS Walk New York
description: The 10th annual AIDS Walk New York, to raise money for Gay Men's Health Crisis, will begin at 10 A.M. tomorrow in Central Park. Registration for the 10-kilometer walk is at 8:30 A.M. on the Great Lawn. Donors pledge either a flat sum or by the distance covered by the walker. An opening ceremony at 9:15 A.M. will feature appearances by the actors Tony Randall, Rosie Perez and Michel Bell and Dr. Joycelyn Elders, the former Surgeon General. The walk begins at 10 A.M. at the Great Lawn, which is near entrances on the West Side at 85th and 81st Streets and on the East Side at 79th or 84th Streets. Registration or other information: (212)807-9255.

title: Crops Tailor-Made for Profit; Farmers Alter Their Way of Life to Assure Sales
description: When he was growing up, Mike Olk helped his father farm. He, too, became a farmer, and like most Midwest farmers he grew as much yellow feed corn or soybeans as possible. Some of the grain was fed to his own animals and the rest was sold to local elevators.

title: Wayne LaPierre, on the Ropes
description: It was almost too delicious watching Wayne LaPierre weasel-wording his way through "Larry King Live" the other night. The once-sleek demagogue-in-chief of the National Rifle Association did not look at all well. Probably it is the wear and tear of being the author of a full-scale public relations disaster.

title: Blair C. Hopkins, Edouard Dejoux
description: Blair Christine Hopkins, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert W. Hopkins 2d of Princeton, N.J. and Gulfstream, Fla., was married yesterday to Edouard Henri Grace Dejoux, a son of Mrs. William H. Brinckerhoff of Locust Valley, L.I., and Jacques H. title: Crisis in India: Leader Survives, for Now
description: On the night of May 21, 1991, P. V. Narasimha Rao was at his home in New Delhi packing for retirement in his native state of Andhra Pradesh when word came that Rajiv Gandhi, the former Prime Minister, had been assassinated on an election trip in southern India.

description: Mary Ann Elizabeth Hester, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard S. Hester Sr. of Newark, was married yesterday to Brendan Michael Gaffney, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Gaffney of Ballyfarnon, Ireland. The Rev. Felix Marciniak performed the ceremony at Our Lady of Good Counsel Roman Catholic Church in Newark.

title: In Old Lyme, a Museum That's More Than Impressionists
description: GHOSTS seem to resonate at the Florence Griswold Museum, once a boardinghouse that was the heart of a colony of American Impressionists in Old Lyme between 1899 and 1937.

title: TEACHING JOHNNY TO BE GOOD
description: Charles Pyle's illustrations for your article were brilliant. Dick and Jane revisited! Those clean-cut, all-American kids were around in the 1930's when I attended St. Anthony's Parochial School in Atlanta. I was taught so many "moral values," along with the 3 R's, that it's taken me over 60 years to sort out the good from the bad. There's no question in my mind that the most enduring "character education" lessons were taught me at home by kind and decent parents. MARY LU WALKER Corning, N.Y.

description: Elizabeth Velazquez, a daughter of Lil Ninoshka Palau of Kona, Hawaii, and Raymond Velazquez of Milford, Conn., was married yesterday to Alexander Bernstein, the son of the late Felicia Montealegre Bernstein and Leonard Bernstein, the composer and conductor. title: Debating Education For Expelled Students
description: SINCE 1981 state legislators have gradually limited requirements that public high schools offer all expelled students an alternative education, typically off campus or after-school tutorials. Educators say such programs often keep troubled students from dropping out or being expelled again, but the programs tend to cost 10 to 60 percent more than districts spend on students who are not expelled.

title: A Shaggy Dog Story With a Cast That's Altogether Human
description: IN "SYLVIA," WHICH OPENS ON Tuesday at the Manhattan Theater Club, A. R. Gurney has a new twist on romantic obsession. His hero's object of desire is a dog, not a well-proportioned young blonde. His twist again is that the dog is played, sans dog costume, by a well-proportioned young blonde.

title: Court Revisits The Last Days Of Doris Duke
