title: Black Politics, White Guilt
description: ONE BY ONE FROM THE INSIDE OUT Essays and Reviews on Raceand Responsibility in America.By Glenn C. Loury.332 pp. New York: The Free Press. $25.

title: Mine's O.K., Yours Isn't
description: IT'S A SUNDAY, about 10 minutes past 1. I've made an early start and am standing inside a turn-of-the-century colonial with a handsome front porch owned by people I don't know, won't see or probably ever meet. I'm examining their vestibule.

title:
CUTTINGS;
The Best Shelling Beans Are the Ones You Grow
description: Hardly a vegetable garden grows that does not contain snap beans, the likes of Kentucky Wonder, Blue Lake or Goldkist Yellow Wax.

title: Tighter Rules Proposed On Ferry Transport
description: Far more than in the United States, ferries are a common means of transportation in Europe. So it was not surprising that the sinking of the ferry Estonia in the Baltic Sea last fall, with the loss of more than 900 lives, sent shudders of fear across the Continent and the islands arrayed around it.

title: It's Technology To the Rescue, So Coast Guard Closes Stations
description: On a wall inside the Shark River Coast Guard station are postcards depicting scenes from a hundred years ago: a lighthouse casting its beam in search of lost boats, a group of men rushing to a rescue in a rowboat.

title: POSTINGS: The Merchants Club Sold for About $1.25 Million; Detective Group Collars a Clubhouse as HQ
description: The grand staircase of the Merchants Club building, at Thomas Street and Trimble Place in Lower Manhattan, was designed to provide "remarkable ease of ascension for the nonathletic gentry." At least that's what Richard L. Bonsal, the club's final president, recalls. Mr. Bonsal said that the staircase was modeled on that of the St. Regis Hotel when the club was designed by a member, Leavelle McCampbell, in 1941.

title: Winning Converts For Linear Parks
description: WHEN the Farmington Canal Trail opened a few years ago, Jane and Wesley Harper of Cheshire, who live near the trail, had some doubts. They liked the old path the way it was and wondered about the consequences of developing the trail, which runs from Cheshire to Hamden. Experience has turned them into fans.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption last Sunday with an article about the rebirth of North Jersey's urban rivers misidentified the river shown in a photograph of a cleanup crew. It was the Second River, not the Saddle.

title: They're Movies, Not Schoolbooks
description: WHETHER THE SUBJECT IS THE Black Panther Party or quiz shows, Thomas Jefferson's sex life or Dorothy Parker's accent, there is one reaction moviegoers can expect when a historical film appears: the scolding, finger-wagging "tut-tut" response. As in, "Tut-tut-tut, Robert Redford changed the facts." Or, "Tut-tut-tut, Mario Van Peebles left facts out."

title: Children at Work
description: Using photographs to engage the mainstream of society in the plight of those who live at the margins was a new concept when Lewis Hine was commissioned by the National Child Labor Committee to photograph children at work in the early part of the century. Hine photographed children shucking oysters, picking beans, making cigars and working in the mines; his work is credited with influencing the passage of child labor laws. Dorothea Lange and Walker Evans continued this tradition of socially concerned photography. Nancy Buirski, a picture editor at The New York Times, has claimed this lineage for her photographs in EARTH ANGELS: Migrant Children in America (Pomegranate Artbooks, cloth, $35; paper, $24.95). Although migrant families now have access to many social services, they still do not sit at the tables they serve. Ms. Buirski photographed migrant workers in five states: New York, Texas, Florida, Washington and California. Her color images depict children weeding, hoeing, playing, sleeping, splendid in party clothes. Their housing is crowded and grubby, but Ms. Buirski conveys their joy and mischief as well as their fatigue and uncertainty. Her aim is to capture the children's spirit in the face of adversity, but she lacks the rigorous vision of earlier documentary photographers. ROSEMARY RANCK

title: CITIES: Changing the Colors of Rome
description: Rome's alleys and piazzas are often savored for their warm earth tones -- ocher, terra cotta, burnt sienna. The real colors, architectural historians have found, were much cooler. By studying early cityscapes and paint chips from buildings, they find that when much of the current city was built, in the 16th and 17th centuries, the dominant colors were off-whites, icy blues, pale yellows, pinks and grays. In the 19th century, the Piedmontese, who unified Italy, repainted many buildings a yellow ocher. In the 20th century, the Fascist dictator Benito Mussolini favored earth tones. The time is right, the historians say, to change back, and the most striking example of restoration is probably Villa Medici on the Pincio, which now houses the French Academy. Last year, restorers returned the graceful balustraded garden terraces (shown above, before and after) to their original 16th-century eggshell tones. The restorers were ready then to start on the villa itself. But many Romans detest the restored pastels for robbing the city of warmth. An expert commission, appointed to decide on the villa's color, is still talking. A decision is hoped for by November.

ART;
Images Quite Alike, Yet Quite Unalike
description: Marcia Gygli King/Robert Rahway Zakanitch Guild Hall Museum, 158 Main St., East Hampton. To June 11. 324-0806.

An outdoor cocktail reception begins at 6 P.M. on the Lincoln Center plaza with music by a Dixieland band. The concert, at 7:30, will also feature performances by the pianist Emanuel Ax, the soprano Harolyn Blackwell and others. Dinner will follow at 8 P.M. at T, the tea salon in the museum. Tickets, $250, or $75 for the reception and preview only, from (212) 423-3561. Cocktails will be served at 6:30. Tickets, $500, from (212) 935-1840. For the Y.M.C.A. JUNE 1 -- Barbara Walters will be the master of ceremonies at a black-tie dinner-dance at the Waldorf-Astoria to benefit the Y.M.C.A. of Greater New York. title: Fine Digs Pulled Out From Under Rug Merchants
description: For nearly a decade the biggest destination for rugs from the old Silk Road has been 601 West 54th Street, an eight-story building whose top half is occupied by the New York Antique Oriental Rug Center. Inside, 65 wholesalers stock thousands of rugs with a total estimated worth of $250 million. Rug experts call it the largest concentration of dealers in one site anywhere in the world.

title: For Home Buyers, Patience Has Paid Off
description: INTEREST rates are falling. Interest rates are falling. It's a mantra being intoned by almost every real estate broker, mortgage banker and potential home buyer these days. And unlike other industry slogans -- like "now is a good time to buy" or "prices are rising" -- this one is unarguable, at least for now.

Benson of Washington and Mr. White of McLean, Va. The Rev. Spencer M. Rice officiated at St. Columba's Episcopal Church. The Rev. Henry Werner, a Roman Catholic priest, took part in the ceremony.

title: INDIGNITIES: The Invisible Diner
description: Lawrence Otis Graham is a Princeton and Harvard graduate, a corporate lawyer, an African-American and a new sort of restaurant reviewer.

title: Playing the Blame Game in Miami
description: The Miami athletic director, PAUL DEE, placed most of the blame for the school's failed drug policy on a former coach, DENNIS ERICKSON. Meeting with school trustees, Dee and Miami's president, EDWARD FOOTE, accepted some blame for the policy, which allowed athletes to play despite testing positive for drugs. (AP)

title: Renee Sands, William Sterling
description: Renee Ledoux Sands, the daughter of Bettina P. Murray of New York and the late Richard J. Sands, was married yesterday to William Lee Sterling, a son of Deborah P. Sterling of Greenwich, Conn., and Robert Lee Sterling Jr. of New York. The Rev. Dr. Mark Anschutz performed the ceremony at St. James' Episcopal Church in New York.

title: THE UNABOMBER AND DAVID GELERTNER
description: David Gelernter's second communication from the Unabomber killer arrived last month. Like the first, it came in the morning mail addressed to him at the Arthur K. Watson computer sciences building at Yale University. It found the 40-year-old professor of computer science at an interesting time in his career. Gelernter has been consistently, almost arrogantly, extending the breadth of his writings beyond the technical, veering toward sociology, psychology, even Biblical studies. He is bracing now for the reaction to his latest book, "1939," a study of that year's New York World's Fair, to be published next month. Gelernter thinks that event was important in part because it embodied what was then an overwhelmingly optimistic view of technology and the future. "In 1939," he writes, "technology was not remote and esoteric . . . its achievements were heroic." In contrast, Gelernter believes, it is now common to consider technology as an enemy.

title: If the Hair Is Gray, Con Artists See Green
description: BETTY NORMAN was no match for the telephone con men who emptied her pockets of more than $40,000.

title: Over the Years, Steaming Here and There
description: I KNEW nothing about thermal water until 1980, when the man who is now my husband decided that a bicycle trip behind the Iron Curtain would be adventurous. Our previous cycling holidays in Western Europe had been rich in sporting, cultural and culinary pleasures. We naively anticipated nothing less, spiced by the novelties of the less-beaten path.

title: Foreign Affairs; Japan, a Frog and a Pail
description: After the U.S. imposed trade sanctions on Japan last week, I found myself thinking back to that old science class experiment where the teacher puts a frog in a pail of water on the stove and gradually turns up the heat. The frog, which is very good at adapting, adjusts to each new level of heat. Eventually, though, the frog boils to death, because it is so good at adapting it never thinks to jump out of the pail.

title: Networking
description: THE KING OF CASH The Inside Story of Laurence Tisch. By Christopher Winans. Illustrated. 288 pp. New York: John Wiley & Sons.

title: For a Young Boxer, the Ring Is a Stage
description: DAMON HARRIS of New Haven is a boxer with a strong, supportive family and a coach who hates to lose.

title: Editorial Notebook; Epitaph for an Ambassador
description: The death last week of Harry Bergold, the American Ambassador to Nicaragua from 1984 to 1987, may have marked a curious milestone in the remembrance of a diplomat. The exceptional accomplishment of his career, according to The Times's obituary, was sharing information with reporters.

title: Sports of The Times; What If Eric Lindros Played for Rangers?
description: HISTORY turns at the forks in its road. But with different people and different circumstances at those forks, history would be different.

title: Grotesquerie in a Box
description: SPEAKER NEWT Gingrich is all wrapped up in boxes. Metaphorically, every day is Boxing Day to Newt. (In Britain, the first weekday after Christmas is called Boxing Day, after the tradition of giving boxes of gifts to servants and public employees.)

title: Centers for the Aged Elude Moratorium
description: WHILE Gov. George E. Pataki has floated a proposal to impose a moratorium on new construction of nursing homes in the state to help reduce health-care spending, it appears that as many as three new multi-million-dollar elder-care centers in Westchester are unaffected by the measure.

title: Pippen Accused of Pushing His Fiancee
description: SCOTTIE PIPPEN, the Chicago Bulls' All-Star forward, was charged with battery after his fiancee accused him of grabbing her and pushing her at his home, the police said yesterday. A domestic disturbance was reported at Pippen's home at 8:15 P.M. Friday, a night after the Bulls were eliminated from the National Basketball Association playoffs. Pippen's fiancee, YVETTE DELEONE, said he grabbed her by an arm and pushed her against a vehicle, the police said. Pippen was charged with simple battery, a misdemeanor, and released on $100 bond. (AP)

title: Robert B. Meyer, 74, Smithsonian Curator
description: Robert B. Meyer Jr., a former curator of aero propulsion at the Smithsonian Institution's National Air and Space Museum in Washington and a longtime director of his family's Cord Meyer Development Company in Forest Hills, Queens, died on Wednesday at his home in Potomac, Md. He was 74.

title: Time to Trellis, Mulch and Make Notes
description: Make a sturdy trellis for tomatoes or beans out of locust or cedar branches. Such rustic structures can add to the beautiful idiosyncrasy of your garden.

title: The World; Killed in Chechnya: An Army's Pride
description: EVERY city has its special tourist attractions, even this one. Most days Russian soldiers eager for the essential souvenir from this shattered region make their way to the charred wreck of the Presidential Palace.

title: Japan's Low Crime Rate Offers Us No Lessons
description: To the Editor:

title: Pacers Don't Have Time for Could Have-Should Have
description: For Pacers forward Antonio Davis, nothing has changed in his thinking since Indiana took a 3-1 lead in the four-of-seven-game National Basketball Association playoff series against the Knicks.

title: May 14-20: Cause for Reassurance; Japan Arrests Leader Of Doomsday Cult In Subway Gas Attack
description: Fearful Japanese citizens found some reason to take reassurance last week from the arrest of a guru, Shoko Asahara, and his top aides on murder charges that stem from the nerve gas attack on the Tokyo subway system that killed 12 people and injured 5,500 on March 20. Mr. Asahara, who leads the sect known as Aum Shinrikyo, was found meditating Tuesday in a coffin-sized secret chamber in the headquarters of the group, and the police said they had established the names of at least 41 Aum members who were involved in the subway attack.

title: Get Smart
description: OUTSMARTING IQ The Emerging Science of Learnable Intelligence. By David Perkins. 390 pp. New York: The Free Press. $23.

title:
TELEVISION VIEW;
An Emptiness in the Late-Night Laughter
description: IT HAS BEEN A YEAR SINCE AR-senio Hall's late-night show went off the air, and even viewers who had stopped watching religiously now miss him. In the much-hyped late-night wars between David Letterman, Jay Leno and Mr. Hall, it was Mr. Hall who made the game interesting, and not only because he was the first African-American to be the host of such a show.

title: Medicare Talk Brings Anxiety To Heartland
description: To Mike Brown, who runs a tiny county health care center about an hour's drive from here, the $250 billion or so in Medicare savings that Congressional Republicans want to achieve over the next seven years is more than an abstract figure in a Washington budget battle.

title:
SOAPBOX;
The Bicycle Thief
description: As I stepped up to the counter at the St. Marks Bookstore on Third Avenue, a copy of Henry Louis Gates Jr.'s autobiography in hand, I glanced through the glass doors to make sure my bicycle was still out there. It was not. I dropped the book and rushed out into a night full of Saturday crowds but empty of my bike.

title: Lifting the Ceiling On French Phone Rates
description: Budget-minded travelers seeking hotel accommodations in France should ask not only the price of a room but also how much the hotel charges "per pulse" for phone calls made in the room, or at pay phones on the hotel's premises. A pulse is the time period used to measure the cost of a call.

title: Where Wall Street's At
description: The last discussed thing about Wall Street during the highflying 80's was how little that mattered actually happened on Wall Street. In the three years I claimed to work there I visited the place only once. My employer, Salomon Brothers, required all new recruits to spend a full day on the New York Stock Exchange. That day four of us trooped from the southern tip of Manhattan to the stone fortress on the corner of Wall and Broad with an indifference that called to mind a middle-school field trip to a Civil War museum, except there was no one to punish you when you shoved your bubble gum down the musket barrel. After a brief tour -- "there is where they put the bomb; here is where they put the TV cameras" -- our ancient guide, who handled Salomon's business on the Exchange, let slip what we all suspected: he made no real money. No one he knew on Wall Street made real money -- at least not compared with the average Salomon bond trader. All at once eight eyes sought the nearest exit. And a few minutes later, with what I took to be touching generosity but now see as an understandable desire to be rid of us, our guide left us in a local bar with an open tab and a few hours to kill. We drank the time dry, then stumbled off Wall Street and back south, into the drama of the 80's.

title: DIARY
description: BANKRUPTCIES Implant Mess: What Is Real? Dow Corning filed for bankruptcy protection last week, swamped by lawsuits over breast implants. But the odd thing about this multibillion-dollar mess is that there is considerable doubt about whether the implants are actually harmful. Scientific doubt, that is. The legal system seems convinced that implants cause a variety of maladies, but a number of scientific studies balk at that -- finding that the diseases are real, but the cause not established. The bankruptcy is real, though, halting all new lawsuits and delaying settlement of existing ones -- for at least two years and probably longer. And the company's owners, Dow Chemical and Corning, will no doubt see their investments go to women's claims. TOBACCO Smoke, but Fire Next Year That huge class-action suit against the tobacco companies will have to wait. A big group of lawyers in New Orleans was going full speed ahead in its attempt to show, among other things, that cigarette makers concealed knowledge that nicotine is addictive. And they had plans to notify -- through nationwide ads -- up to 90 million smokers that they were part of the class. But last week the judge allowed an appeal now -- on whether the class should be certified. The bad news for the lawyers is that this means a delay of six months to a year -- just when they had their engines running. But one lawyer saw a silver lining -- that they could get the certification question cleared up now, before spending vast sums on the case. PUBLISHING Words, Words, Words for Sale The Encyclopaedia Britannica was first published in 1768, before the existence of the United States -- or, yes, even Microsoft -- and is still going. But not surprisingly -- at a time when many homes have more computers than books -- sales are dropping, from 117,000 sets in 1990 to 51,000 last year. Then again, look at it this way: even in the age of the CD-ROM, fully 51,000 people and libraries shelled out $1,500 for the 32 volumes of this ultimate reference work. But that's not enough, and Britannica is losing money -- and last week its owner, a private trust called the William Benton Foundation, put it up for sale. And as befits the age, the potential buyers included not just publishers like Simon & Schuster but, you guessed it, Microsoft. TRADE WARS Tyrannosaurus Lexus? A world without Lexuses (Lexi?) would be a sorry place indeed. Some people would probably have to settle for lapel buttons saying, "I'm so loaded I could spend $50,000 for a mere car." But just such a world loomed as a possibility last week as the Administration, making its move in some convoluted political game, plunked a 100 percent tariff on Japan's luxury cars. It's effective for cars arriving now, but won't be applied till late June -- allowing time for a settlement, or for this saber-rattling to pass. But if it sticks, that'll be it for new Lexuses, Infinitis and the like -- $30,000 to $50,000 is one thing, but $50,000 to $80,000? To the Mercedes dealer, Jeeves. And those of you scooping up "bargain" Lexuses now may find dealers few and far between. BANKING Musical Bank Chairs Anyone inclined to brand loyalty must have a hard time when it comes to banks. These days, the "venerable" banks are the ones that haven't changed their name or ownership in, say, five years. Until 1988, Bowery Savings was a New York fixture, but then it was bought by H.F. Ahmanson, its branches turned into Home Savings offices. But then last week Greenpoint bought 60 Home Savings outlets -- mostly old Bowery branches. It paid dearly -- $660 million -- but Greenpoint used to be a mutual savings bank, and after going public it had a lot of money to spend. Now it has spent it -- and old Bowery customers face a new identity crisis. AUTOS Chrysler Can Spare a Dime Chrysler tossed Kirk Kerkorian a bone last week, raising its dividend from 40 cents to 50 at its annual meeting -- after saying in December that there would be no increases this year. Not that it was admitting being swayed by Mr. Kerkorian's effort to buy the company, and his push for a far bigger dividend increase. "That was not the dominant issue at all," said Robert Eaton, the chairman. Now, Mr. Eaton said, he simply hoped the "disruptive force" of Mr. Kerkorian's nudging just "goes away." And Chrysler's tough stance seems to have worked, for no other big shareholders rallied to Mr. Kerkorian's cause, apparently a vote of confidence in Chrysler's cautious long-term plan. And the stock has settled at around $42, above the $39 before the bid but well below the $55 Mr. Kerkorian offered. STOCK MARKET Dow Drops 82; Life Goes On So why did the Dow industrials plunge 82 points on Thursday, the year's biggest drop? You could trot out the usual suspects -- trade deficits, bond prices, an economy too strong or too weak (pick one). Or you could just look at the numbers: the Dow had risen 750 since November, traders with a fear of heights were glancing warily about to see who'd jump first, and on Thursday some jumped. And remember: 82 points ain't what it used to be. In the days of an 800 Dow, that would have been a scary 10 percent. At today's lofty levels, this drop doesn't even weigh in at 2 percent. So there's a good chance the world is not coming to an end. CONGRESS Tame the Deficit or Bust Balancing the budget has become almost a religious crusade for Republicans, with the House last week charging ahead and voting a specific plan to break even by 2002. Specific, that is, except for things like how they'll save $280 billion on Medicare. If the Senate passes its own cuts this week, they'll have to work out the differences -- mainly that $350 billion House tax cut. But then comes a likely veto -- the House vote, 238 to 193, is not veto-proof. . . . Senate budget-cutters, meanwhile, want to do away with taxpayer-financed elections, which were created as a post-Watergate reform, saying Government should stay out of politics. What did the Democrats think? It would create an "obscene race for dollars," said Senator Christopher Dodd. FUGITIVES How to Steal a Billion It's hard to steal billions of dollars -- because, well, most people don't leave billions of dollars lying around waiting to be stolen. But a German developer named Jurgen Schneider is accused of doing just that -- a year ago, his vast real estate empire collapsed and he disappeared, leaving $5 billion in debts. And last week -- after continuing reports that put him in places like Switzerland and Iran -- he was arrested in Hollywood, Fla., trying hard to look like your basic retiree. Does he have something stashed away? Who knows. But the real question is, How could German banks have let this happen? They may be asked that more often now that Mr. Schneider's dream vacation is over. HOLLYWOOD All Eyes on Mr. Ovitz One thing is certain: Michael Ovitz will continue to call a lot of shots in Hollywood. The only question: where he'll be sitting. There was talk last week that he might leave the Creative Artists Agency, which practically owns Hollywood, to head MCA, which Seagram just bought. But the math gets tricky: Creative Artists could be worth $400 million now, and Mr. Ovitz probably owns half of it, but if he leaves and takes some top agents with him, it'll look a lot less valuable. In short, he's an awfully valuable man, so one wonders whether Seagram -- and its shareholders -- are ready to pay what it will take to get him.

title: THE UNABOMBER AND DAVID GELERTNER
description: David Gelernter's second communication from the Unabomber killer arrived last month. Like the first, it came in the morning mail addressed to him at the Arthur K. Watson computer sciences building at Yale University. It found the 40-year-old professor of computer science at an interesting time in his career. Gelernter has been consistently, almost arrogantly, extending the breadth of his writings beyond the technical, veering toward sociology, psychology, even Biblical studies. He is bracing now for the reaction to his latest book, "1939," a study of that year's New York World's Fair, to be published next month. Gelernter thinks that event was important in part because it embodied what was then an overwhelmingly optimistic view of technology and the future. "In 1939," he writes, "technology was not remote and esoteric . . . its achievements were heroic." In contrast, Gelernter believes, it is now common to consider technology as an enemy.

title:
THING;
Ostriches Are Good For: a) hats b) shoes c) fillets
description: WHAT: Ostrich meat, the plat du jour for those in search of exotic foods. Although the flightless birds have been raised in South Africa since the mid-1800's (first for feathers and, more recently, leather), it is only within the last 15 years that ostrich meat has come to be considered a delicacy.DOES THAT COME WITH A SALAD? Ostrich meat currently commands high prices. Ostrich Vision, a wholesaler in Roslyn, L.I., sells ostrich meat for $22 a pound. This price has limited ostrich to high-end restaurants. The Mansion on Turtle Creek in Dallas serves "Pan Roasted Ostrich Fillet" for $40, while David Waltuck, the executive chef at Chanterelle in New York, includes ostrich as part of his $68 prix-fixe dinner. The Assembly, a steakhouse in Rockefeller Center, recently added ostrich to its menu. Other local chefs who serve ostrich are Daniel Van Etten at Girasole, Nicholas Rabalais at Adrienne and Todd Jacobs at Terra Mar in Westhampton, L.I.OSTRICH CONVENTION: Last Monday, the New York chapter of the American Culinary Federation held an ostrich dinner at the Peninsula Hotel prepared by Randall Warder, the chef de cuisine at the Mansion on Turtle Creek. More than 100 chefs attended. Does this mean that ostrich will become a staple in local restaurants? Gray Kunz, the chef at Lespinasse, says maybe. "Five years ago, people wouldn't touch rabbit or venison, but now every chef in the city has these animals on their menu," he said. "I think it could be the same with ostrich. It tastes fantastic. We just have to change the customer's mind-set."LEAN CUISINE: Although ostrich meat has a color, texture and taste similar to that of beef, it is considerably leaner, prompting advocates to label it "the healthy red meat." According to the United States Department of Agriculture, a 3.5-ounce serving of broiled ostrich has 127 calories, 2.7 grams fat, 77 milligrams cholesterol and 26 grams protein, while an identical portion of broiled beef tenderloin has 229 calories, 12.49 grams fat, 85 milligrams cholesterol and 27 grams protein.RED OR WHITE WITH OSTRICH? "This meat tastes like a cross between beef and lamb," said Tim Wilson, the wine buyer for Le Madri and Mad. 61. "It's screaming for red wine. A white wouldn't stand up to this. You need a robust Burgundy like a Cote de Nuits or a Chianti Classico or even a Rhone, perhaps a Crozes-Hermitage."STOCKS, BONDS AND OSTRICH BELLIES: A fertilized ostrich egg sells for about $850, a yearling pair can cost up to $14,000 and two mature breeding birds may go for $40,000, according to Ostrich Vision.SPARKS OSTRICH HOUSE? Some agricultural experts predict that ostrich may one day have a place at the American table. But Pat Cetta, a co-owner of Sparks Steak House, refuses to jump on the ostrich bandwagon. "I remember when everyone thought buffalo was going to replace beef," he said. "I suspect ostrich is the same kind of thing. Bottom line: people will still eat steak. It's like sex, you have to have it once in a while."RENE CHUN

title:
HERS;
When He Was Good
description: In the room I share with my sister, my bed is closest to the door -- a curse. I am always the first to hear my mother's muffled screams, the scuffling and rushing down the hallway -- closer. My mother jumps into my bed, pleading for my father to stop. He lunges for her, over me, and as he pulls her out of my bed she latches onto me. I pull away terrified, then ashamed; I feel like a coward. My sister is awake now. Sitting up in bed, she cries for me to do something. My mother cringes on the floor. I jump out of bed, drop down over her, yelling stopitstopitstopit. He is reaching around me, but suddenly I feel his hand at my throat, his fingers gripping.

description: It is a tale all too familiar to co-op hunters and agents: What one co-op board demands from applicants may be totally different from what another requires.

title: Yosemite Campsite Delays Opening
description: Camping at Tuolomne Meadows, one of Yosemite National Park's High Sierra campgrounds, will be delayed this summer because of a thick spring snowpack and construction on sewer lines. The meadow is the area's second most popular destination after Yosemite Valley.

title: Solo Actors Can Stretch So Far They Touch Us
description: SCIENTISTS CALL IT "KIN- esthetic-visual matching"; we call it mimicry and imitation. They say that when we engage in it we learn empathy for others. We know that when we watch it -- watch an actor alone on a stage that advertises its own bareness, for instance, watch him reshape his face, voice and body to become 5, 10 or 15 other people -- we experience acute pleasure and wonder.

title: Setting a New Pace In Black and White
description: The somber all-black style of dress popular for the last few years and a cornerstone of fashion's deconstruction shows signs of losing its grip, with spring suit jackets that introduce chalk white and set in motion the first step in the reconstruction of a new fashion look. Elizabeth Tilberis, the editor in chief of Harper's Bazaar (in five pictures left and below) was observed over the last two months wearing exclusively black and white Chanel ready-to-wear jackets, always with black knee-length skirts, stockings and shoes. Her low-key style suggests a starting point for women who are turned off by fashion extremes. The Tilberis style stripped of jewelry gets right to the essential ingredient, the cut and fit of a jacket as the best investment. The white and black trimmed jacket (far left top) worn under a beige rain parka doubled as a dinner jacket (below) with the refined addition of a string of pearls in the form of a belt from the Chanel couture. Other women this spring (right and below right) have followed a similar path of mixing black and white in their trim spring jackets.

title:
CHILDREN'S BOOKS;
Better Than and Nobel Prize: The Newberry Sells Books
description: ON June 25, Sharon Creech will stand before an audience of more than a thousand people in the banquet hall of a Chicago hotel to thank a committee of the American Library Association for selecting her novel "Walk Two Moons" as the year's most distinguished contribution to American literature for children. In 1933, at a banquet in a different Chicago hotel, Elizabeth Foreman Lewis, an early winner, thanked a similar audience for bestowing the same honor on her novel "Young Fu of the Upper Yangtze."

title: Young Chess Players Star for Greenburgh
description: IN the Greenburgh public schools, young chess players "are revered and honored as much as sports heroes."

description: Jodi Meryl Katz, a daughter of Frances Katz of New York and the late George Katz, was married last evening to Gordon Tobias Platt, a son of Herbert and Roberta Platt, also of New York. Rabbi Jerome K. Davidson performed the ceremony at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden.

title: Sprawling Trattoria Draws Bargain Hunters
description: RESTAURANTS can energize the area around them. The Giardino Cafe Ristorante in Roslyn, a six-week-old, sprawling storefront trattoria, is doing just that by pumping life into the fashionable but until now rather quiet Harbour View Shoppes.

title: TEACHING JOHNNY TO BE GOOD
description: I see no danger of character education declining into moral relativism just because the instructor refrains from providing an explicit moral code. What is important is that children learn methods of inquiry and communication. The educator John Dewey wrote that "morals is not a catalogue of acts nor a set of rules to be applied like drugstore prescriptions or cookbook recipes." We must provide children with the creative tools they will need to make difficult decisions. JESSICA WAHMAN New York

POP MUSIC;

In the previous four weeks, Mr. Aronoff had flown 9,000 miles, driven a few thousand more and broken five dozen drumsticks.

title: Buying Guitars, No Strings Attached
description: Scott Chinery bought his first guitar when he was 17. He was working at a music store in Freehold, N.J. "A little old man came in one day with an old, cheap Orpheum No. 16," Mr. Chinery said. "From that moment on I was smitten. I collected as vigorously as I could."

title: Fix-It Journalism
description: A HALF-CENTURY ago, Iphigene Ochs Sulzberger detected what she thought was an appalling ignorance of American history among allegedly educated college graduates. The daughter, wife and mother of newspaper executives, she used her influence to encourage The New York Times to test her hypothesis in a national survey. The survey found that only 18 percent of the nation's colleges and universities required students to take a course in American history. The revelation prompted many schools to change their degree requirements and won a Pulitzer Prize for The Times. Since then, unfortunately, a lot more American history, including Mrs. Sulzberger's modest crusade, has been forgotten.

title: Living Room Curators Lend Works From Collections to the Neuberger
description: RENEE RICHMOND led off with the Rembrandts, moving on to the Goya, Piranesi, Hogarth and Canaletto. She and her husband, Henry, began their art collection with works by the Old Masters, she said, so it was fitting to start a tour of the collection in the couple's front hall, where the oldest pictures hung.

title: Iwo Jima Memorial Is Still A Draw
description: NEARLY three months have passed since the solemn yet triumphant dedication of Connecticut's own Iwo Jima monument, unveiled on the 50th anniversary of one of World War II's bloodiest battles. Thousands of people flooded the grounds of the small park on Feb. 23, where the replica of the Iwo Jima monument in Arlington, Va. cuts into the sky.

title: The Digerati!
description: WE HAVE TO WRAP OUR brains around 3.05 for a second." John Battelle, the managing editor of Wired, is using softwarespeak to start a meeting about the fifth issue of the magazine's third year. But Louis Rossetto seems to be somewhere else. Wearing sneakers and jeans, his wavy gray hair yanked back into a ponytail, curly wisps escaping around the sides, he stares blankly into space, like some cocky kid on an internship. Actually, he's Wired's 45-year-old editor and publisher, looking lost in a daydream . . . about how he trounced the mass media, maybe, those Second Wave dinosaurs who wouldn't know an Ethernet if somebody hacked one directly into their brainstem. . . .

title: Stopping Unwanted Deliveries
description: Q I'm the board president of a co-op building that does not have a doorman. Every week, a delivery company deposits a large plastic bag in the vestibule of the building. The bag contains advertising circulars for major retailers that are separately packaged into about 100 small plastic bags. I have asked the company to stop delivering the circulars because the board considers them a slip-and-fall hazard.

title: Alexis Barbour And Paul Webb
description: Alexis Sprague Barbour, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Warren Barbour of Bronxville, N.Y., was married yesterday to Paul Maurice Webb, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Maurice Webb of Rochester, Minn. The Rev. Dr. Richard Murdoch performed the ceremony at the Rye Presbyterian Church in Rye, N.Y.

title: A NEW MAP OF THE BRAIN
description: It was interesting to note that missing from Michael Rubiner's "A New Map of the Brain" (Endpaper, April 30) were the few things that really count -- a zest for life, empathy and love. Although I imagine they might be found in the emotional area of the brain, I choose to believe they were omitted because they would more likely belong in a diagram of the heart. MYRNA BLANK HERZ East Grand Rapids, Mich.

title: Creating a 15-Mile Human Chain, Torch by Torch
description: JANET M. TEGLEY is putting together 15 miles worth of people for "Passing the Torch," a celebration to mark the 75th anniversary of women's suffrage. If she and her helpers pull it off, at 5 P.M. on Sunday, June 4, 20,000 people will be in place, waving flashlights, in a line stretching from Independence Hall in Philadelphia to Paulsdale in Mount Laurel, N.J., the birthplace of Alice Paul, a national suffragist leader. description: IT sounds like a scene from a Merchant-Ivory film: a gleaming horse and rider galloping down a dirt trail, leaping bushes and gates, and finally clomping cross a tiny bridge leading to a plush green field.

title: Education Needed
description: To the Editor: Some clarification is in order on why Khaled's music is not accept able in Islam [ "Singing of a Beloved Homeland, Fearful of Going Home Again," April 30 ] . The correct practice of Islam calls for the total submission to the one God. Islamic law is designed to keep Muslims on the path of submission, and all Muslims are obliged to follow it. Laws prohibit certain musical instruments and songs that do not increase piety and wisdom. Music can capture the heart and turn listeners away from Islam, exemplified by girls throwing their bras on stage at a Khaled concert.

description: SHAKEUP AT CB 3: Ruth Messinger says it's for peace and quiet. Kathryn Freed says it's for control. AN 'A' FOR AROMA: F.I.T. students have created their own perfume, a unisex fragrance with hints of Italian mandarin and West Indies lime oil. Scentwear by F.I.T., for sale at the bookstore: $25 for 2 fluid ounces. . . . AND NOW, THE MAGAZINE: The up-and-coming-on-strong Flatiron District now has its own magazine: Flatiron. Focusing on the arts and listings, it is not meant to be trendy, said the founder, Michael Ambramson. "It's for people who read, think and are stimulated by images." The next issue is set for the fall. . . . WHAT ABOUT THOSE PAY TOILETS? One was supposed to be installed at 81st Street and Columbus Avenue this spring. But contract problems with the vendor have put the plan on indefinite hold. . . .

title: Oliver's Twist Is Pride of Maryland
description: Billy Boniface trains his horses specifically for this race. His Deputed Testamony was the last Preakness winner who had not started in the Kentucky Derby, winning at 14-to-1 odds in 1983. Today, if a hole on the inside had opened up a little sooner, the Maryland-based trainer might have pulled off the same trick twice, this time with a 25-to-1 shot.

title: Taking Care of the Little Things in the Heart of Leonia
description: The intersection of Broad Avenue and Fort Lee Road is the heart of Leonia, a Bergen County community of about 8,400 people. It's busy, crisscrossed by drivers who don't always want to wait for the light or pedestrians as they head to the George Washington Bridge, the Turnpike, Route 4 or Route 46. It's the corner where lots of children cross the street on their way to the Anna C. Scott Elementary School and the Leonia Middle School. And it's inevitably on the route of local residents doing their errands, because everything in downtown Leonia -- Borough Hall, the library, the recreation center, the banks (three), the pharmacies (two) and the bagel, pet and hardware stores (one of each) -- is within a two-minute walk. title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: SCHOOL FOR THE BLIND By Dennis McFarland. Ivy, $6.99. Francis Brimm, a retired news photographer, moves back to the Florida town of his childhood. Instead of a peaceful old age, he and his sister find mysterious events from their youth reasserting themselves. These characters "register just right in their idiosyncrasies, and . . . we like just reading about their movements through the day," Sven Birkerts said here last year. THE SILENT WOMAN: Sylvia Plath & Ted Hughes By Janet Malcolm. Vintage, $12. They are among the most famous -- and notorious -- of literary couples. Sylvia Plath was silenced by her own hand when she committed suicide in 1963, but in the years since, many writers have attempted to speak for her, which has usually meant speaking against her husband. Janet Malcolm takes the opposite approach while also scrutinizing the nature and practice of biography. In 1994 our reviewer, Caryn James, said: "She lucidly unravels the Plath controversy. . . . Most important, she raises indispensable, uncomfortable issues that journalists and biographers should be brave enough to face." THANK YOU FOR SMOKING By Christopher Buckley. Harper Perennial, $12. Who could be a more convincing antihero for the 90's than a tobacco lobbyist? Nick Naylor doesn't exactly love his work, but hey, it pays the mortgage. "This hilarious novel . . . suggests that by our craft we shall be known," Larry Gelbart said in these pages last year. A MAN ON THE MOON: The Voyages of the Apollo Astronauts By Andrew Chaikin. Penguin, $15.95. This book looks back on the excitement of the early years of the space program, capturing both the human personalities and the technological challenge. In 1994 our reviewer, Alex Roland, said the author "recounts in loving detail the standard Apollo epic," while also rendering the science "interesting and understandable." Two of the astronauts have their own say in MOONSHOT: The Inside Story of America's Race to the Moon, by Alan Shepard and Deke Slayton (Turner, $12.95). In the same review Mr. Roland found their narrative a "swashbuckling" one, told by "true believers." THE END OF THE HUNT By Thomas Flanagan. Warner, $6.99. The last volume in the author's trilogy about Ireland takes place in the years between the Easter Rebellion and the Irish Civil War. Through his characters, Mr. Flanagan illustrates the conflict between idealistic spirit and political necessity. More than "a well-told tale," it is "a significant contribution to . . . historical interpretation," Terence Brown said here last year. RUSSIA UNDER THE BOLSHEVIK REGIME By Richard Pipes. Vintage, $18. A historian analyzes the fruits of 1917, concluding that the revolution was not, in fact, a proletarian uprising and that the totalitarian nature of the Soviet state was directly inherited from its czarist predecessor. In 1994 our reviewer, Marshall D. Shulman, found this "a solid work of historical scholarship" whose prose is "graceful and literate." The same publisher has also reissued GENERATIONS OF WINTER, by Vassily Aksyonov, translated by John Glad and Christopher Morris ($13). A fictional look at the dark era of Stalinism, it follows the fortunes of a physician and his children as they are pulled in different directions by the forces of history. The novel "captures the anxiety, the Kafkaesque pointlessness of state cruelty, with ferocious artistry," Jay Parini said in the Book Review in 1994. More recent events are the subject of THE RISE OF RUSSIA AND THE FALL OF THE SOVIET EMPIRE, by John B. Dunlop (Princeton University, $16.95), which examines the struggle to define the nation's new identity. It includes "a close and provocative look at the August 1991 coup," our reviewer, Celestine Bohlen, wrote in 1993. According to the author, the plot came close to succeeding. WHITE MAN'S GRAVE By Richard Dooling. Picador USA, $13. When Michael Killigan, a Peace Corps volunteer, vanishes into the wilds of Sierra Leone, his ruthless father and his trusting best friend go in after him. Through their humorous adventures in the heart of darkness, the author is "able to revitalize the traditional comic novel of colonialism," Gary Krist said here last year. DIPLOMACY By Henry Kissinger. Touchstone/Simon & Schuster, $17.50. In 1994 our reviewer, Ernest R. May, found this book Machiavellian both in its approach to power and in its tendency to reveal more about the author's personality than about history. Above all, it shows how individuals can mold the future through their manipulation of events. "The strength of 'Diplomacy' lies in its marriage of vision and shrewdness," Mr. May said. TEN TALES TALL & TRUE By Alasdair Gray. Harvest/Harcourt Brace, $11. This collection employs a range of styles and devices to show how people fulfill the scripts they've written for their lives -- usually by choosing someone to bully or be bullied by. It's "a very accessible introduction to a body of work that deserves (and rewards) serious consideration," Ron Loewinsohn said here last year. REINVENTING EDUCATION: Entrepreneurship in America's Public Schools By Louis V. Gerstner Jr., Roger D. Semerad, Denis Philip Doyle and William B. Johnston. Plume, $11.95. This book describes the ways the corporate sector can enrich education by awarding funds to innovative programs at public schools. The authors' model is the Next Century Schools Program, developed by the RJR Nabisco Foundation. Last year one critic called it "an eloquent plea for change." LAUREL GRAEBER

title: London
description: Few cities appreciate spring and summer more than London does. After months of drab days and long nights, flowers and lush greenery burst forth in the city's magnificent parks and gardens, and the promise, however tentative, of sunshine and warmth can coax a smile from the most dour Londoner.

title:
HOME CLINIC;
It's Time to Check the Deck for Weather-Related Damages
description: NOW is a good time to inspect decks and prepare them for summer. Most decks are constructed of moisture- and rot-resistant woods like redwood, cedar or pressure-treated pine.

title: Istanbul Dining
description: To the Editor: Two recent Letters on Travel regarding dining experiences in Istanbul reminded me of my own, quite different, dining adventure in that fascinating city. As a student roaming through Europe, I stopped for a midday meal at a small cafe near the celebrated Blue Mosque. To my dismay, the menu was printed only in Turkish. Seeing my discomfiture, the waiter beckoned to me to follow him to the kitchen. Once inside, the waiter gestured toward all the simmering pots and pans, indicating that I was to point out whatever excited my curiosity and appetite. The resulting meal was exceptional, cost next to nothing, and left one young American with happy memories of Turkish cuisine. GARDNER READ Manchester, Mass.

Brenes of East Williston, L.I., was married yesterday to George Russell Nuce, the son of Mr. and Mrs. George Nuce of Princeton, W.Va. The Rev. Kenneth O. title: New Theme Park in Spain
description: Europe's newest theme park, the 285-acre Port Aventura, opened on May 2 in the heart of the Costa Dorada in Spain. Sixty miles south of Barcelona on the A-7 highway near the resort town of Salou, the park features 28 rides in five themed areas: a Mediterranean port, a Polynesian village, a Chinese town and Imperial Palace, a recreation of Maya and colonial Mexico, and the American West. Port Aventura will close for the winter, but remain open as long as the weather is inviting, then reopen in April.

title: Rehearsing for Life's Important Moments
description: IT iS wedding season again, and brides are everywhere. I spotted my first bride, in full white regalia, in the lobby of a motel on a recent Wednesday morning, along with a whole wedding party. A large sign at the back of the lobby announced "Glen and Cindy's Wedding Rehearsal."

That clarity of character will stand her and her children -- regardless of genetics, which she mentions -- in good stead.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about the dispute between Greece and the former Yugoslav republic of Macedonia over its use of the name Macedonia misspelled the surname of a British historian who has written that Greece has no claim on the name. He is Eric Hobsbawm, not Hobsbawn.

And Bear in Mind (Editor's Choices of other recent books of particular interest) GOD: A Biography, by Jack Miles. (Knopf, $27.50.) Not a joke but a scholarly, entertaining literary inquiry into the character called God as His multiple personalities have been rendered through the ages in the Hebrew Bible. THE HAUNTED LAND: Facing Europe's Ghosts After Communism, by Tina Rosenberg. (Random House, $25.) A moral, political and psychological investigation, by a wise journalist, of four post-Soviet societies struggling with their conduct under the old regimes. THE INFORMATION, by Martin Amis. (Harmony, $24.) Mr. Amis's cool and brilliant novel is sustained throughout by the corroding, corrupting envy of an unsuccessful novelist for a successful novelist who is also his best friend. LANDSCAPE AND MEMORY, by Simon Schama. (Knopf, $40.) A learned and perceptive survey of Western attitudes toward nature in the last five centuries; Mr. Schama's starting point is the Renaissance fascination with river, forest and mountain as signs of a revered prototypal world. THE MAN WITHOUT QUALITIES, by Robert Musil. Translated by Sophie Wilkins and Burton Pike. (Knopf, two volumes, boxed, $60.) A magnificent new version of the unfinished and unfinishable novel by an Austrian contemporary of Proust and Joyce whose acknowledged greatness has always exceeded his acknowledged readership. OSWALD'S TALE: An American Mystery, by Norman Mailer. (Random House, $30.) Stoked by a passion to believe J.F.K.'s death was more than a meaningless absurdity, Mr. Mailer pursues and delivers the assassin's very slightly significant soul, using his own research and that of others. POPE JOHN PAUL II: The Biography, by Tad Szulc. (Lisa Drew/Scribner, $27.50.) Mr. Szulc, a seasoned reporter of Polish birth, inquires into the special circumstances of Polish Catholicism and the special stresses of fascist and Communist domination that formed the present Pope. RIDING THE RAP, by Elmore Leonard. (Delacorte, $22.95.) A dandy re-readable thriller set in post-modern America, land of wised-up rabble and zero authenticity; its crooks intend a whole new crime, never perpetrated before. A RIVER TOWN, by Thomas Keneally. (Nan A. Talese/Doubleday, $24.) It's 1899 in Mr. Keneally's impassioned 21st novel, and Tim Shea, an outsider in an Australia with no insiders, inexorably digs himself into deeper and deeper trouble by always trying to do the right thing. RULE OF THE BONE, by Russell Banks. (HarperCollins, $22.) A novel that reinvigorates the Huck Finn myth in the person of Chappie, a mall rat from upstate New York who lights out for Jamaica with a runaway farm worker. WALT WHITMAN'S AMERICA: A Cultural Biography, by David S. Reynolds. (Knopf, $35.) An intensive historical excavation, aiming to show how Whitman, an enthusiast for almost everything, transmuted into his poetry images from all aspects of American culture.

title: Books That Ask to Be Judged by Their Covers
description: SOME OF THE MOST BEAUTIFUL books in the world, bound in leather and emblazoned on the covers with Cubist and abstract images, are rarely exhibited. Their owners tend to protect these fragile objects from light and dust, studying them alone or in the company of very few people. In fact, one collector is so private in guarding his French modernist bindings, which are coming up for sale next month, that he has kept them in a Manhattan warehouse for a decade.

title:
BACKTALK;
Books, Beer and Volleys: A Year in the Life of a College Standout
description: The college sports season is winding down this month with national championships in many sports, including tennis, golf, lacrosse and baseball. For many student-athletes, the year has produced its share of highs and lows, athletically, academically and socially. Samantha Stevenson followed Jeff Salzenstein, the captain and No. 1 tennis player on the Stanford men's team, during his junior year. It was a year that concluded this weekend with the National Collegiate Athletic Association team and individual championships. SEPTEMBER

In January 1978, Isaiah Sheffer and Allan Miller took over an abandoned movie theater on upper Broadway and staged a free 12-hour Bach concert with the American Symphony Orchestra. Little did they realize that 17 years later they would still be in the same theater, schmoozing with potential financial backers and planning a mix of shows that feature William Hurt one night and public school students another.

title: May 14-20; A Short History of Raising the Dead
description: IF the reports can be believed, Dr. Raul J. Cano has realized the fantasy of the oldest science fiction plot: He has resuscitated life that has been dormant for 30 million years. He has extracted bacteria that have been trapped in suspended animation, in the guts of ancient bees embedded in ancient amber, and brought them back to life. Do we have the right to assume such godlike powers? Science has no answer, but maybe science fiction does.

title: Democratic Clubs: Back to the Future
description: Decades ago, people turned to political clubs for help in finding a job, negotiating with a landlord or even getting a refrigerator moved. As times changed -- and political patronage waned -- the clubs lost clout and popularity. Politicians began setting up their own offices and community boards began taking on some of the clubs' traditional roles as liaisons to city government.

title:
NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: FOREST HILLS;
Muggers Find Much-Used, Desolate Strip
description: On the evening of March 29, Doris Babic walked her usual route along Burns Street beside the elevated Long Island Rail Road tracks to her apartment. A group of men in a car were trailing her along the poorly lit path. When she entered her building's lobby, one of the men jumped out, grabbed her purse and beat her when she resisted. On the same night, another pedestrian was attacked on Burns Street.

title: In High Schools, Volunteer Service Joins the 3 R's
description: EVERY Thursday, Christina M. Kargul, a freshman at New Britain High School, spends four hours as a volunteer at New Britain General Hospital, helping people who are undergoing outpatient surgery.

title: G. D. Reilly, 88, Former Judge And Official in the Labor Dept.
description: Gerard D. Reilly, a former Labor Department official during the New Deal who later served as Chief Judge of the District of Columbia Court of Appeals, died on Thursday as he was leaving the court, where he had been a Senior Judge since his retirement in 1976. He was 88 and lived in Washington.

title: A Photographer Trains His Eye on the Canvas
description: ERIC GUTTELEWITZ began as a photographer, having learned the craft from his father. This was in Guatemala, where he was born in 1956. Mr. Guttelewitz remains a photographer, working mainly for art galleries in Manhattan, but now he is a painter, too. The change came about when, moving to the United States in 1976, he spent a year at the Art Students League.

description: The Clinton Administration has promised to remove 203 Haitian children still at the Guantanamo Bay Naval Station in Cuba by June 30 and speed up efforts to unite those children with parents or relatives in Haiti or the United States.

title: TICKET TO TROUBLE
description: Would you mind telling me what precisely it is you mean by women "of a certain age"? It cropped up twice on April 23 -- in the lottery article and the one on ballroom dancers in Miami. I find it bizarre that a serious newspaper suddenly gets all coy and Victorian when discussing women who are, what -- over 25? over 30? over 40? Care to define your terms?

title: Playing Portugal's Golf Coast
description: THROUGHOUT its long history, Portugal's southernmost province, the Algarve, has been host to a series of visitors from foreign shores. First came the Phoenicians 3,000 years ago, then the Carthaginians, Romans and Moors, who arrived in the eighth century and ruled for over 500 years. Indeed, al-Gharb means "the West" in Arabic, and the Moorish influence remains evident in the whitewashed houses sprouting chimneys that look like miniature minarets. The most recent invasions, however, have come from golfers seeking sunsoaked fairways. The first onslaught was led by the British, who account for about 60 percent of the golfers visiting the Algarve, followed by Germans and Dutch, and now a steady trickle of Americans.

title:
SPAS AND SPORTS;
Yoga Under the Sun
description: AT 5:30 A.M. a hollow gong rang out, obscuring the sound of waves crashing on the beach. The surf outside our hut had lulled us into a deep sleep, but in response to the bell we rose grudgingly and made our way to a small, open-air Hindu temple in a grove of palm trees on Nassau Bay. The rhythms of a new day at the Sivananda Yoga Retreat in the Bahamas had begun.

title:

The Question: T-Bill or Not T-Bill?

The Rev. George Farland performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at Sacred Heart Church in Springfield, Mass.

title: In Bethel, a Beer Garden in Miniature
description: AT an outpost of Germany in Bethel called Helga's, dinner is about as close to a year-round Oktoberfest as Connecticut gets. Enter the front door of the small house by the roadside any weekend evening, and one is likely to be blown away by the exuberant oompah tones of an accordion played by a smiling musician in Tyrolean jacket and hat, while rousing songs are belted out by the owner, Helga Roth, in her native Rhinelander costume, with guests joining in on the choruses.

title: Managing the Perils Of Opening Night; A Press Agent Lives by the Seating Chart
description: For Alma Viator, the opening night of Jean Cocteau's "Indiscretions" began weeks earlier. As press agent for the show, she would then have many duties: coddle the critics, arrange interviews, shepherd photographers. But first she had to build buzz for the show -- which meant picking the party spot and buttonholing celebrities to fill it.

title:
ULTRAMARATHON;
A 54-Mile Race With Cooperation as the Biggest Winner
description: The white man had run 50 miles through the green valleys of South Africa. He was a panting, wobbly wreck. The white-sand beaches and exclusive resort hotels of Durban lay just ahead, but first he would have to pound along the freeway overlooking the shanties -- the houses made of dismantled crates with green vinyl for roofs -- with their black residents lining the roads to watch him.

title: Forever In Debt
description: The U.S. national debt is $4.7 trillion and increasing by $38,158 every four seconds, as a clock posted in the House Budget Committee hearing room reminds us. On Thursday, the House approved a proposal to balance the budget by the year 2002; the Senate is scheduled to vote on its own plan this week. But whatever compromise plan emerges, even if made law, will not necessarily balance the budget: it will only set spending goals. Congress can ignore those goals just as it did those set by the deficit-reduction bills passed in the mid-1980's.

title: It's Deep Spring, Time to Start Worrying About the Garden in Fall
description: SPRING is glorious now with everything in bloom -- late tulips, flowering trees, groundcovers, perennials galore and even some of the annuals. Yet this is the time of year to think about the garden in fall.

description: Jeff Vinik keeps raising his bets, and making them more concentrated.

title: Long or Short on Politics, Photographs Over the Decades
description: AN Independent Curators Incorporated production is making its first stop on a national tour at the Bruce Museum in Greenwich. "Multiple Exposures," as the show is called, consists of group portraits taken by more than 40 photographers since around 1910. The show was organized by Leslie Tonkonow, director of the Zabriskie Gallery in Manhattan, and comes with an illustrated catalogue containing two essays. One is by the curator, the other by Alan Trachtenberg, a professor of English and American studies at Yale and the author of several books including "Reading American Photographs."

title: May 14-20: Shooting Time; The Guns of Sarajevo Imperil The Peacekeepers' Mission
description: Sarajevo, symbol of the civil warfare ravaging the Balkans, was battered last week by the worst fighting in two years. Shelling by Government forces concentrated on two key Serbian supply routes, portending a long and terrifying summer in which the Bosnians appear determined to break the three-year Serbian siege of Sarajevo.

description: Angel Padilla did not blink once as the jury foreman read the guilty verdict, condemning him to spend the rest of his life in prison. Like a statue, he stared deadpan at the United States seal above the judge's head, as if he were waiting for a bus.

title: Sri Lankans Hear Details of Decade of Slaughter
description: For weeks, at hearings in town halls and school auditoriums across this island, bereaved families have been telling their grim stories: of groups of men, sometimes women and teen-age children, being rounded up by armed men at intervals in the last decade and driven away, never to be seen again.

description: In an unusual alignment of opposing political constellations, the Republicans and the Democrats are both on the road in New Jersey this weekend, the Republicans to celebrate a sense of power and purpose, the Democrats literally wondering what to do next.

title: Bubble Gum With a Punk Attitude
description: TO STEPHIN MERRITT, ONE OF ALTERNA- tive rock's newest cult figures, Top 40 jingles are purer music than any punk. Yet it's punk fans who have always been most charmed by his music. So it's no surprise that independent rock record labels have issued and reissued all four of the albums, credited to a group called Magnetic Fields, that Mr. Merritt wrote, produced and largely performed on. (The group is, in effect, one man, Mr. Merritt.)

description: For most of the last 20 years, being a Nasdaq market maker has been a very profitable occupation. If you didn't get caught committing too much capital to one or two stocks, and if you managed to arrange for a steady flow of orders, you had a right to profit by buying low and selling high.

title: Bronx Arts Ensemble Finale
description: THE Bronx Arts Ensemble winds up its spring season with a burst of activity, starting today at 2 P.M. with "Chamber Music in Great Homes." The house is at 7 Blackstone Place in Riverdale, and the music will feature works by Beethoven, Debussy and Brahms and the world premiere of Meyer Kupferman's "Poetics Nine." The guest artist for the recital is Cynthia Phelps, principal violist of the New York Philharmonic.

title: Leader Board a Pleasant Sight for Healthy Singh
description: If sheer hard work counts for anything, if absolute dedication to beating all the vagaries out of the game of golf has any meaning whatsoever, then Vijay Singh is exactly where he belongs today -- right atop the leader board after three rounds of the Buick Classic at the Westchester Country Club.

title: Word for Word / The Sir-Charge; A Fair Lady's Question: Why Can't A Man Be More Like a Woman?
description: ALTHOUGH the nation professes to be worried sick both about how much money is in the Government's coffers and how much crime is in the cities' streets, few people have come forward with practical suggestions for solving both problems at once. But June Stephenson, a research psychologist from Napa, Calif, has a doozy. In her book "Men are Not Cost-Effective: Male Crime in America," published in paperback this year by Harper Perennial, she spells out her plan. Here is an excerpt. SARAH BOXER WHO do the police investigate if the identities of the perpetrators of a crime are unknown? Almost always they would be investigating young men. Thirty-one percent of the people arrested and sent to prison are men between the ages of 18 and 24, and another 45 percent are men aged 25 to 44. Ninety-four percent of prisoners are males. Whether it is robbery, burglary, arson, white-collar crime, crime against children, crime against women, drug dealing, drunk driving, murder, crime in government, treason, or gang violence, crime is a masculine statement. . . .

title:
MUSIC;
A Choral Impresario Prepares for Spoleto

It might happen to give a concert in a church, but its time is spent in daily rehearsal for recordings, and performing with such orchestras as the New Jersey Symphony, the New York Philharmonic and the Philadelphia Orchestra.

title: Crime
description: Big town, small town, crime taints them both. But in a little twerp of a town like Blue Deer, Mont. -- population 3,872, altitude 4,500 feet, hunkered down between the Crazy Mountains and the Absaroka Range of the Rockies -- every felony is a blot on the landscape. Or, as Jamie Harrison would have it in her sparkling, caustic first novel, THE EDGE OF THE CRAZIES (Hyperion, $20.95), crime is "made crueler by a pastoral setting, by the violent who were oblivious to beauty."

title: Obscenity: A Celebration
description: 1 -- I MUST NOT BE PIOUS. OSCAR WILDE WOULD HAVE REFUSED piety. I must not be sentimental. That stance, too, the master would have overturned. One hundred years ago (May 25, 1895), under Britain's notorious Labouchere Amendment, which penalized "gross indecency" between men, Wilde, prime minister of the paradox, was sentenced to two years of hard labor in prison -- this on the heels of his fabulously successful "The Importance of Being Earnest." What crimes did he commit? He practiced love between men and dared to declare it a renaissance; he refused to call his "Picture of Dorian Gray" a perverted book, refused to agree that there existed immoral books, refused to be consistent, refused to submit his language to the thumb of fact.

title: Restaurants Complying On Smoking
description: Despite angry protests by some owners that it is costing them business, most restaurants in New York City are abiding by a six-week-old ban on smoking, leaving the dining rooms of large restaurants and taverns almost smoke-free.

title: TEACHING JOHNNY TO BE GOOD
description: Rosenblatt states that character education was a "subject unheard of a generation ago." On the contrary, in the 1960's and 70's there was intense interest in teaching values in school. One strong impetus came out of the human-potential movement and another out of Lawrence Kohlberg's work on the theory of moral development.

SOAPBOX;

description: ON the national, state and local levels, everyone pays lip service to the notion of reinventing government. But it's a great deal more difficult than it looks. We found this out the hard way in Berkeley Heights this year, and other communities could learn from our experience.

Plus, of course, all the latest bells and whistles -- whether safety items like dual air bags and antilock brakes, or cup holders and CD players.

title: FOUR-LETTER WORDS
description: I support William Safire's plea that we "save our abused and worn-out four-letter words." I despair when I hear so much filthy language on the streets and in school hallways. Some faculty members even use vulgar expressions so they may appear to be "down with" the students. It seems to me that the "f-word" is used so often in ordinary conversation that the battering and abuse of women seems routine and ordinary. If no words are left to express anger and other strong emotion, it is no wonder that our society is plagued by violence, especially from the young. LINA M. LOWRY Brooklyn

title: HO, HO, HO CHI MINH
description: MASTER OF CEREMONIES: Folks, immigrants are what make this country great, especially when they're funny and bring in a lot of money for nightclubs. As you can tell from the festive balloons at every table there's a fabulous national healing that's going on. So as we prepare for another wonderful century, let's all ponder the incredible lesson that we Americans have learned -- those who fail to remember the past are unable to cash in on it. Yes, joining our great heritage of ethnic jokemeisters -- Amos 'n' Andy, Myron Cohen, Jose Jimenez, Yakov Smirnov, Margaret Cho . . . is the funniest man in the jungle! Folks, put your hands together for . . . Charlie Duc Tho! CHARLIE (takes center stage to sound of firecrackers going off): Incoming! But seriously. . . . Thank you, thank you! This is a wonderful club, you're fabulous people and I'm lucky to be here. . . . Frankly, I'm lucky to be anywhere. Waiter, could I have a drink? Thank you. Hey, I know. I need booze like Vietnam needs Slim-Fast. Am I right?

title: Looks a Lot Like 1918 For Red Sox and Cubs After Early Success
description: Boston schoolboys and schoolgirls know the year better than they know the year of the Boston Tea Party. If teachers wanted to make sure their students had at least one answer correct on a surprise quiz, they would include the question: When did the Red Sox last win the World Series?

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: SCHOOL FOR THE BLIND By Dennis McFarland. Ivy, $6.99. Francis Brimm, a retired news photographer, moves back to the Florida town of his childhood. Instead of a peaceful old age, he and his sister find mysterious events from their youth reasserting themselves. These characters "register just right in their idiosyncrasies, and . . . we like just reading about their movements through the day," Sven Birkerts said here last year. THE SILENT WOMAN: Sylvia Plath & Ted Hughes By Janet Malcolm. Vintage, $12. They are among the most famous -- and notorious -- of literary couples. Sylvia Plath was silenced by her own hand when she committed suicide in 1963, but in the years since, many writers have attempted to speak for her, which has usually meant speaking against her husband. Janet Malcolm takes the opposite approach while also scrutinizing the nature and practice of biography. In 1994 our reviewer, Caryn James, said: "She lucidly unravels the Plath controversy. . . . Most important, she raises indispensable, uncomfortable issues that journalists and biographers should be brave enough to face." THANK YOU FOR SMOKING By Christopher Buckley. Harper Perennial, $12. Who could be a more convincing antihero for the 90's than a tobacco lobbyist? Nick Naylor doesn't exactly love his work, but hey, it pays the mortgage. "This hilarious novel . . . suggests that by our craft we shall be known," Larry Gelbart said in these pages last year. A MAN ON THE MOON: The Voyages of the Apollo Astronauts By Andrew Chaikin. Penguin, $15.95. This book looks back on the excitement of the early years of the space program, capturing both the human personalities and the technological challenge. In 1994 our reviewer, Alex Roland, said the author "recounts in loving detail the standard Apollo epic," while also rendering the science "interesting and understandable." Two of the astronauts have their own say in MOONSHOT: The Inside Story of America's Race to the Moon, by Alan Shepard and Deke Slayton (Turner, $12.95). In the same review Mr. Roland found their narrative a "swashbuckling" one, told by "true believers." THE END OF THE HUNT By Thomas Flanagan. Warner, $6.99. The last volume in the author's trilogy about Ireland takes place in the years between the Easter Rebellion and the Irish Civil War. Through his characters, Mr. Flanagan illustrates the conflict between idealistic spirit and political necessity. More than "a well-told tale," it is "a significant contribution to . . . historical interpretation," Terence Brown said here last year. RUSSIA UNDER THE BOLSHEVIK REGIME By Richard Pipes. Vintage, $18. A historian analyzes the fruits of 1917, concluding that the revolution was not, in fact, a proletarian uprising and that the totalitarian nature of the Soviet state was directly inherited from its czarist predecessor. In 1994 our reviewer, Marshall D. Shulman, found this "a solid work of historical scholarship" whose prose is "graceful and literate." The same publisher has also reissued GENERATIONS OF WINTER, by Vassily Aksyonov, translated by John Glad and Christopher Morris ($13). A fictional look at the dark era of Stalinism, it follows the fortunes of a physician and his children as they are pulled in different directions by the forces of history. The novel "captures the anxiety, the Kafkaesque pointlessness of state cruelty, with ferocious artistry," Jay Parini said in the Book Review in 1994. More recent events are the subject of THE RISE OF RUSSIA AND THE FALL OF THE SOVIET EMPIRE, by John B. Dunlop (Princeton University, $16.95), which examines the struggle to define the nation's new identity. It includes "a close and provocative look at the August 1991 coup," our reviewer, Celestine Bohlen, wrote in 1993. According to the author, the plot came close to succeeding. WHITE MAN'S GRAVE By Richard Dooling. Picador USA, $13. When Michael Killigan, a Peace Corps volunteer, vanishes into the wilds of Sierra Leone, his ruthless father and his trusting best friend go in after him. Through their humorous adventures in the heart of darkness, the author is "able to revitalize the traditional comic novel of colonialism," Gary Krist said here last year. DIPLOMACY By Henry Kissinger. Touchstone/Simon & Schuster, $17.50. In 1994 our reviewer, Ernest R. May, found this book Machiavellian both in its approach to power and in its tendency to reveal more about the author's personality than about history. Above all, it shows how individuals can mold the future through their manipulation of events. "The strength of 'Diplomacy' lies in its marriage of vision and shrewdness," Mr. May said. TEN TALES TALL & TRUE By Alasdair Gray. Harvest/Harcourt Brace, $11. This collection employs a range of styles and devices to show how people fulfill the scripts they've written for their lives -- usually by choosing someone to bully or be bullied by. It's "a very accessible introduction to a body of work that deserves (and rewards) serious consideration," Ron Loewinsohn said here last year. REINVENTING EDUCATION: Entrepreneurship in America's Public Schools By Louis V. Gerstner Jr., Roger D. Semerad, Denis Philip Doyle and William B. Johnston. Plume, $11.95. This book describes the ways the corporate sector can enrich education by awarding funds to innovative programs at public schools. The authors' model is the Next Century Schools Program, developed by the RJR Nabisco Foundation. Last year one critic called it "an eloquent plea for change." LAUREL GRAEBER

title: FOUR-LETTER WORDS
description: William Safire's musings on "Four-Letter Words" (On Language, April 30) mirror my own, which always arise when I am teaching my 12th graders about the history and development of the English language: Why, indeed, are these words unacceptable while their synonyms are? Why is it O.K. to use excrement and fornicate and urinate but not their earthier forms? The answer, I suggest, goes back to the Norman Conquest, when the subjugated English people were taught by their captors that all aspects of their Anglo-Saxon culture -- including their language -- were inferior to those of their Latinized masters. It was, in a sense, an attempt at linguistic genocide . . . and it was somewhat successful. ROBERT ROSSNER Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y.
