The police are restricting the number of cars on the block and confiscating boom boxes. Merchants credit the Village Alliance Business Improvement District for the positive changes.

title: Election Chiefs Of Both Parties Fight Charges
description: DENNIS J. MATTHIES of Farmingdale remembers the day five years ago when the lawyer handling his deceased aunt's estate, Joseph G. Cairo Jr., asked him to sign four blank checks to be drawn on her estate account.

title: Correction
description: A report in the "Sunday" pages on April 30 about the Church of Scientology misidentified the magazine in which part of the book "Dianetics," a central text of Scientology, was first published. It was Astounding Science Fiction, not Amazing Science Fiction.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: USTINOV STILL AT LARGE By Peter Ustinov. Prometheus, paper, $15.95.

title: More Fun Than a Zipper
description: BUTTON Written and illustrated by Sara Fanelli. Unpaged. Boston: Little, Brown & Company. $15.95. (Ages 4 to 8) THE HOLE STORY Written by Eve Merriam. Illustrated by Ivan Chermayeff. Unpaged. New York: Simon & Schuster Books for Young Readers.

title: Books That Pop Up (And More)
description: IN the conventional sense, books are for reading, but in the art world they have become a vehicle for expression in surprising ways. Not just page turners, they unfold like accordions, can be tablets, pop-up and -- in endless creative guises -- startle, unfold and imaginatively impart knowledge.

title: Lisa Fogelgaren, Robert Goldbaum
description: Lisa Renee Fogelgaren, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eric Israel Fogelgaren of Dix Hills, L.I., is to be married today to Robert Daniel Goldbaum, the son of Vivien Goldbaum Feder of Great Neck, L.I., and Michael S. Goldbaum of Accord, N.Y. Rabbi Arthur Rulnick is to perform the ceremony at the Woodbury Jewish Center in Woodbury, L.I.

title: Under Vaulted Ceilings
description: A cathedral and an armory play host to two causes: the arts and the fight against AIDS, respectively.

title: Obscenity: A Celebration
description: 1 -- I MUST NOT BE PIOUS. OSCAR WILDE WOULD HAVE REFUSED piety. I must not be sentimental. That stance, too, the master would have overturned. One hundred years ago (May 25, 1895), under Britain's notorious Labouchere Amendment, which penalized "gross indecency" between men, Wilde, prime minister of the paradox, was sentenced to two years of hard labor in prison -- this on the heels of his fabulously successful "The Importance of Being Earnest." What crimes did he commit? He practiced love between men and dared to declare it a renaissance; he refused to call his "Picture of Dorian Gray" a perverted book, refused to agree that there existed immoral books, refused to be consistent, refused to submit his language to the thumb of fact.

title: If That's His Wallace Kilt, Who Stole The Yellow Stripes?
description: LEGENDARY SCOTS AND THEIR CLANS are rampaging across the big screen this spring, leaving bloodied Englishmen in their wake. The sight of a strapping Robert Roy MacGregor (Liam Neeson) or William Wallace (Mel Gibson) in a kilt may make many a lass weak in the knees. But how authentic are their tartans?

title:
1995 N.H.L. PLAYOFFS;
Keenan Attempts To Explain Early Exit
description: It was just a few weeks ago that the Rangers, the defending Stanley Cup champions, were struggling to make the playoffs while the St. Louis Blues, coached by that notorious ex-Ranger Mike Keenan, were a Stanley Cup favorite.

title: MICROSOFT SCRAPS A SOFTWARE DEAL THAT U.S. OPPOSED
description: The Microsoft Corporation said today that it was abandoning its planned $2 billion acquisition of Intuit Inc., which would have been the largest deal ever in the software industry, because of a legal challenge from the Justice Department and the possibility of protracted litigation.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: CALL NO MAN MASTER By Tina Juarez.Arte Publico, $22.95.

title: Nanci K. Staple, Jay W. Fitzpatrick
description: Nanci Klein Staple, the general counsel of Fred Alger & Company, a securities brokerage firm in Jersey City, was married yesterday to Jay W. Fitzpatrick, the chairman of Wiltek, a data-communications company in Norwalk, Conn. Rosalie Vento-Kaufman, a justice of the peace in Fairfield, Conn., performed the ceremony at the bridegroom's house in Fairfield.

title: In One Doctor's Way of Life, a Way of Death
description: Long before his name became synonymous with death and defiance, Dr. Jack Kevorkian had signaled to anyone paying attention that he worked and played by his own rules.

title: Muscle, Hustle and Skill: Three Fearsome Flyers
description: The name for this threesome sounds like a comic book or a television show children might watch on a Saturday morning. They are the Legion of Doom and they play for a team that used to be known as the Broad Street Bullies.

title: INSIDE
description: IN SEARCH OF . . .: When was the last time the guy behind the counter didn't swear his fish was fresh? Our correspondent finds seven markets where it really is. 4 NEWS AND TOPICS The outlook for summer jobs: It could be a whole lot better. 6 RESTAURANTS Creole to Pacific Rim: Eating eclectic in New Brunswick. 15 ON THE TOWNS New Jersey's choral impresario looks to Spoleto. 16 SOAPBOX Reinventing government: One town's reality check. 21

title: New Yorkers & Co.
description: Rockefeller Center Gets A New Tenant: Herman's

title: Jerome Badanes, Novelist, Dies at 58
description: Jerome Badanes, a novelist and film maker who was a faculty member at Sarah Lawrence College in Yonkers, N.Y., died on Thursday at Lawrence Hospital in Bronxville. He was 58 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Broadway Saves Actor on Brink
description: BUZZZZZZZZZZ.

title: Thicker Than Water, and Spilled by the Mob
description: THE CULTURES MAY DIFFER. So may the accents. But movies about ethnic mobs often tell a universal tale, one with a simple moral: the man who tears at the fabric of society risks destroying his most precious piece of it -- his family.

title: Assembly Required
description: Theoretically, summer entertaining is an easy, fluid, carefree proposition. The fair weather that insures a steady supply of good produce also invites a certain playfulness. Guests seem to not to expect a succession of sit-down courses, with attendant linen, silver and stemware. They're willing to be wooed in a more casual key, so long as they can be part of the fun.

title: Yes Virginia, There Is an Afterlife
description: Proving that there is indeed a tennis afterlife, the his and hers senior circuits -- both lucrative and both nationally televised thanks to participation by marketable stars like JIMMY CONNORS, JOHN McENROE, CHRIS EVERT and MARTINA NAVRATILOVA -- were in full swing this weekend. Connors and McEnroe were joined by BJORN BORG and GUILLERMO VILAS in Pebble Beach, Calif., for The Challenge, a $325,000 event on ABC. McEnroe downed Borg, 4-6, 7-5, 7-5, on clay yesterday and he faces Connors today in a final that is worth $150,000 to the victor. The six-city Virginia Slims Legends Tour, featuring competition between doubles teams led by Evert and Navratilova, was in Richmond, Va. Navratilova is expected to announce on Monday that she will join HBO's broadcast team at Wimbledon next month.

title: A Sometime Bartender Busts Out Theatrically
description: IT won't be until Thursday, the morning after "Fortune's Fools" opens at the Cherry Lane Theater in Greenwich Village, that Frederick Stroppel, who wrote it, will have a clue to whether his bartending gig is over.

title: Europe's Elite Ensembles Gather at the Summit
description: FOR DENIZENS OF THIS city, which keeps its head above the surrounding waters only by dint of a constant holding action, meeting challenges is quite literally a way of life. So when, in 1888, the gruff old Johannes Brahms scathingly dismissed the city's musical life ("You are dear people but bad musicians. From now on I shall make music only in Utrecht"), the hard-headed, enterprising burgers of Amsterdam took the insult in the most constructive spirit and founded the Concertgebouw Orchestra.

title: Sky Beauty No Longer Unbeaten At Belmont
description: For 12 straight races at Belmont Park, Sky Beauty had been as picture perfect as her name suggests. But yesterday on a flawless spring afternoon, the champion mare's winning streak finally came to an end in the $133,700 Shuvee Handicap.

title: CHATTER: Finding the Perfect Slice; Made by a Champion
description: Angelo's Pizzeria on Broad Street in Bloomfield is my choice for great pizza. The pies are prepared with pride by the owner, Charles Grande Jr., who is a three-time champion of a competition held annually in Las Vegas, where contestants are judged on speed and neatness. ALFRED PICCOLI Bloomfield

title: What Kind of Mortgage?
description: Fixed or adjustable? That is the basic question pondered by many home buyers when rates are where they are nowadays -- low but not at rock-bottom.

title: Airline Refunds
description: To the Editor: I am happy to report the consideration offered to my wife and me by Continental Airlines last spring.

title: A Restless Borrower, and His Own Man
description: IF THERE'S A MORE REFINED painter and draftsman to emerge in America during those momentous decades of the 1930's and 40's than Arshile Gorky, the name doesn't leap to mind. Almost every inch of his mature works is activated by the springy, rhythmic turns of his line, which coalesce to form strange, winglike and pod-shaped objects, only to dissolve again into ethereal patterns. What makes Gorky's art especially remarkable is that it somehow melds this most exquisite sensitivity to a volcanic and erotic energy.

title: Once More, With Harmony
description: THE LATE CHILD By Larry McMurtry. 461 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $25.

title: Susan J. Koeppel, Steven A. Suslow
description: Susan Jill Koeppel, the daughter of Dorothy Koeppel and Arthur Koeppel, both of New York, was married last evening to Steven Andrew Suslow, a son of Judy and Howard Suslow of New York. Ted Riter, a rabbinical candidate who is a friend of the bride, officiated at the Broadmoor Hotel Golf Club in Colorado Springs.

title: The True Story
description: To the Editor: I enjoyed the article "Those High-Tech Shoot-'Em-Ups Got the Formula from 'The Train' " [ April 30 ] about the 1965 film as a precursor of today's action-adventure films. I have the answer to the question asked by the hero of "The Train," played by Burt Lancaster, in his desperate attempt to stop the train that was returning to Germany with looted art and perhaps hostages: "What do they expect us to do, stop the train with our bare hands?"

title: CHATTER: Finding the Perfect Slice; A Handful of Favorites
description: The California Pizza Kitchen at the Menlo Park Mall, a trendy gourmet pizza place, also serves other tasty dishes. It has lots of garlic on the menu. Pizza and Pasta in Manville (930 South Main St.) has thin-crust pizza and a homey atmosphere that make the trip worthwhile. The adjacent airport is a good spot to relax and watch the prop planes and jet helicopters take off and land.

title: Judith M. Gallent, Scott D. Metzner
description: Judith Monique Gallent, a daughter of Aline and Martin Gallent of Jackson Heights, Queens, is to be married today to Scott Daniel Metzner, a son of Eleanor and Stanley Metzner of Albany. Rabbi Robert Levine is to officiate at Congregation Rodeph Sholom in New York.

title: The Price of Believing a Broker's Promises
description: THE BEEF: Sharon Manion-Fleming handed over $169,000 to a partnership run by a investment advisory firm in December 1990, having been assured, she said, that she couldn't lose more than 10 percent of her money. By October 1991, however, the securities in the partnership had been ravaged by losses in rapid-fire trading, and Ms. Manion-Fleming was left with just $24,000. No problem, said the investment adviser, International Market Strategies; give us five years, and we'll win back your principal. She did; they aren't. In January, she and other partnership investors filed a joint complaint to get their money back from the brokerage firm that did the trades.

title: Tragic Blunders
description: To the Editor:

title: Jennifer A. Brehl, Peter R. Schneider
description: Jennifer Ann Brehl, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard D. Brehl of Huntington, L.I., and Peter Renfro Schneider, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard H. Schneider of Rye, N.Y., were married yesterday. The Very Rev. SaraLouise Krantz officiated at St. Bede's Episcopal Church in Syosset, L.I. The Rev. Kimberly Bosley, a Methodist minister, took part in the ceremony.

title: Robbed in Spain
description: To the Editor: We are seasoned and savvy (we thought) travelers who recently set off for what we hoped would be a megadose of art and architecture in Barcelona. Less than 24 hours after our arrival we were penniless, disgusted and heading back.

title: Ode to an Icon
description: JACKIE UNDER MY SKIN Interpreting an Icon.By Wayne Koestenbaum.Illustrated. 291 pp. New York:Farrar, Straus & Giroux.

title: No Headline
description: "I had a real good business. But you need a decent store front, which I no longer have. I don't know if I'll come back downtown or not." SIDNEY R. COX, who owns an office equipment shop in Oklahoma City. [ 16:1 ]

title:
ART;
An Artist With a Sharp Eye for the Seams Between Two Ages
description: THE Hebrew Home for the Aged at Riverdale has an extensive art program and a collection of 20th-century art, which began with blowups of poignant pictures of immigrant life by photographers like Jacob Riis and Lewis Hine. Now all manner of prints and paintings line the walls.

title: Think Grasses for Find Plumage in the Fall
description: SPRING is glorious now with everything in bloom -- late tulips, flowering trees, groundcovers, perennials galore and even some of the annuals. Yet this is the time of year to think about the garden in fall.

title: Sprinting Into the Spotlight
description: "Who?"

title: Airline Refunds
description: To the Editor: I was pleased to see Betsy Wade's "Nonrefundables: Subject to Change," (Practical Traveler, April 2) about the varying policies on nonrefundable airline tickets.

title: Pope Returns To Prague Amid Strains
description: The last time Pope John Paul II came to Prague, his visit was hailed as a "miracle" by President Vaclav Havel and treated as cause for an end-of-Communism celebration by Czechs and Slovaks, Protestants and Catholics alike.

description: What's happening on stage at all the Atlantic City casinos this week. Tickets are available through Ticketmaster, (800) 736-1420. Bally's Park Place Boardwalk and Park Place. title: TICKET TO TROUBLE
description: The stories in Lois Gould's "Ticket to Trouble" (April 23), about the effect of winning a lottery on the lives of otherwise normal people, were as amusing as they were sad. I must say, though, that I disgree with the implication that sudden wealth from winning a lottery jackpot will probably result in some kind of misfortune for the (un)lucky ticket bearer.

title: Being and Nothingness and Kate Moss
description: In the late 70's, Malcolm McLaren changed the course of popular culture when he discovered the Sex Pistols and set the punk movement in motion. At Sex, the shop he and Vivienne Westwood ran in London, they offered the clothes to match the music. In New York in April to promote his new album, "Paris," a tribute to his adopted city, McLaren attended the fall fashion shows with Holly Brubach, the style editor of this magazine. As members of the audience often do, they chatted, gossiped and exchanged opinions on the spot, off the cuff. MONDAY, 9 A.M., AT BYRON LARS H.B.: Living in Paris, do you follow what's going on in American fashion?

title: The View From: New London; Another Marine Attraction Vies for Waterfront Attention
description: PILES of rubble littering a 24-acre peninsula on New London's shoreline will soon be cleared to make way for Ocean Quest, a $41 million center devoted to the study of the sea.

title: Ideas & Trends: Imaginary Witness; O.J.'s Blood and the Big Bang, Together at Last
description: FOR the squirming jurors held captive in Judge Lance A. Ito's Los Angeles courtroom, the last couple of weeks of DNA testimony must seem like the worst possible visitation of a well-known recurrent nightmare: It's the last week of the semester and suddenly you remember the science class you forgot you signed up for and never thought to attend. Too late to drop it now. In a vast, silent hall, you stare at the final exam with its sickening thicket of meaningless symbols and equations. Your head swimming with the nausea of incomprehension, you run for the exit, but the security guards stop you at the door.

title: Protecting Executive Mansion May Tangle Washington Traffic
description: The road sometimes called America's Main Street got a permanent kink this morning, and even on a Saturday the aches were quickly felt.

title: Factors That Form Child Abusers
description: Child abuse is a terrifying reality that was for too long ignored, denied or minimized as an extraordinarily rare event. It is regrettable, therefore, that in an otherwise informative interview [ "Long Island Q&A: The Need for a Coherent Approach to Child Abuse," April 30 ] a misstatement of fact may lead some to believe (wrongly) that they could not be among those who are capable of committing such abuse. In response to the question whether professionals agree about the causes of child abuse, Dr. Terry Bordan is quoted as saying: "We do know that while not everyone who has been abused becomes an abuser, everyone who abuses a child was himself abused."

title: The Picture of Grace, The Meaning of Objects
description: DOWNTOWN -- Some important people act very unassumingly but make you very nervous. The composer Philip Glass, on the other hand, is so naturally unassuming and conducts himself with such gentleness that he makes you want to lower your voice and become a nicer person.

title: MARKET TIMING
description: Monday Willcox & Gibbs, one of the largest distributors of electrical parts with more than $1 billion in revenues, changes its name to Rexel Inc. Tuesday The Federal Open Market Committee is scheduled to meet. Although some analysts expect it to raise interest rates later this year, signs of slower economic growth should force the Fed to continue to hold rates steady now. Kmart holds its annual meeting in Dearborn, Mich. Richard Cline, who recently stepped down as chief executive of Nicor Inc., is expected to be voted to Kmart's board. There has been speculation that Kmart is close to choosing its new chief executive. The annual ministerial meeting of the 25-nation Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development begins its two-day meeting in Paris. The group is expected to discuss economic growth and employment, but the trade fight between the United States and Japan may dominate the meeting. Ryutaro Hashimoto, the Japanese trade minister, and United States Trade Representative Mickey Kantor are both expected to attend. Deer & Co. scheduled to release fiscal second-quarter earnings. Forecast: $2.67 a share. Wednesday The California Public Utilities Commission is expected to announce the outline of its long-awaited plans for the deregulation of the state's electric utility industry. The Commerce Department releases April durable goods orders. Forecast: down 0.5 percent, after rising 0.6 percent in March. Thursday The National Association of Realtors will release existing home sales for April. Forecast: no change, following an increase of 5.8 percent in March. Friday The Federal Open Market Committee is scheduled to release the minutes from its March meeting.

title: Streetscapes/109 East 39th Street; In First 4 Decades, 3 Unusual Women
description: THE Queen Anne-style town house at 109 East 39th Street, largely intact except for the loss of its stoop, is likely to surprise even an uninformed pedestrian since New York City's post-Civil War rowhouses are generally Italianate brownstone or Renaissance light brick or stone.

title: Travel Industry Anticipates Biggest Summer Season Ever
description: Spurred by an improving economy, widespread discounts and growing consumer confidence, the travel industry is anticipating America's biggest ever summer vacation season.

title: Lisa S. Post, Perry Gershon
description: Lisa Suzanne Post, an associate in the New York law firm Cadwalader, Wickersham & Taft, was married last evening in East Hampton, L.I., to Perry Gershon, a vice president of Nomura Securities International in New York. Rabbi Harvey M. Tattelbaum officiated at the East Hampton Point Restaurant.

title: It's 'Kid's' Play for Players Over 60 in Competitive Softball
description: THE first time Joe Meraglia got up to bat for his softball team, the Tobay Pirates, he heard cheers from his teammates that struck him as odd.

title: In Sarajevo, Victims of a 'Postmodern' War
description: Faruk Sabanovic, a pale and gentle-featured youth, is a thoroughly modern victim of war. He lies in the main hospital here with a video of the moment when he was shot and became a paraplegic.

title: A Violinist Sorts Out the Inseparable
description: BACH'S GREAT WORKS for unaccompanied violin have become so inseparably lumped together that the distinction is rarely made between the Sonatas (BWV 1001, 1003 and 1005), which are stately, formal structures, and the Partitas (BWV 1002, 1004 and 1006), which are dance suites. Christian Tetzlaff shows the difference in his new set on Virgin Classics (45089 2; two CD's), perhaps the greatest achievement of an altogether breathtaking release. Even given Mr. Tetzlaff's penchant for brisk tempos and flexible coloration, the sonatas have a regal and comparatively dark sound; the partitas are nimbler and more given to dynamic shading.

title: Amy J. Merritt, N. C. Papandreou
description: Amy Jill Merritt, the daughter of Myrna and Milton Merritt of Roslyn, L.I., was married yesterday to Nicholas Constantine Papandreou, the son of Elaine and Charles Papandreou of Beverly, Mass. The Rev. Richard Weber, an interfaith minister, officiated at Tamcrest Country Club in Alpine, N.J.

title: Cuba Accord Presents Chance to Lift Embargo
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; Knicks Have Fierce Drive 'To Get Back'
description: THERE is a sheer animal tropism that draws us home. Ever watch a herd of cows working their way back to the barn in the evening? Ever watch migratory birds on a flyway? Ever see a bunch of New York sports journalists flocking to the departure gate at Indianapolis for the first flight out of there? Don't get in their way.

title: Organic Integrity
description: To the Editor:

title: Nature Throws a Curve
description: POETRY OF THE UNIVERSEA Mathematical Exploration of the Cosmos.By Robert Osserman.Illustrated. 210 pp. New York:Anchor Books/Doubleday. $18.95.

title: Material Evidence
description: Months more may pass before the jurors in the O. J. Simpson case deliver their verdict, if they deliver one at all. But the 17 -- at last count -- men and women in the jury box have already spoken, in the language of what they wear. And what they have said may be the best indication that this tortured trial will somehow run its course.

title: Maisie Fritze And Chip Pollard
description: Mary Eleanor Fritze, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gunther E. A. Fritze of Chestnut Hill, Mass., was married there yesterday to Charles Frederick Pollard Jr., the son of the Rev. Lidabell L. Pollard and Mr. Pollard of New Canaan, Conn. The Rev. Curtis G. Kemmerer, a Congregational minister, performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Redeemer. The Rev. Stephen J. White, an Episcopal priest, also took part.

title: Irish Baroque
description: ATHENA By John Banville.233 pp. New York:Alfred A. Knopf. $22.

title: A Centennial -- and a Question
description: The New York Public Library, born 100 years ago this week, is unique in American history. Established through private philanthropy, sustained primarily with public funds, the system has flowered from a single building on Fifth Avenue into a wondrous network of branch libraries that have nurtured generations of writers and scholars and ushered millions of new immigrants into the cultural mainstream. Never lavishly funded, the libraries were seriously weakened by the fiscal crisis of the 1970's and have experienced much budget trauma since then. This week's centennial is a time for both joyous celebration -- and a sobering question: How can the nation's premier library system do its work if government indifference to libraries continues to grow?

title: Imperiled Agencies Mount Life-Saving Efforts
description: Republicans often portray Federal agencies as slothful, lethargic, unresponsive. But many agencies have snapped into action in the last two weeks, galvanized by Republican plans to end their existence or cut their budgets.

title: Sold: Some Rare Works Of Art by Mother Nature
description: ART buyers weren't the only passionate bidders vying for rare properties earlier this month.

title:
RECORDINGS VIEW;
Bang on a Can Issues a Manifesto
description: WHEN THE BANG ON A Can Festival moved from lower Manhattan to Lincoln Center last season, both camps seemed to harbor doubts. Would the formal ambiance of Lincoln Center quash Bang on a Can's anarchic spirit? Or would the cultivated impudence of Bang on a Can undermine New York's bastion of high culture? As the festival's eight-hour new-music marathon returns to Alice Tully Hall today, those questions seem less pressing. By now it is clear that both parties have survived the transition relatively unscathed.

title: Chung Is Removed As CBS Co-Anchor
description: Connie Chung, the second woman to be a regular anchor on a network television evening newscast, has been removed as co-anchor of the "CBS Evening News." She, in turn, has asked to leave the network.

title:
VOICES: FROM THE DESK OF;
The Case for Affirmative Action From Coffers to Conscience: It's No Longer the Back Of the Bus, but . . .
description: WE are unable to get taxis to pick us up in front of office buildings. We are frisked and detained on suburban commuter trains. We are watched in department stores and mistaken for coat-check clerks and restroom attendants while lunching in the best restaurants. We are directed to freight elevators and delivery windows by receptionists who fail to recognize us in our own company offices.

title: Elizabeth Cracks Down On Graffiti, but Gently
description: Hoping to curb what they call a serious graffiti problem in Elizabeth, city and school officials are planning art and cleanup projects in neighborhoods where graffiti is widespread.

title: Hugh R. Rovit, Alice C. Furman
description: Dr. Alice Cary Furman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William S. Furman of South Orange, N.J., was married yesterday evening to Hugh Russell Rovit, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Richard L. Rovit of Scarsdale, N.Y. Rabbi Barry H. Greene performed the ceremony at the Mountain Ridge Country Club in West Caldwell, N.J.

title: A Growing Market for Primary Homes on the Cape
description: Gone are the days when Cape Cod towns opened on Memorial Day and closed on Labor Day. As a newly developing housing community here on the west end of the Cape demonstrates, this market now has the power to draw primary home buyers.

title: Crime
description: Big town, small town, crime taints them both. But in a little twerp of a town like Blue Deer, Mont. -- population 3,872, altitude 4,500 feet, hunkered down between the Crazy Mountains and the Absaroka Range of the Rockies -- every felony is a blot on the landscape. Or, as Jamie Harrison would have it in her sparkling, caustic first novel, THE EDGE OF THE CRAZIES (Hyperion, $20.95), crime is "made crueler by a pastoral setting, by the violent who were oblivious to beauty."

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: SOCCER Everton Wins F.A. Cup Paul Rideout's first-half goal and Neville Southall's two stunning saves led Everton to a 1-0 upset over Manchester United in the F.A. Cup final yesterday at Wembley, England. Rideout's goal came on a breakaway in the 30th minute. (AP) WOMEN'S LACROSSE Trenton State in Final In the semifinals of the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division III women's tournament, Trenton State (16-0) routed Middlebury, 24-12, yesterday on the Lions' home field in Ewing Township, N.J. Jennifer Mazzucco set a women's Division III tournament record with eight goals for the Lions, who captured their 73d consecutive victory. William Smith (16-0) also remained unbeaten by defeating Johns Hopkins (15-3), 16-9. The victors will play for the national title today. The same teams played for the title a year ago, when Trenton State won, 29-11. In the women's Division I semifinals, also at Trenton State, Maryland (16-0), the top-seeded team, defeated Penn State (12-5) by 12-7. In the second game, Princeton (14-2) beat Dartmouth (12-3), 13-8. The Tigers are the defending champions. MEN'S LACROSSE Syracuse Advances The host Syracuse defeated Princeton, 15-11, in the Carrier Dome yesterday to advance to the Division I semifinals for the 13th consecutive year. The freshman Casey Powell had four goals to lead the Orangemen. Third-seeded Syracuse (11-2) will face No. 2 Virginia (12-2), which defeated visiting Brown, the Ivy League co-champion with Princeton, 16-13. Top-seeded Johns Hopkins (13-0) routed No. 8 Loyola, 18-5, in Baltimore and next faces No. 4 Maryland (11-3), a 14-11 winner over Notre Dame in College Park, Md. TENNIS N.C.A.A. Final Set Sixth-seeded Brett Hansen of Southern Cal rallied to beat fourth-seeded Jeff Salzenstein of Stanford, 6-7 (6-8), 6-0, 6-3, yesterday in the semifinals of the National Collegiate Athletic Association men's championships in Athens, Ga. Hansen will meet top-seeded Sargis Sargsian of Arizona State in the final. Sargsian beat unseeded Adam Peterson of U.S.C., 6-2, 6-0. TOP-SEEDED PLAYERS REACH FINAL: Top-seeded Kelly Pace, a Texas senior, defeated 12th-seeded Stacy Sheppard of Georgia, 6-1, 6-3, and U.C.L.A.'s Keri Phebus, the second-seeded player, downed fourth-seeded Jill Craybas of Florida, 1-6, 6-2, 6-2, in the semifinals of the N.C.A.A. women's championships in Malibu, Calif. Pace has a chance to become the first player in the 14-year history of the women's Division I tournament to win the singles and doubles titles as well as play on the team champion. (AP)

description: When Patrick Ewing missed his last-second layup attempt, it was over for the Knicks. The game was over. Their season was over. Perhaps their last chance to win a championship in the Ewing era was over. And Pat Riley's career as the Knicks' coach may have been over, too.

title: Innovation appears to be a scarce commodity. How will multimedia's new talent emerge from the interactive ooze?
description: YOU have read the book, seen the movie, listened to the audio tapes and called the fax line. Now buy the CD-ROM, log onto the Web site and interact!

title: A Peacock on Phoenix Wings; New Ideas and a Little Luck Help NBC's Turnaround
description: NBC, relying on daring programming moves and a commitment to urban, young adult viewers, has emerged from half a decade of slumping ratings, declining revenue and industry ridicule to be the best-positioned network in the business. Competitors and friends alike say it is now seen as the network with the best new programs and the best new strategy to claim a big share of the expanding dollars that advertisers are spending for network commercials.

title: Lots of Little Academics Founded With Lots of Bigs Ideas Produce a Variety of Results
description: Over three decades, New York City educators have opened scores of small public academies, including 46 new high schools in the last two years. In the series, all will be profiled, as well as notable older high schools that served as models and the handful of emerging elementary and middle schools. Here is a sampler of schools representing the array of experiments, some successful, some troubled: The Campus Magnet High Schools at 207 At Andrew Jackson High School, 207-11 116th Avenue, Cambria Heights. IDEA: One building, four new schools. OPENED: 1994. CURRENT ENROLLMENT IN EACH SCHOOL: 300. PEAK IN EACH SCHOOL: 600. GRADES: 9 and 10; 9-12 in September 1996.

title: We Have Met the Future, Uneasily
description: 1939 The Lost World of the Fair By David Gelernter Illustrated. 418 pages. Free Press. $23.

title: Sports of The Times; MacT's Muscular Art: The Crucial Face-Off
description: HE was a Ranger for only three months and now he's a Flyer, but Craig MacTavish will forever be the answer to a trivia question in hockey lore: Who clinched the Stanley Cup in 1994 by winning the final face-off?

title: Victoria and Albert Appoints Director
description: The Victoria and Albert Museum in London has announced the appointment of Dr. Alan Borg as its new director.

title: SCIENCE RESEARCH WOULD BE HIT HARD IN BUDGET CUTTING
description: The glory days of the Federal science establishment may be over, science leaders fear, as cuts proposed by Republicans to wipe out the budget deficit fall hard on civilian research.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Millions of Vehicles Face Recall for Seat Belts

title: DANCE
description: How Those Feet Can Move, So Quickly and Wildly 'Blues and Buckdancing' Winter Garden

title: Smits Makes Big-Time Plays
description: Suddenly, Rik Smits was looking bigger than usual, which isn't easy for someone 7 feet 4 inches. In the waning minutes of the tuck-and-nip final game of this playoff series, the Pacers' center was waving his long arm in the pivot, seeking the ball. He got it, hit a jump shot, a free throw, and another jump shot, then blocked a shot at the other end as the Pacers slipped past the Knicks, 97-95.

title: U.S. May Let Contractors Run Shuttle
description: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration is developing plans to transfer the operation of the nation's four space shuttles to private industry, a prelude to a day envisioned by many experts when commercial operators will own and fly most of the rockets taking payloads into space.

title: New Schools Seeking Small Miracles
description: Once they were New York City's sturdy castles of learning, immense neighborhood high schools with as many as 5,000 students each that dependably churned out graduates to sustain the city and, sometimes, transform the world. Colin L. Powell went to Morris High School in the Bronx, Barbra Streisand and Bobby Fischer to Erasmus Hall in Brooklyn, Lewis Mumford to Stuyvesant in Manhattan.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Seven years ago, MICHAELE VOLLBRACHT, a fashion designer who dressed people like Elizabeth Taylor and Joan Rivers, abandoned Seventh Avenue and moved to a tiny town in Florida, determined, he said, "to reinvent myself after my business closed."

title: Jerry & Ketchum Receives 3 Accounts
description: The Jerry & Ketchum unit of Ketchum Communications in New York has been awarded three accounts with combined billings estimated at more than $15 million: the Union Camp Corporation, Ruff Hewn and Speedo Authentic Fitness, affiliated with Warnaco Inc. Separately, Warnaco awarded assignments to another New York agency, Balet & Albert.

title: Government Also Adds to Property Values
description: To the Editor:

title: Editorial Notebook; Manhattan's African Dead
description: Dig up 10,000 graves to build a hotel? Plant trees in a cemetery and call it a park? Most New Yorkers would have deep reservations about either enterprise today. Not so in the 18th and 19th centuries, when land-hungry Manhattan was growing at a breakneck pace, and the dead were shunted aside or paved over whenever the need arose. Potters Fields, the "final" resting places for the indigent, were rarely that. The current field, on Hart Island in Long Island Sound, barely escaped development as an amusement park.

title:
Behind the Scenes;
Making a Multitude Of Shaqs
description: While Shaquille O'Neal's Orlando Magic wage war on the real court. Reebok has been running two advertisements that feature O'Neal playing against a team of Shaqs in a mock game.

title: Home Care Saves Costs
description: To the Editor:

title: Popular Is As Popular Dies
description: While "Forest Gump" is on top of both the video rental and sales markets, and even placed in the top 10 albums this week (see story below), the music category offers a look at a subtler dominance. Eight of the top 10 are either rhythm and blues or rap, while those segments account for less than half the overall market.

title: Chirac Assures Kohl on Europe's Monetary Policy
description: On his second day as France's leader last week, President Jacques Chirac went to the border city of Strasbourg to assure Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany that the franc would remain closely tied to the mark and on course for a common European currency by the end of the century.

title: Government Also Adds to Property Values; A Tax to Set It Right
description: To the Editor:

title: Matrix Essentials Selects Avrett, Free
description: Matrix Essentials Inc., which markets professional salon hair care products and cosmetics, has named Avrett, Free & Ginsberg in New York as the first agency to handle its consumer advertising account since Matrix was acquired in August by the Bristol-Myers Squibb Company. The billings were estimated at $15 million.

title: More Awards Programs, More Winners, More Money
description: People love the Academy Awards -- the celebrities, the music, the jokes and the suspense of the most prestigious awards program in show business. The Oscars' broad appeal has created a high price tag for advertisers and a crowd of imitators.

title: Praying While They March
description: At Elohim City, religious services are held daily, sometimes lasting less than an hour, sometimes up to three, said the community's leader, Robert G. Millar.

title: After a Rough Month, Penske's Team Is Shut Out at Indy
description: It's as if they told everyone at the Indianapolis Motor Speedway to turn their cars around and drive clockwise: the 79th Indianapolis 500 will start on Sunday without a car belonging to Roger Penske.

title: Sports of The Times; Knicks and Ewing Gave It Their Last and Best Shot
description: The ball was in the right hands. That's all a team can ask, particularly a team that lived and died doing things the hard way. The New York Knicks got the ball to Patrick Ewing with the game, the season -- and maybe even this era -- on the line.

title: Lloyd's Seeking to End Its Strife With a New Offer for Investors
description: Hoping to put behind it years of ruinous losses and end contentious litigation that has left its future in doubt, Lloyd's of Londonis expected to propose a new settlement offer on Tuesday to the investors who provide its financing.

title: Beachcombers' Express
description: With the weather making it already feel as if it were mid-June, getting to the beaches is becoming a bit easier. New Jersey Transit has begun its special summer service, increasing service to shore points in anticipation of ridership demands. Among the major changes are an extra Friday express train serving shore points, eight additional shuttle trains between Long Beach and Bay Head, and express train service between New York City and Hoboken and shore points on Saturday, Sundays and holidays. GERRY MULLANY

title: World News Briefs; Belgian Ruling Coalition Prevailing in Vote Tally
description: Belgium's governing center-right coalition was expected to maintain its parliamentary majority in national elections today, preliminary results showed. Parties on the far right, which have increased their share of the vote in recent elections, made only modest gains.

title: Baltimore Mayor Urges Yale Graduates to Embrace Nation's Cities
description: Saying that American cities are as vital to the nation as the Sun is to the Earth, Mayor Kurt L. Schmoke of Baltimore urged graduates of Yale University today to live, work and thrive in the nation's urban centers.

title: A Survey Finds the Public More Cynical Than Journalists About Leaders
description: The public thinks the press dwells excessively on negative news. But there is new evidence that members of the public are far more cynical than journalists about the nation's leaders.

title: U.S. Said to Want Huge Recall of Cars
description: Federal safety officials and automobile makers plan to announce what could be the largest auto recall in history on Tuesday to repair defective front seat belts in millions of cars, mini-vans and sport utility vehicles, people close to the talks said today.

title: Changchun Journal; Motor City Keeps Communism in the Driver's Seat
description: Here in China's Motor City, the culture of Communism is changing so slowly that only recently have the city fathers considered changing the name of Stalin Street to something less ideological.

title: And Now, a Scramble in Finance Software
description: The market for personal finance software is going to get very competitive very quickly now that the Microsoft Corporation has dropped its attempt to acquire Intuit Inc. in the face of Justice Department opposition.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW SCHOOLS SEEK SMALL MIRACLES

title: Staying Well With Well Done
description: The problems E. coli bacteria can cause when restaurants undercook meat are well known, but many people do not realize that the same problems can result from barbecued meats that are undercooked. Today, Representative Robert G. Torricelli of Englewood and Senator Bill Bradley, both Democrats, will visit the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey, where they will urge outdoor chefs to cook their burgers and chicken breasts all the way through.

title: Lots of Little Academics Founded With Lots of Bigs Ideas Produce a Variety of Results
description: Over three decades, New York City educators have opened scores of small public academies, including 46 new high schools in the last two years. In the series, all will be profiled, as well as notable older high schools that served as models and the handful of emerging elementary and middle schools. Here is a sampler of schools representing the array of experiments, some successful, some troubled: Science Skills Center for Science, Technology and Creative Arts High School At New York City Technical College, 186 Jay Street, downtown Brooklyn. IDEA: Science and more science. OPENED: 1993. (N.V.) CURRENT ENROLLMENT: 268. PEAK: 750. GRADES: 9 and 10; 9-12 by 1996.

title: U.S. to Auction Bills and Notes
description: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week offers sales of bills and notes, beginning with today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills. Tommorrow the Treasury will auction two-year notes, followed by five-year notes on Wednesday and one-year bills on Thursday.

title: Pilot Dies in Small-Plane Crash
description: The pilot of a single-engine plane was killed after it plunged into the bay surrounding an airfield here on Saturday.

title: Whitman on the 'Farm Team'
description: New Jersey's Governor has been touted as a possible member of the Republican presidential ticket, but this weekend the state had more than its fair share of declared hopefuls for the White House. The Republican aspirants were in Atlantic City for the Northeast Republican Leadership Conference, a three-day meeting of party regulars from 11 northeastern states.

title: She's Having Fun, Fun, Fun in Her Dragster
description: On a road in the mountains of California a few years ago, a car blew a tire. The driver, a trim, young woman with shoulder-length blonde hair and fresh out of college, pulled to the side, climbed out along with her traveling companion, her mother, checked out the damage and went to the trunk to roll out a new tire. A truck pulled behind them and the driver got out. "Need help, ladies?" he asked.

title: With Stiffer Security, Capitol Is Fort Pataki to Some
description: There was once an absolute, almost reckless, freedom to wander the history-heavy halls on the second floor of the State Capitol. With no one to bother them, tourists, lobbyists -- pretty much anyone -- could gaze at oil paintings of governors past and roam within inches of the office of the present one.

title: When Going Gets Tough, Holyfield Summons a Triumph
description: Once again, Evander Holyfield, who believes God is not only guiding him but also will not let him get hurt no matter how many punches to the head he absorbs, pushed himself to the limit.

title: Mason's Move Depends On Who Else Remains
description: Let the record show that his last basket -- and his first field goal of the game -- came with 1 minute 35 seconds left. Anthony Mason put his rump on someone for the zillionth time, blocked out, got position and scored with a soft layup off the glass.

title: Progress Seen In Inquiry Of Officers
description: A California woman has come forward as a witness in what police officials describe as possibly an important break in their investigation of the wild, drunken spree by dozens of New York City officers last weekend in Washington.

title: Lots of Little Academics Founded With Lots of Bigs Ideas Produce a Variety of Results
description: Over three decades, New York City educators have opened scores of small public academies, including 46 new high schools in the last two years. In the series, all will be profiled, as well as notable older high schools that served as models and the handful of emerging elementary and middle schools. Here is a sampler of schools representing the array of experiments, some successful, some troubled:Beginning With Children 11 Bartlett Street, Williamsburg. IDEA: Everybody participates. OPENED: 1993. (C.E.I.) CURRENT ENROLLMENT: 150. PEAK: 350. GRADES: K-3; eventually, K-6.

title: Rangers Give Up Lead, Drop Opener in Overtime
description: If the second round of the Stanley Cup playoffs proceeds according to the script of the first round, the Rangers can be encouraged by their defeat here today.

title: Go. Wait. Go. Wait. Crawl. . . .
description: Ah, summer weekends in New York. Marching for causes, grazing at street fairs and pitying the poor souls who think the best way around town involves internal combustion.

title: Limit on Investors' Suits Is Moving Ahead
description: Senate Republicans are preparing legislation to limit investor lawsuits against companies whose forecasts of their financial prospects prove inaccurate, despite a warning from the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission that such a move could make it easier for swindlers to engage in huge frauds.

title: Hitchcock's Show Is Perfect Tonic for Ailing Yanks
description: Another Yankee victory. Another Yankee injury. At this rate, by the time they return from their nine-game West Coast trip, the Yankees may be in first place in the American League East, but they will look more like the Columbus Clippers than the team they started the season with.

title: Upsala's Last Gasp
description: Upsala College is still alive, at least for another week. The college held its final commencement on May 14, but 38 students who are shy of some credits for graduation are still taking classes at the college, which has been forced to shut down after 102 years because of its crushing debt.

title: A Vision of an Apocalypse: The Religion of the Far Right
description: Six miles up a dirt road that rolls and dips through field and forest, Robert G. Millar presides over a religious community whose partially Hebrew name means City of God. There he proclaims a devastating vision of America's future.

title: Engineer Says He Stole Secrets Of Chip Makers
description: In a bizarre tale of industrial espionage, an Argentine engineer says he stole a wide range of technical secrets from two leading computer chip makers in the United States and provided the information to China, Cuba and Iran.

title: Why Is Green Angry? It's the Little Things.
description: Suppose the most generous being in our universe were to give Dallas Green five singles -- not home runs, not triples, not doubles, just singles -- and allow him to drop them anywhere into this young season. Would the Mets be a much better team, be above .500 and be able to scare the most unshakable of big boppers in the National League East?

title: Lawyer Picked For Treasury
description: President Clinton has nominated John Hawke, a lawyer, to serve as Treasury Under Secretary for domestic finances.

title: Pope Asks Czechs to Forgive Sectarian Wrongs
description: In a message aimed at healing a centuries-old legacy of religious wars and hatreds, Pope John Paul II today asked forgiveness for the wrongs committed by the Roman Catholic Church against Protestants and people of other faiths.

title: Lukas and Entourage Prove Hard to Derail
description: Nick Zito, the last man to win a Triple Crown race who wasn't named D. Wayne Lukas, wrapped Star Standard's legs for the van trip back to New York and the Belmont Stakes, and said, "I don't know if I can stop the freight train, but I'll try."

title: Off to College: 257 Smart Survivors
description: IN the class of '95, they know it's not the way it used to be. In days past, teachers didn't run off with students, and box cutters weren't as familiar as No. 2 pencils, and politicians didn't scorn the New York City schools -- they boasted about them. The young men and women in this year's high school graduating class know all of that.

title: Better Days on the Horizon at Cannes
description: Even the most cockeyed optimists have spent the first few days at this year's Cannes International Film Festival looking fretful. After all, consider these synopses from Saturday's screening schedule: "A freighter has been at sea, unable to land for 18 months because of its cargo of toxic waste." "A husband tries to kill his sexually demanding wife so that he can finally be free to get some sleep." "A senator wakes one morning with an urge to eat snails, so he summons all the villagers to search for them."

title: Devils Wonder How They Let Opening Game Slip Away
description: The Devils were walking around with their heads down today after their 3-2 loss to the Penguins Saturday night. They had trouble figuring out how they were beaten by a tired and defensively depleted Pittsburgh team in the opening game of the four-of-seven-game Eastern Conference semifinal series.

title: Patents; An Injury-Alert System Would Mute Loud Television During Emergency Conversions With the Elderly
description: NEARLY half a million Americans carry personal emergency systems: beeper-like devices that elderly people can wear if a fall or other problem prevents them from calling for help on a telephone. If injured, a button can be pushed on a wireless radio transmitter that is worn like a necklace or wristwatch.

title: Lots of Little Academics Founded With Lots of Bigs Ideas Produce a Variety of Results
description: Over three decades, New York City educators have opened scores of small public academies, including 46 new high schools in the last two years. In the series, all will be profiled, as well as notable older high schools that served as models and the handful of emerging elementary and middle schools. Here is a sampler of schools representing the array of experiments, some successful, some troubled: The Choir Academy of Harlem 2005 Madison Avenue. IDEA: Boys and girls who sing. OPENED:1993. CURRENT ENROLLMENT: 450. PEAK: 600; 175 will be girls. GRADES: 4-11; in September, 4-12.

title: Pomp, Circumstance and Suspense: 5 Vie for Valedictorian
description: For much of this school year, Cindy Huang had eyed her fellow brainy classmates at Brooklyn Technical High School with even more anxiety than usual. Last week in particular, when the neck-and-neck race for valedictorian came down to the wire, when mere decimal points separated the five top students, Cindy felt unbearably curious about how the other four were doing.

title: How the Tailhook Party Turned Into a Scandal
description: In the American vocabulary, Tailhook has become a dirty word. Tonight's ABC movie, though weakened with name changes and composite characters, does a serviceable job of explaining why. "She Stood Alone: The Tailhook Scandal" tells the story of Lieut. Paula Coughlin, who went public about being forced to walk a male gantlet at the Navy's 1991 Tailhook Convention in Las Vegas, Nev.

title: Government Also Adds to Property Values; Wetlands Protection
description: To the Editor:

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the scheduled release dates for major economic indicators this week. Monday None Tuesday None Wednesday Durable-Goods Orders . . . April Thursday Weekly Jobless Claims Friday None

title: Spaghetti-O's Keep on Going
description: Fettuccine Alfredo has come and gone as a trendy dish, yet some pastas are more durable: Spaghetti-O's, for instance. Thirty years ago tomorrow, the Camden-based Campbell Soup Company first released the circular-shaped pasta, and to this day the company still sells tens of millions of cans of it annually.

title: Planning for Memorial Day
description: On May 29, the United States will observe its 41st Memorial Day. Before 1954, the holiday was called Decoration Day, when the graves of Civil War veterans were decorated. This year marks the 50th anniversary of the end of World War II, as well as the 20th anniversary of the end of the Vietnam War. Of the nation's 26 million veterans, 2 million are residents of the metropolitan area. IN CONNECTICUT A memorial service to honor those who died and fought on Iwo Jima during World War II begins at noon on May 29 at the Iwo Jima Monument in Newington. NEW JERSEY Vietnam veterans were honored on May 7, with the opening of the New Jersey Vietnam Veterans Memorial in Holmdel. Though there are no special services planned for Memorial Day, the monument is open 24 hours a day, seven days a week. NEW YORK The Albany County Memorial Day Parade will begin at 9:30 A.M. and a service will be held at 11 A.M. at the steps of the State Capitol across the street from the Vietnam and Korean War memorials.

title: The Empty Chair
description: For the much-troubled CBS, bad news has come in such bunches that the network's executives were hard pressed this weekend to measure exactly how serious the impact will be from the latest unwanted development: the removal of Connie Chung from her anchor chair on "CBS Evening News."

title: Berlusconi Says Business Was Victim, Not Extorter
description: The confrontation between Italy's anti-corruption magistrates and former Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi swelled today after the magistrates' decision Saturday to press for the trial of Mr. Berlusconi on corruption charges.

title: Gates, the Pragmatist, Walked Away
description: Bill Gates, the billionaire co-founder of Microsoft, seems to attract admiration and fear in equal measure. In the computer industry and in government circles, he has been called everything from a brilliant inventor-entrepreneur to a ruthless monopolist. Some see him as the Thomas Edison of the information age; others see John D. Rockefeller.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: Taking Another Turn In the Spotlight Colin Carr, cellist Merkin Concert Hall

title: New Details On Review Of Car Plan In Suffolk
description: An investigative report released today offers new details about assertions that the Suffolk County District Attorney, James M. Catterson Jr., used intimidation to discourage questions about a car-leasing plan written by his son, a deputy county attorney.

title: Devils Rebound With a Determined Effort
description: The Devils could have collapsed tonight when Jaromir Jagr's second goal of the game went in off one of their players' skates and tied things with 75 seconds left in the third period. But the Devils came back for a 4-2 victory that tied their four-of-seven-game playoff series with the Penguins at one game apiece.

title: Rowland and Democrats Reach Agreement on $204 Million in Concessions From Unions
description: Resolving one of the thorniest issues in his proposed budget, Governor John G. Rowland, a Republican, and the Speaker of the House, Thomas D. Ritter, a Democrat, announced today that they had reached an agreement with state labor unions for $204 million in concessions.

title: Accounts
description: * Lenscrafters, the retail eyewear division of the United States Shoe Corporation, which is being acquired by Luxottica Group S.p.A. of Italy, to BBDO New York, a unit of the Omnicom Group, to handle the media buying and planning portions of its account, with billings estimated at $40 million. Those duties had previously been handled by Media That Works, Cincinnati. Deutsch Inc., New York, handles the creative portion. * Great Scott Inc., Katonah, N.Y., to Kirshenbaum Bond & Partners, New York, as the first agency to handle the toy marketer's account. The billings were estimated at $8.5 million. * Hockeyland Corp., Los Angeles, to Eisaman, Johns & Laws, Los Angeles, as the first agency to handle the account of the ice-themed entertainment centers. The billings were estimated at $4 million to $6 million.

title: If the Knicks' Future Is Now, Where Do They Go From Here?
description: When the Knicks hold their farewell meeting today, they will also say farewell to their roster in its present form.

title: Excerpts From the Supreme Court's Decision in Term-Limits Case
description: Following are excerpts from the Supreme Court's ruling today in U.S. Term Limits v. Thornton, holding that states may not limit the terms of their representatives in Congress. Justice John Paul Stevens wrote the majority opinion, which was joined by Justices David H. Souter, Ruth Bader Ginsburg, Stephen G. Breyer and Anthony M. Kennedy, who also filed a concurring opinion. Justice Clarence Thomas wrote the dissenting opinion, which was joined by Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist and by Justices Sandra Day O'Connor and Antonin Scalia. FROM THE DECISION By Justice Stevens

title: Molecular Tools May Offer Clues To Reducing Risks of Birth Defects
description: VIRTUALLY every scientist who has ever studied birth defects has been haunted by the same question: why are some babies born with devastating defects when their mothers have taken drugs like the sedative thalidomide or the acne drug Accutane or the epilepsy drug dilantin, while others with the same exposure are unscathed?

title: For Benefit, A Dancer In 'Salome'
description: Patrick Dupond tends to stand out for his blond good looks and for his way of marrying ballet pyrotechnics to abandon. But his performance tonight at City Center in "Salome," a solo created for him in 1985 by Maurice Bejart, promises to reach a new level of extroversion.

title: Corrections
description: A group of tables in Business Day yesterday under the heading "Most Wanted," listing media and software sales in various categories and the performance of media and technology stocks, carried incorrect dates. The tables covered the week of May 15 through May 19, not 22 through 26.

title: County Official Indicted On Ties to Closed School
description: A powerful Essex County official was indicted today over his ties to a crumbling, rat-infested former factory that the troubled Newark school district used as a makeshift elementary school for 21 years. The accusations were the latest attack by prosecutors on a political culture that they say often revolves around cronyism and other backroom dealings.

title: Man Indicted In the Death Of Gerulaitis
description: A Long Island grand jury has indicted a mechanic and his employer for criminally negligent homicide in the death of the tennis star Vitas Gerulaitis, who the authorities said died of carbon monoxide poisoning from a faulty swimming-pool heating system.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball American League CLEVELAND INDIANS -- Activated Paul Shuey, pitcher, from the 15-day disabled list and optioned him to Buffalo of the American Association.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Committee Will Study Police Conduct in Public
description: With the investigation into a drunken spree by New York police officers in Washington making little progress, Police Commissioner William J. Bratton said yesterday that he was forming an internal committee to look into police conduct to avert similar incidents at future public events.

title: Partnerships Help Create New Schools
description: Over three decades, New York City educators have opened scores of small public academies, including 46 high schools in the last two years. In the series, all the new high schools are profiled, as well as older ones that served as models and some elementary and middle schools organized according to the same principles. As this listing shows, the founding of the schools has often involved unusual collaborations. A number have been sponsored by educational reformers working with organizations like community groups, colleges, churches and even a labor union. Community Service Schools East Brooklyn Congregations High School for Public Service, Bushwick, and East Brooklyn Congregations High School for Public Service, East New York Both at 1495 Herkimer Street.

title: Albany's Unsound Tax Cuts
description: Gov. George Pataki and the Democrats in the New York State Legislature have reached agreement on an income tax cut that should help resolve the divisive budget battles of 1995 on terms that both sides can claim as some sort of victory. But their agreement will undermine New York's financial integrity. While scaled back from Mr. Pataki's original proposal, the tax cut is still too drastic to be carried out without further rupturing state services and aid to localities.

title: How to Save Social Security
description: Because we belong to opposing parties, the public might presume that we disagree on everything. But there is one critical matter on which we find common ground. We both believe that the time has come to re-examine some of the fundamental premises of the Social Security system. This is Social Security's 60th anniversary year. The needs of retired Americans have changed radically in six decades. Social Security deserves radical change, too.

title: Foreman Calls for Mandatory Head Gear
description: After the death of another boxer from brain injuries suffered in the ring, GEORGE FOREMAN says headgear should be mandatory. "I'd do it right now," he said of wearing a headgear in a fight. "When is the right time? Now. Oh, man, it's going to be the most revolutionary and compassionate thing that's been done for boxing. The day has come. It's only going to be for the betterment of the sport."

title: Keep Politics Out of Embassy Move in Israel
description: To the Editor:

title: Plants and Animals Save Human Lives
description: To the Editor:

title: Plant Plays Host to Ants, and Reaps the Benefits
description: RESEARCHERS have shown that a rootless tropical plant shelters ants in its saclike leaves because the insects in turn supply it with key nutrients.
