College or Career Preparation Middle College High School At Medgar Evers College, 402 Eastern Parkway, Crown Heights.

title: Peter van de Kamp, Astronomer And Musician at Swarthmore, 93
description: Peter van de Kamp, an astronomer who delighted in peering into the farthest reaches of the heavens and in playing piano accompaniment for silent movies, died on Thursday in Middenbeemster, the Netherlands. He was 93.

title: More Extremes Found in Weather, Pointing to Greenhouse Gas Effect
description: CLIMATE scientists have long predicted that an intensifying greenhouse effect would make for a more extreme climate, and the especially turbulent weather of recent years has suggested that the predictions might be coming true.

title: A Court for Family Drama
description: Although largely unknown to the public, Manhattan Surrogate's Court is the stage upon which many sagas about dying wishes and living desires are played out -- and money, property and family heirlooms are distributed.

title: Decision Opens Door for 72 To Seek Re-election to House
description: Today was liberation day for the United States Congress.

title: Ogilvy & Mather Gets Food Account
description: The Van den Bergh Foods Company, a unit of Unilever N.V., said yesterday that it had named Ogilvy & Mather New York as the first agency to handle advertising for a new product, Five Brothers Premium Pasta Sauce. The billings were estimated at $15 million.

title: BOWATER'S BUSINESS-FORMS UNIT IS PUT ON SALE
description: Bowater Inc. placed its business-forms unit on sale yesterday, to raise cash that may be used for an acquisition. Bowater, the paper and forest products concern based in Greenville. S.C., has hired CS First Boston to advise it on the sale of Bowater Communications Papers Inc.

title: CHRONICLE
description: He was the first grandchild of President Harry S. Truman and the son of MARGARET TRUMAN, the mystery writer, and CLIFTON DANIEL, the former managing editor of The New York Times, but even that pedigree didn't assure CLIFTON TRUMAN DANIEL a smooth passage into adulthood.

title: Speaking Out on Income Credit
description: They work and they pay their bills with some help from the Federal tax code. Today, members of three New Jersey households will join Senator Bill Bradley at a news conference to protest a Republican plan to cut the earned income tax credit for low-income families. They are Linda Bailey of Elizabeth, Michael Thompson of Newark and Deborah Hammerstrung of Barnegat.

title: Man Joined to Machine at 220 M.P.H.
description: The strongest impression left by "Fast Cars," tonight's episode of the PBS science series "Nova," is that the faster you drive, the more blurred becomes the distinction between human and machine.

title:
ALTERNATIVE SCHOOLS;
Partnerships Help Create New Schools
description: Over three decades, New York City educators have opened scores of small public academies, including 46 high schools in the last two years. In the series, all the new high schools are profiled, as well as older ones that served as models and some elementary and middle schools organized according to the same principles. As this listing shows, the founding of the schools has often involved unusual collaborations. A number have been sponsored by educational reformers working with organizations like community groups, colleges, churches and even a labor union. Moms, Dads, Neighbors Bridges to Brooklyn At Junior High School 232, 905 Winthrop Street, East Flatbush.

title: Patterns
description: Searle Branches Out

title: Humility and Limits In U.S. Foreign Policy
description: TEMPTATIONS OF A SUPERPOWER By Ronald Steel 144 pages. Harvard University Press. $18.95.

title: Carrying Torch for Science
description: Students from Governor Livingston Regional High School here carried the torch for New Jersey in the National Science Olympiad. The competition last weekend at Indiana University involved such events as cell biology and the science of fitness. More than 12,000 schools participated in the Olympiad; 52 made it to the finals, where Governor Livingston finished 25th. SUSAN JO KELLER

title: A Ratings To-Do Over a Raw Tale Of City Teen-Agers
description: Two new films stirred fierce reactions here today, and it would be hard to imagine a greater disparity. Ken Loach's "Land and Freedom" captures the ringing idealism of Republican volunteers fighting the Spanish Civil War, and does this so well it stands a good chance of being mentioned at awards time. Mr. Loach directs with impressive immediacy even when working on a grand scale to tell his story. Not even an in-depth discussion of agrarian reform really slows his film down.

title: Lee Nordness, 72, Art Dealer Who Promoted Crafts, Dies
description: Lee Nordness, an art dealer in New York who organized the international traveling exhibitions of American art and crafts for Johnson Wax, died last Tuesday at a nursing home in Newcastle, Wash. He was 72 and had until recently lived in Belfair, Wash., west of Seattle.

title: Owners Aiming to Keep Raiders in L.A.
description: Few rivalries in the National Football League compare with the Raiders and Chiefs, a colorful affair full of big games and big plays and Hall of Fame players.

title: International Briefs; Spanish Unit of VW Agrees to Layoffs
description: Unions and management at Volkswagen's Spanish unit, Sociedad Espanola de Automoviles de Turisme, or SEAT, agreed to lay off 8,875 workers for 15 days, to slow production and offset declining sales. The workers will be laid off from SEAT's plants at Zona Franca and Martorell from June 5-9 and for 10 more days later in the year, the company said in a statement. The additional dates will be decided by the company, the statement said. SEAT has a total of 12,500 employees.

title: Review/Fashion; Fur Tradition Versus Fur Fun
description: Furs have long been treated like fashion's troublesome stepsister, shunted to the industry's back rooms to be trotted out when convenient, as when lucrative licenses are at stake, or at some future date when fur may again represent the zenith of high living. But the collective presentation furriers mounted for the first time last week highlighted an emerging rift between designers and furriers who are looking forward to a fur renaissance and those who believe fur's future lies in what was done in the past.

title: Budget Dispute Erupts Over Loans and Grants to Businesses
description: A new dispute emerged today in negotiations over the state budget, now 52 days late, over whether the State Commissioner of Economic Development should be given greater discretion in giving out tens of millions of dollars in low-interest loans and grants to businesses.

title: Stocks Stage a Sharp Rebound; the Dow Rises 54.30 Points
description: The stock market snapped back yesterday, but some analysts warned that there would be more "corrections" to come like last week's 89-point drop in the Dow Jones industrial average.

title: By Design; Beyond the Basic Pump
description: All the fluctuations in the lengths and shapes of clothes in the last few years have brought about seemingly endless changes in shoes. It's reached the point where the basic pump looks too boring to contemplate.

title: Mexico Strikes at Drug Trade
description: In an important policy shift, Mexico's President has ordered the military to take a greater role in the anti-narcotics fight. Page A3.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Daily Briefing column in New Jersey copies on May 15 misspelled the surname of the new president of the Medical Society of New Jersey. He is Louis L. Keeler, not Keller.

title: Japanese Too Suffer From Trade Barriers
description: To the Editor:

title: Healing the Sick In the Stratosphere
description: "White Dwarf," the television movie on Fox this evening, is certainly different. It will never be confused with, say, a tacky film biography of Madonna or of O. J. Simpson. Among the executive producers are Bruce Wagner and Francis Ford Coppola, whose last collaboration was the mini-series "Wild Palms," a haunting excursion into virtual reality.

title: Navratilova's Hiring Is HBO Master Stroke
description: Last week, the newly retired Joe Montana crossed the line from being suspicious of the news media to being an employee of the media, signing on as a part-timer on NBC's "N.F.L. Live." Yesterday, Martina Navratilova, semiretired tennis icon, agreed to work as a commentator at Wimbledon for HBO Sports.

title: Prosecutor Is Named in Bombing Case
description: The Justice Department today named a Government lawyer from Illinois to head the Federal team that will prosecute the Oklahoma City bombing case.

title: Unfortunately Following In a Mother's Footsteps
description: "RosaLee's Story," the grim eight-part photo report from the inner city for which for its reporter, Leon Dash, and its photographer, Lucian Perkins, were given their Pulitzer Prize yesterday, caused a considerable stir when it ran in The Washington Post in September. Liberally inclined readers feared that this unsparing account of crime, drug use and generational disarray in a black family would be grist for opponents of welfare programs, already under fierce attack around the country.

title: Hachette in Venture to Buy Premiere Magazine
description: Hachette Publications Inc., which has been on a aggressive expansion campaign, has joined with New World Communications Group to acquire Premiere magazine from K-III Holdings.

title: Cinerama v. Technicolor: A Suit That Has Wall Street's Attention
description: Wall Street will be watching as a three-judge panel of the Delaware Supreme Court meets today to review a long-running lawsuit challenging Ronald O. Perelman's acquisition of Technicolor Inc. in 1982.

title: Which Came First: Bees or Flowers? Find Points to Bees
description: BEFORE time turned them to stone at least 220 million years ago, the fossilized logs of the Petrified Forest in eastern Arizona stood as tall trees in a tropical environment. Many of them, scientists have now discovered, still bear traces of insect nests the trees once harbored. The logs are riddled with holes containing little chambers strung together in lines or clusters, nearly everything about them resembling the nests of modern bees.

title:
1995 N.H.L PLAYOFFS;
Penguins Lament a Defensive Lapse
description: With twenty-nine seconds left in regulation, with the Civic Arena crowd still giddy from the Penguins' game-tying goal 46 seconds earlier, Pittsburgh's patchwork defense left its goaltender, Ken Wregget, defenseless. Again.

title: Beastie Boys Shifted
description: A Beastie Boys concert that was to have been at Madison Square Garden tomorrow night has been rescheduled for tonight at 8. The date was changed to accommodate the third game of the National Hockey League playoff series between the New York Rangers and the Philadelphia Flyers. Tickets with tomorrow's date will be honored tonight. Ticket holders unable to attend tonight may receive refunds by presenting their tickets at the places of purchase. Information: (212) 465-6751.

title: Auction of Collectibles on the Internet
description: Hoping to bring excitement -- and paying customers -- to the world of on-line shopping, a Silicon Valley start-up company opened an Internet auction service yesterday. The service plans to offer rare and collectible goods including fine wines, autographed basketball jerseys, vintage computer equipment and rock 'n' roll memorabilia.

title: More Troubles for Upsala
description: Upsala College's headaches are not over. Carolyn V. Meacham, a Councilwoman here, said yesterday that she wants a state investigation of how the school spent a $3.5 million loan from the Essex County Improvement Authority. Ms. Meacham said that the money was gone and that the school did not use it for the projects specified, including a soccer field and library improvements.

title: Roenick Gets Green Light for Blackhawks
description: The wait is over for JEREMY ROENICK. It is time to play hockey. Out since injuring his knee on April 2, the Chicago Blackhawks' best player and emotional leader will return tonight against the Vancouver Canucks in the National Hockey League's Western Conference semifinals. Chicago won Sunday's series opener, 2-1 in overtime. "I'm not going to be the most dominant player," Roenick said yesterday, "but I expect to make good plays."

title: Judge Removes The Executors Of Duke Estate
description: A Manhattan surrogate ruled yesterday that the former butler to the late tobacco heiress Doris Duke had used her fortune to finance his own "profligate life style" and as a result was unfit to be executor of the $1.2 billion estate.

title: Clinton's Aid To Industry Is A G.O.P. Target
description: Buried among the Republicans' sharp cost-cutting proposals to balance the Federal budget is the swift dismantling of two of the Clinton Administration's most prominent economic innovations: the use of the Government to promote exports and the underwriting of new technologies that corporate America considers too risky.

title: SOCCER REPORT
description: European Champions Cup

title: Prudential Hires Chase Officer
description: The Prudential Insurance Company of America has hired an executive from the Chase Manhattan Corporation, Mark Grier, as its new chief financial officer. He is the third Chase executive to leave for the insurer since November.

title: Prices for Bonds End Mixed Ahead of Fed Policy Session
description: Prices of Treasury securities were mixed yesterday in thin trading in advance of today's meeting of the Federal Reserve's Open Market Committee and this week's auctions of new Treasury securities.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Movie stars sign scraps of paper thrust at them, and authors sign title pages of their books. JORG R. JUNG INGER signs the paws or sometimes the identification tags of stuffed animals, and that's just what he was doing on Saturday at F. A. O. Schwarz, where owners of Steiff animals lined up to get his autograph.

title: Electrical Workers Go on Line
description: Bell Atlantic and a major union tentatively agreed yesterday on a five-year contract with raises totaling 14.5 percent over five years, job security guarantees and incentives for more training. The company also won the right to experiment with having employees work at home via computers and a four-day work week for some of the 9,500 employees represented by the electrical workers' union.

title: Chechnya Adversaries Are Said To Agree to Direct Peace Talks
description: European security officials said today that the leader of the separatist rebels in the southern region of Chechnya has agreed to take part in direct peace talks with representatives of the Russian Government in Grozny later this week.

title: In the News: Many Part-Timers
description: When a community awards dinner sponsored by The Jersey Journal was picketed last night, there were plenty of reporters around who could have covered the story. Except that they were the ones picketing. Members of the Journal's chapter of the Newspaper Guild are unhappy because they say management hires too many freelancers and part-time workers.

title: International Briefs; Head of Alcatel Unit Is Under Investigation
description: The head of Alcatel Alsthom S.A.'s Generale Occidentale unit is under investigation by a French magistrate, continuing a string of inquiries into the company and its executives.

title: Brothers Sentenced for Extortion
description: Taking illegal Christmas gifts, pressuring people to get jobs for relatives and extorting $500,000 to insure labor peace -- these misdeeds and more will send two Passaic County brothers to prison for 44 months each. Joseph Labarck Sr. and Raymond Labarck, former leaders of Local 1733 of the textile workers union, were sentenced yesterday in Federal District Court.

title: Serbia Rejects New U.S. Plan On Bosnia War
description: President Slobodan Milosevic of Serbia has rejected an American-backed plan that would suspend many economic sanctions against his country in return for his recognizing Bosnia, Administration officials said today.

title: Wilson Joins Cowboys as Backup Passer
description: The Dallas Cowboys signed quarterback WADE WILSON yesterday as a backup for TROY AIKMAN. Wilson, 36, played for the New Orleans Saints last season. He appeared in only three games, completing 15 of 20 passes for 124 yards. Wilson played for the Minnesota Vikings and Atlanta Falcons before signing as a free agent with New Orleans in 1993. (AP)

title: Trade Dispute Between U.S. and Japan Moves to Paris
description: The United States and Japan brought their bitter trade dispute to the European Continent today, with senior representatives from both sides accusing each other of using misleading figures on Japanese imports of American autos.

title: Russia's New Rulers Govern, And Live, in Neo-Soviet Style
description: When Leonid I. Brezhnev was alive and ailing, the Soviet leader entrusted his health and astrological fate to a well-known psychic healer. In the increasingly superstitious Kremlin of President Boris N. Yeltsin, that role is filled by a high-ranking officer of the widely feared presidential security service, who is said to monitor the President's health and horoscopes.

title: Teacher Now Regrets Fleeing With Student
description: Glenn Harris, the junior high school gym teacher who faces a kidnapping charge for running away with a 15-year-old student, emerged from court yesterday with some advice for anyone considering a similar move: don't do it.

title: ISRAEL SUSPENDS ITS PLAN TO SEIZE LAND IN JERUSALEM
description: Retreating on an issue that had put it in political peril at home and abroad, the Israeli Government suspended its plans today to confiscate land in largely Palestinian areas of Jerusalem.

title: G.O.P. Senators Hold the Line Against Budget Amendments
description: As the Senate moved toward a vote on Wednesday on a general framework for Government spending over the next seven years, Democratic senators tried to score politically by forcing Republicans into uncomfortable votes against popular health and education programs.

title: Collision Over Walkouts
description: Lawyers for the Whitman administration and the state's largest union clashed in court yesterday over whether Division of Motor Vehicles employees who received layoff notices on Friday left their posts as part of an organized job action or were simply too upset to remain at work.

title: Sports of The Times; It's Not The Same Hextall
description: WHEN the Rangers were about to complete their six-game scorching of the Quebec Nordiques last week in the opening round of the Stanley Cup playoffs, the mountain lions up on the slopes above the tree line at Madison Square Garden were in full cry.

title: George Abbott Memorial
description: A memorial for George Abbott, the Broadway showman who died on Jan. 31 at the age of 107, is to be held on June 5 at noon at the Majestic Theater, 247 West 44th Street, Manhattan. It will be produced by the director Harold Prince and by Mr. Abbott's widow, Joy. Among those who are to speak or perform are Carol Burnett, Jerome Robbins, Betty Comden, Adolph Green, Natalia Makarova, Kitty Carlisle Hart, Gwen Verdon, Ray Walston, John Kander, Fred Ebb, Lucie Arnaz and some members of the cast of "Damn Yankees." Admission is free and will be first come first served.

title: New Studies Confirm Pesticide-Cancer Link
description: To the Editor:

title: N.F.L. May Rule Bandanas Out of Action
description: DEION SANDERS may have to do without his bandana next season.

title: Radio Stations Sold by WHX
description: The WHX Corporation said yesterday that it had sold all its radio stations in two separate deals. The terms of the sales, to Segue Communications Inc. and Patterson Broadcasting Inc., were not disclosed.

title: Pullach Journal; In Battle of Beer Garden, Bavaria Bares Its Soul
description: The leaves are greening, the ale is flowing and, at Sepp Kratz's beer garden here, there's revolution in the air.

title: Drama Desk Honors 'Show Boat'
description: "Show Boat" led in the 1995 Drama Desk Awards on Sunday night, winning the prize for outstanding musical and four more: for best director, Harold Prince; set design, Eugene Lee; lighting, Richard Pilbrow, and costumes, Florence Klotz.

title: People
description: * Stephani Cook was named executive vice president for strategic planning at Lowe & Partners/SMS, New York, a unit of the Interpublic Group of Cos., assuming responsibilities from Martyn Straw, executive director for account planning, who left to join N. W. Ayer & Partners, New York, as a managing director. Ms. Cook was previously a senior principal and strategic planning director at Publicis/Bloom, New York, a unit of Publicis S.A.

title: Ghana, Despite Its Successes, Is Swept by Anti-Tax Protests
description: With a record of consistent growth, Ghana has been touted as one of Africa's economic successes. But prosperity has eluded most Ghanaians, and with the approach of elections scheduled for 1996 they appear to be growing increasingly impatient with President Jerry Rawlings and his 13-year rule.

title: Top Business Court Under Fire; Critics Say Politics Is Hurting Delaware Judiciary
description: The Delaware judicial system, chief arbiter of right and wrong in corporate America, is on trial.

title: Partnerships Help Create New Schools
description: Over three decades, New York City educators have opened scores of small public academies, including 46 high schools in the last two years. title: Chess
description: The New York Open Tournament, April 12 to 16, was won by Pavel Blatny, a Czech grandmaster who scored a heavy 8-1 in the nine-round Swiss system event. Blatny was awarded a $10,000 first prize.

title: Former Head of WMX Technologies Returns to the Waste Industry
description: H. Wayne Huizenga, who helped build WMX Technologies Inc. into the world's largest waste-handling company before taking over the Blockbuster video chain, is returning to the trash business.

title: Julian Whittlesey, Archeologist And Architect, 89
description: Julian Hill Whittlesey, an architect who was concerned with large-scale housing projects and city planning for three decades and then went on to work as an archeologist in the 1960's, died on Saturday at his home in Wilton, Conn. He was 89.

title: Orange County Loses Insurer On Bond Issue
description: The financial recovery plan of Orange County took another blow yesterday as MBIA Inc. said that it was withdrawing its insurance backing from the California county's proposed $275 million recovery bond issue.

title: Gray Eminence of Classical Music's Stars
description: He wields classical music's biggest baton, conducting conductors, orchestrating orchestras, giving voice to vocalists. But his name is not to be found on concert hall marquees or opera kiosks. When it comes to publicity, Ronald A. Wilford is happy to be Orpheus's silent partner.

title: AT&T ALLOWS APPLE'S VIDEOCONFERENCING ON ITS NETWORK
description: The AT&T Corporation and Apple Computer Inc. announced an agreement yesterday to allow Apple's videoconferencing software to run over AT&T's network. AT&T, the nation's largest network company, previously had arrangements with the makers of I.B.M.-compatible personal computers and Unix-based work stations. The new agreement lets owners of Apple's computers using Quick-Time Conferencing technology to have video conferences with all others linked through a service that AT&T markets as Worldworx. Quick-Time Conferencing technology, a software-based architecture, lets personal computer users communicate via audio, video and data.

title: Recognize Vietnam
description: Twenty years have passed since the North Vietnamese Communists won the Vietnam War, but Washington has yet to extend full diplomatic relations to Hanoi. With specialists satisfied that Vietnam is cooperating fully in the search for remains of missing Americans, President Clinton should take the advice of top aides and recognize Vietnam before 1996 election pressures encourage further delay.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt * AT&T Corp., New York, filed a shelf registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission for the sale of as much as $3 billion of notes and warrants.

title: Kidnapping Victim Describes the Ordeal of Being Buried
description: A businessman held hostage in a pit for $5 million in ransom gave his first public account of his 13-day ordeal yesterday, telling a court that he thought his life was about to end when he heard his captors shoveling dirt.

title: Minority Scholarship Plans Are Dealt Setback by Court
description: The Supreme Court today let stand a lower-court ruling that a scholarship program intended exclusively for blacks at the University of Maryland was unconstitutional.

title: Weight Watchers Account in Review
description: The Weight Watchers International unit of the H. J. Heinz Company in Jericho, L.I., said yesterday that it had placed in review a second account, with billings estimated at $25 million. For the last year, the account has been at Doig, Elliott, Schur in New York, which was spun off from the New York office of the Earle Palmer Brown Companies.

title: Christian Leaders Searching For Political Middle Ground
description: Saying that the United States is caught in a spiritual crisis worsened by overly politicized churches, a broadly ecumenical group of Christian leaders is releasing a statement calling for a verbal "cease-fire" and a search for common ground untainted by partisan ideology.

title: Study Finds Little Male Responsibility in Birth Control
description: Nearly two-thirds of American men do not think they can be counted on to choose a birth control method, and women agree with them, according to a poll released yesterday.

title: CBS and Connie Chung Continue Negotiations
description: Dan Rather signed off the "CBS Evening News" last night saying that Connie Chung's future was "still under consideration and discussion," after a day in which the network and Ms. Chung continued to negotiate her departure.

title: Bank of New York to Acquire Morgan's Custody Businesses
description: The Bank of New York Company plans to buy J. P. Morgan & Company's global custody business, one of the world's largest, according to a memorandum distributed at Bank of New York.

title: Standing Taller Among Centers
description: "Bum." "Stiff." "Giant flop." These were just some of the sweet nothings hurled at Rik Smits by Indiana Pacers' fans over the last several years, and sentiments often shared by sports commentators when the 7-foot-4-inch center from the Netherlands failed to meet their lofty expectations.

title: Corrections
description: An italic note at the end of an article yesterday about experimental small schools in New York City misstated the name of a school being profiled today as part of the same series. It is El Puente Academy for Peace and Justice, not El Puente Academy for Peace and Freedom.

description: Mules

title: The U.S.-China Slide; A Relationship Strained by Trade Tension Could Worsen Further Over Taiwan Flap
description: With President Clinton's decision to overrule 16 years of American policy and allow the leader of what China considers to be a renegade province, Taiwan, to visit the United States, the decline of United States-China relations during the Clinton Presidency is about to get worse.

title: MCI BUYS NATIONWIDE CELLULAR FOR $190 MILLION
description: The MCI Communications Corporation made a move yesterday to get into the United States cellular market by acquiring Nationwide Cellular Service Inc. for about $18.50 a share in cash, or about $190 million. Nationwide is the largest United States reseller of cellular services. MCI is the No. 2 United States long-distance company after AT&T. Under the agreement, Nationwide shareholders will also get 0.38 share of the Cellular Technical Services Company. Nationwide Cellular, based in Valley Stream, L.I., owns 38 percent of Cellular Technical Services. Nationwide shares rose $6.1875 yesterday, to $23.6875, in Nasdaq trading while MCI shares were up 12.5 cents, to $21. Cellular Technical Services shares were down 12.5 cents at $18.625.

title: Maurice Saatchi and Cordiant Call a Truce
description: In a surprise ending to one of the nastiest disputes ever to roil the advertising industry, Maurice Saatchi and Cordiant P.L.C. said yesterday that they had settled all outstanding legal issues, effective immediately.

title: Keep Politics Out of Embassy Move in Israel; Yes to Jersusalem
description: To the Editor:

title: Vaccine for Hanta Virus Found Safe in Early Test
description: Army scientists have developed a vaccine against hanta virus infection, and initial tests on a small group of people indicate that it is safe and stimulates the immune system to defend against the virus, the researchers said today at a scientific meeting here.

title: HIGH COURT BLOCKS TERM LIMITS FOR CONGRESS IN A 5-4 DECISION
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that in the absence of a constitutional amendment, neither states nor Congress may limit the number of terms that members of Congress can serve. The vote was 5 to 4.

title: Giuliani Obtains a Delay On a Shift in Bond Ratings
description: After an unusual last-minute joint plea from Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and leaders of the City Council, a major bond-rating agency agreed yesterday to hold off a possible downgrade of the city's bond rating, at least until after the city and state budgets are settled.

title: Mattingly, O'Neill Set To Put Pop In Lineup
description: If all goes well, Paul O'Neill and Don Mattingly will return to the lineup together for the first time in 12 games tonight when the Yankees open a nine-game West Coast trip against the California Angels in Anaheim.

title: Lexmark Narrows A Review to 2 Shops
description: Lexmark International, a manufacturer of printers, keyboards and other computer-related equipment in Greenwich, Conn., said yesterday that the review on its account, with billings estimated at $10 million to $15 million, had been narrowed to two agencies from four. The account was previously at Ammirati & Puris/Lintas in New York, a unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies, until that agency resigned in February as part of an effort to concentrate on larger accounts.

title: No Headline

description: Secretary of State Warren Christopher said today that he was urging President Clinton to veto a bill in the House of Representatives that would cut foreign aid and eliminate three foreign affairs agencies.

description: The Fonar Corporation won a Federal jury verdict on Friday in a patent trial against the General Electric Company. The decision could provide a big financial lift for Fonar, a tiny maker of magnetic resonance imaging machines.

description: The bankruptcy filing by the two partnerships that own Rockefeller Center caused the company that holds the mortgage to it to report sharply wider first-quarter losses yesterday.

description: Nellcor Inc. said today that it would acquire the Puritan-Bennett Corporation for about $457 million in stock, expanding its line of patient monitoring and respiratory care systems.

description: The Mets did not know much about him. Dave Mlicki had pitched just 35 major league innings before he was traded to New York from Cleveland last winter. He was one season removed from shoulder surgery, which is always a concern. He had not proven much in his career.

title: On My Mind; Voyage of the Damned
description: On May 13, 1939, the German passenger ship St. Louis left Hamburg, sailing for Havana. On board were 930 Jewish refugees, all carrying landing certificates for Cuba.

description: Here are a few facts now known about George Elmer Pataki, near the end of his first four months as Governor:

title: Dirty Cars in U.S. Foul Up the Seat Belts, Japanese Say
description: Japanese Government officials and auto industry spokesmen offered an explanation today for the reason American drivers might be having trouble with their Japanese-made seat belts: Their cars are too dirty.

title: Serious Crimes Fall for Third Year, but Experts Warn Against Seeing Trend
description: The number of serious crimes reported to the police declined in 1994 for the third straight year, according to an F.B.I. report released on Sunday. But experts cautioned that it would be premature to conclude that crime rates were exhibiting a long-term downward trend.

title: Coke Goes Better With I.B.M. Deal

description: EMI Music, the only major record company that is not part of a diversified media conglomerate, is leaping into multimedia.

title: 10 Companies Join in Effort to Lower Bids by H.M.O.'s
description: More than 100 health maintenance organizations are bidding this week for a chance to offer standardized health coverage to 240,000 employees of 10 big companies. The bidding is the employers' latest effort to push the H.M.O.'s to lower prices and let employer groups monitor the care provided by doctors and hospitals.

title: A Walk to the White House
description: The car bomb, whether deployed in the Middle East or in an American city, has proved to be one of the most deadly weapons of modern terrorism. So the Treasury Department's recommendation to close Pennsylvania Avenue to motor traffic in front of the White House is a reasonable response to the Oklahoma City bombing and other recent attacks. President Clinton was understandably reluctant to go along. Like most of his predecessors, he resists thickening the insulation that separates Presidents from the public.

title: A Bridge From Hope to Social Action
description: In the middle of the school day, Jennifer Suarez sat in the park and watched the traffic whiz onto the Williamsburg Bridge. Nearby, Nytopia Walker spent the afternoon in a vacant lot of dirt and brick. Marlyn Garcia stood outside a bodega with her friends, eyeing the malt liquor ads.

title: Mexico Plans Bigger Role For Military Against Drugs
description: Faced with a growing threat from narcotics traffickers, President Ernesto Zedillo has ordered the Mexican military to take a greater role in the anti-drug fight, including the use of air force jets to intercept planes loaded with cocaine, Mexican and United States officials say.

title: Larry L. Hillblom, 52, Founder Of DHL Worldwide Express
description: Larry L. Hillblom, the largest shareholder in DHL Worldwide Express, an air freight business, died on Sunday in a plane crash in the South Pacific, the company announced yesterday. He was 52 and lived on the Pacific island of Saipan, which is 115 miles north of Guam in the United States Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands.

title: Crippling American Science
description: The budget plan passed by the House mounts an assault on scientific research, science training and American research universities that are the envy of the world. Blinded by ideological fury at government, House Republicans seek to abandon a crucial function of government, the provision of public goods like research that are undersupplied by private markets. Private companies will invest in research that is likely to raise their profit, but they are unwilling to invest in research whose benefits leak out to competitors. By abandoning government's irreplaceable role, the House budget would undermine America's technological base.

title: Flatiron News In Debut Issue
description: A new magazine devoted to the arts, business, restaurants, food, fashion and shopping in New York City has appeared on newsstands.

title: Penske Pulls Fittipaldi Out of the Running
description: EMERSON FITTIPALDI, the last driver bumped from the Indianapolis 500 lineup, will not be the alternate for Sunday's race. Team Penske yesterday withdrew both the car that Fittipaldi used and the one in which his teammate AL UNSER JR. failed to qualify. That made the rookie FRANCK FREON the alternate. (AP)

title: Bang on a Can Uptown Cultivates Crossover
description: Before the last piece in the Bang on a Can Marathon at Alice Tully Hall on Sunday, Michael Gordon, a founder of the new-music festival, asked who in the audience had been there for the full eight hours. The hall was nearly two-thirds full, and well over half the listeners raised their hands. Mr. Gordon then asked how many listeners had attended the marathon in its early days, downtown. Fewer than a dozen hands were raised.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: GLENDALE FEDERAL BANK, Glendale, Calif., a savings institution, agreed to buy 13 branches, $820 million in deposits and about $490 million in real estate loans from Union Federal Bank of California. RURAL/METRO CORP., Scottsdale, Ariz., announced the completion of three acquisitions: Advanced Gold Cross Ambulance, Town's Ambulance and Midlands Ambulance. The three have annual revenue of $15 million./ STATION CASINOS INC., Las Vegas, Nev., which owns and operates hotels, motels and casinos, will acquire the Texas Gambling Hall and Hotel, a casino-hotel complex under construction in Las Vegas, for about $95 million. TALBOTS INC., Hingham, Mass., a retailer of women's apparel, said it planned to open an estimated 500 new stores by the year 2000, which would expand its network to about 900 outlets worldwide.

title: Curious Dealer Uncovers Missing Vatican Treasure
description: It was a cheap plastic envelope that first aroused a rare-manuscript dealer's suspicion about two pages that appeared to be cut from a medieval book.

title: Congress Move on Cuba Irks Canada and Mexico
description: Canada and Mexico have joined forces to defeat proposed American legislation that would tighten the 33-year-old trade embargo against Cuba.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Dow Surges 54 Points, Bouncing Back From Selloff The Dow Jones industrials jumped 54.30 points as buyers swarmed around a wide variety of stocks, often the same blue chips that many traders abandoned during the market's plunge on Thursday. The Dow rose so fast that the New York Stock Exchange's circuit-breaker rules were tripped at 1:53 P.M.

title: Fox Sticks to Its Game Plan
description: Still making its pitch primarily toward young adult viewers, the Fox Television network will present a new fall schedule to advertisers today emphasizing comedy but adding two science-fiction dramas.

description: Robert F. Buckhorn, a former chief spokesman for the Federal Aviation Administration, died on Sunday at Brookhaven Memorial Hospital in Patchogue, L.I. He was 68 and lived in Falls Church, Va.

title: As Levees Hold, Midwest Sighs With Hope
description: The crests of the rain-swollen Mississippi and Missouri Rivers combined muddy forces today and swept past heavily diked St. Louis, leaving the city mostly dry and the rest of the Midwest hopeful that the end was near for the region's third-worst spring flood in modern memory.

description: Resolving decades of constitutional debate, the Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that the police are ordinarily required to knock and announce their presence before entering a home to execute a search warrant.

description: He pump-faked east, west, north and south before taking the shot. The clock read :10, his Houston Rockets trailed by a point, their superstar passed him the ball on a whim and then Robert Horry went into his own personal stall.

title: Ulysses Kay, Prolific Composer And Educator, Is Dead at 78
description: Ulysses Kay, a professor of music and a prolific composer of five operas, 20 large orchestral works and scores of choral, chamber and film compositions, died on Saturday in Englewood Hospital in Englewood, N.J. He was 78 and lived in Teaneck, N.J.

title: Market Place; Investors await clinical word on a new drug from Teva of Israel.
description: FOR shareholders of Teva Pharmaceutical Industries, the leading drug maker in Israel, the next few weeks could be pivotal because of its new drug, Copaxone, which shows promise in fighting multiple sclerosis but is no cure.

title: Head Trip Into the Third Dimension
description: YOU may have to cross your eyes or wear silly-looking glasses, but it does not seem to matter. Creating the illusion of a three-dimensional world from two-dimensional pictures is an idea with timeless appeal.

description: DINOSAURS were warmblooded, colorfully marked, gregarious creatures that made terrifying noises but nurtured their young and finally died out when the Earth was hit by a comet. Or so some say.

title: Lionel Ovesey, Psychoanalyst, Is Dead at 80
description: Lionel Ovesey, a Columbia University psychoanalyst who wrote two important works about the psyche of homosexuals and African-Americans, died on Sunday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 80 and lived on the Upper East Side of Manhattan.

title: Japan's Auto Makers Feel Bite of U.S. Tariff
description: The high tariff imposed by the Clinton Administration on Japanese luxury cars imported into the United States has begun to bite, forcing Japanese companies to suspend exports and cut production.

title: Shoe Deal by Liz Claiborne
description: Liz Claiborne Inc. said yesterday that it would license its sport and dress shoe business to a company being formed by the former chief executive of Nine West Group Inc. Terms were not disclosed. Liz Claiborne, the women's apparel company based in New York, said its shoe operation had revenue of about $63 million last year. The company said it would transfer certain assets and personnel from its shoe business to a new company run by Wayne Weaver, the former chief executive of Nine West, a women's footwear company based in Stamford, Conn.

title: RYKA, IN DEFAULT, SAYS LENDER CALLED IN DEBT
description: Ryka Inc., a maker of women's athletic shoes and apparel, said yesterday that a lender had called in $2.5 million of debt, a move that could put the company out of business. Ryka, based in Norwood, Mass., said it was in default under financing agreements and had received a 30-day termination notice from the lender, the Pro-Specs America Corporation. The company also posted a loss of $2.2 million for the first quarter, compared with earnings of $105,810 in the first quarter a year ago. Sheri Poe, president and chief executive of Ryka, said that the company has been approached by a number of parties and is pursuing several financial options.

And now, it must be closed."

Hogan, 82, was released from All Saints Hospital after a 15-day stay for emergency surgery. "He's doing great," his wife, Valerie Hogan, told the Fort Worth Star-Telegram, "and the doctor feels it's better for him to be at hom." (AP)

description: After weeks of refusing to offer specific counterproposals to Republican plans to balance the Federal budget in seven years, the White House has begun to prepare ideas, and President Clinton has explicitly said for the first time that he believes such a goal is achievable.

title: Charles F. Reade Sr. Manufacturer, 79
description: Charles Falkiner Reade Sr., former head of a 222-year-old family business dealing with special metals, pharmaceuticals and chemicals, died on May 16 at Martin Memorial Medical Center in Stuart, Fla. He was 79 and lived in Stuart and Morehead City, N.C.

title: In War's Horrors, Chaos May Rank With Carnage
description: Joseph Vilsmaier's epic war film "Stalingrad" goes about as far as a movie can go in depicting modern warfare as a stomach-turning form of mass slaughter. The $14 million German movie, which opens today at Film Forum, dwells so intently on war's carnage that it inadvertently points up the limits of cinematic gruesomeness. As realistically as it may portray shooting and maiming, a movie can't convey the smells, tastes and physical agonies of the killing fields.

title: China Demands U.S. Cancel Visit by Taiwan's President
description: The Chinese Government summoned the American Ambassador today and demanded that the United States reverse its decision to allow Taiwan's President to visit the United States next month.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday with an article about the political impact of the Supreme Court's nullification of Congressional term limits contained an erroneous quotation in some copies. Representative Bill McCollum, who backs term limits, said, "To walk away now is not smart." But he did not add: "Do I have to worry as an advocate about overreaching? No. Never." The latter quotation was from a different article, previously published in The Times.

description: More than 220 students received bachelor's degrees yesterday in ceremonies at Stevens Institute of Technology here.

title: Fed Policy Makers Decide To Leave Rates Unchanged
description: Faced with slowing growth in the American economy and a strengthening dollar, the Federal Reserve left short-term interest rates unchanged at a meeting today.

title: The Slow Search for Rowdy Cops
description: Ten days have slipped by since New York City cops went on a drunken rampage though several Washington D.C. hotels, trashing the buildings, harassing guests and illegally firing their guns. Yet police officers have been reluctant to step forward to admit wrongdoing or identify others who participated in the mayhem. This instinct to close ranks behind a wall of silence can only compound the shame of the original outrageous behavior.

title: In America; Good Works? Bah!
description: Philip Edward Wu Jr. is an AmeriCorps member who has been working with Habitat for Humanity, helping to build homes in Georgia and Florida. He is a religious man who spent four years in the Army and has now dedicated his life to helping others.

title: Making It Easier to Get Justice in America; When Prisoners Sue
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Bids Allowed For Sub Builder
description: Britain said today that it would allow two competing bids for the nation's sole submarine maker to go ahead, overruling a recommendation from antitrust regulators that one of the offers, by General Electric P.L.C. of Britain, be blocked.

title: Founder of Askin Capital Agrees To Settlement of S.E.C. Charges
description: David J. Askin, whose investment firm collapsed after bond prices plummeted last year, yesterday settled Securities and Exchange Commission charges that he had misled investors.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt * Houlihans Restaurant Group, Kansas City, Mo., filed a shelf registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission for the sale of as much as $125 million in debt securities. Wertheim Schroder & Co. will be the lead underwriter.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Mets Solve Nomo, But Bullpen Fails Its Latest Test
description: The Mets were able to survive the Hideo Nomo whirlwind road show last night. It was their bullpen and lack of clutch hitting that again did them in.

title: Boeing to Cut 5,000 More Jobs Than Originally Expected
description: The Boeing Company said yesterday that it expected to eliminate 5,000 more jobs this year than it originally anticipated, bringing the total number of cuts to 12,000. The company said its new forecast resulted from actions taken to reduce costs to stay competitive.

title: Gerulaitis Death Attributed to Short Pipe
description: A pool mechanic's failure to install an extra $1.44 worth of plastic exhaust pipe led to the death of Vitas Gerulaitis, the tennis player, as he inhaled carbon monoxide fumes from a new $8,000 pool heater last year, Suffolk County prosecutors said today.

title: Bradlees Halts Dividend, With Big Loss Foreseen
description: Bradlees Inc. suspended its 15-cent quarterly dividend today and predicted a fiscal first-quarter loss about twice as large as had been expected.

title: Posters and Posturing: Senators Talk Money
description: With decided sourness, the senior Senator from Arkansas rose to beg that colleagues take a long look back across time and money.

title: Right Call on Term Limits
description: With persuasive reasoning and a compelling vision of the national union, a majority of the Supreme Court has ruled that states may not limit the terms of the senators and representatives they send to Congress. The Court stated with absolute clarity that the qualifications for the Federal legislature were determined by the Constitution alone and that individual states may not tamper with them. This means that voters must still limit terms of legislators the old-fashioned way, by voting them out of office.

title: Food Notes
description: Organic and Convenient

title: Wine Talk; The Weekend of 100 Bordeaux
description: BIPIN DESAI and some of his friends gathered in New York over the weekend. They went to museums, visited old friends, did a little shopping, watched the Knicks games on television.

title: Donald Roehrs, Architect, 80, For Gardens
description: Donald Manfred Roehrs, a landscape architect who received more than 40 awards for his garden designs, died on Sunday at St. Joseph's Hospital in Paterson, N.J. He was 80 and had lived in Franklin Lakes, N.J., most of his life.

title: IN PERFORMANCE: THEATER
description: Wacky Singles Get Together For a Wacky Denouement 'Dates and Nuts' Theater Off Park

title: Intertech Withdraws Its Bid for Holvis
description: Intertech Group Inc. withdrew its bid for Holvis Holzstoff A.G. yesterday, clearing the way for the International Paper Company of Purchase, N.Y., to acquire the Swiss paper company. Intertech, a South Carolina paper and plastics company, made the move after International Paper said that assuming it won control of Holvis, it had an agreement to sell Holvis's distribution unit, Muehlebach Group, to Arjo Wiggins Appleton P.L.C. of London. Intertech said it had also held negotiations with Arjo Wiggins.

title: AT DINNER WITH: George Foreman; Round Two
description: GEORGE FOREMAN is one step from sitting down to dinner at the only table set up for business, a table where no one but awed waiters and a nervous captain would interrupt him. But a middle-aged woman scurries over, duck-walking like Groucho Marx, pen and a photograph in hand.

title: Toyota Considers Suit Against U.S. Sanctions
description: The Toyota Motor Corporation is considering filing suit against the United States Government in an effort to remove or reduce the impending sanctions on luxury vehicles, company officials said today.

title: Lee Goerner, 48, Editor and Publisher
description: Lee Goerner, who served as editor and publisher of the literary house Atheneum from 1989 until its demise last year, died on Saturday at his home in Manhattan. He was 48.

title: Alastair Pilkington, 75, Inventor Of a Process to Make Flat Glass
description: Sir Alastair Pilkington, who developed the flotation process that revolutionized the way flat glass is formed, died in London on May 5. He was 75.

title: JOSTENS TO SELL A MAJORITY STAKE IN LEARNING UNIT
description: Jostens Inc. of Minneapolis said yesterday that it would sell an 81 percent stake in its Jostens Learning unit to two investment entities for about $85 million in cash and notes. The stake will be sold to Bain Capital and Information Partners, both of which are based in Boston. Information Partners is led by Bain Capital and the Dun & Bradstreet Corporation. Jostens, a provider of class rings and school yearbooks, will receive about $50 million in cash and about $35 million in notes. The company will continue to own 19 percent of Jostens Learning, which is based in San Diego and develops educational computer software. The parent company will retain the Wicat Systems division of Jostens Learning.

title: Riley Says Dissension Spoiled the Knicks' Season
description: Giving his end-of-the-season address today, Pat Riley sounded like a coach who planned to return. But Riley made it clear that he was tired of the Knicks' internal problems, problems that he believed cost New York a chance to win a championship.

title: Thyssen, in Rebound, Has Half-Year Profit
description: The German steel and engineering company Thyssen A.G. said yesterday that strong demand and lower costs had helped it return to profit in the first half of its fiscal year.

title: Fifth Avenue Hasn't Quite Turned Into a Mall
description: To the Editor:

title: Lessons From '93 Flood Help Soggy Midwest Now
description: With overflowing rivers beginning to subside in the raid-soddened Midwest, Federal disaster officials said today that special damage-control programs adopted after the flood of 1993 had sharply reduced losses of lives and property this time.

title: Limited Plan to Sell Stake
description: Limited Inc. said today that it expected to raise about $700 million through the sale of stock in Intibrands Inc., a newly formed company that includes Limited's successful Victoria's Secret stores and catalogue divisions. About 15 percent of Intibrands' common stock would be sold to the public, with the rest to be owned by Limited, according to a Securities and Exchange Commission filing. The stock sale was expected to be completed in the third quarter.

title: All-Bernstein Recital
description: The soprano Angelina Reaux, the pianist Ken Noda and Michael Sokol, a baritone, are to perform a recital of works by Leonard Bernstein tonight at 8 at the New-York Historical Society, 170 Central Park West, at 77th Street. Members of the Bernstein family will offer reminiscences about the composer as part of the program. Tickets are $6 (free for Historical Society members). Information: (212) 873-3400.

title: Sports of The Times; The Knicks' Crossroads Summer
description: PAT RILEY spoke eloquently yesterday about "chemistry" and "collective spirit" and all of the intangibles that do not show up in playoff box scores. These were the things, he said, that cost this year's Knicks another run into June. The things which made this, for him, the "toughest year I've ever spent as a coach."

title: Washington Talk; The Charge That Poses Most Peril to Packwood
description: The most dangerous charge contained in the thousands of pages of evidence that the Senate Ethics Committee delivered to Senator Bob Packwood today is probably the one about which the least is known -- that he altered his diaries to conceal evidence.

title: The Pope Visits His Homeland, and Lingers
description: On his last stop on a one-day swing through southern Poland, Pope John Paul II was clearly stalling. A late afternoon sun had cast its shadows on the main square, jammed with people, and the 100-voice choir drifted from church music to something more sentimental.

title: World of Grilling: Saigon to Yucatan
description: IT'S no longer certain that baseball will have an opening day every year, but there is another harbinger of summer that can always be counted on: people hauling out their grills to begin another season of outdoor cookery.

title: BANK OF NEW YORK CONFIRMS DEAL WITH MORGAN
description: The Bank of New York Company confirmed yesterday that it had agreed to buy the securities custody business of J. P. Morgan & Company, one of the world's largest operations that holds stocks and bonds for customers. Bank of New York will take over $800 billion in client assets that J. P. Morgan now holds in custody accounts, lifting its total assets under custody to almost $3 trillion. Terms of the transaction were not disclosed, although analysts estimated that the bank had agreed to pay about $300 million. Most of the 1,000 J. P. Morgan employees in the custody business will move to Bank of New York in the next six to nine months. Bank of New York's shares rose $2, to $39.25, and J. P. Morgan gained $1.625, to $69.875, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: ALTERNATIVE SCHOOLS: International High Schools; Combining Techniques Old and New
description: Over three decades scores of small public academies, including 46 high schools in the last two years, have opened in New York City. In this series, all the new high schools are profiled, as well as influential older ones and some innovative elementary and middle schools. Here is a sampler of schools using an array of instructional techniques, some experimental, some traditional. International High School at La Guardia Community College 31-10 Thompson Avenue, Room MB 25, Long Island City, Queens. OPENED: 1985. (C.C.E.) CURRENT ENROLLMENT: 460 (peak). GRADES: 9-12.

title: After the Quilted Giraffe, There's Sony and Cyberspace
description: IN the early 1980's, when a colossal gastronomic wave washed over New York City, Barry Wine surfed on the edge of the curl with his luxuriant Quilted Giraffe, perhaps the most extravagant and innovative restaurant in America. Caviar purses served on silver pedestals (at $50 a bite), tuna-and-wasabi pizza, hazelnut-coated sweetbreads, exotic seafood -- all enchanted the devoted, well-heeled patrons.

title: IN PERFORMANCE: DANCE
description: A Theatrical Humanist Creates an Eclectic Program Louis Johnson Dance Theater Ensemble Henry Street Settlement

title: Morgan Stanley Names Perella
description: Morgan Stanley & Company said yesterday that it had named Joseph Perella, whose name is synonymous with high-stakes corporate takeovers, as head of its corporate finance department.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about elections in the Mexican state of Guanajuato imprecisely summarized the views of Vicente Fox, an opposition candidate for governor. Although Mr. Fox did say that the record of the interim governor, Carlos Medina, a member of his own National Action Party, would cost him votes, he also said that the Institutional Revolutionary Party was even more unpopular with the voters.

title: Sports of The Times; World Champions Older and Wiser?
description: THIS time they won't be naive. This is what Carla Overbeck promises herself as she prepares for another world championship. This time they'll be more prepared for the large crowds and the rugged play and the tournament games that follow one after another.

title: Still Here: Sylvia, Who Survived Stonewall, Time and the River
description: SYLVIA RIVERA, the transvestite who in 1969 battled passionately and inspirationally at the Stonewall uprising, tried to kill herself 10 days ago by walking into the Hudson River.

title: Man and Agent in Shooting On the White House Lawn
description: An armed intruder jumped a fence onto the South Lawn of the White House late Tuesday night and was shot and wounded by a uniformed Secret Service agent. The bullet passed through the man's arm, wounded a second agent, and both men were reported in stable condition in the hospital early this morning.

title: Accounts
description: * Department of Housing and Urban Development, Washington, to BBDO South, Atlanta, a unit of the Omnicom Group, to handle its advertising contract for one year, with four annual renewal options. J. Walter Thompson Atlanta, a unit of the WPP Group, was the previous agency. The billings were estimated at $10 million.

title: Tap Dance Celebration
description: A free performance, "Jambalaya! Tapping to Cajun, Zydeco and Country Music," will be given tomorrow at 12:30 P.M. at Sony Plaza, 550 Madison Avenue, at 55th Street, as part of a weeklong celebration of National Tap Dance Day. The celebration ends on Sunday with "Tap Extravaganza '95" at 7 P.M. in Haft Auditorium at the Fashion Institute of Technology (227 West 27th Street, Chelsea). Performers include Buster Brown, Savion Glover, Jimmy Slyde and Tarik Winston. Tickets, $22 to $40, are available through Ticket Central: (212) 279-4200. Information on other events during the week: (718) 920-4461.

title: Corrections
description: An article by Reuters on Sunday about a petition to dig up John Wilkes Booth's grave misidentified the lawyer who questioned the credibility of a historian opposed to the petition. The lawyer was Mark S. Zaid, not Jeremy Friedberg; both are lawyers for the petitioners.

title: Real Estate; Wilmington, Del., gets a shot in the arm from office construction for two big banking companies.
description: TWO big banking companies are generating a small burst of office construction in downtown Wilmington. Both plan to relocate operations from the suburbs.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ARMCO INC., Parsippany, N.J., and USX Corp., Pittsburgh, said they planned to sell their joint venture, National-Oilwell, a supplier of oilfield pipe and equipment, to a group including Duff & Phelps Corp., Chicago, and Bain Capital of Boston. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Bosnian Serb Is Expressing New Interest In Old Plan
description: Radovan Karadzic, the Bosnian Serb leader, expressed some new interest today in an international peace plan for Bosnia and Herzegovina that the Serbs have long rejected.

title: Politician's Son Arrested in Mexico
description: Acting on a random customs check, Mexican officials arrested the son of one of Mexico's most powerful politicians as he entered the Mexico City international airport late Monday carrying 12 suitcases full of carved ivory and rare animal pelts that he had not declared.

title: For Captive, A Struggle To Stay Sane
description: For Harvey Weinstein, the hardest part of being held captive in a cramped, pitch-black pit for 12 days was keeping his sanity.

title: Lloyd's Sets Plan to Aid Its Investors
description: Saying that its survival required decisive action, Lloyd's of London proposed a sweeping reorganization today intended to pare the losses of its hard-hit individual investors and allow it to retain its role as a powerful force in the insurance industry.

title: A Big Noodle Shop Opens in the Village
description: Asian noodles are starting to give pasta some serious competition. The newest noodle shop in Manhattan is the big, bustling Sammy's Noodle Shop and Grill, installed last week at 53-61 Avenue of the Americas (near 11th Street). The space was occupied until recently by Jefferson Market, which moved across the street. Spare ribs, roast pork and ducks are hung in the windows, and the menu offers well-seasoned dim sum, noodle dishes and the like. Its Chinese bakery opens this week.

title: With a Roar, a Wound Is Closed in Oklahoma City
description: The remains of the Federal Building, hulking over this quiet city like a gaping, ugly wound for a month, came tumbling down today in a final roar of dynamite.

title: Isaac Stern Workshop For Young Musicians
description: The Isaac Stern Chamber Music Workshop at Carnegie Hall, a three-week seminar for chamber musicians between the ages of 17 and 30, is to hold public sessions Tuesday, next Wednesday and June 1. The open sessions are from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. each day at Weill Recital Hall and at the Alice and Jacob M. Kaplan Space. Tickets are $10.

title: Thorn EMI Posts Rise In Operating Earnings
description: Thorn EMI P.L.C said yesterday that its pretax profit before one-time charges rose 23.1 percent in the fiscal year that ended on March 31. Thorn, which has interests in music, consumer rentals and security systems, reported pretax profit of $:423.6 million, or $667 million, compared with $:344.2 million a year earlier. Thorn incurred one-time charges totaling $:126.9 million, including a loss of $:97.9 million for closing its electrical retailing chain Rumbelows.

title: Cut in Beach Aid Is Predicted
description: New Jersey would be a big loser under a Clinton Administration plan to cut aid to restore beaches, a state official says.

title: Patient Influx Is Protested
description: Governor Whitman arrived here yesterday for a memorial service honoring the seven New Jersey police officers killed in the line of duty in the last year. She was greeted by silent protesters who fear that her plan to close Marlboro Psychiatric Hospital will flood Ocean Grove with more former mental patients.

title: New Hewlett-Packard Device Sends Vital Signs by Modem
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company, a leader in computerized medical monitoring systems, plans to introduce a wireless mobile unit today that will let doctors receive patients' electrocardiograms and other vital signs for remote diagnosis in emergencies.

title: Coke Puts Model In New Commercial
description: Lucky Vanous, the muscular model who became a popular advertising character after appearing in a television commercial for Diet Coke, is returning to promote the brand.

title: TV Fights Turnpike's Film Ban
description: A television station is going to court to fight for its right to shoot videotape on the New Jersey Turnpike whenever it wants.

title: Arabs Want Israel to Kill Land Seizure
description: Buoyed by Israel's retreat on a major issue affecting Jerusalem, Arab leaders demanded today that the Israelis not merely suspend their planned confiscation of land in Palestinian neighborhoods but go on to cancel the move outright.

title: Firefighting Is Hungry Work, So Dinner's a Serious Matter
description: MOST evenings around 6:30, the sleek red pumper from Engine Company No. 18 pulls up to the Jefferson Market in Greenwich Village and a half-dozen firefighters, ready for action in waterproof boots and suspendered pants, pile into the store. They grab a cart and inspect the meat, bread and produce counters -- debating the merits of arugula versus radicchio and hammering out the menu for the evening's meal.

title: Top German Court Virtually Absolves Eastern Spymasters
description: Closing a final chapter of the cold war, Germany's highest court ruled today that East Germany's spymasters could not be tried in a reunited Germany and that top espionage officials already convicted would not have to serve their sentences.

title:
ALTERNATIVE SCHOOLS: Career Preparation Or College;
Combining Techniques Old and New
description: Over three decades scores of small public academies, including 46 high schools in the last two years, have opened in New York City. In this series, all the new high schools are profiled, as well as notable older ones that served as models. Here is a sampler of schools using an array of instructional techniques, some experimental, some traditional. Gateway to the Health Sciences Secondary School At Junior High School 72, 108-35 167th Street, Jamaica, Queens. OPENED: 1994. CURRENT ENROLLMENT: 110. PEAK: 1,000. GRADES: 7-9; eventually, 7-12.

title:
ALTERNATIVE SCHOOLS: Educational Innovators;
Combining Techniques Old and New
description: Over three decades scores of small public academies, including 46 high schools in the last two years, have opened in New York City. In this series, all the new high schools are profiled, as well as notable older ones that served as models. Here is a sampler of schools using an array of instructional techniques, some experimental, some traditional. Landmark High School 220 West 58th Street, Manhattan. OPENED: 1993. (C.C.E.) CURRENT ENROLLMENT: 153. PEAK: 300. GRADES: 9-10; eventually, 9-12.

title: IN PERFORMANCE: DANCE
description: Rituals for Women From Diverse Traditions Perspectives in Motion Dia Center for the Arts

title: CHRONICLE
description: A judge ruled yesterday that ETAN MERRICK, the third and fifth wife of the Broadway producer DAVID MERRICK, is entitled to a divorce on the ground that she was abandoned by her husband -- even though they weren't living together.

title: 'Inspector Calls' to Close
description: "An Inspector Calls," the revival of the 1946 drama by J. B. Priestley, is to close after the matinee on Sunday at the Royale Theater, 242 West 45th Street, Manhattan. The matinee of the play, directed by Stephen Daldry, will be its 454th regular performance; it had 14 previews.

title: Acquisition of Technicolor Under Court Scrutiny Again
description: The deal that formed the foundation of Ronald O. Perelman's fortune, his 1982 acquisition of Technicolor, was under scrutiny today for the third time before the Delaware Supreme Court, in a case that could revise the ground rules for corporate takeovers.

title: No Headline
description: "I came here to say goodbye. But when I heard the explosion, it brought it all back. That's just what it sounded like. That's what I remember." PRISCILLA SALYERS, a survivor of the Oklahoma City bombing, who watched the demolition. [ A18:1. ]

title: INSIDE
description: Push for Electronic Banking

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: A FRIEND writes:

title: What Aum Offered
description: Now that Shoko Asahara and his disciples in the Aum Shinrikyo religious sect have been apprehended, one might think that most Japanese would feel immense relief. But the incident will have enduring repercussions; it brought to the surface many of the unspoken crises that, we have long known, undermine our society's patina of blissful productivity.

title: Robinson Captures the M.V.P. Trophy but the Celebration Is Muted
description: David Robinson's trophy came wrapped in Styrofoam today -- in case he dropped it.

title: More Suspects in Smuggling of Prostitutes
description: Five more suspects have been accused of smuggling women from Thailand into the United States to work as prostitutes in a Chinatown brothel, Federal authorities announced yesterday.

title: Giuliani Is Hopeful After Going to Albany in Quest of Money
description: With the state budget headed toward completion, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani made a last-minute sojourn to Albany in search of cash today and said he thought New York City would fare better than Albany leaders have previously suggested.

title: SHARES OF DEERE DECLINE DESPITE INCREASE IN PROFIT
description: Shares of Deere & Company fell yesterday even though the company reported a 25 percent increase in net income for its fiscal second quarter. Net income rose to $237 million, or $2.74 a share, in the quarter ended April 30, compared with $189.3 million, or $2.20, in the year-earlier period. Revenue rose 15 percent. The per-share results were higher than the average estimate of $2.68 a share by 17 analysts surveyed by Zacks Investment Research. Still, Blair Brumley, an analyst with Dain Bosworth, said: "That's not good enough. These guys have been beating consensus estimates very handily for quite a while." Shares of Deere, which is based in Moline, Ill., fell $3.25, to $86.50.

title: When Teachers Unite to Run School
description: By the time the bell rang at the end of the school day, the chalk dust had lightly frosted Maura Malarcher's purple cotton cardigan and swirled around the rasp in her voice. She had turned off the classroom lights four times that day, and once, the ploy actually worked, casting a brief and welcome spell of silence over her sixth and seventh graders.

title: Market Place; Viacom is enmeshed in a quiet tug-of-war over its share price.
description: WHILE Viacom Inc. grabs headlines with bullish stories about the video release of its Academy Award-winning film "Forrest Gump" and MTV's venture in the Far East, it is quietly fighting to lift its stock price, hoping to avoid paying millions to a lot of hungry traders.

title: Donating Organs of Anencephalic Babies Is Backed
description: TAKING a stand on one of today's most contentious ethical issues, an expert committee of the American Medical Association says it should be permissible to take organs from anencephalic babies while they are alive.

title: Julian Pretto, 50; Owned Art Galleries
description: Julian Pretto, an art dealer known for his devotion to young artists, died on Monday at St. Vincent's Hospital in Greenwich Village. He was 50 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Sonia Moore, 92, Stanislavsky Expert
description: Sonia Moore, the founder and leader of the American Center for Stanislavsky Theater Art and the Sonia Moore Studio of the Theater, died on Friday at her home in Manhattan. She was 92.

title: Freeholder May Lose New Job
description: Joseph C. Parlavecchio, an Essex County Freeholder, has a new problem. First he was indicted on Monday on charges that he concealed his ownership of a rundown building that the Newark school system leased from him as an elementary school.

title: Mansell Is Dismissed by McLaren Team
description: The career of the former Formula One champion NIGEL MANSELL, which took a drastic downturn last year, reached an even lower point yesterday when he was dismissed by McLaren.

title: GRAMM PROPOSAL FOR DEEP TAX CUT KILLED BY SENATE
description: On a vote suffused with Republican Presidential politics, the Senate today rejected a proposal to include deep tax cuts in its budget framework.

title: Kmart Has Trouble Finding New Chief Executive
description: The Kmart Corporation's toughest sell these days is persuading someone to become its chief executive.

title: Senate Panel Opposes Change On Foster Care, Aides Say
description: Rebuffing changes adopted by the House, the Senate Finance Committee will vote this week to maintain Federal subsidies for foster care and adoptions as an entitlement available to all who meet certain income and other requirements, Senate aides said.

title: Atlanta C. Sampson, Artist, 98; Had Her First Solo Show at 91
description: Atlanta Constance Sampson, a painter who had her first one-woman show in New York at the age of 91, died on Thursday at a nursing home in St. Ansgar, Iowa. She was 98 and lived in Toeterville, Iowa.

title: When the Musician Upstages the Music
description: When readers write critics, they often ask, "Were we at the same concert?" It's a better question than you think, for maybe we were not. How weird it is to sit (or stand) silently in the midst of roaring, happy audiences -- among people who have heard nothing but right -- andto believe privately that something has been wrong. It's like listening to a musician with one piece, one instrument, one set of concert clothes, one Social Security number who has ended up producing two performances.

title: ALTERNATIVE SCHOOLS: Career Preparation Or College; Combining Techniques Old and New
description: Over three decades scores of small public academies, including 46 high schools in the last two years, have opened in New York City. In this series, all the new high schools are profiled, as well as notable older ones that served as models. Here is a sampler of schools using an array of instructional techniques, some experimental, some traditional. Kingsborough Academy for the Sciences High School 2001 Oriental Boulevard, Building T7, Kingsborough Community College, Manhattan Beach, Brooklyn. OPENED: 1993. CURRENT ENROLLMENT: 360. PEAK: 720. GRADES: 9-10; eventually, 9-12.

title: Focus on Federal Power
description: The surprise in the Supreme Court's decision on term limits on Monday was not the result; ever since the Court agreed last June to decide the case, it had been widely assumed that the Justices would find state-imposed limits on Congressional terms to be unconstitutional.

title: The Baton Is Lifted, And There Is the Show
description: Tonight "Great Performances" looks at "Legendary Maestros," with those curious figures waving their arms in front of instrumentalists who are seemingly paying little or no attention. The program's subtitle is "The Art of Conducting." It could just as well be "The Mystique of Conducting."

title: Bacterium That Causes Ulcers Discovered in Drinking Water
description: An important clue as to how people are infected with the bacterium that causes stomach ulcers was reported by researchers at a meeting here today of the American Society for Microbiology. They say they have identified the bacterium in contaminated drinking water, which may therefore be the source of infection. Many experts have hitherto favored person-to-person contact as the route of spread.

title: Book Notes
description: Big Successes

title: Gerulaitis Death Laid To Lack of Vent Pipe
description: A pool mechanic's failure to install an extra $1.44 worth of plastic exhaust pipe led to the death of Vitas Gerulaitis, the tennis player, as he inhaled carbon monoxide fumes from a new $8,000 pool heater last year, Suffolk County prosecutors said yesterday.

title:
BASEBALL;
Finley Has 2-Hitter With 15 Strikeouts
description: Injuries and ineffectual pitching -- the twin demons of their season -- followed the Yankees here on the first stop of a nine-game West Coast trip. And, when combined with the spellbinding pitching of Chuck Finley, it made for a miserable evening at Anaheim Stadium.

title:
Business Travel;
Reclaiming value-added tax can help take some of the sting out of the weak dollar in Europe.
description: AMERICANS who go to Europe on business can counter the continuing decline of the dollar there by reclaiming part of the value-added taxes, or V.A.T., that they incur while they travel.

title: Democrat Would Slow Tax Cut
description: Senator Bernard F. Kenny Jr., Democrat of Hudson, wants ranking Republicans to back a Republican lawmaker's idea to phase in Governor Christine Todd Whitman's proposed 15 percent income tax cut rather than allow the full reduction to take effect next January.

title: Magic Keeps Cool and Mounts Comeback
description: The sign flashed tonight for all at Orlando Arena to see. "Shaq is the real m.v.p.," it said. Earlier in the day, Shaquille O'Neal had found out he finished second in the National Basketball Association's most-valuable- player voting to San Antonio's David Robinson.

title: Rangers, Behind by 2-0, May Redo Lineup
description: If the Rangers don't win Game 3 against the Philadelphia Flyers on Wednesday night at Madison Square Garden, they probably have no chance of successfully defending their Stanley Cup championship.

title: Four From UConn Aim for National Teams
description: The four women's basketball players from Connecticut's national collegiate champions have survived the next-to-last cuts for three national teams. The final cuts will be announced tomorrow.

title: Convicted Killer Seeks 3d Trial
description: A millionaire businessman from Chatham who has been convicted twice on charges of murdering his wife has filed a motion seeking a third trial. Lawyers for John Dreher, whose trial ended two weeks ago, claim that the judge's instructions to the jury about reasonable doubt were imbalanced.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday of Larry L. Hillblom, a founder of DHL Worldwide Express, misstated a detail about the investigation of the plane crash that killed him. Because of misinformation provided by officials of Saipan, the Pacific island, to the Associated Press, a body was identified on Sunday as Mr. Hillblom's. It was actually that of another man. But Mr. Hillblom is still believed to have died in the crash into the ocean, and the search for survivors of the crash has been called off.

title: ALTERNATIVE SCHOOLS: Career Preparation Or College; Combining Techniques Old and New
description: Over three decades scores of small public academies, including 46 high schools in the last two years, have opened in New York City. In this series, all the new high schools are profiled, as well as notable older ones that served as models. Here is a sampler of schools using an array of instructional techniques, some experimental, some traditional. High School of Economics and Finance 100 Trinity Place, Manhattan. OPENED: 1993. CURRENT ENROLLMENT: 270. PEAK: 650. GRADES: 9-10; 9-12 in 1996.

title: Clarke Goward Buys Mintz & Hoke Unit
description: Clarke Goward Advertising in Boston has acquired the Boston office of Mintz & Hoke in Avon, Conn., and absorbed that office into Clarke Goward. The terms were not disclosed.
