title: In the Valley of the Kings
description: A spectacular find in Egypt's Valley of the Kings promises to shed fresh light on the domestic life of Ramses II, who is believed to have fathered 100 children, 52 of them sons. Most of the sons were apparently buried in a huge mausoleum containing no less than 67 chambers, whose discovery was announced last week by the Egyptologist Kent R. Weeks of the American University in Cairo. But equally interesting, it may reveal more about the demise of Pharaonic Egypt as a major imperial power in the ancient Near East.

title: Fledgling World Trade Arbiter Listens to the War Cry of Giants
description: At the annual meeting of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development here, one of the major players turned out to be not a member of this select club of 25 rich nations but an invited guest.

description: A New York City detective who was assigned to the Police Department's elite Organized Crime Control Bureau killed himself on Monday night on Staten Island, the police said.

title: Hiding in Plain Sight: Search for Haitian Exile
description: Emmanuel (Toto) Constant, leader of a violent anti-democracy group in Haiti, was well known to United States officials. He had been on their payroll as an informer even as he headed the opposition to the American-led effort to reinstate President Jean-Bertrand Aristide. Late last year, he embarrassed American authorities when he eluded Haitian prosecutors by fleeing to the United States, entering legally on an old visa.

title: Stock Prices Rise Strongly For a 2d Day
description: Wall Street rushed back to stocks for a second consecutive session yesterday, nearly wiping out last week's losses, after the Federal Reserve signaled a continuation of its steady interest-rate policy and traders speculated that there would be a rate cut later this year.

title: Suspect in Murders and Rape Wins Plea to Defend Himself
description: Reginald McFadden, the paroled murderer accused of killing two people shortly after his release from a Pennsylvania prison last year, has decided to serve as his own lawyer in a rape case in Rockland County.

title: BIOCHEM INTERNATIONAL AGREES TO BE ACQUIRED
description: Biochem International Inc., a medical supplies maker based in Waukesha, Wis., said yesterday that it had agreed to be acquired by a company controlled by John J. McDonough for about $66 million. Under the letter of intent, Mr. McDonough's company will acquire all of Biochem's capital stock in a cash transaction valued at $5 a share. The stock jumped $1.25, to $4.25, in Nasdaq trading. Mr. McDonough is the founder and former chief executive of Dentsply International Inc. of York, Pa., which designs, makes and distributes X-ray systems.

title: House Panel Backs B-2 But No More Seawolf Subs
description: House Republicans today took the first step toward canceling a Seawolf nuclear submarine, which the Navy desperately wants, and buying two more B-2 Stealth bombers, which the Air Force says it does not want, does not need and cannot afford.

description: Confronting the Republican Congress on several major fronts, a combative Clinton Administration today threatened to veto foreign aid legislation the President denounced as "isolationist," as well as any welfare bill that would turn the Federal food stamp program over to the states.

description: The former treasurer of Seton Hall University and an associate have pleaded guilty to a conspiracy that siphoned off nearly $1 million from the university here.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TRACK AND FIELD Hazel Clark Double Winner in Relays Hazel Clark anchored Columbia-Maplewood, (N.J.) High School to two victories Monday night in the East Coast Relays at Morristown High School. Clark, one of the top girls' distance runners in the country and sister of Olympian Joetta Clark, ran the 800-meter final leg in 2 minutes 9.5 seconds on the sprint medley which posted a meet record of 3 minutes 58.56 seconds. Clark had the same split for the anchor 800 leg on the 3,200-meter relay which the school won in 9:18.0. Columbia also won the 1,200-meter intermediate hurdles in 3:11.2, a meet record. In boys' events, Westfield, with Matt Elmuccio its outstanding sophomore running a 1:54.5 anchor 800, took the 3,200-meter relay in 7:50.2.

title: Disunity in Foreign Policy
description: The uneasy peace between the Republican Congress and Democratic Administration on international issues is collapsing under a torrent of misbegotten Republican legislation that would seriously damage United States interests. The initiatives would disrupt America's relations with China and Russia, shrink an already skeletal foreign aid budget, limit American participation in international peacekeeping and overturn President Clinton's efforts to establish a more rational Cuba policy.

description: Stocks closed mixed yesterday, as stock traders wondered whether the latest evidence of an economic slowdown was good news or bad.

description: Aging, weary and overmatched, the Rangers have one more noble, realistic goal before they surrender their Stanley Cup. They can try to avoid being swept by the bigger, younger, hungrier Philadelphia Flyers.

description: Plunging for the first time into the Chelsea Flower Show, which opened today for its 80th year, is a bit like dog paddling up the nearby Thames when the river is full of Olympic swimmers.

title: Sanders Is Found Not Guilty
description: Cincinnati Reds outfielder DEION SANDERS was found not guilty yesterday of all charges related to a dispute with a Riverfront Stadium security guard after a game Aug. 8. description: A DREAM of Eden lies dormant in everyone. Or so it seems in spring.

description: A State Supreme Court justice accused the Pataki Administration today of trying to reward the chemical industry by repealing a restriction on the use of a chemical, the main ingredient of many insect repellents, that some scientists consider a health risk.

description: Two top-ranking subway officials have dodged serious punishment for botching an asbestos removal project at six subway stations in Queens and Brooklyn two years ago. The lenient treatment by the Transit Authority's president, Alan Kiepper, is inadequate and should be adjusted by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority board if Mr. Kiepper cannot recognize the severity of the misconduct.

title: Quartet of the Macabre From the Inner City
description: The title of Rusty Cundieff's film "Tales From the Hood" describes the movie perfectly. Three teen-age gangsters are regaled with four tales from the crypt by a chortling, wiry-haired undertaker) Clarence Williams 3d) who could be a macabre cousin of Don King. The trio (Joe Torry, De'Aundre Bonds and Samuel Monroe Jr.) have been lured to the Simms Funderal Home expecting to recover a lost cache of drugs, but get much more than they bargained for.

title:
CURRENTS;
Tableware With Lots of Personality
description: THE Tom Wolfe of tabletop is 35-year-old Mark Switzer, with his acid visages on teacups, bowls, candle holders, vases and teapots. "Subliminally, these are people I have met," he said. An actor from Brooklyn with an elastic Jim Carrey-type face, he practices expressions in the mirror, then renders them in china, enlivened with vivid food-safe colors. (His "Man before coffee," a green face with bags around the eyes, is a self-portrait.) He plans to do a dinner service, which would give hosts the opportunity to match each guest's physiognomy with a place setting. Prices begin at $20 for salt cellars; a teapot is $195 to $250. At Pure Madderlake, 478 Broadway (at Broome), (212) 941-7770.

title: Dollar Slips as Durables Report Stirs Interest-Rate Speculation
description: The dollar slipped against most leading currencies yesterday after a large decline in American durable goods stirred speculation that the Federal Reserve might cut interest rates.

title: International Briefs; Loss of $30 Million For El Al in Quarter
description: El Al, Israel's national airline, lost $30 million in the first quarter of 1995, the chief executive, Rafael Harlev, said yesterday at a meeting of the carrier's officials at Israel's Transport Ministry. The state-owned airline had expected a $20 million loss in the quarter, he said, attributing the added $10 million of losses to the continued unexpected strength of the shekel, the Israeli currency. El Al earned a profit of $14 million in 1994 and $10 million in 1993.

title: Unicef Vows Not to Buy From Companies That Exploit Children
description: Taking the lead in a campaign to end the use of child labor, Unicef said today that it would no longer buy from suppliers that violate provisions of an international accord on children's rights.

title: Editors' Note
description: A front-page article on Feb. 8, headlined "So It May Be True After All: Eating Pasta Makes You Fat," discussed problems encountered by some people in trying to lose weight on a low-fat, high-carbohydrate diet.

title: A Leap Oft-Imitated
description: The latest breach of security at the White House was the most common kind, an unstable fence-jumper, quickly caught. But for those charged with protecting the President, it raised an unsettling fear: The more such acts happen, the more likely other, and perhaps more dangerous, people are to try them again -- and again and again.

title:
CURRENTS;
A Legacy of Oddities
description: HOUSES designed by Bruce Goff were as idiosyncratic as his clients. A 1940's home in Aurora, Ill., for Ruth Ford, an artist, has a wall made of chunks of glass and coal. In the 1950 Bavinger house in Norman, Okla., a futurist fantasy (in sketch above), Goff avoided floors and interior walls; large saucer-shape platforms suspended at different levels from the roof served as rooms. "They had to have netting around the platforms so people didn't fall off," said Pauline Saliga, the curator of a Goff retrospective, from June 9 to Sept. 4 at the Art Institute of Chicago. Goff, left, who died in 1982, "was a child prodigy and a genius," Ms. Saliga said, "but I don't think I'd like to live in one of his houses."

title: Players Split in Arbitration
description: The players will not go without a victory in salary arbitration this year. After losing two cases heard by experimental three-man panels, the players gained a split of the first two cases argued before the more traditional single arbitrator. In those cases, decided yesterday, MORTON MITCHNICK awarded outfielder DARREN LEWIS a $1.85 million salary over the San Francisco Giants' offer of $1,025,000, and RALPH BERGER gave catcher CARLOS HERNANDEZ the $300,000 salary the Los Angeles Dodgers sought instead of his request for $525,000. Last year Lewis had a $350,000 salary, Hernandez $265,000.

title: The Rev. John Howard Johnson, Religious and Civic Leader, 98

title: SHARES OF MICHAELS STORES FALL ON EARNINGS FORECAST
description: Shares of Michaels Stores Inc. fell 23 percent yesterday after the company said increased sale promotions would hurt profits in the second quarter. Michaels Stores, a retailer of arts, crafts and home furnishings based in Irving, Tex., reported first-quarter results that were in line with analysts' forecasts but warned investors that more markdowns were being used to increase sales in the current quarter. Shares of the company fell $7.50, to $24.75, as more than 5.6 million shares changed hands in Nasdaq trading.

description: As President of Brazil until last December, Itamar Franco displayed an indecisiveness that was the despair of the nation. Out of office, his dithering over a plush diplomatic post has become mass entertainment.

A yellow dining room chair sat near the front of the building at 34-33 Junction Boulevard in Corona with the number 47 taped to its back.

title: Sex, Bias and Budget Debates in Senate
description: The Senate could not even get through its budget debate without dealing with sex.

title: Agreement On Revisions In Sentencing
description: Gov. George E. Pataki and the state's legislative leaders said tonight they had agreed in principle on major changes in the state's sentencing laws, including limiting parole for some violent felons but repealing the requirement that repeat nonviolent offenders serve time in jail.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: SOCCER Ajax Amsterdam Wins Patrick Kluivert, who entered the game midway through the second half, scored with seven minutes left last night, leading Ajax Amsterdam over AC Milan, 1-0, in the final of the European Champions Cup in Vienna. Marc Overmars crossed the ball from the left, catching AC Milan's defense out of position. Edgar Davids passed to to Frank Rijkaard, who sent it to Kluivert. The 18-year-old forward beat a desperate challenge from Franco Baresi and pushed the ball off the side of his foot past goalkeeper Sebastiano Rossi from eight yards. Ajax, unbeaten in 33 games in the Dutch League, had beaten AC Milan twice by 2-0 earlier this season in Champions Cup league play. It was the fourth European title for Ajax, which won the Champions Cup from 1971-73. (AP) TENNIS Russia Defeats Spain Sergi Bruguera of Spain, the two-time defending French Open champion, needed only one hour yesterday to defeat Yevgeny Kafelnikov, 6-3, 6-2, at the World Team Cup in Dusseldorf, Germany. But Kafelnikov and Andrei Olhovsky won the round-robin matchup for Russia, 2-1, by teaming to beat Bruguera and Carlos Costa, 6-4, 6-3. Despite another victory by Goran Ivanisevic, Croatia was beaten by the Netherlands, 2-1, with doubles again the decider. Jacco Eltingh and Paul Haarhuis were 6-2, 6-2 winners over Ivanisevic and Sasa Hirszon, who also lost in singles. (AP) McNEIL ELIMINATED: Unseeded Yone Kamio defeated fifth-seeded Lori McNeil, 6-3, 2-6, 6-3, at the Strasbourg Open in France. Second-seeded Kimiko Date beat Nicole Bradtke, 6-4, 6-1. (AP) HORSE RACING Two Jockeys in Spill Diane Nelson and John Velazquez were thrown when their mounts fell at Belmont Park in the third race yesterday. Nelson was taken to a hospital after complaining of dizziness and lower back pain. She also suffered a bruise on her forehead. Velazquez was not injured.

title: Tribute at Wolf Trap
description: A tribute to Catherine Filene Shouse, the philanthropist and the founder of the Wolf Trap Farm Park for the Performing Arts, is to be held on June 9 at 8 P.M. at the Wolf Trap Filene Center in Vienna, Va. Mrs. Shouse died in December at the age of 98. Among those scheduled to speak or perform are Ambassador Jacques Andreani of France, Beverly Sills, Roberta Peters, the Preservation Hall Jazz Band and the Joffrey Ballet.

title: European Official Fears Sprint Venture Might Muzzle Competition
description: The Sprint Corporation's attempt to form a global alliance with the French and German telephone companies hit another obstacle yesterday, when a top official of the European Union sharply criticized a joint venture at the center of the deal between the European partners.

title: Gasoline Contract Prices Decline On Report of Increased Output
description: Gasoline prices fell yesterday after a report showed that refinery output rose last week to its highest rate this year, easing concerns that stockpiles were running below levels a year ago.

title:
CURRENTS;
They Serve, Then Disappear
description: SMALL is beautiful, but versatile is best: this summer's new collapsible furniture saves on space when folded and extends the comfort and function of a home when open. Giulio Manzoni's Spider armchair (below) is essentially a footstool-in-waiting that opens up to make an extra armchair ($1,300); from Palazzetti, 515 Madison Avenue, at 53d Street, (212) 832-1199. The umbrella chair (left) by John Kelly is "a little outdoor room, rather like sitting under a tree," he said. Ideal for a painter or sensible sun worshipers, the chair is made of white oak and brass and will turn barn gray with age. It can be folded (far left) and hung when not in use. The chair is $500, the umbrella $200, from Mr. Kelly, 144 Chambers Street, (212) 385-1885.

title: Design Help, Free for All
description: A DECADE ago, solving a design dilemma, however minor, demanded a trust fund and a celebrity decorator. At least that was the impression broadcast monthly by America's shelter magazines, whose gleaming photographs and gilt prose seemed less inspirational than promotional.

title: Bringing His Gospel Home; City Hall Lends Ear to Captain of Privatization
description: Until recently, E. S. Savas considered himself the quintessential prophet without honor. For more than two decades, ever since he says he learned a crucial lesson from the New York City Department of Sanitation, he has traveled the world preaching the virtues of having private companies perform government services, and he found appreciative audiences just about everywhere, except in the place of his inspiration.

title: UNITED STATES CAN ENDS TALKS WITH FRENCH COMPANY
description: The United States Can Corporation said yesterday that it had ended negotiations to purchase 54 percent of the French packaging company Massilly S.A. United States Can, a maker of metal containers based in Oak Brook, Ill., said Patrick Bindschedler, who owns most of Massilly, had reconsidered the deal. Timothy W. Stonich, executive vice president and chief financial officer of United States Can, said Mr. Bindschedler got "cold feet" when it came to giving up control of his family-owned company, which is based in Cluny. United States Can announced a preliminary agreement to buy the stake in Massilly in February. Shares of United States Can gained 25 cents, to $19.125, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Scott Fires First Shots In Magic Arsenal
description: According to Orlando Magic General Manager Pat Williams, small forward Dennis Scott "truly never met a shot he didn't like."

title: Working Mothers Are Equal Providers
description: To the Editor:

title: Second-Class Soldiers
description: The House National Security Committee yesterday launched the first of several expected Congressional efforts to overturn President Clinton's abortion policies. In approving a measure that would restore a ban on abortion services in military hospitals, it effectively voted to return military women (and servicemen's wives and daughters) to second-class citizenship.

title: Owners Give Raiders Reason to Stay
description: National Football League owners ended their two-day meetings today by giving the Raiders an incentive to stay in Los Angeles and devising a revenue sharing plan that would assist small market teams.

title: The Court Stands Idly By
description: The Supreme Court's refusal to hear the University of Maryland's plea to save a scholarship program for black students is a depressing setback for civil rights. Without issuing a ruling, the Court simply stood by while forces hostile to affirmative action scuttled a worthy program.

title: International Briefs; Spanish Retailer's Bid
description: Spain's biggest chain-store company, El Corte Ingles, has bid for its struggling rival, Galerias Preciados, a Galerias spokesman said yesterday. The merged company would have 50 stores across the country, excluding the Corte Ingles hypermarkets, and sales of more than $8 billion a year. Three other bidders have already offered to buy Galerias, which went into receivership in December. Corte Ingles, the most obvious suitor, had until now denied interest. (Reuters)

title: Long War Turns Liberia Into Core of a Spreading Blight
description: Nearly every street of this city bears the marks of the five-year-old conflict in Liberia. Medical clinics have been stripped of their roofs. Government ministries, dark and looted shells, are crowded homes to squatters.

title: SHOPPING WITH: Stanley Marcus1; So, What Does a Retailing Legend Buy?
description: WHEN Stanley Marcus graduated from Harvard in 1925, he wanted to be a book publisher. But his aunt, Carrie Neiman, and his father, Herbert Marcus, wouldn't hear of it. So, after Harvard Business School, he went to work in the family store. By 1935, he was its president and, with the Depression in full swing, realized he had to do something to increase sales. Especially when he saw that his affluent customers still traveled and bought their clothes in New York or Paris. So, he arranged a lunch with Conde Nast. And when Mr. Marcus says Conde Nast, he doesn't mean a group of corporate executives. He means the guy.

title: Friction Over Experimental Schools
description: The Rev. Calvin O. Butts, a Baptist minister who helped found a small new public school in Harlem, visited its director this spring to tell her that the Board of Education's superintendent in Harlem was demanding her removal.

title: Officials Doubt Intruder Meant President Harm
description: A Virginia man who was shot on the White House grounds by a Secret Service officer after scaling the fence there late Tuesday night was charged with assault and weapons violations today. But the authorities said they doubted that he had been trying to harm the President.

title: Newsweek Venture To Cover Cyberspace
description: Virtual City, a quarterly life-style magazine about cyberspace, will be introduced in September in a joint venture by Newsweek and Virtual Communications, a privately held San Francisco-based company. The magazine will be distributed at newsstands and in computer stores and is expected to have an initial distribution of 300,000.

title: Korea's Christians: A Surging, Prayerful Force
description: The choir had stopped and 12,000 seated churchgoers in the giant auditorium started chanting and bowing frantically, waves rippling through a sea of sound, thanking the Lord, thanking the nation, telling off the Devil.

title: Menem Complains, but Press Has Turned President to 'Star'
description: When President Carlos Saul Menem declared victory before cheering crowds last week in winning a second term, he could not resist taking a jab at journalists.

title: Dole Abandons His Plan For Significant Tax Cut
description: Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the Republican leader, today abandoned any notion that the Senate's budget plan could allow for a substantial tax cut right away.

title: Barron's Announces Finn as New Editor
description: Dow Jones & Company said yesterday that Edwin Finn Jr., managing editor of Barron's magazine, had been promoted to editor of the business and financial weekly.

title: Push for Term Limits
description: No task is more important than reversing the pernicious rise of a professional political class on Capitol Hill. That means continuing the campaign for term limits so as to eventually purge the newly elected Republicans even as, in November's revolutionary election, they ended the Democrats' 40-year majority.

title: Screaming About 'Scream'
description: Michael Jackson got an unexpected jolt when he tuned in to a Los Angeles radio station earlier this month. He heard his new single, "Scream," a duet with his sister Janet, on KKBT-FM, said people working on the recording. Normally, Mr. Jackson would be pleased to hear one of his new songs on the air. But this was 13 days before "Scream" was supposed to be released to radio stations.

title: Congress, Clinton in Stalemate Over How to Trim Spending
description: Congress and the White House engaged in last-minute efforts to reach a compromise over a bill cutting $16.5 billion from current-year spending but gave up any hope today of resolving their differences. The stalemate means the bill will go to the Senate on Thursday for a final vote before being sent to President Clinton, who has said he will veto it.

title: Same Hotel, Different Messages
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman and angry state workers did not cross paths here today, but their messages did.

title: While Orange County Can Seek Bankruptcy, Its Fund Can't
description: In a precedent-setting ruling in the evolving area of municipal bankruptcy law, the Federal bankruptcy judge handling Orange County ordered the dismissal yesterday of the bankruptcy case of the California county's investment pool.

title: G.O.P. Delays a Bill To Cut Foreign Aid
description: House Republicans abruptly postponed a vote on their foreign aid bill last night when it became swamped in amendments.

title: Sect Leader Denies a Tie To McVeigh
description: Six miles up a red-dirt road, into a remote pocket of forest in the Ozark Mountains of far eastern Oklahoma, reporters came today to a religious community that calls itself Elohim City. They were met by blue-shirted security guards bearing pistols, billy clubs and walkie-talkies, but also by women bearing cookies and finger sandwiches, and by laughing children scurrying about on tricycles.

title: Trial in Killings of 4 May Move
description: The United States Attorney, Faith S. Hochberg, said yesterday that she would try to move the trial of Christopher Green, who is accused of killing four people in a Montclair post office in March, from Camden to Newark. Relatives of the victims have complained about having to travel to Camden to attend the proceedings. Federal trials in New Jersey are assigned randomly among judges in Newark, Trenton and Camden.

title: Securities-Bill Staff Has Ties to the Industry
description: From breakfast meetings to late-night conferences, Senate staff members have been working furiously in recent weeks to hammer out the details of legislation long sought by the securities industry.

title: DICKSTEIN PARTNERS RAISES BID FOR HILLS STORES
description: Dickstein Partners Inc. said yesterday that it had raised its hostile offer for the Hills Stores Company to $27 a share from its original bid of $25 a share on May 3. The offer values Hills at roughly $292 million, up from $270 million. Dickstein Partners, an investment firm based in New York, said the new offer consisted of $22 a share in cash and $5 a share in debt securities. Hills, a discount retailer based in Canton, Mass., had rejected Dickstein's earlier all-cash bid as inadequate. Dickstein Partners, which already holds about 10 percent of Hills and is the company's largest shareholder, said last week that it would seek to nominate new directors to the board of Hills who would be more receptive to the takeover. Shares of Hills rose 12.5 cents yesterday, to $23.875, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: International Briefs; Carlton's Profits Soar
description: Carlton Communications P.L.C. said yesterday that its profits soared in the first half of its fiscal year. Carlton, a British television, film and video duplication and production company, said pretax profit for the six months that ended on March 31 jumped 63.6 percent, to $:120.1 million, or $189 million, compared with $:73.4 million a year earlier. Sales grew 22 percent, to $:800.6 million, or $1.26 billion, from $:658.7 million. (Reuters)

title: Surgery for Barkley. And Then?
description: CHARLES BARKLEY is scheduled to have knee surgery today and probably will not decide until after a six-week rehabilitation whether to return to the Phoenix Suns. After the final team meeting of the season, Barkley sounded less serious about retirement than he did on Saturday, when his 18 points and 23 rebounds could not keep the Houston Rockets from eliminating the Suns in the second round.

title: 1 State-Federal Tax Collector Is Better Than 2, I.R.S. Says
description: Relief is coming soon for small businesses that fall behind in turning over income, Social Security and other taxes withheld from their employees' paychecks, an Internal Revenue Service official said today.

title: Bonds Surge On New Sign Of Slowdown
description: A Government report yesterday showing the biggest drop in factory orders in more than three years sent bond prices surging and the yield on the long bond to its lowest level in nearly 15 months.

title: Lawyer Linked to 80's HUD Scandal Is Named to Investigate Housing Chief
description: A panel of appellate judges today named a lawyer who had been brushed by a scandal at the Department of Housing and Urban Development in the Reagan years to investigate whether Henry G. Cisneros, the department's current head, broke the law when he misled the F.B.I. about payments to his former mistress.

title: At Dawn, the Milkman Rides Again
description: AT 3 A.M., a van creeps along empty Manhattan streets and stops in front of a darkened building. The doorman stirs sleepy-eyed from his chair to let in the milkman.

title: A Sale by Cox Cable
description: Cox Cable Communications Inc., a unit of Cox Enterprises, said today that it had sold its 50 percent ownership in the Danish cable television company Stofa A.S. to Telia A.B., a Swedish telecommunications concern.

title: G.O.P. Delays Bill on Foreign Aid, but First Adds a Telling Anti-Abortion Amendment
description: The Republicans abruptly pulled their foreign aid bill off the House floor tonight after it became swamped in amendments, including one that demonstrated the anti-abortion sentiment that prevails in the House now that Republicans are in control.

title: Derivatives Specialist Quits Salomon After 3-Week Stint
description: On May 4, Sheldon Epstein, renowned in the arcane world of derivatives for his role in inventing the indexed-amortizing swap, pledged himself to Salomon Brothers Inc.

title: Sports of The Times; Cool Lindros Gives Garden The Big Chill
description: LET history note that the moment Eric Lindros hit the ice for his first run at Mark Messier last night, it was the start of a long, contentious relationship between Lindros and Madison Square Garden. Let history also note that it was the Garden ice, and nothing else, that Lindros had a problem with.

title: Mets' Backward Trend Continues With Loss
description: It may be too soon to worry about where the Mets are in the standing, as Dallas Green again asserted last night. But after a 5-0 loss to the Dodgers, the Mets have lost four games in a row. They are 10-16. Most important, they are 10 games behind the East Division-leading Philadelphia Phillies in the loss column.

title:
CURRENTS;
Two Roads to Splendid: One Long, the Other Short
description: ONE new restaurant took 11 years and several million dollars to complete. The other, eight weeks and several thousand dollars. Both epitomize smart, stylish New York design.

title: California Moves to Form an Agency to Purchase Power
description: The California Public Utilities Commission voted yesterday to recommend the creation of an agency to buy power for the state's utility customers from the lowest-cost producers in many states in an effort to bring down power costs.

title: 'Gump,' a Huge Hit, Still Isn't Raking In Huge Profits? Hmm.
description: How can a huge hit film like "Forrest Gump," the third-highest-grossing movie of all time, not yet show a profit? The answer is, well, Hollywood bookkeeping and the strange ways studios spend money.

title: International Briefs; In Brief
description: Allied Signal Inc. said yesterday that a Japanese company was joining its joint venture, Kalyani Brakes, a brake component manufacturer in India. Under the agreement, Allied Signal, Kalyani Group of India and Nabco of Japan will be equal partners in Kalyani Brakes. (Reuters)

title: Journal; Ghosts of 1600
description: Did it happen too fast, or are we really that numb? You'd think the country might have taken a breath and paused to mark a turning point in history over the weekend when barricades abruptly sealed off the White House from drive-by voyeurs. Instead, there were a few sighs from politicians and Sunday TV pundits and some happy visuals of Roller bladers and pedestrians enjoying the newest mall-heaven, a sunny, car-free Pennsylvania Avenue. After which everyone went back to talking about . . . Connie Chung.

title: Hextall Stays Focused Amid Noise in Garden
description: The force of the noise within Madison Square Garden early last night was directed toward one small spot on the ice, the light blue half circle occupied by Ron Hextall. The people in the stands had wanted him so badly that they chanted his name a week in advance, when Quebec was still the Rangers' opponent and the first round was not yet complete.

title: Europe Warns of Trade Suits On Car Quotas
description: Fearing they might be cut out of a deal on auto imports, European officials warned Japan and the United States today that they would sue both countries if the Japanese agreed to demands to set numerical targets for increased imports of American cars.

title: International Briefs; Results at Bass Improve
description: Bass P.L.C. said yesterday that its pretax profit for the first six months of its fiscal year rose nearly 9 percent, helped by strong performances from its hotel and leisure divisions. Bass, the British brewer that also owns and operates hotels, pubs and casinos, posted pretax earnings of $:263 million, or $413.8 million, for the six months ended April 15, compared with $:242 million the year before. Sales were flat at $:2.24 billion, or $3.52 billion. (Dow Jones)

title: Choice to Head Jacobi Faces Opposition
description: Several board members of New York City's public hospitals agency said yesterday that they plan to mount a campaign against City Hall's choice for executive director of Jacobi Medical Center in the Bronx, an administrator who was forced to resign the very same post nearly 10 years ago.

title: C. R. BARD TO ACQUIRE MEDCHEM PRODUCTS
description: C. R. Bard Inc. said yesterday that it would acquire Medchem Products Inc. in a stock transaction valued at about $101.8 million. C. R. Bard, a maker of catheters and other medical products based in Murray Hill, N.J., will pay $9.25 in stock for each of Medchem's 11 million outstanding shares. Medchem, based in Woburn, Mass., is a maker of surgical devices. Shares of Medchem rose $2.125, to $8.625, on the New York Stock Exchange, while shares of Bard fell 37.5 cents, to $29.

title: Arranged' Marriage
description: To The Home Section:

title: The Human Brain Behind Electronic Ones
description: Where that famous information superhighway will lead and exactly what will travel down it remain the stuff of speculation or dreams, but the speculators seem to agree on at least on one point: William H. Gates, the subject of "Tycoon," tomorrow night's NBC documentary, is likely to be in charge of a lot of whatever it turns out to be.

title: Corrections
description: The Our Towns column on Friday about Waneta E. Hoyt, who is imprisoned in Owego, N.Y., for killing her five children, referred incorrectly to the Guildford Four. The Guildford Four -- defendants in a case that involved testimony from an expert on coerced confessions, also consulted by Mrs. Hoyt's lawyers -- were imprisoned in a pub bombing in Guildford, England, and released after their conviction was overturned. The authorities accused them of being members of the Irish Republican Army, but the defendants denied the allegation and it was never proved.

title: VWR TO BUY BAXTER'S INDUSTRIAL SCIENCES UNIT
description: The VWR Corporation signed a definitive agreement yesterday to acquire the industrial and life sciences division of Baxter International Inc. for $400 million in cash. VWR, a distributor of laboratory supplies and chemicals based in West Chester, Pa., also said that EM Industries, the United States unit of E. Merck of Germany, had agreed to exercise its warrant to buy 967,000 common shares of VWR for $11 a share and purchase an additional 6.8 million shares of common stock for $12.44 each. VWR said it would change its name to the VWR Scientific Products Corporation after the deal is completed. The combined company will have annual revenue of about $1 billion, VWR said.

title: Police Supervisors Are Questioned About Hotel Rampage
description: Beginning a process that could take weeks, Police Department investigators yesterday interviewed five captains and other supervisors who were among an estimated 800 officers in Washington during the drunken rampage through several hotels earlier this month.

title: World News Briefs; U.S. Issues Advisory To Americans in Algeria
description: The United States has issued an advisory to all American citizens in Algeria to "have substantial armed protection while traveling overland, on their work sites or in their accommodations." The warning follows a move by the State Department earlier this week naming the Armed Islamic Group as a terrorist organization.

title: Charitable Giving Rose 3.6% in 1994, Philanthropy Trust Says
description: Charitable giving in the United States rose by 3.6 percent last year to $130 billion, just slightly ahead of inflation, according to figures made public yesterday by the American Association of Fund-Raising Counsel's Trust for Philanthropy. After inflation, the gain amounted to six-tenths of 1 percent.

title: Educators' Partnerships Test New Ideas Within Framework of a Traditional System
description: Over three decades, New York City educators have opened scores of small public academies, including 46 high schools in the last two years. In the series, all the new high schools are profiled, as well as influential older ones and some innovative elementary and middle schools. Here is a sampler of schools that are trying to create oases of learning in depressed communities where many children never finish high school. Oceanhill-Brownsville Secondary School At Intermediate School 55, 2021 Bergen Street, Brooklyn. IDEA: remake a junior high. OPENED: 1994. (N.V.) CURRENT ENROLLMENT: 200. PEAK: Not available. GRADES: 6; eventually, 6-12.

title: Trustee for Bankrupt Foundation Asks Charities to Return Funds
description: The court-appointed trustee for the bankrupt Foundation for New Era Philanthropy said yesterday that he was asking nonprofit groups that received funds from New Era to return them voluntarily, and he noted that one group, which he would not name, had already written a check for $25,000.

title: International Briefs; Holvis Shares Fall 14% After Intertech Drops Bid
description: Shares of Holvis Holzstoff A.G., a Swiss paper company that is a takeover target, fell 74 Swiss francs, or 14 percent, yesterday, yet continued to trade at more than the price of 435 Swiss francs, or $362.50, that the International Paper Company has offered. The share plunge, to 443 francs, came a day after Intertech Group Inc., a closely held South Carolina paper and plastics company, dropped a competing bid of 500 francs a share bid for Holvis.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Bonds Rise and Yields Drop On New Signs of Slowdown Bond prices surged and their yields fell sharply after a Government report showed a drop of 4 percent in orders in April, convincing some investors that the Fed's next move would be to lower interest rates.

title: World News Briefs; U.S. Calls Nuclear Talks With North Korea Useful
description: The United States and North Korea are still far from agreement over the North's nuclear program but have held "useful discussions" here that could end with an accord, the chief American negotiator said today.

title: A Child's View of Divorce
description: To The Home Section:

title: Hewlett Profit Sharing
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company said yesterday that it had distributed more than $255 million in profit-sharing payouts to more than 97,000 eligible employees throughout the world. The computer company, based in Palo Alto, Calif., said the profit-sharing checks were based on net earnings for the first half of 1995 of $1.2 billion, compared with $776 million in the first half of 1994. The company said this payout represents the highest profit-sharing payout in its history. Hewlett-Packard employees are eligible for profit-sharing after six consecutive months of service with the company.

title: Struggle for control of Ayer & Partners goes public as its charismatic leader departs unexpectedly.
description: A BATTLE behind the scenes for control of N. W. Ayer & Partners, the venerable New York agency struggling to make a comeback, erupted publicly yesterday. The investors who own most of Ayer announced unexpectedly that Steve Dworin, the charismatic adman hired to run the agency only 13 months ago, was leaving, effective immediately.

title: U.S. Withholds Recognition As a Tribe From Paugussetts
description: The Golden Hill Paugussetts, who have claimed much of Fairfield County as ancestral lands, have failed to qualify for Federal recognition as a tribe, the Bureau of Indian Affairs has ruled.

title: Calendar: Exhibitions, A House Tour, a Festival
description: Beyond Stone or Steel Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53d Street; (212) 708-9400.

title: Letter Grades Flunk The Evaluation Test
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: INTERNATIONAL MULTIFOODS CORP., Minneapolis, a food service distributor, signed a definitive agreement to purchase Alum Rock Foodservice, a unit of Conagra Inc., for undisclosed terms. JOHN ALDEN FINANCIAL CORP., Miami, an insurance holding company, said its board had authorized the repurchase of up to 2.5 million common shares. The company currently has about 25.4 million shares outstanding.

title: Market Place; A Quiet Board Room Revolution: Power Shifts to Outside Directors
description: Shareholders can take heart from a new study: Procedural changes in corporate board rooms seem to be shifting the balance of power toward their representatives, the outside directors, and away from the chairmen and chief executives.

title: Penske Jumps the Indy Gun
description: This is how bad Roger Penske's month of May has been at the Indianapolis Motor Speedway: He couldn't even withdraw a car from the lineup and get it right.

title: BUFFETT GROUP TO BUY R. C. WILLEY HOME FURNISHINGS
description: Berkshire Hathaway Inc., the holding company controlled by the investor Warren E. Buffett, signed an agreement yesterday to acquire the closely held R. C. Willey Home Furnishings. The terms of the deal were not disclosed. Berkshire Hathaway said the acquisition had been approved by shareholders of R. C. Willey of Salt Lake City, which has seven stores. Berkshire Hathaway owns several consumer products companies, including See's Candies and the Dexter Shoe Company. The company also owns Nebraska Furniture Mart and 80 percent of Borsheim's, a jewelry store in Omaha.

title: Counterfeit Airliner Parts Are Said to Be Often Used
description: Counterfeit aircraft parts, like improperly reconditioned castoffs, are commonly used on commercial airliners because of suppliers' greed and poor Government oversight, officials of the Federal Aviation Administration and the Federal Bureau of Investigation told a Senate panel today.

title: In Performance; CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: A Gentle Successor To 'Cavalleria Rusticana' Mascagni's 'Silvano' Carnegie Hall

title: School Safety Officer Is Arrested With a Pinata Full of Marijuana
description: A safety officer in the New York City public school system was delighted when a package was delivered to him yesterday, the police said. A moment later, the police said, delight turned to despair when he found himself under arrest for marijuana possession.

title: Pack Up and Go
description: The United Nations Secretary General, Boutros Boutros-Ghali, has called for a "fundamental review" of U.N. operations in Bosnia. Such an examination is long overdue. Even those who still staunchly defend the idea of U.N. peacekeeping have been dismayed by Mr. Boutros-Ghali's continued insistence that the operation has been a success. Now he must admit it has been nothing of the sort and call for the removal of U.N. forces.

title: Tyson Confirms McNeeley Bout But Won't Say Much More
description: In his first news conference in more than three years, Mike Tyson answered some questions yesterday and deflected others while confirming that his return to boxing would come Aug. 19 against a wild-swinging heavyweight named Peter McNeeley.

title: House Panel Moves Ahead On Phone Plan
description: Amid furious horse-trading to satisfy rival interest groups, the House Commerce Committee began voting today on provisions of a sweeping bill to overhaul the nation's communications laws.

title: Defendants Say Shut Door Killed Tennis Star
description: The death of Vitas Gerulaitis, the tennis star, might have been avoided if someone had not shut the door to the basement of the pool cottage where he took a nap last September, lawyers for the mechanic and the company charged in his death said today.

title: Hameroff to Acquire Ruhr of Minneapolis
description: Chuck Ruhr Advertising in Minneapolis, which filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in March, said yesterday that it would be acquired by Hameroff/Milenthal/ Spence of Columbus, Ohio, and would be renamed HMS/Ruhr Ltd. The terms of the agreement were not disclosed.

title: A Missing Uniform Wrapped in a Mystery
description: As though "The Maltese Falcon" had met "The Pride of the Yankees," the reported theft of an old Babe Ruth uniform from a car in midtown Manhattan opened a window yesterday into decades of mystery, money and murder.

title: A Culture Built On a Wall of Silence
description: HOW could it be? How could it happen that as many as 800 New York City police officers go to Washington to honor fallen colleagues, that about 50 of them get drunk and create such havoc in downtown hotels that guests in one of them had to be routed from their rooms -- and not one officer from New York steps forward to say who did what.

title: Accounts
description: Garibaldi Factory Warehouse, New York, to Bleecker & Sullivan Communications, New York, as the first agency to handle advertising and public relations for the men's apparel retailer. The billings have not been determined.

title: 2 Indicted Over Fire Dept. Loss
description: About $64,000 that should be in the bank account of Buena Vista Fire Department District 3 is missing. Yesterday a former fire chief, Bobby Hines, and a former treasurer of the department, Robert Bryant, were indicted in the case.

title: International Briefs; Defending Record, Head Of Daimler Steps Down
description: Edzard Reuter stepped down yesterday as chairman of Daimler-Benz, Germany's biggest company, with an impassioned defense of his eight years at the helm. Under Mr. Reuter, Daimler doubled in size and was transformed from its Mercedes-Benz roots as a luxury-car maker into an "integrated technology group," encompassing aerospace, rail and electronics.

title: U.S. Pressing China Hard to Maintain Democracy in Hong Kong
description: Signaling heightened interest in Hong Kong's future, American officials have issued their boldest warnings yet to China over its future treatment of the British colony when it reverts to Chinese sovereignty in two years.

title: A Season Of Change To Woo The Young
description: Trying not only to resurrect itself but also to reinvent itself, CBS announced a fall prime-time schedule yesterday that emphasized the network's quest for younger viewers, while changing its programming every night of the week.

title: Mitchell Is Minus His Check
description: While the paid absence of KEVIN MITCHELL from the lineup was a frequent occurrence in his days as a major leaguer, his Japanese employers are considering the current injury sojourn a violation of his contract. The Dakei Hawks yesterday told Mitchell, who has been missing games with a sore right knee, that they will not pay his salary for May because he won't accept their plan for treatment. Paychecks are issued each Thursday. "I won't play if I don't get money," Mitchell said.

title: One Salmon Doesn't Mean Rhine Is Fit to Drink
description: In the midst of all the damage created by the flooding of the Rhine early this year, the discovery of a lone, stranded salmon seemed an odd bit of good news. The appearance of the salmon, a fish that is choosy about water quality, seemed proof that the river was at last becoming cleaner.

title: China Takes Its Own Way in World Economy
description: To the Editor:

title: In Performance; DANCE
description: A Cooperative Celebrates Itself 'States of Grace' Dance Theater Workshop

title: Lincoln Hospital Severely Injured Baby in Delivery, a Jury Finds
description: A Bronx jury has found that inexperienced doctors at Lincoln Hospital botched the delivery of a baby girl 17 years ago, causing deafness and lifelong brain damage, and it ordered the city's hospital agency to pay the mother $42 million.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball American League

title: Death of Baby Girl Is Ruled a Homicide
description: The death of a 21-month-old baby girl at Bellevue Hospital Center in Manhattan early yesterday was ruled a homicide by the City Medical Examiner's office, which found that the infant suffered from child abuse and had died after a "blunt impact to the head and torso."

title: Charged-Up Devils Zap the Penguins And Go Up, 2-1
description: The Penguins-Devils playoff series was supposed to be a classic clash of Pittsburgh's offensive power against New Jersey's tight defense. After three games, the Devils are the team that has provided the firepower while retaining the strong defensive system that stymied opponents all season.

title: Raytheon Can't Complain About Electric Rates
description: To the Editor:

title: Open Door to Conspiracy Theories
description: THE KILLING OF ROBERT F. KENNEDY An Investigation of Motive, Means and Opportunity By Dan E. Moldea Illustrated. 342 pages. W. W. Norton. $27.50.

title: Computer Gap Worries Blacks
description: HIGH technology already plays some part in American daily life, from automatic teller machines to pay-per-view cable channels. But a recently released study by the Census Bureau has confirmed what black people in the computer industry have long suspected: that many blacks, even those who can afford to buy personal computers, are not embracing them as necessary tools.

title: Guilty Plea in Dog Fund Theft
description: Gertrude Cooper, the Borough Treasurer, pleaded guilty on Monday to stealing $12,000 from the dog license trust fund. "She seems to be genuinely remorseful," said the Sussex County Prosecutor, Dennis O'Leary.

title:
BASEBALL;
McDowell Loses No-Hitter and Game in 8th
description: Jack McDowell traveled the path from no-hitter to oh-no tonight at Anaheim Stadium.

title: Educators' Partnerships Test New Ideas Within Framework of a Traditional System
description: Over three decades, New York City educators have opened scores of small public academies, including 46 high schools in the last two years. In the series, all the new high schools are profiled, as well as influential older ones and some innovative elementary and middle schools. Here is a sampler of schools that are trying to create oases of learning in depressed communities where many children never finish high school. Manhattan East School At Junior High School 99, 410 East 100th Street, East Harlem. IDEA: one building, four academies. OPENED: 1981. (C.E.I.) CURRENT ENROLLMENT: 230 (peak). GRADES: 6-8.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a passage in the TV Sports column on Tuesday dealing with local Nielsen ratings for the Knicks and Rangers games on Sunday misstated the number of households represented by each point. In the New York market, each point represents 67,160 households; it is one national rating point that represents 954,000.

title: Bridge
description: In 1929, in Manhattan, the late Oswald Jacoby won the first Goldman Open Pairs, which was the start of the Eastern Regionals, the oldest such tournament played anywhere. The 67th Easterns begin tomorrow at the Sheraton New York Hotel, Seventh Avenue at 52d Street.

title: Another Bomb Scare at a Rutgers Library
description: A bomb squad combed the undergraduate library on the Rutgers University campus in Camden, N.J., yesterday after a suspicious device was found in a hollowed-out book.

title: Founder to End His Role as Chief At Vanguard
description: John C. Bogle, who for 20 years has been both the mutual fund industry's best-known gadfly and one of its most successful executives, said yesterday that he would soon give up the latter role.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, the Advertising column on the Media Business page on Tuesday, about a settlement between Maurice Saatchi and Cordiant P.L.C., omitted the given name of an advertising executive who is now free to join Mr. Saatchi's agency, the M &C Saatchi Agency. He is Jeremy Sinclair.

title: Heavy Traffic Driving to Airport
description: Travelers flying out of Newark International Airport this holiday weekend may find their getaways delayed by traffic on the ground. Nearly 400,000 people are expected to use the airport this weekend, and officials are advising drivers to expect heavy traffic and to allow extra time to use the long-term parking lots. Information on parking is available at (201) 961-6000 or at 530 on the AM radio dial.

title: INSIDE
description: Harold Wilson Is Dead

title: Chinese Won't Yield on Isolating a Global Women's Forum
description: Disregarding the advice of United Nations officials and diplomats, including the United States chief delegate, Madeleine K. Albright, the Chinese Government is holding fast to its decision to move a huge forum on women's issues to a remote tourist area 30 miles from Beijing, a spokeswoman for a Chinese organization said today.

title: In Performance; THEATER
description: When Even Compatriots Are Bitterly Divided 'Fleischer' Brooklyn Academy of Music

title: NATO May Be Called On to Silence Guns in Sarajevo
description: Responding to Sarajevo's steady slide back into terror and isolation, the United Nations commander in Bosnia and Herzegovina issued an ultimatum today threatening NATO air strikes if heavy weapons in the capital were not quickly silenced.

title: Gerry Adams and Briton Discuss Ulster Peace in Washington
description: Gerry Adams, the political leader of the Irish Republican Army, and Sir Patrick Mayhew, the British Secretary for Northern Ireland, met for the first time today to discuss the peace effort in Northern Ireland.

title: A Young Bear Gains Entry To an Exclusive Community
description: Lawrence Farms South, a private community of large colonials and expansive lawns, is home to corporate lawyers and business executives. Their neighbors include a son of Dorothy Schiff, a former owner of The New York Post.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;
description: A woman whose fetus was killed in a traffic accident involving a municipal recycling truck has been awarded $2.5 million in an out-of-court settlement with the township. "There is no amount of money that can replace my son," said Helen Hartnett, whose own injuries make it risky for her to become pregnant again. The settlement will be paid from a taxpayer-subsidized municipal insurance fund. SUSAN JO KELLER

title: Educators' Partnerships Test New Ideas Within Framework of a Traditional System
description: Over three decades, New York City educators have opened scores of small public academies, including 46 high schools in the last two years. In the series, all the new high schools are profiled, as well as influential older ones and some innovative elementary and middle schools. Here is a sampler of schools that are trying to create oases of learning in depressed communities where many children never finish high school. Bronx Coalition Community High School At Intermediate School 193, 1919 Prospect Avenue, East Tremont, the Bronx. IDEA: personal guidance. OPENED: 1994. (C.C.E.) CURRENT ENROLLMENT: 58. PEAK: 350-400. GRADES: 9; eventually, 9-12.

title: A Generation Gap in Venture Capital
description: In his 11 years in the venture capital business, Jonathan Flint found himself becoming more and more frustrated at other people getting rich from all his work. Sure, he earned a six-figure salary, lived in a stylish suburb of Boston and was respected by his peers. But after steering his firm, Burr, Egan, Deleage & Company, through a series of stellar software start-ups -- including a $105 million payback on a $3 million investment in the Powersoft Corporation -- he wanted more.

title: Government Is Urged to Act Quickly in Protecting Habitats
description: An expert panel convened by the National Academy of Sciences today called on the Government to act more swiftly to protect the habitats of plant and animal species that are found to be in danger of extinction.

title: Holocaust Museum Proposes Director
description: The United States Holocaust Memorial Museum has nominated Dr. Walter Reich, a child of Holocaust survivors, to be the museum's new director, pending board approval.

title: Educators' Partnerships Test New Ideas Within Framework of a Traditional System
description: Over three decades, New York City educators have opened scores of small public academies, including 46 high schools in the last two years. In the series, all the new high schools are profiled, as well as influential older ones and some innovative elementary and middle schools. Here is a sampler of schools that are trying to create oases of learning in depressed communities where many children never finish high school. Fannie Lou Hamer Freedom High School 486 Howe Avenue, Soundview, the Bronx. IDEA: relief for a troubled neighborhood. OPENED: 1994. (C.C.E.) CURRENT ENROLLMENT: 61. PEAK: 350-400. GRADES: 9; 9-12 in September 1997.

title: Judge Assails Pataki
description: A state judge accused the Pataki administration today of trying to reward the chemical industry by repealing a restriction on the use of a chemical in many insect repellents. The substance, called DEET, is used in many insect repellents for sale across the United States.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The summer party whirl of Martha's Vineyard began in Manhattan on Tuesday night when a group of friends gave a book party for "By Vineyard Light," honoring its author, ROSE STYRON. With Vineyard-inspired poems by Ms. Styron and shimmering images by CRAIG DRIPPS, a photographer by summer and a mathematics teacher the rest of the year, the book from Rizzoli International Publications evoked beach fever among the guests, many of whom were preparing for the coming weekend on the island.

title: Economic Scene; First luxury cars, now bicycles get the trade once-over.
description: IF Tokyo does not bend, say goodbye to all those sleek Japanese luxury cars. But look on the bright side: You can always buy a bicycle.

title: Essay; Dole's Divine Distrust
description: The voters' trust, goes the truism, is the most valuable asset any politician can possess. Image-makers strive to create it; candidates ache to make voters' trust the touchstone of their candidacies.

title: New York City Workers Have Sacrificed Plenty
description: To the Editor:

title: Los Angeles City Council Declines to Act Against Police Chief Accused of Misconduct
description: The Los Angeles City Council met in closed session today to discuss whether to discipline Chief Willie L. Williams, who is accused of lying about receiving free rooms at a Las Vegas hotel and casino.

title: MERIDIAN TO ACQUIRE UNITED COUNTIES BANCORPORATION
description: Meridian Bancorp Inc. signed a letter of intent yesterday to acquire the United Counties Bancorporation in a stock swap valued at $360 million. An earlier round of talks ended in December after the companies failed to agree on merger terms; a letter of intent signed in August set the value of the merger at $376 million. Under the new agreement, each share of United Counties common stock will be exchanged for five shares of Meridian Bancorp, a financial services company based in Reading, Pa. The deal will be a tax-free exchange for United Counties shareholders. Shares of United Counties rose $22.50, to $150, in Nasdaq trading. Shares of Meridian fell 87.5 cents, to $32.125.

title: Kean Backs Lamar Alexander
description: Former Gov. Thomas H. Kean is endorsing Lamar Alexander, former Governor of Tennessee, in the Republican race for President. They will appear today at news conferences here and at the Newark Airport Hilton, and at a fund-raising event in East Brunswick.

title: Uncovered Short Sales Up 2.6% For Month on Nasdaq Market
description: In a short sale, an investor borrows shares from a brokerage firm and sells them, hoping to buy them back later at a lower price and make a profit on the difference. Uncovered short sales, or those with open positions, are those that have been borrowed and sold, but which have not yet been covered by a repurchase.

title: Robert Arpin, 48, Catholic Priest Who Announced He Was Gay
description: The Rev. Robert Arpin, the first openly gay Roman Catholic priest in the United States, died on Tuesday at his home in San Francisco. He was 48.

title: Meningitis Is Traced to a Bar
description: Two cases of meningitis have been reported in Cumberland County and the State Department of Health is warning people who patronized a Millville bar to seek treatment.

title: 'Love Letters' to Hitler, a Book and Play Shocking to Germans
description: Of all the books and theater productions about the Third Reich that have flooded Germany as it marks the 50th anniversary of the end of World War II, few are as bizarre and provocative as one called "Love Letters to Adolf Hitler."

title: Charles Wohlstetter, 85, Founder of Contel, Dies
description: Charles Wohlstetter, who developed small rural telephone companies and combined them into a $3 billion business before selling it to the GTE Corporation, died yesterday at his home in New York City. He was 85.

title: Garden Q.&A.
description: A Shooting Star

title: Matsushita Posts Big Profit, Sees Big Loss
description: The Matsushita Electric Industrial Company said today that it expected to report a loss of nearly $1.9 billion on the sale of its controlling interest in MCA Inc., the Hollywood entertainment company, to the Seagram Company.

title: Dole and Gramm: At Play in the Field of Budgets
description: At a passing glance, it may appear that the Senate's 100 members have spent most of the week debating a plan to balance the Federal budget. In fact, maybe 46 of them have. The other 54 -- that is to say, the Republicans -- have been watching a race for President.

title: TENET HEALTHCARE TO SELL ITS HOSPITALS IN ASIA
description: The Tenet Healthcare Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its Asian and Australian hospitals to Parkway Holdings of Singapore for $415 million. Tenet, formerly known as National Medical Enterprises, said Parkway would pay $352 million for Tenet's hospitals in Singapore, Malaysia and Thailand and assume $78 million in debt. Parkway also agreed in principle to pay $63 million for Tenet's 53 percent stake in Australian Medical Enterprises. The sale would free Tenet, based in Santa Monica, Calif., from most of its international operations and enable the company to focus on its United States operations, which includes 83 hospitals. The sale was announced after the stock market had closed. Earlier, shares of Tenet were unchanged at $16.25 on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Harold Wilson, Twice British Prime Minister and Old Lion of Labor Party, Dies at 79
description: Harold Wilson, a Yorkshireman who combined a common touch with an uncommon intellect that turned him into the British Labor Party's most formidable vote getter and perennial Prime Minister, died early yesterday in London. He was 79.

title: Executive Changes
description: CABLE NEWS NETWORK, Atlanta, a unit of Turner Broadcasting System Inc., promoted Lou Dobbs, a CNN Business News anchor, to executive vice president, in addition to his post as head of the cable news station's business news division. CORNING INC., Corning, N.Y., named Van C. Campbell, its vice chairman, to the additional post of chairman of its Corning Life Sciences Inc. unit.

title: George Cottrell, 91; Official at Harvard
description: George William Cottrell Jr., the founding editor of the Harvard Library Bulletin who was a former research associate in ornithology at Harvard's Museum of Comparative Zoology, died last Thursday at the Riverwoods retirement community in Exeter, N.H. He was 91 and formerly lived in Cambridge, Mass., and Hillsboro, N.H.

title: A Liability to Dole
description: To the Editor:

title: Factory Orders Skid: A Harder Landing?
description: Evidence mounted today that the economy was cooling faster than the Federal Reserve intended when it doubled short-term interest rates from February 1994 to February 1995.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt * Anheuser-Busch Co., St. Louis, is selling $200 million of notes due in 2005 through Dillon, Read & Co. The notes are priced at 99.225 to yield 6.858 percent. Callable in seven years at par, the issue is rated A1 by Moody's Investors Service Inc. and AA- by the Standard & Poor's Corp.

title: Reforming Special Education
description: An independent panel has recommended a wholesale restructuring of the troubled special education programs in New York City. Instead of teaching the students in a huge, separate, costly system, the panel would integrate more than 100,000 disabled children into regular classrooms. The impulse is right. Now it is up to Schools Chancellor Ramon Cortines, the Board of Education and City Hall to muster the political will to make changes.

title: TALKS WITH HOUSE ARE NEXT
description: In what could be a first step toward a revolutionary change in Government economic policy, the Senate today approved a Republican road map that is supposed to put the Government on the course to a balanced Federal budget in seven years.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in Business Day yesterday with an article about the emergence of new venture capital firms reversed the identifications of two men who are starting Polaris Ventures. Jonathan Flint was on the left and Terrance McGuire in the middle.

title: Air Strike in Bosnia
description: NATO's bombing raid yesterday against the Bosnian Serbs, its first in six months, was a justified use of force to safeguard the civilians of Sarajevo. By hitting an ammunition dump near the rebel capital of Pale, the alliance bolstered the credibility of the beleaguered U.N. mission in former Yugoslavia and signaled that escalating military pressure on Sarajevo would not be tolerated. With luck and follow-through, this action could save civilian lives, avert a messy U.N. withdrawal and nudge along the painstaking search for a diplomatic settlement.

title: In New Sign of Slow Economy, Home Resales Plunge by 6.4%
description: More signs emerged today that the economy was heading toward a sharp slowdown. Sales of existing homes fell 6.4 percent in April to the lowest level in almost three years, despite declining mortgage rates.

title: A Museum Marvels At a Brave New World Of Materials
description: WHAT a smart idea for the Museum of Modern Art to mount a design show about materials. At a time when so much fuss is being made over cyberspace, virtual reality and other odysseys into the immaterial realm of pixels, bytes and holograms, "Mutant Materials in Contemporary Design" reminds us that we still inhabit a world of things.

title: O Canada
description: To the Editor:

title: Art In Review
description: Gael Stack Condeso/Lawler Gallery 524 Broadway (at Spring Street) SoHo Through tomorrow

title: INSIDE
description: Golan May Be Key to Peace

title: U.S. Dismayed Over Cuban Political Prisoners
description: The Clinton Administration and human rights groups said today that Cuba had still not freed six political prisoners after telling a French human rights organization on Tuesday that it would do so, and they expressed disappointment over the delay.

title: Bomb Suspect's Brother Has Hopes
description: Proclaiming that he was just a "happy-go-lucky guy" and "an average American," James D. Nichols, the brother of one of the two chief suspects in the Oklahoma City bombing, emerged from a court hearing today to say of the bombing, "I hope they find the people who have done it."

title: Vice Chairman Quits J. Walter Thompson
description: The J. Walter Thompson Company in New York said yesterday that William C. Thompson Jr., vice chairman and chief marketing officer, would leave "to pursue other interests," effective immediately.

title: No Double Duty for Davy Jones
description: DAVY JONES's dream of driving in the Indianapolis 500 and the Coca-Cola 600 on the same day ended yesterday when he wrecked his best stock car in a practice session at Charlotte Motor Speedway in Concord, N.C. Jones, who will start 32d in Sunday morning's event in Indiana, had hoped to catch a plane after the race and fly to North Carolina for the late-afternoon start of Nascar's longest race. But the Winston Cup rookie wrecked his Ford Thunderbird beyond repair in a late-afternoon practice mishap and his team decided it would be unable to get the backup car ready in time for the second round of qualifying. (AP)

title: U.S. Lobbied Allies for Weeks Before NATO Attack on Serbs
description: In the two weeks leading to NATO's air attack on a Bosnian Serb ammunition depot today, the Clinton Administration heavily lobbied United Nations officials and European allies to use air strikes to restore credibility to the United Nations force in Bosnia, Administration officials said today.

title: In the world according to Haagen-Dazs, ice cream is your friend and you shouldn't ration friends.
description: REMEMBER when I screamed, you screamed, we all screamed for ice cream? Haagen-Dazs is hoping to reignite that kind of enthusiasm with advertising ambitiously seeking to change attitudes about a brand that for many consumers still embodies the excesses and extravagances of the 1980's.

title: Roosevelt S. Zanders, Stars' Chauffeur, Dies at 81
description: Roosevelt S. Zanders, New York's "celebrity chauffeur," whose concept of personal service included shipping 100 pounds of shrimp to John Wayne in Paris and even securing theater tickets for Sol Hurok, died last Saturday at the Jewish Home and Hospital in Manhattan. He was 81, and had lived much of his life in Harlem.

title: CHRONICLE
description: How far will a literary agent go to sell his client's book?

title: The Senate Saves a Campaign Law
description: In a surprising display of bipartisan support for cleaner politics, the Senate voted this week to abandon a Republican plan calling for abolition of the nation's public campaign financing system for Presidential candidates. Such public financing has proved its value, over five national elections, by decreasing the need for Presidential candidates to raise large sums from special interests and by preventing the party in power from gaining an insurmountable financial advantage.

title: SONAT TO SELL BAKER HUGHES SHARES AT A LOSS
description: Sonat Inc. said yesterday that it would sell preferred stock back to Baker Hughes Inc. for $167 million, taking a loss of $8 million on the sale. Sonat, a gas pipeline and exploration company based in Birmingham, Ala., said it would sell back to Baker Hughes four million shares of preferred stock it received as part of the April 1992 sale of Sonat's Teleco Oilfield Services Unit. Sonat will report an after-tax loss of $8 million, or around 9 cents a share, on the sale of the stock, which has a face value of $200 million and was carried on Sonat's books for $180 million. The preferred stock pays a 6 percent dividend and is convertible into common shares of Baker Hughes for $32.50 a share. Sonat said it was selling the stock to help pay off $700 million in debt and to raise money for exploration and drilling.

title: Lost, Found and Somewhere in Between
description: A visit to Christian Boltanski's "Lost: New York Projects" requires a handful of subway tokens and an hour or two of travel, from a church at the top of Manhattan to a synagogue at the bottom, with stops at a museum and a train station in between.

title: After Surgery, Barkley Facing a Decision
description: CHARLES BARKLEY had torn cartilage repaired in his left knee yesterday, and the Suns star is expected to complete his rehabilitation in six weeks. "Everything went according to plan today," said Dr. RICHARD EMERSON, a team physician who performed the arthroscopic procedure at St. Lukes Medical Center in Phoenix.

title: 1995 N.B.A. Playoffs; Spurs Are Clamoring for Some Continuity
description: A new scapegoat just hit town, and his name is Bob Hill. The San Antonio Spurs were unrecognizable Wednesday night -- after their coach, Hill, produced a lineup straight out of preseason -- and it even brought Dennis Rodman sympathy.

title: Japanese Concerns Show Sharp Gains
description: Some of Japan's biggest electronics companies today posted large profit increases for the year that ended March 31, but they warned of a slowdown in the current fiscal year as the strong yen cuts into earnings.

title: Take My Date, Please. Take All the Men. Please.
description: A recent HBO special from Aspen, Colo., provided a 1995 showcase for young comedians, who all turned out to be men. The performers, including the host, Garry Shandling, spent much time musing on what used to be called "private parts." Today, apparently, they are public objets d'art. Tomorrow, in HBO's oddly segregated comedy universe, female comics get their turn, also out of Aspen, in the curiously titled "Women of the Night IV." They focus more on aging, dating and, yes, men obsessed with their crotches.

title: MAKER OF ARIZONA TEAS WILL NOT BE SOLD TO HEILEMAN
description: The makers of Arizona teas and juice drinks, Ferolito, Vultaggio & Sons, will not sell the company to the G. Heileman Brewing Company, Ferolito's chairman said yesterday. Speaking at a conference in Manhattan, Don Vultaggio, the chairman of the company, said that the takeover was not going to happen. Heileman is best known for Colt 45 malt liquor. The Dallas buyout firm Hicks Muse Tate & Furst bought a majority stake in the company last year. Ferolito, privately held, introduced its line of teas in 1992, when it sold 700,000 cases; sales were 20 million cases last year. People familiar with the two companies had said that talks had nearly led to a purchase estimated at more than $400 million. Mr. Vultaggio also said Arizona would introduce new drinks this summer, including a carbonated chocolate drink.

title: Borders Shares Off to Good Start
description: Shares of Borders Group Inc., a book retailer, rose 5.2 percent higher than their initial public offering price yesterday, as the Kmart Corporation gave up control of the company.

title: Art In Review
description: 'Gems of the Floating World'

title: A Call to Rally Against Budget Cuts
description: SPONSOR: United Federation of Teachers The 60-second radio ads by the teachers union have run from 1 to 10 times each day since May 20 on WINS-AM, WLTW-FM, WOR-AM, WPAT-AM/FM and WQEQ-AM.

title: Democrat's Republican Lawyer
description: A Democratic Congressman from New Jersey has turned to a former Republican colleague to act as his lawyer before the House Ethics Committee. Jim Courter, who is now with the law firm of Verner, Liipfert, Bernhard, McPherson & Hand, will represent Robert Torricelli, who is accused of revealing confidential intelligence information about the death of a United States citizen in Guatemala. SUSAN JO KELLER

title: HOUSE PANEL ACTS TO LOOSEN LIMITS ON MEDIA INDUSTRY
description: Rolling over the protests of several Democrats, the House Commerce Committee voted today to kill most cable television price regulation and lift scores of restrictions on the number of television, radio and other media properties a single company can own.

title: NATO Jets Bomb Arms Depot At Bosnian Serb Headquarters
description: Confronting the Bosnian Serb leadership more directly than ever before, NATO warplanes bombed an ammunition depot today near the Serbs' political headquarters in the town of Pale.

title: 15 Months of NATO Air Strikes
description: FEB. 28, 1994: United States F-16's shoot down four Bosnian Serb warplanes violating a "no flight" zone in central Bosnia, the first military strike by NATO in its 45-year history. Serbs do not react. APRIL 10, 1994: Two United States F-16's strike Bosnian Serb positions near Gorazde, a Muslim enclave. Results are inconclusive.

title: Topics of The Times; Toxic Politics
description: It could be that Edward Rollins Jr. really meant it when he apologized last week for offensively referring to two Jewish Congressmen, Howard Berman and Henry Waxman of California, as "Hymie boys" at a political dinner in San Francisco. With Mr. Rollins, it is often hard to tell.

title: Art In Review
description: Nam June Paik

title: Overseer for Lloyd's Suggested in Britain
description: A British parliamentary committee has recommended creating an independent body to oversee Lloyd's of London, the world's oldest insurance market, which lost $:8 billion ($12.6 billion) in five years.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Daily Briefing column on April 27 in New Jersey copies included an incorrect reference from the office of Faith S. Hochberg, the United States Attorney in New Jersey, to magazines that figure in a Federal investigation of advertisements for Chew-Lite diet gum and Lipo/Trim diet pills. Officials of Glamour and Parade say they published no such ads. Ms. Hochberg's staff says its information was based on consumer complaints; it has not yet been able to confirm that the ads were published.

title: Powell on Politics: Still Cagily Noncommittal
description: From the viewpoint of some who want to make him President, Colin L. Powell is playing his cards too close to his vest. Either he gives a hint of interest soon, one of his main backers said last week, or people at the grass roots will dismiss him as "too coy."

title: Believers in African Eve Think They Have Found Adam(s)
description: If there was an African Eve, a kind of common maternal ancestor of all modern humans as suggested by recent studies in human evolutionary genetics, there must naturally have been an Adam, and now scientists think they have homed in on him -- or really them.

title: L.I.R.R. Is Set To Go to Court To Block A Walkout
description: The Long Island Rail Road was preparing last night to go to court to block a possible strike by engineers this morning, but no one at the railroad seemed to know whether a job action was a real possibility or just a rumor.

title: Investors Still Put Cash Into Stock Funds
description: Mutual funds that buy American stocks are continuing to attract a lot of cash from investors, although May's cash flows have been down from April's extraordinarily high levels, fund managers said yesterday.

title: CHRONICLE
description: When EDO DE WAART takes to the podium in Minneapolis to conduct "Otello" tonight, it will be his last appearance as music director of the Minnesota Orchestra after nine years there. But the 54-year-old maestro is hardly disappearing from the musical scene. Rather, he is going to Australia to become chief conductor and artistic director of the Sydney Symphony Orchestra.

title: Article 924295 -- No Title
description: The burrito proliferation has leveled off. Two years ago, new places specializing in gargantuan burritos were opening all over Manhattan, and established restaurants were opening branches with abandon. But a consolidation seems to have taken place, with the weaker restaurants closing and fewer new ones opening.

title: Long Beach Journal; From Cambodia to Doughnut Shops
description: The first English words that Ly Yiv learned 15 years ago after fleeing the slaughter in Cambodia were the names of doughnuts: twist, glazed and jelly, chocolate, buttermilk and old-fashioned.
