title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: Reporter's Notebook; The Lonely Americans, Isolated in a Trade War
description: It's not a nice feeling to be alone. And if you were an American trade official in Paris this week, you may have felt remarkably isolated.

title: The Many Transitions of Georg Baselitz
description: WHAT can be said about a painter who thinks it's radical to paint images upside down? That he needs to think again, is one possible answer, and it's one that frequently comes to mind in the middle of the large retrospective of Georg Baselitz's work at the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum.

title: Power Cable Failure Cuts Liberty's Light
description: The inscription on the Statue of Liberty reads, "I lift my lamp beside the golden door," but an electrical failure left the statue's interior dark for about six hours yesterday. The National Park Service closed Liberty Island for the day, sending about 3,000 visitors, some of whom were already inside the statue, back to Manhattan or to Ellis Island.

title: KOGER EQUITY PLANS TO SELL 92 BUILDINGS
description: Koger Equity Inc. said yesterday that it would sell 92 office buildings to an investment entity managed by J. P. Morgan Investment Management Inc. for $154 million in cash. Upon completion of the sale, Koger Equity, based in Jacksonville, Fla., said it had agreed to sell to J. P. Morgan three other office buildings with a value of $28.2 million. The sale of the 92 buildings is expected to be completed in July. Koger Equity said it would use the proceeds to pay off debt.

title: Home Video
description: Gather 7,000 people at a video convention, as happened in Dallas this week, and "name" titles get the attention. Video dealers already hunger for big feature films like "Die Hard With a Vengeance" and "Batman Forever," which have yet to finish or even start theater runs but are expected to be in video stores by late this year or early 1996. But this summer, there are scores of other future titles to tout, from "Scarlett," the television mini-series, to "The Flo Jo Workout: Mind, Body and Spirit."

title: No Headline
description: If I can see them but I can't talk to them, or if I'm talking to them but I don't know where they're at, what good does that do? -- CHRISTOPHER S. BOUGHN, union representative of the air traffic controllers, describing a power failure. [ B5:2. ]

title: A Bitter Mix Of Politics And Money
description: For 30 years, the African Development Bank has dispensed advice and lent money in volumes that place it second only to the World Bank among international lenders for Africa's economic development.

title: Albany Budget Slows
description: The State Comptroller erected a new roadblock on the path to a New York State budget agreement yesterday by rejecting a plan to save money by reducing scheduled payments to the pension system. Officials said there was a tentative agreement to provide financing for 19 stadium projects.

title: Incursion Into Realm of Confidential Legal Fees Reaches a Broader Stage
description: In the most recent incursion into the once highly confidential realm of legal fee arrangements, a New York lawyer has received court approval to hold up to analysis his opposition's legal fees, which were paid by a farmer's shell corporation.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Bill Would Overhaul Communications Industry In a 38-to-5 vote approving an overhaul of communications regulation, the House Commerce Committee voted to kill most cable TV price limits and to lift scores of restrictions on how many television, radio and other media properties a company can own.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball American League BOSTON RED SOX -- Purchased the contract of Tim Wakefield, pitcher, from Pawtucket of the International League.

title: International Briefs; U S West's Czech Deal
description: U S West Inc., based in Englewood., Colo., said yesterday that it had paid $100 million for a 28.5 percent stake in Kabel Plus, the biggest cable television operator in the Czech Republic, moving U S West deeper into the European phone and cable markets. Kabel Plus, a five-year-old operation based in Ostrava, serves 400,000 customers in 10 cities. The move bolsters the presence of U S West in the Czech Republic. U S West and the Bell Atlantic Corporation together own 49 percent of Eurotel, a cellular phone company jointly owned with the state-run phone company of the republic, SPT Telecom. The stake in Kabel Plus will help U S West carry phone calls over cable lines. (Bloomberg Business News)

title: Murder and Existentialism
description: If Agatha Christie and Jean-Paul Sartre had ever collaborated on a play (and why in the world would they?), the result might have been as misguided and mind-bogglingly dreadful as "A Pure Formality," which combines a creaky murder mystery with a pretentious existential theme. Giuseppe Tornatore, the director of the fine "Cinema Paradiso" and the laborious "Everybody's Fine," has been blessed with two extraordinary actors, Gerard Depardieu and Roman Polanski. They are always worth watching, and they are the only reason to see this film.

title: Simpson Juror Let Go
description: The murder trial of O. J. Simpson took yet another odd turn when a juror was dismissed after a mysterious closed-door meeting of four hours between Judge Lance A. Ito and lawyers for both sides.

title: Air Traffic Snarled After Third Failure At a Center on L.I.
description: A power failure yesterday morning knocked out the air traffic control center that handles high-altitude flights in the New York area, blacking out radar screens and severing all radio links to some pilots. Tens of thousands of people were delayed.

title: Microsoft: Who Won
description: To the Editor:

title: Despite Veto Threat, Senate Joins House in Cutting Budget
description: The Senate followed the lead of the House and approved $16.5 billion in midyear budget cuts today, and President Clinton vowed again to use his first veto to kill the legislation.

title: Clinton Urges Investment In Ulster
description: President Clinton urged American companies today to invest in Northern Ireland, saying jobs created by new factories and businesses there would "lift the despair that breeds violence" and help turn a nine-month-old cease-fire into a permanent peace.

title: A Dynamo Who Adds Power and Clarity to a Tharp Work
description: Paloma Herrera, one of American Ballet Theater's most gifted young dancers, had a busy day at the Metropolitan Opera House on Wednesday. In the afternoon, her debut in the waltz solo in "Les Sylphides" had dynamic verve that others might emulate. In the evening, she made her New York debut in Twyla Tharp's "How Near Heaven," in the role she originated in Washington. The bill here also featured Amanda McKerrow and Wes Chapman in "Paquita."

title: The Wrong Woman, the Wrong Approach
description: Joey Buttafuoco, Long Island's most famous body shop owner, returned to New York yesterday and appeared at an airport news conference after the Los Angeles police charged him with soliciting a prostitute.

title: Transit Worker Hit And Killed by Train
description: A subway train struck and killed a transit worker in a tunnel in Harlem yesterday, in the third such fatality in less than eight months.

title: They're Liars, and That's Just the Least of Their Problems
description: THE LIARS' CLUB A Memoir By Mary Karr 320 pages. Viking. $22.95

title: With Budget a Priority, Other Senate Work Stalls
description: For want of a vote a decision on the Surgeon General was delayed again, a property-line dispute on the Nez Perce Indian Reservation in Idaho went unresolved, and a weighty discussion on democracy and the rule of law in Hong Kong failed to get its airing.

title: Kean's Presidential Candidate
description: When former Gov. Thomas H. Kean signed on yesterday with Lamar Alexander's Presidential campaign, he became the latest New Jersey Republican to choose sides in the 1996 race.

title: Kathryn H. Stone, 88; Fought Segregated Schools
description: Kathryn Haeseler Stone, a former Virginia legislator who challenged school segregation and a reapportionment plan that penalized urban voters, died last Friday at her home in Alexandria, Va. She was 88 and had been a longtime resident of Arlington, Va.

title: A Plea for Tougher Truck Rules
description: Andrew O'Sullivan of Flemington, N.J., knows what it is like to lose a child in a traffic accident. That's why he came to the Capitol yesterday to help lobby for tough Federal regulation of trucks and their drivers. "How do you let a mother, wife, daughter, son and grandparent know that somebody you love is dead?" said Mr. O'Sullivan, whose 28-year-old daughter, Lorraine, was killed in a 1992 accident involving a truck.

title: Cannes: Pomp for Some; Problems for Others
description: Being savvy about the movie business despite a number of career choices that suggest otherwise ("house payments," she said about films like "The Specialist"), Ms. Stone now knows that the appearance of power goes only so far. She was a co-producer of "The Quick and the Dead," the festival's closing feature. Still, she found that once she'd finished acting in the film, she couldn't make Tri-Star listen to her suggestions, despite the fact that, as she put it, "I'm best friends with their star."

title: NEWS OF INQUIRY DROPS LOUISIANA-PACIFIC
description: The shares of the Louisiana-Pacific Corporation fell 14 percent yesterday after the company said Wednesday that it expected to be indicted by a Federal grand jury on charges of tampering with environmental monitoring equipment. Louisiana-Pacific stock was down $4, to $22.75. The charges would add to a string of environmental problems at the company in the last few years. Louisiana-Pacific has paid $17 million in environmental penalties in the last two years. The company first reported the grand jury investigation in documents filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission in March 1994 and said in November that it would probably be indicted. The allegations include tampering with emissions-monitoring equipment and altering records at its Montrose, Colo., plant, according to a Federal filing by the company. The Wall Street Journal reported the contents of the filing yesterday. Company officials could not be reached for comment.

title: For Children
description: 'Flapping While Chirping'

title: From Convictions to Code of Ethics; Ex-Prosecutor Tackles Essex County Graft in Counsel Role
description: When Michael Chertoff was the United States Attorney in these parts, he brought down more than a few wayward local officials, people so steeped in the clannish customs of New Jersey politics that they often did not seem to grasp what they had done wrong. A little money pocketed, some jobs doled out to friends, a private deal or two -- what was the problem?

title: International Briefs; Cable and Wireless Reports Lower Profits
description: The British telecommunications company Cable and Wireless P.L.C. said yesterday that its pretax profits in the year that ended on March 31 fell 22.4 percent, mainly because of a series of restructuring charges. In the latest year Cable and Wireless had a pretax profit of $:844 million, or $1.3 billion, compared with $:1.08 billion a year earlier. Sales were $:5.13 billion, or $8.15 billion, up 9 percent from $:4.69 billion.

title: Senate Panel Approves Bill To Restrict Investors' Suits
description: The Senate Banking Committee approved and sent to the full Senate tonight a bill that would drastically change the way publicly traded companies are regulated, by making it more difficult to bring lawsuits against companies and stockbrokers when stock prices drop sharply.

title: Atlanta's Welcome for Olympics Draws a Rebuff in Rural Georgia
description: As Atlanta prepares to open its arms to the world for the 1996 Summer Olympics, that welcoming embrace has become a cold shoulder in the rolling hills of northeastern Georgia.

title: Another Juror Taken Off Simpson Case
description: The O. J. Simpson trial took one more odd turn this evening when yet another juror was dismissed after a mysterious four-hour closed-door meeting that included Judge Lance A. Ito, prosecutors, defense lawyers and investigators for both sides.

title: China Warns U.S. Over Taiwan Visitor
description: China warned today that it would carry out further reprisals in its relations with the United States unless Washington "immediately reverses its erroneous decision" to allow Taiwan's President, Lee Teng-hui, to make a private visit to Cornell University.

title: Transportation Bill Is Approved
description: The State Senate was busy yesterday.

title: Timberland Account Goes to BBDO
description: The Timberland Company yesterday named BBDO Worldwide in New York to handle its account, which had been at Mullen Advertising in Wenham, Mass., for the last seven years. The billings were estimated at $8 million but are expected to grow to as much as $20 million.

title: U.S. Stumbles in Role of Mideast Peace Broker; Noncapital Embassies
description: To the Editor:

title: Mahler and Mendelssohn
description: The New York Philharmonic is in the enviable position of having access to the television airwaves once or twice a season through the "Live From Lincoln Center" series. But Kurt Masur has used these opportunities oddly, broadcasting his weaknesses as frequently as his strengths. A thoroughly unidiomatic reading of Bernstein's "Symphonic Dances" from "West Side Story," for example, made an indelible impression in 1992. Generous listeners who appreciated this gesture to American music excused its shortcomings on the ground that Mr. Masur was not yet at home in the style. Other explanations will have to be found for the tepid account of the Mahler First Symphony that he brought before the cameras on Wednesday evening.

title: TALKS WITH HOUSE ARE NEXT; Fight Now Turns Intraparty, And Battleground Is Taxes
description: Republicans in Congress have been fighting Democrats for five months over how to balance the Federal budget. Now they start fighting each other.

title: NOVELL SHARES DROP ON PRODUCT CONCERNS
description: Shares of Novell Inc., the second-largest maker of personal computer software, fell 8 percent yesterday in extremely active trading as analysts expressed concerns about the company's chief product line, despite much stronger second-quarter earnings. Late on Wednesday, Novell said it earned $95.9 million, or 26 cents a share, up 45 percent from the corresponding period last year. But while revenue for Novell's flagship product, NetWare operating system software, was higher compared with the corresponding quarter last year, it was lower than that of the quarter ended in January. This probably caused much of the stock movement, said Maria Lewis, an analyst at Cowen & Company. In Nasdaq trading yesterday, Novell shares closed down $2 at $20.625.

title: Art In Review
description: Herbert Bayer Kent Gallery 67 Prince Street SoHo Through June 3

title: Peres Inches Toward Ceding Golan for Peace With Syria
description: Foreign Minister Shimon Peres came as close today as any top Israeli official has to saying baldly that Israel will give up the entire Golan Heights as the price for a peace treaty with Syria, which he said would end war in the Middle East.

title: Kasper, 33, Is the New Coach of the Bruins
description: STEVE KASPER was introduced yesterday as the coach of the Boston Bruins, even though his head-coaching experience was just one season in minor league hockey. At 33, Kasper will be younger than some of his players. His contract reportedly will be for two years plus an option season at about $250,000 per year.

title: Diner's Journal
description: Paris in New York

title: LABATT'S BELIEVES A BETTER TAKEOVER OFFER WILL COME
description: John Labatt Ltd. said yesterday that it expected to receive a better takeover offer than the Onex Corporation's $1.7 billion bid, either from Onex or another suitor. Labatt's president, George Taylor, said the Toronto-based brewer was in discussions to sell the company to other parties besides Onex and some of these discussions was "well advanced." Onex, a buyout company in Toronto, is offering 24 Canadian dollars a share, or 23 billion Canadian dollars, for Labatt, Canada's second-largest brewer and owner of the Toronto Blue Jays baseball team. Labatt says the offer "seriously undervalues the company's core assets."

title: Bald Facts: Pacers Can't Stop O'Neal
description: Shaquille O'Neal shaved his head this morning because, "I thought it would make me look more mean." Tonight, with his team in desperate need, he clearcut the Indiana Pacers' frontline.

title: Virginia Executes a Killer Who Spent 15 Years on Death Row
description: A barber who had been scheduled for death six times in 15 years was executed by lethal injection tonight after the courts had rejected his argument that his repeated trips to the "death house" were unconstitutional.

title: Paramilitary Group Leaders Try to Burnish Their Image
description: They came to participate in the Government they so often disparage, vowing to answer every question and even to take a polygraph test if requested.

title: If Nations Owned Up to Their Misdeeds
description: To the Editor:

title: New York Lifts Its Ban Of Lasix on Race Day
description: Lasix, the medication allowed in every racing state except New York, will be legalized for use in New York on Sept. 1, ending one of the most fundamental disputes on drugs in horse racing.

title: Home on the Range
description: The white extremist subculture that has come to light since the Oklahoma City bombing spreads its message of hate mostly through newsletters, talk radio and the Internet. Along with giving advice on making bombs, camping out after a nuclear attack and fighting the Government, many groups also promote an alternative geography, reorganizing the United States into separate ethnic and religious nations.

title: Unicef Says Fraud Cost $10 Million
description: The United Nations Children's Fund lost as much as $10 million to serious fraud and mismanagement by its Kenya office in 1993 and 1994, Unicef's new executive director, Carol Bellamy, reported today.

title: Bond Rally Is Cut Short by Profit Taking
description: What appeared to be the making of another strong bond rally was cut short yesterday by a sharp decline in the dollar and profit taking.

title: Arts Boosters Who Give Other People's Money
description: To the Editor:

title: Security Cameras for Rutgers
description: New surveillance cameras and other security measures are planned for libraries at Rutgers University after an explosive device -- the third in two months -- was found Wednesday at the library here.

title: On Stage, and Off
description: Readying Mad Money

title: Abroad at Home; Capitol Power Grab
description: The Articles of Confederation, which joined the American states together in 1781, assigned the running of foreign affairs to Congress. The idea was such a dismal failure that in 1787 the Framers of the Constitution made the President the principal voice of the United States abroad.

title: AIDS Walk Was More Than a Roadblock
description: To the Editor:

title: Panel Backs Flag-Burning Ban As Constitutional Amendment
description: Reviving a proposal the House rejected five years ago, a House subcommittee voted today for a constitutional amendment against desecration of the American flag.

title: Market Place; Looking beyond the flash in the meteoric rise of Solomon-Page.
description: THE stock market has been pretty excited about Solomon-Page Group Ltd., but that is no endorsement of the smarts of the investors who are signing up for the company's shares.

title: International Briefs; In Brief
description: The Pohang Iron and Steel Company of Korea, the world's second-largest steel producer behind Nippon Steel of Japan, said yesterday that it would build a new furnace by 1998, which it said would make it the world's largest steel producer. The construction of the giant furnace will begin in 1997 in the southern Korean port city of Kwangyang, where Pohang already has a plant.

title: Slowdown Signs Hurt the Dollar, And Stocks Fall
description: Fresh news suggesting an economic slowdown -- this time in housing and unemployment --hit the dollar hard and divided stock and bond traders yesterday.

title: Friendly and Translucent? He's Back
description: You can call him a ghost, or think of him as a computer-generated pretend friend. Or along with Dr. James Harvey, the kindly "ghost therapist" played by Bill Pullman, you can regard him as one of the "living impaired." Any way you define him, Casper is the adorable creature at the center of a sweet, special-effects-laden children's movie.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: LIBERTY MUTUAL INSURANCE, Boston, a fire and casualty insurance company, said it planned to open an international reinsurance unit, Liberty Reinsurance Company, in London.

title: What Went Wrong? Read Next Book
description: MARK MESSIER is a man who believes in the battle cry of the Showtime Warrior, winning is everything, and he has been enormously successful living by it. He is so devoted to team and to goal, he says, that he has avoided long-term commercial and romantic commitments. Messier is so open, even eloquent, in his philosophy, that it seemed natural several months ago to blurt at him, "So when are you going to write a book?"

title: Devils Seize the Psychological Edge
description: This series was supposed to be the hockey equivalent of boxer versus slugger. Pittsburgh's pure power opposed by New Jersey's patience.

title: International Briefs; VW's Spanish Unit Narrows Its Loss
description: SEAT, the Spanish unit of Volkswagen A.G., said yesterday that recovering car sales and an aggressive cost-cutting plan had helped it to reduce its first-quarter loss by 83 percent, to 4.88 billion pesetas, or about $39 million. The improvement was similar to a reduction of 80.5 percent of losses for all of 1994. In the first quarter a year ago SEAT lost 28.692 billion pesetas.

title: U.S. Stumbles in Role of Mideast Peace Broker
description: To the Editor:

title: On My Mind; The N.R.A.: Fatter and Meaner
description: The leadership of the National Rifle Association did not invent the technique, certainly not. That is the point -- it's been around in Europe almost a century.

title: Ousted Phar-Mor President Found Guilty in $1 Billion Fraud
description: Michael I. Monus, the ousted president of Phar-Mor Inc., was found guilty yesterday of 109 Federal felony charges for his role in a $1 billion fraud that plunged the company into bankruptcy.

title: Reducing Debt Has a Depressing History
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about Wednesday's House debate on a foreign aid bill referred incorrectly in some editions to the process by which debate was cut off and the bill withdrawn from the floor. There was no connection between those actions and an earlier vote to amend the bill to restrict the flow of American money to groups overseas that advocate or provide abortions.

title: Mobil Will Cut Track Ties
description: In discussions on Wednesday with track and field's world governing body, Mobil Oil Corporation gave every indication that it will end its 15-year international association with the sport after this season, a person familiar with the negotiations said yesterday.

title: Inside Art
description: Dispersing a Collection

title: Study Finds Lead Hazards Under F.D.R.
description: More than six weeks after a work crew sandblasted the steel columns beneath the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive at 23d Street, a group of environmental health graduate students from Hunter College examined the debris left behind and found lead levels that far exceeded public safety standards.

title: International Briefs; Profit Up at Powergen
description: Powergen P.L.C., the second-largest electricity generator in Britain, said yesterday that pretax profit in the recent fiscal year rose 14.5 percent, which was better than expected, as cost-cutting helped offset a decline in revenue. Profit before tax in the year that ended on March 31 rose to $:545 million, or $860 million, from $:476 million a year earlier. Like National Power P.L.C., the biggest generator in Britain, Powergen improved profits by cutting its work force and reducing fuel costs as its share of the nation's electricity market continued to shrink. (Bloomberg Business News)

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF Alderete and Bradley Share Corning Lead Loretta Alderete matched the best round of her career with a five-under-par 67 yesterday to share the first-round lead of the $500,000 Corning Classic with Pat Bradley. Alderete took the lead in an L.P.G.A. tournament for the first time since turning pro in 1985. Bradley is a Hall of Famer who has won 31 L.P.G.A. tournaments and more than $4.7 million. The leaders were one stroke ahead of Allison Finney, who missed a 2-foot putt for par on No. 18. Suzanne Strudwick, Melissa McNamara and Missy McGeorge were two shots back at 69. (AP) COLONIAL CO-LEADER RIGHT AT HOME: Clark Dennis shot a 64 on the course that was his childhood playground and grabbed a share of the first-round lead in the Colonial National Invitation in Fort Worth. "It's good to be home," Dennis said after the six-under-par effort that gave him a tie for the top spot with Lennie Clements on the rain-softened Colonial course. Dennis's parents were members of Colonial and he has played this layout "since I was a kid." . (AP) TENNIS Sweden Spoils U.S. Bid in World Team Cup Stefan Edberg beat MaliVai Washington, 6-4, 6-4, yesterday as Sweden ended America's hopes of reaching the World Team Cup final in Dusseldorf, Germany. Edberg won a battle of big servers as Sweden swept the United States, 3-0, in the Blue Group match. Magnus Larsson, ranked No. 10, defeated Todd Martin, 7-5, 7-5, and Edberg and Jonas Bjorkman teamed to beat Jared Palmer and Richey Reneberg, 6-3, 4-6, 6-3.

title: Family Files Suit In Hospital Slaying
description: The family of an 83-year-old man who was found strangled in his bed at Interfaith Medical Center in Brooklyn last August filed suit against the hospital yesterday, charging that security was lax.

title: Shell to Raise Gas Output by Going Deeper in Gulf of Mexico
description: The Shell Oil Company said yesterday that it plans to step up production from its gas fields in the Gulf of Mexico by plunging deeper than ever below the ocean, about a mile down.

title: Dairy Groups Reach 'Got Milk?' Accord
description: A campaign to stimulate milk sales by Goodby, Silverstein & Partners in San Francisco will begin appearing nationally after Dairy Management Inc., a joint venture of the United Dairy Industry Association and the National Dairy Board, agreed yesterday to use that campaign in place of one created for the association by J. Walter Thompson Chicago, part of the WPP Group.

title: Art In Review
description: Tom Wesselmann

title: CHRONICLE
description: In a few short minutes the other day, GINA QUINTON, a college student from Tahlequah, Okla., saw both the best and worst of New York City.

title: Events for Memorial Day Weekend
description: Here is a sampling of Memorial Day weekend events in the New York metropolitan region. Unless noted, events are free. NEW YORK CITY Today

title: Abused in One Home, Child Meets Death in the Next
description: Queenie Baker came to the home of Edwin and Rosa Hall so beaten and stunted that at 18 months old she still did not eat solid food. Taking only milk or other liquids, she arrived in a body cast that stretched from the middle of her small chest to the top of her left foot.

title: Joey Baron Seeks an Essence
description: For the last several years, the drummer Joey Baron has led a small, joyously odd trio that's also made up of Steve Swell on trombone and Ellery Eskalin on tenor saxophone. The band performed at the Knitting Factory on Wednesday night, and it played elemental music, as if Mr. Baron had reduced styles to their gestures.

title: Peace Talks In Chechnya Suspended
description: Internationally mediated peace talks between Russia and Chechen leaders were suspended today after about four hours of conversation in which both sides appeared to restate old positions.

title: How the Government Could Aid Job-Seekers
description: To the Editor:

title: McCall, Citing Pension Fund Payments, Blocks Budget Plan
description: The Democratic State Comptroller, H. Carl McCall, erected a new roadblock on the path to a budget agreement today by rejecting a plan to save money by lowering the state's scheduled payments to its pension system.

title: Fearless Rebels of the Airwaves Surrender to Pop
description: From the day it first went on the air in 1981, calling itself "the official voice of the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front," Radio Venceremos was a thorn in the side of El Salvador's military. For more than a decade, the station's announcers and transmitters were constantly under fire and on the move, eluding bombing attacks and ambushes intended to silence them.

title: Article 376795 -- No Title
description: In the biggest software deal ever, Computer Associates International said yesterday that it would acquire one of its largest competitors for $1.78 billion, consolidating its position as the leading independent supplier of large-system software, rivaled only by I.B.M.

title: Ruling Gives Drug Makers Up to 3 Extra Years on Patents
description: In a move that could cost consumers billions of dollars, the Food and Drug Administration ruled today that a new Federal law gives pharmaceutical companies an extension of up to three years on their drug patents.

title: Devils Get a Rare Shot at Exposure
description: Here's an unanticipated bonus for the New Jersey Devils, one that did not have to be negotiated with the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority over a piranha-filled moat: Figuring that the Rangers are doomed against the Flyers, Fox Sports will show Game 5 of the Devils-Penguins playoff series.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: No Runs, Few Hits, No Victory For Mets
description: Dallas Green yelled on Tuesday. He sighed on Wednesday. And last night at Shea Stadium, he crossed his arms and bit off his words.

title: In Book, Simpson Friend Takes a Skeptical Tone
description: On the day after Nicole Brown Simpson and Ronald L. Goldman were killed, O. J. Simpson boasted to friends and to Brian (Kato) Kaelin that Mr. Kaelin could provide him with an alibi, according to a new book based on extensive interviews that Mr. Kaelin gave before taking the stand in March.

title: Sonny Bloch, Radio Show Host, Charged With Fraud
description: Sonny Bloch, the self-styled consumer advocate whose financial radio show is broadcast on some 170 stations across the nation, was charged with fraud yesterday by Federal prosecutors and the Securities and Exchange Commission. The Government contends that Mr. Bloch and his associates defrauded hundreds of investors of more than $21 million.

title: Senate Welfare Plan Cuts $41 Billion Over 7 Years
description: The Congressional Budget Office said today that welfare legislation proposed by leading Senate Republicans would cut projected spending by more than $41 billion over the next seven years, a saving of at least 10 percent.

title: Judge Allows Libel Lawsuit Against Prodigy to Proceed
description: In a ruling that could change the nature of on-line information services, a New York judge cleared the way yesterday for a $200 million libel lawsuit against the Prodigy Services Company when he ruled that the popular on-line network was a publisher, and not just a passive distributor of information.

title: Where Riches And Fantasy Reigned
description: PEERING out the car window at palaces protected by ornate, wrought-iron gates, pointing out homes hidden in manicured forests of linden and copper beech trees, Paul Mateyunas was in his glory.

title: Holiday on Monday
description: Memorial Day will be observed on Monday. NEW YORK

title: 1995 N.H.L. Playoffs; The Rangers Turn to Healy in Their Hour of Need
description: The Rangers, facing the doom of a four-game sweep by a playoff-sharpened legion of Philadelphia Flyers, will try to change the momentum of their Eastern Conference semifinal with a change of goalies. Instead of Mike Richter, who started the first three games of the playoff series, the Rangers will go with Glenn Healy in Game 4 Friday night at Madison Square Garden.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a mechanical error, a picture of Mike Tyson in the sports pages yesterday was reproduced in mirror image in some copies. The watch shown on his right wrist was actually on his left.

title: Too Much on His Mind, Ready to Go BLOOEY
description: Keanu Reeves is not supposed to be a robot or an android or any other humanoid form in "Johnny Mnemonic," but from his robotic delivery you'd never guess he's meant to be a flesh-and-blood man with a memory chip implanted in his brain. The date is 2021, and Johnny is an overambitious courier whose head contains more gigabytes than he can handle. He has 24 hours to get rid of the excess information or his head will explode. That is a problem, because he has only part of the access code he needs to download the memory. (This is what happens if you misplace your PIN number.) And there is the more immediate danger that Johnny's head will be lopped off before he can get the rest of the code. A ruthless pharmaceutical company wants the information and sends Japanese hit men to chop off Johnny's head and preserve it cryogenically.

title: Joan Thayer Hupper; 'Romper Room' Teacher, 61
description: Joan Thayer Hupper, Miss Joan of "Romper Room" in New York City from 1957 to 1961, died last Friday at her home in Wilton, Conn. She was 61.

title: Lobo of UConn Survives U.S. Olympic Team Cut
description: In professional football, he is known as the Turk, the personnel official or functionary who knocks on the dormitory door and informs a player that he has been cut. Yesterday, in Colorado Springs, the basketball equivalent of the Turk knocked on the dormitory doors of the 16 finalists for the revolutionary United States women's team with good news and bad.

title: Overhaul of Securities Laws: A Fast Track to Change or a Hasty Decision?
description: It was a measure that had lingered for years on the wish lists of corporate lobbyists. But in about 60 days, Representative Christopher Cox, Republican of California, led an effort early this year that succeeded in overcoming the objections of state and Federal regulators to win House approval of a major overhaul of securities laws written in the aftermath of the market crash of 1929.

title:
BASEBALL;
No Joking For Perez And Yanks In Anaheim
description: What was the line of the night? Nothing from David Letterman's top 10 list, nor a wisecrack from Jay Leno. It was this -- one and two-thirds innings, nine runs, all earned, five hits, four walks and two strikeouts. And it belonged to Melido Perez, the Yankees' starting pitcher tonight at Anaheim Stadium, and the king of late-night comedy for an evening.

title: Fistfuls of Coupons
description: Mary Tolja recently learned that she was a winner in a class-action lawsuit brought against the Ford Motor Company on behalf of 65,000 owners of possibly leaky 1983-86 Mustang convertibles. She is less than elated.

title: Backlash in a Backyard Over Society's Rejects
description: MAIN AVENUE is lovely this time of year.

title:
About Real Estate,;
Reviving Luxury Buildings: Builders Take Two Approaches
description: Different approaches are being taken by new owners seeking to revive two luxury condominium projects in New York suburbs. The projects, which were conceived during the real estate boom of the mid-1980's and went sour with the downturn in the market, were acquired last year at foreclosure auctions.

title: Grand Central Partnership Is Subject of U.S. Inquiry
description: Federal officials said yesterday that they had begun an investigation prompted by the assertions of several former outreach workers that they beat up homeless men at the urging of the Grand Central Partnership, a business improvement district in Manhattan. Depending on the findings of the inquiry, the Department of Housing and Urban Development said it would consider cutting off or demanding repayment of a $547,000 Federal grant to the Partnership.

title: Young Romance, Volatility And the Repercussions
description: From "Splendor in the Grass" to "Endless Love," Hollywood has always found it difficult to portray teen-age passion in a way that isn't saccharine or condescending. If "Mad Love" does a better job than many Hollywood movies at maintaining a level-headed psychological credibility, this story of young lovers who impulsively flee their middle-class backgrounds still comes hazed in a thick romantic mist.

title: Retreat Made On New Head For Hospital
description: The Giuliani administration yesterday backed away from its choice for executive director of the Jacobi Medical Center in the Bronx, saying it would wait until city investigators could resolve allegations that the candidate it has vigorously championed mismanaged the same hospital nearly a decade ago.

title: Times Mirror Will Close The Evening Sun of Baltimore
description: The Evening Sun of Baltimore, one of the more prestigious remaining afternoon newspapers in the country, will cease publication in September, the newspaper said yesterday.

title: Goodby, Silverstein Wins at One Show
description: Goodby, Silverstein & Partners in San Francisco has won the most awards, eight, at the One Show for creative excellence in advertising, sponsored by the One Club for Art and Copy.

title: Last Chance
description: Here is a sampling of shows and exhibitions that are to close soon: Closing This Weekend

title: Release Without Bail Is Sought for Bombing Suspect
description: Calling the Government's case "lamentably thin," the lawyer for Terry Nichols, the second man charged in the bombing of the Oklahoma City Federal Building, sought today to have his client released without bail.

title: U.S. Stumbles in Role of Mideast Peace Broker; An Anti-Israeli U.N.
description: To the Editor:

title: Olde Is Sued by Former Trader In Racial Discrimination Case
description: A former trader at the Olde Discount Brokerage Corporation accused the brokerage firm yesterday of racial discrimination, in a class-action lawsuit filed in Federal District Court in Chicago.

title: 5 Council Mavericks Offer Own Budget
description: For nearly four months, five members of the City Council have been laboring over an alternative city budget, a plan that addresses the deficit and reshapes Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's proposal.

title: Cortines Is Conspicuous by His Absence
description: It was billed as a rally to stand up for New York City's schoolchildren and to protest school budget cuts. The teachers' union -- showing a toughened stance against Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani -- bused thousands of teachers to City Hall. Some school board members walked across the Brooklyn Bridge with many of the school system's top leaders, a few hundred parents, students and more teachers -- everyone except Schools Chancellor Ramon C. Cortines.

title: Art In Review
description: Dorothea Rockburne and Isabella Gherardi Tricia Collins Grand Salon 83 Grand Street SoHo Through June 3

title: Where's the Winning Ticket?
description: In a pocket, in a wallet or maybe in the drain of a washing machine is a piece of paper worth $24.3 million. It is the winning ticket from Pick 6 Lotto drawing on May 11, purchased somewhere in Passaic County.

title: House Foes Talking on Foreign Aid Bill
description: With the vote on the delicate foreign aid bill postponed until June, House Republicans are negotiating with Democrats in hopes of making the bill more palatable to Democrats, according to some of those involved.

title:
RUGBY;
South Africa Ascends World Stage
description: Here was the summation of an emotional statement broadcast within South Africa and around much of the world: South Africa 27, Australia 18, in a game of rugby.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about a sex discrimination suit against National Public Radio misspelled the name of a reporter who threatened to file such a suit in the 1980's but settled out of court. She is Mara Liasson, not Mora.

title: Japan's Biggest Banks Post Dismal Results
description: Slumping bond prices, the rising yen and weaker demand for loans hurt results at Japan's largest commercial banks in the latest fiscal year, with two of them saying today that they had incurred pretax losses -- the first for the industry in the postwar period.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: POWER FAILURE DISRUPTS AIR TRAFFIC A power failure knocked out the air traffic control center that handles high-altitude flights in the New York City area, blacking out radar screens and severing all radio links to some pilots. Tens of thousands of passengers were delayed. The shutdown was the third major failure in six weeks at the control center, prompting the Secretary of Transportation to order an investigation by the Federal Aviation Administration. [ Page A1. ] NEW YORK CITY U.S. INVESTIGATING REPORTED BEATINGS Federal officials said they had begun an investigation prompted by the assertions of former outreach workers that they beat up homeless men at the urging of the Grand Central Partnership, a business improvement district in Manhattan. The Department of Housing and Urban Development said it would consider cutting off a $547,000 Federal grant to the partnership. [ B4. ] LEAD HAZARD CHARGED AT WORK SITE More than six weeks after a work crew sandblasted the steel columns beneath the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive at 23d Street, a group of environmental health graduate students from Hunter College found lead levels that far exceed public safety standards. The site is near a playground and other public areas. [ B4. ] COUNCIL MAVERICKS OFFER OWN BUDGET For nearly four months, five members of the City Council have been laboring over an alternative city budget. But to hear many people tell it, the proposal has virtually no chance of receiving the slightest formal consideration, let alone being adopted. [ B6. ] GERMAN TOURIST OFFICE ACCUSED OF BIAS An official of Germany's Government-funded tourism office in New York said he had been dismissed after uncovering a directive from his head office in Frankfurt saying "Jews, blacks, Hispanics and Asiatics" should be discouraged from visiting Germany. [ A9. ] REGION PATIENTS TROUBLE RESORT As it does every spring, Ocean Grove, N.J., is primping like a prom queen, but it risks ruining its reputation as a sweet, unspoiled resort once the summer guests arrive. What if they notice the people who urinate off the curbs, the panhandlers on the corners or the individuals arguing with imagined acquaintances in Auditorium Park? The village has confronted this problem for about 10 years, ever since its faded resort hotels began taking in patients released from state psychiatric hospitals. [ Our Towns by Evelyn Nieves, B5. ] L.I.R.R. PREPARES FOR POSSIBLE STRIKE The Long Island Rail Road was preparing last night to go to court to block a possible strike by engineers this morning, but no one at the railroad seemed to know whether a job action was a real possibility or just a rumor. Railroad officials said any strike would violate Federal law and would be brought to a swift end by a court order. [ B5. ] THE RETURN OF JOEY BUTTAFUOCO Joey Buttafuoco, Long Island's most famous body shop owner, returned to New York and appeared at an airport news conference after the Los Angeles police charged him with soliciting a prostitute. [ B5. ]

title: Brighter Lights for Broadway
description: Times Square has long been famous for its bright lights, but lately they have gotten noticeably brighter. A specialist in the sign business says there is more and brighter signage now than at any time since the earliest years of neon glitz in the 1920's.

title: DNA Fully Decoded In Living Organism
description: Two scientists say they have determined the complete genetic code of a free-living organism for the first time. One expert said the achievement with a bacterium that usually causes an ear infection fulfilled a long-sought goal of geneticists, and others said such DNA sequencing may eventually lead to medical applications by pinpointing a bacterium's virulent genes.

title: Restaurants
description: There are no lobsters at Peter Luger. There are no major credit cards, either. And those looking for a great wine list will be disappointed. But Peter Luger does have one thing: the best steak in New York City.

title: Bacterium's Full Gene Makeup Is Decoded
description: For the first time, the entire DNA sequence of a free-living organism has been deciphered, displaying a full set of the genes needed for life, two scientists announced here on Wednesday night.

title: Firestone Returns With Front-Row View
description: It was the most celebrated fourth-place finish in Indy-car racing history.

title: Corrections
description: A credit listing yesterday with a television review of "Tycoon," a documentary on NBC tonight about William H. Gates, misstated the broadcast time. It is 10 P.M., not 9.

title: Talks With Ovitz Continuing on Top Job at MCA
description: Michael Ovitz, the chairman of the Creative Artists Agency, has been locked in intense negotiations this week with Edgar Bronfman Jr., the Seagram Company's chief executive, over whether Mr. Ovitz will become head of MCA Inc., the entertainment giant that Seagram is taking over, three people familiar with the discussions said yesterday.

title: Betting on Tyson? Not With Ladbrokes
description: MIKE TYSON is such a sure bet to win his comeback fight that British bookies are refusing to take money on it. Bookmakers at Ladbrokes have made PETER McNEELEY a 10-1 shot to upset the former champion in Las Vegas, Nev., on Aug. 19, but are offering no odds on a Tyson victory. "Tyson's odds would be too short for anyone in Britain to have a bet -- at least 1-40," the bookmakers' spokesman, PAUL AUSTIN, said yesterday in London. "The only consolation for McNeeley is that at 10-1 against we quote him at exactly the same odds as a certain BUSTER DOUGLAS."

title: Myer Rashish, 70, Economist and Aide
description: Myer Rashish, a Harvard-trained economist who served as Under Secretary of State for Economic Affairs in 1981, died Tuesday in Sibley Memorial Hospital in Washington. He was 70 and had lived in Washington since 1952.

title: 1995 N.H.L. Playoffs; Nordiques Off to Denver After $75 Million Deal
description: The Quebec Nordiques surrendered to the economics of playing in a small market yesterday and were acquired for $75 million by the same entertainment company that purchased the Denver Nuggets in 1989.

title: International Briefs; Debt Revamping Plan At Aerovias de Mexico
description: Aerovias de Mexico S.A., the largest airline in Mexico, is trying to restructure $137.5 million of debt due on June 10, the company said in a statement yesterday. The airline, also known as Aeromexico, said the debt included $100 million in Eurobonds and $37.5 million in commercial paper. Aeromexico officials said they would try to convince the holders of their bonds and commercial paper to exchange them for medium-term securities.

title: Reunion of Three Sisters Who Ponder Lofty Issues
description: Peopled with thoughtful adult characters who carry on intelligent, if less than scintillating conversations, Richard Franklin's film "Hotel Sorrento" is an appealing grown-up movie whose leisurely pace cuts purposefully against the high-adrenaline grain of contemporary film making.

title: German Accuses Tourist Office of Prejudice
description: An official of Germany's Government-financed tourism office in New York City said tonight that he had been dismissed after uncovering a directive from his head office in Frankfurt saying "Jews, blacks, Hispanics and Asiatics" should be discouraged from visiting Germany.

title: International Briefs; Guardian Plans Cuts
description: Guardian Royal Exchange P.L.C., a life and general insurer in Britain, said yesterday that it would dismiss 220 employees engaged in selling life insurance and pension products.

title: Those Who Work With Teen-Agers Must Respect Boundaries
description: To the Editor:

title: Clothing Company Is Common Link in 3 Killings
description: One victim was an immigrant from Soviet Armenia shot to death two and a half years ago outside a prospering suburban sewing factory. Another garment industry executive, at his job less than a year, was slain in December while waiting at a stoplight in Los Angeles's inner city. Just three weeks ago, a longtime apparel industry executive was shot to death in his car.

title: Albany Slices Bacon
description: In the clearest sign that final agreement on the New York State budget is near at hand, Gov. George E. Pataki and legislative leaders focused their energies yesterday on deciding how to apportion an estimated $24 million in "program initiatives," better known as pork. Article, page 25.

title: Hopes for a National Title Run High at Johns Hopkins
description: The showcase weekend for men's college lacrosse starts at the University of Maryland's Byrd Stadium on Saturday afternoon, with top-seeded Johns Hopkins opposing the host school and hoping to record its third undefeated championship season.

title: Power Outage Interrupts Wagering
description: Belmont Park's holiday weekend got off to a disrupted start yesterday when a transformer burned out on Hempstead Turnpike and cut electric power at the track for 1 hour 20 minutes, delaying races and eliminating betting entirely on the fifth race.

title: Two Indicted on Drug Charges 1
description: Two men who were with 16-year-old Lawrence Meyers when he was fatally shot by a housing police officer in February have been indicted on drug charges stemming from the episode. Kiante Hall, 19, and Thomas Jackson, 20, were charged with possession of 23 grams of crack cocaine by a Passaic County grand jury on Thursday. The police were trying to arrest the three men on Feb. 21 when Officer Ronald Cohen shot Mr. Meyers. The shooting of the black youth by the white officer set off several days of unrest here.

title: POP
description: Looking Beyond Techno, With Frenetic Dancing Moby Irving Plaza

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 2-5 SERBS TAKE U.N. TROOPS HOSTAGE The Bosnian Serbs used at least eight U.N. officers as human shields at an ammunition depot and other sites near the Serbian headquarters at Pale after a second consecutive day of NATO air attacks. 1

title: Stock Prices Tumble for A Second Day
description: The stock market extended its losses for a second consecutive session yesterday, setting off the so-called circuit-breaker rules of the New York Stock Exchange twice in one session. But leading stock indexes still managed to finish ahead for the week.

title: Manila Helping Small Investors
description: The Philippines will set aside at least 10 percent of all initial public offerings for small investors in an attempt to increase domestic participation in the stock market.

title: DSG INTERNATIONAL AGREES TO TAKE COMPANY PRIVATE
description: DSG International Ltd. said yesterday that its board had agreed to have a management group and two other investors take the company private by buying out all other shareholders for $19.25 a share, or about $77 million. The price represents an increase over an earlier offer of $19 a share. Management owns about four million of the disposable-diaper maker's approximately eight million shares outstanding. Management's stake in the company, which is based in Hong Kong, would increase to about 88 percent from its present 53 percent. DSG's stock gained 25 cents, to $18.25, in Nasdaq trading.

title: DANCE
description: Two Debuts in Spanish Suite Staged by Natalia Makarova American Ballet Theater Metropolitan Opera House

title: Corrections
description: A listing in Weekend yesterday with an article about Long Island mansions misstated admission prices for the former Phipps Estate at Old Westbury Gardens in Old Westbury. Admission to the house and gardens is $10 ($7 for the elderly and $6 for those 6 to 12 years old). Admission is free for children under 6 and members of Old Westbury Gardens. For the gardens alone, admission is $6 ($4 for the elderly; $3 for children 6 to 12).

title: An Indian Reservation? Right in Detroit?
description: Detroit has tried for decades to revitalize its moribund downtown, but never before with so novel an approach as a proposal now on Gov. John Engler's desk: to create an Indian reservation in the heart of the city solely to establish casino gambling there.

title: He's Most Motivated Player
description: The whimpering and wailing on Thursday night came from the locker room showers, where a very big and strong man appeared to be experiencing a very private and weak moment: "My trophy," he said. "They took my trophy! How could they do that to me?"

title: Apartment Building Falls in Brooklyn
description: A four-story apartment building collapsed yesterday in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn, injuring no one but forcing the evacuation of a building next door and shutting part of an elevated subway line.

title: Penske Vanishes; It's Anybody's Race
description: Team Penske, winner of 7 of the previous 11 Indianapolis 500 races, cleaned out its garages here at the Indianapolis Motor Speedway four days ago when both of its drivers failed to qualify for the race.

title: Serbs Call and Raise
description: By ordering NATO air strikes on two consecutive days, the United Nations, strongly prodded by the Clinton Administration, has embarked on a high-risk policy from which there appears to be no way back.

title: 2 Car Makers In Japan Post Huge Losses
description: Two of Japan's leading car manufacturers, Nissan and Mazda, reported huge losses today for their last fiscal years, heightening concern that Japan's overcrowded automobile industry is heading for a consolidation.

title: Hey, Sailor, Want to See an Etching?
description: THESE guys are sailors loose in the big city for a few days after months at sea, so what do you expect? It was barely past noon yesterday and already the three seamen were in a room full of scantily clad, statuesque women.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about a ruling by the Food and Drug Administration, giving pharmaceutical companies an extension of up to three years on their drug patents, misspelled the name of a University of Minnesota professor who was quoted on the impact of the ruling. He is Stephen W. Schondelmeyer, not Steven Shondelmeyer.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about the sale of the Kennedy house in Palm Beach, Fla., referred incorrectly in some copies to its size. The house has six bedrooms, not six rooms.

title: Fathers' Tactic in Divorce Wars; Jewish Custom Is Revived as Leverage Against Wives
description: The obscure biblical verse lay dormant for centuries.

title: I.B.M. Plans to Combine 2 of Its Divisions
description: ARMONK, N.Y., May 26

title: Corrections
description: The Market Place column in Business Day on May 10 about a large investment by the Robertson Stephens Contrarian Fund in a Canadian mining company referred incorrectly to the performance of the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index compared with the fund. The index was up 14 percent through May 9, not 18 percent, while the fund rose 17.5 percent in the same period.

title: Judge Bars Simpson's Police Interview
description: After replacing yet another juror, the judge in the O. J. Simpson trial today rebuffed an effort by defense lawyers to introduce as evidence a taped interview Mr. Simpson gave to the police before his arrest.

title: Sri Lanka Will Uncover Rights Abuses
description: To the Editor:

title: CHIPCOM SHARES PLUNGE AS PRODUCT SHIPMENTS WANE
description: The shares of the Chipcom Corporation plunged 37 percent after the computer network equipment maker said lower shipments of its products by the International Business Machines Corporation would cut estimated earnings. I.B.M., which accounted for 38 percent of Chipcom's 1994 revenue, said it had too much of Chipcom's equipment in inventory and would not order more until it could sell the backlog. The company, based in Southborough, Mass., said it now expected to earn about $1 to $1.30 a share this year, about half of what some Wall Street analysts expected for 1995. Shares of Chipcom, the sixth-largest independent maker of computer network equipment in the United States, were down $11.875, at $20.125, in Nasdaq trading of 10.2 million shares.

title: Senate Committee Approves A Vast Overhaul of Welfare
description: The Senate Finance Committee approved a momentous shift in social policy today, voting to cancel the Federal guarantee of a subsistence income for poor children while giving states vast new power to design their own welfare programs without Federal standards.

title: Nonlethal Rat Control
description: To the Editor:

title: The Fate of Sterling Forest
description: Representative Marge Roukema is worried about Sterling Forest. New Jersey, New York and the Federal Government have long been trying to work out a deal to buy the privately owned 17,500-acre woodland that straddles the border of the two states. Their effort could be derailed by a proposed five-year Federal moratorium on land acquisition, so Ms. Roukema sent a letter yesterday to Representative Ralph Regula of Ohio, head of a key House subcommittee, urging him to oppose the moratorium.

title: Partial Shutdown Planned For Troublesome Radar
description: Technicians at the air traffic control center that handles high-altitude flights in the New York area plan to shut down one-third of the radar screens, possibly as early as before dawn today, so they can remove a circuit breaker that failed on Thursday, delaying tens of thousands of travelers.

title: AFTER 2D STRIKE FROM NATO, SERBS DETAIN U.N. TROOPS
description: The Bosnian Serbs chained up at least eight United Nations officers today at an ammunition depot and other sites near the Serbian headquarters at Pale, using them as human shields after NATO warplanes bombed the area for a second day.

title: France Threatens Pullout
description: Faced with Serbian reprisals against its soldiers in the peacekeeping force in Bosnia, France today repeated a threat to withdraw its troops if the United Nations did notprotect them, Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali said.

title: Penguins' Lack of Offense Puts Wreggett Through a Wringer
description: Pittsburgh goaltender Ken Wregget did all he could to keep his team's sputtering offense in the game. For 78 minutes 36 seconds, to be exact.

title: U.S. to Accept Asylum Pleas For Sex Abuse
description: The Immigration and Naturalization Service yesterday announced new guidelines that formally recognize rape, domestic abuse and other forms of violence against women as potential grounds for political asylum.

title: We Have to Get There From Here
description: If the New York State Department of Transportation recommends to Gov. George Pataki a deferral or "stretching out" of the reconstruction of the West Side Highway from the Battery to 59th Street, the downtown business community and the public would be betrayed -- again.

title: Holiday on Monday
description: Memorial Day will be observed on Monday. NEW YORK GOVERNMENT OFFICES Federal, state and municipal offices are closed. POST OFFICE Express Mail and special delivery only. BANKS Option to close. PARKING Sunday rules in effect. SANITATION No pickups, street cleanings or recycling. SCHOOLS Closed. FINANCIAL MARKETS Closed. TRANSPORTATION Buses and subways, L.I.R.R. and Metro-North on holiday schedules. NEW JERSEY GOVERNMENT OFFICES Federal and state offices closed. Municipal offices have option to close. POST OFFICES Express Mail and special delivery only. BANKS Option to close. SCHOOLS Closed. TRANSPORTATION N.J. Transit trains on Sunday schedule. Some N.J. Transit buses on holiday schedule. CONNECTICUT GOVERNMENT OFFICES Federal, state and municipal offices closed. POST OFFICES Express Mail and special delivery only. BANKS Closed. SCHOOLS Closed. TRANSPORTATION Metro-North on holiday schedule.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: Japan Inc.'s Dying Bit Players; Rising Yen Is Wreaking Havoc on Small Factories
description: Tomohiro Koseki is one of the unsung heroes of this nation's industrial miracle. A journeyman metal worker, Mr. Koseki can craft a turbine blade or a shaft to a precision of less than the thickness of a human hair. He has also written books celebrating the Japanese metal-working artisan. But Mr. Koseki, 62, said such craftsmen were now a dying breed.

title: 3 Convicted In Mob Plot To Cheat U.S. Of Gas Taxes
description: Three men, including an associate of John Gotti, were convicted today of defrauding the Government of more than $100 million in gasoline taxes in a huge scheme that provided new evidence of the growing ties between the Italian Mafia and emerging Russian organized-crime groups.

title: Ex-Chronicle Chairwoman Loses Lawsuit
description: Nan Tucker McEvoy, the former chairwoman of the Chronicle Publishing Company, lost a suit today to regain her board seat when a state judge ruled she was not an employee entitled to protection under age discrimination laws.

title: Between Frocks and Pants Suits, a Superstar Gets His Turn
description: There are dancers and there are dancers. And then there is Patrick Dupond. One of ballet's few remaining superstars, he may break a few rules but he will always give a performance in the truest sense.

title: Walkout Is Seen as a Quixotic Quest
description: The walkout by Long Island Rail Road engineers yesterday brought railroad officials, labor leaders, mediators and rider advocates to the same conclusion: that the action was the work of a militant faction that recently took control of the engineers' union and is holding out for larger raises than other unions accepted.

title: Beliefs
description: It was unlike any other event associated with the White House Conference on Trade and Investment in Ireland: A diminutive, rosy-faced Irish Archbishop and a bearded Presbyterian official joined in a conversation that veered wildly from the nuts and bolts of fair employment practices and investment opportunities to abstruse talk of "ontological individualism" and Trinitarian theology.

title: Frankenstein Found
description: To the Editor:

title: Why Parliament Isn't Like Congress
description: To the Editor:

title: Excerpts From Debate on Foster Nomination as Surgeon General
description: Following are excerpts from the statements of Senators Nancy Landon Kassebaum and Bill Frist before the vote by the Judiciary Committee on the nomination of Dr. Henry W. Foster Jr. to be Surgeon General. Ms. Kassebaum, a Kansas Republican, opposed the confirmation; Dr. Frist, a Tennessee Republican, supported it. By Senator Kassebaum

title: Knock First
description: A unanimous Supreme Court decision is rare these days, but the justices found themselves in agreement this week that the Constitution ordinarily requires police, when executing a warrant, to knock first and announce their authority and purpose. For good reason. The principle is embedded in American and English law.

title: Bernard Pisani, 85; Doctor Urged Others To Political Action
description: Dr. Bernard J. Pisani, an educator and leader of New York medical associations, died yesterday at St. Vincent's Hospital in Manhattan. He was 85 and a resident of Englewood, N.J.

title: Executed Man Left Gun Behind, Lawyer Says
description: Willie Lloyd Turner made no final statement before his execution on Thursday night, but today his lawyer said the condemned man left a haunting souvenir: a loaded pistol hidden in the typewriter that Mr. Turner had taken to his final cell.

title: Evolution Provides No Excuses to Kill Whales
description: To the Editor:

title: CHRONICLE
description: The number "40" has particular resonance for STAN RUBIN, the swing band leader. "This is the 40th anniversary of the sellout landmark concert of the Tigertown Five in Carnegie Hall," he said, referring to the band he organized at Princeton University in 1951. "It is also 40 years since I met Grace Kelly at a big party in her honor, and I played at her wedding the following year."

title: FONAR AWARDED $110.5 MILLION IN PATENT CASE
description: The Fonar Corporation was awarded $110.5 million yesterday by a Federal jury that concluded the General Electic Company infringed two patents covering magnetic resonance imaging technology. The award, if upheld, would provide a big financial lift for Fonar, based in Melville, L.I. The company posted sales of $15.4 million last year. G.E. said it would file a motion asking Judge Leonard Wexler to overturn the verdict. G.E. was found liable for infringement last week after a three-week trial.

title: Business Digest
description: Philip Morris Recalls 8 Billion Cigarettes Philip Morris is recalling more than eight billion cigarettes, including its Marlboro, Virginia Slims and Benson & Hedges brands, because of a defect in their filters that could cause "temporary discomfort" from an irritant that is similar to a commercial pesticide.

title: Connecticut May Sell Share In Its Lottery
description: Desperate to produce a tax cut in the next budget, Gov. John G. Rowland and top legislators from both parties have proposed doing something no other state has tried: selling a substantial interest in the state's lottery to raise hundreds of millions of dollars.

title: Spurs Climb Right Back Into Series
description: The San Antonio Spurs desperately needed a victory tonight, and they played like it.

title: JAMESWAY TO HIRE ADVISER ON SALE OF COMPANY
description: The Jamesway Corporation said yesterday that it planned to hire an investment banking firm for advice on the possible sale of the company. The discount retailer said on May 4 that "several parties" had gotten in touch with it about a possible acquisition of the company or its assets. The company, which operates 90 stores in the Northeast, said its investment bankers would consider those proposals, as well as other possible sales or ways to "maximize shareholder value." A Jamesway spokesman said the company had not selected its adviser yet. Shares of the company, based in Secaucus, N.J., rose 37.5 cents yesterday to close at $3.375 on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: AMERICAN ANNUITY TO ACQUIRE LAURENTIAN CAPITAL
description: American Annuity Group Inc. said yesterday that it would acquire the Laurentian Capital Corporation of Wayne, Pa., an insurance concern, for about $105.6 million in cash. American Annuity, an investment and insurance company based in Cincinnati, will also redeem about $45 million of Laurentian's debt. The Desjardins Laurentian Financial Corporation, which owns more than 80 percent of Laurentian's stock, has granted American Annuity an option to buy its shares for $13.875 each. American Annuity will pay $14.125 a share for all the other Laurentian shares. The stock dropped 25 cents a share, to $13.50, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: U.S. Provides First Details Of Its Business Ethics Code
description: The Clinton Administration today disclosed its plans for encouraging American and foreign companies to respect the voluntary code of ethical practices it issued earlier this year for American corporations doing business overseas.

title: Labatt Says Bid Isn't Equitable
description: The Canadian brewer John Labatt Ltd., continuing its rigid opposition to the Onex Corporation's $1.7 billion takeover offer, said today that it had filed a lawsuit contending that Onex was being unfair to Labatt's United States shareholders.

title: Tobacco Giant Recalls 8 Billion Faulty Cigarettes
description: The Philip Morris Companies yesterday announced a $100 million recall involving more than eight billion filter cigarettes, including its Marlboro, Virginia Slims and Benson & Hedges brands. The company said manufacturing defects in filters could cause smokers "temporary discomfort" from an irritant similar to a commercial pesticide.

title: Asuncion Journal; A 2,000-Mile Highway of Water for Commerce
description: Entranced by visions of barges piled high with sugar, soy and wheat, Latin American businesses are pressing for construction of a 2,000-mile-long waterway that they say would be South America's liquid spinal cord.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF Parry Leads Colonial by Two Shots Craig Parry had five birdies in a six-hole stretch on the way to a 65 and a two-shot lead yesterday halfway through the Colonial National Invitation in Fort Worth. The 5-foot-6-inch Australian had the best round of a breezy day and completed two trips over the Colonial Country Club course in 131, nine under par. Lennie Clements, still looking for his first victory in a 15-season PGA Tour career, was second at 133 after a 69. John Daly went from an opening 71 to a 77 and missed the cut. (AP) BRITTON AND FERRARA WIN: For the past two years, the team of Bob Britton and John Ferrara has managed the lowest rounds at the Charles E. Wilson Memorial tournament, a one-day, 36-hole better-ball event in Hartsdale, N.Y. Last year the two golfers did it in the morning round and two years ago in the afternoon round. Today, the twosome from Silver Lake Golf Club in Staten Island finally put it all together. With a three-under-par 69 this morning and a five-under 67 in the afternoon, Britton and Ferrara teamed to win the 24th annual Wilson Cup by one stroke over Joe Sommers and Paul McCarthy of Mount Kisco. Teams from 51 local golf clubs participated. Steve Green of Stanwich notched a hole-in-one on the 130-yard 15th hole. BRADLEY HOLDS LEAD: Pat Bradley shot a four-under-par 68 yesterday for a nine-under total of 135 that gave her a two-stroke lead over Loretta Alderete and Alison Nicholas after two rounds of the $550,000 Corning Classic. In her second consecutive bogey-free round, Bradley made three of her four birdies in a five-hole span and saved par three times. The 21-year L.P.G.A. veteran is looking to become the first two-time winner at the tournament in Corning, N.Y., after winning it in 1990. (AP) GILBERT RALLIES: In Midway, Pa., Larry Gilbert rallied for four birdies on the back nine yesterday to take a one-stroke lead on the first day of the $1.1 million Quicksilver Classic. Gilbert shot a five-under 67 at the soggy Quicksilver Country Club. (AP) RUGBY Hastings Scores 44 Points to Set Record Gavin Hastings, captain of the Scottish team, scored a world-record 44 points as his team romped to an 89-0 victory over the Ivory Coast in its World Cup opener yesterday in Rustenburg, South Africa. In the Group D match, Hastings scored 4 tries (4 points apiece) as well as kicking 2 penalties (3 apiece) and 9 conversions (2 apiece) to break the record of 30 points held by Didier Camberabero of France and Rob Andrew of England. In a Group D match in Pretoria, France defeated Tonga, 38-10. In the last Group D match of the day, in Port Elizabeth, Canada crushed Romania by 34-3. (Reuters)

title: Son Says Body Isn't American's
description: The son of an American relief worker missing in Chechnya said today that a body discovered two weeks ago was definitely not that of his father, who disappeared in the secessionist region in April.

title: Clinton Defends NATO Air Strikes in Bosnia and Calls on Serbs to Free U.N. Hostages
description: President Clinton defended NATO's air strikes on Serbian ammunition dumps in Bosnia today and called on the Serbs to release United Nations troops seized in retaliation as hostages.

title: Yeltsin Wins Small Success at Meeting of Commonwealth
description: Russia and Belarus, its eastern neighbor, signed a customs union and agreed to remove border posts between the two countries today, a significant step in the slow economic reintegration of core members of the Commonwealth of Independent States.

title: The Love That Leads To a Ball And Chain
description: With three light romantic comedies looming large on the movie box-office charts, and a fall television roster crammed with new shows about young things dating and mating, America seems to be falling in love with love again. After a siege of admonitory tales of sexual obsession, the entertainment industry has returned to couples meeting cute, fighting cuter and, as often as not, ending up in a church wedding.

title: Marsalis Alumni Regroup For at Least 3 Good Reasons
description: A sizable chunk of Wynton Marsalis's last band came into the Village Vanguard on Tuesday night to present their version of jazz. The trombonist Wycliff Gordon, the alto saxophonist Wessell Anderson, the pianist Eric Reed and the bassist Ben Wolfe have all spent time in the band; the drummer Greg Hutchinson was the ringer.

title: CHRONICLE
description: A judicial love story: ROBERT J. WARD, a senior judge of the Southern District of New York, and RENEE SOKOLOW, who will be married tomorrow, have known each other for years, through joys and sorrows.

title: The Moderate Tack: Can Big Drinkers Just Cut Back?
description: He was in his mid-20's, an age when drinking until the small hours with a bunch of friends weekend after weekend is still called partying rather than alcoholism. Twice the man, an installer of security systems from Nassau County, was arrested for drunken driving.

title: Competency In Child Cases Is Questioned
description: A pattern of low exam scores for workers training to be child-abuse investigators has raised concerns among city officials, with some proposing that trainees be required to pass a minimum competency test before being certified to investigate allegations of neglect or abuse.

title: Pre-Holiday Caution Weighs on Bonds
description: Treasury prices ended mixed yesterday in a shortened session ahead of the Memorial Day holiday weekend.

title: Severn Darden, 65, a Master of Improvisation
description: Severn Darden, an improvisational comedian and actor who worked in theater, film and television, died yesterday at his home in Santa Fe, N.M. He was 65.

title: 5-to-15-Year Prison Term In Slaying of an Officer
description: A man who threw a 30-pound bucket off a roof in upper Manhattan two years ago, killing a housing police officer, was sentenced in State Supreme Court yesterday to 5 to 15 years in prison, the maximum.

title: Electric Car Sets a Record: 238 Miles Without a Charge
description: A four-passenger electric car with the interior space of a Ford Taurus and a lightweight all-composite body has set a record for the distance traveled by a battery-powered vehicle without recharging: 238 miles in mixed city-highway driving.

title: 54 Years to Get the Cup, Just 1 to Give It Away
description: All season the Rangers held the high rank of Stanley Cup champions. But for most of the lockout-shortened schedule, they played more like pretenders. Their reign ended with a thud last night at Madison Square Garden.

title: Dry Spell Was Good for Beaches
description: The snow that didn't fall last winter and the rains that didn't come this spring should help keep the water clean off New Jersey's beaches this summer. That word comes from Dave Rosenblatt of the Department of Environmental Protection, who said dry weather holds down the pollutants that run off into the ocean. (It also helps, he noted, that there has been steady progress in upgrading sewage disposal systems and other pollution controls.) The state's first water-quality checks this week showed that the ocean is in good shape.

title: Toll Supervisors Stage a Sickout
description: Something must be going around. Nearly all the toll plaza supervisors for the Garden State Parkway called in sick yesterday. But holiday travelers probably did not notice their absence. The supervisors manage the toll collectors but don't do the collecting themselves. Officials at the New Jersey Highway Authority, which manages the Parkway, described the absences as a sickout and said they were illegal. Officials of the supervisors' union declined to comment.

title: Research Repays Time and Costs
description: To the Editor:

title: No Warning, and No Escape
description: For hours they had been standing around Pennsylvania Station, staring at a blank arrivals-and-departures board, waiting vainly for any train that might take them home. So when rumors began circulating just after 3 P.M. yesterday that a train would be leaving from Track 19, 500 Long Island Rail Road riders frantically grabbed their briefcases, stuck out their elbows and rushed the platform.

title: Sides Take What They Like From Clinton Speech on Irish Conflict
description: Sir Patrick Mayhew, the British Secretary for Northern Ireland, and Gerry Adams, the political leader of the Irish Republican Army, disagreed today on the direction of United States policy on Northern Ireland.

title: International Briefs; Olivetti's 1994 Net Loss Is Bigger Than Expected
description: The Italian computer company Ing. C. Olivetti S.p.A. reported a wider-than-expected 1994 net loss yesterday but said it had almost broken even at the operating level. The loss was caused by restructuring costs and losses on its bond portfolio. Olivetti said the net loss widened to 678.9 billion lire ($413 million) in 1994 from 464.6 billion lire in 1993. Analysts had predicted a loss of 545 billion lire.

title: New Look For Mets But Same Old Result
description: Dallas Green stuck David Segui at first base for the first time this season. He started Ricky Otero and Chris Jones in the outfield on the same night. He gave Tim Bogar his second start of the season and let Jeff Kent -- who is in the Mets' worst hitting slump -- bat cleanup.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The airlines are serious about not smoking. JIMMY PAGE learned that lesson the hard way the other day. Mr. Page, the Led Zeppelin guitarist, is in trouble for his nicotine habit, The Associated Press reported.

title: U.S. Sues to Force V.M.I. to Admit Women
description: The Justice Department asked the Supreme Court today to make Virginia Military Institute coeducational, saying that the college's effort to remain all male by supporting a separate program for women amounted to "sex segregation."

title: U.S. Carrier Force in Adriatic
description: A U.S. aircraft carrier and three other warships took up positions in the Adriatic to support further NATO air strikes in Bosnia. Page 4.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about bogus aircraft parts misstated the affiliation of a Government official who said such parts were common in commercial airliners. The official, A. Mary Schiavo, is an inspector general with the Department of Transportation, the parent agency of the Federal Aviation Administration, not with the F.A.A. itself.

title: Irving Kirschenbaum, Judge, 83
description: Judge Irving Kirschenbaum, a retired justice of the New York State Supreme Court, died yesterday at his home in Harrison, N.Y. He was 83 and had lived in Manhattan until three years ago.

title: 10-Minute Clock Keeps Shots Low At G.M. Meeting
