description: When the chairman of the General Motors Corporation muzzled a nun, any shareholder's hopes that G.M. might bend its new rules to limit their speaking time at its annual meeting here surely began to melt away.

title: Now Starring: The Profound and the Perky
description: The profound and the perky surfaced at the New York State Theater on Thursday night when the New York City Ballet presented Jerome Robbins's "Goldberg Variations" and George Balanchine's "Danses Concertantes."

title: TELCO STOCK FALLS AS DEFICIT IS EXPECTED
description: The stock of Telco Systems Inc. fell 22 percent yesterday after the company, a maker of fiber optic equipment, said it expected a loss in its third quarter. Telco Systems cited lower revenues and record spending levels on new product development in the three months ending May 28 for the dip in net income. The company blamed order delays from resellers and certain regional Bell operating companies for the decline in sales. Some of the delayed orders will be recovered in the fourth quarter, Telco said, adding that it is taking steps to enhance revenues, including stepping up the introduction of new telecommunications products. Telco's stock closed at $9.9375, down $2.8125, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Broken by the Budget?
description: One of the best-kept secrets of the welfare reform legislation passed by the House of Representatives in March and passed yesterday by the Senate Finance Committee is the virtual decimation of the Supplemental Security Income program for children with severe disabilities.

title: Flyers' Fortunes Rise As the Rangers Fall
description: The players in the orange sweaters raced off the bench at the final buzzer last night, swarming toward Ron Hextall's goal with an unexpected backdrop greeting a Philadelphia Flyer sweep of a Stanley Cup series in Madison Square Garden. In the seconds leading up to the end of the convincing 4-1 Flyer victory, Ranger fans were standing and cheering.

title: An Old Chinese Style But a Modern Flavor
description: The gripping third act of "The Case of Chen Shih-mei" at the Taipei Theater on Thursday night hardly seemed like the conclusion of a century-old drama sung in the centuries-old style of the Beijing Opera. Instead, the highly mannered gestures, the swooping inflections of the speech, the partly improvised arialike declamations, the elaborately painted faces and the accompaniments by 11 musicians playing traditional Chinese instruments seemed in service to an almost contemporary tale of power and justice.

title: One Last Sip: Cup Passes From the Rangers
description: The rise and fall of the Ranger empire was so brief and vivid that it may become a model for these fast-forward times. And because victory last season left such a curiously sour aftertaste, defeat may bring a cleansing fresh start. By losing to the Philadelphia Flyers last night, 4-1, at Madison Square Garden, the New York Rangers finally gave up their unconvincing defense of their first Stanley Cup since 1940.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: Performing a Premiere With Composer as Singer New York Pro Arte Chamber Orchestra Church of the Heavenly Rest

title: Torments Of Youth Distanced With Age
description: Schubert's "Winterreise" at the Metropolitan Museum on Wednesday night asked listeners to rearrange their ideas of what singing is. Received wisdom tells us that it begins with a voice and all the accoutrements attached to that voice: resonance, timbre, reliability, size, smoothness through register shifts, the skill to make vibrato both color notes and accentuate them.

title: For 3 Senate Democrats, A Hard Choice on Budget
description: Democrats by and large despise the budget outline that the Republican Senate approved on Thursday. They said so all week.

title: Dollar Takes Another Big Fall On Worry About U.S. Economy
description: The dollar tumbled against the Japanese yen and the German mark for a second day yesterday as concerns grew that a slowing United States economy could prompt the Federal Reserve to cut interest rates.

title: Never Far From Punk, And 31 Songs to a Set
description: The group All must have had severely mixed feelings when Green Day conquered the pop market last year. All and its predecessor, the Descendents, had been playing the same kind of tuneful, high-powered punk-pop since 1978, recording on independent labels and building a cult-size following. All's eighth album, "Pummel" (Interscope), is its first on a major label, and All is touring again. It headlined Irving Plaza on Thursday night for a happily moshing crowd with plenty of shoulder surfers.

title: Hitchcock Falls Victim To the Home Run Pitch
description: One more baseball flew over their cuckoo's nest tonight, and the Yankees can now introduce themselves to third place.

title: In America; Suffering The Children
description: The Clinton Administration appears to be saying one thing and doing the opposite with regard to the unaccompanied Haitian children being held in U.S. custody at the Guantanamo Bay naval base in Cuba.

title: Wafer Reduces Germ Risk in Communion
description: Dipping a wafer into the communion cup does not abolish the risk of infection to the communicant, but it is safer than sipping wine from a common cup, according to a study reported at a scientific meeting here this week.

title: THEATER
description: In Sinful Pursuit Of the Kingdom of God 'Shabbatai' American Jewish Theater

title: Man Who Arranged Editor's Death Is Sentenced to 18 Years
description: A drug dealer who testified against his former colleagues was sentenced yesterday to 18 years in prison for hiring a hit man to kill a journalist whose writings angered a Colombian drug cartel.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about the candidates for valedictorian at Brooklyn Technical High School misstated the ethnic breakdown of the student body. It was 39.2 percent black, 13.6 percent Hispanic, 14.8 percent white and 32.5 percent Asian and other, according to the annual school report for the 1993-1994 school year, the latest figures available. The figures in the article -- 38.3 percent black, 33.7 percent Hispanic, 17.5 percent white and 10.4 percent Asian and others -- were for all high schools in the city.

title: INSIDE
description: Philip Morris Recalls Eight Billion Cigarettes

title: Catholic College and Diocese in Dispute Over Address by Steinem
description: The trustees of a Catholic liberal arts college near here, Dominican College, say they will not cancel a speaking appearance by the feminist author Gloria Steinem despite the strong objections of the Archbishop of San Francisco to the event's sponsor, a Planned Parenthood group.

title: Sports of The Times; A Moving Farewell to The Rangers
description: WHEN it was nearly over, mercifully over -- the game, the series, the Rangers' short, sad but touching defense of their Stanley Cup championship -- the capacity crowd of some 18,200 rose in Madison Square Garden last night and began to cheer and chant, "Let's Go Rangers!"

title: Fatal Fall Is Ruled a Homicide
description: The death of a local businessman who was gagged and then apparently pushed off the roof of a seven-story building was ruled a homicide yesterday. The body of Jose Bueno, 50, was found on Wednesday in an alley outside the building where he lived. Prosecutors said they have neither suspects nor a motive. The victim owned stores here and in New York City.

title: Two Boys Arrested in Bomb Plot
description: At Mountain Lakes High School, the rumor was no secret: Two boys were planning to blow up the school this weekend. Other students told school officials, who told the authorities. A search of the boys' homes, with their parents' permission, turned up a pipe bomb and two M-80 firecrackers taped to a bottle containing gasoline, prosecutors said. Yesterday the boys, ages 15 and 17, were under arrest.

title: Praising New Officers, Mayor Adds Warning
description: Delivering a gentle admonition to a new group of New York City police officers, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani told the 81 graduates of the police academy yesterday that their loyalty must lie with upholding the law and not with protecting corrupt or abusive officers.

title: Suing Over Meadowlands Lease
description: A newspaper sued yesterday to force the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority to disclose its lease agreements with the four professional sports teams based in the Meadowlands. The suit, by The Record of Hackensack, was filed as officials were trying to persuade the Devils hockey team to remain in New Jersey. Gov. Christine Todd Whitman said yesterday that if a deal is struck, the public will know "the bottom line" of what the state offered.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: L.I.R.R. WALKOUT BRINGS CHAOS Locomotive engineers on the Long Island Rail Road staged a walkout in a long-simmering labor dispute, all but shutting down the nation's busiest commuter line and sending more than 100,000 passengers scrambling for alternate transportation at the start of the long Memorial Day weekend. [ Page 1. ] NO WARNING, NO WAY OUT FOR RIDERS For hours they had been standing around Pennsylvania Station, staring at a blank arrivals-and-departures board, waiting vainly for any train that might take them home. So when rumors began circulating that a train would be leaving from Track 19, 500 Long Island Rail Road riders grabbed their briefcases, stuck out their elbows and rushed the platform. [ 1. ] THE UNION LEADERS BEHIND THE WALKOUT The walkout by Long Island Rail Road engineers brought railroad officials, labor leaders, mediators and rider advocates to the same conclusion: that the action was the work of a militant faction that recently took control of the engineers' union and is holding out for larger raises than other unions accepted. [ 24. ] NEW YORK CITY LOW TEST SCORES RAISE FEARS A pattern of low exam scores for workers training to be child-abuse investigators has raised concerns among city officials, with some proposing that trainees be required to pass a minimum competency test before being certified to investigate allegations of neglect or abuse. [ 23. ] DRUG DEALER GETS 18 YEARS IN MURDERS A drug dealer who testified against his colleagues was sentenced to 18 years in prison for hiring a hit man to kill a journalist whose writings angered a Colombian drug cartel. [ 23. ] MAXIMUM SENTENCE IN OFFICER'S DEATH A man who threw a 30-pound bucket off a roof in upper Manhattan two years ago, killing a housing police officer, was sentenced in State Supreme Court yesterday to 5 to 15 years in prison, the maximum. [ 23. ] MAYOR GENTLY ADMONISHES NEW OFFICERS Delivering a gentle admonition to a new group of New York City police officers, Mayor Giuliani told the 81 graduates of the police academy that their loyalty must lie with upholding the law and not with protecting corrupt or abusive officers. [ 23. ] REGION 3 CONVICTED IN FRAUD CASE Three men, including an associate of John Gotti, were convicted in Newark of defrauding the Government of more than $100 million in gasoline taxes in a huge scheme that provided new evidence of the growing ties between the Italian Mafia and emerging Russian organized-crime groups. [ 25. ] TROUBLES CONTINUE AT UTILITIES AGENCY Troubles at the agency that regulates utilities in New Jersey appeared to grow when a second of its three commissioners was accused of accepting a meal paid for by a utility that has been charged with misconduct. [ 25. ] SHUTTING DOWN RADAR TO FIX IT Technicians at the air traffic control center that handles high-altitude flights in the New York area plan to shut down one-third of the radar screens, so they can remove a circuit breaker that failed on Thursday, delaying tens of thousands of travelers. [ 25. ] Holiday schedule 22

title: Fed Panel Was Unanimous For Steady Rates in March
description: Federal Reserve policy makers were unanimous at their March 28 meeting in deciding to hold interest rates steady, according to the minutes of the session that were released today.

title: Ex-Mets Show Interest in Yanks
description: The agent for Darryl Strawberry and Dwight Gooden said yesterday that he believed the Yankees had "a genuine interest" in Strawberry and Gooden, both of whom are out of baseball on drug-related suspensions. The agent, Bill Goodstein, said he had a conversation regarding his clients with George Steinbrenner in a social call two weeks ago. Steinbrenner could not be reached for comment.

title: No Headline
description: "I thought I came from a big city, coming from Charlotte. But there's a lot more countercultures here." -- JOHN LAZENBOY, a sailor in town for Fleet Week, as he surveyed Eighth Avenue. [ 23:3. ]

title: With Budget Near, Talk Turns to Pork
description: In the clearest sign that final agreement on the state budget is near at hand, Gov. George E. Pataki and legislative leaders focused their energies today on deciding how to apportion an estimated $24 million in what they politely call "program initiatives," better known as pork.

title: Albany's Painful Budget Accord
description: It is not a pretty sight to watch Gov. George Pataki and New York State's Legislature stumble toward the finish line in their budget negotiations. Nearly two months late, they have reached agreement on the most punishing cuts in years in programs serving the poor, the sick, the elderly, the mentally disabled and the young. They have also resorted to fiscal gimmicks that are certain to create new budget problems next year. The best that can be said is that Republicans and Democrats have faced up to the difficult job of crawling out of a financial hole while mitigating some of the worst cutbacks demanded by Mr. Pataki.

title: Worst May Be Over in Zaire's Ebola Outbreak
description: With only six new cases of Ebola infection reported in Zaire over the last week, the World Health Organization said today that the epidemic of the deadly viral disease in the African country was "coming under control."

title: Nicaragua Distortions Don't Die Easily
description: To the Editor:

title: BBA Group Bids $390 Million To Acquire Swiss Paper Maker
description: The BBA Group P.L.C. of Britain bid 443 million Swiss francs ($390 million) today for the Swiss paper maker Holvis Holzstoff A.G., topping a hostile offer of 387 million francs from the International Paper Company.

title: Mr. Giuliani's Patronage Retreat
description: Faced with the prospect of an embarrassing public fight over an indefensible appointment, Mayor Rudolph Giuliani has wisely backed off from installing Leonard Piccoli as executive director of the Jacobi Medical Center in the Bronx.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Walkout Shuts L.I.R.R., Stranding Thousands
description: Locomotive engineers on the Long Island Rail Road staged a walkout yesterday in a long-simmering labor dispute, all but shutting down the nation's busiest commuter line and sending more than 100,000 passengers scrambling for alternate transportation at the start of the long Memorial Day weekend.

title: New Kenya Opposition Party Draws Fierce Response
description: The creation this month of a new opposition party has shaken Kenya's political establishment, panicked the Government and underscored the country's growing instability, Western diplomats say.

title: Bird Eviction Plan Short-Circuits
description: On paper, the plan looked good. The Garden State Parkway was going to evict pigeons from their toll plaza perches using mild electric shock. Unfortunately, someone made an error in the specifications for the solar-powered "pigeon deterrent system." What that meant for the pigeons is perhaps best left to the imagination. Now it's back to the drawing board in the parkway's decadelong battle of the birds. SUSAN JO KELLER

title: Utility Commissioner Accused Of a Violation of Ethics
description: Troubles at the state agency that regulates utilities appeared to grow today when a second of its three commissioners was accused of accepting a meal paid for by a utility that has been repeatedly charged with misconduct in recent years.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CMS ENERGY CORP., Dearborn, Mich., an electricity and natural gas concern, said its board had approved an increase of 14 percent in its common stock dividend to 24 cents a share from 21 cents. CENTERCORE INC., Exton, Pa., a manufacturer and designer of office furnishings, announced that it had signed an agreement to sell its furniture business to Apollo Group Inc., an investment firm. Terms of the transaction were not disclosed. DIGITAL EQUIPMENT CORP., Maynard, Mass., has cut its prices by as much as 20 percent on four of the eight models in its Starion line of personal computers.

title: 2 House Leaders Propose Ending Plans for a Permanent Nuclear Waste Site in Nevada
description: In a move that caused agitation in the Department of Energy and the state of Nevada, two House committee chairmen have said that the Government should consider scrapping its efforts to carve out a cavernous dump for high-level nuclear wastes beneath a barren Nevada ridge.

title: Political Memo; An Unusual Turn in a Democratic Race: Clinton Has the Field All to Himself
description: While the ever-expanding group of Republican Presidential competitors has been drawing the attention recently, there has been a significant development in the Democratic field: it has narrowed to one.

title: Samuel Tamposi, 70, Real Estate Developer, Dies
description: Samuel A. Tamposi, who rose from modest beginnings as a farmer and vacuum cleaner salesman to become New Hampshire's largest commercial real estate developer, died at the Dana Farber Cancer Institute in Boston on Thursday. He was 70 and lived in Nashua, N.H., and Hernando, Fla.

title: Bridge
description: The sponsorship of bridge events has been standard practice in Europe for years but is rare on this side of the Atlantic. In January, the Manhattan Club, 27 West 72d Street, was able to find three sponsors for a Calcutta event. With help from Pipeline, an Internet provider in New York City, OKbridge, which lets four players in any location compete, and Famous Famiglia Pizza, the organizers assembled a prize fund of over $16,000. This is thought to be a record for a single-session event.

title: SENATE COMMITTEE APPROVES NOMINEE FOR HEALTH POST
description: Benefiting from the swing vote of a freshman Republican, President Clinton's beleaguered choice for Surgeon General, Dr. Henry W. Foster Jr., cleared his first political hurdle today when the Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee sent his nomination to the full Senate.

title: MacLean and Broten Bring the Devils Closer to Their Goal
description: John MacLean has scored some of the biggest goals in Devils history, but on this electric spring night, MacLean assumed the role of playmaker.

title: Tony Azito, 46, Stage Actor
description: Tony Azito, the lanky, loose-limbed Broadway actor who led the Keystone Kops in the New York Shakespeare Festival's 1981 production of "The Pirates of Penzance," died yesterday at St. Vincent's Hospital in Manhattan. He was 46 and lived in Manhattan.

title: KAUFMAN FINANCIAL APPROVES SWEETENED OFFER FROM AJK
description: H. W. Kaufman Financial Group Inc. said yesterday that its board had approved a sweetened acquisition offer of $8.20 a share in cash, or $27.9 million, from AJK Enterprises, a privately held company led by Alan J. Kaufman. Mr. Kaufman is the son of H. W. Kaufman's chief executive and president, Herbert W. Kaufman. The transaction is expected to be completed within 90 days. The company, an insurance holding company based in Farmington Hills, Mich., had earlier received an offer of $8 a share from AJK Enterprises. H. W. Kaufman Financial has 3.4 million shares outstanding. H. W. Kaufman Financial sells insurance through its primary unit, Burns & Wilcox Ltd., with 35 branches in 49 states.

title: International Briefs; German Builder Seeks Larger Stake in Rival
description: Hochtief A.G., a German construction company, agreed yesterday to buy a 10 percent stake in a rival, Philipp Holzmann A.G., from Commerzbank A.G., in a move that could raise its total stake to 34.9 percent. The purchase will be completed only if a German court now reviewing the matter permits a closer relationship between the country's two largest building companies.

title: Markets to Close
description: All financial and commodity markets in the United States will be closed Monday in observance of Memorial Day. Markets in Britain will also be closed for a spring bank holiday. But most markets in other countries will be open.

title: Conseco Goes to Open Market To Acquire Bankers Life Shares
description: Conseco Inc. said yesterday that it had withdrawn its offer to acquire all the publicly traded shares of the Bankers Life Holding Corporation for $22 a share but that its board had approved buying up to 10 million shares on the open market.

title: Amnesty for East German Spies
description: Markus Wolf was a master spy. During the 33 years he ran East Germany's foreign espionage network, he infiltrated agents into the highest echelons of Western power, including NATO headquarters in Brussels and the West German Chancellor's office. Since the reunification of Germany five years ago, Germans from east and west have debated whether Mr. Wolf and his fellow East German spy chiefs should be held accountable for their espionage activities.

title: Observer; Straining At Art
description: The testosterone fad seems to be over among writers of overwrought prose. I began tracking it back in 1991 when it looked as if testosterone might become the biggest thing in writers' workshops since electrification of audiences, a feat so commonplace that I have done it many times myself without shame or remorse.

title: Devils Have Won 3 Games, and Nothing
description: The Devils may be only one victory away from playing the Philadelphia Flyers in the Eastern Conference finals, but they are quick to point out that their second-round series isn't over yet. Particularly since they are playing a Pittsburgh team that in the first round became the 13th team in league history to come back from a 3-1 deficit.

title:
THE FRESH AIR FUND;
City Lessons From a Country Weekend
description: Looming like a legend up in the trees at the Fresh Air Fund's Hudson Valley campground, "the ropes" await teen-age campers and fill the minds of the uninitiated with foreboding.

title: In the Region/Connecticut; Landlord Leaseholds Troubling Condos and Co-ops
description: IN the 70's, when condominiums and co-ops were unregulated in Connecticut, certain caveats relating to ownership in some of them with modest-income purchasers were hidden in plain sight in the small print of sale contracts.

title: As Unhomogenized as the U.N.
description: THE CHOCOLATE TOE SHOES and tulips that a local confectioner displayed in the lobby of the War Memorial Opera House were no stranger than some of the premieres in United We Dance, the international ballet festival presented here two weeks ago by the San Francisco Ballet.

title: GRANT US PEACE
description: Regarding Grant: Leave his tomb alone. It is perfect New York. A quirky folly with a noble past.

title: Classic Salads, Without Tomatoes
description: THOUGH lettuce and tomatoes are often considered a salad classic, there are times when this combination is not the best. Until ripe field tomatoes come into the market, usually in July, other ingredients are better choices to add interest to a lettuce salad.

title: An Immigration Disaster?
description: To the Editor:

title:
Connecticut Q&A;: Dr. Anthony S. Morgan;
Putting Youngsters Back Together Again
description: GANGS, why they exist, why they persist, and how to keep young men and women from joining them, are among the troublesome questions facing many cities today.

title: May 21-27: Don't Inhale; Philip Morris Recallsx Billions of Cigarettes
description: Smokers wondering about cutting back got yet another sign last week when the Philip Morris Companies announced that some of its cigarettes could be immediately hazardous to their health.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: ON THEIR TOES

title: End Arbitration Delays
description: To the Editor:

title: Road and Tunnel: 8 Spots to Avoid
description: A look at trouble spots you may encounter in the next week -- or month, or months -- courtesy of Transcom, an interstate transportation agency.

title: Germany's New Right Wears a 3-Piece Suit
description: IN the wake of German unification in 1990, there were widespread fears that a far-right movement might attract broad support from alienated and angry voters. To the relief of almost everyone, that has not happened.

title: Ousted Arafat Aide Assesses Future of the P.L.O.
description: Bassam Abu Sharif does not recall ever being told by Yasir Arafat that he was out of a job after a quarter-century of service as his senior political adviser, close aide, trouble-shooter and one-man information ministry.

title: THE WAR AND THE LAW
description: We could either have done nothing (forgive and forget) or put upward of 250,000 Germans against a wall. I share Frankel's frustrations and sorrow and anger, but not his facile criticism. Even if often flouted, Nuremberg remains a top legal precedent. MAX ISENBERG-LIKIN New York

title:
About Men;
Angry Fathers

Ilse Bing peers dead-on through her Leica, next to a mirror image of her profile, its eye wide with scary intensity. Germaine Krull, her face obliterated by her camera, defines herself with a pair of masculine hands, heavy cuff links and the inevitable phallic prop, a cigarette.

They show once again that guns fight a real enemy and that real combat soldiers shed real blood in real battles. Every picture tells the same authentic story: we fought that war for a sensational concept -- freedom. DEBBY KALL Bronx

title: A Dangerous Literacy: The Legacy of Frederick Douglass
description: ONE hundred and fifty years ago, on May 28, Frederick Douglass published the first of his three autobiographies, "Narrative of the Life of Frederick Douglass, an American Slave, Written by Himself." He was barely 27 years old and already a popular figure on the abolition lecture circuit. Almost overnight he would become the most celebrated black author in history; his slender volume supplanted a book of verses by the 18th-century slave poet Phillis Wheatley as the abolitionists' favorite emblem of black eloquence and intelligence. By the time Douglass died, 100 years ago this past February, he had long been accustomed to being the most famous Negro in the world. Years before, he had been dubbed "the representative colored man of the United States" -- a title that surely implied a confinement as well as a coronation, but that he wore proudly. The former slave, in so many ways the least representative of men, had become a great orator, abolitionist and -- in a phrase much in favor these days -- the first black "public intellectual."

But we are also promised that the cities will be rent by highways and that the fumes of carbon monoxide will have replaced the smell of manure. At critical hours, the city's streets and all major roads for miles around will be so clogged that a 15-minute journey will take nearly an hour, and even longer when some giant truck has overturned.

title: A Grand Russian Original Steps Out of the Mist
description: AND WHO, PRAY TELL, IS Ustvolskaya? A public that has embraced Prokofiev and Shostakovich, acknowledged Alfred Schnittke, taken note of Sofia Gubaidulina and eyed Giya Kancheli might well grow weary at the prospect of greeting yet another figure in the endless procession of Russian and former Soviet composers. All the same, here she is. The collected works of Galina Ustvolskaya, utterly unknown a decade ago, have suddenly burst into view: performances have dotted several continents; nearly a dozen recordings have seeped into the record stores. An imposing figure in 20th-century musical history has stepped out of the mist.

title: A Mill Town's Reluctant Son
description: JAMES McNEILL WHISTLER was such a cosmopolitan dandy and sophisticated esthete in mid-Victorian England that it surprises many to learn he was born in Lowell, Mass. Moreover, there is so much to see in this splendidly preserved cradle of the American Industrial Revolution, that his birthplace, the Whistler House Museum of Art, is often overlooked.

title: Clinton Assails Effort to Change His Anti-Terrorism Plan
description: Trying to keep pressure on Congress to pass his anti-terrorism measures, President Clinton warned today that he opposed Senate efforts to weaken his proposals.

title: Man in the Background at the F.B.I. Now Draws Some Unwelcome Attention
description: For years, Larry A. Potts toiled quietly at the headquarters of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, occasionally working 36 hours at a stretch to engineer some of the bureau's greatest successes.

title: Julie Ann Fisch, J. S. Hollenberg
description: Julie Ann Fisch, the daughter of Karyl and Steven Fisch of Sudbury, Mass., was married last evening to Jonathan Samuel Hollenberg, a son of Judith and Jack Hollenberg of Rockville Centre, L.I. Rabbi Lawrence Kushner officiated at the Copley Place Marriott in Boston.

title: Greetings From the Shore
description: TO ME, the shore will always begin at Ocean Grove, for that is where my wife, a Jersey girl who surfed there when surfboards were still big and clumsy, introduced me to it. The introduction was brief, for already those days lived more in her photo album than on the beach, where she no longer knew anyone. What the shore is all about, she told me, is growing up summer by summer surrounded by familiar faces as well as places; she'd done that, it was over, and so we admired Ocean Grove's gingerbread cottages and drove on.

title: An Inventor in a Business Suit, With None of the Usual Angst
description: The great mythic symbol of scientific invention is the eccentric loner sweating away in a makeshift lab, chasing a vision. That does not even remotely describe John R. Novak. Mr. Novak is a smooth and polished 47-year-old salesman. He wears monogrammed shirts. He does not appear to sweat.

title: Foreign Affairs; The G-Who?
description: On June 15, in Halifax, Canada, 5,000 journalists will gather for the annual meeting of the Group of Seven. Not since the G-7 summit in Naples a year ago will so many journalists be gathered in so small a spot to cover so little news. G-7 summits used to make history. Now they make tourism. I loved the pasta noodles the Italians gave all the journalists who attended the Naples G-7. The noodles expanded into little G's and 7's when you put them in soup. They also had free Coke dispensers set up all around the Naples conference hall, with Italian models doing the dispensing. The Coke machines were better attended than the briefings.

title: School for 4-Year-Olds Can't Charge Tuition, State Says, Putting Its Future in Doubt
description: One morning last week, a cluster of children at the Mount Hebron Middle School painted, danced and watched a pet spider eat a caterpillar. At age 4, they were not yet reading or taking tests. They were preparing for school in a popular program whose future is uncertain.

title: INSIDE
description: BETWEEN MAIN AND WALL/Page 6 Two Florida retirees want to play it safe with their money and end up in limited partnerships. Who should pay? By Susan Antilla. MUTUAL FUNDS/Page 9 With four new funds coming to market, the Vanguard Group is looking more like the rivals it belittled for so long. By Reed Abelson. FROM THE DESK OF/Page 12 In denial that she might owe the taxman money for 1994, Danelle Morton tries procrastination as a tonic for a tough tax return. EARNING IT/Page 15 A Wall Street analyst moves to Milwaukee so she can hit the ice and snag a gold in the 1998 Winter Olympics. By Edmund L. Andrews.

title: CUISINE: Tastes Just Like . . .
description: To inaugurate barbecue season, here are 10 things that aren't chicken but taste like it (all citations from The New York Times):

title: Street Smarts; Double Trouble: Bad News Delivered Late
description: LOTS of publicly traded companies pick cutesy ticker symbols that represent something about their business. That's why the ticker is littered with such winners as "BUD" (Anheuser-Busch), "LOG" (Rayonier Timberlands), and "CASH" (First Midwest Financial).

title: Fear Stalks the Quick and the Dead in Zaire
description: For Casongo Malele, the news that her sister was being moved from Ward 3 to Ward 2 in the overtaxed hospital here, the epicenter of Zaire's Ebola virus epidemic, was a sign of hope.

title: The Dark Science Of Fund-Raising by Mail
description: MORE than a few Americans were outraged to learn that the National Rifle Association, in a recent fund-raising letter, called the agents who enforce Federal gun laws "jack-booted Goverment thugs" who wear "nazi bucket helmets and black storm trooper uniforms to attack law-abiding citizens." Former President George Bush publicly resigned from the group, and President Clinton lambasted it. But the creative scribes who ghost-write the frenzied appeals that spill from every mailbox these days had quite a different reaction: they sensed a fund-raising bulls-eye.

title: Peter A. Quiros, Katherine A. Yi
description: Katherine Ann Yi, the daughter of Byung J. Yi and Chun Y. Yi of Bedford, N.Y., is to be married today to Peter Anthony Quiros, the son of Natalia and Pedro Quiros of Miami. The Rev. David Harkness, a Presbyterian minister, is to perform the ceremony at Tappan Hill in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: Beyond Foot Longs and Zeppole
description: PEOPLE say there's no place to eat on the Jersey Shore.

title: Armed With List, Italy Pursues Artworks Looted by Nazis
description: For decades, a list of artworks looted by the Nazis in Italy during World War II -- including a grotesque marble head of a faun attributed to Michelangelo, a drawing of Christ by Tintoretto and a Titian portrait of the Renaissance writer Ludovico Ariosto -- lay locked away here at the Foreign Ministry.

title: Talk About Friendly! Now Casper Has A Crush on a Girl
description: Casper Christina Ricci, Bill Pullman, Cathy Moriarty, Eric Idle Directed by Brad Silberling PG 96 minutes

title: Yankees' Sick Bats Take Turn For Worse
description: The Yankee virus is spreading. Another starter is wrapped in gauze, another opposing pitcher pushed the Yankees' mute button and another member of their farm system was no antidote.

title: Shade, Glorious Shade
description: I HAVE nothing against the sun -- in its place. Shining just right on six inches of new snow, slanting obliquely through dark autumn clouds, flooding our summer garden, going down in the west in a soft oranging that gradually widens, flattens to a rusty crimson, slowly ebbs. Seeing what our great and familiar star can do to even the most humdrum of landscapes, the lighting effects it creates, the new life and growth it elicits from a grudging earth, fills me with a joy so exhilarating it's all I can do not to shout out loud. It's only when it targets less hospitable ground, the exposed skin of my forehead, nose and cheeks, that the problem, my chronic solar-phobia, starts making me change my mind.

title: P. M. Kapsimalis, G. H. Parsells 3d
description: Pamela Mary Kapsimalis and George Henry Parsells 3d, associates at the law firm of Connell, Foley & Geiser in Roseland, N.J., were married yesterday. Msgr. William P. Devine performed the ceremony at St. Rose of Lima Church in Short Hills, N.J.

title: The Power of DNA Evidence
description: While the O. J. Simpson trial stumbles ahead with a dwindling pool of jurors and new revelations bearing on the veracity of a key witness, the most important development in recent weeks may be the respect accorded to the science of DNA blood testing. Even in this bitterly contested murder trial, the principles and potential of DNA testing have not yet been seriously questioned. Indeed, the defense has not generally challenged the validity of the science but has instead charged that blood evidence was mishandled or manipulated by conspiratorial police before it was subjected to DNA analysis.

title: Budget Test for Mr. Clinton
description: Except for his tactically inept proposal to balance the budget in 10 years, President Clinton has played the budget game pretty cannily for a person who lacks the votes to impose his will on Congress. Debate driven by the warring ambitions of Bob Dole, Phil Gramm and Newt Gingrich has brought the brutality of the Republican plan into full view.

title: Let Them Explain
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Your Home Computer Would Scoff at These Plots
description: IN THE NEW FILM "JOHNNY Mnemonic" Keanu Reeves plays a 21st-century data courier who is required to carry 320 gigabytes of information in his "wetware," or computer-enhanced memory cells. That movie, which opened on Friday, is obsessed with the storing, finding and retrieving of data. And it is not alone.

title: Will the Lawyers Kill Off Norplant?
description: WHEN Norplant came on the market in February 1991 after 30 years of development and testing, family planners were delighted. Here was a birth-control device, implanted just under the skin, that was not only safe and effective but also lasted five years.

title:
ART;
Gonzo 'Gallery Beat' Prowls Late-Night Cable TV
description: WHEN THE ARTISTS Walter Robinson and Cathy Lebowitz aren't painting, they work as editors at Art in America magazine.

title: Loony Tuna
description: It's not just a tuna salad sandwich. It's the last straw.

title:
SOAP BOX;
Loving the Shore, and Leaving It
description: I WASN'T born on the Jersey Shore, but I grew up there. I've spent nearly every summer on the shore since I was 14 and worked there as everything from bar band musician to boardwalk barker. It's where I went to college (Monmouth College, now Monmouth University) and met my wife (on the boardwalk) and where two of my three kids were born (Red Bank).

title: In the Cards for Bogota: Another Bright Century
description: To the Editor:

title: Preserving Britain's Heritage
description: THE fire that swept through the magnificent 17th-century house of Uppark in the summer of 1989 gutted whole wings, destroyed or badly damaged many of Uppark's priceless possessions, and left the house smoldering and close to ruin. The question was, what to do next?

title: Julie E. Bram, Evan Goldfischer
description: Julie Ellen Bram, the daughter of S. Yales is to perform the ceremony at the Ritz-Carlton Hotel in Boston.

title:
HOME CLINIC;
How to Wash Windows So They Become Clear
description: PERHAPS the most tedious and frustrating part of spring cleaning is window cleaning. The average person attacks a dirty window with a roll of paper towels in one hand and a spray bottle of commercial glass cleaner in the other.

title: Good News But No Good Explanation
description: AT 12:58 last Tuesday afternoon, an auspicious event occurred in the corporate life of Presstek Inc.: the printing press technology company surpassed a total market value of $10 million -- per employee, that is.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 3-16 SERBS AND U.N. BATTLE IN SARAJEVO The new policy of standing up to the Bosnian Serbs brought peacekeepers into battle, with two French soldiers killed in Sarajevo as fighting spread in the wake of the NATO air strikes. 1 NATO RENEWS DIPLOMATIC EFFORT France and its NATO allies renewed diplomatic efforts to stop the violence and asked Russia to help persuade the Serbs to free U.N. troops seized as hostages. 1

title: Beach Blanket Business Reading
description: THERE are two extremes among summer readers. There are, first, the edifiers, who start saving their serious reading in September for June, when the pace of life slows down and there are no new episodes of "N.Y.P.D. Blue" to compete for their attention. These are the people who used to turn up on the beach with all 542 parts of The New Yorker's series on airline gateway rights. "Incredible," they would be heard to say. "A good writer can make anything fascinating."

title: Man in Black vs. The Boss: Two Places Compared
description: If the New Jersey Devils win the Stanley Cup, local fans may have to savor it from a long distance. Nashville has made a lucrative offer to lure the team away. But Governor Whitman is trying to prevent the team from leaving.

title: Simple French Fare, Swirling Stream
description: A FIRST visit to Brookside Bistro, a block from the covered bridge in West Cornwall, produced an acute attack of nostalgia. This same frame house, with a screened-in deck in the rear, overlooking a swirling stream (actually the Housatonic River at a narrow point), has been home to at least two restaurants in the recent past: the Deck and Freshfields.

title: Grassy Dunes, Beach Tags And a Special Pink Shell
description: Last summer, my family took a trip to Sandy Hook. About noontime, when the waves were enlarging, the sea gulls flew around in a circle near the waves. Then they flew at a fast pace toward the sky. There was a thunderstorm heading our way. How strange. CHRIS KING Cedar Knolls

title: Queens College Has Named Two Leaders
description: A physicist and former diplomat has been named president of Queens College and a State Supreme Court justice will take over as dean of its law school.

title: Stocking This Summer's Beach Bag
description: It's too soon to tell which items will be de rigueur for this season's well-equipped beach bag, but on the basis of early demand, shore merchants are making some predictions. BEACHWEAR Despite growing concern about skin cancer and television commercials touting sunscreen with as much protection as you'd get if you wore a paper bag, the rule of women's swimsuits still seems to be the skimpier the better. Thongs (the tiniest of bikini bottoms) and triangles (another name for a minuscule top), as well as side-tying bikini bottoms, are popular. For those who lack the nerve to walk around in a thong, there's a new version that allows the wearer to add an extra piece of fabric with Velcro, providing a little (but not much) more cover. The colors are bright, but neon is out. Flowers and textured fabrics are popular. For men, the popular bathing suits reflect the somber colors of the office: navy and gray.

title: It's Temporary, but Is It Beaux-Arts?
description: It's just a park. Not even a permanent park. Yet, the acre and a half at the northern tip of Donald Trump's multibillion-dollar development project along the Hudson River has become yet another lightning rod for community opposition.

title: Gems From Bernie Bland
description: BERNIE BLAND has been an elevator operator at Tiffany & Company's flagship store for only four years, but he has already become an institution. The manager of the store, on Fifth Avenue at 57th Street, calls him "Tiffany's ambassador"; fellow elevator operators try to imitate his commanding bass and gracious touch with customers. He has won the store's highest in-house award for customer service.

title: Streetscapes/New York State Marine Amphitheater; At Old Aquacade, Things Aren't Going Swimmingly
description: IT was a star of the 1939-40 World's Fair, but vandals and decay have turned the amphitheater in Flushing Meadows-Corona Park that housed Billy Rose's Aquacade into scenery from a war zone. Parks Commissioner Henry J. Stern wants to demolish it this year, but Queens preservationists are fighting to save the waterfront structure.

title: Firing Range Gets Cleaner, but No Quieter
description: After more than three years of legal battles, a plan to clean up lead-laden soil at the Police Department's firing range at Rodman's Neck is under way, but residents remain angry that a noise abatement plan has not been implemented.

title: The Ultimate Test
description: Definition of torture: visiting France on a low-fat diet tour. Actually, organizers of the tour, Sea Gate Travel Agency of Manhattan, maintain that the food that will be served on the tour of Paris, Provence and the Riviera will be delicious as well as good for the heart. Of course, they also say this is a 13-day, 11-night trip, so they might be used to doing the impossible.

title: Lincoln Center Has a Mission
description: To the Editor:

title: MONUMENTS TO A CRIME-FEARING AGE
description: IN THE MORNING OF APRIL 19, AN unexceptional, glass-concrete-and-steel Federal office building in Oklahoma City became, in a matter of seconds, a smoldering ruin, and then, in a CNN flash, a monument: a site to mark for years to come 90's-style hatred of government. Public buildings have always mirrored their times, embodying the concerns and conflicts of those who built them, used them, even sought to destroy them. Years from now, our anxious decade -- with its heightened fear of crime, its tele-fascination with the justice system and its urge to settle every dispute before a judge -- will be read not only in whatever remains of the Federal building in Oklahoma City but in the scores of Federal courthouses now being built and renovated across the nation.

title: Nancy E. Davis, Daniel S. Hack
description: Nancy Ellen Davis, a daughter of J. Philip Davis of Massapequa, L.I., and the late Nancy E. Davis, is to be married today to Daniel Seth Hack, the son of Elayne and Raymond S. Hack of Kew Gardens, Queens. Judge Robert Dale of the Sonoma County Municipal Court in Santa Rosa, Calif., is to officiate at the Bay Hill Mansion in Bodega Bay, Calif.

title: The Second Suspect -- A special report.; With Extremism and Explosives, A Drifting Life Found a Purpose
description: Terry Lynn Nichols had always done pretty much what was expected of him. He was predictable, accommodating. He stayed close to home, in rural Michigan, where he was raised on a farm. Then, at age 33, when few men do such things, he surprised everyone and joined the Army. He was the oldest man in his platoon; the other recruits called him grandpa.

title: Keeping Track Of the Future On the Hudson
description: ON these fine spring days, Mayor Sean Treacy of North Tarrytown has taken to strolling along Beekman Avenue, the main village thoroughfare, which slopes down to the Hudson River. On his walks the Mayor sorts out worries in his mind, including the future of the 97-acre General Motors site at the end of the street. The automaker is leaving next year, and Mr. Treacy wonders how the village will replace the revenue it received in lieu of taxes on the prime waterfront site.

title: CONNOISSEURS: Water, Water Everywhere
description: Americans already have a nagging sense of inferiority to Europeans when it comes to wine. But what about water? Visitors to Amsterdam can now stop by Waterwinkel (literally "water shop"), a boutique selling nothing but bottled mineral and spring water.

title: Going Farther Afield For Concert Programs
description: AS that quiet period arrives between the close of spring concert seasons and the start of summer festivals, it can pay to go outside the county. The short drive to City Island, for instance, yields Sunday noon recitals at Le Refuge Inn (620 City Island Avenue). Sharon Kam, the young Israeli clarinetist, is the featured soloist today and next Sunday, first playing the two Weber Concertos and then next Sunday the Mozart Clarinet Concerto and a set of Rossini Variations, accompanied on both occasions by the City Island Baroque Ensemble.

title: Shoulder Problem or Not, Saberhagen Has Fine Arm
description: All you need to know about Bret Saberhagen's right shoulder is what the San Francisco Giants found out yesterday afternoon.

title: Anne C. Freeman, Robert Clothier 3d
description: Anne Chandler Freeman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David N. Freeman of Newtown Square, Pa., was married yesterday to Robert Clarkson Clothier 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Clothier Jr. of Haverford, Pa. The Rev. Dr. Eugene C. Bay performed the ceremony at the Bryn Mawr Presbyterian Church in Bryn Mawr, Pa.

title: Diane L. Prescott, Edward A. Slafsky
description: Diane Lyn Prescott, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Gary Prescott of Providence, R.I., is to be married today to Edward Andrew Slafsky, a son of Dr. and Mrs. S. Frederick Slafsky of Providence. Rabbi Chaim Shapiro is to perform the ceremony at Touro Synagogue in Newport.

title: Girl Injured in Father's Suicide Goes Home
description: No longer frozen by a fear of heights, Lidiya Kitayev, 8 years old, has mastered playground slides anew. And she has overcome initial concerns that there might not be ice cream in the United States.

title: When Art (the Artist's) Meets Art (the Printer's)
description: THE news from the Zimmerli Art Museum is of prints 103 of them, spanning the period 1960 to 1990. Not that this is remarkable in itself, for under Philip Dennis Cate -- whose 25-year tenure as director was celebrated by an award-laden gala last month -- the museum has vastly expanded its holdings in the graphic arts.

title: Teresa Heinz and John F. Kerry
description: Teresa Simoes-Ferreira Heinz and Senator John Forbes Kerry, Democrat of Massachusetts, were married on Friday evening at the bride's summer house in Nantucket, Mass. Judge Richard G. Stearns of the United States District Court in Massachusetts performed the ceremony.

title: BEST SELLERS: May 28, 1995
description: Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction 1 1 5 THE RAINMAKER, by John Grisham. (Doubleday, $25.95.) A young man barely out of law school tries to expose a corporation's multibillion-dollar scam. 2 2 3 LET ME CALL YOU SWEETHEART, by Mary Higgins Clark. (Simon & Schuster, $24.) Over the years, a prosecutor finds that an unusual murder case haunts her career and private life. 3 4 5 LADDER OF YEARS, by Anne Tyler. (Knopf, $24.) At 40, a woman leaves her physician husband and children to start a new life in a strange town. 4 3 65 THE CELESTINE PROPHECY, by James Redfield. (Warner, $17.95.) An ancient manuscript, found in Peru, provides insights into achieving a fulfilling life. 5 5 49 POLITICALLY CORRECT BEDTIME STORIES, by James Finn Garner. (Macmillan, $8.95.) A Georgia family endures the divisive stresses of the Civil War. 9 1 MIND PREY, by John Sandford. (Putnam, $23.95.) Lucas Davenport pursues the kidnapper of a psychiatrist and her two daughters. 10 10 14 BORDER MUSIC, by Robert James Waller. (Warner, $17.95.) A Texas rancher, trying to erase his Vietnam trauma, takes to the road with an exotic dancer. 11 9 2 ONCE UPON A MORE ENLIGHTENED TIME, by James Finn Garner. (Macmillan, $9.95.) Eight more "politically correct bedtime stories." 12 15 10 PHENOMENAL WOMAN, by Maya Angelou. (Random House, $10.) Four poems celebrating women. 13 12 3 THE CAROUSEL, by Belva Plain. (Delacorte, $23.95.) Compulsion and revenge threaten the survival of a family dynasty noted for its respectability. 14 11 8 A DOG'S LIFE, by Peter Mayle. (Knopf, $20.) The memoirs of Boy, a shaggy canine in Provence; with drawings by Edward Koren. 15 11 THE GLASS LAKE, by Maeve Binchy. (Delacorte, $23.95.) The unspoken ties that bind a woman and her mother in a small Irish town. Weeks This Last On Week Week List Nonfiction 1 2 33 THE HOT ZONE, by Richard Preston. (Random House, $23.) The discovery of a lethal virus, more infectious than H.I.V., and the efforts to keep it from spreading. 2 1 5 IN RETROSPECT, by Robert S. McNamara with Brian VanDeMark. (Times Books/Random House, $27.50.) The author recalls his role in the Vietnam War. 3 4 22 SISTERS, by Carol Saline. Photographs by Sharon J. Wohlmuth. (Running Press, $27.50.) The relationships of 36 sets of sisters, reported in words and pictures. 4 8 2 LISTEN TO MY HEART, by Kathie Lee Gifford and Cody Gifford. (Hyperion, $12.95.) The television personality tells her 4 1/2-year-old son about matters like family relationships and good manners. 5 3 64 MIDNIGHT IN THE GARDEN OF GOOD AND EVIL, by John Berendt. (Random House, $23.) The mysterious death of a young man in Savannah, Ga. 6 7 4 MY LUCKY STARS, by Shirley MacLaine. (Bantam, $22.95.) The actress reminisces about her four decades in Hollywood. 7 6 6 FROM BEGINNING TO END, by Robert Fulghum. (Villard, $20.) The rituals we practice and the spiritual journeys we take, from childhood to old age. 8 5 15 THE DEATH OF COMMON SENSE, by Philip K. Howard. (Random House, $18.) A biography of the legendary actress. 11 11 75 THE BOOK OF VIRTUES, by William J. Bennett. (Simon & Schuster, $30.) Moral stories adapted from the Greeks, the Bible, folklore and elsewhere. 12 1 SLEEPING AT THE STARLITE MOTEL, by Bailey White. (Addison-Wesley, $20.) A Georgia schoolteacher tells about her adventures while traveling and dealing with folks at home. 13 13 38 COUPLEHOOD, by Paul Reiser. (Bantam, $19.95.) Essays on the ups and downs of marriage by the television star and stand-up comedian. 14* 14 3 LIZ, by C. David Heymann. (Birch Lane/Carol, $24.95.) A biography of Elizabeth Taylor. 15 10 2 PAULA, by Isabel Allende. (HarperCollins, $24.) The novelist tells stories of her family's life as she tends her fatally ill daughter. Weeks This Last On Week Week List Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous 1 2 51 IN THE KITCHEN WITH ROSIE, by Rosie Daley. (Knopf, $14.95.) Recipes by Oprah Winfrey's cook. 2 1 105 MEN ARE FROM MARS, WOMEN ARE FROM VENUS, by John Gray. (HarperCollins, $23.) Ways to improve communication and relationships between the sexes. 3 3 10 THE SEVEN SPIRITUAL LAWS OF SUCCESS, by Deepak Chopra. (Amber-Allen/New World Library, $12.95.) How to "generate wealth in all its forms." 4 3 HOW TO ARGUE AND WIN EVERY TIME, by Gerry Spence. (St. Martin's, $22.95.) A lawyer's advice. Rankings reflect sales figures, for the week ending May 13, at 3,050 bookstores plus wholesalers serving 28,000 other retailers (gift shops, department stores, newsstands, supermarkets), statistically weighted to represent sales in all such outlets nationwide. An asterisk indicates that a book's sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. And Bear in Mind (Editor's Choices of other recent books of particular interest) ATHENA, by John Banville. (Knopf, $22.) In this wickedly mannerist novel, a murderer turned "art expert" runs smack into his own past when he has to catalogue a batch of stolen Old Masters. GOD: A Biography, by Jack Miles. (Knopf, $27.50.) Not a joke but a scholarly, entertaining literary inquiry into the character called God as His multiple personalities have been rendered through the ages in the Hebrew Bible. THE HAUNTED LAND: Facing Europe's Ghosts After Communism, by Tina Rosenberg. (Random House, $25.) A moral, political and psychological investigation, by a wise journalist, of four post-Soviet societies struggling with their conduct under the old regimes. THE INFORMATION, by Martin Amis. (Harmony, $24.) Mr. Amis's cool and brilliant novel is sustained throughout by the corroding, corrupting envy of an unsuccessful novelist for a successful novelist who is also his best friend. THE MAN WITHOUT QUALITIES, by Robert Musil. Translated by Sophie Wilkins and Burton Pike. (Knopf, two volumes, boxed, $60.) A magnificent new version of the unfinished and unfinishable novel by an Austrian contemporary of Proust and Joyce whose acknowledged greatness has always exceeded his acknowledged readership. ONE BY ONE FROM THE INSIDE OUT: Essays and Reviews on Race and Responsibility in America, by Glenn C. Loury. (Free Press, $25.) An African-American economist tackles race and poverty in a collection of biting pieces that emphasize black self-help while also calling on the Government to aid the nation's poor. OSWALD'S TALE: An American Mystery, by Norman Mailer. (Random House, $30.) Stoked by a passion to believe J.F.K.'s death was more than a meaningless absurdity, Mr. Mailer pursues and delivers the assassin's very slightly significant soul, using his own research and that of others. POPE JOHN PAUL II: The Biography, by Tad Szulc. (Lisa Drew/Scribner, $27.50.) Mr. Szulc, a seasoned reporter of Polish birth, inquires into the special circumstances of Polish Catholicism and the special stresses of fascist and Communist domination that formed the present Pope. A RIVER TOWN, by Thomas Keneally. (Nan A. Talese/Doubleday, $24.) It's 1899 in Mr. Keneally's impassioned 21st novel, and Tim Shea, an outsider in an Australia with no insiders, inexorably digs himself into deeper and deeper trouble by always trying to do the right thing. RULE OF THE BONE, by Russell Banks. (HarperCollins, $22.) A novel that reinvigorates the Huck Finn myth in the person of Chappie, a mall rat from upstate New York who lights out for Jamaica with a runaway farm worker. WALT WHITMAN'S AMERICA: A Cultural Biography, by David S. Reynolds. (Knopf, $35.) An intensive historical excavation, aiming to show how Whitman, an enthusiast for almost everything, transmuted into his poetry images from all aspects of American culture.

title: Celebration Is Disputed In Jerusalem
description: In this bitterly contested city, preparations to mark 3,000 years since King David made Jerusalem the capital of the biblical Kingdom of Israel have set off a dispute over rights to the city's heritage and its future.

title: Irish Economic Growth Lifts Hopes
description: When Lisa O'Dea's parents finished school 38 years ago, job opportunities were few, and like generations of Irish before them they went abroad to find work, in their case staying 15 years in economic exile in the United States before coming home.

title: Agassi Seeks a Fourth Feather for His Cap
description: Just three weeks ago, Andre Agassi, the world's No. 1 player and master of all the world's Grand Slam tournaments except the one that starts on Monday -- the French Open -- brought his golf cart to a stop and eased himself into a deck chair at Florida's exclusive Fisher Island resort.

title: THE WAR AND THE LAW
description: Your special World War II issue was a wonderful commemoration.

ART;
'Shelter Me,' and a Juried Show That Is Strong on Sculpture
description: "Shelter Me"

title: Danielle De Mucci And John Esposito
description: Danielle De Mucci, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William De Mucci of Rolling Hills, Calif., was married yesterday to John Patrick Esposito, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael P. Esposito Jr. of Oradell, N.J. The Rev. Timothy Nichols performed the ceremony at St. James Roman Catholic Church in Redondo Beach, Calif.

title: Aiming to Thwart Fire I. Deer
description: WHEN Loretta Li makes coffee each morning at her home in Fair Harbor on Fire Island, two brown doe eyes routinely watch her through the kitchen window.

title:
Long Island Q&A;: Leo A. Guthart;
Devising Security Systems for the Home and for Business
description: LEO A. GUTHART is chairman of the Ademco Security Group of Syosset, the largest manufacturer and distributor of alarm systems. It is a subsidiary of the Pittway Corporation of Chicago and accounts for a sizable share of its alarm-systems division, which grossed $601 million last year. Ademco employs 1,400 people on Long Island, representing about two-thirds of its worldwide work force.

title: GRANT US PEACE
description: I should have known from John Tierney's blase voice as we spoke on the telephone what sort of article he was writing (The Big City: "Grant Us Peace," May 7). Somehow, he didn't sound enthusiastic about Grant's Tomb.

title: Thou Swell, Ella
description: To the Editor:

title: In a Corner of Rego Park, New Three-Family Houses
description: WHEN assorted land investors and farmers were selling off their property for home construction in the Rego Park section of Queens almost half a century ago, the Negri family stood pat.

title: Newsstand Is Missing, Not Missed
description: Here's a new one for the annals of city thievery. A large metal newsstand that had stood on the northwest corner of 14th Street and the Avenue of the Americas for two years has vanished.

title: Don't Let Sharp Operators Near Social Security; Scrap the System
description: To the Editor:

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: A DEAD MAN IN DEPTFORD By Anthony Burgess.Carroll & Graf, $21.

title:
HERE NOW;
For Fashion Set, Try . . . Luna Park?
description: MUCH has been made of the recently opened Fashion Cafe and the super model troika of Claudia Schiffer, Naomi Campbell and Elle MacPherson who are the restaurant's figureheads. But now that the opening night confetti have been swept away and the paparazzi have gone home, the chances of spotting a model there are about as remote as bumping into Sylvester Stallone at Planet Hollywood.

title: 'Small-Market' Angels Enter the Disney Fold
description: Baseball officials were delighted when the Walt Disney Company recently added 25 percent of the California Angels to a stable that already included Mickey Mouse and the Mighty Ducks of Anaheim. In a time of low morale and suffering economy, the officials viewed Disney's interest and entry into their game as a highly positive development.

title: Anatomically Correct
description: When the mythological hero Aeneas fled the fall of Troy and set out to discover Rome, he carried two things with him: his father and a bag full of penates -- household gods in human form. He knew that the quickest way to personalize his new home was to decorate with figurines. Since then the history of the decorative arts has been crowded with effigies on everything from pediments to prows, statues to table lamps.

title: Fish Stories for the Armchair Angler
description: Are fish stories parables of something larger? The writers excerpted below would probably say yes.

title: New Jersey: Exploring the Shore
description: The reviving economy, a weak dollar abroad, and millions of dollars spent on storm-ravaged coastline, beach replenishment and other improvements promise a banner year for the Jersey shore, where, despite crowds, congestion, tedious tolls and beach fees, happiness is still a bit of sand, a splash of surf, a place to park and a meal in any place that's air conditioned.

title: Fight Over Terrorism Laws
description: President Clinton used his weekly radio address to criticize Senate efforts to weaken his package of anti-terrorism measures. Page 24.

title: May 21-27: A Spymaster Goes Free; Germany Makes Short Shrift Of the Cold War Years, But the Reich Still Haunts
description: More than most, Germans are used to living with the sins of the past, but they have discovered since reunification five years ago that history is divisible: Hitler simply will not go away; post-war calamities are easier to dispose of.

description: To the Editor:

title: A. V. Mochary, Seth Bergstein

Judge William H. Walls of the United States District Court in Newark is to perform the ceremony at the National Museum of Women in the Arts in Washington.

title: Bustling Along With a Southern Accent
description: SAVANNA'S is a gorgeous Southern belle. This new Southampton restaurant is holding court in the historic building that once was the old village hall and more recently housed a series of bars and eating spots.

title: Habitats/Fifth Avenue and 87th Street; Long Journey From Manhattan Beach to Manhattan
description: SHIRLEY GOLDSTEIN, who laughingly calls herself "a very senior citizen," had lived all her life in the Manhattan Beach section of Brooklyn; an unmarried first-grade teacher, she had lived first with her parents, then with her sister and her sister's family and, most recently, with her two maiden aunts.

title: Corrections
description: A brief article in the Neighborhood Report last Sunday about a new magazine covering the Flatiron District misstated its name. It is Flatiron News, not Flatiron.

title: At Indy 500, Parity Forges Way Into Driver's Seat
description: The 1995 Indianapolis 500 may end up belonging to the mice that roared. Among them, Scott Brayton speaks the loudest.

title: HOW THE SOUL IS SOLD
description: During my recent two years as an executive story editor and then co-producer of "Star Trek: The Next Generation," nearly every episode I wrote was inspired, directly or indirectly, by the books of James Hillman ("How the Soul Is Sold," by Emily Yoffe, April 23). When Hillman reworks the world, it's by way of ideas so startling they can induce vertigo, by way of paragraphs so rich they border on poetry. JOE MENOSKY Florence, Italy

title: Martha Lawler, R. H. Ropelewski
description: Martha Mary Lawler, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John A. Lawler of Wellesley, Mass., and Richard Henry Ropelewski, the son of Henry C. Ropelewski of Riverview, Fla., and the late Theresa Contois Ropelewski, were married yesterday. The Rev. Peter Walsh performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Cecilia in Boston.

title: Picture Palace: Can Loew's Jersey Theater, Gem of the 20's, Regain Its Old Glory?
description: The Loew's Jersey Theater is faded and tarnished now, its 3,000 red velvet seats dusty and discolored with age, its extravagant facade marred by a clunky marquee from the 1940's. Opened with great glamour and fanfare in 1929, an architectural event in an era when movies were an event, it hasn't shown a feature film since it closed (with "Friday the 13th") in 1986.

title: FOOD SCIENCE: Healthy Hemp Burgers
description: No, it won't get you high. In fact, it's supposed to be healthy. The Hempeh Burger, shown below, introduced last month by Sharon's Finest, a California health food company, does contain cannabis seeds, but from a nonhallucinogenic variety of the plant.

title:
ARCHITECTURE;
Restoring Windsor Castle: Still Gothic to Its Garters
description: WINDSOR CASTLE IS probably the most beautiful and best-known asset Britain's royal family possesses. So, when the building was disfigured by fire, in November 1992, people everywhere were touched by the accident. Britain's civilization is nowhere near as old as she likes to pretend, but this castle does go back to William the Conqueror.

title: Leaders Agree to Toughen Laws That Hinder Drug Convictions
description: Gov. George E. Pataki and state legislative leaders have reached tentative agreement on amending laws to make clear that defendants in felony drug cases can be convicted even if they do not know the weight of drugs they are carrying or attempting to sell.

title: Miss Dekker, Dr. Schmelkin
description: Jacqueline Dekker, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Marcel Dekker of Greenwich, Conn., is to be married this evening to Dr. Alan Edward Schmelkin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles L. Schmelkin of Great Neck, L.I. Rabbi Morton L. Gordon is to officiate at Tappan Hill in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: Nazi Arrogance Made Stalingrad Disaster
description: To the Editor:

title: In Wilton, a 'Year of Very Hard Work'
description: LILLIAN BROWN never complained about diving into the pool at the Wilton Family Y.M.C.A. at 5:15 each morning. She never complained about hard practices, even during Christmas break. Or about the New Year's Eve she spent in the pool. She and her teammates were so tired that night that they slept at the Y, then broke out into hives the next morning. Too much chlorine.

title: Q and A
description: Israel for the Disabled

title: Residential Sales
description: In the following reports, the "listed at" price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to contract.

title: All Hail (With Grit) the Coming of Summer
description: "I LOVE the summer," said Beverly Kidd. "On weekends, it's even quiet out there." She gestured out her window at Third Avenue, noisy and angry and on this midweek afternoon as congested as the Long Island Expressway. "Weekends, I think of all the people jammed together on the L.I.E. and I feel great."

title:
If You're Thinking of Living In/Great Neck Village;
Country Living 20 Miles From Manhattan
description: COUNTRY living just 20 miles from Manhattan seems like an impossibility. But in the Village of Great Neck, where stately trees and neatly landscaped lawns flank neighborhoods of stone-and-brick homes, residents enjoy spacious, relaxed living.

title: Can Broker Play a Dual Role?
description: Q Does the law prevent a broker from acting as both a real estate broker and a mortgage broker in the same transaction? . . . Remington Kirby, Manhattan. A Keith Osber, a Binghamton, N.Y., lawyer who is chairman of the real estate section of the New York State Bar Association, said that there is no prohibition in the law against such a practice.

title: THE NATION: Past Masters; Blowing the Dust Off the Constitution That Was
description: THE Supreme Court gift shop keeps stacks of pocket-sized Constitutions by the cash registers and sells them to tourists by the thousands each year. The little booklets are 35 pages long and are, of course, completely authentic. But when the Justices meet upstairs to decide a case, the written Constitution is only one of several constitutions that are, in a manner of speaking, also on the table.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS: The Gulf War Veteran; Victorious in War, Not Yet at Peace
description: AMERICA is fickle about its wars, and how it treats the men and women who fought them.

title: Monica I. Fischer, Jay D. Rosenbaum
description: Monica Ilana Fischer, the daughter of Vibeke and Laszlo Fischer of Boca Raton, Fla., was married last Saturday to Jay Douglas Rosenbaum, a son of Meg and Roy Rosenbaum of Glen Cove, L.I. Rabbi Ronald Millstein officiated at the Sands at Lido Beach, L.I.

title: The Hardest Part: Making the Actors Sound Welsh
description: FOR ALL THOSE PEOPLE who haven't yet recovered from Kevin Costner's strangled surfer-dude-of-Sherwood-Forest accent in "Robin Hood" several years ago, the current movie season would seem to provide great prospects for merriment.

title: Talk About Friendly! Now Casper Has A Crush on a Girl
description: Die Hard With a Vengeance Bruce Willis, Samuel L. Jackson, Jeremy Irons Directed by John McTiernan R 112 minutes

title: Washington Talk; The Revolution Just Keeps Rolling
description: In their five months in control of Congress, the Republicans have lost only one big vote they expected to win, when the Senate resisted the balanced-budget amendment. Yet this city is constantly alert for signs of disarray and division, wondering if the moment of collapse is at hand.

title: Japanese Put Stability Above Competition, in Life as in Business
description: To the Editor:

title: New York's Quest For More Visitors
description: Maybe the oldest joke about New York City, Stephen J. Morello said, is the one about the guy who gets off the bus, puts down his bags, looks at the sky and shouts: "Look out, New York! I'm going to conquer you!" Then he looks down and his bags are gone.

title: Congress Has a Plan To Get Rid of the Debt
description: To the Editor:

title: THE SALAD BAZAAR
description: Salads that guests assemble themselves solve a multitude of summer entertaining problems, including how to accommodate a large crowd with idiosyncratic tastes and appetites. Since they are basically a collage whose components can be prepared hours (or even days) ahead of time, salads assure you that your party will be casual, the most successful way to operate in summer.

title: Emily W. Scott, David S. Pottruck
description: Emily W. Scott, the president of ESP and Associates, a marketing consulting firm in San Francisco, is to be married today to David S. Pottruck, the president of the Charles Schwab Corporation and its securities brokerage subsidiary, both in San Francisco. Rabbi Robert Daum is to perform the ceremony at the couple's home in Blackhawk, Calif.

title: The People's Library Turns 100
description: For the celebration at the New York Public Library, there was dining, singing and even dancing on stilts, May 20 and 22.

title: Guatemalan Ex-Dictator on Rebound
description: When he was Guatemala's head of state, his 16-month tenure was among the bloodiest in this country's violent history, with thousands killed and more than a million displaced. When he was ousted in a coup in 1983, many Guatemalans assumed that like other deposed dictators before him, he would fade quietly into obscurity.

title:
POP MUSIC;
Pop Musicians Look to the East (Again)
description: WHERE THERE IS ROCK-and-roll, religion has never been far behind. In the 1960's, the Beatles became entranced by a Hindu guru named Maharishi Mahesh Yogi. In the 1970's, Cat Stevens became a Muslim and donated most of his money to an Islamic school. In the 1980's Bob Dylan explored his Jewish heritage, and, for a while, was a born-again-style Christian. Now, in the 1990's, Tibetan Buddhism has captured the imaginations of many pop musicians.

title:
CUTTINGS;
An Old Rose Is a Rose Planted a Long Time Ago
description: It's one of the hazards of being a rosarian: five minutes into a lunch the inevitable happens, and out comes the plastic baggie spilling with petals and then the question -- do you know which rose this is?

title: Casting Calls For Towels, Toys And You-Name-It On the Stage
description: GEORGE FENMORE COULD NOT be happier. He has put a chicken on Broadway. And not just any chicken. A Tyson-Holly Farms chicken. It makes its entrance swathed in butcher paper in the second act of "Having Our Say," the new play at the Booth Theater in which at every performance two actresses playing centenarian sisters dress, stuff and slide into the oven a fresh, corn-fed roaster.

title: May 21-27; Hail to the Veep, Head and Shoulders Above the Chest
description: IT'S easier to be satirized than immortalized in Washington politics. A current greeting card tailored for the working women of this city begins, "Georgie Porgie Pudding and Pie, kissed the girls and made them cry." The punchline within reads: "Senator Porgie denies the allegations and claims all the women who have come forward to accuse him are making the whole thing up."

description: To the Editor:

title: Grilling Barbecue Experts
description: ON the cover of a mail-order catalogue stuffed in my mailbox last week was an advertisement for a "professional outdoor grill" priced at $3,295.

title: Mamaroneck Calls Housing a Success
description: WITH cedar shingles and New England-style pitched roofs and railings, Hommocks Park, a 53-unit affordable housing complex just off the Boston Post Road here, resembles any other affluent suburban cooperative or condominium development.

title: Clerical Error Clouds Future Of a Library
description: For the last two years, City Island residents have been campaigning to expand their branch of the New York Public Library. But a clerical error in the city government is threatening to halt the process.

title: Robert J. Ward, Renee J. Sokolow
description: Renee Joan Sokolow and Judge Robert Joseph Ward, both of New York, are to be married today at the Harmonie Club in New York. Rabbi Irving J. Block is to officiate.

title: Chinese Food War Overheats
description: After toiling for years in other people's restaurants, Patrick Chan struck out on his own and eventually opened two Chinese restaurants. Last November, he and his family decided to open a third one in a shopping center off the Whitestone Expressway.

title: Debra Reiter, Gerson Panitch
description: Debra Ellen Reiter, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Stanley F. Reiter of New Haven, is to be married in New York today to Gerson Seth Panitch, a son of Rabbi and Mrs. Herbert Panitch of Milwaukee. Rabbi Albert Feldman is to officiate and the bridegroom's father is to take part in the ceremony at the Pierre.

title: What's Still Very Wrong With the Meadowlands
description: To the Editor:

title: Venice
description: Every other summer, Venice is host to the four-month-long Biennale, a sprawling multinational exhibition of contemporary art that has come to define the high season in a city that needs no excuse for a visit in any season. Most art critics agree that the Biennale stopped being a significant artistic event some time ago. But that hasn't stopped it from being an event pure and simple, a fixed moment on the international art calendar, and a draw for artists, tourists and, yes, critics who come every two years to see what's out there in contemporary art and to see it in Venice, one of the most beautiful cities in the world.

title: How To Make $34 Million In a Year
description: John W. Sidgmore is a winner in this year's hottest game on Wall Street, the high-tech I.P.O. fad.

title: Politics, North Bergen-Style, Through the Eyes of a Gadfly
description: In North Bergen, a gritty Hudson County township of 48,400 people, politics is a blood sport, dominated by deep, interconnected feuds that go back decades. For 25 years, Herbert H. Shaw, a resident who is a maintenance worker for the Newark Public Library, has watched it from a singular perspective, partly inside the action and partly outside: he's a gadfly.

title: Who Will Organize Next Year's Parade?
description: TOWNS and cities across Connecticut are observing Memorial Day this weekend with parades down their main streets.

title: Focused Featherweight Rises Above Adversity
description: The run of bad luck began even before he could walk or talk.

title: Molly McBride, Thomas Desperito
description: Dr. Molly McBride, the daughter of Susan and J. Stephen McBride of Wilmington, Del., is to be married today to Thomas Joseph Desperito, the son of Paula and Ernest Desperito of Bedford, N.Y. Lieut. Col. Owen J. Mullen, a Roman Catholic chaplain of the United States Military Academy at West Point, of which the bridegroom is a graduate, is to perform the ceremony. It will be at St. Patrick's Church in Philadelphia.

title: Cornwall
description: To the Editor: The article on Corwall brought back many happy memories of weeks of walking the South West Way, of which your author's four days covered possibly one of the most popular and hence perhaps more crowded sections in the summer tourist season.

title: Artful Bond of Yonkers and Italian Town
description: MONTICHIARI, Italy, a city of 17,000 people near Milan, is notable for its open-air market, a 12th-century Romanesque church and a restored 15th-century castle. Except for its hills and proximity to a major city, Montichiari would seem to have little in common with Yonkers, a city of nearly 200,000 beset by all the urban turmoil of the late 20th century.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Times Magazine on May 7 about Herbert DeGreve, a con man who passed himself off as a Japanese-language translator in a World War II Marine unit, misstated part of the combat record of his commander, Col. Victor F. Bleasdale. In World War I, Colonel Bleasdale, then a captain, won the Navy Cross, the Army Distinguished Service Cross, the Silver Star and the Croix de Guerre. He did not win the Medal of Honor.

title: David Joseph and Kathie-Ann Ramsay
description: Dr. Kathie-Ann Ramsay, a daughter of Royes Ramsay of Brooklyn and the late Thelma Ramsay, was married yesterday to Dr. David Joseph, the son of Myrtle and Denis Joseph, also of Brooklyn. The Rev. Dr. David Adamovich, a Unitarian Church of God minister, officiated at Coral House, a catering establishment in Baldwin, L.I.

description: To the Editor:

title: Duran Duran, Hungry Like the Wolf Again
description: WHEN you're Duran Duran and you've just released an album that all the critics hate and the money isn't what it used to be when you were MTV stars in the 1980's, you do things that you'd rather not.

title: F.Y.I.
description: Tribe of Democrats Q. On the Upper East Side, there's a tiny street called Cherokee Place, just east of York Avenue. What's the story of its name? Indians? Jeeps? A. How about politicos?
