description: TIME LINE FOR State Dinner" is the title on the fax transmittal cover sheet from the Office of the First Lady. (You did not know there was such an office? You thought it was still the East Wing? Regards to Rip Van Winkle.)

description: NOBODY gives us any money! We've been sitting here bleeding to death!"

title: Illustrations of the Body Depict the Rare and the Marvelous
description: ONE definition of a sleeper is something valuable whose worth has been kept under wraps. By that standard "The Fabric of the Body: French 18th-Century Anatomical Illustrations" at the Neuberger Museum of Art on the Purchase College campus here is a genuine sleeper. But after negotiating the hurdles put in the show's way, a viewer realizes he has happened upon something rare and marvelous.

title: Next Week in Trenton: Government Day by Day
description: MONDAY Governor Whitman will honor the state's veterans, traveling to Mountain Lakes for a parade and ceremony at 10:30 A.M. and then going on to Boonton at 11:45 for an observance there.

description: THE SPREAD OF NUCLEAR WEAPONS A Debate. By Scott D. Sagan and Kenneth N. Waltz. 160 pp. New York: W.W. Norton & Company. $16.95. title: Patricia Durkin and Kenneth Wignall
description: PATRICIA ANN DURKIN, 40, is the director of advertising for Tommy Hilfiger, the men's sportswear company whose advertisements are filled with guys wearing jeans rolled up at the cuffs, seersucker shorts with loafers and no socks, and khakis with dreadlocks. They look like the laid-back, rugby-playing brothers of the Ralph Lauren models.

title: Journal; Breach of Faith
description: In this fractious time, it's hard to fathom what extraordinary political cause could unite leaders of religious denominations as various as Baptists, Episcopalians, Roman Catholics, Methodists, Quakers, Seventh-day Adventists, Lutherans, Muslims and Jews. But such is the stark secular agenda promoted by Pat Robertson and Ralph Reed that people of faith, all faiths, have started mobilizing against the Christian Coalition in the 10 days since it handed down its "Contract With the American Family" to genuflecting Republican leaders on Capitol Hill.

title: In Milford, Building A Memorial Coin by Coin
description: SIGISMUND SKIBEK spends part of each day in front of grocery stores, department stores, a small table in front of him, a tin can at its center, asking people to drop in their spare change. He sat outside through the fall, during the winter, as the forsythia came out; he's still there and plans to continue even as summer temperatures may threaten to wilt him.

title: Duck!
description: TELL SOMEONE THAT PLANET Earth needs a missile defense system against asteroids and they may laugh a little nervously or wonder what militia you belong to. But raise the question with astronomers or planetary geologists and they are likely to differ only on whether a defense should be built right now or sometime over the next several decades.

title: Tennis in Central Park: It's No Jungle Out There
description: To the Editor:

title: Correction
description: An article on May 14 about Jerome Robbins's "West Side Story Suite" misstated the names of two New York City Ballet dancers. The role of Anita will be danced by Nancy Ticotin, and the role of Bernardo by Jock Soto. The article also rendered a character name incorrectly. Nikolaj Hubbe plays Riff, not Biff.

title: POSTINGS: New $16 Million Pavilion for Hebrew Home for the Aged; Linking Elderly to Services and Independence
description: The new four-story Link Pavilion to be built at the Hebrew Home for the Aged in the Riverdale section of the Bronx is aptly named. Physically, it will link the home's Resnick and Stolz Pavilions and bring residents closer to essential services. Emotionally, it will link residents to more independence.

title: The Right Attitude and the Right Stuff
description: ONCE, the hardest part of working at home was convincing clients and office-bound colleagues that you didn't rise at noon, stagger to the computer in your Snoopy bathrobe and work with one eye on your Lotus files and the other on reruns of "The Rockford Files." The upside of the lingering economic downturn is that the ranks of home workers are growing and that they are no longer stigmatized.

title:
HOME CLINIC;
How to Wash Windows So They Become Clear
description: PERHAPS the most tedious and frustrating part of spring cleaning is window cleaning. The average person attacks a dirty window with a roll of paper towels in one hand and a spray bottle of commercial glass cleaner in the other.

title: MARKET TIMING
description: Monday Memorial Day holiday. Banks and exchanges are closed in the United States. They are also closed in Britain for the spring bank holiday. Tuesday The Conference Board index of consumer confidence for May is released today, one of several economic indicators scheduled this week that are expected to show a slowing economy. Forecast: the perception of gloomier business conditions is expected to weaken the index to 102.3, down from 105.5 in April. Richard A. Grasso becomes the new chairman and chief executive of the New York Stock Exchange, succeeding William H. Donaldson. Wednesday The Commerce Department announces new home sales for April. Forecast: a 1.2 percent rise, to 584,000 homes. The second estimate of gross domestic product is expected. Forecast: 3.1 percent growth, up from 2.8 percent announced last month. Thursday The National Association of Purchasing Managers releases its May indices. Forecast: 50.4 down from 52 in April, indicating a further slowdown in manufacturing. The Commerce Department reports personal income and spending for April. Forecast: income up 0.3 percent and spending unchanged from March. Factory orders for April are to be released. Forecast: down 0.1 percent, after falling 0.1 percent in March and 0.3 percent in February. Friday The Labor Department releases May unemployment numbers. Forecast: 5.7 percent, with 193,000 jobs added to the nonfarm payroll. The Commerce Department announces leading economic indicators for April. Forecast: down 0.4 percent. This would be the third monthly decline in a row, which in the past has often signaled recessions. April construction spending is scheduled. Forecast: down 0.4 percent.

title: Topics of The Times; Nurturing the Bluebird

In Thoreau's time, bluebirds may have been as common as robins are today, but their numbers peaked in the early 1900's and then went into a long decline. Now bluebirds are coming back, thanks largely to the efforts of bird lovers.

The beauty of this tree and the chestnuts are fond memories to those of us who are elder citizens, but the tree has long been considered extinct, due to a disease that could not be controlled at the time.

The string he was clutching made it look as if he were actually spinning a web. It rose to the top of the fence, slipped down through the bare branches of the tree, dipped and ascended again, and finally halted where the kite had become ensnared in the fire escape of an adjoining building.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: THE HOMELESS By Christopher Jencks. Harvard University, $10. Liberals and conservatives tend to blame each other's policies for increasing the number of Americans who live on the street. This analysis of numerous studies shows that each political group is partly right. " 'The Homeless' is undoubtedly a major achievement," Brigitte Berger said here last year. A DANCE TO THE MUSIC OF TIME By Anthony Powell. University of Chicago. Originally published as 12 separate novels depicting the unraveling of English society between the wars, this cycle has been reissued in four volumes (titled "movements") of three books each: "A Question of Upbringing," "A Buyer's Market" and "The Acceptance World" ($17.95); "At Lady Molly's," "Casanova's Chinese Restaurant" and "The Kindly Ones" ($17.95); "The Valley of Bones," "The Soldier's Art" and "The Military Philosophers" ($17.95); and "Books Do Furnish a Room," "Temporary Kings" and "Hearing Secret Harmonies" ($18.95). The narrator, Nicholas Jenkins, begins his long history, which partly reflects the life of the author, at Eton in 1921. By the end of the first trilogy, Nick and his school fellows are witnessing the Depression and approaching their 30's with little sense of resolve. In 1956 Aileen Pippett, reviewing "The Acceptance World" for The New York Times, called Anthony Powell "a comic artist who knows exactly what he is doing." In the second volume, a flashback to Nick's childhood at the brink of World War I is juxtaposed with an England steadily advancing toward World War II. "Reading Powell is like living someone else's life for an hour or two, inextricably tangled with one's own," Elizabeth Janeway said here in 1962 in a review of "The Kindly Ones." The third volume ends with the Allied victory and more rearrangements in the central characters' lives. Writing in these pages in 1969, Ms. Janeway said Mr. Powell's fiction "carries such human truth that one finds oneself feeling these folk must be real." By the end of the series, Nick has become a writer and both he and the century are in their late 60's. In 1976 our reviewer of "Hearing Secret Harmonies," Robert Towers, said Mr. Powell "ranks with the radically different Doris Lessing . . . as the best of the novelists now writing British fiction." MY OWN COUNTRY: A Doctor's Story By Abraham Verghese. Vintage, $13. In 1985 an Indian physician returns to the rural community of Johnson City, Tenn., where he had completed his residency. Feeling like an outsider himself, he begins to treat the ultimate outsiders: AIDS patients. Abraham Verghese's chronicle of his own arrival and that of the disease is "beautifully written, fascinating and tragic," Perri Klass said here last year. THE RUSSIAN GIRL By Kingsley Amis. Penguin, $10.95. Richard Vaisey, a married scholar of Slavic literature living in London, has an imprudent affair with an emigre Russian poet whose verse is far less appealing than she is. In 1994 our reviewer, Christopher Buckley, found this novel "brilliant, mordant and quite funny." STORIES OF SCOTTSBORO By James Goodman. Vintage, $14. In 1931 nine black men were accused of raping two white women on an Alabama freight train. Despite a lack of evidence, two Supreme Court decisions and one woman's admission that she lied, the young men were repeatedly tried and convicted. This book is "a superb retelling of this vital but largely forgotten episode," David M. Oshinsky said here last year. DI AND I By Peter Lefcourt. Harper Perennial, $12. Those who think Princess Diana is out of place in Britain's royal family might enjoy seeing her cast as an American manquee. In this novel she finds true happiness in the world of McDonald's and miniature golf with a lover who writes for television. In 1994 our reviewer, Janet Maslin, praised "Mr. Lefcourt's bright conversational style and his expert comic timing." THE LATE SHIFT: Letterman, Leno, and the Network Battle for the Night By Bill Carter. Hyperion, $12.95. The author, who reports on television for The New York Times, takes the reader behind the scenes at NBC and CBS as they debate the futures of David Letterman, Jay Leno and late-night entertainment. The result is "unfailingly balanced" and "filled with scoops and fresh details," Jon Katz said in the Book Review last year. APOSTLES OF LIGHT By Ellen Douglas. Banner/University Press of Mississippi, $16.95. Martha Clarke and Lucas Alexander are friends and lovers who happen to be in their 70's. Now back in print, this novel chronicles their attempt to free themselves from the grip of younger relatives who have turned Martha's house into a nursing home and their lives into a prison. The author "achieves a revelation that is brilliant and disturbing," Martin Levin said here in 1973. THE FORCE By David Dorsey. Ballantine, $12.50 This book's title takes on many meanings as the author reveals the inner workings of the Xerox Corporation's Cleveland office. While salesmen bully customers in order to fill quotas, egos and spirits on both sides are broken. Last year our reviewer, Steven Levy, said Mr. Dorsey was "imaginative and energetic . . . and some of his portraits are unforgettable." Another business culture is examined in JUST DO IT: The Nike Spirit in the Corporate World, by Donald Katz (Adams, $10.95). Here the scene is Beaverton, Ore., where sneakers, deals and an entire life style are manufactured by a company named for the Greek goddess of victory. Mr. Katz "lets us know that this was a totally appropriate name," George Vecsey said here in 1994. LAUREL GRAEBER

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: There are very few swinging doors in Tokyo. In TOKYO STYLE (Kyoto Shoin/RAM Publications, 2525 Michigan Avenue A-2, Santa Monica, Calif. 90404, $150), his loving photographic tribute to Japan's middle class, Kyoichi Tsuzuki shows us why. Most doors in Tokyo slide sideways; there is simply no room for an entryway that opens out. Mr. Tsuzuki's Tokyo is a town where the citizens live in such ordered clutter that one must keep one's fingernails short in order to enjoy some extra space. Mr. Tsuzuki spent two years documenting how people live in Tokyo's congested jumble of apartments, condominiums and (occasionally) single-family dwellings. Living in tiny quarters surrounded by all of your possessions is called the "cockpit effect." One of Mr. Tsuzuki's aims is to shatter old myths about Japan, and he succeeds. This is no world of peaceful Zenlike tranquillity. This is a world of stuff -- compact disks, comic books, computers and James Dean posters. And it's mostly American-inspired stuff; examples of traditional Japanese art are almost nowhere in evidence. "Tokyo Style" is an important photographic record of a way of life, but it's almost 400 pages of clutter, and ultimately, for an American, it's like viewing life lived in an M.R.I. machine. Mr. Tsuzuki predicts that the "art of living well in small quarters might just prove the style of the future." Not in the United States. Expansion, not contraction, is in our blood. We are the children of pioneers, and our doors swing wide open.DAVID MCDONOUGH

title: Grassy Dunes, Beach Tags And a Special Pink Shell
description: The year: 1956. Our young family, New Yorkers newly arrived in New Jersey, swelters in an apartment in Palisades Park. We decide it is time to discover the Jersey Shore. A local suggests Jenkinson's in a town whose name is lost to history. My first annoyance is paying to park near Jenkinson's, but I hand over the bills. Then to the boardwalk with wife, two small children, where a bronzed fellow stops me. "Gotta have a badge to get on the beach," he says. "Two dollars." "Are you kidding? That is my ocean," I say, sweat forming, dander rising. "Gotta have a badge," he insists. Kids crying. Wife upset. Long line of badge-holders getting restive. I am tempted to shout, "We're going home," but the vision of the long trek home in an uncooled Nash rises up. I buy the badges for the first (and last) time. I subsequently discover the best-kept secret in the Garden State: Island Beach State Park. I have outlived admission prices (senior citizens get in free). I still think it is my ocean. GENE MURPHY Bayville

description: There are eight million animals in the naked city. Or so it seems -- mountain lions in L.A., coyotes in the Bronx. At the Animal Damage Control Program, Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service, Department of Agriculture in Washington, they've seen it all. From their files, here's the story on what creatures are where:

title: Ulster County
description: To the Editor: Somehow your article "Ulster County's Young Crop" (April 16) neglected the best restaurant in Woodstock, in my opinion and that of my friends -- the Blue Mountain Bistro. In the restaurant's second year, the chef-owner, Richard Ericson, formerly of Bistro du Nord in New York, serves wonderful food. My favorites: salmon in parchment with julienne vegetables and savory Moroccan bisteeya with almonds and currants. Salads are from the organic garden of Richard's wife, Mary Anne, who is also the charming hostess. She bottles their special homemade vinegars (raspberry, blueberry) and arranges the flowers.

title: Nations With Peacekeepers in Bosnia Stand Firm
description: Several countries with troops in the United Nations mission in Bosnia resolved here today to stand firm against "blackmail" by the Serbs, but they clearly differed on whether NATO should mount more of the air strikes that led the Serbs to take peacekeepers hostage this week.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: FREE CHOICES

title: Tour de Sol Has Come to This: Buses, Bikes and Composite Cars
description: THE Tour de Sol has always been a showcase for electric cars, but the seventh annual running of the race, which ended yesterday, was a magnet for everything from electric scooters to an electric bus. Another remarkable vehicle was an electric sedan with an all-composite body.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: HOLLYWOOD Mecca of the Movies. By Blaise Cendrars. University of California, $30.

title: Guiltless Lunches: How to Say When
description: YOU'RE one meal away from sealing a deal with a crucial client, and you have to impress him at a fine restaurant. Or you're wooing a potential business partner over dinner. Or, at a midweek lunch, you're celebrating a protege's promotion.

title: Reason for Hope
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: New Orleans Casino Gets Its Feet Wet
description: Only a week after its grand opening, the first land-based casino in New Orleans almost joined the ranks of the floating casinos that have been plying the waters around the city for more than a year.

title: From Yankee Stadium To a Rooftop Garden
description: Cheryl Howard made her singing debut 14 years ago. She was in college, and sang the national anthem at Yankee Stadium, where her late father, Elston Howard, had been a famed catcher for the Yankees. Since then, she has performed the title role in a European stage production about Josephine Baker, called "Josephine," and has been in several Off Broadway shows.

title: No Headline
description: "To try to talk to the young people who will run the future of our society -- in 10 minutes -- is a little like trying to put a cantaloupe in a Coke bottle." -- QUINCY JONES, on commencement speeches. [ 8:4. ]

title: Topics of The Times; Fresh-Air Dining in New York
description: The howling against the city's new smoking restrictions was especially hearty from restaurateurs and those diners who believe that cigarettes complement cuisine. But in a remarkably brief time, the shouts have died to a whisper and the air in New York's restaurants is, if not exactly Edenic, a lot fresher than it used to be.

title: U.S. Backs French on Moving Peacekeepers
description: The Clinton Administration is prepared to support a French plan to move United Nations troops in the former Yugoslavia into more secure defensive positions, while pressing to preserve the option of further air strikes against the Bosnian Serbs, senior Administration officials said today.

title: U.S. FINDS ITSELF VIRTUALLY ALONE ON JAPAN TRADE
description: Japanese trade officials have spread through Asia in recent days, warning government officials that their booming economies will be the next targets if Japan is forced by the United States to set aside a certain portion of its market for American goods.

title: When Alcohol and Silence Mix
description: At the turn of the century -- at perhaps the nadir of the New York Police Department's struggles with alcohol -- Police Chief William S. Devery did much of his work from "the Pump," a saloon at Eighth Avenue and West 28th Street in the Tenderloin of Manhattan.

title: The Dishes Are Coming: Satellites Go Suburban
description: Walter Allen Jr. and his adult son, Walter 3d, are the sort of television viewers who ought to give cable television executives the willies.

title: For This Year's Graduates: Pomp, Circumstance and a Little Rock-and-Roll
description: First Michael Bolton received an honorary degree from the University of Connecticut. Then Barbra Streisand collected one from Brandeis University. Neil Diamond got one from New York University -- the very school he dropped out of 35 years ago.

title: Halifax Journal; Uprooted, and Now Withered by Public Housing
description: The pavement stopped where Africville began, and the tiny waterside community of freed slaves' descendants had neither running water nor streetlights.

title: Is Anyone Investigating Senator Daschle?
description: The Senate Ethics Committee has been asked to investigate whether Senator Tom Daschle improperly helped a friend in trouble with air safety inspectors. The Transportation Department's inspector general has been urged to look into a related charge against the Federal Aviation Administration. Three months have passed. The committee has not decided what to do and the inspector general's delay is unexplained. It is high time both of them showed some sign of a pulse.

title: To Promote Peace, Move the Embassy
description: There is something more than Presidential politics behind the bills in Congress to relocate the United States Embassy in Israel from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem. It is sensible policy.

title: Bridge
description: The Greenpoint Pairs, played Friday in Manhattan at the start of the Greater New York Bridge Association's Eastern Regional Championships, provided one of the most notable triumphs for a pair of women in the city's history. Margie Gwozdzinsky of Manhattan, who won a world title six years ago, and Joan Dziekanski, the proprietor of the busy Beverly Club at 130 East 57th Street, outdistanced a star-studded field and won the first prize of $2,700.

title: Britain Weighs Rules That Would Rein In Murdoch
description: The document issued by the British Government last week revising the rules for control of newspapers, television and radio was given a dutiful bureaucratic title: "Media Ownership: The Government's Proposals." It might as well have been titled "What to Do About Rupert."

title: Reward Offered for Murder Tip
description: To many people, the Memorial Day weekend means the start of summer. To Kent Negersmith of Carmel, N.Y., it is a cruel reminder of the death of his daughter, Susan. On the holiday weekend five years ago, his 20-year-old daughter was found dead behind a restaurant garbage bin in Wildwood, where she had been on a beach trip with friends. At first, the death was attributed to alcohol poisoning. But after pressure from the family, further examination was done, and she was found to have been raped and smothered. Now, Mr. Negersmith has offered $25,000 to anyone, except police officers and their relatives, who provides information leading to the conviction of his daughter's killer.

title: Not Just Memories
description: A respectful ceremony is being held here today at the National Memorial that was the battleship Arizona.

title: Olajuwon Eyeing U.S. Uniform
description: Houston Rockets center HAKEEM OLAJUWON will probably represent the United States in the 1996 Olympic Games, according to yesterday's editions of The Houston Chronicle. The Chronicle quoted unidentified National Basketball Association and international sources as saying an agreement with FIBA, international basketball's governing body, is "98 percent done."

title: Abroad at Home; . . . Or Karadzic Dead
description: By taking United Nations peacekeepers hostage and using them as human shields, Dr. Radovan Karadzic and the other Bosnian Serb leaders have defined themselves as outside law and civilization. But then that should not have been a surprise to anyone who knew their works.

title: Art, Money and N.Y., N.Y.
description: New York, its critics say, is too crowded, too noisy, too much. True. But those of us who live here can make a claim about our difficult -- no, exasperating -- city no other Americans can make about theirs. Even at its bitterest and bleakest, New York has a buzz -- a buzz that emerges from having more museums, more galleries, more dance groups and more concerts than any other city in the country.

title: Sports of the Times; Brodeur Is So Hot And Yet He's So Cool
description: BEHIND his red and black Devils mask, Martin Brodeur's reactions are like a perfectly cooked rare steak -- hot to the touch outside, cool inside.

title: U.S. to Seek Stronger Trade and Political Ties With Europe
description: The Clinton Administration will announce a major effort this week to strengthen ties with Europe, a move that would start with more cooperation on helping poor nations and removing trade barriers and could ultimately lead to a free trade area encompassing North America and Europe.

title: World News Briefs; Chinese Cancel Talks On Weapons Questions
description: In the latest reprisal for President Clinton's decision to allow Taiwan's President to visit the United States, China today canceled its talks with Washington on nuclear energy and on the control of ballistic missile technology.

title: In the Hamptons, the Gridlock Season Begins
description: Twelve hours before this year's bistros-of-the-moment served their first calamari appetizers, in fact well before many of their clients had even lifted an eyelid, Danny King was on the bay, straining under nets laden with just plain squid.

title: Foreign Policy Is Congressional Territory
description: To the Editor:

title: Citadeed Storms Past Peter Pan Favorites
description: The big horses, Thunder Gulch and Timber Country, were back in the barn at Churchill Downs yesterday resting and reading their press clippings after winning the Kentucky Derby and the Preakness. But a new factor was placed in their path toward completing a sweep of the Triple Crown for the trainer D. Wayne Lukas when Citadeed scored an upset victory in the Peter Pan Stakes at Belmont Park.

title: Flat Monitors' Bargain Prices Are Hampering U.S. Producers
description: Looking past today's dominant flat-panel video technology in hopes of catching the next big wave, small American manufacturers had hoped to produce big display screens better than anything now available for portable computers -- even large enough and thin enough to fit television sets that could hang on the wall like framed pictures.

title: Clemens Does Well in Pawtucket
description: ROGER CLEMENS allowed one hit over five innings and struck out five last night for Class AAA Pawtucket in his final rehabilitation start before he joins the Boston Red Sox rotation for the first time this season. The three-time Cy Young Award winner, who strained a muscle in his right shoulder during spring training, threw 81 pitches -- 46 for strikes -- and hit 95 miles an hour with his fastball as the Pawtucket Red Sox beat the Syracuse Chiefs, 4-3.

title: Techology; ON THE NET
description: A NEW demographic survey of the Internet has confirmed that the global computer network is predominantly a men's club, with male users outnumbering female users by a ratio of nearly 2 to 1. But the new numbers are considered surprising, because earlier and less rigorous surveys had put the margin closer to 9 to 1.

title: Preserving History, and the Trees
description: The state is restoring Battlefield State Park to the way it was on June 28, 1778, when the Continental Army won a resounding victory at the Battle of Monmouth. Trouble is, the battlefield area did not have trees then, and it does now. About 120 acres have been cut down -- the work is only half done -- and many local residents do not like the idea at all. They say they miss the trees that used to line Route 522, and they complain that deer have been routed from their habitat. About 1,200 new trees and shrubs are to be planted in other areas of the park before next spring, state officials says.

title: Bigger Means Better
description: To the Editor:

title: Angel Fire Journal; From One Man's Loss, Comfort for Thousands
description: Dwight Perry has scarcely slept through the night since the Vietnam War. Last week he wasn't sleeping at all. So he left his Albuquerque home at 5 A.M. on Friday and drove three hours north to visit a white chapel surrounded by mountains and talk to an old man who understood his pain.

title: Hard Work, and a Lot More
description: For some graduates, commencement was an unusually long -- or short -- labor of love. Jayme Cantu Colorado School of Mines, Golden

title: Death Penalty Popular in Japan, but Rare Recently
description: Mitsuo Fujishima is a charming 37-year-old who seems to have strong views about only one political subject: capital punishment.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: A Composer From Siberia Finds an Angel in the U.S. Russian Chamber Chorus of New York Church of the Good Shepherd

title: Sports of The Times; Giants Have Power Punch For the Ages
description: SEE, the trouble with baseball is there aren't any stars anymore. All the kids are out in the schoolyard practicing their walking and their palming so they can be like Mike. The other day in my town I saw at least 50 kids practicing for a roller hockey league. Roller hockey. Fifty of them.

title: Youth Is Shot, And New Case Hits Paterson
description: A youth posturing for friends with a relatively harmless air pistol that looked like a .45-caliber semiautomatic was shot in the head and critically wounded on a salsa-thumping, teen-age corner hangout in Paterson, N.J., early Saturday by a police officer responding to a report of a man with a gun.

title: Before the Formalities, Some Final Frivolities
description: Many colleges across the nation cling to quirky commencement traditions whose roots are sometimes as puzzling as the practices themselves. Wasting Time?

title: Shift at Nuclear Plant
description: Federal inspectors and a range of employees at the troubled Indian Point 3 nuclear plant in Buchanan, N.Y., contend that vastly improved procedures and work habits are in place at the plant. Whether that equates with safe, reliable and profitable operation remains to be seen.

title: Monk Gives Up on Restaurant Project
description: In the last year, Brother Denys Cormier and his restaurant, the Wandering Monk's Guild and Bakery, became something of a landmark here.

title: INSIDE
description: Officer Shoots Teen-Ager

title: 'Marshal,' Renewed, Is Repeated
description: "The Marshal" is joining a select group of television series. The ABC show, which began with a "preview" in late January, is one of the few that have been renewed for next season. Furthermore, although its ratings were hardly sensational, "The Marshall" is going into the strong 8 P.M. time slot just before "Monday Night Football." Meanwhile, the original run is being repeated on Mondays, beginning tonight.

title: How to Read the Constitution on Term Limits; State Variations
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: U.S. Is Isolated, Both East and West

title: 2 Films on Strife in Balkans Win Top Prizes at Cannes
description: "Underground," Emir Kusturica's earthy, boisterous, powerfully metaphorical film about the fate of his native Yugoslavia, was awarded top honors at this year's Cannes International Film Festival. Ten years ago, Mr. Kusturica was in Sarajevo when he won a Palme d'Or for "When Father Was Away on Business." But this time he was here to accept his prize for a film that was received with widespread enthusiasm when it was shown on Friday. It was easily the most affecting, far-reaching film shown here this year.

title: Rummage Sale of Land: One Way G.O.P. Will Try to Balance the Budget?
description: The Republican budget proposals moving through Congress include a subtle change in accounting rules that for the first time in a decade would invite Congressional committees to pay for their spending by selling land and other publicly owned assets.

title: The Information Industries
description: Business Day's new Monday report on the information industries focuses today on Direct Boradcast Satellite, a technology that is taking rural habits of satellite television to urban America. The section also reports on the digital special effects featured in the new movie "Casper."

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about the securities legislation being prepared by the Senate Banking Committee misspelled the surname of the committee's counsel in some copies. He is Robert J. Giuffra Jr., not Gifra.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about criticisms that a single law firm has influenced the Delaware judicial system misstated the corporate position of James H. Gilliam Jr., chairman of the Delaware Governor's judicial nominating commission. He is executive vice president and general counsel of the Beneficial Corporation, not the company's chairman.

title: Plan for Private Police Force Sets Off Alarms on Upper East Side
description: LEAVE it to New York. One of the city's richest, most elegant neighborhoods comes up with the brash and unprecedented idea of hiring a private security force. And who shoots down the idea but leaders of the same neighborhood.

title: An Acid Test on Red Clay in Paris
description: Some like it fast, some like it slow, and some don't like it all. This is May in Paris, French Open time, and that means the yearly debate over what it takes to tame the immaculate acreage of brick-red clay at Roland Garros is raging.

title: Corrections
description: The Digital Commerce column in Business Day last Monday, about several new CD-ROM titles, misstated the ownership of the software programming code used to create one such title, "Johnny Mnemonic." The code is owned by Cineactive L.L.C., a subsidiary of Propaganda Films Inc., and by the individuals who wrote the software; it is not partly owned by the Sony Corporation. Sony licensed the programming code from Cineactive.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: Conquering Complexity With a Virtuoso Flair Gabor Fuchs, pianist Weill Recital Hall

title: Rollins Quits Campaign Over 'Hymie' Joke
description: Edward J. Rollins Jr., the Republican political consultant, has resigned as an unpaid adviser to Senator Bob Dole's Presidential campaign after referring to two Jewish Congressmen as "Hymie boys."

title: Colombians Mourn Fallen Hero
description: Thousands of mourners crowded into a cemetery in Barranquilla, Colombia, yesterday to say farewell to the boxer Jimmy Garcia, who died May 19 from injuries sustained in a fight for the World Boxing Council superfeatherweight title.

title: Six Injured When Fire Truck Collides With Car
description: Six people were injured yesterday when a fire truck responding to a false alarm in the Fort Greene section of Brooklyn struck their car, officials said.

title: Publishers Wince as 1920's Classics Go Public
description: For the original publishers of Fitzgerald, Hemingway, Joyce and their contemporaries, the next few years are likely to be depressing, as they lose exclusive control over the classic literature of the 1920's.

title: Mayor Calls Ranking Unfair
description: Mayor Sharpe James says an F.B.I. ranking of Newark as the nation's most violent city is undeserved. The city reported 96 murders, 207 rapes, 5,775 robberies and 4,331 aggravated assaults to the F.B.I. last year for a total of 10,409 violent crimes, up nearly 200 from 1993. The F.B.I. calculated that Newark had more than 38 violent crimes for every 1,000 residents. But the Mayor said Newark has 325,000 residents, not the 271,025 the U.S. Census Bureau counted. The larger population figure would bring the number of violent crimes down to 32 for every 1,000 residents, which would still put Newark in the top five in the nation.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: IN THE HAMPTONS, THE GRIDLOCK SEASON Memorial Day weekend marks summer moving to full throttle in the Hamptons, the annual onslaught of the chic, both welcomed and dreaded by the locals. The transformation from ordinary to constantly crowded and vaguely exotic makes the natives feel like strangers in their own land, even though it is almost the sole support of their economy. Each summer they feel a little more besieged in this string of quaint, highly groomed villages that thrive on the annual tide of summer trade, a tide that never recedes as far as the year before. It has been years since those rooted on eastern Long Island got a September break from the crowds. Faxes, computers and multimillion-dollar houses have made the Hamptons a virtual extension of Manhattan. A state study estimated that $10 billion has been invested in second homes, and there is no great urge to shutter them come Labor Day. [ Page 1. ] NEW YORK CITY

title: Milking the Mustache: A Contest
description: A milk-mustache contest at the State House? Why not, since June is National Dairy Month. The contest will be sponsored (and free samples of milk will be given away) on Thursday by the New Jersey Milk Association. The association was formed in 1948 by 120 dairies; now there are 11. While producers are fewer, the association says, a cow today produces 16,708 pounds of milk annually, almost 7,000 pounds more than in 1970.

title: CHRONICLE
description: It has become much easier in recent years to be conscientous about recycling. Just ask BLYTHE DANNER, the actress who is starring in the Manhattan Theater Club production of "Sylvia."

title: The issue is not the future of Connie Chung, but the future of evening newscasts as we know them.
description: BEYOND the overheated debate last week about whether Connie Chung has a future now that CBS has dropped her from its nightly newscast is a larger question likely to be asked more and more frequently in the coming months: Is there a future for anybody on the networks' nightly newscasts?

title: Patents
description: MORE than 10 years ago, George A. Eby, a city planner turned self-educated pharmacologist, made headlines with a study showing that zinc lozenges could cut down the average length of a cold to about 4 days from nearly 11.

title: Balanchine's 'Serenade' Continues Revealing New Layers to Examine
description: The eternal beauties of George Balanchine's "Serenade" returned to the New York State Theater on Friday night for the first time this season. One of the great virtues of a repertory company, as the New York City Ballet proves so consistently, is the opportunity provided to dig deeper into a classic each time it reappears onstage.

title: 2-Edged Sword: Asian Regimes On the Internet
description: Tran Ba Thai sits among tangles of computer wire in his dingy Hanoi office, hoping that he can continue to connect this long-isolated nation to the distant reaches of cyberspace.

title:
OUTDOORS;
Celebrating Fly-Fishing Tradition in Catskills
description: On a balmy day recently when the shad bushes were in full bloom, Joan Wulff and Lisa Lyons were fly-fishing on the Delaware River just south of Hancock, N.Y. Both women stood waist-deep in the cold water, about 30 feet apart. Hungry trout were pouncing on emerging caddis flies in the main current in front of them.

title: Harvard Student Stabs Roommate to Death
description: Students at a Harvard University dormitory awoke to screams, sirens and a blood-splattered courtyard today after a 20-year-old pre-med student stabbed her roommate to death, wounded an overnight guest and then barricaded herself in a bathroom where she hanged herself.

title: How to Read the Constitution on Term Limits
description: To the Editor:

title: School Safety Officer Charged in Queens Rape
description: A New York City school safety officer was charged with rape and assault in an early-morning attack yesterday on a 28-year-old woman in Hollis, Queens, the police said.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: WOMEN'S GOLF Mochrie's Big Payday

title: Fertility Clinic Told to Close Amid Complaints
description: One of the nation's leading fertility clinics has been ordered to close this week after its sponsor, the University of California, accused its doctors of playing God with their patients, transplanting their eggs and embryos and conducting research on them without their knowledge or consent.

title: Japanese Face Glut Of Computer Screens
description: Japan's ability to manufacture sophisticated small computer screens, one of the few bright spots for the country's electronics industry, is becoming a victim of its own success. With far more screens becoming available than computer manufacturers need, prices for notebook computers are dropping, dragging the screen makers' profits down with them.

title: Portrait of Whitman as a Product of His Times
description: WALT WHITMAN'S AMERICA A Cultural Biography By David S. Reynolds Illustrated. 671 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $35.

title: Troops Infected With H.I.V. Facing Unexpected Fear of Losing Their Jobs
description: Ever since learning in 1988 that he had been infected with the AIDS virus, a 31-year-old petty officer based in Southern California has comforted himself that he would be taken care of, because the Navy always takes care of its own.

title: FRANCE DEMANDS REINFORCEMENTS
description: Prime Minister Alain Juppe said tonight that France would press for withdrawal of the United Nations peacekeeping forces from Bosnia unless NATO and the United Nations agreed in the next few days to send them reinforcements.

title: That Darryl-Doc Talk Is Merely That: Talk
description: No one speaks for George Steinbrenner, least of all an agent named Bill Goodstein, which is why some perspective is needed on the rash of reports suggesting that the Yankees' owner is interested in having Darryl Strawberry and Dwight Gooden play for the Yankees.

title: Spinning Into Game 4, It's a Dizzying Debate
description: First, they stole the first two games of the series. Then, they tried to take the pinwheels away. Now, it is personal. Or, if one listens to Reggie Miller, rather pathetic.

title: Villeneuve Goes the Extra Mile (Well, 5) to Win
description: Leslie Goodyear sat in the press room here today and dabbed tears from her eyes. Three years ago, her husband, Scott, was crying with joy even though he could not quite pass one car to win the Indianapolis 500. The tears today were because he passed one car too many: the pace car.

title: Holiday Today
description: Memorial Day is observed today. NEW YORK GOVERNMENT OFFICES: Federal, state and municipal offices are closed. POST OFFICE: Express Mail and special delivery only. BANKS: Option to close. PARKING: Sunday rules in effect. SANITATION: No pickups, street cleanings or recycling. SCHOOLS: Closed. FINANCIAL MARKETS: Closed. TRANSPORTATION: Buses and subways, L.I.R.R. and Metro-North on holiday schedules. NEW JERSEY GOVERNMENT OFFICES: Federal and state offices closed. Municipal offices have option to close. POST OFFICES: Express Mail and special delivery only. BANKS: Option to close. SCHOOLS: Closed. TRANSPORTATION: New Jersey Transit trains on Sunday schedule. Some New Jersey Transit buses on holiday schedule. CONNECTICUT GOVERNMENT OFFICES: Federal, state and municipal offices closed. POST OFFICES: Express Mail and special delivery only. BANKS: Closed. SCHOOLS: Closed. TRANSPORTATION: Metro-North on holiday schedule.

description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings this week: TUESDAY CCP INS Inc Conseco Inc Ipalco Enterprises WEDNESDAY Deere & Co Oneida Ltd Stanley Wks THURSDAY Allegheny Pwr Sys Atlantic Energy Inc NJ Englehard Corp General Pub Utils Corp Witco Corp

title: E.P.A. to Discuss Cleanup Plan
description: The Federal Environmental Protection Agency will hold a public meeting at 7 P.M. on Thursday in the City Council Chambers to review its plan to clean up radium-contaminated materials at the Superfund site at High and Alden Streets, where the U.S. Radium Corporation operated from 1917 to 1926.

title: Graduation: Words From the Famousa to Those Who May Be
description: With the bombing in Oklahoma City still fresh in their minds, many of this year's college commencement speakers are warning of a world run by extremists and urging graduates to turn the tide through political action. The growing scope of cyberspace was often discussed with awe and trepidation. But some speakers offered high-spirited, good-humored advice on the more traditional commencement topics of family and career. These excerpts were taken from transcripts provided by the universities and colleges at which the speakers appeared.TAMMY AUDEHClaremont Graduate School ROBERT REDFORDActor

title: Bankrupt, but Honest
description: To the Editor:

title: Congressional Memo; In Budget Battle, a Side Skirmish Over Medicare
description: The battle of the budget is often presented as a highly stylized and scripted clash between two parties on the floor of the House and Senate. But away from the official show, as real-life constituencies defend real-life programs, the struggle is more subtle, more sophisticated and sometimes more like a political campaign than a legislative process.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Home Section on Thursday about free interior decorating services at home furnishings stores misstated the fees charged by independent designers. They generally charge clients the wholesale prices of goods and services plus a markup of 30 to 40 percent, not retail plus the markup.

description: A Folk-Rock Band With Traces of Pop Better Than Ezra Mercury Lounge

description: To the Editor:

title: Serbs Kill a Bosnian Leader and Take More Hostages; Copter Downed - 33 Britons Are Seized
description: Bosnia's Foreign Minister was killed today, and the Bosnian Serbs stepped up their humiliation of the United Nations by adding 33 British soldiers and 8 Canadians to a long list of hostages.

title: Governing Socialists in Spain Suffer Defeats in Local Voting
description: Spain's Socialist Party appeared to suffer crushing defeats in local and regional elections today, with 85 percent of the votes counted nationwide.

title: A Nuclear Plant Gets New Equipment and a New Attitude
description: Thirteen months ago, S. David Freeman, the new president of the New York Power Authority, strode to the podium to address 500 workers in the cavernous turbine hall at the Indian Point 3 nuclear power plant.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a meeting of nations with peacekeeping troops in the former Yugoslavia misstated Canada's contribution to the force in some copies. As the accompanying chart indicated, Canada's contingent in Bosnia alone is the 10th largest. In Bosnia, Croatia and Macedonia combined, Canada's force is the 5th largest, after those from France, Britain, Jordan and Pakistan.

title: 5 Bidders for Belgian Mobile Phone System
description: Belgium will consider bids from five groups of companies to operate the nation's second mobile-phone network as part of a wider plan to inject competition into its telecommunications industry.

title: Request to Change a Boundary Stirs Emotions in the Bronx
description: Westchester Square in the North Bronx still resembles one of New York City's old-style neighborhoods, a cluster of houses, delis and pastry shops, an Irish pub and a Navy recruitment office. Just a few miles to the south, the blocks become grittier, with stretches of crowded housing projects, garbage-strewn lots and knots of drug dealers on one stoop after another.

title: Most Wanted; An Internet Provider Becomes a Hot Stock
description: It was a big week for hot initial public offereings in high tech, with no fewer than five of them leaping as soon as public trading began. But the hottest of them all was Uunet Technologies, a company that provides access to the Internet, and is partly owned by Microsoft. It closed Friday at $27.50, 96 percent above the offering price of $14. The company has never made a dime, but hjopes to change that after Windows 95 is issued by Microsoft, using Uunet (pronounced you-you-net) to provide access to the Internet computer network.

title: Markets Closed
description: All financial and commodity markets in the United States are closed today in observance of Memorial Day. Markets in Britain are also closed for a bank holiday, but most markets in other countries are open.

title: Ready to Win, Goodyear Passes One Car Too Many
description: Without Penske entries in the Indianapolis 500 today, speculation was intense as to which car would have the greatest influence on the outcome. It turned out to be the pace car.

title: Wimbledon Slows the Ball
description: According to The Sunday Mail, Wimbledon officials will introduce a new, slower tennis ball this summer, designed to make the tournament more attractive by taking away some of the speed of the serve.

title: Kimble Charged in California
description: BO KIMBLE, the nation's college basketball scoring leader with Loyola Marymount in 1989-90 and later a member of the Clippers and Knicks, was arrested on charges of drunken driving, authorities in Malibu, Calif., said yesterday. The Los Angeles County sheriff's office said Kimble, 29, who played in the Continental Basketball Association this past season, was stopped Saturday night after deputies spotted him driving 80 miles an hour in a 50-mile-an-hour zone on the Pacific Coast Highway, and he was arrested after he failed a sobriety test. He was released pending a court appearance.

title: A Change of Heart for the Chief
description: In January, Police Chief Gerald J. Napoleone agreed to step down by June 1. But the 51-year-old chief has changed his mind.

title: For the Devils, A Return Trip To East Finals
description: The Devils consoled opponents with a handshake after five games for the second time in the Stanley Cup playoffs this spring. They did it at Boston Garden two weeks ago and they did it this afternoon at Civic Arena with the Pittsburgh Penguins.

title: In Search of Nielsens for the Internet
description: Like many companies still unsure whether the Internet is a business fad or the face of the future, the Chrysler Corporation recently took a leap of faith into on-line advertising.

title: Topics of The Times; A Long String of Pearls
description: Glenn Miller has gotten back on the charts. A new recording of his World War II band's radio broadcasts from London landed on the British best-seller charts last month at No. 22. The two-CD set is titled "Glenn Miller: The Lost Recordings." They were not really lost, just out of circulation, but no matter. On the 50th anniversary of the war's end -- and of Miller's disappearance on a flight over the English Channel -- his "In the Mood" and "String of Pearls" and all the rest are hits again.

title: A Compromise Bid on Kashmir
description: India's Prime Minister, P. V. Narasimha Rao, is exploring the idea of offering the troubled state of Kashmir a form of political autonomy. That could help resolve a sectarian conflict that has cost at least 20,000 lives since 1990. In another welcome move, Mr. Rao let a broad anti-terrorism law expire last week. More than 65,000 people, including Government critics and journalists, had been rounded up under the law since its enactment a decade ago.

title: Russian Earthquake Kills More Than 300
description: At least 300 people were reported dead and about 2,500 people remained unaccounted for after an earthquake flattened a town on an island off Russia's Pacific Coast. Rescue workers reported hearing moans from under the rubble in the town that bore the brunt of the 7.5-magnitude earthquake, which struck Sakhalin Island while most of its residents were sleeping.

title: Taking In the Sites; Banking With a Difference
description: Few banks boast of falling prey to bandits, and fewer would quote the miscreants and publicize their misdeeds on the Internet. Wells Fargo & Company, however, flaunts its colorful Old West past on the World Wide Web and has managed to accomplish a rare feat: it offers entertainment to those window-shopping for banking services on the Internet.

title: The Spurs Get Even By Routing Rockets
description: The San Antonio Spurs started the weekend in trouble. They ended the weekend in style.

title: Vivian Cadden, 78, Writer and Editor
description: Vivian Cadden, a New York writer and magazine editor, died on Thursday at Lenox Hill Hospital. She was 78 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Debts of Honor
description: For much of the nation, it seems, Memorial Day has come to mean the unofficial start of summer, a holiday to spend at the beach or in the backyard. In small towns in this part of the country, however, people still feel deeply their obligations to the past. And there aren't many of us who don't willingly remember and honor our dead, whether they died in the service of their country or simply succumbed to illness or age.

title: G. Robert Nail, 70, Champion at Bridge
description: G. Robert Nail, one of America's leading bridge players, died on Thursday in Houston. He was 70.

title: Collecting Works by Black Artists, Blacks Add Detail to Their Heritage
description: As they walked through an exhibition of works by black artists at the San Antonio Museum eight years ago, Harmon and Harriet Kelley were hit by two powerful but conflicting emotions. As blacks, they felt their pride soar over the works of artists like Roscoe O. Tanner and Elizabeth Catlett. At the same time, they felt a sense of shame. These were beautiful and arresting works, yet the Kelleys had never even heard of most of the artists.

title: Sheppard Beidler, An Executive, 76
description: Sheppard Beidler, a founder and former president of Grow Group Inc., a producer of specialty chemicals and paints, died on Tuesday in Kingston (N.Y.) Hospital. He was 76 and lived in Great Neck, L.I.

Its leading roles can be interpreted in many ways. American Ballet Theater is revealing some of them this season at the Metropolitan Opera House by offering Natalia Makarova's production of the classic. Recent performances included two debuts.

title: Smokejumpers Face Summer's Fires With Memories of Last Year's Deaths
description: Just a few weeks before they return to their seasonal job of bailing out of airplanes to land on steep slopes full of burning trees, the Smokejumpers of the United States Forest Service are consumed by an earthbound chore.

Yankees Manager Buck Showalter heard from his owner this morning on the telephone, passed along Steinbrenner's good tidings to the club and New York tried something novel: winning.

title:
Behind the Scenes;
Ethereal Effects and Hard Technology

While computer animation plays an increasing role in cutting costs in film makeing, this is the first time that so large a portion of a film features such effects ina central role. "Jurassic Park," for example, had onlysix minutes of computer animation.

title: Claudio Segre, 58, Writer and Expert On Fascism, Dies
description: Claudio G. Segre, a writer, historian and authority on Italian fascism, died of a heart attack on Thursday while jogging near his home in Berkeley, Calif. He was 58.

title: What Goes On?; Call of the Modem, to Some, Is a Sweet Nothing
description: It is the white noise of the electronic age, the signature tune of computers, faxes and just about all things that interconnect over phone lines. It is to the office what the blue jay's screech is to the garden.

description: Dave Mlicki did everything he could for seven innings.

description: The women come to the squat brick factory in Queens from apartments in Jackson Heights and Corona, arriving by city bus before morning has fully broken. Their backs and legs aching, but willing, they come wearing saris or carrying merengue tapes.

description: A 5-year-old Long Island boy who was hit by a foul ball off the bat of Brett Butler in Saturday's Mets-Giants game, underwent three and a half hours of surgery yesterday to repair a fractured skull.

description: It was 4:30 P.M. on a recent afternoon and the 34 prospective jurors looked tired and impatient. Judge Jeffrey Rosinek of Dade County Circuit Court apologized for bringing them into the courtroom so late in the day but warned that jury selection would take a few hours.

description: Out of the blue duffel bag that she lugs from house to house, Adaljiza Nunez pulls her magic box. The box is plain and white, just big enough for a scarf or a tie, and its magic lies not so much in its appearance or what it holds -- two magnets and some paper clips -- as in the delight it brings to Geraldine Peralta's tiny face.

title: No Headline
description: "I knew I had no way of getting them out and no way of protecting them. I said to myself, 'My men are going to die if they start shooting back. And for what? For peace?' So I ordered them to surrender." -- JEAN-PAUL MICHEL, commander of the French U.N. peacekeepers. [ A1:4. ]

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: On the Trade Scoreboard, U.S. and Japan Gain Points The United States and Japan seemed far from resolving their trade dispute, but Japan picked up support in the World Trade Organization for its contention that Washington's automobile sanctions violated the rules of the organization.

title: SCIENTIST AT WORK: Martha K. McClintock; How Biology Affects Behavior And Vice Versa
description: ONE of the enduring cliches about scientists is that while they may be a bit large for the average seesaw, and indeed may even have graying beards, they remain forever young at heart: full of childlike wonder and curiosity about the natural world, their eyes as round as pies, their energy infinite, their speech a variant on the worshipful "Wow!"

description: As Federal agents gathered evidence in the case of Anthony Melnikas, an Ohio State University art history professor who recently gave a rare-book dealer two pages stolen from a medieval manuscript, longtime colleagues and former students discussed a series of problems that Mr. Melnikas had had over the years.

description: Clyde Drexler has reached the point in his career where the question will be asked. If he never wins a championship, will his professional career be unfulfilled?

description: Less than two weeks after Jacques Chirac took office as President of France, the markets in Europe are sending an unmistakable message to Elysee Palace -- they are nervous about his new economic plans for stimulating growth to reduce the country's 12.2 percent unemployment.

title: 'Tags' to Help Catch Bombers
description: For close to 20 years, technology has been available to help trace explosives. Taggants, or microscopic coded "tags," in explosives can be "read" by experts to find out where the explosives came from. In America's two big terrorist attacks -- the World Trade Center and Oklahoma City bombings -- this technology could have helped law enforcement authorities. Yet the explosives industry, along with the National Rifle Association, has lobbied hard to prevent legislation to require taggants in explosives.

description: An autopsy today found that the Harvard University student who was killed by her roommate early Sunday morning had been stabbed 45 times over virtually all of her body and had awakened in a futile effort to defend herself.

All those quiet, motionless bodies packed into their seats, all those gowned and monkey-suited performers in their serried ranks onstage. And then there's the expense. Tickets to hear big-city orchestras with big-name soloists do not come cheap. Fortunately, there's an alternative: the open rehearsal.

Besides chewing up the paths, he argues, they ruin the tranquillity of the woodlands and drive out hikers, bird watchers and strollers.

description: A 22-year-old woman from Waterford will represent the state in the Miss America Pageant in Atlantic City this fall. Dena Querubin, a student at Rowan College of New Jersey, was crowned Miss New Jersey 1995 here on Sunday. Miss Querubin, who played a Beethoven sonata, the "Pathetique," on piano during the talent portion of the competition, will receive $9,500 in cash and scholarships in addition to other prizes. SUSAN JO KELLER

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF Langer Pulls Off a Close Victory Bernhard Langer sank a tricky 3-foot putt yesterday to par the final hole and win the European PGA Championship for the third time in Virginia Water, England. The German shot a final-round 71 for a nine-under-par total of 279, but needed to hole the final putt to avoid a playoff with Michael Campbell of New Zealand and Per-Ulrik Johansson of Sweden, who both finished on 280. "It was a bit of a struggle, all day long it went back and forth," said Langer, who has won at least one title in Europe in each of the last 17 years. "I never got as far ahead as I would have liked." A bogey on the 13th by Langer set up a three-way tie among the German, Campbell and Johansson, with Mark Mouland of Wales and Andrew Sherborne one behind. But Langer holed a 15-foot putt on the short 14th to nose back in front. Both Mouland and Sherborne followed that with two bogeys to leave it a three-man race among Langer, Campbell and Johansson, who missed a 10-foot birdie putt at the 17th that would have given him a share of the lead. Langer then parred the final two holes to add to his 1987 and 1993 European PGA titles. (AP) SOFTBALL U.C.L.A. Beats Arizona for Championship Kelly Howard hit a two-run homer in the fifth inning yesterday to help U.C.L.A.'s softball team to a 4-2 victory over Arizona in the championship game of the Women's College World Series in Oklahoma City. Second-seeded U.C.L.A. won its eighth title and finished with a 50-6 record. Top-seeded Arizona (66-6) was seeking a second straight title. With the score 2-2, Howard homered off Carrie Dolan, who finished the season with a 33-2 record. U.C.L.A. pitcher Tanya Harding, the tournament's most valuable player, allowed eight hits in winning her fourth straight game in the series. She finished with a 17-1 record after joining the U.C.L.A. team in midseason. U.C.L.A. had defeated Arizona three times in four previous meetings this season. (AP) CYCLING Citterio Takes 16th Stage of Italian Tour Giuseppe Citterio took the 16th stage of the Tour of Italy yesterday as fellow Italians Giovanni Lombardi and Mario Manzoni were penalized by the jury for exchanging pushes in the final mass sprint. Citterio, originally second behind Lombardi with Manzoni third, was awarded victory after the jury checked the film of the sprint and noticed a series of improper acts. Tony Rominger of Switzerland finished in the same time as the winner and retained the pink jersey of overall leader as the race entered its final week. Rominger was temporarily without wheels after thieves stole his favorite bicycle during a stopover Sunday in the Swiss Alpine resort of Lenzerheide. He used a replacement bicycle as the tour headed from Lenzerheide to Treviglio today. Rominger, who took the overall lead in the second stage, held a lead of 3 minutes 14 seconds over the Latvian runner-up Pyotr Ugrumov. (AP)

title: BBC's World Service: A Cultural Lifeline To Educated People
description: The streets in Algiers had cleared two hours before the nightly curfew. The guests at the El Djazair Hotel, who would not go out until morning, settled into their rooms, and many -- out of either boredom or devotion -- switched on their short-wave radios to the BBC World Service. Minutes after an unsettling ripple of automatic fire echoed from one of the side streets, the service began to broadcast William Shakespeare's poem "Venus and Adonis."

title: Let's Dawdle, Spit and Play Ball!
description: For baseball fans, time was rarely a measure of the quality of a game. Innings took as long as they had to, and what mattered was pace and rhythm, not minutes and seconds. Without the rigidity of a clock, baseball reveled in not being tyrannized by time. A game ended when it ended, without a flurry of timeouts, free throws, penalties or balls purposely thrown out of bounds.

The billings were estimated at $10 million to $15 million. Ketchum Advertising Los Angeles, a unit of Ketchum Communications Inc., was awarded the account last week after a three-month review that was narrowed to that agency and the San Francisco offices of McCann-Erickson, a unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies, and J. Walter Thompson, a unit of the WPP Group.

description: Summer weekends at the beach are times for fun, not for fussing. But you still want to look good when you go out to dinner after a day of swimming or sailing, which can wreak havoc on the hair.

title: Man Is Revived, but Dies in Crash
description: Manuel Cortez, felled by a blow with a piece of lumber, was given new life by rescue workers on Sunday night only to die minutes later in an accident. Prosecutors say Mr. Cortez, 33, got into an argument with another man in the street who hit him in the neck with a two-by-four. His heart was not beating when rescue workers arrived, but they revived him. But on the way to the hospital, the ambulance Mr. Cortez was riding in was hit so hard by another car that it flipped over. The police and medical workers riding in the ambulance escaped serious injury, but Mr. Cortez never recovered. He died in a North Bergen hospital a few hours later. Prosecutors, who were treating the case as a homicide, were sorting out conflicting accounts of the assault.

title: For Europe, Echoes of Vietnam War
description: For Europeans, Bosnia is the quagmire that Vietnam was for the United States three decades ago. None of the countries providing peacekeeping soldiers to the United Nations force in Bosnia can get out unless all of them agree to a humiliating withdrawal in failure.

title: Plodding Genie Plays Catch-Up
description: WAY back in 1985, when General Electric's Genie network made its debut, consumer on-line information services were fairly crude, unfriendly systems.

title: There's Joy in Villeneuve's Camp, but Prayers in Fox's
description: In Jacques Villeneuve's garage, there was a winner's wreath, empty champagne bottles and a happy crew polishing the winning car. Not far away, in Stan Fox's garage, there was a racing car sheared in two.

title: Science Times E-Mail
description: Science Times has an electronic mail address for comments from readers about published articles and suggested areas of coverage:

title: Saving the U.N. Mission in Bosnia
description: Bosnian Serb forces have thrown the long-suffering United Nations protective mission in Bosnia into what could become a terminal crisis. Last week the Serbs began forcibly taking back the heavy weapons they had earlier yielded to U.N. custody in the Sarajevo area. Now, after NATO tried to halt these weapons seizures with air strikes, they have seized more than 325 hostages from the U.N. force.

title: In Performance; THEATER
description: Time May Sometimes Freeze, But Eventually It Dances On 'Betty Suffer's Theory of Relativity' La Mama E.T.C.

title: Exploring the Crusade Of the Anti-Darwinians
description: If you thought the battle over the teaching of evolution in America's schools was settled 70 years ago at the famous Scopes trial in Tennessee, "In the Beginning: The Creationist Controversy" should set you straight. This two-hour report by Randall Balmer, a professor of religion at Barnard College, offers plenty of evidence that the anti-evolutionists are far from extinct.

title: Market Place; Sometimes speed can be everything in making money.
description: SOMETIMES, it's not what you know that determines whether you make money on your investments. It's how fast you can get to the trading desk to place your sell order.

title: Free Screening
description: Music videos, animated films and other movies by film makers at the School of Visual Arts will be shown in a free screening today from noon to 6 P.M. at the Cineplex Odeon Worldwide Cinema, 50th Street west of Eighth Avenue. Information: (212) 592-2180.

title: On My Mind; Why Only Bosnia?
description: All over the world, rebel peoples are at war with their internationally recognized governments. They die to destroy regimes they detest -- or just separate from them.

title: Tomintoul Journal; Good Lord! Scotland Yard Has Its Pockets Picked
description: On a Saturday night at The Grouse's Nest, they're still willing to raise a glass or two to "Laird Williams," though now his title prompts laughter. And now they just call him "Tony."

title: Hospital Research Falling Victim to Lean Budgets
description: Biomedical research, long considered a cornerstone of American medicine, threatens to become a silent casualty of the reorganization of the country's health care system, caught between the nation's relentless search for cheaper medical care and budget-cutting fervor among politicians.

title: F.B.I. Agent Killed by Suspect In Police Shootings, Officials Say
description: An F.B.I. agent searching for a man who had ambushed two District of Columbia police officers was killed by the suspect early this morning, law-enforcement officials said.

title: Public Broadcasting Is Anguishing Over Commercials
description: During last fall's election, Congressional Republicans promised to cut Federal money for public broadcasting as part of their taxpayer relief program. Recently, it has become clear that they intend to make good on this promise: the House budget plan calls for complete elimination of all Federal appropriations by the year 1998.

title: New Jersey Transit Turns to Rosanio
description: New Jersey Transit has selected Rosanio, Bailets & Talamo in Cherry Hill, N.J., to handle a three-year integrated marketing services assignment previously divided between the FCB/Tierney unit of True North Communications in Philadelphia and Keyes-Martin in Springfield, N.J. The billings for 1996 were estimated at $4.9 million; the remaining budget will be determined annually.

title: India Said to Cancel Plans for Elections in Troubled Kashmir
description: The Indian Government, concerned over potential violence in the state of Jammu and Kashmir, has bowed to widespread opposition and decided against carrying out its plans for elections there, a top Indian official said tonight.

title: Alcohol-Laden Cloud Holds the Story of a Star
description: USING one of the world's largest radiotelescopes, British scientists have analyzed an interstellar gas cloud and calculated that it contains enough alcohol to make 400 trillion trillion pints of beer.

title: Accounts
description: * A & M Products Inc., Danbury, Conn., a subsidiary of the First Brands Corp., to McCann-Erickson New York, a unit of the Interpublic Group of Cos., to handle its Jonny Cat brand of cat litter. The billings were estimated at $5 million. Evans Hardy & Young, Santa Barbara, Calif., handled Jonny Cat before it was acquired by A& M, which awarded McCann New York other cat litter brands last year. * Beiersdorf A.G., Hamburg, Germany, to TBWA Stockholm, a unit of the Omnicom Group, to handle advertising for Nivea skin care products in Denmark, Finland, Norway and Sweden, previously handled by Jersild & Co., Denmark. TBWA International handles advertising for Beiersdorf in 13 countries including the United States. The billings were estimated at $10 million. * Mazatlan Tourism, Mazatlan, Mexico, to Garcia Patto Publicistas, Mexico City, and Vitt Media International, New York, to handle the creative and media portions of its account in the United States and Mexico. The Atkins Agency, San Antonio, previously handled those duties in the United States and Gaudelli & Associates, Mexico City, handled them in Mexico. The billings were estimated at $3 million. * Nalley's Fine Foods Inc., Tacoma, Wash., to Cole & Weber, Seattle, a unit of the WPP Group, to handle advertising for its Nalley's chili and Adams peanut butter brands, previously at Freeman Balanshei & Partners, San Francisco. The billings were not disclosed.

title: Effort to Reintroduce Thick-Billed Parrots In Arizona Is Dropped
description: A SEVEN-YEAR effort to return thick-billed parrots to the pine forests of Arizona where they once thrived has failed because birds raised in captivity floundered in the wild, quickly becoming prey for hawks.

title: Czech Avionics Contract
description: A group led by the Rockwell International Corporation has received a contract valued at $200 million from Aero Vodochody Ltd. of the Czech Republic to develop fighter aircraft avionics. Rockwell, based in Seal Beach, Calif., said its North American Aircraft Modification division would design, test and install a new avionics system in a prototype L-159 light attack aircraft made by Aero Vodochody for the Czech Air Force. The avionics system includes guidance, navigation, radar and weapons control.

description: Edgar Scott, a prominent Philadelphia investment banker and Main Line socialite, died on Friday at Ardrossan, the family farm in Radnor, Pa. He was 96.

description: To the Editor:

title: No Upsets in France, But Muster Proves to Be A Bit on the Edgy Side
description: There were clouds overhead that threatened but never struck, and a full cast of tennis underdogs did much the same today, all of which rendered the opening day of the French Open a harmless affair for the favorites who graced the show courts.

description: To the Editor:

title: Henning Kronstam, 60, Dancer Who Led Royal Danish Ballet
description: Henning Kronstam, a former director of the Royal Danish Ballet and a dancer of exceptional elegance, died on Sunday at his home in Copenhagen. He was 60.

description: Honoring veterans in Memorial Day ceremonies, President Clinton promised today to "leave no stone unturned" in accounting for prisoners of war and troops missing in action in Vietnam, and he praised Hanoi for cooperating in such efforts more "than ever before."

description: I'll go up to the cemetery if the weather's good today and give the old-timers their due. Putting peonies on their graves is the usual way of doing that in our part of the world, but my way is to tap a tombstone and remember something that tickles me about the party it celebrates.

description: Q. What makes honey resistant to spoilage, even at room temperature?

description: Around the world, in rich and poor countries alike, the structure of family life is undergoing profound changes, a new analysis of research from numerous countries has concluded.

description: Sara Lee Foundations, a unit of the Sara Lee Corporation, and its public relations agency, Marina Maher Communications in New York, took top honors, winning the "Best of the Best" award at the Big Apple Awards ceremony for excellence in public relations, sponsored by the New York chapter of the Pubic Relation Society of America. Sara Lee and Maher were honored for a campaign introducing the Wonderbra brassiere.

description: Cigar was resting for his shot at a $500,000 bonus in Massachusetts next Saturday. Cherokee Run was recovering from an ankle injury. And Devil His Due was scratched because of a heavy track.

description: Rik Smits walked from a timeout huddle back onto the floor with 1.3 seconds left today, envisioning each detail of the game's final play. Come to the ball. Catch. Fake. Shoot.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about alcohol abuse by police officers misstated the date on which Sgt. Frederick G. Sherman struck and killed a pedestrian while driving a patrol car on Park Avenue. It was March 15, 1985, not March 15, 1986.

title: The Latest: Language Skills via CD-ROM's
description: ONCE upon a time, you took a class to learn or refresh your knowledge of a foreign language, or perhaps bought a set of records or tapes or a book. You can still do that, but now, with powerful personal computers that show animation and play and record sound, language courses and accessories for PC's are proliferating. The following are just a few of those that have recently shown up.

title: William Platt, 79, Insurance Executive
description: William Vernon Platt, an international insurance-brokerage executive, died last Wednesday at Jupiter Island Hospital in Hobe Sound, Fla. He was 79. A former resident of Rye, N.Y., he lived in Hobe Sound and Siaconset, Mass.

title: I.R.S. Scrutiny Forces Delays In Some Refunds
description: In the name of fraud prevention, the Internal Revenue Service has delayed refunds for up to eight weeks to as many as 4.5 million taxpayers, many of whom filed flawless tax returns.

description: Mapping the Brain

description: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills.

title: Wasserman May Leave If Ovitz Joins MCA
description: Lew Wasserman, the longtime chairman of MCA Inc., has told Edgar Bronfman Jr., the chief executive of the Seagram Company, that he will leave the entertainment giant if Michael Ovitz is put in charge of the company, several people close to the discussions said yesterday.

title: People
description: * Raymond S. Rizzo, chairman and chief executive of Clarion Marketing and Communications, Greenwich, Conn., a unit of D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles Inc., was named to the additional new responsibilities of handling D.M.B.& B.'s development of new-media and communications capabilities, overseeing three interactive business units: Advista Group, Westport, Conn.; Einstein & Sandom Interactive, New York, and Feldman & Associates, New York. * Rob Schapiro was named to the new position of senior vice president and creative director at Ketchum Advertising, Pittsburgh, a unit of Ketchum Communications. He was previously a creative director at Earle Palmer Brown, Richmond, a unit of the Earle Palmer Brown Cos. * Don Casey was named to the new position of director at Deskey Associates, New York. He was previously president at Seabrook Consultants, Holmdel, N.J.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday of Sheppard Beidler misstated his residence. He had homes in Manhattan and Accord, N.Y. The obituary also misstated the residences of his daughters; Patricia Appel lives in Woodstock, N.Y., and Barbara Brewster lives in Manhattan.
