description: Songs for a Gilded Age Near Furniture to Match William Bolcom and Joan Morris Metropolitan Museum of Art

title: Yzerman's Status Unclear
description: Maybe he's having surgery and maybe he isn't. Maybe he'll play this week, and maybe not until mid-June. There were a lot of maybes yesterday after the Detroit Red Wings issued a news release about their injured captain, Steve Yzerman, then refused further comment.

title: An Early Work Speaks To Modern Audiences
description: George Balanchine was so major an influence on the New York City Ballet, which he established with Lincoln Kirstein in 1948, that it is easy to forget how many different choreographers were invited to work with the company in its first 15 years.

title: Last 3 Bodies Found
description: Three bodies were found yesterday in the wreckage of the Federal Building in Oklahoma City, and the authorities said they were the last expected to be recovered after the April 19 bombing that took the lives of 167 people. Medical examiners expect to identify the bodies today.

title: These Rangers Say Goodbye for Last Time
description: As their players cleaned out their lockers, shook hands all around and said goodbye for the summer, Neil Smith and Colin Campbell discussed how the Rangers could contend again for the Stanley Cup.

title: Markets Closed
description: Financial and commodity markets in the United States were closed yesterday in observance of Memorial Day. Markets in Britain were also closed for a spring bank holiday. But most markets in other countries were open.

title: State Vote Buoys Mexico's Ruling Party
description: After a combative opposition leader won in a landslide in voting for governor in the central Mexican state of Guanajuato, the governing party appears to have broken its political free fall at least temporarily here with a narrow, disputed victory in elections in the southern state of Yucatan.

title: Smith Barney Replaces Head Of Bond Sales and Trading
description: Smith Barney Inc. has named Steven M. Bowman and William Heinzerling the co-heads of bond sales and trading, after ousting John F. Lyness from the post on Friday because the businesses had not met the brokerage firm's profit expectations.

title: Only Insurers Like Early Settlement
description: To the Editor:

title: Invader From Asia Increases Gypsy Moth Threat
description: WHERE have all the gypsy moths gone? Six years ago, millions of trees throughout the Northeast were eerily leafless in midsummer, thanks to the voracious appetite of this European import. Foresters frantically tried to contain the damage by spraying huge tracts with bacteria that infect the leaf-gobbling larvae, while homeowners girdled trees with sticky tape to impede their leaf-bound trek. Hundreds of hairy caterpillars spoiled summer outings by crawling or falling onto walks, decks and picnic tables.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Rabbi ALEXANDER M. SCHINDLER, the president of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations, took the tallit, or prayer shawl, on which his wife had embroidered the Hebrew words for knowledge, compassion and the beauty of holiness, off his own shoulders and placed it on those of his daughter JUDITH SCHINDLER. He said a few words to her and blessed her.

title: In Performance; THEATER
description: Humor From Words That Were Actually Spoken 'Loose Lips' Triad Cabaret

title: Syracuse Gives Coach Possible Farewell Gift
description: His 25th season as head coach ended in the best possible way today for Roy Simmons Jr. when his Syracuse team won another national lacrosse championship. The Orangemen broke open a tight contest with Maryland late in the second half and went on to a victory that was easier than the 13-9 score suggested.

title: Gorecki Joins Compatriots' Program
description: Who can guess what might lure a reclusive composer out of his lair? Henryk Mikolaj Gorecki, the Polish composer whose mournful, post-Minimalist Symphony No. 3 brought him international fame, has turned down invitations from many a prestigious ensemble. Yet on Sunday afternoon he performed not in a conventional concert hall and not with famous musicians, but in a ballroom at the Marriott Marquis Hotel, on a program otherwise devoted to amateur Polish-American choruses and dancers. (He is also to play at the Kosciuszko Foundation, 15 East 65th Street, Manhattan, on Thursday.)

title: Tax Protester Gears Up for Trial
description: A 58-year-old tax protester who spent five years as a fugitive is getting ready to stand trial. Harry A. Coombs, who is acting as his own attorney, plans to argue that the state income tax is unlawful and that he is a political prisoner. Mr. Coombs, whose next court date is Friday, was indicted in October 1989 on charges of not filing state tax returns.

title: Blockbuster Trims List for Music Unit
description: Blockbuster Entertainment said yesterday that it had narrowed the review on the account of its Blockbuster Music chain of music retail stores, with billings estimated at $30 million, to two finalists: Foote, Cone & Belding in Chicago, part of True North Communications, and Young & Rubicam Inc. in New York.

title: Foreign Affairs; Jesse's Right
description: In case you missed it, Jesse Helms, the chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, was at it again last week, pronouncing President Clinton as "not qualified" to be Commander in Chief. Senator Helms said he hoped Mr. Clinton would turn over any military decisions regarding intervention in Bosnia to the Joint Chiefs, because the President just wasn't up to the task. The North Carolina Senator's comments stirred up the usual furor over at the White House, and were swatted away by Clinton spokesmen.

title: 3 Shops Are Added By Postal Service
description: The United States Postal Service said yesterday that it had added to its agency roster three shops specializing in sales promotion and direct marketing: Frankel & Company in Chicago, Lee Hill Inc. in Chicago and FCB Direct in New York. The combined billings were estimated at as much as $32 million.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Monday about the competition between cable television and the broadcast satellite service offered by DirecTV, a venture of the Hughes Electronics subsidiary of the General Motors Corporation, misstated the estimated percentage of DirecTV customers who live in areas reached by television cables. It is 52 percent who have such access to cable, not 52 percent who lack it.

title: Harvard Officials Stress the Positive Despite the Most Recent Events in a Year of Trials
description: When Neil L. Rudenstine, the president of Harvard University, took an unscheduled leave of absence last winter, suffering from the stresses of his job, he received 1,500 get-well cards from faculty and students.

title: Demons and Conspiracies Haunt a 'Patriot' World
description: In one sense, Doug Monroe is like many other Americans. He is a husband, a father of two and the owner of a small business, which sells parts for old Ford Mustangs.

title: Arista Records President Renews Contract
description: Clive Davis, the president and founder of Arista Records, who signed stars including Whitney Houston and the Grateful Dead, has renewed his contract with BMG Entertainment until the year 2000, the company said yesterday.

title: Dollar Steady as Traders Await Friday's Report on Employment
description: The dollar was steady against most leading currencies yesterday, supported by expectations that the United States employment report on Friday would show enough strength to dissuade the Federal Reserve from cutting interest rates.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; To reach entrepreneurs and growing companies, many marketers count on Inc. magazine.
description: AT a White House briefing this month, the leaders of the businesses on the Inc. magazine list of the 500 fastest-growing privately owned companies were greeted by top Federal officials. Then they left for Norfolk, Va., for an annual three-day conference for executives from the current Inc. 500, as well as heads of previous companies on the list.

description: THE SCENE: Riverside Drive and 81st Street.

description: A man who is serving a 72-year sentence for shooting a Maryland woman during a robbery in the Vera Wang bridal salon in the Hotel Carlyle last year was sentenced to another 90 to 180 years in prison yesterday in a Manhattan court for six other robberies.

description: For the residents of East 13th Street, the squatters who had long lived in their midst were a mixed blessing: some saw them as a noisy annoyance with their wild parties, but others said they gave life to a cluster of buildings that would otherwise have been left to decay.

Human conflict has been taken out of the chambers of City Hall and put back on the opera stage, where this festival thinks it belongs.

title: Soybean Prices Decline Sharply As Fears of a Poor Harvest Ease
description: Soybean prices fell sharply yesterday as forecasts for sunny skies and drier weather eased concern that rain-delayed planting would reduce this year's harvest. Corn and wheat prices also fell.

UAL's United Airlines, the "launch customer" -- it has 34 of the 777-200's ordered and 34 more on option -- will fly paying passengers from London's Heathrow Airport to Dulles International Airport near Washington on an inaugural run, followed by flights between Chicago and Frankfurt, Chicago and Denver, and Chicago and Washington.

title: Riot Police Remove 31 Squatters From Two East Village Buildings

title: When Young Break the Law, A Town Charges the Parents
description: Municipal Court in this Willamette Valley town of old-style rhythms is being visited by a new class of offenders: mothers and fathers of the children of Silverton. They are charged, essentially, with being bad parents.

description: With the June 6 primary elections just around the corner, it's time to talk politics. But the contests that are drawing all the attention will occur in 1996 and 1997, not this year.

Prosecutors say 18-year-old Quincy Rodriguez went up to his room, got a gun and fatally shot the friend, Abel Respes, 44. Yesterday, Mr. Rodriguez was in court, being arraigned on murder charges.

title: Message to Mr. Moi
description: Kenya's dictatorial President, Daniel arap Moi, seems unwilling to learn from his recent experiences with international aid donors. Four years ago donors suspended development assistance to Kenya because of its human rights abuses, economic waste and corruption. The moratorium was lifted in 1993, after a period of limited political and economic reform, and late last year donors pledged $800 million in new financial assistance.

Kreuz's offers no sauce, no beans, no potato salad, no plates and no chance to walk away with the steak knives because they are chained to the tables. The lime-green walls are bare, save for the mounted body of an 11 1/2-pound bass and the hide of a 6 1/2-foot rattlesnake. This is a place to eat, not to see and be seen.

title: Fox's Condition Unchanged

RENKENS, a neurosurgeon, said that doctors at Methodist Hospital in Indianapolis removed a blood clot from Fox's brain Sunday and that there were no other injuries. Fox, 42, was breathing with help from a respirator, the hospital said in its first public comment on the driver. (AP)

title: Vanilla: The Definition of Plain Is Getting Sophisticated

No longer relegated to the auxiliary scoop of ice cream or a puddle of creme anglaise, it is now being featured as a principal flavoring in the dishes at many fine restaurants in New York.

title: Police Toss a Curve to Find Babe Ruth's Stolen Uniform
description: The uniform that Ruth wore is now in police custody. So is a onetime pitcher who told detectives that the strikeout record he set years ago at Trenton High School still stands.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a dance review yesterday about a performance by the New York City Ballet misidentified a work that is to have an extra performance on June 11. It is "West Side Story Suite," not "The Four Seasons."

title: No Headline
description: "It's like somebody took a knife and went chunk. Everything else on either side is just fine." LOU DAVIS, describing the tornado that hit Great Barrington, Mass. [ A10:1. ]

title: It Was No Lost Weekend For NBC in Ratings Game
description: As the National Basketball Association playoffs invade prime time this week, NBC sprints into the telecasts knowing that having lost teams from New York, Chicago, Los Angeles and Phoenix is not a death knell for ratings.

title: Steelers' Foster Is Traded To the Carolina Panthers
description: BARRY FOSTER, the former Pro Bowl running back whose big contract and lack of durability made him expendable, was traded by the Pittsburgh Steelers yesterday to the Carolina Panthers for future considerations.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: COASTAL BANCORP INC., Portland, Me., a bank holding company, agreed to acquire Texas Capital Bancshares Inc., which offers commercial and individual banking services, for $21.1 million in cash. FORE SYSTEM INC., Pittsburgh, a maker of computer-networking products, acquired Applied Network Technology Inc., Westford, Mass., which makes components for computer networks, for about $26 million in stock and $9 million in stock options.

title: Two Big S.&L.'s In the Midwest Plan a Merger
description: Two of the Midwest's largest savings institutions, Charter One Financial Inc. and the First Fed Michigan Corporation, said yesterday that they had agreed to merge, in a deal that reflects the continuing consolidation of the savings and loan industry.

title: Some Like It Dry
description: The 1993 vintage of Marilyn Merlot, a wine that is becoming a collector's item, is appearing in a few wine shops. Marilyn Monroe, who was born on June 1, 1926, will be commemorated with a postage stamp being released tomorrow. The wine, with a photograph of the actress on its glittery label, was first produced in 1985, with a different image on the bottle each year. Today, some bottles sell for $100 or more.

title: School Safety Chief Resigns, Urging Job Be Done by Police
description: After several incidents in the last week involving misconduct by school safety officers in New York City, Zachary Tumin, the executive director of the Division of School Safety, resigned yesterday, saying that the schools lacked the resources to police themselves and that the Police Department should take over the job.

title: Policing New York City's Schools
description: A rash of arrests of school safety officers and a reported increase in school violence make a compelling case for upgrading New York City's school security forces. The best approach -- proposed by Mayor Rudolph Giuliani and endorsed yesterday by the outgoing head of school security -- is to put the city Police Department in charge of school safety.

title: The Adventure Is Back for David Lynch
description: It has been very quiet out in David Lynch land. For nearly three years, the dancing dwarfs have been idle. The Log Lady's log, a popular figure in its own right during the heyday of "Twin Peaks," Mr. Lynch's guerrilla assault on mainstream television, lies in a safe-deposit box, drying out.

title: U.S. and NATO Demand Quick Release of the Hostages
description: The United States and NATO, in their strongest terms yet, warned the Bosnian Serbs to release more than 320 detained United Nations peacekeepers immediately or suffer serious consequences.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday with a brief review of "Betty Suffer's Theory of Relativity" at La Mama E.T.C. misspelled the surname of a cast member. As noted in the review, she is Dale Soules, not Doules.

title: Opposition In Mexico Calls Vote Fraudulent
description: Political conflict deepened in the southern state of Yucatan today as the conservative opposition began to rally its supporters against what it said was widespread cheating in elections that the governing party appeared to have won there on Sunday.

title: Berkshires Storm Kills 3, But Leaves Scores in Awe
description: A tornado that blasted through this former mill town on Monday night cut a swath of destruction at times 700 yards wide through the Berkshire Hills, killing at least three people and leaving thousands more in awe at being spared.

title: Turn Back the Tide of Commercialization
description: To the Editor:

title: Young Chagall In Russia, Discovering His Powers With Esprit
description: At no time in the last 70 years has the work of Marc Chagall looked as strong, as inventive, as pertinent and as fresh as it does at this moment at the Musee National d'Art Moderne de la Ville de Paris. The show, "Chagall: The Russian Years, 1907-1922," presents 214 works, in all, and from start to finish it looks like what it is: the work of a young man who was in a hurry to define himself.

title: Matthew Welsh, 82, Governor of Indiana
description: Matthew E. Welsh, the Governor of Indiana from 1961 to 1965 who brought in the state's first sales tax and who fought the Presidential aspirations of George C. Wallace, died on Sunday at his home in Indianapolis. He was 82 and a longtime resident of the city.

title: Federal Officials Cite Deficiencies at Harvard Hospital
description: Federal health officials issued a report yesterday citing a wide variety of serious deficiencies in patient care at Dana-Farber Cancer Institute in Boston, a Harvard teaching hospital that is among the most prestigious cancer centers in the country.

title: Maradona Looks to Brazil
description: The Argentine soccer star DIEGO MARADONA is set to join the Brazilian club Santos, the team that once featured PELE.

title: Seattle Journal; Will the Cost of One Victory Be a Team's Future?
description: It took only a second to stop the pulse of Seattle on Friday night.

title: Philip Morris Shares Gain After Recall of Cigarettes
description: Shares of the Philip Morris Companies began recovering yesterday after the company tried to reassure Wall Street that it was moving quickly to complete its $100 million recall of more than eight billion filter cigarettes.

title: Bonds Surge As Weakness In Economy Feeds a Rally
description: The bulls showed the credit markets yesterday that they were still in charge as Treasury securities continued their rally amid recent signs that the economy was slowing with inflation in check.

title: Market Place; Pacific Telesis, its rivals say, is crying wolf about regulators.
description: TO hear its executives tell it, the Pacific Telesis Group has been knocked flat on its back by onerous state regulations. But rival telephone companies say the Baby Bell is like a basketball player who falls melodramatically on the hardwood in hopes of a drawing a foul.

title: Britain Fines Wall St. Firm In Client Deals
description: Morgan Stanley & Company said yesterday that it had paid a fine of $:240,000, or $384,000, to British regulators because of a failure to conduct and supervise foreign-exchange business that led to $28 million in losses for its clients.

title: Stocks Are Mixed as Technology Issues Show Big Losses
description: The stock market closed mixed yesterday, but technology stocks lost big, in part because of the prospect of slowing sales and in part because of profit taking by traders.

title: CHRONICLE
description: EDA LeSHAN, a family counselor and the author of books with names like "When Your Child Drives You Crazy" and "It's Better to Be Over the Hill Than Under," has outdone herself in creating a title for her first play: "The Lobster Reef."

title: Jean Muir, an Elegant Classicist Of British Fashion, Dies at 66
description: Jean Muir, the British fashion classicist whose design career spanned more than 30 years, died on Sunday in London at the London Clinic. She was 66.

title: No Love Lost Between Bowe And Gonzalez in the Ring
description: Riddick Bowe, in his view, has been denied his rightful place among boxing's elite, at least by the major sanctioning bodies, who don't even deem him worthy of being their No. 1 contender. He suffers not only from being good, but also from having the outspoken and often aggravating Rock Newman as his manager, alienating the heads of all those groups.

title: Everett C. Reed, 78, Fabric Executive
description: Everett C. Reed, a retired chairman of the Albany International Company, died on Thursday in Albany Memorial Hospital. He was 78 and lived in Menands, N.Y.

title: P. J. Kramer, 91, Authority on Plant Physiology
description: Paul Jackson Kramer, a Duke University authority on plant physiology, died last Wednesday at the health center of the Carolina Meadows retirement community in Chapel Hill, N.C. He was 91 and had lived in Durham, N.C., until seven years ago.

title: Nicosia Journal; With Only Hate in Common, They Share an Island
description: On the deserted asphalt tract that slices through the center of the world's last divided capital, there is a small painted triangle.

title: NO SIGN IN JAPAN OF DEAL ON TRADE
description: The senior Japanese politician managing the country's increasingly contentious trade dispute with the United States said today that he had already made "the maximum possible concession" to Washington, contending that the planned American sanctions would add to job losses in Japan.

title: Juventus May Sell Baggio
description: ROBERTO BAGGIO, soccer's world player of the year in 1993, may be put up for sale by Juventus of Turin. AS Roma and Internazionale of Milan are interested in acquiring Baggio, whose transfer fee could be as much as $13 million.

title: Study Finds Educational TV Lends Preschoolers Even Greater Advantages
description: In the 25 years since "Sesame Street" was created, assorted studies have shown that it helps preschool children learn about numbers and the alphabet, and thus helps prepare them for school.

title: Bell Atlantic Reviews $50 Million Account
description: The Bell Atlantic Corporation said yesterday that it had begun a review on its account, now divided between J. Walter Thompson New York and FCB/Tierney in Philadelphia. The billings were estimated at $50 million.

title: F.A.A. Allows Boeing 777 to Skip a Test Period
description: The Boeing 777, which is is scheduled to enter commercial service next week, can skip a two-year test period and begin flying routes up to three hours from the nearest possible landing point, the Federal Aviation Administration said yesterday.

title: Reds Plan New Ball Park
description: The Cincinnati Reds owner MARGE SCHOTT and the city's top business executives have agreed to work on plans to build a ball park next to Riverfront Stadium, which the Reds have shared withthe football Bengals since 1970. Schottr, who has considered moving the Reds from Cincinnati to get a new stadium, and members of the cincinnati Business Committee said yesterday they hope a new stadium can be ready for the 1998 or 1999 season.

title: Jaguars' Raymond to Lions
description: The Jacksonville Jaguars traded the veteran cornerback COREY RAYMOND yesterday to the Detroit Lions for tight end TY HALLOCK. Raymond was the Jaguars' second selection in the expansion draft in February. The four-year player had spent the past three seasons with the Giants. (AP)

title: Dance Theater of Harlem Cuts Staff and Budget
description: The Dance Theater of Harlem has announced a reduction in staff that will save the company $300,000 this year and a projected half-million dollars next year. "We're addressing Dance Theater's situation but also the plight of the arts in America and internationally right now," Arthur Mitchell, the founder and artistic director of the troupe, said in a recent interview.

title: Simpson's Lawyers Press Attacks on Blood Evidence
description: The struggle by O. J. Simpson's lawyers to cast doubt on the reliability of the evidence against him gained a bit more momentum today when a police crime analyst acknowledged that blood samples in other cases had been found mysteriously contaminated in the police laboratory.

title: Behind 'Patriots,' A Shared Distrust
description: Many people in the right-wing Patriots Movement share an alarmist view of America: that government officials are letting constitutional freedoms erode. Many of them have something else in common -- a single, profound experience that helped form the prism through which they see a world of conspiracies.

title: When Times Were Slower And Crime Was Lower
description: ARE things worse, crimewise, than they were in the old days? Was your grandmother right when she remembered that you could once walk anywhere at any time without worrying, or has nostalgia put a mellow gloss on years when she was young enough to skip easily out of harm's way. Weren't there people at the Five Points who would bite anyone's ear off for a quarter? What about the Plug Uglies, the Dead Rabbits, Murder Inc. and the hatchet men of the Chinese tongs who menaced the citizenry?

title: One-Day State Industry Strike Ties Up Paris
description: Public employees in France staged a one-day strike today to protest the European Union's plans to end state monopolies in telecommunications, postal service, energy and transportation.

title: MARSAM PHARMACEUTICALS GETS SEVERAL OFFERS
description: Marsam Pharmaceuticals Inc. said yesterday that it had received merger offers from several parties for about $19 a share, putting a value on the drug maker of about $210 million. Marsam, based in Cherry Hill, N.J., makes a range of sterile injectable products, including penicillin and morphine sulfate. The company did not identify those making the offers. Marsam's shares gained $2.375 yesterday, to $18.625, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Modern 'Wolfmen' May Have Inherited Ancient Gene
description: CASTING a slender ray of light on the mysteries of both hair growth and the legend of the werewolf, scientists have discovered a gene that in its mutant form causes hair to sprout thickly and thoroughly across the face and upper body, covering the cheeks, forehead, nose, even the eyelids.

title: Eating Well
description: CONSUMPTION of milk has dropped steadily, almost 30 percent, in the last 35 years. To some extent, the milk industry has itself to blame, because it failed to keep up with the increasing interest in low-fat products. In its advertising, it did not make the distinction between the various kinds of milk and their fat contents. As a result, according to a 1994 industry study, many women are convinced that milk is fattening and have stopped drinking it.

title: Tariff Won't Help American Car Makers
description: To the Editor:

title: Israel's Army, Once Sacrosanct, Is Now Becoming Deglamourized
description: After decades as the country's main unifying force -- more than religion, certainly more than politics -- the Israeli Army is slowly losing the enormous power it once had to shape this society.

title: Miller Brewing Plans Interactive Growth
description: The Miller Brewing Company said yesterday that it was talking to agencies about seeking help to expand its interactive marketing efforts.

title: By U.S. Law, Rail Talks Can Last Years
description: Ever since 1982, when the United States Supreme Court ruled that New York's commuter railroads came under the Federal Railway Labor Act, transportation officials have been trying to get Congress to exempt them from the law.

title: Stakes in the Duke Case: A Long Reputation and a Lot of Dollars
description: Since 1853, the United States Trust Company of New York has managed the fortunes of famous American families, from the Astors to the Rockefellers. From its headquarters in midtown, it quietly and conservatively handled their investments and -- when they died -- administered their wills.

title: Bullpen Lets Down Perez And Yanks
description: Melido Perez handed the baseball to his bullpen tonight without instructions and paid for it. Bob Wickman and Steve Howe needed only 10 minutes to tear down the house that Perez built as the Yankees lost to the Mariners, 7-3.

title: Masur's Yearly Concert, Spiritual and Free
description: Ever since his first season as music director of the New York Philharmonic, Kurt Masur has led his orchestra in a free Memorial Day concert at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, a generous end-of-the-season gesture that also affords an opportunity to look at the spiritual side of the repertory. He could not have found a more fitting work than the one he conducted that first year, Benjamin Britten's "War Requiem," a piece that honors the fallen and at the same time decries the horrors of war. Since then these concerts have offered symphonic evocations of universality (the Beethoven Ninth Symphony) and mortality (the Mahler Ninth Symphony).

title: The G.O.P.'s War on Nature
description: President Clinton, whose record on conservation issues has been tepid, may yet turn out to be the last, best line of defense against Congress's blitzkrieg on the nation's environmental laws.

title: When a 'Legend' Takes a Bow
description: True fans don't need to be told that Thursday is Marilyn Monroe's birthday.

title: Salmon and Sweetness
description: THERE are some wonderful little tomatoes called cocktail tomatoes, which are usually sold in net bags, attached to their stems. With their excellent sweet flavor, they would be perfect with this meal of salmon burgers and mashed potatoes.

title: Nights in Cambridge
description: To The Living Section:

title: Safe Holiday on the Highways
description: The Memorial Day weekend was the safest on New Jersey roads in a dozen years. Five people were killed in auto accidents, matching a 1984 low, officials said. The figure is down from 12 last year. Three deaths were in Bergen County -- a driver in Cresskill and pedestrians on Route 17 in Ramsey and Route 4 in Paramus.

title: U.S. SET TO OFFER AID TO REINFORCE U.N. BOSNIA TROOPS
description: United States officials said today that the Clinton Administration was prepared to offer military equipment and logistical support to reinforce United Nations forces in Bosnia. They left open the possibility that Washington might contribute troops for a limited mission to help regroup and move the United Nations force into safer, more fortified positions.

title:
Real Estate;
A law firm's New York office is moving from lower Manhattan to the Met Life Building.
description: AFTER 15 months of negotiations, the law firm of Winston & Strawn has signed a lease for two floors totaling 86,000 square feet in the Met Life Building, formerly the Pan Am Building, at 200 Park Avenue at 45th Street.

title: For Spurs, Home Is Where the Heartbreak Is
description: The Houston Rockets love to play in San Antonio, but they hope not to return until next season.

title: After the Quake, Political Tremors Are Felt in Moscow
description: The devastating earthquake on Russia's remote Sakhalin Island, eight time zones and 4,500 miles from Moscow, is beginning to have political consequences.

title: Microwave: Revolution That Never Happened
description: THE microwave oven has become one of the country's most beloved appliances. About 87 percent of American households have at least one.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball American League

title: OLSTEN AND HOOPER HOLMES IN SWAP TRANSACTION
description: The Olsten Corporation said yesterday that it was acquiring Nurse's House Call, the home health care business of Hooper Holmes Inc. Simultaneously, Hooper would purchase from Olsten the stock of ASB Meditest, a provider of mobile health care services. The deal is structured as a swap, according to Olsten, a provider of health care, industry and business staffing services, based in Melville, L.I. Hooper is a health care and health information services company based in Basking Ridge, N.J. Nurse's House Call operates through 116 offices in 29 states and had 1994 revenues of $159 million. In 1994, ASB had sales of about $80 million.

title: E.D.S. Resumes Purchase Talks With Kearney
description: The on-again, off-again acquisition talks between the Electronic Data Systems Corporation and A. T. Kearney, the Chicago-based management consulting firm, are on again, the two companies said yesterday.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: POLICE OUST EAST VILLAGE SQUATTERS

title: Wine Talk
description: THERE'S a story often told about a radio quiz show that had Leonard Bernstein as a guest contestant. A bit of music was played and he was asked to identify it.

title: PARAMETRIC TO PAY $180 MILLION IN STOCK FOR RASNA
description: The Parametric Technology Corporation, the nation's largest maker of mechanical design automation software, agreed yesterday to buy the privately held Rasna Corporation for about $180 million worth of stock. Parametric Technology, based in Waltham, Mass., would issue 4,253,491 shares of its common stock for 100 percent ownership of Rasna. Parametric's stock was off 75 cents yesterday, at $42.25, in Nasdaq trading. Rasna, based in San Jose, Calif., develops, markets and supports the Mechanica family of integrated software products for mechanical design.

title: A Conservative Group Proposes Abolishing the F.C.C.
description: A conservative research group closely linked to House Speaker Newt Gingrich called today for abolishing the Federal Communications Commission, arguing that the agency had consistently hurt consumers by blocking competition and innovation.

title: LOOKING FOR LUNCH WITH: Alix Kates Shulman; A Feminist at Walden Pond
description: AS she strolled through Central Park, Alix Kates Shulman, the feminist novelist and social advocate, looked like any number of well-seasoned New Yorkers. The acceptance of a certain age seemed to soften the web of concern in the corners of her eyes. Her pace was still purposeful, even though these days Ms. Shulman tends to pursue the wild and the edible with the passion she once reserved for tossing off sexual conventions and gender stereotypes.

title: Virginia Governor Orders Inquiry on Death Row Gun
description: Gov. George F. Allen of Virginia today ordered the State Police to investigate the discovery of a loaded pistol last week in the typewriter of a man who had just been executed. The Governor said he was responding to criticism that prison officials had concluded too hastily that the incident must have been a hoax by the man's lawyer.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Sometimes there's a happy solution to scheduling conflicts faced by prominent New Yorkers.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: No Sign of Compromise In Japan Over Trade

title: Bomb Charge to Be Dropped Against Six in Terror Trial
description: Defense lawyers for six of the men accused in a conspiracy to blow up New York City landmarks were told yesterday that the prosecution intends to drop a bomb-possession charge against the men, lawyers and law enforcement officials said.

title: Heat Reportedly Eyes Calipari
description: The University of Massachusetts coach, JOHN CALIPARI, has been interviewed for the Miami Heat coaching job, The Palm Beach Post reported yesterday.

title: Flowers and Candles Mark Site of Fatal Shelling
description: Public gatherings have been banned in Tuzla as a safety measure, and today the only group larger than a handful was formed by those bringing flowers and candles to where two winding, cobblestoned streets meet in the old part of the city.

title: Send in Ground Troops, and A Lot of Them
description: The Bosnian Serbs have once again thrown the cold water of reality in our faces.

title: O'Neal Says Foul Calls on Him Hardly Seem Fair
description: The Indiana Pacers have discovered there is an even better way to neutralize Shaquille O'Neal than merely pounding his body and sending him to the free-throw line with the intriguing chance that he may chip paint off the rim.

title: An Anti-Patient Act
description: Doctors in New York State, backed by the American Medical Association, are lobbying Albany to protect them from losing their patients. The residents of New York are increasingly turning to managed-care health plans, which often charge less and provide more benefits than traditional fee-for-service physicians. But many doctors dislike managed care because these plans closely supervise physician practices and hold down physician income. Unable to win in the market, doctors want the State Legislature to constrain the competition.

title: Barings Successor Sells Back Dillon Stake
description: The Baring Holding Company Ltd. said yesterday that it had sold half its 40 percent stake in Dillon, Read & Company back to the investment-banking firm.

title: Supreme Court Roundup; Ruling Broadens State Inmates' Access to Federal Courts
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that state inmates may challenge their convictions in Federal court even after serving their sentences, if they remain behind bars serving a consecutive sentence for another crime.

title: John Paul Invites Other Churches to Talk but Defends Primacy
description: In an appeal for greater unity among Christians, Pope John Paul II invited leaders of other churches today to join him in a discussion on the role of the papacy, one of the most divisive issues in the history of Christianity.

title: Playoffs Take Long Television Timeout
description: In a season that began with a 15-week labor lockout, you would think the National Hockey League would be eager to cut to the chase for the Stanley Cup and conclude its playoffs before the beginning of Independence Day weekend, or Canada Day weekend, as it is known north of the border.

title: REPORT TO CLINTON HAS A MIXED VIEW ON MINORITY PLANS
description: In a sweeping review of the Government's affirmative-action programs, Clinton Administration officials have concluded that most hiring and other preferences based on race or sex are justified in employment and education. But they found problems with some purchasing programs that reserve Federal contracts for companies owned by blacks or women.

title: Surgery for Paterson Youth
description: The 19-year-old factory worker shot by a police officer here Saturday underwent three and a half hours of surgery yesterday to remove bullet and bone fragments from his brain. Jiovani Ruiz was reported to be in critical but stable condition and breathing with the help of a respirator after the operation at St. Joseph's Hospital and Medical Center. The officer who shot him, Heriberto Rodriguez, has been placed on administrative duty pending completion of an investigation. Mr. Ruiz was shot after Officer Rodriguez responded to a report of a man with a gun, which turned out to be an air pistol said to resemble a .45-caliber handgun.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Thursday about former Prime Minister Harold Wilson, who first joined the British Cabinet at age 31, misstated the date of the first Cabinet appointment of William Pitt, the youngest British Cabinet member ever. Pitt became Chancellor of the Exchequer at age 23 in 1782, not 1792.

title: BEVERLY DELAYS SPINOFF OF INSTITUTIONAL PHARMACY
description: The shares of Beverly Enterprises Inc. fell 12 percent yesterday after the company said it would delay the spinoff of its institutional pharmacy unit and would report lower-than-expected second-quarter profits. Beverly said the unit, the Pharmacy Corporation of America, was losing customers because of recent acquisitions and changes in pricing for intravenous therapy services. Those problems are expected to cut Beverly's second-quarter earnings by 5 cents to 7 cents a share, the company said. Beverly's shares fell $1.625 yesterday, to $11.375, in New York Stock Exchange trading of almost 2.3 million shares.

title: Woman Hurt in Subway Theft Is Improving
description: A woman who fell beneath a subway train while chasing a man who had snatched her sister's purse was reported in stable condition at Jamaica Hospital yesterday, a day after both her legs were amputated.

title: Sabina Lietzmann; German Journalist, 75
description: Sabina Lietzmann, a former American correspondent for the Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung, Germany's most influential daily newspaper, died on Monday at her home in West Cornwall, Conn. She was 75.

title: Sports of The Times; Steinbrenner Wouldn't, Would He?
description: DARRYL STRAWBERRY wishes to become a Yankee and George Steinbrenner may wish for him to become one, too. If you've heard that one, that's because Bill Goodstein, Strawberry's agent, has told you so. Not Steinbrenner, who normally foretells of Yankee developments by assuming the role of Well-Placed Source.

title: M.T.A. Seeks To Call Off Mediation
description: For the first time in its history, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority has decided to forgo extended mediation with its railway unions, which could mean a strike against the Metro-North commuter railroad as early as June 23.

title: Brazil's Ex-President Accomplished Much
description: To the Editor:

title: Harnisch's Fine Effort Is Matched By Offense
description: Pete Harnisch rummaged in his locker early yesterday evening, muttering about losing streaks and bad stretches and his fervent hope that the Mets could somehow change their miserable luck.

title: Toll Rises in Zaire Virus Even as Epidemic Ebbs
description: The World Health Organization yesterday reported an increase, to 153, in the number of deaths from infection with the Ebola virus in Zaire. But it said the new numbers represent cases that occurred in the earliest phase of the epidemic, from January to March, and are just now being confirmed.

title: F.C.C. Will Not Force Rate Increase for Digital Phone Lines
description: No doubt to the relief of some who surf the Internet, the Federal Communications Commission said today that it would not enforce a rule requiring telephone companies to raise the price of new digital telephone lines.

title: INSIDE
description: Looking Like a Contender

title: Utility Bills as Inducements
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman says that giving discounts on utility bills will help keep some businesses from leaving the state. And at a hearing yesterday on the policy known as "flex rating," the chairman of the State Board of Public Utilities, Herbert Tate, said the discounts could in fact be applied more broadly, to persuade businesses to continue buying power from big utilities rather than smaller competitors. The hearing was the first step toward passage of legislation that would allow the discounts.

title: Smokers Litter Our Streets Without a Thought
description: To the Editor:

title: Move to Stiffen Jail Terms for Violent Criminals Bogs Down Budget Debate Even More
description: A dispute over a proposal to make major changes in criminal sentencing laws widened today, threatening to delay passage of the state budget yet another week.

title: Two in Chile Get Jail Terms In U.S. Killing
description: The former head of the Chilean military's secret police and his deputy were sentenced to prison tonight when the Supreme Court upheld a lower court's ruling that they had ordered the assassination of the opposition leader Orlando Letelier in Washington in 1976.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: CYCLING Rominger Widens Lead Tony Rominger extended his lead and moved closer to his first victory in the Tour of Italy yesterday by winning the 17th stage of the race. The 34-year-old Swiss cyclist beat the Russian Yevgeny Berzin by 1 minute 39 seconds in a 26.6-mile individual against-the-clock race. Rominger, the overall leader since the second stage, scored his 100th victory as a professional. He completed the run from Cenate to Selvino in 1:05:59. The victory was the fourth in this tour for Rominger and widened his advantage in the overall standing to 5:08. The event ends next Sunday in Milan. (AP)

title: No Parade Again
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on April 7 about the orchid show at the World Financial Center in Manhattan misidentified two officials inspecting an arrangement. They were Dr. William W. Wilson, a judge, and Betty Levine, an assistant to the judges -- not Cammy Koeber and Merritt Huntington. Dr. Wilson reported the error in a letter dated April 26. Checking of Ms. Levine's identity was delayed in part by an oversight at The Times.

title: Japan's Jobless Rate at Highest Level Ever
description: Japan's unemployment rate rose to its highest level ever in April, adding to fears that the world's second-largest economy was slipping back into recession and entering an era of higher joblessness.

title: A Meticulous Eye for War's Poetry and Brutality
description: 1920 DIARY By Isaac Babel Illustrated. 126 pages. Yale University Press. $20.

title: Medicare, Jot This Down
description: Business has a lot to teach the Government about controlling medical costs. But the Government hasn't been listening.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the possibility that Lew Wasserman, the current chairman of MCA Inc., might leave the entertainment company referred incorrectly in some editions to the price the Seagram Company is paying the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company for an 80 percent stake in MCA. It is $5.7 billion, not $5.7 million.

title: Milton Grafman, 88, a Rabbi Active in Civil Rights Struggle
description: Rabbi Milton Grafman, a Birmingham, Ala., civic leader for more than 50 years who figured in a chapter of the civil rights struggle there, died on Sunday at Baptist Montclair Hospital in Birmingham. He was 88.

title: Lawyer's 50-Year Journey to the Bar; Christian Rightist From Long Ago Says It's Justice, Finally
description: Now that he is officially, legally and in every other imaginable way a member of the New York bar, John F. Cassidy doesn't plan to open a practice. His eyesight is poor -- he has cataracts -- and he is getting on in years: this October he will be 85.

title: Where the Diner Is the Star
description: IS there a gustatory paradise, a place where it is not shameful to eat the food of childhood -- 12 ounces of cholesterol-laden roast beef and, afterward, a bowl of pale, soothing rice pudding -- where the diner rules, and chefs live to serve?

title: Ruling Makes Schools Rethink Scholarships
description: To the Editor:

title: Calvin Sperling, 38, U.S. Plant Explorer
description: Calvin R. Sperling, a botanist who led the Department of Agriculture's explorations for plants for seven years, died on May 20. He was 38.
